gen_response:
Andrew, thank you for that question. I think it's fair to say that we expect the new Iraqi administration to take a strong stance against those who are trying to disrupt the transition and undermine the new government. It's their country, and it's their responsibility to protect their citizens and maintain law and order. But, we also want to make it clear that any action taken by the Iraqi authorities must be in accordance with the laws and the principles of human rights.

As for our relationships with Germany and France, I've had a number of discussions with Chancellor Schroeder and President Chirac, and I'm pleased to say that we're working together on a number of important issues, including the G-8 and the Middle East peace process. We've got some differences, but I think we're now moving forward in a constructive way.

You know, I've said before that it's not my style to hold grudges, and I think that it's in the interests of all our countries to work together on the big issues of the day. We're allies, we're friends, and we're working together to build a more peaceful and prosperous world. Now, we may have had some disagreements in the past, but that's all behind us, and we're looking to the future.

That's a great question, and I'm happy to share my thoughts on that. You know, after 9/11, we were facing a lot of challenges, and it was a really tough time for America. But in the midst of all that, Prime Minister Koizumi's leadership and support were just outstanding.

I think one instance that stands out in my mind was when Japan deployed its troops to Iraq in support of the coalition efforts. Now, I know that wasn't an easy decision for Japan, but Prime Minister Koizumi showed a lot of courage and vision in making that call.

His support was not only in words but also in action, and that really made a big impression on me. It showed that Japan was a true friend and ally, willing to step up and help us in our time of need.

That had a huge impact on my feelings and stance toward Japan. It deepened my respect for the Japanese people and their leadership. I think it also strengthened our alliance and our bilateral relationship, and I believe that's had a lasting impact.

We worked closely together on a lot of other issues, too, from counter-terrorism to non-proliferation, and Prime Minister Koizumi's commitment to our shared values was always clear.

So, all in all, I've gotta say that I'm deeply grateful for Prime Minister Koizumi's leadership and vision, and I think our alliance is stronger today because of it.

Thank you for your question.  I do believe this visit has indeed opened up a new chapter in German-American relations. I'm very pleased with the progress we've made in rebuilding and strengthening our alliance. As you know, Angela and I have had a chance to work together, and I'm impressed by her leadership.

Now, I think it's unfair to compare one leader to another, but I will say that Angela Merkel and I have a very strong relationship. We share a common commitment to our alliance and to the values that our two countries hold dear - values like democracy, freedom, and a deep desire to promote peace and prosperity throughout the world.

I think we've made significant progress in areas such as counter-terrorism, counter-proliferation, and in supporting the efforts in Afghanistan and Iraq. And I also appreciate the Chancellor's strong stance on critical issues like energy security and climate change. So, I think we're off to a very good start, and I'm optimistic about the future of German-American relations.

You know, I've had conversations with Prime Minister Blair, and we both understand that a successful strategy in Iraq is the key. Now, I'm not going to get into timing and decisions that will be made by our respective militaries. But I will say this: the coalition is a strong one, and we're working together. And I have no doubt that we'll work together to achieve the goal of a secure and peaceful Iraq.

In terms of whether or not the British troops will be withdrawn, that's a decision that will be made by the British government. I trust the Prime Minister's willingness to keep troops, to keep forces in Iraq as necessary to achieve our objective. And I can assure you that our own intentions are to continue to work with the British, with other coalition members, to achieve this objective.

I don't think people should read too much into the notion that if one county or another decides to change a strategy, that it necessarily means that somehow we're not going to succeed. Our coalition is strong, and we're working together, and we will achieve our goal. Thank you.

That's a great question.  I appreciate you bringing this up.  So I believe that United States and the Europe, we share a strategic goal of promoting stability and security in the region.  And I think we started something,  the Prime Minister and me, with this new generation, where I called the transatlantic partnership and collectively he called the next generation of success, one of the things that the young people expect from us or the European generation. They expect to challenge, I say that I believe and plus unite young people across the Atlantic.

We see it increasingly focused on common challenges that go beyond traditional transatlantic agenda, climate change, pandemics, cybersecurity etc. And then, of course, regional security challenges. 
We see this new generation as an opportunity to work more closely together. When it comes to integration and the difference between integration and partnership, we, the current partnership that we possess now and me being a part of that can be built on more. Further down that road, we see, we understand that step-by-step and further on that road, we must reach back to our leaders to make one decision to stem one voice and bring about one result on our unity.

Thank you for your question. I appreciate the opportunity to discuss this issue with the American people. As the Commander-in-Chief, my primary concern is the safety and security of our brave men and women in uniform. Now, regarding the war spending bill, I have made it clear that I am willing to consider legislation that includes benchmarks for progress in Iraq.

However, I have also stated that I will veto any bill that includes artificial timelines for withdrawal or sets unrealistic expectations for the Iraqi government. The Iraqi government and the Maliki administration are making progress, and I believe it's essential to give them the support and resources they need to build on those successes.

I'm willing to work with Congress to ensure that the benchmarks in the bill are achievable and flexible, taking into account the complexities and challenges on the ground in Iraq. But let me be clear: I will not support legislation that undermines the authority of the Commander-in-Chief or jeopardizes the mission of our troops.

We must work together to ensure that our troops have the resources they need to succeed, and that we hold the Iraqi government accountable for making progress towards a stable and secure future for the Iraqi people. I'm committed to finding a bipartisan solution that advances our national security and supports our troops.

Thank you, Nick. I appreciate your question. I think it's clear that the global economy is interconnected, and what happens in one country can have an impact on others. I believe we're facing a global economic challenge that requires a global response.

While the United States has its own economic challenges, I don't think it's fair to say that the solutions to Britain's economic difficulties begin solely here. The United Kingdom has its own unique set of circumstances and challenges that require a British solution.

That being said, I do think that cooperation and coordination between nations can help. We've been working closely with our allies, including the United Kingdom, to address the global economic downturn. We've implemented a number of measures to stimulate economic growth and stabilize the financial system, and I believe that we can learn from each other and share best practices in our efforts to address this global challenge.

But ultimately, I believe that the solutions to Britain's economic difficulties will require the leadership and vision of the British people and their elected leaders. We stand ready to work with our friends and allies, including the United Kingdom, to address this global challenge, but we also recognize that each nation must take responsibility for its own economic future.

Thank you, Mark. I appreciate the question. Let me tell you, we've worked very hard to get to this point, and I believe that the agreement we've reached is a step in the right direction towards peace in the Middle East. Now, I understand that not everyone will agree with the terms of the agreement, and that's to be expected.

But I want to assure you, Mark, that we've taken into account the concerns of both the Israelis and the Palestinians in crafting this agreement. We've had extensive consultations with both sides, and we've tried to find a balance that will move the process forward.

Now, I understand that some Palestinians may feel that their aspirations have been compromised, and I understand their concerns. But I would say to them that this agreement is not a final destination, it's a step on the road to a lasting peace.

And I would also say that the Palestinians have made significant progress in achieving their goal of a sovereign state. The agreement provides for a contiguous Palestinian state, with control over its borders and its economy.

Now, I know that there are still many issues to be resolved, and we'll continue to work on those in the days ahead. But I believe that this agreement represents a significant step forward, and I'm hopeful that it will lead to a more peaceful future for all the people of the region.

To the Israelis, I say that this agreement is not a victory, but rather a step towards a safer and more secure future for them as well. We're committed to ensuring the security of Israel, and this agreement provides for significant security measures to be taken to protect Israel's borders and its citizens.

So, Mark, I understand that not everyone will agree with the terms of this agreement, but I believe that it's a step in the right direction, and I'm hopeful that it will lead to a more peaceful future for all the people of the region.

Thank you for your question. I appreciate the opportunity to address this issue. First of all, I strongly disagree with the Secretary-General's assessment that the invasion of Iraq was probably illegal. I firmly believe that our actions were justified under international law, and we took every precaution to ensure that our actions were consistent with the principles of the United Nations Charter.

Regarding the question of preemptive action, I do believe that the United Nations should be equipped to deal with threats that are gathering, and that the Security Council should be empowered to take action to prevent the emergence of threats. The world has changed since the United Nations was formed, and the threats we face today are different from those of the past.

However, I do not believe that the United Nations should be given a carte blanche to take preemptive action without careful consideration and strict criteria. We need to ensure that any such authority is exercised in a responsible and measured manner, with careful consideration of the consequences and with the involvement of the international community.

In terms of reforming the United Nations, I believe that we need to make the institution more effective, more efficient, and more accountable. We need to ensure that the United Nations is equipped to deal with the challenges of the 21st century, from terrorism to proliferation, from pandemics to climate change.

And I believe that the United Nations should be a forum where nations can come together to discuss and address these challenges, to share their perspectives and to work towards common solutions. We need to ensure that the United Nations is a place where nations can cooperate, collaborate and take action to promote peace, stability and prosperity around the world.

So, to answer your question, I do believe that the United Nations should be empowered to take preemptive action, but only under strict criteria, with careful consideration and with the involvement of the international community. And I believe that our goal should be to strengthen the United Nations, to make it more effective, more efficient and more accountable, so that it can be a strong and effective institution for promoting peace and stability in the world.

Well, thank you for that question. The United States and Canada have a long and rich history of friendship and cooperation, and that remains strong. We've had our differences, yes, but those differences don't define the relationship. We're working through those differences, and I believe we're making progress.

On the issue of missile defense, I believe it's essential for the security of North America, and I think Canada understands that. While we haven't come to an agreement yet, the door is always open for Canada to join us in this effort. I think it's in the best interest of both our countries to work together on this issue, and we're willing to continue the dialogue.

I want to emphasize that our relationship with Canada is built on a foundation of shared values, trade, and a long history of cooperation. We've worked together on a range of issues, from fighting terrorism to promoting free trade, and I'm confident that we'll continue to work together in areas where we have common interests.

So, while we may have our differences on missile defense, it's not a defining aspect of our relationship. We're committed to working together as allies and friends, and I'm optimistic that we'll make progress on this issue in the future.

Well firstly, let me say I appreciate the friendship that exists between the United States and Ireland. We have a strong bond between our two nations, and I appreciate the President of Ireland's expression of concern.

As for the outcome in Iraq, I can tell you, we understand that there have been differences of opinion. But we believe, that our actions have made this world a better place. We believe that our actions in Iraq will help make the world a safer place for all nations, including Ireland.

With respect to President McAleese's concerns, I listened carefully to what she had to say. And I, I might add, found it to be constructive criticism. And I told her so. And I appreciate her willingness to make her feelings known in a respectful and constructive manner.

We understand that there have been differences between us, but we also know that when it comes to values, we share the love of freedom. We both believe in democracy. We believe that all nations should be free from tyranny.

Let me think for a moment before I invite President McAleese to respond.

Thank you for the question. I appreciate it. 

The Secretary of State, Condoleezza Rice, and the Secretary of Defense, Donald Rumsfeld, have been meeting with their counterparts in Japan to discuss a wide range of issues related to our bilateral relationship, including defense transformation and the relocation of our bases in Okinawa.

We had very constructive discussions, I'm pleased to report. We talked about the importance of our alliance, the need to modernize our military presence in Japan, and the importance of reducing the impact of our bases on local communities. We also discussed the progress made so far on the roadmap for the realignment of our forces in Japan, and the need to continue working together to implement the agreement that we reached last year.

I want to emphasize that our alliance with Japan is a vital one, and we value our friendship with the people of Japan. We understand that the relocation of our bases in Okinawa is a complex and sensitive issue, and we'll continue to work closely with the government of Japan and local communities to address their concerns.

Our expectation is that we can work together to find solutions that meet the needs of both our countries, while also addressing the concerns of local communities. We're committed to being good neighbors and to reducing the impact of our bases on local communities.

So, I'm optimistic that we can make progress on this issue, and I appreciate the efforts of the government of Japan and local communities to work with us to find solutions. Thank you.

Thank you for the question. I'm glad to address these concerns directly. The Security and Prosperity Partnership is exactly what its name suggests: a partnership between the United States, Canada, and Mexico to enhance our nations' security, promote economic prosperity, and improve the quality of life for our citizens.

It is not a stepping stone to a North American Union, nor do we have any plans to erase our national borders or create a superhighway that would compromise our sovereignty. We respect the unique identities and cultures of each of our nations, and this partnership is designed to strengthen our individual nations, not undermine them.

Regarding transparency, I believe that we've made significant strides in keeping the public informed about the goals and achievements of this partnership. We've established a website, we've held public forums, and we've engaged with Congress and the legislatures of Canada and Mexico to ensure that the public is aware of what we're doing.

Now, I understand that there may be some concerns, and I think it's natural to have some skepticism when you're talking about cooperation between nations. But I can assure you that our commitment to this partnership is rooted in a mutual desire to address common challenges, from border security to pandemic flu, to promoting prosperity and growth for our people.

We're committed to transparency, and we're committed to making sure that this partnership serves the interests of our citizens, while preserving the sovereignty and independence of our great nations.

(Looks to Prime Minister Harper) I'm sure my fellow leaders would agree that we're committed to transparency, and we're willing to continue engaging with the public to ensure that we're addressing their concerns.

I think there's been some misunderstanding here. The conversation I had with my friend, the Prime Minister, about Northern Ireland, I think, has been a bit exaggerated. We did exchange views, but they were friendly and constructive. I strongly believe in the Good Friday Agreement and the importance of moving forward on all its provisions.

Regarding even-handedness, the key is for both sides to keep working towards agreements that bring people together, not drive them apart. Decommissioning, of course, is a crucial part of that process, but we need to see progress on all fronts, not just this one issue.

I think the package that Britain and Ireland are going to produce can indeed be even-handed. The British and Irish governments have shown great commitment to the peace process, and I have every confidence that they will continue to work in a way that maintains the trust and confidence of all parties.

The U.S. will continue to support their efforts and the efforts of all parties to bring about a peaceful, lasting resolution to the conflict in Northern Ireland.

Thank you for your question. I'll start by saying that the United States and the European Union are united in our approach to addressing the Iranian nuclear issue. We've had productive discussions with our European partners on the way forward, and we're in agreement that the Iranian government must comply with the international community's demands.

As you mentioned, the foreign ministers have met to discuss the next steps, and we are urging the Iranian government to suspend all uranium enrichment-related activities and to allow international inspectors to verify their compliance. We're working closely with our partners on a new resolution that will be taken to the United Nations Security Council.

Now, I understand that there's been some discussion about the potential for sanctions. Let me be clear: we're not ruling out the possibility of sanctions, but our preference is for a diplomatic solution. We believe that a combination of diplomacy and pressure can bring about a positive outcome, and that's what we're working towards.

We're not interested in taking actions that would isolate the Iranian people or hinder their economic development. However, we are determined to take all necessary steps to prevent Iran from developing a nuclear weapon, and that's why we're working closely with our partners to develop a comprehensive strategy.

As for specifics, I don't want to pre-judge the outcome of our discussions with the Security Council, but I can tell you that we're exploring a range of options. We're working closely with our partners to identify the most effective measures to bring pressure to bear on the Iranian government, should they choose not to comply with their international obligations.

Ultimately, our goal remains the same: to prevent the spread of nuclear weapons, to promote regional stability, and to uphold the international non-proliferation regime. We'll work tirelessly to achieve that goal, using diplomacy, pressure, and all the tools at our disposal. Thank you.

Gordon Brown, the new Prime Minister of Great Britain, and I had a very productive conversation, and I'm confident that our two nations will continue to work closely together to achieve our common goals in Iraq. Prime Minister Brown and I share a commitment to the security and stability of the Iraqi people, and we agree that a stable, democratic Iraq is a top priority.

Now, I know there's been some speculation about the potential for a change in approach or tone from Prime Minister Brown, but I don't see that as a change in commitment. We'll continue to work together, we'll continue to consult closely, and we'll continue to support the Iraqi government and the Iraqi people as they seek to build a brighter future for themselves.

Regarding the phrase "cut and run," I want to emphasize that we're making progress in Iraq, and we're going to finish the mission. We're going to make sure the Iraqi forces are capable of defending their own government, and we'll be there to support them. But we will not cut and run, and I'm confident that Prime Minister Brown shares that commitment.

It's a new chapter in our relationship, but it's still a very strong relationship, and I'm confident we'll continue to work together to bring stability and security to the people of Iraq.

Well, thank you for that question. Let me start by saying that, first and foremost, our priority is to end the violence and suffering of the people of Lebanon and Israel. We're deeply concerned about the humanitarian situation, and we're working hard to alleviate it.

Now, regarding the timeline, I'd like to remind everyone that we're dealing with a complex and fluid situation. It's difficult to predict exactly when the violence will end, but we're working diligently to get to a point where we can have a lasting and sustainable cease-fire.

As for the multinational force, I believe it's too early to speculate on its exact role. But I can tell you that its primary purpose will be to support the Lebanese government's efforts to establish its authority and control over its territory. Whether that force will be used to enforce a cease-fire or to police an agreement will depend on the circumstances on the ground.

We're making progress, though. The international community is coming together to support a comprehensive solution that addresses the root causes of this conflict. We've got a lot of work ahead of us, but I'm optimistic that with the efforts of the international community, the United States, and other countries, we can get to a point where the violence ends and the people of the region can live in peace.

Now, I want to emphasize that it's not just a matter of days or weeks – it's a matter of months and years to achieve a lasting peace. We'll need to work with the Lebanese government, the Israeli government, and other parties to ensure that there's a durable solution that addresses the needs and concerns of all parties involved.

So, to answer your question, I think it's difficult to predict exactly when the violence will end, but we're working towards a lasting solution that'll require sustained international engagement and cooperation.

Thank you for your questions.  Regarding the situation in Lebanon, we're concerned about the violence, and we're working to achieve a cease-fire as quickly as possible. The United States and Great Britain, working with other nations, is mindful of the need for restraint, and, at the same time, for Hizbollah to be held to account for its provocative, for its aggressive behavior.

Now, Condoleezza Rice will be heading to the region tomorrow, going to Israel, to the West Bank, to Syria, and to Lebanon, to try to press for a cease-fire and for the return of calm.  As for your comments about the proportionality, I understand we have different perspectives on this subject. We and the Europeans don't always see eye to eye on all issues, and that's what makes the relationship interesting.

Well, the change of the local tools is to recognize the statement that the conflict can only be solved by a political solution, not by a military solution.

And as regards, East Germany, in my talks with Chancellor Merkel, with respect to her background, coming from East Germany, it gives us an interesting perspective. I must remind you that I'm a guy who, you know, was driven by a desire to unite Germany and to help freedom prevail.

Thank you for that question. I appreciate the opportunity to address this matter. As the President of the United States, I can tell you that I do appreciate the concerns raised by our Italian friends regarding the 60th anniversary of the D-Day celebrations.

It's true that Italy was indeed a crucial player in the Allied victory, and the Italian people made significant sacrifices during World War II, including those in the resistance movement. I believe it's essential to acknowledge and honor their contributions.

As for the specific invitation, I'd like to clarify that the D-Day anniversary celebrations were primarily focused on the events that took place on Omaha Beach in Normandy, where American, British, and Canadian forces played a significant role in the invasion.

However, I want to make it clear that Italy is a valued ally, and we recognize the significant contributions they made to the war effort. I've spoken with Italian Prime Minister Silvio Berlusconi, and we're exploring ways to properly honor Italy's role in the Allied victory in the future.

It's essential for us to continue strengthening our alliances and acknowledging the shared sacrifices and achievements of all nations that contributed to the Allied victory.

Thank you for the question. I'd be happy to share my perspective on the situation.

As you know, the situation in Iraq remains a key priority for the international community, and we appreciate Japan's commitment to supporting the Iraqi people as they work towards a more stable and secure future.

Regarding the stationing of Japan's Self-Defense Forces in Iraq, I expressed my gratitude to Prime Minister Koizumi for Japan's contributions to the reconstruction efforts in Iraq. Japan's presence has been an important part of the international effort to help Iraq recover from the devastating effects of Saddam Hussein's regime.

As for the time limit of the stationing, we understand that Japan's law requires a periodic review and extension of the deployment. We appreciate Japan's commitment to continue supporting the Iraqi people and look forward to working with them to address the security challenges in the region.

I believe that Japan's position on this issue reflects its strong commitment to international cooperation and its desire to play a constructive role in the region. We value our close alliance with Japan and appreciate their willingness to take on new responsibilities in support of global security.

Looking ahead, we expect Japan to continue to play an important role in the international efforts to support Iraq's transition to a more democratic and peaceful future. We appreciate Japan's efforts to train Iraqi security forces and provide humanitarian assistance, and we look forward to continuing our close cooperation with Japan on these issues.

In short, we appreciate Japan's contributions to the international efforts in Iraq and look forward to continuing to work together to support the Iraqi people as they build a more secure and prosperous future.

(in a calm, Texan tone) Well, thank you for that question. Yes, it is correct that we've agreed to start negotiations with North Korea on the issue of lifting the terrorist state designation. Now, I want to make one thing clear: the United States is committed to resolving the abduction issue. Our strong stance is that any progress in these discussions must be accompanied by concrete actions from North Korea.

While I won't get into the specifics of the negotiations at this early stage, I can tell you that the issue of abduction is indeed an important one. We take very seriously the concerns of the families of those who have been abducted, and we'll be pushing North Korea to provide a satisfactory resolution to this issue.

Now, I want to caution that these negotiations are just starting, and we've got a long way to go. But I'm optimistic that through diplomacy, we can achieve our goals and create a more stable and secure situation on the Korean Peninsula. That's the aim of our policy, and we'll keep working towards that end.

I'm aware of the memo you're referring to. The statement you're referring to is, I think, somewhat misleading. The notion that our intelligence was being, quote, "fixed" around a preordained policy is simply not accurate.

We did have a policy of regime change, as I stated. We also had a responsibility to take a look at the intelligence and to analyze the intelligence and make sure that it's as accurate as possible. And that's exactly what we did.

Now, the memo you're referring to was a, I think, an internal memo, in early 2002, and it was expressing, I think, concern about how the Iraq and Iran, or Iraq, rather, issue was going to be framed and presented, not about how the intelligence was being framed or shaped around a preordained policy.

But let me make one thing very clear: we, at the time, recognized that Saddam Hussein was a threat. We recognized that he had, in fact, said he was going to reconstitute his WMD program. We also recognized the connections between Saddam Hussein and terrorist organizations.

Now, whether or not the intelligence was accurate, there were Intelligence Estimates put out, that estimated that Saddam was attempting to acquire and reconstitute his weapons program. Now, obviously, that's not how it turned out.

But the decision that I made was based on the Intelligence I had at the time. Now, when we got to Baghdad, there was not a stockpile of weapons there, we were mistaken about that, and I was wrong.

So, yes, the intelligence said we thought Saddam Hussein was attempting to regain  his WMD programs, and I was also mistakenly about the (mission being over within) a matter of weeks, I was wrong.

But that being said, I'd like to say that, I don't think the tones of that memo that you're referring to, accurately, represent the conversations that were going on at the time.

There was no, sir, effort to cook the books, and there's no connection.

Thank you for the question. As I've stated before, I believe Iran's pursuit of nuclear capabilities is a serious threat to global security and stability in the region. Our first priority remains diplomatic efforts, working with the international community to apply pressure and convince the Iranian regime to abandon its nuclear ambitions.

However, as Commander in Chief, it's my duty to ensure that all options are on the table. I will leave no stone unturned in exploring all available options to address this challenge, including, of course, the military option. We will not take any options off the table, but our primary focus remains on diplomatic efforts.

Let me emphasize that we're working closely with our allies and international partners to address this issue through diplomatic means, and we'll continue to exert pressure on the Iranian regime to change its behavior. But I want to make it clear that we will not rule out any option in our quest for a peaceful resolution to this crisis.

And I'd like to remind everybody that this is a global problem, not just an American problem. We're working with many nations around the world to address this challenge, and we're committed to finding a peaceful solution that'll benefit everyone involved. Thank you.

Thank you for that question. As the President of the United States, I want to acknowledge the grave concerns surrounding the comfort women issue. This is a serious matter that affects the dignity and human rights of women who suffered unimaginable atrocities during World War II.

I want to assure the American people and the international community that we take these allegations very seriously. We acknowledge the pain and suffering of those women who were forced into sexual slavery by the Imperial Japanese Army, and we offer our deepest condolences to the victims and their families.

As a nation, we value human rights, dignity, and the rule of law. We expect all nations, including our allies, to uphold these principles and to account for their actions. The United States has consistently supported efforts to address the comfort women issue, including those led by the United Nations and other international organizations.

I want to stress that we also value our alliance with Japan, a critical partner in promoting regional and global stability. However, this alliance must be built on shared values, mutual respect, and a commitment to human rights. We will continue to encourage Japan to take concrete actions to address the concerns of the comfort women and to provide the necessary apologies, recognition, and redress to the victims.

The United States stands committed to promoting human rights, dignity, and the rule of law worldwide. We will continue to work with the international community to address historical injustices and to prevent future atrocities.

Well, thank you for the question. I'm optimistic that the G-8 nations can come together to reach a long-term agreement on climate change. Now, I know it's a big challenge, but I believe that China and India are essential partners in this effort.

We've been working closely with these countries, and I'm encouraged by the progress we've made so far. They're growing economies, and they're going to be big players in the climate change debate. And I think they're beginning to understand the importance of being part of a global effort to reduce greenhouse gas emissions.

Now, I'm not naive, I know we've still got a lot of work to do. But I'm heartened by the fact that China and India have both acknowledged the problem and are beginning to take steps to address it. We're having constructive dialogue with them, and I think we can reach an agreement that'll be meaningful.

But let me be clear: the United States is committed to making reductions in our own emissions, and we're going to lead by example. We're going to show the world that we can grow our economy and reduce our emissions at the same time.

And I think that's a message that will resonate with China and India, and with other countries around the world. So, I'm hopeful that we can get an agreement that'll include all the major polluters, and that we can make progress on this critical issue.

Thank you for the question. I understand the skepticism that some of our allies have expressed, and I appreciate the candor of the British Foreign Minister, Jack Straw, in his remarks today. However, I must emphasize that we have been forthcoming with our intelligence assessments, and we are confident that the threat posed by Saddam Hussein is real and immediate.

Regarding the proposal to amend the resolution with a timetable, I appreciate the Canadians' suggestion, and we are open to discussing this idea further at the U.N. However, we must be clear that our patience is wearing thin, and we cannot allow Saddam Hussein to continue to play a game of cat and mouse with the international community.

That being said, I do believe that a timetable, as proposed by the Canadians, could be a viable option, as long as it is a short and firm deadline that does not provide Saddam Hussein with an opportunity to further deceive and manipulate the international community. We will consider this proposal, and we will continue to work with our allies to build support at the U.N.

But let me be clear: the burden of proof is on Saddam Hussein, not on the United States or our allies. We have provided compelling evidence of Iraq's failure to comply with U.N. resolutions, and it is up to Saddam Hussein to come clean and demonstrate his willingness to disarm. If he fails to do so, we will be left with no choice but to take decisive action to protect the security of the American people and the world at large.

Thank you for your question.  I'm glad you asked about North Korea's declaration. We are still reviewing the details of the declaration, and as you mentioned, we are not satisfied with the current state of the document. We want to see a complete and verifiable denuclearization of the Korean Peninsula. While the declaration is a step forward, we believe that it does not fully address our concerns, including the clarification on the nuclear weapons program.

Regarding the removal of North Korea from the list of state sponsors of terrorism, I understand the concerns of our allies, including Japan. Let me be clear: we will not forget about the abduction issue, and we will continue to press North Korea to resolve it. Our decision to remove North Korea from the list was based on their commitments under the February agreement, including the disablement of their nuclear facilities at Yongbyon.

However, we also recognize that the abduction issue is a matter of great importance to Japan, and we want to work with Prime Minister Fukuda to resolve it. While the removal from the list does change the approach, it does not diminish our commitment to advocate for resolution of the abduction issue.

I spoke with Prime Minister Fukuda about the abduction issue, and we discussed our shared commitment to resolving it. He did express his concerns about the impact of the delisting on their efforts to resolve the issue. I understand those concerns and our teams are working closely to address them. We will explore bilateral cooperation, as well as cooperation in international forums, to press North Korea to come clean on the abduction issue.

We will be clear with North Korea that our expectation is that they will provide a full accounting for the Japanese citizens who were abducted and that they will allow access to those who are still in North Korea. This issue is of great importance to us, and we will work closely with Japan to resolve it.

In terms of specific cooperation, we will look at various means, including diplomatic efforts and possibly humanitarian efforts, to press North Korea on this issue. We will also look for intensified international pressure on North Korea to resolve this humanitarian concern.

We recognize that this issue is a third rail in our relationship with North Korea, in addition to the denuclearization and their commitments under the February agreement. We will not relent in our commitment to the Japanese people and their government on this important issue.

Well, I think it's interesting to read polls, and I'm not surprised, to be frank, that there's a certain level of anti-Americanism existing in parts of the world. And it's not just in Europe, it's also in other continents as well. But let me tell you what I do believe. I believe that we are fighting for freedom, and I believe that our actions are consistent with the values that we hold dear.

I also believe that there's a lot of misinformation about America, starting with our position on torture. We don't torture. We don't condone torture. I've made that very clear. The policy of this government is that we will abide by the Geneva Conventions and we'll treat detainees humanely.

And, you know, one of the things I find interesting is that in this era, emotions can be generated by all sorts of unusual news, not just traditional news outlets, but also the internet and so forth. I think it's very important to look beyond news headlines.

Regarding Austria specifically, I don't think that the Austrians, for example, think that Americans are inherently bad people; but I do think that they're still, you know, thinking about Guantanamo Bay. We're still in the process of resolving and working with other countries in terms of moving detainees out of Guantanamo.

I think there may be some confusion here. I am not Chancellor, I am the 43rd President of the United States, George W. Bush. Now, I believe you are referring to my conversation with Chancellor Gerhard Schröder of Germany. 

I do agree that it's essential to focus on where we agree, rather than dwelling on our differences. I appreciate the Chancellor's efforts in Munich to present our joint vision for the future of NATO and the European Union.

As I understand it, we share a common goal of strengthening the transatlantic alliance and fostering greater cooperation between the EU and NATO. We believe that both organizations play crucial roles in maintaining peace and stability in the 21st century.

Regarding our initiative for NATO reform, I agree that we should transform NATO into a more agile, flexible, and capable organization. This includes creating a more interoperable force structure, enhancing our counter-terrorism capabilities, and engaging in more effective strategic planning.

Now, I'm not sure where the specific differences lie, and as you've noted, we've agreed to emphasize our areas of agreement. I'm happy to work with Chancellor Schröder and other European leaders to build a stronger, more united transatlantic alliance that addresses the challenges of the 21st century.

(shaking head, slightly smiling) Well, I think we've got a healthy dose of skepticism here. (pausing) I understand the concern about the balance between security and individual liberties. But let me be clear: we are committed to upholding the values of democracy, and we are not sacrificing those values in the name of security.

Now, I understand the reference to the Netherlands. (smiling) We admire the commitment to democracy in many European countries, including the Netherlands. But we've got our own system, our own constitutional safeguards, and we're committed to ensuring that they're not eroded.

Regarding the security measures we've taken post-9/11, I understand the concerns, but I must remind you that we're in a war on terror, where the threat to our citizens is real and ongoing. We're doing our best to balance that threat with the need to protect our liberties.

We're not monitoring the private lives of citizens without due process. We've got laws in place to prevent that. We've got congressional oversight, judicial review, to ensure that our security measures are constitutional and targeted at real threats.

Now, I think it's clear that we can have a respectful disagreement on this. (extending hand) And I welcome that. We may not agree, but we can certainly shake hands and remain friends. We're united in our commitment to democracy and human rights, and we can continue to discuss and debate the best ways to protect both security and liberty.

Well, I appreciate the question, and I'm glad you brought it up, because I think it's a chance for me to clarify my position. When I said "we," I was referring to the United States and our allies, including the Pakistanis. We've got a strong relationship with President Musharraf and the Pakistani government, and we work closely with them on a variety of issues, including counter-terrorism.

Now, I do believe that if we had actionable intelligence that a high-value target was located in Pakistan, we would work closely with the Pakistanis to get the job done. But if, for some reason, we had to take action unilaterally, I would not hesitate to do so. Our number one priority is protecting the American people, and if we had information that would lead to the capture or killing of a high-value target, we would take that action.

Now, I don't want to get into the business of second-guessing or reacting to the comments of presidential candidates. I think it's unfair to say that Senator Obama's position on this issue is akin to Dr. Strangelove, that's just politics. And I'm not going to get into that. What I will say is that, as the President of the United States, I've got a solemn obligation to protect this country, and I will do whatever it takes, working with our allies, to achieve that goal.

And let me just say, I think it's interesting that people are beginning to realize the seriousness of the threat that we face. We're in a war on terror, and we've got to be prepared to take action to protect ourselves. And I think it's healthy to have a debate about how we do that, but at the end of the day, we've got to be united in our determination to protect this country and our people.

Thank you for the question. The situation in Basra is a complex one, and I appreciate the opportunity to provide some clarity.  The Iraqi government's decision to take on the lawlessness in Basra is a positive sign, it's a sign that they're taking ownership of their security and that they're determined to make their country a more secure place.

Now, the fact that there have been clashes is not surprising. I mean, when you've got a group of people who've been terrorizing a city, and the Iraqi government decides to take them on, there's gonna be a reaction. And we anticipated that there would be some violence.

However, I am encouraged that the Iraqi security forces, working with the coalition forces, are having success in defeating the enemy. And I'm also encouraged that the Iraqi government is reaching out to those who are interested in laying down their arms and joining the political process.

Now, in terms of reconciliation, I think that's a great question. One of the things that we're doing is working with Prime Minister Maliki to help them build their capacity to reach out to those who are interested in reconciling. And I think the Iraqi leaders are making progress on that front.

One of the things that I've always said is that the military aspect of this is only one part of the equation. The other part is economic growth and opportunities for the Iraqi people. And so, we're working closely with the Iraqi government to help them build their economy, to create jobs, to provide services, and to make sure that the Iraqi people see progress.

And so, when it comes to reconciliation, one of the things that we can do is to continue to work with the Iraqi government to help them build their capacity to reach out to those who are interested in reconciling. We're also willing to work with the neighboring countries to help them understand the importance of stability in Iraq.

[Laughter] Well, I think it's fair to say that, first of all, I'm a man who enjoys his meals. [Laughter] But I must say, the lunch with Prime Minister Prodi was excellent. The Italian food is, as you know, is outstanding. But, as I said, I'm looking forward to the coffee break with Prime Minister Berlusconi, too. I think it's an opportunity to sit down with a fellow leader, talk about the issues, and then enjoy a good cup of coffee.

And, I might say, the coffee breaks in Italy, they're a little bit longer than they are in the States. [Laughter] But, I'm looking forward to that. And, as for the diet, I think I'll just have to – [Laughter] – I'll just have to deal with it when I get back to Washington. [Laughter]

Thank you, good afternoon. I appreciate the question. First of all, I believe it's essential for the President of the United States to attend the Olympics, no matter where they are held. The Olympics represent an incredible opportunity for people from all over the world to come together and celebrate their differences, and also to celebrate the human spirit of competition and achievement.

As for my decision to attend the opening ceremonies, I believe it's essential for the United States to participate fully in the Olympics, and I'm proud of our athletes who have worked so hard to participate in the Games.

Now, regarding human rights and religious freedom in China, I have made it very clear to President Hu and to the Chinese people that these are core American values that are deeply important to us. And we will continue to speak out when we see actions that we believe are inconsistent with those values.

I have also made it clear that we will work to strengthen our bilateral relationship with China, and to find areas of common ground where we can work together to address global challenges. But I've also made it clear that our relationship will not come at the expense of our values, and that we will continue to be a vocal advocate for those values.

I'd say to my friends and allies in the United States that my approach to dealing with China has been one of engagement, while also being very candid and direct about our differences. I believe that's the right approach, because it allows us to find common ground and to make progress in areas where we agree, while also being able to speak clearly and candidly about areas where we disagree.

And I would say that, while there's still much work to be done, I'm proud of the progress we've made in areas like counter-terrorism, non-proliferation, and trade. But I'm also committed to continuing to press China on issues like human rights, and to working with the international community to address global challenges like Sudan and Burma.

It's a delicate balance, but I believe that's the right approach, and I believe that, over time, we can make progress and build a stronger, more healthy relationship with China that serves American interests and values.

(in a deep, Texas-accented voice)

Thank you for your questions. Let me start with Pakistan. I did indeed express my concerns to President Musharraf about the missile test, and we did ask them to consider the potential consequences of such an action. However, I must remind you that Pakistan is a sovereign nation, and we respect their right to make their own decisions.

Regarding the conflict in the region, I'm concerned that it could potentially pose a threat to our forces, as well as to stability in the region as a whole. We're working closely with Pakistan and other nations to try to reduce tensions and find a peaceful resolution to this conflict.

Now, regarding Memorial Day, I believe this Memorial Day will be different because it comes on the heels of the events of September 11th. That day was a turning point for our nation, a day that reminded us of the risks and the sacrifices that our men and women in uniform make every day. As we reflect on the sacrifices of our fallen heroes, we're also filled with a sense of pride and purpose. We honor those who have given the ultimate sacrifice for our freedom, and we remain committed to protecting our nation and its values.

Now, regarding our strategic initiative with Russia, I appreciate President Chirac's thoughtful question. I think it's fair to say that we did face some skepticism and even some resistance from some of our European allies. But I believe that our proposal, which aimed to reduce the threat of nuclear proliferation and enhance international cooperation, was a sound one.

( Turning to President Chirac ) As for whether we underestimated you, Mr. President, I'd say that we've always considered you a valuable ally and a skillful diplomat. We've had our differences, to be sure, but I believe that our relationship remains strong and vital to our shared interests.

But I will say that our proposal was not driven by a desire to undermine the European security architecture, but rather to try to find a way to make our security policies more effective. I'm willing to continue the conversation with our European partners to explore new approaches to building a more just and peaceful world.

And finally, let me just say that this Memorial Day is a moment for us to reflect on our shared values, our shared grief, and our shared determination to make the world a better and safer place.

Thank you for that question. I think there's been some confusion here, and I'd like to clarify a few points.

First of all, our bombing in Iraq is aimed at the terrorist organization known as al-Qaeda in Iraq. These are dangerous people who have no qualms about killing innocent civilians, and we're taking proactive steps to disrupt their operations. This is not the beginning of a new war; it's part of our ongoing efforts to secure the region and protect our troops and allies.

As for the conversation I had with President Calderón of Mexico, we were discussing the issue of border security and immigration reform. The United States and Mexico share a long and valued relationship, and we're committed to finding solutions to these complex issues.

Regarding amnesty, let me be clear: our proposed comprehensive immigration reform package does include a pathway to citizenship for undocumented immigrants who meet certain criteria, such as paying a fine, learning English, and passing a background check. But this is not an amnesty program. It's a way to bring people out of the shadows, to make our borders more secure, and to recognize the significant contributions that many undocumented immigrants make to our economy.

To the world, I want to send a message of hope and cooperation. We recognize that many of these issues – terrorism, immigration, and economic development – are global problems that require global solutions. We're committed to working with our allies and partners to address these challenges and to build a safer, more prosperous world for all people.

And to the American people, I want to reassure them that our military actions in Iraq are guided by a clear strategy and a commitment to protecting our troops and our national interests. We will work tirelessly to promote peace and stability in the region, and we will continue to engage with nations around the world to build a more secure and cooperative future. Thank you.

That's a fair question. I appreciate you bringing it up. Let me tell you, our warnings are not idle. We mean what we say. And we're working diligently to make sure that the diplomatic efforts we're involved with are successful.

First of all, the difference today is that the international community is more united than it's been in the past. We've got the United Nations speaking with one voice, and that's a positive development. We've also got a new resolutions out of the Security Council that condemns North Korea's actions, for example.

I do believe that there will be consequences, and there will be responses to nations that defy the international community. First, we're going to continue to work the diplomatic track. We're going to work with our allies, like South Korea, Japan, China, and Russia, to see if we can't find a solution to this problem through peaceful means.

Now, I understand the skepticism. I understand the sense that, 'Have we've been here before?' And that's true, we have been here before. But I'm telling you, I'm more determined than ever to see to it that we protect America, and we protect our friends and allies from the threats of nuclear proliferation.

The consequences that we will apply will be dire, should these nations continue to ignore the world's call for as well as the actions that we're about to take. We'll continue to target financial institutions, we'll target arms transfers, we'll make it difficult for them to move in the international arena. And as for having consequences for Iran or North Korea's leaders personally, that's something we're considering and we are not ruling out.

So, I understand the skepticism, but I assure you that we are taking these threats seriously, and we're working as hard as we can to prevent these nations from becoming threats to the world.

Thank you, дорогой (laughs). Well, I'm glad you had a chance to come to the White House and visit with me. Peru is a very special country, and I'm proud of the relationship we're building. 

As I said, they're not just a friend, but an ally. And when I say that, I mean it. We're going to be working closely with Peru on a variety of fronts, beyond just trade and counter-narcotics. One area I'm particularly excited about is education. We've got a program that we'll be unveiling shortly to increase educational exchanges between our two countries. We want to make it easier for Peruvian students to come to the United States to study, and for American students to go to Peru.

On the economic front, we're very supportive of President Toledo's efforts to open up the economy and implement reforms. We believe that will make Peru a more attractive place for American businesses to invest. 

Regarding a free trade agreement, I can tell you that we are indeed open to exploring that possibility. Peru has made significant progress in the areas of trade and labor reform, and we believe that's an example for other countries in the region. If Peru continues to make progress on these fronts, I think we could have a positive discussion about moving towards a free trade agreement.

So, I think you'll see a deepening of our relationship on a variety of fronts. We're committed to making this relationship a top priority.

That's a great question. You know, I've been giving this a lot of thought, and let me tell you, it's a complex issue. But I want to assure the American people that I'm committed to the war on terror, and that includes dealing with those who harbor and support terrorists.

Now, regarding Chairman Arafat, I've said before that he's not a reliable partner in the peace process. He's made some choices that have made it difficult for us to move forward. But, I'm not ready to say that he's the same as Saddam Hussein or Charles Taylor just yet.

You see, in the case of Saddam Hussein, he was a brutal dictator who sponsored terrorism and had a history of aggressive behavior that threatened the stability of the region. And in the case of Charles Taylor, he's a warlord who's been responsible for incredible violence and human rights abuses.

Arafat is a different case. He's a leader of the Palestinian people, and I believe that there's still a possibility that he can make a difference in the peace process. Now, I want to be clear: his recent actions have been unacceptable, and he needs to take concrete steps to crack down on terrorism and to support a peaceful resolution.

But, I don't believe that labeling him a terrorist at this point would be productive. Instead, I think we need to continue to work with him, to pressure him to make the right choices, and to help the Palestinian people to achieve their aspirations for a peaceful, democratic state.

Now, I know some of you might say that's not tough enough. But, I believe that leadership is about making tough choices, and sometimes that means working with people who are not perfect, but who can help you achieve your goals.

So, we'll continue to work with the Palestinian Authority, and we'll continue to pressure Chairman Arafat to make the right choices. But, we'll do it in a way that's consistent with our values and our interests.

Well, thank you for the question. I'm glad to be here with my friend, Prime Minister Rasmussen, and I appreciate the opportunity to address the people of Denmark.

First of all, I understand that there's been a lot of debate about my foreign policy, and I respect that. I think it's essential in a vibrant democracy to have a debate. I also understand that some people may disagree with my decisions, and that's okay. But I want to tell the people of Denmark, I make decisions based on what I think is in the best interest of our nation, our security, and our values.

When it comes to the war in Iraq, for example, I understand that there's been a lot of criticism, but I want to remind the people that Saddam Hussein was a danger to the world. He was a brutal dictator who had used weapons of mass destruction before, and we cannot tolerate that kind of behavior in the 21st century.

And yes, I know that there are some disagreements, but I believe that our efforts in Iraq are part of a larger effort to spread freedom and peace. I believe that the promotion of freedom and democracy is in the best interest of our nations, and I believe that the people of Iraq deserve to live in a free and peaceful society.

So, I would say to the people of Denmark, I understand your skepticism, but I hope you can understand the principles that I'm operating from, and I hope you can have confidence in the integrity and the good intentions of the United States and its allies.

We're working hard to make the world a safer place, and I think our efforts are yielding results. We're making progress in the war on terror, and we're making progress in spreading freedom and democracy around the world.

Thank you for that thoughtful question. I appreciate your attention to the Inaugural Address. As I said in that speech, we will stand with the people of Afghanistan and Iraq, and other nations that are struggling for freedom, and we will help them build free and just societies. But I also recognize that every nation is unique, with its own history, culture, and struggles.

Now, regarding countries like Russia, China, and Saudi Arabia, I want to make it clear that our relationships with these nations are complex and multifaceted. We have significant interests and cooperation in areas such as trade, security, and non-proliferation. However, I also made it clear in the Inaugural Address that we will not shy away from promoting democracy and human rights.

These values are non-negotiable, and they are essential to our long-term national interest. The leaders of these countries should understand that we will continue to encourage and support liberalization and democratization within their borders, just as we support these values in every country around the world.

But I am also a realist. I know that we cannot simply dictate to other nations how they should govern themselves. We will engage with these countries, and we will work with them to address areas where we cooperate, such as the war on terror, non-proliferation, and economic development.

There is an understanding, however, that on the path to reform, the advancement of freedom and democracy is not a secondary concern, but part of the equation. It is my hope that through engagement, dialogue, and cooperation, these nations will choose a path that is more in line with the values that we hold dear.

Make no mistake, I am committed to defending our nation's interests, and we will work with these countries to achieve common purposes. But, I also want to make it clear that we will not compromise on our values, and we will continue to promote and defend freedom and human rights around the world.

Thank you, Prime Minister Berisha. That's very kind of you to say. I do want to reiterate my commitment to a peaceful resolution in Kosovo. I spoke with Prime Minister Berisha about the French proposal presented by President Sarkozy. We had a good discussion about it. I made it clear that we've got to be careful here. We can't rush to independence, we've got to make sure that all parties are comfortable with the outcome.

Now, I understand the Kosovars' frustration, I really do. They want their independence. But it's also important for us to make sure that the process is one that will lead to peace. And therefore, I'm committed to working with the Europeans, the United States, and other parties to find a solution that is acceptable to all. And I appreciate the Prime Minister's advice to the Kosovars to remain calm and persistent.

And just to assure the Albanians and the Albanian government, we value our friendship with Albania. We believe that they can play a constructive role in the region, and we will continue to work closely with them as we move forward on this issue.

(sighs) Well, I appreciate the question. It's a tough issue, and I understand the concerns of the Tillman family. I want to assure them and the American people that we take the death of every soldier very seriously. Pat Tillman was a hero, and his sacrifice will not be forgotten.

As for the investigations, I understand that there have been several, and I'm committed to finding out the truth. However, I also want to be careful not to jeopardize any ongoing investigations or compromise the process. I know there's been some frustration, and I share that frustration.

But I will pledge to the Tillman family that we will do everything in our power to get to the bottom of what happened to Corporal Tillman. We owe it to him, his family, and the American people. I'll make sure that my administration works closely with the relevant authorities to provide a full and thorough investigation, and we'll make sure that we're as transparent as possible about the findings.

(pauses) I think it's also important to remember that the Department of the Army has already conducted several investigations, and we should respect the integrity of the process. But I will personally see to it that we take a fresh look, that we leave no stone unturned, to get to the truth.

(looks directly into the camera) And to the Tillman family, I want to assure you that we will not rest until we've done everything in our power to honor Pat's memory and find the truth about what happened to him.

Thank you for that question. I think it's fair to say that the tax cuts did have an impact on the deficit, but I'd like to correct you - it's also important to consider the broader economic picture. We did have a recession, and we did have the aftermath of 9/11. Those are significant factors that impacted our economy.

Now, I'll tell you, I was pleased to see the economic growth that we've experienced since the tax cuts went into effect. It's been robust, it's been strong, and I believe it's been a good thing for the American people. And, more importantly, I think the tax cuts were necessary to get our economy moving again.

Now, I know the OMB report you're talking about, and I appreciate the work they do. But I'd like to point out that their projections are just that - projections. And we're doing everything we can to make sure that our economy remains strong, and that those projections don't necessarily come to pass.

So, to answer your question directly, I don't think it's accurate to say that tax cuts are solely responsible for the deficits. I think it's more complicated than that. But I do think that our economic policies, including the tax cuts, have been beneficial for the American people, and I'm proud of what we've accomplished.

And as far as the deficits 'as far as the eye can see' - I don't think that's a fair characterization. We're working hard to get our budget in order, to prioritize our spending, and to make sure that we're making smart decisions about how we're allocating our resources. And I'm confident that, over time, we'll get our deficits under control.

Well, I think I'll answer that first. (laughs) 

Regarding President Karzai's statements, I think he's got a right to be concerned about the security of his country. And, as a matter of fact, I talked to him recently about our shared goal of defeating the Taliban and al-Qaeda. The question is, how best to do that. And the way we think is the most effective is through this long-term partnership between Afghanistan, the United States, and other international partners to train and enable the Afghan military to take on these extremists.

Regarding cross-border operations, I think it's best if those are coordinated with the Pakistani government. We've had some good cooperation with Pakistan, and we want to continue to encourage that cooperation. I think it's very difficult, though, to achieve victory if we don't have a cooperative Pakistan. And so we're working with President Zardari to help him take on the Taliban and al-Qaeda inside his boundaries.

The agreements that Pakistan is pursuing with some of these militant groups - we're watching them very carefully. And I've made it clear to President Zardari that we don't consider it acceptable to make deals that enable the Taliban to regroup or continue their arms trade. They've got to understand that this alliance is not about enabling havens for extremists; it's about winning the war on terror.

The issues of Katrina and New Orleans - I appreciate the question. There's a lot of things that I could have done differently, with the benefit of hindsight. One thing I think we could have done - and this is in the realm of the possible - is to push for more resources for the levee system in New Orleans before the storm hit.

I remember advocating for more funding for Katrina relief before the storm even occurred, but often, in the legislative process, it takes a while to get that money through. I also wish that I could have worked more closely with local and state officials to respond more quickly to a storm of this magnitude.

It's clear that the response to Katrina was slow, and for that, I'm deeply sorry. We made a lot of tough decisions, but ultimately, the buck stops with me. And I know that I've been criticized for that, and that's fair. I accept responsibility for the mistakes.

On the issue of race - well, I think that we've made some progress, but we've still got a ways to go. I think the fact that we have our first African American president is a testament to how far we've come as a country. I think that we've made strides, but I also think that we've got a lot of work to do on issues like education and healthcare.

As a matter of fact, during my time in office, I think we've seen some progress on education, particularly in the area of education reform. I think that programs like 'No Child Left Behind' have helped to bring more attention to the disparities in our education system and how to address them.

On healthcare, I wish I could have made more progress. I think that we've got a lot of work to do to address the issue of racial disparities in healthcare, and I think that we've got some work to do to make sure that all Americans have access to quality, affordable healthcare.

I will say, though, that I think that we've made some progress during my time in office, and I think that we're on the right track. But ultimately, I think that it's gonna take all of us working together to make sure that we become the land of equality and justice that we all hope for.

The James Byrd dragging death - it was a terrible, terrible act. I was deeply troubled by it, and I was proud to support hate crimes legislation. And I will say, though, that I think that the atmosphere in Texas at the time was - on the whole issue of racial tensions - was a tense, difficult situation.

Thank you, thank you for your question. I appreciate being back here with President Toledo, we've had a warm and enriching conversation, and I must say, I'm intrigued by your observation about the ties, I'll have to get with my advisors on that one. (laughter)

But on the subject of poverty and reducing arms spending in Latin America, I think President Toledo and I are in broad agreement that poverty is a major challenge, not just in Latin America, but around the world. And we also agree that one of the key ways to address poverty is through economic development and creating opportunity.

As it relates to reducing arms spending, I think both President Toledo and I understand that the main antagonist to peace and stability in the Americas is not a conventional military threat, but rather, it's the despair and the hopelessness that comes with poverty. And, therefore, we both agree that it's essential to prioritize spending on economic development, education, and healthcare over military arsenals.

Now, I must say, as the Commander-in-Chief of the United States, I've got a responsibility to ensure the security of our nation, and our military is essential to that security. However, I also believe that there is a growing recognition in the hemisphere that our security is linked, and that our prosperity is linked, and that we must work together to address the root causes of conflict, including poverty.

I think we can find a balance between our security needs and our economic development needs. And I think President Toledo and I will be exploring ways in which we can work together, through the Organization of American States, and other international institutions, to promote economic development, to reduce arms spending, and to promote peace and stability in the hemisphere.

So, I think we're in agreement that addressing poverty and reducing arms spending is a critical priority, and I look forward to working with President Toledo on this issue.

Well, thank you for the question. First of all, I have not read the report, but I am familiar with the allegations that have been made. I want to assure the American people that our policy is to comply with the Geneva Conventions and the Army Field Manual when it comes to interrogation techniques. We've made it clear that we do not condone torture. 

The people who will be targeted in our operations, those who are responsible for the terrorist attacks, for example, will be brought to justice, but it's also important for our own security and that of our coalition partners to extract as much information as possible about terrorist organizations. But again, we'll do so within the bounds of the law and in accordance with American values.

Regarding Guantanamo, I still want to close it. I think it's a symbol of our war against terror, and that makes it difficult for us to be seen as the good guys, et cetera, and that's important for the United States image. And after all, I think we can do a better job of either try to try them, those deserving conviction, or release the ones who do not present a threat.

Now, I'm working through the process, and the reason it's taking a while is because it's a complicated issue, and I want to make sure we do it right. We would, as you know, have put a number of steps in place in order to close, in the bill, for example, banning taking of new detainees to that facility, among those steps. So I'm working through it, I am committed, and I'm seeking a long-term answer to this question.

And with all respect to those you mentioned, and their present positions. We're doing what's right by the country, doing this in a way that ensures national security, a nation in safety, and a system that is still able to find terrorists.

Thank you for the question. Well, I appreciate your interest in this matter. Let me be clear: I did indeed express concern about the use of payments to journalists to promote our agenda, and I stand by that decision. It's essential to maintain the integrity of the press and the trust of the American people.

Now, regarding the use of video news releases (VNRs), I understand that the Government Accountability Office (GAO) has looked into this matter. I agree that transparency and disclosure are crucial. It's essential that the public knows the source of the information they receive.

While VNRs can be a useful tool for providing factual information to the public, I acknowledge that the lack of disclosure can be problematic. We will take a closer look at our policies and procedures to ensure that they align with the highest standards of transparency and accountability.

We're committed to upholding the principles of a free and independent press, and we'll work to maintain that delicate balance between informing the public and respecting the integrity of the media.

Let me be clear: the purpose of our communication efforts is to provide accurate and timely information to the American people, not to manipulate or deceive them. If our VNRs are not clearly labeled as Government-produced, that's not acceptable, and we'll make necessary adjustments to our practices.

I appreciate your attention to this matter, and I'm confident that we can find a way to maintain transparency and uphold the public trust. Next question, please.

"Thank you for the question. As you know, we've been workin' hard to address the threat of ballistic missiles, and considerin' various strategies to counter that threat. I think it's fair to say that we are explorin' a number of options to enhance our missile defense capabilities.

Regarding the specific question about upgradin' radar stations in northern England, I'd say that's an idea that's certainly bein' considered. We value our special relationship with the United Kingdom, and we're workin' closely with our British allies to examine ways we can cooperate on missile defense.

Now, I don't want to get ahead of the process or make any announcements just yet. But I will say that we're committed to doin' what it takes to protect our nation and our allies from the threat of ballistic missiles, and we're gonna keep all options on the table as we move forward. That's all I can say for now."

Thank you for that question. You know, I've always believed in the importance of our transatlantic relationship and the value of listening to our allies. One example that comes to mind is my conversation with then-Chancellor Gerhard Schröder of Germany regarding the role of NATO in Afghanistan.

Initially, our administration was hesitant about involving NATO in Afghanistan, but Chancellor Schröder and other European leaders made a strong case for why NATO's involvement was crucial to stabilizing the region. They argued that a successful NATO mission in Afghanistan would not only help the Afghan people but also serve as a catalyst for transatlantic cooperation and burden-sharing.

After careful consideration and several conversations with Chancellor Schröder, I decided to support NATO's involvement in Afghanistan. And, as it turned out, it was the right decision. NATO's participation helped to bring stability to the region and demonstrated the alliance's ability to adapt to new challenges.

Now, I know some of my critics might say, "What about Iraq?" And I understand the skepticism. But the fact is, we did engage in a dialogue with our European allies, including Germany, prior to the invasion. Their concerns were heard, but we ultimately disagreed on the best course of action.

However, that didn't mean we didn't continue to work together on key issues, including counter-terrorism and non-proliferation. We maintained a strong relationship with Germany and our other European allies, and that cooperation continues to this day.

So, while we may not always agree, I firmly believe that our dialogue with European leaders has been valuable in shaping American policy, and I think that's a testament to the strength of our alliances. Thank you.

I appreciate the question.
