First, let me just say that the welfare and safety of the American citizens who are being held by the FARC is of the utmost importance to Laura and me, and to our administration. We're deeply concerned about the well-being of these individuals, and we're working closely with the government of Colombia to try to find a peaceful resolution to this crisis.

Regarding a humanitarian agreement, I think it's a reasonable question to ask. We're exploring all options, all diplomatic options, to try to bring these people home safely. We believe that a humanitarian agreement, in the context of a broader peace agreement, could be a positive step forward. But I want to emphasize that any agreement would have to be negotiated in good faith, with concrete results, and with a clear commitment from the FARC to end its terrorist activities.

Regarding military action, I can tell you that we've had discussions with President Uribe about a range of options, including the potential for military action. We believe that military action should always be a last resort, but it's something that we have to consider in order to protect our citizens and to protect the sovereignty of Colombia.

And finally, regarding extradition, our policy on extradition remains unchanged. We believe that those who have committed crimes in Colombia should be held accountable in Colombia, and we support the efforts of the Colombian government to bring these individuals to justice. We're working closely with the Colombian government to make sure that any individuals who are wanted for crimes in the United States are extradited to face justice here.

Embedded in your question are a lot of ifs. Let me first say that I'm deeply concerned about the American people's safety, and I am. And I understand the anxiety and the fear that exists. And I want to assure the American people that we're doing everything we can to run down every lead, every hint, every rumor to protect the American people.

Now, regarding the information, I want to be careful not to disclose information that might in some way harm our efforts to protect ourselves. But I want to assure the American people that we're working as hard as we can to prevent any potential attacks from happening. We're working with state and local authorities, law enforcement, to make sure that our critical infrastructure is protected.

To the question of locking down systems, we will take the necessary precautions to protect the American people. But I don't want to get into specifics about what those precautions might be, because I don't want to, in any way, give potential adversaries information that might be useful to them.

To the American people, I'd say, first, is to stay tuned to your local news, to your local reports. If there are any specific instructions or advice being given in your area, I urge you to follow that advice. Stay calm, but be vigilant. We will do everything we can to protect you, but we need your help. If you see something that's suspicious, report it to the proper authorities.

In the meantime, I want the American people to know that we're working as hard as we can to bring those who would do us harm to justice. And I'm confident that we will succeed in this mission. We're a strong nation, a resilient nation, and we will get through this difficult time.

I urge all Americans to go about their daily lives, to be aware, but not to be paranoid. I understand the anxiety, but I also understand the resolve and the strength of the American people. And I'm confident that, together, we'll get through this.

Thank you for the question.  I appreciate the opportunity to talk about a very important topic, and that is the free trade agreement with Central America. First, let me talk about my commitment to free trade. I believe that when we trade, all parties benefit. I believe that it's not only good for our economy, but it's good for the economies of those with whom we trade.

Now, I know there are concerns about our agricultural subsidies. I want to remind you that we have, in fact, made a commitment to eliminate tariffs and to reduce subsidies in the Doha rounds. That's our stated position. Now, I will admit to you, we have a long way to go, but we're making progress.

And the Central American Free Trade Agreement that we're negotiating is a step in that direction. It will reduce our tariffs and subsidies. It will help farmers in Central America, and it will help our farmers here in the United States.

Now, I know there are some in Congress, not just the Senate, but the House as well, who are skeptical about trade agreements. I understand that. But I'll tell you this: we've had some experience with trade agreements, and they've worked. And I believe this one will as well.

Now, I'll be frank with you. We've got some work to do to get the Senate to approve the Trade Promotion Authority. And I'm working on it. I'm talking to senators. I'm reminding them that this is in our interest, it's in the interest of Central America, and it's in the interest of trade, which I believe is essential to economic growth.

So, I'm optimistic that we'll get the Trade Promotion Authority. And once we do, we'll be able to finish this negotiation and have a CAFTA that will benefit all the parties involved.

Well, I appreciate the question. Let me tell you, we care deeply about the people of New Orleans, and we're committed to helping them recover and rebuild. The plan that was put forward by Mayor Nagin and the city council did have some concerns that we had to address. We're working very closely with the state and local officials to make sure that the plan is viable and that it's going to help the most people.

I understand that there are concerns about the poorest of the poor, and I want to assure the people of New Orleans that we're going to do everything we can to help those folks. But we've also got to be responsible with the taxpayers' money, and we've got to make sure that we're spending it in a way that's going to yield results.

I don't think that there's a limit to the extent to which the city can be rebuilt, but I do think that we've got to be smart about how we do it. We've got to think about the long-term viability of the city, and we've got to make sure that we're not just rebuilding in a way that's going to put people back in harm's way.

So, I've tasked Don Powell, who's our coordinator on the ground, to work closely with the local officials to come up with a plan that's going to meet the needs of all the people of New Orleans. We're committed to helping the city rise again, and we're going to do everything we can to make that happen.

And I want to remind people that we've already made a significant commitment to New Orleans, over $85 billion in aid, and we're going to continue to work to help the city recover and rebuild. This is a long-term commitment, and we're in it for the long haul.

(pauses, looking serious) Well, I appreciate the question, and I understand the skepticism. Let me be clear: our strategy in Iraq has always been to help the Iraqi people achieve a stable and secure democracy, and that's still our goal. When I said "stay the course," I meant that we would not pull out of Iraq prematurely, that we would see it through to its successful conclusion.

Now, as the situation on the ground has evolved, we've had to adapt our tactics to match the changing circumstances. That's just good military strategy. The reality is, the Iraqi government is stepping up to their responsibilities, and we're working closely with them to set realistic goals and timetables for security, for reconstruction, and for political reconciliation.

I know some have tried to say that "benchmarks" and "timetables" are code for "cut and run." But that's not true. These are tools to measure progress, to hold everyone accountable – ourselves, the Iraqis, and the international community.

(looking directly at the reporter) And let me be clear: we're not making this up as we go along. We've been working on this strategy for months, and we've got a plan to win. I'm not a politician; I'm the Commander-in-Chief. This isn't about politics; it's about getting the job done, and we're making progress.

Thank you for that question. I appreciate it. I've heard some of these allegations, and I'll tell you, they concern me. No administration wants to be known for trying to exert undue influence over the Department of Justice. I've got faith in our Attorney General, Alberto Gonzales. I've got faith in the professionals at the Justice Department to do their job.

But I agree, it's very important that the Attorney General be responsive to these allegations. He is, by the way. He's testified, I think, for hours and hours and hours before the committees. He's been very forthright in his answers, and I believe he will continue to do so.

I'm confident that the Department of Justice can continue to serve the American people with honor and integrity, that they can continue to have the confidence of the American people. And the Attorney General assures me that since these allegations were made, he's has taken steps to ensure that we do not repeat mistakes that have been made.

Now, I'll give you a little insight into how I think about these kinds of situations. I believe that in order for the system to work, there must be accountability. There must be people who are willing to take charge and make decisions. But there must also be accountability.

And I think that my Attorney General, by being willing to go testify and by being transparent, is demonstrating to the American people that we are indeed serious about making sure that the Department of Justice functions the way it should.

I hope that gives you some comfort. It's a serious matter, and I know that, and I want the American people to know that I take it seriously, as does the Attorney General.

Well, I appreciate the question. First, let me start by saying that the United States has a long tradition of a free press, and I'm a strong supporter of that. We've had a very open society for many years, and I think that's one of our strengths.

Now, in terms of your question about the tension between national security and the need to have a free press, I think it's always a delicate balance. On the one hand, we do need to protect sources and methods in order to be able to wage an effective war on terror. On the other hand, we do need to have a free press in order to hold people accountable.

I think one of the keys is that we want to make sure that we're not squelching unfettered public debate. We want the American people to have access to a wide range of information and to be able to make their own judgments about what's going on.

Now, in terms of specific decisions, such as the one with Osama bin Laden not being able to get on the air, well, I think that's a pretty easy call. The man is a terrorist, he's trying to kill Americans, and we don't want to give him a platform to be able to inspire other people to kill Americans.

In terms of discussions with the media, I think it's perfectly reasonable for my administration to talk to the media about sensitive information that might, in fact, put lives at risk if it were to be disclosed. And I'm sure that we've had some cordial, but direct conversations with various media outlets about what they can and cannot report.

But let me make one thing very clear: we're not trying to intimidate the press. We're not trying to tell the press what to report and what not to report. We're simply trying to make sure that we're able to balance our national security needs with our commitment to a free society.

Now, I think the question, "where is the line?" is a good one. And I think the line is crossed when we start to see, for example, information that would allow terrorists to learn how to avoid our law enforcement activities or to create a threat to the security of the United States. That's when I think we've got to draw the line.

And I'm confident that the vast majority of the American press understands that balance and is willing to work with us to get it right. And if we don't, I'm sure that the American people will let us know that we're not striking the right balance.

Thank you for the question. The issue of interdiction flights in Peruvian airspace is indeed a serious one, and we're taking a very close look at it. We recognize the importance of disrupting the flow of drugs into the United States and the harm it causes to our citizens and the people of Peru.

Now, as I said in Monterrey, we are reviewing the issue, and I will say we're interested in resuming those flights, but we need to make sure they're effective, they're efficient, and most importantly, they're safe for our pilots and crew members. You know we had some concerns about the shoot-down of one of our planes a while back, and we need to satisfy ourselves that the risks have been mitigated.

In terms of preconditions, we want to make sure that the Peruvian military is committed to providing adequate support for our missions, and that the necessary protocols are in place to ensure the success of the operation. We're also looking for a commitment from the Peruvian government to take a comprehensive approach to combating narco-terrorism and drug trafficking.

Now, as for your question, President Toledo, I am hoping that President Toledo will address the issue of coca eradication. We have a responsibility to work together to combat this problem, and it does require a comprehensive approach, which includes eradication, interdiction, law enforcement cooperation, and economic development alternatives for those who are dependent on the coca trade. The Peruvian government has made some progress in this area, but we believe there is more that can be done. And I would like to hear from President Toledo on how he plans to step up Peru's efforts to address this issue.

[Turns to President Toledo] And President Toledo?

Well, I understand the concerns of the American people, and I appreciate the fact that they're thinking deeply about this issue. I understand the skepticism and the frustration. But I want to remind them that we're in a global war on terror, and Iraq is a major front on that war. We're fighting against an enemy that's ruthless, that's determined to harm America, and they're using Iraq as a center of their operations.

Now, I also understand that there was a significant amount of debate about the intelligence that led up to the decision. And I also know that we're working to address those concerns. We've had several investigations, including the commission that I asked for, to make sure that our intelligence is sound.

But the reason I made the decision I did is because Saddam Hussein was a threat. He was a threat to the region, a threat to his own people, and a threat to the United States. And I was not willing to take the risk of allowing him to continue to pose that threat.

Now, I know that it's not going as smoothly as we had hoped. I know that there are people who are now questioning the decision. But I want to assure them that we're working hard to make sure that we're doing everything we can to succeed in Iraq. We're working with the Iraqis to train their army, to help them develop a functioning government, and to provide security to the Iraqi people.

And I would say to the American people, don't give up on this cause. We're making progress. We're making progress on the ground. We're making progress in the way the Iraqis are behaving. They had a very successful election, and they're starting to make some tough decisions.

Now, I know that there are still many dangers ahead of us. But I have faith in the American people. I have faith in the U.S. military, and I have faith in the Iraqis. And I think we're making progress.

Regarding the troops, I understand that the Army is saying we're going to need to keep a significant number of troops in Iraq for a while longer. I agree with that assessment. We cannot leave Iraq until the job is complete. We cannot leave Iraq until we've finished the mission.

And finally, regarding the funding request, I understand that there may be some debate on the Hill about whether or not to provide this funding. I urge Congress to work with us to make sure that our troops have the resources they need to complete the mission.

I appreciate the question, and I'm happy to clarify the agreement reached with President Putin. Let me make one thing clear: our commitment to developing and deploying a missile defense system for the American people remains unchanged. The agreement with President Putin did not commit us to slowing down or delaying the development of missile defense technologies.

What we did agree to do, and I think this is an important step forward, is to continue to consult and discuss with the Russians the future of the ABM Treaty, as well as the development of offensive and defensive systems. We want to make sure that as we move forward with our missile defense system, we're doing so in a way that's transparent and takes into account any concerns the Russians may have.

Now, let me be clear: we're not bound by the ABM Treaty. We believe it's a Cold War relic that doesn't reflect the world we live in today, where we face threats from rogue states and other non-state actors. But we're willing to work with the Russians to find a way forward that allows us to move forward with missile defense, while also taking into account their concerns.

So, to answer your question directly, we will continue to develop and deploy our missile defense system as needed, while continuing to consult with the Russians and work towards a mutually beneficial agreement.

"I think it's an excellent question. As I said earlier, we are committed to the roadmap, and I appreciate the Prime Minister's efforts to promote the peace process. We're discussing ways to accelerate it. However, as for actual implementation, it's essential to emphasize that the roadmap's implementation requires decisive action from both parties.

 We're considering our role in supporting that process. We'll work closely with both Israelis and Palestinians to achieve the two-state solution. But, as I told the King earlier, it's vital that we see some real progress on the ground before we decide the next step.

 As for involvement, I wouldn't rule out an American role in the actual implementation. What that role will be, remains to be seen. We will do what it takes to facilitate a lasting peace between Israel and the Palestinian people. But it's critical that we don't simply dictate; we work together, ensure the security of all parties, and build on the courageous efforts we see already. Thank you."

Thank you for the question. First of all, I do believe that we are making progress in Iraq. The Iraqi people are beginning to take control of their country, and the training missions for the Iraqi security forces are going well. Now, I think it's - I believe it's - a possibility that we can reduce some troops, but I won't give any firm predictions, because I can tell you for certain that we will not leave until the job is done.

The military objectives are being met, but I believe, as I - we - as we continue to make progress, it's possible that some troops could be redeployed. But I'm also mindful that we must complete the mission. I've always said, you know, we'll stay as long as necessary and leave as soon as possible.

But I think it's - the key is this: I want to make it clear to you, and to the American people, and to the Iraqis that we're making progress, but that it's still tough. This is a tough, tough battle.

Thank you for your question. I appreciate your interest in the important efforts to combat the scourge of drug trafficking in our region.

First, I want to commend the governments of Mexico and Canada for their leadership on this issue. We have indeed been working together to develop a comprehensive plan to combat the effects of drug trafficking, and we are making good progress.

Now, I know there have been some delays, and I'm glad you asked about that. The obstacle, frankly, is that this is a complex issue. It requires a coordinated effort from all three countries, and we need to make sure that we get it right. We're not just talking about throwing money at the problem or sending troops to the border. We're talking about a sustained effort to disrupt and dismantle the trafficking networks, to protect our citizens, and to support the brave men and women who are on the front lines of this fight.

Now, regarding the support of the United States to Mexico, I can confirm that we are committed to providing significant assistance to our neighbor to the south. We believe that this is a shared problem that requires a shared solution. We are prepared to provide Mexico with the resources they need to take on the cartels, to strengthen their law enforcement institutions, and to protect their citizens.

The levels of support I've seen reports about – a tenfold increase – I'd say that's in the ballpark, but I'd rather not get into too many details here today. Let's just say that we're committed to providing substantial support to Mexico, and we're working closely with the Mexican government to determine the best way to use those resources.

Now, I know there's been a lot of discussion about the model we're using. Some have compared it to the efforts we've made in Colombia. I think that's a fair comparison. We've learned a lot from our experience in Colombia, and we're applying those lessons to our efforts in Mexico.

But let me be clear: this is a unique situation, and we need to tailor our approach to the specific challenges we're facing. We're not just cutting and pasting a plan from Colombia and applying it to Mexico. We're working closely with the Mexican government to develop a plan that's tailored to their needs, their circumstances, and their priorities.

And let me just say, finally, that I'm proud of the leadership that Mexico is showing on this issue. President Calderón is a brave man, and he's showing real courage in the face of some very formidable adversaries. We stand with him, and we stand with the Mexican people, in this fight against the cartels.

Thank you.

Thank you for that question.  I've had a very good discussion with President Aznar about our mutual desire to fight terror.  And I want to thank him for carrying the torch for that fight here in Spain.

First, let me just start by saying that, obviously, we respect the laws of Spain and the laws of any country we work with.  The death penalty or not, we will work with countries based on their laws and their systems.  That's the way the international system works.

However, there are plenty of areas where we can cooperate, and we will cooperate with the Spanish government to bring terrorists to justice.  We can share intelligence.  We can cooperate on law enforcement.  We can work together to disrupt the financing of terror.  And we will do just that.

One of the things that I've learned in the fight against terror is, is that we're not just fighting terror, we're fighting the ideology that breeds terror.  And one of the ways to defeat that ideology is to spread freedom and liberty, and to help stabilize regions that are unstable.

Now, the President and I have talked about a lot of these issues, and we've talked about the mission to help democracy in places like Afghanistan and Iraq.  And I want to thank him for Spain's contributions to the Iraqi mission.

But in terms of specific assistance, I think that what you're trying to get at is that there's a whole set of ways we can cooperate in the fight against terror, the death penalty not being one of them, obviously.  And we'll work within the systems of our respective countries to make sure that we're doing everything we can to bring terrorists to justice.

Thank you for the question. I appreciate the interest in this important initiative. Let me be clear: our commitment to combating AIDS in Africa is strong and unwavering. The United States has a moral obligation to act in the face of this pandemic, and we're committed to making a difference.

Now, regarding the funding, I'd like to clarify the numbers. Our proposal is indeed a $15 billion commitment over five years, with a significant portion of those funds directed to Africa. The first year, we're allocating $2 billion, which includes a significant increase in funding from previous years.

Now, I know there's been some discussion about the exact numbers, but I want to assure you and the American people that we are committed to following through on this pledge. I've already spoken with the Secretary of the Treasury and the Secretary of Health and Human Services, and they're working closely with the Appropriations Committee to ensure that the necessary funds are allocated.

As President, I'm committed to making sure that our word is our bond, and we deliver on this critical initiative. I've also asked my advisors to work closely with Congressional leaders to ensure that we're able to meet our commitment.

Now, I know that there's going to be some back-and-forth on the details, but let me be clear: our commitment to combating AIDS in Africa is unwavering, and we're going to follow through on our pledge. I appreciate your interest in this issue, and I'm committed to making sure that we make a real difference in the lives of those affected by this pandemic.

Well, I appreciate the question. You know, the FTAA, the Free Trade Area of the Americas, was a good effort, and I'm proud of the fact that we pushed hard to try to get a hemisphere-wide free trade agreement. However, as you mentioned, it didn't work out.

I think the difference, though, is that the Doha Round of the WTO negotiations is a more focused effort. We're dealing with specific issues, particularly agriculture, industrial goods, and services. And I believe we can make progress on those specific issues.

Now, I will say, the FTAA experience did teach us the importance of being more precise in our goals and having a clear timeline. That's one of the reasons why I've been pressing the G-8 + 5 countries to work hard to get a Framework Agreement by the end of July.

And the reason I invited President Lula here was to reinforce our commitment to getting that Framework Agreement. We didn't have a deadline for the FTAA, and I think that was one of the shortcomings of that effort.

In terms of speaking the same language, I think that's a great metaphor. In trade negotiations, we must be clear about our goals and be willing to make concessions to achieve those goals. And I believe that President Lula and I do speak the same language when it comes to our commitment to free trade and global economic growth.

As for deadlines, I think having a deadline can be helpful, it can be a catalyst for action. And I did propose, and I think President Lula agrees, that we need to have a sense of urgency here. We can't let this opportunity slip away.

Now, I don't want to pre-judge the outcome of our meeting in Washington, but I do think that having our trade ministers meet to discuss the details of a possible Framework Agreement is an important step. And I'm optimistic that we can make progress, not just in Washington but also here in Brazil. We've got a lot of work to do, but I'm confident that we can get it done.

Thank you for having me today. (pauses for a moment)

First of all, I'm optimistic about the future of Africa. The continent is rich in natural resources, rich in talent, and has a deep desire for freedom and opportunity. But as you said, there are challenges that must be overcome. To address these challenges, Africa needs leaders who are committed to fighting corruption, who are committed to rule of law, and who are committed to economic freedom.

One of the things that I've seen in my presidency is that when countries make the decision to move towards democracy and to move towards economic freedom, the US stands with them. And we'll continue to do so. We'll continue to support countries that are making the tough decisions to fight corruption, to promote transparency, and to promote good governance.

In terms of what we can do to help, we've increased our aid to Africa over the past seven years. We've launched several initiatives to fight disease, such as the President's Emergency Plan for AIDS Relief, which has helped to save millions of lives across the continent. We've also launched initiatives to help stimulate economic growth, such as the African Growth and Opportunity Act.

Now, I'm excited to be visiting five nations in Africa, including Ghana, Liberia, Benin, Tanzania, and Egypt. I'm looking forward to meeting with the leaders of these countries, to learn from them, and to share our vision for a prosperous and peaceful Africa.

One of the main reasons I decided to visit Africa on the last leg of my term is because I believe that the US has a vital interest in the future of this continent. Africa is a continent of growing economic importance, of growing strategic importance, and of growing moral importance.

As I prepare to leave office, I want to make sure that we're laying the foundation for a long-term partnership between the US and Africa. And I'm confident that the next administration will continue to build on the progress that we've made.

But one thing I do hope to achieve through this trip is to raise awareness among the American people about the importance of Africa to our nation's interests, and about the opportunities that exist for us to work together to promote peace, prosperity, and freedom across the continent.

And finally, I want to say that I'm committed to ensuring that the work that we've started is continued and completed. I'm committed to working with the next administration to ensure a seamless transition, and to ensure that our commitment to Africa remains strong and remains a central part of our foreign policy.

Thank you for that question. Let me address the first part of your question. I do think it is appropriate for individuals who are under investigation, regardless of their position, to cooperate with the relevant authorities. Invoking the Fifth Amendment is certainly a right that is afforded to all citizens in this great country of ours, but as a leader, I expect more from corporate America. In these uncertain times, when investor confidence is crucial, it is imperative that executives demonstrate transparency and accountability.

Moving on to the second part of your question, regarding the Sarbanes proposal, I must say that our administration is committed to meaningful corporate governance reform. While we appreciate the Senator's efforts, we still have concerns about the independent board proposal as it stands. However, I am willing to be flexible and am committed to finding a solution that works. I have directed my staff to work closely with Congress to find common ground on this issue, and I remain open to the idea of an independent board with the right structure and mandate.

It's all about getting it right and ensuring that we have in place a regulatory framework that promotes transparency, accountability, and fairness in the corporate world. We want to create an environment that inspires investor confidence and helps to drive economic growth and job creation. So, while we may not be there yet, I'm hopeful that we can work together to find a solution that works for everybody.

Thank you for your question. I understand your skepticism, but I'd like to remind you that diplomacy is a complex and often painstaking process. While it's true that we've seen some concerning developments from North Korea, I believe we've made significant progress in laying the groundwork for future talks and building an international consensus on this issue.

First, we've worked closely with our allies and partners in the Six-Party Talks – China, Japan, Russia, and South Korea – to present a unified front in our message to the North Koreans. We've also engaged in bilateral talks with China, which has a significant influence over the North Korean regime.

Second, we've been actively working with the United Nations to strengthen the international non-proliferation regime, including passage of UN Security Council Resolution 1718 condemning North Korea's nuclear test. This resolution demonstrates the global community's commitment to preventing nuclear proliferation and places increased pressure on North Korea to change its behavior.

Third, we've taken steps to strengthen our bilateral relationships with Japan and South Korea, which are critical to regional security and stability. We've also increased our engagement with the North Korean defectors and refugees, listening to their stories and supporting their efforts to bring democratic change to their homeland.

Lastly, I'd like to remind you that we've also been making progress in interdiction and law-enforcement efforts, including working to disrupt illicit activities, and working to close all modalities by which the North Korean regime earns hard currency. That will pressure them in various ways.

Now, I know that some may view these achievements as incremental, but I believe they represent significant progress in advancing our long-term goals of denuclearization and regional stability. We remain committed to a diplomatic solution to this crisis, but we will also continue to consider all options – diplomacy, defense, and other – to protect American interests and security.

That's a great question. I appreciate you bringing up the issue of Russia's accession to the WTO. I'd like to clarify that the United States has indeed been a strong supporter of Russia's efforts to join the WTO. However, as you know, this process is a complex and multilateral one, involving many countries and multiple issues.

Regarding the current status of the negotiations, I'd like to say that we've made significant progress with Russia on many key issues, such as non-tariff barriers, services, and intellectual property rights. However, there are still some outstanding concerns that need to be addressed.

One of the main issues is Russia's domestic support for its agricultural sector. We've been working closely with the Russian government to ensure that their domestic support is in compliance with WTO rules, but we've not yet reached a mutually acceptable agreement.

Additionally, there are concerns regarding Russia's compliance with WTO rules on issues such as customs valuation and certification requirements. We're working with the Russian government to resolve these issues, and I'm hopeful that we can make progress in the coming months.

I want to emphasize that our goal is to support Russia's accession to the WTO, not to impede it. We believe that Russia's membership in the WTO will be beneficial to both the Russian economy and the global trading system as a whole.

I'd like to assure you that my Administration is committed to continuing the negotiations with Russia in good faith, and we're working to resolve the outstanding issues as soon as possible. But we also have to ensure that any agreement is in compliance with WTO rules and is in the best interests of the United States.

Well, first of all, I want to say that the United States and South Korea have a strong partnership, a strong alliance, and we're working closely together to address the challenges posed by North Korea. In my State of the Union address, I did label North Korea, along with Iraq and Iran, as part of an axis of evil. I did so because of their support for terror and their development of weapons of mass destruction.

Now, I know that President Kim and the South Korean people have a unique perspective on North Korea, and we respect that. The sunshine policy is an important initiative, and we support the goal of improved relations between North and South Korea. However, our approach and the South Korean approach are not mutually exclusive.

In fact, I believe that our tough stance on North Korea's bad behavior can actually complement the sunshine policy. By standing firm against North Korean provocations, we're creating an environment where North Korea is more likely to take the sunshine policy seriously.

Now, I've spoken with President Kim, and he's assured me that he shares my concerns about North Korea's actions. I think it's fair to say that we both believe that North Korea has more to do to demonstrate its sincerity.

Regarding their sincerity, I think it's fair to say that their actions speak louder than their words. While they have made some gestures towards reform and openness, they still have a long way to go to demonstrate that they're genuinely committed to change.

However, I do think that there are signs that North Korea is beginning to understand that isolation is not in their interests. They're facing tremendous economic challenges, and I think they're starting to realize that access to the international community, access to foreign investment, and access to economic assistance, are all conditioned on their behavior.

Now, I'm not naive about North Korea. I know that they've made promises before and failed to deliver. But I also know that it's in our interests, in the interests of South Korea, and in the interests of the international community, to continue to engage with North Korea, to continue to talk to them, and to continue to press them to make good on their commitments.

So, I'm optimistic that progress can be made, but I'm also realistic about the challenges we face. We'll continue to work closely with President Kim and the South Korean government to address these challenges, and we'll do so in a way that respects the unique relationship between North and South Korea.

Well, I appreciate you bringing this to my attention. I think there's been some misinformation floating around, and I'm happy to clarify our position. The United States has been supportive of Italy's participation in the P5+1 talks on Iran, and we continue to believe that Italy's involvement can be constructive in helping to address the Iranian nuclear issue.

That being said, our position, as Steve Hadley indicated, is that we're waiting to see how the dynamics of the P5+1 grouping develop, and how Italy's involvement plays out in those discussions. We're focused on finding a united approach that will effectively address Iran's nuclear ambitions, and we're working closely with all the parties to that end.

So, I'd say that our position is one of cautious optimism, and we're looking forward to seeing how the P5+1 talks unfold. I appreciate you bringing this to my attention, and I hope that clears up any confusion. Next question, please?

I think there might be some confusion, I'm President Bush, not President Blair. Prime Minister Blair and I have been in close consultation, and we're working closely together. We're working with a coalition of nations that understand the threat of Saddam Hussein and the importance of enforcing the United Nations resolutions.

Now, as for the military operation, we're assembling a coalition of like-minded nations who understand the threat and the importance of dealing with Saddam Hussein. I'm not going to get into specifics about which countries will be participating and which ones won't, but I can tell you that we've had a significant amount of cooperation, and we're working hard to assemble a coalition that will help bring peace and stability to the region.

Regarding the post-Iraq reconstruction, we are working closely with the United Nations. The Secretary-General Kofi Annan has been very cooperative, and we believe that the UN has a vital role to play in the reconstruction efforts in Iraq. We're committed to working through the United Nations to help the Iraqi people rebuild their lives and create a stable, democratic government.

As for Prime Minister Aznar's question, I think he should answer for Spain's participation in the military operation. Prime Minister Aznar?

I appreciate the question. Well, let me start by saying that the United States is very supportive of Brazil and Petrobras's efforts to develop their own energy resources and to participate in the global energy market. That's a good thing. We also believe that all countries, including Brazil, should be mindful of the potential risks associated with investing in Iran's energy sector.

You see, Iran is a country that has refused to comply with the international community's demands to suspend its nuclear program. This is a concern for all of us who believe in the Non-Proliferation Treaty. And it's a concern because a nuclear Iran would pose a significant threat to regional and global stability.

Now, the United States has made it clear that we strongly oppose investments in Iran's energy sector because we believe that such investments can help fund the Iranian regime's nuclear ambitions. We've got a problem with the current government in Iran. They're a destabilizing force in the region, and they're a threat to our friends and allies.

Now, I want to make it very clear that our desire for Petrobras to refrain from investing in Iran is not meant to limit Brazil's energy diplomacy or to undermine Petrobras's business. On the contrary, we believe that there are many other countries and opportunities around the world where Petrobras can invest and grow, while also contributing to the stability of the global energy market.

I hope that answers your question. And I appreciate the opportunity to discuss this issue further with President Lula and with all of you.

Well, I appreciate the opportunity to clarify our position on this issue. As you know, our policy towards both North Korea and Iran is focused on non-proliferation, particularly when it comes to nuclear arms. And we take the threat posed by both regimes very seriously.

In the case of North Korea, we've made it clear that their pursuit of nuclear weapons is unacceptable. And we're working through the six-party talks to encourage Kim Jong-il to abandon his nuclear ambitions and return to the negotiating table. We believe that a diplomatic solution is the best way forward, and we're working closely with our partners, including China, Japan, and Russia, to achieve that goal.

Regarding Iran, we also believe that their nuclear program is a threat to the stability of the region and to the global non-proliferation regime. We're working with the Europeans and the Russians to encourage Iran to comply with its international obligations and to abandon its nuclear enrichment activities. We've made it clear that all options are on the table, but our preferred course of action is a diplomatic one.

Now, I know that some of you may be thinking, "Well, what about regime change?" Let me be clear: our policy is not focused on regime change in either North Korea or Iran. Our focus is on changing the behavior of these regimes, not on changing the regimes themselves.

Having said that, we do believe that the people of both North Korea and Iran deserve to live in freedom and under governments that are accountable to them. And we'll continue to support those who are working towards that goal, including human rights activists and pro-democracy groups.

But let me be clear: we will not preemptively use military force to achieve regime change. Our military options are always on the table, but they will only be used as a last resort, and in the most extreme circumstances.

So, to answer your question, our policy is focused on non-proliferation, diplomatic engagement, and supporting those who are working towards democratic change.

That's a great question. I have discussed the issue of human rights with President Hu, and I've been very candid with him about our concerns. We've had some disagreements, of course, but I believe that dialogue is an important part of this relationship.

As for China's human rights record, I've said it before, and I'll say it again - we're troubled by the situation. We're troubled by the reports of harassment and detention of people who express dissent, who try to exercise their fundamental human rights. We've raised these concerns with the Chinese government, and we'll continue to do so.

Now, I also want to say that we recognize China's progress on economic reforms and the steps they've taken to improve the lives of their people. We welcome those efforts. But on human rights, we believe that more needs to be done. We believe that China should allow greater freedom of expression, association, and the right to a fair trial.

We'll continue to work with China to address these concerns, while at the same time, recognizing the importance of our relationship on issues like trade, security, and the battle against terrorism.

You know, I've always said that I'm a realist when it comes to foreign policy, but I'm also an optimist. I believe that by engaging China, by talking candidly with them, we can encourage them to move in a positive direction. That's what we're trying to do. And I firmly believe that one day, China will be a more open, more free, and more just society.

Thank you, appreciate the question. First of all, I want to assure the Muslim world, and I want to assure the Afghan people, that we take these allegations very seriously. The abuse of prisoners is abhorrent, and it doesn't represent the values of the United States of America. We are a nation that respects human rights, and we are a nation that is dedicated to the Geneva Conventions.

And so we're going to investigate these allegations fully. We'll find out what happened, and if there was wrongdoing, those responsible will be held to account. And I want to assure the Muslim world that we understand the seriousness of these allegations. We also understand the importance of respecting the Koran. We take our responsibilities in this regard very seriously.

It's also important for the world to understand that the actions of a few should not condemn an entire nation. It's also important for the world to understand that the United States is dedicated to liberty, and we're dedicated to freedom, and we're dedicated to treating people with respect and human dignity.

And I want to assure the Afghan people that we're committed to the security of their country. I met with President Karzai today, and I assured him of our continued commitment to help bring stability to Afghanistan.

Regarding Iraq, it's a tough fight, no question about it. The fact that there's 50 deaths today is a sober reminder of just how tough the fight is. But I believe that we're making progress. We're making progress in training Iraqi forces, and we're making progress in consolidating democratic reforms. It's difficult, but we'll stay the course. We'll work with the Iraqi government to defeat these terrorists and fatal minority that's trying to disrupt the democracy.

It's getting harder in some ways, but we'll prevail. We've got a great military, and we've got great allies, and we're committed to the cause of freedom and liberty. And I believe that as the Iraqis take more control of their own country, we'll start to see the intensity of the conflict decrease.

But make no mistake about it, it's tough. It's tough, and we're not going to leave until the job is done.

Thank you for your questions.  I'm not the Prime Minister, I'm the President of the United States, so let's get that straight. 

Now, I agree with General Abizaid's assessment that the major challenge facing Iraq is the sectarian violence and the division among different religious and ethnic groups. This is a critical issue that we're working to address, and we're working with the Iraqi government to help them build a more inclusive and representative government that can address these sectarian tensions.

In terms of a security plan, we're working with the Iraqi government to implement a comprehensive strategy that includes not only military action but also economic development, political reconciliation, and social programs to address the root causes of the violence. It's a complex and difficult challenge, but we're making progress and we're committed to supporting the Iraqi people as they work to build a more secure and stable country.

Regarding the situation in Lebanon, I want to emphasize that our goal is to support the Lebanese people and help them defend themselves against the terrorist organization Hezbollah. We're providing humanitarian aid to those who have been affected by the conflict, and we're also working with Israel to help them defend themselves against the attacks that have been launched by Hezbollah. 

-Israel has a right to defend itself, and part of that defense includes the use of modern and sophisticated military equipment, including, among other things, precision-guided munitions. 

Now, I know that this situation is complex and it's tense, and there are many different perspectives on it. But our goal is to stand up for peace, to stand up for the protection of innocent civilians, and to help those who are suffering. And we'll continue to work with all the parties in the region to try to find a peaceful and sustainable solution to this conflict.

Thank you for your question. I think it's very… it's a very valid question. And, you know, I remember when we made the decision to remove Saddam Hussein from power, one of the hopes was that it would lead to a more peaceful Middle East. Now, we understand that the situation in Iraq is the central front in the war on terror, and that the challenges we're facing are real.

Regarding Iraq, I do think that our policy has been and continues to be, to support the Iraqi government and to help them become a stable, self-sufficient, and democratic country. The Iraqi Prime Minister, Maliki, has stated that he agrees with our goal, and we're working closely together to help him strengthen the government.

Now, as for Arab governments criticizing Israel, I think that's an understandable, you know, commentary. I've always said that our allies, Arab countries, have got to be able to criticize Israel, without fear of being criticized themselves. It's just part of the ongoing conversation, John.

However, concerning Iran and Syria's support for Hezbollah, we have been very clear and consistent in our warnings to both countries to cease their support. We're not going to tolerate this sort of violent destabilizing behavior in the region, particularly not in Lebanon.

The idea that my words aren't being listened to is just not right, however. Our allies are listening, our friends are listening, and I believe the American people are united in the face of this terror threat.

I think history has proven that we, as America, are not short-term thinkers, and I would say that your perception and your analysis might not be shared by others, and I'm not saying that you're wrong either, but it's more complex. The Middle East is a place that's given to pronounced shading and gray.

Thank you for that question.  As the leader of the free world, the United States will always stand by its allies and stand up to those who challenge freedom and democracy.

Now, I have had very constructive conversations with President Calderón of Mexico, and I have found a strong partner in him. We did discuss ways to work together to strengthen the democracies in our hemisphere, and he has committed to standing strong against authoritarianism and against extremism. Now, Mexico and the United States, we share a long border, we share a deep friendship, and we share a desire to spread democracy throughout the world.

Regarding our relationship with Venezuela, we are committed to working with all countries in our hemisphere that share our values of freedom and democracy, and believe in the rule of law and human rights. That doesn't mean we won't talk to those who don't necessarily share our values, though. As a matter of fact, we believe it's essential to engage with those countries, including Venezuela, to see if there's a desire to improve relations.

My friend, I have directed our Secretary of State, Condoleezza Rice, to keep the dialogue open with Venezuela, with all countries that wish to work with us to strengthen our democratic institutions, our economies, and our regional security. But make no mistake about it: if a country's intent is to undermine the values that we share, the United States, and Mexico, and other like-minded countries will speak out against it and work vigorously to strengthen our partnerships around the world.

It's always a balance, you see, between encouraging dialogue and standing firm for the values we hold dear. And we believe that after our discussions here, with countries like Mexico, we can achieve that balance.

Thank you for your question. I did have a productive meeting with King Abdullah earlier today, and one of the topics we did discuss was the issue of prisoners. As you know, the United States has been a strong supporter of the Israeli-Palestinian peace process, and we've been actively engaged in efforts to move that process forward.

Now, regarding the issue of prisoners, I'd say we're making progress, but it's a complex and difficult issue, and it's one that's going to take some time to resolve. King Abdullah and I both understand the importance of addressing the concerns of the Palestinian people, as well as the concerns of the Israeli people. We recognize that this is a sensitive issue, and one that's deeply rooted in history.

What I will say is that we're committed to working with both the Israelis and the Palestinians to find a way forward on this issue. And I believe that our discussions today were productive in terms of advancing our understanding of the challenges that lie ahead.

So, to answer your question, I'd say that we're making progress, but we've still got a lot of work to do. We're going to keep on working, and we're going to keep on pushing, and we're going to keep on striving to find a solution to this issue that is just and fair for all parties involved. Thank you.

Well, thank you for the question. I don't think we're losing the debate on free trade. I'm proud of the progress we've made on expanding trade agreements around the world, and NAFTA is a big part of that.

Now, I understand that there are some folks who are skeptical about trade, and that's okay. We should have a debate, we should have a discussion. But I think the facts are on our side. I mean, since NAFTA was signed, our exports to Mexico and Canada have more than tripled, and it's created a lot of jobs here in the United States.

I'm not worried about the Democratic candidates' rhetoric, to be frank. I think that when it comes down to it, most Americans understand that trade is good for the economy, it's good for jobs, and it's good for opportunity. And we're gonna keep making that case, we're gonna keep pushing for more free trade agreements.

Now, I will say this: if people are worried about the impact of trade on certain communities, I understand that. And we've got programs in place to help those folks who have been impacted by trade. But to scrap NAFTA or to renegotiate it in a way that would harm the economy, I think would be a mistake. We've got a good agreement, it's working well, and we ought to build on it, not tear it down.

Thank you for your question. I appreciate your interest in the Middle East peace process. Now, I must correct you - it's "Mr. President", not "Your Majesty" (laughs). 

As for your question, I believe the roadmap does provide a framework for the Quartet – which includes the United States, the European Union, Russia, and the United Nations – to monitor the progress and to report on the implementation of the obligations. However, I also believe that this process must be owned by the parties themselves. It's the Israelis and the Palestinians who must take the lead in this process. The international community, and the Quartet in particular, can play a supporting role.

As for stricter monitoring mechanisms, I think it's a good idea. We are open to exploring ways in which we can work with the international community to ensure that both parties are fulfilling their obligations. We've got a lot of work ahead of us to make sure this happens, and we'll continue to work with the Quartet to come up with a mechanism that will make sure that both parties are held accountable.

But let me make one thing very clear: we will not impose our will on either the Israelis or the Palestinians. We will work with them in a constructive way, but at the end of the day, it's the parties themselves who must make the tough decisions to achieve peace.

First of all, I appreciate the chance to talk about this very serious issue. I'm deeply troubled by the news out of Guatemala, particularly the murder of those three Salvadoran Congress Members. Our condolences go out to the families and the people of El Salvador.

Now, regarding our strategy, we do indeed believe that this problem requires a regional approach. We can't just focus on one country; we need to work with all the countries in Central America to tackle this threat. That's why we're committed to working closely with the governments in the region, including Guatemala.

Now, the U.S. has a long-standing commitment to helping countries in the region combat narco-trafficking and organized crime. We've got a number of programs in place, including the Central America Regional Security Initiative, which provides funding and assistance to help these countries build their capacity to fight this threat.

Regarding the issue of a "mini-Colombia Plan," I think what we're looking at is a comprehensive approach that involves not just military assistance, but also economic assistance, law enforcement assistance, and judiary reform. We need to make sure that we're addressing the root causes of this problem, which is poverty and lack of opportunity, as well as the institutional weaknesses that allow these traffickers to operate.

In terms of U.S. cooperation, we're committed to working closely with the government of Guatemala and other governments in the region to provide the necessary assistance to help them tackle this problem. That includes providing training and equipment to their law enforcement and military forces, as well as providing intelligence and logistical support.

We're also working closely with the government of Guatemala to address the issue of corruption, which is a major obstacle to progress in this area. We need to make sure that we're supporting the institutions that are going to help Guatemala and other countries in the region to build a more just and equitable society.

Regarding the investigation into the murder of the Salvadoran Congress Members, we're cooperating fully with the government of El Salvador and the government of Guatemala to get to the bottom of this heinous crime. We'll provide any assistance we can to help bring those responsible to justice.

So, I hope that gives you a sense of our commitment to this issue and our willingness to work with the governments in the region to tackle this problem.

Thank you for the question. Regarding Cuba, our policy is clear: we will continue to support the Cuban people in their quest for freedom, while maintaining pressure on the Castro regime to reform. The embargo remains an important tool in our efforts to bring about democratic change and respect for human rights on the island.

Now, I know that some of our European allies have differing views on this matter, and we respect those differences. But we also believe that our embargo is a necessary component of our overall strategy to promote freedom in Cuba. We will continue to work with our allies to seek a world where the Cuban people are free to determine their own fate.

Regarding Plan Colombia, we are committed to continuing our support for President Uribe and the Colombian government as they work to bring stability and security to their country. We believe that our partnership with Colombia is critical to the region's stability and to our own national security interests.

We will continue to work with our friends in Colombia to help them address the challenges posed by narcoterrorism and to support their efforts to promote economic development and reform. I've had the chance to talk to President Uribe a number of times, and I'm impressed by his courage and commitment to bringing peace and prosperity to his country.

So, in short, we will continue to pursue our policies in these areas, even as we work to build stronger relationships with our friends and allies in the region.

(pausing for a moment) Well, I appreciate the question. As I've said before, I believe that marriage is a sacred institution between a man and a woman, and I oppose same-sex marriage. I understand that there are people who disagree with me on this issue, and I respect their opinions.

However, I still firmly believe that society's interest is best served by upholding the traditional definition of marriage. I know that this issue is complex and emotional, and it's one that affects many people in a very personal way.

Regarding the children, I believe that every child deserves a loving and stable home, regardless of the circumstances of their birth or the relationship status of their parents. I think it's essential to support all families, including those with same-sex couples, but I also believe that children are best raised in a home with a married mother and father.

That being said, I understand the significance of the situation in San Francisco and the images that came from that. But I don't believe that the actions of Mayor Newsom changed the fundamental nature of this issue. As a matter of fact, I believe that the traditional definition of marriage has been an essential part of our society for centuries, and it's worth preserving.

(firmly but calmly) I want to be clear: as President, I will continue to promote policies that support traditional marriage and the well-being of all families, including those with same-sex couples, but I will also defend the traditional institution of marriage.

Thank you, I'll do my best to answer your questions. First of all, we're concerned about the situation with the British sailors and marines being held by the Iranians. We're working closely with our British allies to see a peaceful resolution to this crisis. As for the British considering a military option, that's for them to decide, but I think it's clear that they're exploring all avenues to resolve this situation.

Regarding whether the U.S. would consider a similar action an act of war, I think it's safe to say that we would take any situation involving the taking of our service members very seriously. We'll always reserve the right to defend ourselves and our people, and we'll do whatever is necessary to protect American lives and interests.

Now, regarding the five Iranians who were captured in Irbil, we've made it clear that we're willing to consider the release of those individuals if it would help resolve the crisis and if it would help to reduce tensions. However, any decision on this front would have to be made in consultation with our coalition partners and in a way that's consistent with our long-term goals in the region.

I want to emphasize that our goal is to resolve this crisis peacefully, and we'll continue to work with all parties to achieve that objective.

Thank you for the question. I think it's a fair one. As I reflect on the past year, I believe it's safe to say that the Democratic leadership in Congress had high ambitions, but they have not been able to deliver on some of their key promises, particularly when it comes to the war in Iraq.

By passing the war funding without strings, Congress has shown that, despite our disagreements, we can work together to fund our troops and support their mission. I believe this is a testament to the commitment of members of Congress from both parties to do what's right, even if we disagree.

Now, as for whether I've gotten my way, I'd say that I've worked hard to build coalitions and find common ground, while also being clear about my non-negotiables – like keeping our troops well-funded and keeping America safe. I think that's good governing.

Regarding my relations with the leaders of Congress, I think it's no surprise that we've had our disagreements – after all, we're from different parties and have fundamentally different views on some important issues. But I believe we've been able to work together, albeit not always smoothly, to get some important things done.

I will say that the Democrats set the bar high for themselves last year, and the public has expectations that they'll be able to deliver on those promises. And while they've certainly passed some legislation, there's still a lot of work to be done on the bigger issues, like immigration reform and Social Security reform.

In the end, I think it's healthy for our democracy to have a robust debate and a give-and-take between the branches of government. As President, my job is to lead and advocate for what I believe is in the best interests of the country. If that sometimes means using my veto pen to make a point or block something I think is a bad idea, so be it.

Thank you for your question. I had a very good discussion with the Pope on the issue of stem cell research, and I must say that his perspective was enlightening. As you mentioned, the Pope's concerns were primarily with the creation of embryonic stem cells for research purposes. I understand and respect that view.

However, our conversation did touch on the existing stem cells that are available for research. I explained to the Pope that these cells are typically embryonic stem cells that were created prior to my taking office, and that they are currently being used by researchers across the country.

As for options and compromises, I'm considering a number of proposals that have been put forth by lawmakers, scientists, and ethicists. Some of these options include allowing research on existing stem cell lines, while others propose creating a limited number of new stem cell lines using embryonic cells that would otherwise be discarded. There are also proposals that suggest alternative methods for deriving stem cells, such as using adult stem cells or somatic cell nuclear transfer.

It's a complex issue, and I'm taking my time to consider all the different perspectives and opinions. I want to make sure that any decision I make is grounded in both moral and scientific principles. I'm committed to advancing the hope of medical breakthroughs that stem cell research holds, while also upholding the values that are at the core of our society.

That's all I can say for now. I appreciate your understanding, and I look forward to continuing this important discussion.

Thank you for your question. Let me first address the issue of the Antiballistic Missile Treaty. As you know, the events of September 11th have changed the landscape in many ways, and our priorities have shifted to address the threat of terrorism. However, our commitment to defending our nation and our allies remains unwavering. We have been engaged in discussions with Russia to better understand their perspective on theabilmek Ballistic Missile Treaty, but I will not rule out any option that is in the best interest of our national security. We will continue to pursue diplomatic efforts to find a resolution that meets our concerns, but we will not be limited by a treaty that was written for a different era.

Regarding the Muslim world and the Arab world, I am pleased with the support we have received, and I believe it's essential to acknowledge that many leaders have spoken out against terrorism. While there could have been more vocal statements, we have seen a broad coalition of nations condemn the acts of terror. It's also important to recognize that we're not at war with Islam, but against the terrorists who claim to act in its name. We're working closely with our friends and allies in the region to combat terrorism, promote understanding, and address the root causes of this problem.

I'm heartened by the cooperation we've received from leaders in the region, such as Pakistan's President Musharraf and Jordan's King Abdullah, who have been instrumental in our fight against terrorism. We will continue to work together to ensure that this is a broad-based effort to deal with a shared threat, and that we stand together to defend innocent lives and the values of freedom, justice, and peace.

Thank you for the question. I understand the concern about the use of the word "executed". I was referring to the fact that the British servicemen did not surrender. Instead, brave as they were, they fought to the end, and in doing so, they were killed in the battle. And that's what I meant by executed.

Now, regarding your main question, I want to address the issue of international support for our efforts in Iraq. I agree that it's true that some of our traditional allies, like France and Germany, have not supported our position on this war. However, I also want to remind you that we have a strong coalition, including many countries from around the world, who have stood with us in this fight for freedom and democracy.

Now, I understand the reservations that some of our friends may have had. But let me be clear: the United States of America did not make this decision to act in a vacuum. We did it because we were attacked on September 11th. Nearly 3,000 innocent lives were lost. And we will not forget the fact that Saddam Hussein, a brutal dictator, was a threat to the stability of the region and to our national security.

I've talked to our allies, and many of them share our concerns about the threat posed by Saddam Hussein and the rogue states who harbor and support terrorists. And I believe that over time, as more and more countries see the progress we're making in Iraq, they will come to understand that our efforts are aimed at a just cause, spreading freedom and peace in a region that's been troubled for too long.

I also want to remind you that just because we didn't have a unanimous vote at the United Nations does not mean that we don't have the support of many nations around the world who share our values and our goals. And I'm willing to continue working with our friends and allies to build a strong and united front against the forces of terror and tyranny.

Thank you.

Thank you for the question. I appreciate it. You're right, we did have a briefing by the generals, and I'm proud of the progress we're making in Iraq. Now, I want to clarify the difference between what I said and what the generals said.

When I mentioned those numbers, I was referring to the fact that there are Iraqi battalions that are being trained, that are in the process of being trained, and some that are deployed. Now, when the generals went up to the Hill, they were asked a specific question about, "How many are capable of, or fully deployed and battle ready?"

Now, I think it's fair to say that there's a difference between those two questions. We're making progress, but I also acknowledge that the situation on the ground is challenging, and we've got to continue to work with the Iraqis to build their capacity.

The fact is, we are making progress. The Iraqis are taking on more responsibility. We are reducing the number of our troops. And we've got a strategy that's working. But I also acknowledge that we still have got more work to be done.

Now, I know that some Senators have raised questions, and I respect that. But I think it's also important to take a step back and recognize the progress we're making, and the fact that we're on the right course. We've got to keep our focus on the enemy, on al-Qaeda and on the extremist groups that are trying to stop the Iraqi people from determining their own future.

So, I understand there's a difference, and I think I might have misspoken, might have spoken too quickly on that occasion. But the fact is, we are making progress, and we need to keep our focus on the overall strategy and supporting the Iraqi people in their fight for freedom and democracy.

I appreciate the question, and I'm glad you're interested in the situation in Iraq. First of all, let me remind you that the war on terror is a global fight, and it's a fight for our way of life. And I understand the concerns of our allies, like Australia, and the good people of Sydney, who are, you know, feeling the pressures of this global conflict.

Regarding Iraq, I firmly believe that we're making progress towards reconciliation. The Iraqi people are taking control of their country, and the Iraqi Security Forces are becoming increasingly capable of defending themselves against the insurgents.

Now, as for the opposition leader's view on staged withdrawal, I respectfully disagree. You see, we cannot give the enemy a timetable for our departure. That would be a recipe for disaster. It would embolden the enemy, and it would undermine the very progress we're making.

When I meet with the opposition leader tomorrow, I'll remind him that our strategy in Iraq is conditions-based, not calendar-driven. We will continue to review the situation on the ground, and we will make adjustments as necessary. But we will not let the terrorists dictate our schedule.

I'll also remind him that we're making progress on the political front, with the Iraqi elections, the formation of a government, and the drafting of a constitution. We're making progress on the economic front, with the international community supporting Iraq's reconstruction efforts.

We will not abandon the Iraqi people to the mercy of the terrorists. We will continue to support them in their quest for freedom and democracy, and we will do so in a way that's responsible and conditions-based.

Well, I appreciate the question. I think it's fair to say that the economy is going through a tough time, and we're working hard to get it back on track. Now, I believe that the tax cuts we've implemented have been the right thing to do. They've put more money in people's pockets, and it's helped stimulate economic growth.

Now, I know that the unemployment rate has risen, and that's a concern. But I think it's also important to look at the long-term picture here. We've created over 7 million new jobs since I took office, and I think that's a testament to the robustness of the American economy.

Now, I will admit that the deficit is a concern. We're going to have to work hard to make sure that we're living within our means and making smart fiscal decisions. But I don't think the answer is to raise taxes. I think that would be a mistake. Raising taxes would stifle economic growth and hinder our ability to recover from this recession.

In terms of evidence that the tax cuts are working, I'd point to the fact that revenue is coming in higher than expected, even in these tough economic times. That's a sign that the economy is still growing, and that the tax cuts are helping to stimulate that growth.

Now, I'm open to new ideas and new approaches. I'm always willing to listen to different perspectives and consider different solutions. But I'm confident that our economic policies are on the right track, and I think we're going to see continued growth and progress in the months and years ahead.

One thing I do want to mention is that we've got a global economy that's affecting our economy here at home. The slowdown in Europe, the slowdown in Asia, that's having an impact on America. But I'm confident in the resilience of the American economy, and I'm confident in the American people's ability to overcome any challenge that comes our way.

Thank you for the question.

I think it's interesting that you bring up the oil-for-food scandal, because that's a perfect example of why we've had concerns about the effectiveness and the accountability of the United Nations. Now, I do believe that the United Nations has a vital role to play in the world, and we've worked closely with them in many areas, particularly in areas of humanitarian aid and development.

But when it comes to the question of legitimacy and moral authority, I think it's interesting that you bring up the fact that the United Nations has its own set of challenges. And I think that's a fair point. I think that the United States and the United Nations are both held to high standards, and we should be. We should be held to high standards when it comes to our actions, our decisions, and our accountability.

But I think the key difference is that in a democratic society like ours, we have the checks and balances, we have the system of accountability and oversight that allows us to hold our elected officials and government agencies accountable for their actions. And I think that's what sets us apart from some of the challenges that the United Nations faces.

Now, I think it's also important to remember that we didn't act alone in Iraq. We had a coalition of 30 nations that worked with us to bring about a new era of freedom and democracy to the Iraqi people. And I think that's a testament to the fact that we're not alone in this effort, and that there are many other nations that share our values and our commitment to freedom and democracy.

So, while I think the United Nations has a role to play, I also think that the United States has a unique set of strengths and abilities that allow us to lead the world in many areas, particularly in areas of freedom and democracy. Thank you.

Well, thank you for your question. First, let me just say that John Negroponte is an exceptional individual. I've known him for a long time, and I have great respect for him. He's a highly capable individual who understands the importance of the intelligence-gathering process.

Regarding the budget, I'm confident that the Director of National Intelligence will have the authority he needs to oversee the budget and to make recommendations to me and to the Congress. Now, I know that there are different agencies within the government that have varied perspectives on intelligence gathering. And the Department of Defense is one of those agencies. But I'm confident that Secretary Rumsfeld and Don Rumsfeld's team will work closely with Director Negroponte to ensure that we're using our intelligence assets in the most effective way possible.

As for Mr. Negroponte's workspace, he will be located in the Office of the Director of National Intelligence, which will be established in a new facility. He will have a close working relationship with me and my national security team. He'll be able to come to the Oval Office anytime he needs to, and he'll be able to provide me with the intelligence I need to make informed decisions.

Regarding the daily briefings, I receive my intelligence briefings from the CIA Director, Porter Goss, but I also look forward to having Director Negroponte keeping me informed on a regular basis about the overall intelligence picture.

Well, thank you for the question. Let me make it clear: our goal is to ensure that Hizballah is not a destabilizing force in the region, that it does not continue to pose a threat to the State of Israel, and that it does not undo the great progress that the Lebanese people have made in building a free and democratic society.

As for the disarmament of Hizballah, I believe that's a goal, and it's a goal of the United Nations resolution, and it's a goal of the international community. But I also recognize that this is going to be a difficult task, and it's going to require a lot of diplomacy, and a lot of work on the part of the Lebanese government, the international community, and the peacekeeping forces.

Now, I'm not going to prejudge how this is going to be done, or when.
