Now, let me just add one thing, I also believe it's very important that the Commission understands that there's certain information that we just can't give 'em. I know there's a lot of curiosity about some parts of our national security, but we cannot give out the kind of sensitive information that could compromise our national security. I'm willing to make sure that we cooperate, but we also have to protect ourselves at the same time.

The situation with Syria and Iran remains a significant concern for us. Their meddling in Iraq's internal affairs is unacceptable, and it's a major hurdle in achieving stability and security in the region. One of the key issues is the flow of foreign fighters, many of whom are coming from Syria, across the border into Iraq. They're targeting our troops, Iraqi forces, and innocent civilians, and it's undermining our efforts to bring order to the country.

Regarding the interference in the political process, we're seeing evidence that both Syria and Iran are trying to influence the upcoming Iraqi elections. This could potentially undermine the democratic process and affect the legitimacy of the new Iraqi government. We're working closely with our allies and the Iraqi government to prevent such interference and ensure the election process is free and fair.

Now, regarding consequences, let me be clear: we take these concerns very seriously, and we're considering a range of options to address these issues. While I won't go into specifics, rest assured that we're working to hold both Syria and Iran accountable for their actions. We'll continue to work with our international partners to increase pressure on these countries to cease their destabilizing activities.

We're also working with the Iraqi government to strengthen their capabilities to secure their borders and prevent foreign interference. We're committed to supporting the Iraqi people as they build a more stable and secure future for themselves, and we'll take action to protect our troops and interests in the region.

Make no mistake, we will not tolerate foreign interference in Iraq's internal affairs, and we will take the necessary steps to address this issue.

Thank you for your question. I understand that there are a lot of opinions out there about our efforts in Iraq. Senator Kennedy's characterization of Iraq as a "quagmire" is, in my view, a mischaracterization of the situation. I believe we've made tremendous progress in Iraq, and I'm proud of the work our men and women in uniform are doing. They're doing a magnificent job under very difficult circumstances.

We've removed a brutal dictator, Saddam Hussein, from power, and we've begun the process of helping the Iraqi people to build a free, prosperous, and peaceful society. It's a tough road ahead, no question about it. But I have every confidence in the American people and the Iraqi people that we can succeed.

I must say, I'm disappointed by some of the rhetoric coming out of Washington. I think it's not helpful to our troops, and it's not helpful to the Iraqi people. The message that gets sent with this kind of language, I believe, is a message of "Don't worry about the American people being there to help you." And that's just not true. We've made a commitment to help Iraq become a stable, free country. And we're going to follow through on that commitment.

As for the effect on our troops' morale, I think they're pretty much focusing on the mission at hand, and that's to complete the job they've been asked to do. And I think they're proud of what they're doing. I've seen it in their eyes when I visited with them in Iraq. I've seen it in the letters they write, the emails they send, and the phone calls they make.

Now, I do think we've got to watch the tone in Washington. We've got to be mindful of the language that we use. I think it's a reflection on all of our leadership, and I think it's a reflection on our nation. We can disagree without undermining the morale of our troops or the confidence of the Iraqi people. And I'm looking for a more constructive debate about the way forward in Iraq.

(becoming slightly defensive) Well, I strongly disagree with the Amnesty International report. The United States is a country that upholds the rule of law and respects human rights. The notion that we're running some kind of gulag is absurd. We have a system in place for detaining and interrogating enemy combatants that's designed to protect American citizens and allies from terrorist attacks.

We're at war with an enemy that doesn't wear uniforms, that hides in caves, and uses civilians as shields. We're dealing with an enemy that has no respect for human life, and we have a responsibility to keep America safe.

I'm not concerned about what critics say, I'm concerned about keeping America safe. And I can tell you, we're doing that. We're working with allies, we're working with international organizations to make sure that detainees are treated humanely, but also to make sure that we're able to gather intelligence to protect our country.

(to leaning forward)
And let me remind you, we're not just dealing with these issues in a vacuum. We're dealing with them in the context of a global war on terror. And I'm proud of the work that we're doing to disrupt and defeat al-Qaeda, to deal with the Taliban, and to bring stability to places like Afghanistan and Iraq.

If we're seen as the bad guy, that's unfortunate. But if we're also seen as a country that's willing to take risks to protect its citizens, then that's a badge of honor. We're not going to let terrorist threats dictate our actions, but we're going to work with our allies to make sure that the values of human rights and dignity are upheld.

Now, I know there are differences of opinion, but let me tell you, we're on the right track. We're making progress, and we're going to continue to work with our allies to defeat the terrorist threat.

I appreciate Prime Minister Maliki's statement on this issue. We do have information that suggests Hizballah has provided training to some of the groups, including the Mahdi Army led by Muqtada al-Sadr. Now, we can't pinpoint with absolute certainty the extent of this training, but we do have reason to believe that there has been some level of interaction.

It's worth noting that our main concern here is not just the presence of foreign actors or foreign influence in Iraq, but also the actions of these groups. When we talk about Hizballah training extremist groups, we're talking about groups that have carried out attacks on innocent civilians and coalition forces. That's unacceptable, and we will continue to work closely with our Iraqi partners to root out these extremist groups and stabilize the country.

Let me be clear: we respect Iraq's sovereignty, and we agree that no outside party should interfere in the internal affairs of Iraq. But at the same time, we also have a responsibility to support our allies and protect our own national security interests. We'll work closely with the Iraqi government to address this issue and promote a peaceful, stable future for the Iraqi people. Next question, please.

I appreciate the question, thank you for askin'. Now, regarding Latin America, I disagree with the notion that we've turned our back on the region. We've been actively engaged, through various initiatives such as the Millennium Challenge Account, the Central American Free Trade Agreement, and our support for the democratic processes in countries like Mexico and Brazil.

Now, there is always more we can do, and I acknowledge that we can improve our engagement with Latin America. In my remaining two years, I plan to focus on promoting free trade, increasing economic opportunities, and supporting democratic institutions in the region.

Regarding the issue of subsidies, I must say that I'm a strong supporter of American farmers and the agriculture sector. However, I also recognize that trade agreements require give-and-take. I've instructed my trade representatives to be open to finding common ground on this issue.

President Lula and I did discuss this matter, and while there's no easy solution, we did agree that our trade ministers would continue to work together to find mutually beneficial solutions. I'm not prepared to make any specific commitments on reducing domestic subsidies, but I'm willing to listen to alternative proposals that could benefit both our countries.

It's worth noting that we've already taken steps to reform our farm policies, including the 2002 Farm Bill, which introduced significant changes to our agricultural subsidy programs. We're committed to continue this reform process, but any changes must be done in a way that ensures a level playing field for American farmers.

Thank you for that thoughtful question. I appreciate the historical context you provided. As I've said before, the United States is committed to a stable and secure South Asia, and that means addressing the concerns of all countries in the region, including Pakistan.

First, let me say that we believe that a strong and stable Pakistan is in the interests of the entire region, and we're committed to helping Pakistan achieve that goal. We recognize that Pakistan has legitimate security concerns, including concerns about its territorial integrity, and we're willing to work with Pakistan to address those concerns.

In terms of conventional weapons, you're right that Pakistan has concerns about its ability to match India's military capabilities. But I want to emphasize that the United States is committed to helping Pakistan strengthen its conventional defense capabilities, so it can feel more secure and less reliant on nuclear deterrence.

Now, our focus is on encouraging both India and Pakistan to engage in a constructive and peaceful dialogue to resolve their differences, including on Kashmir. We believe that a peaceful resolution to this conflict is the best way to address the underlying security concerns of both countries.

And let me be clear: we're not asking Pakistan to give up its nuclear program unilaterally. We're urging both India and Pakistan to work together with the international community to reduce the risks associated with their nuclear programs, and to move towards a more stable and secure region.

So, in short, we're committed to working with Pakistan to address its security concerns, and we believe that a stable and secure Pakistan is essential to the stability of the entire region.

The situation with the Iraqi government is a complex one, and as Commander-in-Chief, I want to assure the American people that I'm deeply concerned about the lack of progress. I've made my frustrations clear to Prime Minister Maliki, and I believe it's essential for the Iraqi government to step up and take ownership of the process.

Now, I understand that patience is a virtue, but I also believe that we can't wait indefinitely for the Iraqi government to make the necessary decisions. We've seen some progress, but it's not happening at the pace we'd like to see.

As for how long we'll wait, I'm not setting a specific timeline, but I will say that I'm deeply concerned about the stalemate in Baghdad. I've made it clear to the Iraqi government that we need to see more progress on reconciliation, on the oil law, on de-Baathification, and on other key issues.

We're working closely with the Iraqi government to help them build their capacity, but at the end of the day, they've got to make the tough decisions. And if we don't see some progress soon, we'll have to re-evaluate our strategy and consider other options.

But let me be clear: we are committed to success in Iraq. We've made a commitment to the American people, to the Iraqi people, and to the troops who are fighting for freedom and democracy. We will not abandon the Iraqi people to the forces of extremism and terrorism.

So, we'll continue to press the Iraqi government to make progress, but we'll also take the necessary steps to ensure that our troops have the resources they need to succeed, and that we're doing everything we can to support the Iraqi people as they build a more stable and secure future.

We're going to take a thoughtful and common-sense approach to addressing the gas tax holiday issue. While I understand the concerns of the American people about gas prices, I've consistently said that we must prioritize fiscal responsibility and long-term solutions to our energy challenges. Our administration is working closely with Congress to explore all options, but we will not support a proposal that might undermine the funding for our nation's vital infrastructure projects.

That being said, I do appreciate the willingness of some lawmakers to consider a gas tax holiday. If Congress can come up with a plan that truly offsets the lost revenue and ensures we continue to invest in our roads and bridges, then I'd be willing to consider it. But I will not support a plan that mortgages our nation's infrastructure needs for the sake of short-term politics.

I appreciate the work of Republican lawmakers who are engaged in this debate, and I encourage them to keep working with us to come up with solutions that will bring relief to the American people while maintaining our commitment to responsible governance.

Good afternoon. I'm glad you asked that question. First, let me say that I'm a strong believer in the transatlantic relationship, and I believe it's in the interests of the American people for us to work closely with our friends in Europe. We've had some discussions today about deepening our cooperation in areas such as counter-terrorism, proliferating technologies, the Middle East peace process, and the Balkans.

There are areas where we agree, and there are areas where we don't agree. And I think it's healthy that we don't agree on everything. The Europeans have some concerns about our missile defense systems, and I understand that. But I've made it clear to our friends that our intentions are good, and we're not trying to create a defense system that would be a threat to Europe.

Now, on the Kyoto protocol, I want to say that we share the concern about global warming. We want to find a way to reduce greenhouse gas emissions. The Kyoto protocol, in my judgment, is a flawed document that won't accomplish what we want to accomplish. That being said, I have instructed our negotiators to be open to new ideas and to research. And if there's a way to modify the Kyoto protocol in a way that makes sense for us, we'll take a look at it.

But let me make it clear: we're not going to ratify a treaty that will damage our economy or hinder our economic growth. We must be good stewards of the environment, but we also must be good stewards of our economy.

Well, thank you, I'm glad you brought this up. I am concerned about the price of oil and its potential impact on the American economy. No question, it's a tough issue. And I think the American people are feeling the pinch, and rightly so.

First of all, let me just say that our foreign policy is designed to encourage oil production around the world. I've worked with the OPEC nations to try to get them to increase their production, and some of them have done so. But I think it's also important to note that we've had some disruptions in the world oil market that have affected the price.

In terms of refining capacity, that's a issue we're working on. The EPA's regulation on MTBE is going to be relaxed, so that we can, in fact, produce more gasoline. And today, I announced that we're going to streamline the regulatory process for the construction of new refineries.

Now, I know that might not sound like much, but it's a step in the right direction. And I'm a believer that if we can get a new refinery built, it'll show the market that we're serious about increasing capacity. So we're also going to work with Congress to pass an energy bill that will, among other things, provide incentives for new refinery construction.

Now, it's a tough issue, and it's not something you can just snap your fingers and wish it away. But I'm committed to working on it. And I'm optimistic that we can get the price down, or at least stabilize it. The American people deserve no less.

Thank you for your question. I appreciate the concern that many in Europe have expressed about the United States' commitment to human rights. Let me be clear: the United States is committed to upholding the rule of law and respecting human rights, even in the face of the threat of terrorism. Our government is duty-bound to protect the American people, but we also recognize that we must do so in a manner that is consistent with our values and our laws.

Regarding the individuals being held in CIA custody, I can assure you that we are committed to ensuring that they are treated humanely and in accordance with U.S. law and international obligations. We are working to establish a system of review and processing for these detainees, to determine whether they are in fact enemy combatants and what should be their ultimate disposition.

As for the prospect of these individuals seeing a judge, we are exploring a range of options, including the possible use of military tribunals or other forms of judicial process. We are committed to providing due process for these individuals, while also ensuring that we take into account the needs of national security and the protection of intelligence sources and methods.

Make no mistake, the United States is not interested in holding onto these individuals indefinitely. We will continue to work to resolve their status in accordance with our laws and our values, and we will do so in a manner that is consistent with our commitments to human rights and the rule of law.

I want to assure our European friends and allies that we are not seeking to abandon the rule of law or to treat these individuals as if they were beyond the reach of judicial process. We are working hard to balance our obligations to protect the American people with our commitment to upholding the principles of justice and human rights that are at the heart of our democracy.

Well, thank you for the question. I'd first like to say that our trip to Latin America has been a tremendous success, and I'm grateful to be standing here today with my good friend President Lula da Silva. We've had productive discussions, and our agreement on biofuels is a great step forward for both our countries.

Now, regarding the other fellow you mentioned, I think it's clear that there's a divide in this hemisphere between those who want to have a positive, constructive relationship with the United States and those who are promoting a different kind of approach. And let me tell you, the American people are not interested in a situation where there's a self-appointed leader in the region who is trying to undermine the good work that we're doing.

I think that our approach, based on trade, based on democracy, based on human rights, based on values that are not only American values, but universal values, stands in stark contrast to the kind of approach that we see being promoted by that other fellow. I believe that, over time, the people of this hemisphere will determine that the kind of approach that we're promoting is the right approach for the future.

Regarding ethanol, we had a very productive discussion on this subject. The United States is committed to using more ethanol as part of our strategy to reduce our dependence on foreign oil. President Lula da Silva and I agree that we need to work together to make sure that we're using this commodity in a way that benefits both our countries.

As for the tariffs issue, I think it's fair to say that we've made some progress on that front. The USA is willing to take a look at the tariffs that are in place and see what we can do to make sure that we're promoting a greater trade environment for ethanol. But the issue is, of course, complex. We've got interests that we've got to balance here, but I'm confident that we can work through this and find a solution that satisfies the legitimate interests of both our countries.

Well, I appreciate the question. First of all, I want to remind everybody that we're dealing with a serious threat in Saddam Hussein and his regime. The primary goal of the United States is to protect our citizens and the citizens of the world from the threats posed by terrorist organizations and rogue states.

Now, I understand that there are differing opinions on how to achieve this goal, and I respect that. But I must say that I'm not going to let public opinion or the opinion of other nations dictate what I believe is in the best interest of the United States. I've made a decision, along with my administration, that the use of force is necessary to disarm Saddam Hussein and remove his regime from power.

Now, I know some nations have disagreed with me, and that's okay. But I would remind them that in the Security Council, we've passed Resolution 1441, which called for Iraq to disarm. And as it stands today, Iraq is still not in compliance with that resolution.

As for the notion that the United States is seen as an arrogant power, I would say that I don't think that's a fair characterization. I believe the United States is a nation that is committed to spreading freedom and protecting our interests, and I'm proud of that.

We are a nation that is concerned about the suffering of the Iraqi people under Saddam's regime. We are a nation that is willing to take the lead on these issues, and I believe that's what's expected of us.

Now, I understand that we have a difference of opinion on this issue, but I believe that history will show that we're doing the right thing. We're removing a threat to the stability of the region, and we're giving the Iraqi people a chance to have a more peaceful future.

So, I'm not going to let criticism from around the world deter me from what I believe is in the best interest of this country.

Well, thank you for your question. I want to commend our brave men and women in uniform for their tireless efforts in Iraq. The fact that we were able to eliminate Uday and Qusay, Saddam's sons, is a significant step forward in our mission to bring stability and security to the Iraqi people.

As for Saddam himself, we are making progress, but I can't give you a timeline on when he'll be brought to justice. Our military and intelligence are working diligently to track him down, but this is a complex and challenging operation. We will not rest until he is found and held accountable for his crimes.

Capturing or killing Saddam will be a major blow to the insurgency and a significant step towards ending the violence against our troops. It will be a clear demonstration that the former regime is no longer in power, and that the Iraqi people are taking control of their own destiny.

As for our troops, I want to express my deepest gratitude for their service and sacrifice. I know they're eager to come home, and I want to assure them that we're working hard to bring them home as soon as possible. However, we also must ensure that the mission is complete, that Iraq is stable and secure, and that the Iraqi people are safe.

Regarding coalition troop deployments, we're working with our international partners to step up their support for the mission. We're making progress, but I understand the concerns about the timing and the deployment. We're committed to ensuring that our troops have the support they need to complete their mission and return home safely.

Let me make one thing clear: we will not leave Iraq until the job is done. We will not abandon the Iraqi people to the forces of chaos and terrorism. We will stay the course, and we will ensure that Iraq emerges as a stable, free, and democratic nation.

Thank you for your question.  I do believe this trip is mending fences. I had a great discussion with the Prime Minister, and we had a very productive meeting.  Our relationship between the United States and this country is strong, and I'm glad to report that we agree on a lot of issues.  We talked about the Middle East, and the Prime Minister reminded me of the importance of the Greater Middle East initiative. He also talked about our strong bilateral relations and their willingness to stand side by side with the United States.  
With regards to the demonstrations, I fully understand that there are differing opinions, not just here, but all across the world.  There will be differing opinions, but I'm convinced that the Prime Minister and I share the same vision for a more peaceful world.  We were able to have a very cordial conversation about areas that we didn't necessarily see eye to eye.

As for the Prime Minister's statement about troop levels in Iraq, I'll let the Prime Minister answer that for himself.

You know, I think it's a positive step, and I think it's a testament to the determination of the Iraqi people that we've been able to transfer sovereignty back to them. Now, I also think that this is a moment where some of the critics are looking at the progress that's been made in Iraq and I think that they're reassessing their views. And that's healthy. 

I think there's no question that the critics have re-examined their positions on the liberation of Iraq. As a matter of fact, I've had some honest conversations with some of the leaders of NATO countries that were not with us on the initial decision to liberate Iraq, and I think they now see that it was a cause worth fighting for.

And I believe that when they take a close look at what's happening on the ground, the transfer of sovereignty is a significant step towards a free and peaceful Iraq. And the images of families embracing their freedom is a powerful message to the rest of the world about the potential for democracy to spread in that part of the world.

So, does it matter what the critics say? Well, I think it always matters. We value the alliances and the friendships that we have, and we always want to see our friends view our actions in a positive light. But, I also know that there's a time to make hard decisions, and if they're the right decisions, then we'll be vindicated over time.

So, we're not going to let public opinion affect our will and our determination to achieve a safer world. But we are mindful of the fact that our friends are watching, and we want to be in a position to continue to say to them, "Join us. Be involved. Work with us for the cause of peace and freedom."

Thank you for that question.  Let me just make some context, first. The situation in Iraq is complex and fluid, as you all know. And we're constantly evaluating our policy and our strategy to make sure we're achieving our goals.

Regarding Moqtada Al Sadr, as I've said before, we view him as a complicated figure, with some positive contributions to the Iraqi polity and some very negative aspects, particularly in terms of his support of the violent elements that are causing so much harm in Iraq.

Our goal in Iraq is to support the democratically elected government of Prime Minister Maliki, and to help them achieve the unity and security that the Iraqi people so desperately want and need. And we're working closely with the Prime Minister and his government to achieve those goals.

Now, as to whether or not we would encourage the Prime Minister to break with Moqtada Al Sadr, that's a matter of tactical decision-making, that the Prime Minister and his government will ultimately have to make. And we've had discussions with him about the challenges posed by the Sadr militia and the need to work towards a solution that insures the long-term unity and security of Iraq.

I did discuss these issues with Prime Minister Maliki this morning, as I have on every occasion that I've met with him. I reminded him that we're committed to supporting him and the Iraqi people, and that we're working closely with him to develop the solutions that will address the challenges that Iraq faces. But ultimately, the decisions about how to address those challenges, of course, will be made by the Iraqi government, not by us.

I appreciate that question. As the Commander-in-Chief of the United States Armed Forces, I have taken a close and personal interest in the progress of the Iraqi government. And I will tell you, Prime Minister Maliki is a good man with a big vision. He's under a lot of pressure, no question about it. But he's also made some tough decisions and worked hard to move the process forward.

I think it's fair to say that the Iraqis are making progress, albeit not nearly as quickly as any of us would like. But we can't confuse setbacks with a lack of progress. We're in this for the long haul. We're in this to make sure that the Iraqi government is able to sustain, govern, and secure itself, and it's going to take some time.

Now, Prime Minister Maliki has assured me that he's committed to a multi-ethnic Iraq. He's shown a willingness to take on some tough tasks, like going after the death squads and other violent groups. And we're working closely with him to ensure that these goals are met.

Now, I want to assure the American people that we're not going to leave Iraq until the job is done. And when we leave, we'll leave behind a government that can function and a security force that can defend itself.

It's not a question of doubt, but rather a question of whether or not we can do this, whether we can make a difference in this part of the world. And I believe with every fiber of my being that we can, and we will.

I think it's also fair to say that we've come a long way since the spring and the amount of violence this summer. Although it's still high, I believe that there's been improvement, particularly in the areas where the Iraqis are moving forward with the help of coalition forces.

Now, look, I'm under no illusions about the difficulties that remain, and we're going to be patient, we're going to be persistent, and we'll go on till we get the job done. But we've got to stay the course, I firmly believe.

Thank you for the question. I'm glad to have a chance to address this. I do believe that a vote of disapproval can embolden the enemy. When we're in a difficult fight like we are in Iraq, our troops deserve a united America and a message of support. And I think when there's a vote of disapproval, it can have the effect of emboldening our enemies, which would be unfortunate.

Now, I understand that there's disagreement on how to proceed in Iraq, and I respect that. But I believe that we've got a good strategy in place, and that's a strategy of working with the Iraqi government to help them secure themselves, and training Iraqi troops, and eventually having them take the lead in securing their country. And I think it's very important for our enemies to know that we're committed to this effort.

Now, in terms of the appropriation, I'm working the phones pretty hard to persuade members of Congress to make sure that our troops get the resources they need to do their job. And I'm optimistic that, in the end, Congress will come together and provide the necessary funds. We're not asking for a blank check; we're asking for the necessary funds to support our troops in a time of war.

And let me just say that, you know, I'm a bit frustrated that we're having to debate this at all. Our troops are fighting a ruthless enemy, and they deserve the support of the American people. And I'm going to keep working to make sure that we don't tie the hands of our commanders in the field, and that we give them the resources they need to succeed.

I understand the skepticism, and I appreciate it, because it's healthy to have a skeptical press. But I want to remind you, the intelligence community has genuine concerns, based on the information they had at the time, about Saddam Hussein's intentions, as it relates to having a nuclear program. And while it's true that no stockpiles have been found, the fact is, the culture of that regime, the intentions of that regime, were clear.

Regarding Iran, I've made it clear to the Iranian people that we're concerned about their intentions. We've seen their bombast - excuse me, their ballistic missile program, which is a threat to the region, as well as their declarations about wanting to build a bomb.

I don't think I was hyping the danger when it comes to Iran. I was informing the American people of the concerns that we have. And we'll continue to work to make sure that the international community comes together to address the problems posed by the Iranian regime.

As for credibility, I think our credibility is based on the fact that we've seen the threat of a nuclear terrorism, and we've seen it, over and over again. We saw it in Afghanistan, with the Taliban harboring al-Qaeda. We saw it with the missiles in Afghanistan and in Pakistan. And we've seen it in Iraq, with the connections to terrorist states and terrorist organizations.

Let me make it clear, the threat of a nuclear arms program, and the ability of a state sponsor of terror to achieve a nuclear capability, is a real and present danger to the region and to the world. We are working hard, and I believe in close partnership with the international community, to try to deal with it in the most constructive way possible.

Thank you for your question. Let me address both parts. Firstly, on the issue of troop levels, I'd like to emphasize that our policy is tried and true. We're a nation of flexible, adapting to the situation on the ground. Our generals are doing a fantastic job. We're adjusting our strategy, of course. Clearly, we must ensure we have sufficient troop levels in both theaters of operation. We are reviewing and reevaluating our troop deployments, as is prudent and wise. And you'll see us responding to those needs.

On the second part of your question, I strongly disagree with the characterization of our strategy in Iraq. The reality on the ground, as is often talked about, belies that notion. Iraq has been and is a central battlefront in the global war on terror. Al-Qaeda made the decision to consider Iraq a battlefield; we followed suit and took the fight to them. As we've made gains in Iraq that's spilled over, positively, into that region and the Central Command – Afghanistan and more areas are drawn into it. So, I think it's very important and beneficial for our country to confront al-Qaeda, and we will.

Thank you for your question. Well, I'll tell you, we're working hard to get the United Nations Security Council Resolution 1441 implemented, which calls for Saddam Hussein to disarm. We've made it clear to Saddam that this is a serious resolution and he must take immediate steps to comply. I believe the inspectors will know in a relatively short period of time whether or not he's intending to comply. We'll see signs, for example, of whether he's allowing inspectors unrestricted access, whether he's providing information about his programs and facilities.

I wouldn't dream of trying to guess the exact timeline, but I would say within the next few weeks we'll have a pretty good idea of whether he's going to comply or not. The inspectors will report back, and if Saddam Hussein isn't complying, we'll take that into account and consider further action.

Make no mistake about it: we expect him to comply fully and immediately. And if he doesn't, the consequences will be serious. But we'll work with the international community to make sure that we exhaust all diplomatic options before we consider taking any further action.

So I think it's going to be a shorter period of time, rather than a longer period of time, before we know whether or not Saddam Hussein intends to comply with the will of the world.

(frowning) Well, I appreciate the question, but I must say, I strongly disagree with the premise. Our policy towards France has been one of cooperation and mutual respect, despite our differences on certain issues. Now, I know there have been some disagreements on Iraq, and perhaps that's what you're referring to. But let me be clear: we value our relationship with France and the French people, and we will continue to work with them on a wide range of issues, from counter-terrorism to trade.

Regarding the second part of your question, I want to be very clear: the actions of a few individuals at Abu Ghraib do not represent the values or the policies of the United States government. We took swift and decisive action to address those abuses, and we've held those responsible accountable. We will not be swayed by unfair comparisons to Saddam Hussein or any other dictator. We are a nation of laws, and we will uphold those laws and our values, even in the face of adversity.

As for the issue of state terrorism, I reject that label outright. We are a nation that respects human rights and the rule of law, and we will not engage in actions that undermine those principles. And as for the weapons of mass destruction, while we may not have found the stockpiles we expected, intelligence agencies around the world, including the French intelligence agencies, agreed that Saddam Hussein posed a threat to international security. We acted on the best intelligence available at the time, and we will continue to work to prevent the proliferation of WMD.

(leaning forward)
Now, I understand that there are those who will continue to question our actions and our policies. But I can tell you that our commitment to protecting the American people, and to upholding our values, will not waver. We will continue to work with our allies, including France, to build a safer and more secure world for all.

That's a great question. I appreciate you bringing it up. First of all, let me just remind people that our strategy for victory in Iraq is to help the Iraqis take the lead, to train the Iraqis, to get them to a position where they can provide their own security. And that's happening. The troop levels will be determined by the generals on the ground, not by some arbitrary number decided by politicians in Washington.

Now, in terms of our ability to respond to other threats, I would say that our military, because of its flexibility and because of its strength, is capable of responding to threats from around the world. That's why we are calling it the expeditionary force, not for a specific place. I mean, we are going to respond to threats when they come.

Now, I think we are in a delicate phase of diplomacy right now with North Korea, and we are optimistic that through the six-party talks, that North Korea will agree to dismantle its nuclear programs. I think that our diplomatic pressure is being effective in convincing them that it's in their best interest to be a part of the international community, rather than to try to isolate themselves.

Now, I think our troop levels will be determined by the job on the ground, not by perceived threats from around the world. We will not cut and run based on hypotheticals. This nation will respond to threats, no matter where they are, if they are directed at our interest.

Thank you for the question. Well, I think it's very important for there to be a peaceful resolution in the Middle East. I want to thank Mr. Sharon for his bold move to disengage from Gaza. I think it's a historic moment. And I think it's going to be an opportunity for the Palestinians to show the world they can govern themselves.

Regarding the issue of airspace and control of ports, we're working closely with the Israelis, the Palestinians, and other parties to ensure that there's a coordinated approach to these issues. My administration's position is clear: we want to see the Palestinians having control of their territory, and we want to see the Israelis feeling secure. And we're working to find a way to make that happen.

Now, I want to emphasize that the roadmap is a process, and we're not there yet. We've got a lot of work ahead of us. But I'm optimistic. I believe that with strong leadership and a commitment to peace, we can get there. And I think the disengagement from Gaza is a great first step.

And I must say, I'm heartened by President Abbas's commitment to democracy. It's a reminder that peace is not just between governments, but between peoples. And I'm committed to helping the Palestinian people achieve their aspirations for freedom and democracy.

Now, I know there's a lot of skepticism out there, but I'm an optimist. I believe that with perseverance, with good faith, and with a commitment to peace, we can achieve great things. And I think this is a moment of hope for the Palestinian people, and I'm committed to seeing this process through.

Thank you for your question. I appreciate it. Secretary Powell is going to the Middle East to, of course, visit with our friends and discuss a range of issues, and one of the issues he will discuss is the sanctions and how to make them more effective. The message he will take is that we're committed to containing Saddam Hussein, we're committed to making sure he doesn't threaten his neighbors, and at the same time we're committed to relieving the suffering of the Iraqi people.

We believe that the sanctions must be focused on Saddam Hussein and his regime, not on the Iraqi people. And we're working to find ways to make the sanctions more effective in this regard. And I think you'll see, over time, that we'll continue to refine our policy to make sure that we're able to pressure Saddam Hussein without hurting the Iraqi people.

We've made significant progress in the oil-for-food program, and we're continuing to work with the international community to make sure that the program is implemented effectively, and that the Iraqi people receive the food and medicine they need.

So, Secretary Powell will go, as I said, with a message of hope, a message of cooperation, and a message that we're committed to relieving the suffering of the Iraqi people, but also to making sure that Saddam Hussein doesn't threaten the neighborhood.

Good afternoon, thank you for your questions. I was indeed informed of the Holy Father's declaration, and I appreciate his strong stance on this issue. As I've said before, I've always been a strong supporter of the sanctity of human life, and I share the Pope's concerns about the manipulation of embryos.

Regarding federal funding for embryonic stem cell research, I've made my position clear: while I support research that could lead to improved medical treatments and cures, I am opposed to using taxpayer money to fund research that involves the destruction of human embryos. I will continue to take the Holy Father's words into consideration, as well as the views of other leaders and the American people, as I examine this decision.

I will re-evaluate my position in light of the Pope's declaration, and I will work with our scientific advisors and ethicists to ensure that our policies are informed by both the latest scientific advancements and a deep respect for human life.

And now, I'll turn this question over to Prime Minister Berlusconi to address the second part of your question. Prime Minister?

And if I may add, I believe Italy has a unique role to play in our bilateral relationship, as well as in Europe. Italy is an important partner and ally in the war on terror, and we've had a long history of cooperation on defense and security issues. Italy has also been a key player in promoting democracy and stability in the Mediterranean region.

I think our relationship with Italy is strong and multifaceted, and it goes beyond our shared membership in NATO and other international organizations. We work together on a range of issues, from counter-terrorism to non-proliferation, and we value Italy's role as a leader in European affairs. Prime Minister?

Thank you for that question. I appreciate your interest in the situation in Afghanistan. First, let me say that the safety of the citizens of Kabul is a top priority. We're working closely with our coalition partners, the United Nations, and other international organizations to ensure that humanitarian aid reaches those in need.

In the next several days, we will be working to establish a secure environment in Kabul, which will enable us to deliver assistance to the Afghan people. We're also working with the international community to establish a conference, a meeting, to bring together the various parties, including the Northern Alliance, to discuss the future of Afghanistan.

Regarding the Northern Alliance, they have played a crucial role in the fight against the Taliban and al-Qaeda. As we move forward, we're interested in seeing a government that is representative of all the people of Afghanistan, not just one group or another. The Northern Alliance, like other factions, will certainly have a seat at the table, but we will not be favoring one group over another.

Our goal is to help the Afghan people build a representative government, and we're committed to making sure that the rights of all Afghans, regardless of their ethnic background or regional affiliation, are respected and protected. We will be working with the United Nations, with other countries, to ensure that a broad-based government is established, one that represents the will of the Afghan people.

We've made some progress, but there's still a lot of work to be done. We're committed to seeing this through, to helping the Afghan people build a stable, peaceful country, and we'll be working with all parties to make that happen.

Thank you for that question. I appreciate your interest in the Middle East peace process. The situation is indeed complex and challenging, and I must say that I'm disappointed, but not surprised, by the fact that both sides have not fully complied with our expectations.

Regarding U.S. aid, let me be clear: we are committed to supporting our allies and partners in the region, including Israel. However, I also want to make it clear that our aid is not a blank check. We expect our friends to work with us towards a peaceful resolution to the conflict, and to respect the principles of peace and non-violence.

As for consequences, I want to say that we will continue to work closely with both sides to encourage them to comply with our expectations. We will also continue to hold them accountable for their actions, and we will make our views clear to the international community.

Now, I'm not going to rule out any options at this point, including re-evaluating our aid packages. But I want to emphasize that our goal is to promote peace and stability in the region, not to punish our friends or undermine their capacity to defend themselves.

Regarding the comments made by Chairman Arafat, I want to say that I find his language to be unacceptable and unhelpful. It's not constructive to use inflammatory rhetoric, and it undermines the prospects for peace. I've told Chairman Arafat that in no uncertain terms, and I will continue to speak truth to power on this issue.

Finally, I want to emphasize that as the President of the United States, I will not be swayed by personal attacks or inflammatory rhetoric. I will continue to work towards a peaceful resolution to the conflict, even in the face of setbacks and disappointments. And I will hold both sides accountable for their actions, because that's what leaders do.

I understand the doubts and the worries that the American people have. I want to assure them that I understand the decision to go to war is a difficult one. I understand the sacrifices that our troops and their families will have to make. I also understand that the Iraqi regime is a threat to the security of the United States and to the security of the world.

As for the evidence, I can assure you that we have given the intelligence committee, the Senate and the House, over 90 briefing on Saddam Hussein's intentions and capabilities. The evidence that we've gathered points to the fact that Saddam Hussein is reconstituting his nuclear program. He is in violation of 17 United Nations Security Council resolutions calling upon him to disarm. He has the capacity to make biological and chemical agents.

Now, I understand that I haven't made it clear enough, perhaps, to some, but I think the American people understand that Saddam Hussein has proven himself to be bad news, and that our diplomacy efforts have failed, unfortunately, over the course of the last 12 years.

Now, I'd like to add, the reason I believe we have to take this course of action is because we can't have diplomacy without the threat of force behind it. And I believe that now is the time to disarm Saddam Hussein, rather than to wait until he decides to unleash a threat against the United States or against our friends and allies.

I understand the doubts and the worries, but I'm resolute in my commitment to keep America secure and to disarm Saddam Hussein.

Thank you for that question. I understand the concerns you're raising, and I share 'em. It's a changing world we live in, and the global economy is presenting new challenges for many Americans. Now, first of all, I want to remind folks that our economy is strong. We've had a remarkable recovery from the recession, and we're growing at a good clip.

However, I also recognize that some folks are struggling to adapt to this new economy. That's why we've been working on a comprehensive strategy to help Americans acquire the skills they need to compete in this global economy.

One of the initiatives I'm proud of is our commitment to improving education and job training. We've increased funding for programs like the Workforce Investment Act, which helps people get the skills they need to fill the jobs that are available.

We've also launched a major initiative to improve math and science education, because those are the skills that are going to be in high demand in the 21st century.

And let me tell you, we're also working on a new program called "TechSkills," which is a program to help workers upgrade their skills in technology.

Now, I know that some folks are concerned that jobs are being outsourced, and I understand that concern. But the truth is, the American economy is still creating jobs. We've added 4.6 million jobs over the past three years, and many of those jobs are in sectors that didn't even exist 10 years ago.

But we can do more, and we will do more. That's why we're committed to continuing our efforts to make it easier for workers to get the training they need to succeed in this fast-changing economy.

Thank you for the question.  Let me be clear on this issue. I've been listening to all the different perspectives, and I appreciate the input from Chairman Thomas and Senator Snowe, and many other lawmakers, for that matter.

Now, regarding the notion of a guaranteed benefit, I think it's a good concept. We want to make sure that our seniors have a safety net, a floor of protection, that they can rely on. And so, while the details are still being worked out, I am open to the idea of providing a guaranteed benefit for those who opt into personal accounts.

I think it's essential to remember, however, that the personal accounts are meant to provide a measure of personal ownership and control for each individual. We want people to have a stake in our economic growth, and to benefit from the fruits of their labor. So, we're gonna work on the details to find the right balance, but I am open to considering a guaranteed benefit as part of that overall package.

Now, to my fellow Republicans who are worried, I say: let's have an open and honest dialogue about this issue. I understand the concerns, and I share many of them. But I also believe that we have an historic opportunity to reform our Social Security system, to make it more solvent, more secure, and more personalized for every American.

I'm not gonna back away from that goal. I'm gonna keep working with Congress, and I'm gonna keep listening to all of your perspectives, to find the right way forward. And I'm confident that, together, we can get this done. Thank you.

Thank you for the question. I appreciate it. Well, first of all, let me just say that this is a tough issue, and it's going to take tough decisions to make sure that Social Security is solvent for our children and grandkids. And I'm committed to making those decisions.

I believe that personal accounts are an important part of the solution, because I think they give the younger workers a chance to own a piece of their own retirement security, and that's a fundamental aspect of freedom, in my opinion. But I also understand that there are concerns about the solvency of Social Security.

Now, I've laid out a general framework for reform. I've talked about the problems that we face, and I've proposed some solutions. And I'm willing to listen to ideas from members of Congress, from the American people, from experts.

We've had a series of meetings with the framework group, and we've had a lot of discussions with Congress about the various options. I think we're making progress. And I'm optimistic that we can find common ground.

Now, in terms of a specific plan, I think it's a little like a negotiation. You know, I've got to work with members of Congress, and we've got to find something that we can all agree on. And I'm willing to make some compromises in order to get a deal done.

I will say this: we've got a problem with Social Security. If we don't do something about it, the next generation is going to face some very tough times. And so, if we can't find a way to deal with this now, when we've got a chance to do it, I think we're going to regret it.

So, I'm committed to working with members of Congress to find a solution. I'm committed to being bipartisan. And I'm committed to finding a solution that works for the American people.

Good morning. Thank you for the question. I appreciate your interest in our trade agenda. Look, I'm optimistic about our ability to get trade agreements passed through the Congress. I know the CAFTA vote was close, and I understand there are concerns among some members of Congress. However, I believe that our trade agreements are in the best interest of the American people and the people of the countries with whom we're negotiating.

Regarding the Panamanian free trade agreement, we're working closely with the Panamanian government to address any concerns they may have, including the issue of unexploded ordnance. I've instructed our team to work diligently to resolve this issue, and we're committed to helping Panama decontaminate the affected areas.

As for the support in Congress, I'm hopeful that once our lawmakers see the benefits of this agreement – the jobs it will create, the economic growth it will stimulate – they will come to the conclusion that this is a good deal for America. We're working hard to educate members of Congress about the benefits of this agreement, and I'm confident that we can build a strong coalition of support.

Now, I will say that it's not going to be easy. There are always going to be challenges when it comes to trade agreements. But I'm a believer in the power of free trade to lift people up and create opportunity, and I'm willing to work hard to get this done.

Thank you for that question. I'm glad to be standing here alongside Prime Minister Rasmussen. We've had some very productive meetings, indeed. As we head into the NATO summit, I am optimistic that we will see increased commitments from our allies, both in terms of trainers and Provincial Reconstruction Teams.

You see, the situation in Afghanistan is dire, and it requires a collective effort to ensure its stability. The threat of terrorism emanating from that region is a global concern, and it demands a global response. As the world's leading democracies, I'm confident that we will see a sincere effort from our partners to do their part.

Now, I will not predict specific commitments, but I can tell you that the international engagement we've had this week – with Denmark, the UK, and others – has been very encouraging. I think Prime Minister Rasmussen can attest that the Danish contribution has been exemplary, and I appreciate his nation's leadership.

Anders, would you like to chime in on this point? I think he's got some valuable insights to share. ( gestures to the Prime Minister )

Thank you for that question. The numbers you cited are indeed noteworthy, and I appreciate your bringing them to my attention. As you know, I've long been a supporter of the death penalty, but as President, it's also my duty to ensure that justice is served in a fair and equitable manner.

The McVeigh case, the recent examples of wrongful convictions being overturned - these do give us pause. We need to make sure that our system is sound, that the procedures are in place to prevent mistaken executions. I still believe that the death penalty can be an effective deterrent, but I also believe it cannot be applied in a way that denies the basic principles of justice.

Now, I've been in discussions with my advisors, with Attorney General Ashcroft, about the need to review our procedures, to make sure that we're doing everything possible to prevent mistakes in the administration of capital punishment. We need to be mindful of the concerns you've raised, and I want to assure the American people that we take these concerns seriously.

That being said, I still believe the death penalty is an effective tool for societal protection, and I'll continue to work with state governors and legislatures to ensure that it's applied in a way that's consistent with our values of justice and fairness.

However, in light of the recent developments, I do think it's prudent to have a more thorough examination of our procedures to make sure we're getting it right.

Well, thank you for the question. The capture of Saddam Hussein is a significant day, and I want to congratulate the brave men and women of our military, as well as our coalition partners, who made this success possible. Now, regarding the post-war phase of Iraq... (pauses)

First of all, let me tell you, our objective in Iraq remains the same as it's been from the start: to create a free, sovereign, and peaceful Iraq. We're committed to helping the Iraqi people establish a stable, democratic government that can stand on its own two feet. The timeline for an interim government is ambitious, but it's achievable. We're working with the Iraqis, the international community, to make sure this happens.

As for the drawdown of troops, we'll make those decisions based on the conditions on the ground, not based on a specific date on the calendar. Gen. Abizaid and Gen. Sanchez will make those recommendations to me, based on the security situation, and we'll adjust accordingly.

Now, I understand the speculation about the elections, but I want to assure the American people that our decisions are guided by one thing, and that's the interest of our country and the safety of the Iraqi people. We're making progress, there's no doubt about it, but we'll be guided by the need to get the job done.

(pauses)

We've got a long way to go, but I'm optimistic, I know we can achieve our goals, working with our allies and the international community. We're determined to see this through, for the sake of our security and for the sake of the Iraqi people themselves.

(otherwise known for being unpleasant with the press) We have evidence of Saddam Hussein being a ruthless dictator and the situation was intolerable for much of the world. Now the regime was very good at deceiving people. And that is why, to begin with, there might be some skepticism. But as I indicated… accountability will come.

First of all, the war in Iraq is about our national security. Now, the risks of doing nothing versus the benefits of taking out a tyrant were really the biggest reasons and the biggest wins. But make no mistake, democratization has also been a goal that we believe because we are conservative.
 
(Switching) Going over to the other side of the map with respect to the man sent to sell teen clothing to young women last week: Kim Chong-il here serves as the rule but I believe North Korea should associate with the World.

Thank you, thank you very much. I appreciate your interest in our discussions. We have had some very constructive talks with Tony on a lot of issues. The debt relief package is an important part of the discussions we're having here. I think we're making good progress, I really do. The United States has been a leader on the debt relief initiative, and we'll continue to take the lead in working with our G8 partners to make sure that the package is robust and gets the job done. We're talking about the details of how to finance it, but I'm optimistic that we can work through those issues.

Regarding the Africa Commission, I do think that this is a historic moment, not just for Africa, but for the world. Africa's struggles with poverty and disease need to be addressed, and we need to work together to do so. I appreciate the work that Tony and his commissions have done to shine a spotlight on this issue. We've got a great opportunity to make some significant progress here, and I think we're all committed to doing just that.

Tony, would you like to add anything on the debt relief package?

Thank you for that question. I appreciate the chance to clarify my position. I want to make it clear that I do listen to the voters, and I respect the will of the American people. The election results send a clear message that the American people are eager for a new direction on Iraq.

As Commander-in-Chief, I have a responsibility to ensure the safety and security of our troops and the American people. The Vice President's comments were a reflection of our commitment to the mission in Iraq, but also an acknowledgment that we are always looking for ways to improve and adjust our strategy.

A "course correction" means that we will continue to work with the Iraqis, our coalition partners, and our military leaders to find new and effective ways to achieve our goals in Iraq. It means that we will be flexible, and we will adapt to changing circumstances on the ground.

It's not about moving full speed ahead without adjusting to the realities on the ground. It's about making sure that we're doing everything we can to succeed in Iraq, and that we're using all the tools and resources at our disposal to support our troops and the Iraqi people.

I appreciate the advice and the input of the Vice President, but ultimately, as the Commander-in-Chief, I make the decisions, and I will continue to do what I think is in the best interest of our country.

Thank you for the question. I understand the concern about the Iraqi government's ability to assume responsibility for their own security. And I understand the suggestion that a gradual withdrawal might be a way to address this concern.

However, I must remind you that the situation on the ground is complex. Our military leaders tell me that a premature withdrawal would embolden the enemy, Al Qaida, and other extremist groups that are trying to destabilize the Iraqi government.

Now, we are making progress in Iraq. We're working with the Iraqi government, with the military, to build up their capacity to provide security for their own people. And that's an important mission. The Iraqis are beginning to take more and more responsibility.

But a timed withdrawal, or a withdrawal tied to an arbitrary deadline, would signal to the enemy that we're getting ready to leave. And I'm not going to send a signal to the enemy that we're going to abandon the Iraqi government or the Iraqi people.

We have to be careful in our approach, because any signal we send will be interpreted not just by our friends, but by our enemies as well. So, while I understand the concern, I'm not convinced that a gradual withdrawal is the way to go right now.

We've got to work on building up the Iraqi capacity, we've got to work on showing the enemy that we're committed to the mission, and we've got to give the Iraqis a chance to succeed.

That's my assessment, after listening to the military leaders, that a gradual withdrawal at this point would not be a good idea.

Well, let me start by saying that we appreciate the Prime Minister's efforts to engage with his neighbors. It's a positive development for Iraq's future stability and unity. Now, I understand that the visit to Iran may have raised some eyebrows, and I'll tell you why. We've had our differences with the Iranians, as you well know. Their development of nuclear arms is a grave concern, not just for the United States, but the entire international community.

However, we also believe that Prime Minister Maliki's efforts to engage with the Iranians can be a positive step towards resolving the regional issues that affect Iraq. Now, our policy on Iran remains firm: we expect them to comply with the United Nations resolutions and suspend their enrichment activities.

As for the images from the visit, I think it's natural that the Prime Minister would meet with his counterparts in the region. What's important to us is that Iraq remains a key partner in the war on terror and a staunch supporter of our efforts to bring stability to the region.

In terms of a message, I believe it sends a signal that Iraq is willing to engage with its neighbors, and that's a positive development. However, we expect the Prime Minister to remain committed to the values that we've worked hard to promote in Iraq, including democracy, human rights, and the rule of law.

Let me be clear, though: our relationship with Iraq is built on shared interests and shared values. And while we acknowledge the importance of engagement with Iran, our policy towards the Iranian government remains unchanged. We will continue to work with our allies in the region to see the region become more secure and more prosperous, and to counter the destabilizing actions of the Iranian regime.

Now, next question, please.

Thank you, thank you. I appreciate the question. (turning to the Prime Minister) I'll let José María speak to his efforts in a minute.

We're making progress, but I understand it's not complete yet. I believe that we will have a vote, and I believe that we will have, at the very minimum, the nine votes necessary for passage. And I believe that we will get more than four.

As for veto, we'll just have to wait and see. We'll make the case and hope that logic and reason and the desire for peace and safety prevail. We're not going to predict how others will vote, that's their decision to make.

But I want to assure the American people and the world that we'll try to round up as many votes as possible. I believe we've got a very strong case in terms of our desire to disarm Saddam Hussein, and to bring stability to the region.

Now, José María, would you like to speak to your conversations with world leaders? (turning to the Prime Minister)

Well, thank you for the question.  As for the religious conservatives, I appreciate their support, and I want to assure them that I'm committed to the values that we share.  We've made some important strides on issues like partial-birth abortion, faith-based initiatives, and defending the sanctity of marriage. But I also understand that there's more work to be done. 

One issue that's still on my radar screen is the confirmation of qualified judges who will uphold the Constitution and the values that we hold dear. We've had some success in the Senate, but there's still more to be done.  Another issue is the reauthorization of the No Child Left Behind Act, which has provisions to support the work of faith-based organizations in helping disadvantaged children.

Now, I think it's fair for the folks to expect results, and I'm committed to working with them to get those results.  But I also want to remind them that we're making progress, and that it's not always easy to get things done in Washington.

Now, as for my reading contest with Karl Rove, (laughs) well, I'm pleased to report that I'm ahead in the number of books read.  I've read 51 books so far, and Karl's read 37. But I'll tell you, he's a relentless reader, and he's catching up fast. We're approaching the end of the year, and I'm going to have to pick up the pace to stay ahead.

Well, I understand that there have been disappointments, and there have been difficulties. But I will tell you, I have done my best, given the information that I had, to make good decisions for the country. And I'm proud of what we've accomplished. We've implemented tax cuts that have helped our economy grow stronger. We've reformed our education system to leave no child behind. We've taken a strong stand against terrorism, and we've kept America safe from another attack.

Look, execution is a part of the presidency, and we've had our fair share of difficulties. But I'll tell you this: I've always tried to do what I think is right, not what's popular. And I think that's an important part of being the President of the United States.

I know that there are those who think that we could have done things differently, and that's fine. But what I would say to the American people is that I'm proud of what we've done. We've made some great progress, and we've overcome some tough times. And I believe that history will be kind to my administration.

But I also want to say that I appreciate the criticism. I appreciate the fact that people care enough about the country to speak their minds and to hold us accountable. That's the greatness of America. We've got a system of government where people can express their opinions, and that's what makes this country so strong.

So, I want to thank the American people for giving me the privilege of being their President. And I want to thank the press for keeping me on my toes. And I hope that, at the end of the day, history will show that we did our best, and that we did what we thought was right.

Thank you for the question. I appreciate it. First of all, the state of the war on terror is this: We are making progress. We're making good progress. The Taliban, which provided haven to Al Qaida, is no longer in power. That's a significant achievement. The borders of Afghanistan are no longer leaky now, unlike they were prior to our involvement. And there's a lot of cooperation around the world.

Now, to answer your specific questions about Usama bin Laden, I don't have information that confirms his death, and I don't have information that confirms he's alive. We just don't know. We've made efforts to find him. We've spent a lot of manpower and resources to find him, as well as to find other Al Qaida leaders.

Al Qaida is still a viable organization, but its ability to operate has been severely impaired. They don't have the same kind of haven they had prior to our operations. We've rounded up or killed a lot of the top Al Qaida leaders. The network has been severely damaged.

Now, as for cells within the United States, I do know that there's a concern that there may still be people here that we don't know about yet who would kill an American if they could. But we've got a good counterterrorism team, and we're working hard to find those who would do us harm.

But let me put it to you this way: We are safer today than we were prior to 9/11. We're safer today because of the hard work of the FBI, CIA, Department of Homeland Security, and the military. But I also understand it's a complex world we live in, and that there's still threats to America.

I want to reassure the American people that we're working hard, that we're making progress, and that we will continue to do everything in our power to protect this nation and our friends.

That's a fair question. I want to assure the American people that when I made the decision to go into Iraq, I was deeply concerned about the existence of weapons of mass destruction. There's no doubt that Saddam Hussein had a history of aggression and deception. He had used chemical weapons against his own people, and we knew he had the capability to produce more.

Over the past 15 months, we've had a team of inspectors from the Iraq Survey Group, led by Charles Duelfer, and they've done a good job of trying to determine what happened to those weapons. Based on their findings, we now know that while Saddam Hussein had a program in place to develop and maintain chemical and biological capabilities, the weapons themselves were not found in the quantities that we thought.

It's still unclear exactly what happened to those capabilities. David Kay, the former head of the Iraq Survey Group, has said that it's possible that some weapons were moved, but I want to assure the American people that we're doing everything we can to find out exactly what happened.

Now, I've shared this information with my G-8 partners, and I believe that we all agree that we need to continue to support the Iraqi people in their efforts to build a democratic government and a free and prosperous society. The main reason I went into Iraq was to protect the American people and our allies from the threat posed by Saddam Hussein, and I believe that we've accomplished that goal.

But I want to assure you, I still have questions, and I'm not satisfied with where we are on this issue. I'm committed to getting to the bottom of it, and we will continue to work with the Iraqis, with our allies, and with the international community to find out what happened to those capabilities.

Well, I appreciate the question, and I appreciate the opportunity to address the situation with Mr. Ali Hattar. First of all, we have spoken to the government of Jordan about this issue, and we are seeking more information. It's a sovereign nation that's got its own laws, and we respect that.

However, we also believe in the principles of freedom and democracy, and we will continue to speak out on behalf of those who are persecuted for speaking their minds. And we will continue to press the Jordanians to respect human rights.

And I want to make it clear that we're friends with the Jordanians, but we're also friends with those who would propagate freedom. And it's a delicate balance, I understand that. But we'll continue to press for reforms and human rights in all countries around the world.

Now, as to my words, I don't think it's mere rhetoric when I speak about freedom and democracy. I believe that the spread of freedom is in the interests of the United States. I believe it's the key to a peaceful world.

And when I speak out on human rights abuses, I mean it. And I'll continue to speak out on human rights abuses, no matter what country it is. And we'll use our influence to promote freedom and human rights, just as we'll use our influence to protect our citizens and our interests.

But I'll also make it clear that we have to be realistic about how we deal with nations around the world. And in this case, we've made our concerns known to the Jordanians, and we'll continue to work with them to promote human rights and freedom.

miner: I appreciate your question. The issue of immigration and border security is a complex one, and it's a challenge that we're workin' hard to address.

Now, I want to be very clear: I strongly condemn the actions of any individuals who are takin' the law into their own hands, particularly in a way that's targetin' migrants or any other group of people. We're a nation of laws, and we need to uphold those laws.

At the same time, I also understand the concerns of many Americans who are frustrated with the current state of our immigration system. We need to work towards comprehensive immigration reform that secures our borders, provides a pathway to citizenship for those who are here, and addresses the root causes of migration.

But we can't let our desire for security and control lead us to abandon our values of compassion and justice. We're a nation of immigrants, and we need to treat all people with dignity and respect. I've made it clear to my administration that we'll do everything in our power to prevent vigilantism and protect the rights of all individuals, regardless of their immigration status.

So, to those who are thinkin' about takin' the law into their own hands, I urge you to stand down. Let's work together to find a solution that's fair, humane, and in line with our American values.

I understand the frustration. I really do. And I want to assure the American people that our goal is to achieve a sustainable peace in the Middle East. We believe that the only way to achieve that is through a two-state solution, where the Israelis and Palestinians live side by side in peace.

Now, I know that the process can be frustrating. It's a difficult process. But I also know that leadership requires patience and persistence. We're making progress, steady progress. We've got a framework, a foundation, a set of principles that have been set forth in resolution 1559. And we're building on that with this new resolution.

I think it's essential for the American people to understand that diplomacy is not just about signing a piece of paper and declaring victory. Diplomacy is about making incremental progress toward a goal, and pushing parties to move towards that goal.

Now, I know some might say, "Is it going to take another resolution, and another resolution, and another?" And the answer is, I hope not. I hope that we can get this done quickly. But we're not going to sacrifice the goal of a sustainable peace for the sake of expediency. We're going to take the time necessary to get it right.

And I want to remind the American people that the United States is not going it alone. We've got a coalition of like-minded nations that are working with us to achieve this goal. We're not going to let the terrorists, we're not going to let the spoilers, undermine this process. We're going to stay focused, and we're going to keep pushing forward towards a sustainable peace.

Well I appreciate the question. First of all, I want to remind people that the reason the international community came together to support a U.N. resolution was because we were concerned about the violence in the region. And the U.N. resolution was a necessary step, in our judgment, to create a framework for a lasting peace. Now, I understand the Lebanese Prime Minister's frustrations. The Prime Minister's frustrations, I think, reflect the frustration of a lot of people who want to get on with rebuilding their country. And I share that frustration.

But the idea of this U.N. resolution was to create a framework, and then take it to the international community to support and help Lebanon and Israel deal with the problem of Hezbollah's influence in southern Lebanon. And the fact that there have been some incidents does not, in my judgment, undermine the international effort. It simply means that we've got to work harder to make sure that everybody is on the same page.

Now, regarding the forces that are going to be deployed, I think it's very important for people to understand that the forces are going to be led by the international community, they're going to be made up of, primarily, European and Muslim nations, and they will be working very closely with the Lebanese army. Now, it's going to take some time to get the international force on the ground, and it's going to take some time for the Lebanese government to deploy their army throughout the country.

But I believe we're making progress. I believe that we're on the right track. I believe that we're creating a framework for peace. And I believe that, eventually, we'll have a lasting peace in the region.
