It's going to be difficult, there are going to be ups and downs, but I'm committed to this. I'm committed to the international effort. And I'm committed to supporting the Lebanese government and the Israeli government as they work through the difficulties in the region.

It's not just a piece of paper. It's a framework that says to the world, we want peace. We want people to be able to live in peace. We want children to be able to go to school and play without fear of violence. And I believe that's what the U.N. resolution is all about. So I remain optimistic, but I also remain realistic. I understand that there's still a lot of work to be done.

You know, that's a very thoughtful question. And I appreciate it. First of all, I'd like to take a moment to honor the sacrifices of those who served in Vietnam. It's a sacrifice that we must always remember and respect.

Now, I understand that the comparison between Vietnam and Iraq is a natural one to make. But I must remind you that the circumstances are quite different. The enemy we're facing today is a regime that harbors and supports terrorists, has used chemical and biological weapons in the past, and has threatened its neighbors. Saddam Hussein's regime is a threat not just to the region but to the world.

We've made it clear that we're not just going into Iraq to change the regime, we're going after a threat. We believe that Saddam Hussein has got to be held accountable for his actions, and at the same time, we're working hard to build a coalition of nations that will help us achieve that goal.

I want to assure the sons and daughters of those who served in Vietnam that we will not commit our troops to an open-ended or unconditional intervention. We're going to go in with a clear objective, a clear strategy, and a commitment to do what it takes to get the job done.

And I want to remind everyone that the sacrifice of our men and women in uniform is not made lightly. We mourn every loss, we pray for their families, and we honor their service.

We will do everything we can to minimize risk, to maximize our chances of success, and to get the job done as quickly and safely as possible.

Well, I appreciate that question. First, let me just say that we're working hard to get a resolution passed that will unite the world in the face of a threat. And we're making good progress. We're talking to delegates, we're listening to their concerns, and we're trying to find common ground.

Russia and France are important members of the Security Council, and we're working closely with them to address their concerns. We believe that a strong, unified resolution will help to build international support for disarming Saddam Hussein.

As for the June 30th deadline, I've made it clear that time is running out for Saddam Hussein. We're not going to let terrorist states get in the way of progress. We're going to see this through, and if that means going without a second resolution, we'll do that.

Now, I want to turn to my friend, President Aznar. José María, you've been a strong ally in this effort, and I appreciate your commitment to seeing this through. Perhaps you could speak to the efforts that you're making to move the process forward.

(looks at President Aznar)

We're working together, and I think we're making good progress. We've got a broad coalition of nations who share our view that Saddam Hussein must disarm. And we're going to keep working until we get the job done.

As for public opinion, I think the American people understand that this is a moment of consequence. They understand that we can't let terrorist states threaten our security, and they support our efforts to disarm Saddam Hussein.

(looks back at the reporter)

So, we're moving forward, we're working closely with our allies, and we're going to see this through.

Thank you for the question. I appreciate your concern about the situation on the ground in Iraq. While I understand the assessment of our intelligence officials, I do not share the same sense of pessimism. We've made tremendous progress in Iraq, and we're seeing signs of improvement every day. The Iraqis are taking more control of their own security, and our forces are working closely with them to make that happen.

Now, I will say that we're closely monitoring the situation, and we're always considering our options. We're committed to doing what it takes to succeed in Iraq, and if that means adjusting our troop levels, then we will do so. But I'm not prepared to make any announcements today about troop increases or changes to our strategy.

I want to emphasize that our policy is to work with the Iraqi government to transfer responsibility for security to Iraqi forces as quickly as possible. We're making progress on that front, and we'll continue to support the Iraqis as they take on more responsibility for their own security.

It's also worth noting that the enemy we're facing in Iraq is a violent and determined one, and we'll adapt our strategy as necessary to counter their tactics. But I'm confident that with the bravery and determiniation of our troops, we can help the Iraqis build a stable and secure future.

So, to summarize, we're closely monitoring the situation, we're working closely with the Iraqis, and we'll do what it takes to succeed. But I'm not prepared to share the sense of pessimism that some others may have.

Thank you for your questions. On the issue of domestic spying, I've said before that this is a highly classified program, and I'm not going to discuss specific details on operations that have been conducted under our terrorist surveillance program. I can say, however, that this program has been instrumental in disrupting terrorist plots and identifying potential threats to our national security. I think it's safe to say that we've made significant progress in protecting our country from those who wish to harm us, and this program has been a key component of our efforts.

Regarding the issue of race, I appreciate the opportunity to discuss this important topic. In the aftermath of Hurricane Katrina, I acknowledged that we didn't do enough, soon enough, to help the good people of New Orleans, and I took full responsibility for the federal response. I've made it clear that we're committed to ensuring that all Americans, regardless of their background or ethnic origin, have equal access to opportunities and the support they need to rebuild their lives.

In 2006, we're building on that commitment. We're working to ensure that every American has access to quality education, healthcare, and economic opportunities. We're also committed to upholding the principles of the Voting Rights Act, which is a cornerstone of our nation's commitment to equality and fairness. I've made it clear that we'll work with Congress to renew the Voting Rights Act, to ensure that every American can exercise their right to vote without facing barriers or obstacles.

Now, I know some may still have questions about my commitment to these issues, but I hope that our actions speak louder than my words. We're making progress, but we've still got work to do. And I'm committed to doing everything in my power to ensure that every American, regardless of their background, can live in a country where they can pursue their dreams, free from the fear of terrorism and with equal access to opportunities.

I appreciate the question. The report I read, the information I received, said there was a relationship. But I also understand that there's been debate over whether or not that's true. The report you refer to, the Senate Intelligence Committee report, concludes that there was no relationship. I also understand that there's still some debate about whether or not Zarqawi was actually part of al-Qaeda.

I want to clarify that I've always said, I've always said, that Saddam Hussein was a threat. And there were intelligence reports that suggested there was a collaboration between Zarqawi and Saddam Hussein. I understand that the evidence doesn't support that, according to the Senate Intelligence Committee report.

Let me tell you, I'm very comfortable with the decisions that we made. We removed a확 from power, a man who was a threat to the region, and therefore a threat to the United States.

Now, I also understand that there may have been some confusion or some lack of clarity about the exact nature of that relationship. I'm not going to speculate on the degree of the relationship. The Senate Intelligence Committee has done a thorough analysis, and I'm willing to accept that their findings are important and I appreciate the work they've done.

But what is confirmed is that Zarqawi was in Iraq, and that Saddam Hussein's regime provided safe haven to him. And he was a threat, and had he been left unchecked, would have continued to wreak havoc.

But I'm trying to clarify that my positions that I've made in the past, I think were based, of course, on the information that I had available. And as new information comes, I am, and my administration is, always willing to revise our analysis of the matter.

Thank you for your question. As the President of the United States, I'd like to assure the American people and the global community that we are closely monitoring the situation in the stock markets. While there's certainly been some volatility in recent weeks, I believe our economy remains strong and resilient.

Now, as for the possibility of a stock exchange crash, I don't think it's productive to speculate on that. What I will say is that our financial regulators, the Federal Reserve, and my administration are working closely together to ensure that we have the necessary measures in place to prevent any potential instability in the markets from affecting the real economy.

We've taken a number of steps to address the current market conditions, including working with our international partners to promote stability and cooperation in the global financial system. We're also closely monitoring the situation and are prepared to take any necessary actions to protect the integrity of our financial markets.

Regarding the opposition party's stance on this issue, I believe it's essential for us to work together to address the challenges we face. I've reached out to the opposition leaders and invited them to engage in a constructive dialogue on our economic policies. I'm hopeful that they will accept our invitation and that we can work together to find common ground and move forward.

We'll be presenting our report shortly, and I'm confident that it will provide a comprehensive and responsible plan for addressing the economic challenges we face. I'm committed to working with Congress to pass legislation that will help stabilize the markets and promote economic growth.

So, I'm optimistic that we can work together and find ways to move forward. America is a strong and resilient nation, and I have faith that we'll get through this challenging period and emerge even stronger on the other side. Thank you.

Thank you for that question. I appreciate the opportunity to address this issue. I want to assure the American people that I am committed to seeing this intelligence reform legislation through to completion. I've made it clear that we need to act, and we need to act urgently, to reform our intelligence agencies and make sure we're better equipped to deal with the threats of the 21st century.

Now, I will admit, it's been a tough fight. We've made good progress in the House, but we're facing some obstacles in the Senate. And I'm working hard, behind the scenes, to build support for this bill. I'm meeting with key lawmakers, I'm making phone calls, and I'm urging those who are hesitant to come on board.

Now, I know some folks may say, "Well, you're not out there beating the bushes, giving speeches, and mobilizing the base like you do on other issues." And that's a fair point. But let me tell you, this is a delicate negotiation, and it requires a certain amount of finesse. We're trying to build a coalition, we're trying to find common ground, and we're trying to get a bill that will actually make a difference.

I will say this: I'm not going to give up on this issue. I'm going to keep pushing, I'm going to keep prodding, and I'm going to keep working until we get a bill that's worthy of the name "intelligence reform." And if that takes a little bit longer than some folks might like, so be it. This is too important to rush.

As for my relationship with members of my own party, let me tell you, I've got a good working relationship with many of them. And I'm not afraid to challenge them when I think it's necessary. But at the end of the day, I'm also a uniter, not a divider. And I'm going to work with those folks, even when we disagree, to find common ground and get the job done. Thank you.

Thank you for your questions. First, regarding Osama bin Laden, I want to assure the American people that we are working tirelessly to bring him to justice. We have intelligence assets and dedicated personnel working around the clock to track him down and bring him to account for his heinous crimes. While I do not have specific information on his whereabouts that I can share with you today, I can tell you that we are following every lead, every tip, and every shred of evidence to bring him to justice. We are working closely with our allies and partners in the region to ensure that we leave no stone unturned in this pursuit.

Regarding the detainees at Guantanamo, I understand the concerns about the status of these individuals and the delays in bringing them to trial. Let me be clear: the United States stands for the rule of law, and we are committed to treating all individuals, including detainees, with dignity and respect.

However, we are also dealing with a unique and difficult situation, where we have individuals who have been captured on the battlefield, many of whom are hardened terrorists who would stop at nothing to harm innocent lives. We have to balance our commitment to justice with our duty to protect the American people.

I want to assure you that we are working hard to establish a fair and just process for trying these detainees, one that balances our security concerns with our commitment to human rights. And I've called for the development of a system that would allow us to prosecute these individuals in a fair and expeditious manner, while also protecting the sensitive intelligence information that we gather.

We are actively engaged in discussions with the Congress on this issue, and we are committed to finding a solution that upholds the values that America represents, while also protecting the safety and security of the American people.

And I would add that our actions have been guided by the advice of the Attorney General and the Secretary of Defense, as well as the Department of State, to ensure that we are meeting our international obligations and upholding American values.

And I'd like to add, that, the criticisms of Guantanamo, I understand, but we've also saved lives. We've also prevented attacks, and we will continue to work hard to defend our nation and defend our values.

Thank you for those questions. You know, I... (pauses) ...I think history's gonna be kind to this administration. (smiling) Now, I know some folks are fixated on Iraq, and rightfully so, but we've been working on a lot of other important issues too.

Let me tell you, we've made significant progress on education with No Child Left Behind. We've reformed our tax code, making it more fair and pro-growth. We've protected America's national security through the creation of the Department of Homeland Security, and we've worked to support the spread of freedom and democracy around the world. I believe these are all lasting legacies that we're gonna be proud of.

Now, regarding your second question, (pauses) I'm not concerned about my role changing, I'm not worried about who's going to control the agenda. My focus is on continuing to lead this country for the next 16 months, and I intend to keep pushing my agenda forward, whether it's on energy, climate change, immigration, or healthcare.

Now, I know there are gonna be challenges ahead, especially with Democrats in control of Congress, but I've always said that I'm a results-oriented fella. I want to get things done for the American people, so I'll be working with the Congress to try to find common ground, where we can, and I'll keep pushing for my priorities where we can't.

You know, I've always said that I'm the decider, and I'll continue to decide what's in the best interest of this great country of ours. And I'm confident that, come '08, the American people will judge me and my administration on our record of action, and I'm proud of what we've accomplished so far. Thank you.

(in a deep, Texan-accented voice) Well, thank you for your question. I'm glad you asked that. Let me tell you, the situation in Iraq is a complex one, and it's a tough environment. Our commander, General (Peter) Pace, and I are on the same page. We understand that the Iraqi forces are making progress, but they still need our support and training. And let me tell you, we're committed to seeing this through to victory.

Now, as for passing on the fate of the war to the next President, I don't think that's the right way to put it. The American people expect us to see this mission through, to make sure that Iraq is a stable, free, and secure country. And that's exactly what we're gonna do. We're gonna continue to work with the Iraqi government, with the international community, to make sure that we achieve our objectives.

And to the Prime Minister's question, I think we've learned some valuable lessons from our experience in Iraq. One of the biggest mistakes, I think, was underestimating the extent of the insurgent threat, and the ways in which they would exploit the situation. But I think we've made adjustments to that, we've come up with a new strategy, with the surge, and it's showing real signs of success. We're also working hard to build up the Iraqi economy, to give people alternatives to the insurgency.

(The British Prime Minister, Tony Blair, steps forward)

Tony Blair: (in a British accent) Thank you, Mr. President. I think one of the biggest mistakes was not having a proper strategy for post-conflict reconstruction. We were focused on the military effort, which was necessary, but we didn't have a clear enough plan for what came next. And that meant that the vacuum was filled by some of the extremist forces that we're now fighting.

As for what we propose to do, I think we need to redouble our efforts on the civilian side, working with the Iraqi government to build up the institutions of state, to get the economy going, to improve the humanitarian situation. We also need to continue to support the Iraqi forces, to help them to build the capability they need to take on the insurgents. And we need to work more closely with the international community, to bring in other countries, and to get their help and support for the Iraqi people.

I think if we can do that, we can make real progress, we can start to see the end of the tunnel, and we can bring our troops home with a sense of pride and accomplishment.

Thank you, thank you for the question. I appreciate the opportunity to talk about our relationship with Benin and the important issue of cotton. 

During my visit, I did have the chance to discuss this issue with President Kérékou. I'm proud to say that we've made some progress on this front, and I want to thank the President and the people of Benin for their leadership on this issue.

As you know, the subsidies that the United States provides to our farmers can have a negative impact on cotton producers in countries like Benin. And I understand the importance of cotton to the Beninese economy, so we've been working to address this issue.

We've made some changes to our farm bill to reduce the impact of our subsidies on cotton producers around the world. And I'm also proud to say that we've increased our support for the Cotton Sector Improvement Program, which provides assistance to cotton producers in Benin and other West African countries.

However, I will also be the first to say that there's still more work to be done. The issue of cotton is still a sensitive issue, and we need to continue to work together to find a solution that's fair to all parties involved.

I'm committed to continuing to work on this issue, and I look forward to continuing our dialogue with the government of Benin and other interested parties to find a solution that benefits cotton producers in Benin and around the world.

[Laughter] Well, thank you, Mr. Kabagambe. I'm glad to be here alongside my friend, President Kagame. 

First, I don't think I'll be on the ballot in 2008. [Laughter] I think I'll be out of office, which will be a welcome change for some of the press corps, I'm sure. [Laughter]

However, I do believe the Republican Party has got a strong chance of winning the presidency. We've had a good two terms in office, in my opinion. We've kept the country safe, and the economy is strong.

As for the challenges, I think the next President will face some serious decisions to make on the economy. The economy is always something that's on people's minds, and I think there's concern about oil prices and the cost of living.

But I am confident the American people will continue to choose a leader who is strong on national defense and can keep our economy strong.

And I'm also confident that come November 2008, the American people will be talking a lot about who's got the most experience, who's got the best vision for winning the war on terror, and who's got the best plan to keep America's economy strong.

But I'm not going to be on the ballot, so it's going to be up to my successor as to see who that is.

Thank you for the question. I appreciate the opportunity to clarify our position on tax cuts. As I've said before, I believe that a rate reduction is essential to stimulating economic growth, and I'm committed to seeing it through.

Now, when it comes to the quick, short-term stimulus, I understand that Congress is considering various options. While I'm open to different approaches, I do think it's essential that we link these two initiatives in some way.

Ideally, I'd prefer to have a single package that includes both the rate reduction and the short-term stimulus. This would provide clarity and certainty for the American people and the business community, and it would ensure that we're taking a comprehensive approach to boosting economic growth.

That being said, I'm a pragmatic person, and I'm willing to consider alternative approaches. If Congress can provide a verifiable promise that they'll take up the rate reduction later, I'd be willing to consider that as well.

But let me be clear: the rate reduction is not optional. It's essential to our economic growth strategy, and I'll continue to push for it. I'll work with Congress to find a solution that works for everyone, but I won't compromise on our core principles.

And let me add one more thing. I believe that we need to move quickly on this. The American people are looking for action, and they're looking for leadership. I'm committed to providing both, and I'm confident that we can find a solution that works for everyone. Thank you.

Thank you for your question.  Well, I understand there's been some concern, and I want to address that concern right off the bat. We're not talking about privatizing Social Security. We're talking about giving people a chance to invest a portion of their money in the market, just like many federal employees do. It's an option, a voluntary option.

Now, in terms of the transition costs, I've asked the bipartisan commission we set up, led by Richard Parsons and James Baker, Mike Leavitt and others, to look at various proposals to address this issue. We're committed to exploring all the options to make sure that the transition is orderly and costs are manageable.

Now, we're not going to raise the payroll tax to cover this transition, as some have proposed. I believe that would be unfair to the American people. We need to be mindful of the burden on the taxpayer, and we'll work closely with Congress to figure out the best way to phase this in.

I also want to emphasize, though, that the current system is unsustainable in its present form. It's headed for bankruptcy, as the bipartisan commission has noted. We need to take action, or else we'll leave younger workers with a ticking time bomb of unfunded liabilities. This is a problem we can't afford to ignore.

So I'm committed to working with both parties to find a solution that will not only save and strengthen Social Security but do it in a way that's responsible, that doesn't raise taxes, and that strengthens the system for future generations. And I think we can do that, and I'm hopeful we can get there in a timely fashion.

Well, Mark, thank you for your question. I think it's a very timely and important question, given the evolving dynamics in the Asia-Pacific region. I'll start by saying that the United States views the rise of China as a significant development, and we're approaching it with a sense of realism and pragmatism.

While it's true that we have concerns about China's military modernization and its potential implications for regional security, we also believe that China's economic growth and integration into the global economy can have positive benefits for the region and the world.

Regarding Australia's role, I have to say that I'm very pleased with the state of our alliance with Australia. We've had a long-standing relationship built on shared values of democracy, freedom, and a commitment to stability in the region.

I believe Australia can play a critical role in managing the emerging relationship between the United States and China. As a respected and influential player in the region, Australia can help facilitate dialogue and cooperation between our two nations, particularly on issues such as counter-terrorism, non-proliferation, and regional security.

Furthermore, as a trusted ally, Australia can help us promote a more balanced and nuanced view of China's rise, one that acknowledges both the opportunities and the challenges that come with China's growth.

We value Australia's expertise and insight on regional matters, and we look forward to continuing to work closely with your country to address the complexities of the Asia-Pacific region.

I think it's also worth noting that our trilateral dialogue with Japan and Australia has been very helpful in coordinating our approaches to regional security issues, including China's emergence.

Thank you for your question. I appreciate the opportunity to clarify our strategy on troop levels in Iraq. The "stand up/stand down" policy remains a guiding principle of our approach, but I must emphasize that the situation on the ground is dynamic and ever-changing.

While we have made significant progress in training Iraqi security forces, the enemy is adapting and evolving as well. The numbers you mentioned, 294,000 trained Iraqi troops, are indeed impressive, but we must also consider the quality and capability of these forces, not just the quantity.

Furthermore, our military commanders and experts advise me that the situation in certain regions of Iraq, particularly in the Sunni heartland and in Baghdad, requires a sustained coalition presence to ensure stability and security. The Iraqi armed forces, as capable as they are, still require our support and guidance to tackle the insurgency and sectarian violence.

Make no mistake, we are committed to reducing our troop presence in Iraq as conditions permit. But we will not make decisions on troop withdrawals based solely on arbitrary benchmarks or timetables. Our decisions will be guided by the recommendations of our military leaders, the Iraqi government's readiness to assume greater responsibility, and the overall security situation on the ground.

So, I would not say that the goalpost is moving, but rather, we are continuously reassessing and adjusting our strategy to respond to the fluid situation in Iraq. And I'm confident that, with our continued support and the growing capabilities of the Iraqi forces, we will ultimately achieve our goals and bring our troops home.

I've been asked this question before, and I'll tell you, we were dealing with a very serious situation after 9/11, and the Attorney General, John Ashcroft, was indeed ill, and we were in a time of great crisis, trying to protect the American people.

I did authorize Andy Card and Alberto Gonzales to visit the Attorney General, and the reason I did so was to ensure that that program, which was a highly classified program, was continued, effective, and that we were able to continue to protect the American people.

Now, I'm not going to get into all the details of what happened that evening, and I'm not going to go into the classified aspects of this program. But I'll tell you this: it was a very emotional and trying time, and we were trying to get the job done.

As far as whether or not it was proper conduct, I stand by the actions that I took, especially in the post-9/11 era, to protect the American people. We were facing some very serious threats, and I'm not going to apologize for taking the actions that I took to try to protect this country.

It's also worth noting that the program was deemed lawful by the Justice Department. Now, I understand there may be some concerns and some differing opinions on this matter, but I believe that the actions we took were necessary, and they were constitutional.

In terms of the process, I will say that we have been very transparent in terms of the overall program, in terms of advising members of Congress of its existence, and explaining the rationale behind it.

Thank you for that question. I appreciate it. Look, I'm convinced that we've got a serious problem in Iran. They're a threat to peace, they're a threat to our allies, they're a threat to the stability of the region. And the world needs to take a strong stance, a united stance against this regime.

As for Israel, I've had many conversations with Prime Minister Olmert, and I'm confident that we're on the same page when it comes to diplomacy. We both understand the threat, and we both understand that we're working towards a diplomatic solution. Now, I'm not going to speculate on what Israel may or may not do, but I will tell you that we're working closely together on this issue.

Regarding the mixed messages from Iran, I think it's quite clear what's going on here. They're trying to confuse the world, they're trying to delay, and they're trying to avoid confronting this issue head-on. But I'm convinced that the world will not be deterred. We will continue to work through the United Nations, we'll work with the Europeans, we'll work with our other allies to address this problem.

Now, the Strait of Hormuz, that's a very serious business, and I think it's in the world's interest that this strait remain open. We'll take the necessary precautions to protect our interests, to protect our allies, and to ensure that the global economy is not disrupted.

So, we're taking a sober look at this situation. We're not going to be threatened by empty rhetoric from Iran, and we'll work to try to find a diplomatic solution that will bring this nuclear program to an end. That's our goal, and I'm confident that the world will see that this is a reasonable goal, a necessary goal, to achieve.

I understand the question, and I appreciate the opportunity to address this issue. As you know, I've made it clear that I'm concerned about the perception that my administration is not holding accountable those who have done wrong. And I want to assure the American people that we are committed to upholding the law and promoting a culture of integrity and accountability.

Regarding the pardons, I understand that there are differing opinions on the matter. As President, I take my responsibility to uphold the Constitution and the laws of the land very seriously. And I believe that, in this case, the pardons that were granted were done so in accordance with the powers vested in me by the Constitution.

That being said, I also recognize that there is a sense of disappointment and disillusionment among some Americans who feel that justice was not served in this case. And I want to assure those individuals that I understand their concerns. However, I also want to reiterate that the decision to grant pardons was made after careful consideration and consultation with the relevant authorities, including the Attorney General and the Justice Department.

As for the legacy of the sixties, I believe that it's essential for leaders to take a stand and acknowledge when mistakes have been made. And I'm committed to doing just that. I've taken steps to address the excesses of the past, including the Abu Ghraib prison abuse scandal, and I've made it clear that we will not tolerate any form of abuse or corruption in our government.

But I also want to emphasize that we must move forward, as I said, while acknowledging the past. We can't be held back by past mistakes, but we must learn from them and work towards a better future. And that's exactly what I'm committed to doing.

Well, thank you for your question. You know, I think it's essential to recognize that the Middle East is a complex situation, and it's been a complex situation for a long period of time. And, you know, I decided that it was necessary for the United States to take a step back and allow the parties to try to work some things out themselves.

Now, I don't think that was a mistake, but what I think is a mistake is to assume that either party is going to make the necessary sacrifices and commitments to get to the goal of peaceful negotiations without the United States' help. And, you know, we went through a period where we said, "Okay, we've crossed the Rubicon," with the Roadmap. 

And the President has taken the step of giving a speech announcing the Roadmap, and we've been working closely with our Arab friends, the international community, and here at home to see the process go forward. Today's speech is a reminder, again, of America's optimism - without any illusions that the road will be difficult and will go on for some time.

I do think our efforts are important, and you know, whether my successor remains as involved in the process, or if the level of detail - certainly the American setting of objectives remains consistent in assisting the parties managing to barrel down the - what is really tough road to achieve peace that creates a Palestinian State living next to the secure State of Israel, which is necessary under our judgment for peace overall.

Thank you for your question. I think it's fair to say that the situation on the ground has evolved, and as a result, our strategy has evolved as well. The notion of nation-building, as you put it, has taken on a different context in this particular case.

We have begun to think about what kind of government would be acceptable to the Afghan people. And I think that's the key. We want a government that is going to be acceptable to the Afghan people, a government that is broad-based, that is representative of the different factions, the ethnic groups, the different points of view within Afghanistan.

As for King Zahir Shah, we've had some contact with him. We have not made any decisions about what role, if any, he might play in a future government. We are open to listening to his thoughts and his ideas, but ultimately, the decision is going to be made by the Afghan people themselves. We're not going to impose our will on them, but rather, we're going to try to facilitate a process that will allow them to choose their own leadership, their own government.

Now, it's a difficult process, I understand that. Nation-building is not as easy as just walking into a country and saying, "Here, this is the kind of government we want." It's much more complicated than that. But we are going to work towards a broadly based government, a government that is acceptable to the Afghan people.

I also want to make it very clear that our goal is not to create a model democracy in Afghanistan. Our goal is to create a country that is no longer a haven for terrorists. And if we can achieve that goal, then we will have achieved a major victory in the war on terrorism.

Thank you for the question. I understand that there are concerns about the potential consequences of military action in Iraq, and I respect those concerns. However, I believe that the analysis you're referring to is incomplete, because it does not take into account the dangers posed by a Saddam Hussein who is allowed to retain his arsenal of weapons of mass destruction.

This is a man who has used poison gas on his own people, who has invaded neighboring countries and who has shown a willingness to cooperate with terrorist organizations. If we allow him to continue to possess these deadly capabilities, I fear that we will be inviting a catastrophe, not just for the Iraqi people, but for our own country as well.

I understand that there is always a risk of anger and resentment when the United States takes military action. But I also know that we have a duty to protect the American people and our friends and allies from the threats that Saddam Hussein poses. We will work to minimize the risks and to ensure that any military action we take is proportionate and just, but I am confident that the threat posed by Saddam Hussein is real, and that we must take action to address it.

And let me be clear: our goal is not to create new terrorists, but to help create a new and more peaceful and democratic Iraq, where the Iraqi people can live in freedom and security, without the shadow of Saddam Hussein's regime hanging over them. And I believe that if we succeed in that effort, it will be a major blow to the forces of terrorism and a major step forward for the security and stability of the world.

Well, thank you for the question. I believe that faith played a significant role in this election, and I'm grateful for the support I received from people of faith across the country. But I also understand and respect that we are a diverse country, and people have different beliefs and values.

Now, I want to assure the American people that as President, I'm committed to preserving the separation of church and state. I believe in the Founding Fathers' vision of a faith-filled country, where people are free to worship as they see fit, but also where the government doesn't impose its will on the people.

To those who are concerned about the role of faith in public life, I want to assure you that I will be a President for all Americans, regardless of their faith or background. My policies will be guided by my commitment to the Constitution, my principles, and the values of justice, compassion, and freedom that unite us as a people.

I also want to say that faith is not just about what you do on Sunday, but also about how you live your life and make decisions every day. My faith informs my values, but it does not dictate my policies. I will work to find common ground and build bridges across the divide, and I will be a President who respects and honors the diversity of our great nation.

And let me add, I think it's interesting that the media often focuses on the role of faith in this campaign, but I think it's equally important to note that my opponent, Senator Kerry, also spoke about the importance of faith in his life and campaign. So, I think this is an issue that transcends party lines and is a part of our national conversation.

Thank you, and I'd be happy to take the next question.

Thank you for the question. Let me address the issue of withdrawal from Iraq. We're making good progress in Iraq, and we're working closely with the Iraqi government to ensure a successful transition. As you know, we've been transferring authority to the Iraqi security forces, and they're becoming increasingly capable of defending their own country.

Now, regarding the issue of a withdrawal timeline, I've made it clear that our policy is to succeed and to get the job done. We're not setting a specific deadline for withdrawal, but we do expect to reduce our troop levels as the Iraqi security forces become more capable.

Regarding the visit of Secretary Rice, I can assure you that we're committed to supporting the Iraqi government as they move towards democracy and self-governance. We believe in the importance of the sovereignty of Iraq, and we're not trying to pressure them in any way. Our goal is to help the Iraqi people achieve their aspirations for a free and prosperous country.

Let me be clear: we're in Iraq at the invitation of the Iraqi government, and we'll continue to work with them to ensure a successful outcome. We're making good progress, and we'll continue to do so, but I want to assure you that our decisions will be made in consultation with the Iraqi government and based on conditions on the ground, not based on artificial timetables or deadlines.

I appreciate the question.  And I do agree, it's in our interests that we work together to promote peace and understanding in the world.  And I believe one way to do that is to reject the notion that there's a war between Islam and the West.  That is simply not the case.  The enemy we're fighting is a radical ideology that doesn't respect the rights of women, doesn't respect the rights of minorities, and is willing to use violence to achieve its objectives.

And so, yes, I believe we ought to be promoting the kind of dialogue and understanding that you're talking about.  And I think President Musharraf has been a valuable ally in these efforts, because he understands the importance of promoting a moderate, tolerant and inclusive form of Islam.

We, the United States, have done a lot of work to promote interfaith harmony.  We've got a lot of initiatives in place to promote dialogue between Muslims and Christians, and Jews and Muslims — all aimed at promoting understanding.

But I will tell you that I also believe that those who are advocating for violence and terror must be confronted.  And we will continue to do so.  But at the same time, we must promote a hopeful vision, a vision that says that all people have the right to live in peace and dignity, regardless of their religion or their background.

And so, I think it's a great question, and I think it's a noble endeavor, and I'm happy to be working with President Musharraf and other world leaders to promote this kind of understanding and cooperation.

Well thank you, I appreciate that question. Two years ago, I did indeed say that I was willing to invest political capital in the Israeli-Palestinian peace process. And I have. We've made significant progress, and I'm proud of what we've accomplished. The Roadmap for Peace has laid out a clear path forward for both sides, and we've seen some encouraging signs of cooperation.

Now, I do believe that a resolution to the Israeli-Palestinian conflict is linked to our broader goals in the Middle East, including our success in Iraq. A peaceful and stable Middle East will be more likely to produce a peaceful and stable Iraq. And that's why I've continued to push for a two-state solution, with Israel and Palestine living side by side in peace and security.

Now, I know that the situation in the Middle East is complex and multifaceted, and we still have work to do. But I remain committed to this effort, and I'm looking forward to continuing our discussions with all parties involved.

As for my upcoming trip to the Middle East, I'll be meeting with Prime Minister Olmert of Israel, as well as other regional leaders, to continue our conversations on the peace process and other key issues. I'm hoping to make further progress on the outstanding issues between Israel and the Palestinians, and to reiterate our commitment to a peaceful and stable region.

But I want to be clear: we're not just going to be jawboning, we're going to be working on tangible steps to move the process forward. We're going to be talking about specific actions that both sides can take to build confidence, to build trust, and to move us closer to a lasting peace. That's what the American people expect, and that's what we're going to deliver.

(first taking a deep breath) Well, I appreciate the question. Let me tell you something, the situation in Iraq is complex, and progress is not always linear. But I can tell you, we are making progress. The surge has helped to bring down sectarian violence, and we're seeing some encouraging signs from the Iraqi people.

Now, I know there's frustration about the benchmarks, but let's take a step back. These benchmarks were set by the Iraqis themselves, with our help, and they're making progress on some of them. It's not going to happen overnight, and I understand the impatience of the American people. But I also know that if we give up now, the consequences would be severe. We'd be abandoning the Iraqis to a bloodbath, and we'd be sending a signal to the region that we can't be trusted.

I'd like to correct you, by the way, Senator McCain did walk in the marketplace, but I think you should also note that there have been other cooperative efforts, such as the successes in Anbar province, where the Iraqis and the coalition have made significant gains against al-Qaeda.

I understand the skepticism, but I want to assure the American people that we're doing everything in our power to succeed in Iraq. We're adjusting our strategy as needed, and we're working closely with our allies and the Iraqis to find a way forward. And I'll make one promise: I will not abandon the Iraqis, and I will not abandon our mission to bring stability to that region.

I appreciate your question. I believe the progress we're making on climate change, it's a significant step forward. The Chancellor and I agree on the urgency of this issue. We're working together to find ways to address it. 

Now, when it comes to the instruments to get there, we do have a difference of opinion, and that's okay. That's what dialogue is all about. The Europeans, as you said, have taken a certain approach, and we respect that. In the United States, we've taken a more technology-driven approach, focusing on ways to reduce greenhouse gas emissions through innovation and voluntary action.

Now, I know some people might say that a voluntary approach will not work fast enough, and I understand that concern. But what I would say is that our approach has delivered some significant results. For example, our Methane to Markets initiative has led to a significant reduction in methane emissions worldwide.

Now, I'm not saying we've solved this problem yet. We still have work to do. But I think it's fair to say that we're making progress. The key is to find areas of agreement and work from there. And I'm committed to working with the Europeans and with other countries around the world to address this global challenge because, ultimately, we all share the same planet.

Well, I appreciate your question, and I'll try to give you a straight answer. I do want to say that this administration, like all administrations, has a strong commitment to protecting classified information, including the identities of our brave men and women who serve in the intelligence community.

Now, regarding the matter at hand, I want to say that I have considered this matter very carefully. I understand that this has been a topic of concern for some time now, and I've thought about it a great deal, not just as President, but as Commander-in-Chief.

While I understand the particular circumstances that led to the disclosure of Valerie Plame's identity, I must say that I am disappointed – yes, I am disappointed – that we were not able to protect her identity, and that seems to be the end of it.

Now, with regard to the question of the behavior of senior officials, I've got to say that this issue has been looked into, and it's been looked into extensively. As for what I've said to my senior officials, I think the American people understand that I had to consider all of the options available to me to handle the problems that were put at my doorstep. I can assure you that my senior officials and I are fully committed to our obligations to our people who work in the intelligence community, and we will continue to take steps to ensure that those secrets are kept.

In terms of what I would say now in relation to different aides, I'm not going to tell everybody in public what I may have said in private. I just can't do that. But I can assure you that I've heard from the investigative agencies, and they did review, indeed, all the facts pertinent to this in reaching the conclusions they reached.

Thank you for the question. I appreciate the opportunity to clarify my administration's position on this important issue. 

First of all, let me say that I'm proud of the energy legislation we signed yesterday. It's a significant step forward in our efforts to reduce our dependence on foreign oil, increase energy efficiency, and address climate change. And I want to commend Speaker Pelosi and Senator Reid for their hard work in helping us get this bill across the finish line.

Now, regarding California's request to implement its own plan to restrict tailpipe emissions, I understand the state's desire to take bold action on climate change. And I appreciate Governor Schwarzenegger's leadership on this issue. However, our decision to deny California's waiver request was based on our concern that a patchwork of different state standards would create confusion, duplication, and ultimately, undermine our ability to address this issue at the national level.

As President, I believe it's my responsibility to ensure that we're taking a comprehensive and coordinated approach to addressing climate change. And that's why we've been working to develop a federal strategy that will provide a clear and consistent framework for reducing greenhouse gas emissions.

Now, regarding my conversation with Vice President Gore, I can tell you that we had a productive and respectful discussion about climate change. We agree that it's a serious issue that requires immediate attention and action. However, we also have some differences in our views on how to address it. As you know, Vice President Gore has been a vocal advocate for more aggressive action on climate change, and I respect his passion on this issue. But as President, I have to consider a wide range of perspectives and interests, and make decisions based on what I believe is in the best interest of the American people.

Let me be clear: addressing climate change is a priority for my administration. And I'm committed to continuing to work with Congress, state leaders, and the international community to find solutions that will reduce our greenhouse gas emissions and promote a more sustainable energy future. Thank you.

Thank you, thank you very much. I'm honored to be here in Benin, and I'm glad to be the first president to make this trip. I think it's a significant moment in our relations, and I don't view it as a stunt at all. In fact, I believe it's a manifestation of our commitment to the people of Benin and to the continent of Africa.

As you mentioned, we've had a long-standing relationship, but I think this trip marks a new chapter in that relationship. We're not just looking back at the past 47 years, we're looking to the future. And I believe that our partnership can help us address some of the big challenges that we face, whether it's HIV/AIDS, or economic development, or counter-terrorism.

One of the things that I'm most excited about is the opportunity to work together to improve the economic fortunes of the people of Benin. We believe that by increasing trade and investment, we can help create jobs and opportunities for the people here, and that's going to be a key part of our agenda during this visit.

But I also want to make it clear that this trip is not just about economics. It's about strengthening our partnership, our friendship, and our shared values. We believe in democracy, and we believe in the importance of human rights, and we're committed to supporting countries that share those values.

So, I don't think this is a stunt at all. I think this is a genuine effort to strengthen our relationship and to make a positive difference in the lives of the people of Benin.

Thank you, and that's a great question. Laura and I are thrilled to be here, and I thank the President of Benin for his hospitality. You know, as President of the United States, I've got to make some tough decisions, and one of those decisions is how to allocate my time.

First of all, let me tell you, our diplomacy is not limited just to my physical presence. We've got an active diplomatic corps all across the continent, working with leaders, working with civil society, working with people to advance the values of peace and prosperity.

But as the President, I do get to make some decisions on where I go, and when. And I decided to come to Benin because it's a country that is making progress. It's a country that's making a difference. And I wanted to come and not only express our support for the President, but also to encourage the people of Benin to continue on this path of reform.

Now, you're right, there are other parts of the continent that are struggling, and we're paying attention to those countries as well. Kenya is one example, and we're working closely with the Kenyan government to try to help them stabilize the situation and find a peaceful resolution.

In fact, just the other day, Secretary Rice was in Kenya, helping to facilitate a dialogue between the government and the opposition. And we're also providing humanitarian assistance to those who are affected by the conflict.

So, it's a balancing act, it's a tough decision, but I believe that by coming to Benin, we're not only celebrating success, we're also sending a message to the rest of the continent that we care, that we're engaged, and that we're committed to helping those who are committed to peace and prosperity.

And that's a message that I think resonates not just in Benin, but across the continent. And so, that's why I'm here, and that's why I'm glad to be here. Thank you.

(smiling) Ah, Buenos dias, it's a pleasure to have you here from Mexico City. I'm happy to address this issue, and I'll start by saying that the United States and Canada have a long-standing relationship when it comes to energy, and we're exploring ways to expand that cooperation to the rest of the hemisphere.

In terms of a hemispheric-wide energy plan, I believe we need to start by recognizing the diversity of energy resources across the Americas. We have significant oil and gas reserves in North America, and of course, there are also important energy resources in Central and South America.

What we envision is a system where energy can flow freely across borders, where it can be transmitted and traded in a way that's transparent and efficient. We want to promote a culture of cooperation and coordination among energy producers and consumers.

Now, we've already taken some important steps in this direction. Prime Minister Chretien and I have established a bilateral working group to explore ways to expand energy trade between the United States and Canada. And through the Organization of American States, we're working with other countries in the hemisphere to develop a set of principles for a hemispheric energy strategy.

That strategy will focus on a few key areas, including promoting greater transparency and stability in energy markets, encouraging investment in energy infrastructure, and supporting research and development in new energy technologies.

In terms of commitments, we're already working together with Mexico on a number of energy projects, including a planned pipeline that will transport natural gas from Mexico to the southwestern United States. And we're also exploring ways to expand cooperation with other countries in the hemisphere on energy research and development.

Now, I know that for such a plan to be equitable, it needs to benefit all partners, producers and consumers alike. That means we need to ensure that we're not just talking about energy exports, but also about energy access and energy security. We want to make sure that countries across the hemisphere have access to reliable, affordable energy, which is essential for economic development and poverty reduction.

Prime Minister Chretien, would you like to add anything to that?

Thank you for that question. First, let me clarify my position on this piece of legislation. The Partial-Birth Abortion Ban Act is a crucial step towards upholding our nation's values and protecting the sanctity of human life. This procedure is, in my view, particularly heinous and should not be tolerated in a society that prides itself on being a defender of life and dignity.

Regarding the broader question of a complete ban on abortion, my position remains steadfast. I do believe that there are certain circumstances under which abortions should be permitted, such as in cases of rape, incest, or when the life of the mother is at risk.

However, I also believe that we, as a nation, have a duty to work towards a culture that values life in all its forms, from conception to natural death. And so, I will continue to support and advocate for policies that promote this goal, such as encouraging adoption, providing support for pregnant women, and ensuring that our young people have access to quality education on the value of human life.

Now, regarding the case of Terri Schiavo, I'll just say this: I do believe that my brother, Governor Jeb Bush, was right to sign legislation that helped to ensure that Terri's case received the attention it deserved. It is, in my view, our duty as public officials to protect the most vulnerable members of our society, and in this case, that meant intervening to ensure that Terri's wishes, as expressed by her husband, were respected and carried out in a humane manner.

However, I also want to acknowledge that this was a deeply difficult and complex case, and I believe that my brother's decision was made in good faith, with the best interests of Terri Schiavo in mind. Thank you.

Well, thank you for your question. First of all, let me make it clear that our position is that Saddam Hussein is a prisoner, a prisoner of the Iraqi people, and he will face justice. We'll let the Iraqi authorities handle his case, but the idea of negotiating with him, I think, is pretty much a moot point.

He's got one choice, and that is to cooperate with the Iraqi authorities and to face the justice that he so rightly deserves. I mean, this is a man who has been responsible for the death of hundreds of thousands of people. The idea of negotiating with him, I just don't think is a realistic possibility.

Now, regarding the greeting, I think it's an interesting little anecdote, but I think it's been overplayed a bit. My message to him, if I had to give one, would be: 'You've been found; justice will be served.' That's about all he needs to know from me.

Well, thank you for the question. I appreciate it. The situation in Iraq is complex, and I understand that there are different views on the ground. Let me try to help clarify. The Vice President, Dick Cheney, and I are in constant communication with our top commanders, including General Abizaid. We have regular briefings, and I can assure you that we receive accurate and timely information about the situation on the ground.

Now, I understand that there may be some discrepancy in the characterization of the insurgency. I think what the Vice President was trying to say is that the enemy is being actively pursued and engaged by our brave men and women in uniform. The insurgents are using tactics that are desperate, and that's a sign of their frustration.

On the other hand, General Abizaid and other commanders are looking at the situation from a different perspective. They're looking at the day-to-day realities on the ground, and they're seeing that the insurgency is still a force to be reckoned with. And I agree with them on that.

So, I don't think there's a disagreement between the administration and the commanders. I think there's a nuanced understanding of the situation, and we're working together to make sure that our strategy is sound and that we're making progress.

But let me make one thing clear: we will not be deterred by the insurgents. We will not be deterred by the naysayers. We will continue to work with our allies, we will continue to work with the Iraqi government, and we will continue to pursue the enemy until we achieve our goals.

And I'm proud to say that we're making progress, despite the difficulties. We're making progress in training the Iraqi security forces, we're making progress in rebuilding the economy, and we're making progress in bringing hope and freedom to the Iraqi people.

So, I hope that helps to clarify the situation. Thank you for the question.

Well, thank you for the question. Let me just say that I understand the concerns of the American people when it comes to high gas prices. I was concerned about the price of gasoline in 2001, too, and that's why we proposed a comprehensive energy plan that had a number of different elements to it.

First of all, I think it's important to note that our energy policy was designed to address a number of different challenges. We were concerned about the reliability of the grid, we were concerned about the lack of refining capacity, and we were concerned about the need to diversify our energy mix.

Now, I know that some people suggested that we should have pushed for higher CAFE standards. I think the CAFE standards we did put in place have been effective in encouraging the American automobile manufacturers to produce more fuel-efficient vehicles. And I'm proud of the fact that we were able to get an increase in the CAFE standards for our nation.

I do think, however, that one of the most promising areas is in the area of alternative fuels, and that's why we've invested heavily in research and development of new technologies, such as cellulosic ethanol, hydrogen fuel cells, and biodiesel.

Now, I don't think that higher CAFE standards alone would have cured the problem of high gasoline prices. The fact is, the price of gasoline is set on the global market, and it's influenced by a whole range of factors, including the demand for oil from rapidly growing economies like China and India.

So, I think our approach was a comprehensive one, and I think it's laid the foundation for the U.S. to become more energy independent over time.

Thank you for your question. I appreciate it. As you know, I'm looking forward to going to the U.N. next week, and I will, indeed, be discussing the situation with Iran and our concerns about their nuclear program and their support of terrorism.

Now, with regard to the situation in Iraq, I'm glad you brought it up. We've made a big decision in Iraq, a tough decision, to help the Iraqi people achieve democracy and freedom. I understand that there's been criticism. I respect criticism. But I also want to remind people that the decision I made was made in the best interests of our country and the world, to say that we'll spread democracy and freedom into parts of the world that are desperate for it.

And the fact that we're in Iraq, fighting against al-Qaeda, will make it easier for us to deal with the Iranians, not harder. And I'm looking forward to, you know, having some discussions with leaders around the world about this issue.

Now, regarding Prime Minister Maliki's trip to Iran, I think it's vital to understand that the Prime Minister of Iraq's got a lot of leeway, and he needs to make decisions that are in the best interests of his country. I didn't have direct conversations with him before he went, but I do know that we have the same goal in mind - which is a stable Iraq. And I'm optimistic that we'll be able to achieve that goal, despite some ups and downs.

It's also worth noting that our message on Iran is very clear. We're not isolated; the international community shares our concerns about Iran's nuclear program. And we'll work together to achieve a collective goal - and that's a free, independent Iraq and a Iran that's not a threat to its neighbors.

Let me just say this, the world has spoken clearly on this issue. The Security Council has sanctioned Iran. I'm confident that we can work through our differences to achieve our common goals. We're committed to a diplomatic effort, but we will not back down. And I believe we can resolve this peacefully, but it's going to require the international community to be steadfast in their commitment to the principles we've established.

(pausing for a moment, choosing my words carefully) Well, I appreciate the question. I understand that there are critics, and that's part of democracy. But I believe our strategy in Iraq has been sound, and it's a complex situation. We've made some tough decisions, and we've had to adjust along the way.

Now, on the issue of troop levels, I relied on the advice of my generals, and we made a conscious decision to keep our troops on the ground to a minimum, with the goal of getting the Iraqi army trained and taking over. And I still believe that was the right call.

Regarding Al Qaida, we knew that they would try to exploit the situation, and we've been working to stop them. We've got a strong partnership with the Iraqi military, and we've seen successes in Anbar Province and other areas where the enemy's been pushed back.

As for the Iraqi government, we've been working closely with Prime Minister Maliki to build up the Iraqi army and police forces, and we're seeing progress. It's not easy, I know. But I have faith in the Iraqi people's desire for freedom and democracy.

Now, I know there are doubts about our strategy, but I can assure the American people that we've got a plan in place for victory. We're pursuing a dual-track approach - security and politics - and we're seeing signs of hope. The surge has shown us that with the right strategy and resources, we can make progress.

So, I understand the skepticism. But I believe we're making headway, and I'm optimistic that, with time, patience, and determination, we will succeed in Iraq.

(pausing for a moment) Well, I appreciate the question. I think it's fair to say that, first and foremost, I still believe in the decision we made to go into Iraq. We were dealing with a tyrant, Saddam Hussein, who had invaded his neighbors, who was sponsoring terrorist groups, and had openly defied UN resolutions.

Now, I do understand that there have been some difficulties, some unexpected challenges, some tough fighting in Iraq. But I firmly believe that we made the right decision to take out Saddam Hussein. We took out a ruthless dictator, and we're now helping the Iraqis build a democracy.

Now, that being said, I am always a man who thinks about the lessons learned. I've had discussions with our generals, with our diplomats, and with my advisors on ways we could improve the situation. But I still believe that we did the right thing.

Regarding Afghanistan, I would argue that we did concentrate our efforts on Afghanistan initially. Remember, we took out the Taliban in '01. And we took out Al-Qaeda's sanctuary. And we've continued to work diligently with NATO, with our allies, to rebuild that country.

However, I do think that the rise of the Taliban, nearly six years later, is a serious challenge. We need to make sure we've got the right balance of efforts in Afghanistan and in the broader War on Terror.

On the Lisbon Treaty, I think it's a bit early for me to comment. I think you should be asking the European leaders about that one. I'll leave that to them. (laughs)

Well, I think it's a little misleading to say that my decision was based solely on emotion. That's not what Andy Card said, and I think there's been a little bit of twisting of words there. What I've tried to do is make a decision based on what's in the best interest of the American people.

The Kyoto Protocol, as it was negotiated by the previous administration, was not in the best interest of our economy. It didn't take into account developing nations that are beginning to grow and are a huge part of the problem when it comes to CO2 emissions. And it also didn't take into account the flexibility and the creativity of the American people to come up with new technologies.

So, I think the decision was based on practicality and doing what's best for the American economy. Did I get frustrated, perhaps, with some of the rhetoric coming out of Europe and other places? Yes, I did. I think there's a lot of posturing, a lot of grandstanding. I think it's not in the best interest of our relations to make grand statements without backing them up with real deeds.

I've said I'm committed to reducing greenhouse gas emissions. And I think I've taken a step in a wise way. I don't think it's wise to sign a treaty that's not going to work. I think we need to work with our allies, though, and I think we will work with them on a practical solution that makes sense, not only for America, but for the world.


I'm sorry, next question.

"Thank you for your questions. We are making progress on the anthrax investigation, but it's still an ongoing process. I'm not at liberty to discuss classified information, but I can assure the American people that we're working diligently to find those responsible for these heinous attacks. As for foreign interests, I would not speculate on any connections at this time, but rest assured we are exploring all avenues.

Regarding the situation in Afghanistan, I can confirm that our military operations have begun. We've taken steps to strike at the Taliban and al-Qaeda training camps, and to disrupt their ability to plan and carry out attacks. But let me be clear: this is a long-term effort, and it will require patience and resolve from the American people. We will take the time necessary to complete our mission, to disrupt and dismantle these terrorist organizations.

To answer your question, President Musharraf has been a strong partner in our fight against terrorism, and Pakistan has taken significant steps to stand with us in this effort."

Well, let me tell you, I was... (pauses, choosing words carefully) ...surprised, to say the least. The approval of those visas was a mistake, a serious mistake. As Commander-in-Chief, it's my duty to get to the bottom of it.

Regarding the credibility of the INS in their antiterrorism efforts, I want to assure the American people that we're taking immediate action to rectify the situation. We're conducting a thorough investigation into how this happened, and we'll hold people accountable for their actions.

In the short term, we're going to conduct a review of our visa approval process to ensure that it's as robust as it needs to be. We'll also be providing additional training for INS officials to make sure they have the tools and resources they need to make informed decisions.

In the long term, we'll be working to implement more advanced technologies and procedures to help identify potential threats before they get to our shores. We'll also be working with our international partners to share intelligence and best practices in the fight against terrorism.

But let me tell you, I am committed to making sure that the American people are protected, and we will learn from this mistake. We will get it right, and we will not let our guard down in the fight against terrorism.

(pausing for a moment) Well, let me tell you, I appreciate your question. I think it's an opportunity for me to clarify my involvement with Harken Energy. (clears throat) As a member of the board of Harken, I was not directly involved in the day-to-day operations, but I did serve on the audit committee. Now, regarding the sale of Aloha Petroleum, I can tell you that it was a complex transaction, and I relied on the advice of our accountants and auditors.

As for the SEC's requirement for Harken to restate its earnings, I understand that the company had to rectify some accounting issues. However, I must emphasize that I was not aware of any intention to create a phantom profit or to hide losses. I relied on the expertise of our financial advisors, and I was not involved in the detailed discussions and negotiations surrounding the transaction.

Now, with regard to my credibility on corporate responsibility, I can assure you that I take these issues very seriously. As President, I'm committed to promoting transparency and accountability in corporate America. While I may have made some mistakes in the past, I've always acted in good faith, and I've learned from my experiences. I believe my record on corporate responsibility, including my support for the Sarbanes-Oxley Act, speaks for itself.

So, I hope this clarification helps to put this matter into perspective. I'm happy to answer any further questions you may have. (smiling)

Well, I appreciate you bringing up Teddy Roosevelt's words. He was a great leader and a strong voice for the American people. I think it's true that in every era, there are those who would seek to use their wealth and power to undermine the system and hurt the average citizen.

Now, I believe that corporate America is an integral part of what makes our country strong, but I also believe that it's the responsibility of the government to protect the American people from those who would abuse that power.

My administration is committed to enforcing the laws on the books and making sure that those who break them are held accountable. We've also taken steps to increase transparency and accountability in corporate America, from the Sarbanes-Oxley Act to our efforts to strengthen the SEC.

Now, I don't think it's a question of one or the other - do the people rule, or do corporate organizations rule? I think it's a both-and proposition. We need to create an environment where corporate America can thrive, but also where the American people are protected from abuse.

As for my own approach, I'd say it's a straightforward one: I'll work with anyone who's willing to work with me to make America a better place for all its citizens. And I'll oppose anyone who tries to undermine the interests of the American people.

So, I'd say we share a common goal with Teddy Roosevelt - to make sure that this country is run by and for the people, not just the special interests. But I think we can do that in a way that's consistent with our values of freedom and competition, and that's what I'll strive to do as President.

Well, I appreciate the enthusiasm of my conservative friends, and I appreciate their support. But I also understand that we've got a great responsibility to reach out to the other side of the aisle and to work in a bipartisan fashion. I believe that's what the American people expect of us.

Now, I do think it's time to address the issue of Social Security. I think it's a very serious issue, and I think we've got to make sure that the promises that have been made to America's seniors are kept. But I also think we've got to think about the next generation. And so, I've made it clear that I want to work with the Congress to create a system that's sustainable for the long-term. And I think personal accounts are an important part of making sure that Social Security is around for future generations.

On the issue of judges, I'm disappointed that some of my nominees were rejected by the Senate. But I believe that it's my duty, as the President, to continue to put forward nominees who share my vision of interpreting the laws as written. And I hope that the Senate will take a look at some of the nominees that I've put forward and give them a fair hearing.

On the issue of abortion, I believe that we can find common ground and we can work together to reduce the number of abortions in our society. I've always said that I'm a pro-life President, but I also understand that there are differences of opinion on this issue. And I'm willing to work with anybody who's willing to find common ground and make sure that we're promoting a culture of life in America.

And finally, on tax reform, I'm a big believer in simplifying the tax code, making it fairer for American taxpayers, and reducing the number of tax expenditures that discourage investment and job creation. But I've also got to be mindful of the fact that we've got to keep reducing the deficit, which is a serious challenge for our nation's economy.

So, all these issues, I think, are important, but they've got to be addressed in a responsible and a bipartisan fashion. And that's what I intend to do.

Thank you for your question. I understand the concerns of both the Israelis and the Palestinians on this issue. Let me be clear: the United States supports the Israeli people and their right to security, but we also believe in the importance of a two-state solution, with the Palestinians having their own sovereign nation.

Now, regarding the issue of settlements and the security fence, I have indeed expressed my concerns to Prime Minister Sharon directly. We've made it clear that we do not support the expansion of settlements, as it can create obstacles to peace. The Roadmap to Peace, which we sponsored along with the international community, calls for Israel to freeze settlement expansion.

However, I must say that Israel has a right to defend itself against terrorism. The security fence is a response to that terrorism, and we understand that concern.

While I've not yet taken concrete action, I remain committed to pushing the parties towards a negotiated settlement and a peaceful resolution to this conflict. As the President of the United States, I'll continue to use diplomatic efforts to encourage both parties to work towards a solution that addresses their concerns and needs.

One thing is certain: the status quo is unacceptable. We need to move forward with the peace process. I'll continue to emphasize the importance of restraint, the importance of cooperation, and the importance of moving towards a peaceful resolution that results in two states living side by side, in peace and security.

Thank you for that question. I must say, I'm a bit tired of the pessimism from my opponent, always trying to trash the good news. Our economy is growing strong, jobs are being created, and Americans are more confident about their future.

Now, I acknowledge that we're not out of the woods yet. We've made significant progress on fiscal discipline, but we've still got more work to do. Our tax cuts have stimulated growth, and I believe they're a key part of our recipe for success.

As for my father's experience, I learned from it. He didn't get the credit he deserved for turning around the economy, and I'm determined to make sure that Americans know the facts about our economic record. We've taken steps to reduce the debt, and we're committed to keeping our promise to the American people to reduce the federal budget deficit.

Now, I'm not going to get into a lot of speculation about the campaign, but I will say this: we've got a strong story to tell, and we're going to tell it. And I'm confident that when the American people take a hard look at our record, they'll see that we're on the path to prosperity, and we're not going to let anyone – including my opponent – tear us away from that path.
