And one more thing: I think it's interesting that my opponent is spending so much time criticizing our economic record. I think it's because he doesn't have a compelling vision for America's economic future himself. We do, and we're going to keep pushing forward to ensure that every American can achieve their dreams.

I think it's a fair question. You know, as I said, we need to be idealistic in our drive for democracy and yet practical in our diplomacy. And I think you can have a situation where a country isn't exactly mirror-imaging American-style democracy, but is a peaceful factor in the neighborhood.

And that's why the definition of "success" is not only democracy, but is a government that responds to the will of its people and is a peaceful nation. And if we have a government that's willing to make peace, and the alternative is a government that is not willing to make peace and is hostile to the neighborhood, I think the latter is unacceptable.

Now, let me talk about Palestinian issues. I have said loud and clear that the Palestinians need to develop a democratic society. I also believe that Israel should have a partner in peace, and that partner must be a non-terrorist partner. We have to be careful about promoting democracy, and then having that person fail to deliver. The road map is a way to, I think, to provide some clarity of vision for both the Israelis and the Palestinians.

Thank you for your question. I appreciate that. (pauses) Well, first, I want to thank the people of Canada for their outpouring of support after the attacks of 9/11. It was a wonderful gesture, and I'll never forget it. I think it was a significant moment in our relationship, and I appreciate the display of friendship and solidarity.

As to why our peoples may be diverging, I think, well, first, it's natural that two separate and independent nations are going to have differences. (pauses) But I do believe that it's essential for us to continue working together to address the common threats that we face, like terrorism.

Now, I know there's been some disagreement on the issue of Iraq. I understand that the Canadian decision was not to join the coalition, and that's okay. It's a sovereign decision. But I also believe that we've got to work together on a lot of other issues – on trade, on energy, on security, on health issues. There's a lot of places where we can cooperate, and I believe we must.

(Pauses, and then responds to the request to include French)

Déjà, nous avons eu des désaccords sur la question de l'Irak, mais je pense qu'il est essentiel de continuer à travailler ensemble pour relever les défis communs que nous devons relever. Nous devons coopérer sur les questions de terrorisme, de sécurité, de santé et d'énergie. Il y a beaucoup d'endroits où nous pouvions coopérer, et je pense que nous devons le faire.

Thank you, Nick. First, I appreciate your question. I think the phrase "make poverty history" is more than just rhetoric from rock stars. I think it's a call to action from people who care deeply about the suffering of millions around the world. And I believe that it's a challenge that the developed world must answer.

Now, as for whether I believe it's possible to make poverty history, I do. I think we have the resources, we have the knowledge, and we have the will to make a significant impact on poverty. The question is, are we willing to use them? And I think the G8 has taken a major step forward in making those resources available through debt relief, through increases in foreign assistance, and through our efforts to promote economic growth and trade.

And now, on climate change... (pauses) Look, I've said it before, and I'll say it again: the jury's still out on the extent to which human activities are contributing to climate change. But I do believe that we need to take action to reduce our greenhouse gas emissions. We need to address the issue of climate change in a way that's science-based, that's economically sound, and that's international in scope.

As for my personal responsibility as the leader of the United States, I believe that I do have a responsibility to lead on this issue. And we are leading. We're spending more on research, we're investing in new technologies, and we're working with our international partners to address the issue of climate change. It's a tough problem, but I'm optimistic that with concerted effort, we can make progress and find solutions that work for everyone.

I understand the concerns of that woman from Cleveland, and the concerns of many Americans who are worried about the progress in Iraq. The violence we're seeing in Baghdad is unacceptable, and my heart goes out to the families of those brave Iraqi police officers who lost their lives.

But I want to remind Americans that we are fighting a war against terrorism, a fight for freedom and stability in a critical region of the world. It's not going to be easy, and it's not going to be quick. There will be setbacks and challenges along the way, but we cannot let the enemy dictate our strategy.

We have a plan to train and empower the Iraqi security forces to take the lead in the fight against the insurgents. We're making progress, but it's tough, and I don't deny that. The Iraqis are getting better every day, every week, every month. But it's tough.

To that woman from Cleveland, I would say: I understand your concerns, but I want to assure you that we are doing everything in our power to bring this war to a successful conclusion, to help the Iraqis build a stable and free society, and to protect the American people from the threat of terrorism. We're going to continue to work hard to achieve that goal, and I believe that we will succeed.

And I'd like to remind Americans that, while we've been in Iraq for a while, we've made tremendous progress. We've helped bring down a brutal dictator; we've helped establish a democratic government; and we're helping the Iraqi people build a better future. And that's something to be proud of.

So, I understand the frustration, but I want to reassure Americans that we're making progress, we're working hard, and we will achieve our goals.

The reporter has brought up some very grave concerns that have been on our minds for a long time. First of all, I want to assure the American people and our allies that we take these allegations very seriously. We're a nation of laws, and we'll make sure that those who have committed abuses will be held accountable.

In my conversations with the Prime Minister, I've expressed our commitment to upholding the highest standards of human rights, and we expect all of our personnel to adhere to those standards. We're a nation that values human life and the dignity of every individual. We've taken action to prevent such abuses from happening in the future, implementing new policies and training to ensure our military is held to the highest standards.

Regarding Haditha, we are conducting a thorough investigation into the incidents, and we will follow the evidence wherever it leads. We cannot comment on the specifics of the case, as the investigation is ongoing, but rest assured that justice will be served.

We are working closely with the Iraqi authorities and other international partners to ensure that our actions are consistent with our values and the rule of law. We recognize that we are not perfect, but we are committed to being a force for good in the world.

And to the Prime Minister, I'd like to offer a complement on the progress the Iraqi people are making toward democracy and self-government. We are allies in this fight, and we will continue to work together to build a brighter future for the Iraqi people.

(Turning to the Prime Minister) Your Excellency, would you like to add anything?

Thank you for that question. Immigration reform is indeed a crucial issue, and I've been working hard to address it comprehensively. I understand the concerns and the opposition in Congress, but I believe that with a bi-partisan approach, we can find common ground and move forward.

We're making good progress on a bill, and I'm optimistic about the prospects of passing legislation that will strengthen our borders, improve interior enforcement, and deal with the 12 million undocumented immigrants in the country.

Now, I know there are different views on how to approach this issue. Some people want to focus solely on border security, and I agree that's essential. We need to secure our borders, and we're working on that. We're increasing the number of border patrol agents, improving surveillance, and enhancing infrastructure.

However, I also believe that we need to address the issue of the undocumented immigrants who are here and have been here for years. We need to provide a pathway to citizenship that's fair, and it's earned. People ought to learn English, pay a fine, pay their taxes, and get in line behind those who have been waiting patiently to become citizens.

What's holding up the process right now is negotiating with members of Congress on the specifics of that pathway and making sure we've got the right balance between security and compassion. My staff and I are working closely with Senators, as you mentioned, from both parties to address their concerns and find a solution that can pass.

I'm confident that with a little bit of goodwill and a willingness to compromise, we can get a bill that the American people will support. It won't be a perfect bill, but it'll be a bill that makes our country more secure and our communities more just.

I want to assure the American people that I'm committed to getting this done. We're working diligently, and I believe we can get a bill on my desk this year.

Thank you for the question. Well, I believe that accountability is essential for effective governance, and we've implemented various measures across different sectors to ensure that.

Firstly, when it comes to education, we passed the No Child Left Behind Act, which requires schools to show student progress and improvement. We've also implemented measures to improve teacher quality and ensure that resources are allocated effectively.

In the area of national security, we've taken steps to reform our intelligence agencies to prevent the kind of intelligence failures we saw prior to 9/11. And we've also implemented reforms within the Department of Defense to improve our ability to respond to threats and protect our country.

Regarding the Libby case, I made the decision to commute his sentence after careful consideration and consultation with my team. While I understand the concerns about the decision, I believe it was a just one given the circumstances.

As for the Iraqi leaders, we're working closely with them to ensure they're taking steps towards democracy and responsible governance. We're also providing training and support to help them build their institutions and security forces.

In terms of holding people accountable, we've taken action against those who've failed to serve the American people well. For example, we've taken disciplinary action against officials at the Department of Justice who mishandled the US attorneys' dismissals.

Accountability is an ongoing commitment, and we're continually working to ensure that our federal agencies, programs, and policies are serving the American people effectively.

Thank you, thank you. Well, I appreciate the opportunity to address these important questions.

First, on the issue of the war on terror in Afghanistan, I want to start by saying that this is not a partisan issue. The safety and security of the United States, and indeed the world, is a bipartisan concern. As President-elect Obama takes over, I expect that we will have a productive and cooperative relationship in addressing the shared interests of our nation.

Now, I do believe that our strategy in Afghanistan, one that has been sustained over time, has been a successful strategy. We've made progress, but I also recognize that there's more work to be done. And I expect that President-elect Obama will bring his own perspective to this issue, and that's entirely appropriate.

As for whether Republicans will support his planning, I can tell you that we will always put the security of the United States first. And if the President-elect has ideas and proposals that we think will help achieve that goal, then we will certainly consider them, and we will be open to working with him to achieve our shared objectives.

Now, with respect to Pakistan, this is a critical relationship for the United States. Pakistan is a key partner in the war on terror, and we've had a long-standing relationship with them. I think it's very important that we work with the Pakistani government to address the issue of terrorist networks and sanctuaries within Pakistan.

I think it's essential that we use a combination of both diplomacy and military pressure to deal with this problem. I believe that our military forces have been working very effectively with the Pakistani military to address the issue of terrorism in the region.

But I also believe that we need to be mindful of the fact that Pakistan is a sovereign nation, and we need to work with their government to address these issues in a way that is respectful of their sovereignty.

To President-elect Obama, I would say that I think it's essential that we continue to work closely with the Pakistani government to address the issue of terrorism. I think we need to be firm, but we also need to be respectful.

And finally, I think it's essential that we continue to support the Pakistani people, who are struggling with many challenges, including poverty and extremism. We need to work with them to address these issues, and to help build a more stable and prosperous Pakistan, which is in the interests of all of us.

Thank you.

Well, thank you for the question. I'll address the first part of the question, and then I'm sure my friend, President Fox, will be happy to address the second part.

Regarding Fidel Castro's early departure, I must correct the notion that our government, the United States government, had any role in pressuring President Castro to leave the summit. That simply is not the case. We've had our differences with the Cuban government for many years, and I'm not surprised that there would be tensions, but I can assure you that we played no role in President Castro's decision to leave the summit early.

As for your second question, I think it's quite clear that a President of the United States, such as myself, would not have a meeting or encounter with Fidel Castro in the context of this summit. We do have a very deep disagreement, particularly with respect to principles of freedom and democracy.

Now, I think it's best if President Fox addresses the second part of your question regarding the relationship between Mexico and Cuba. Mr. President?

(Pauses for President Fox to respond)

Thank you for the question. I appreciate the opportunity to address this important issue. As you know, the security situation in Iraq is a top priority for our administration, and we're working closely with the Iraqi government and our coalition partners to ensure a secure environment for the upcoming elections.

Regarding troop levels, I'd like to emphasize that our strategy is to stand down as our Iraqi partners stand up. We're making good progress in training and equipping the Iraqi security forces, and they're increasingly taking on more responsibility for their own security.

That being said, we do recognize that additional support will be needed in the short term to ensure the security of the electoral process. The Pentagon is working on contingency plans to surge additional troops into Iraq, if necessary, to support the elections.

I'll tell you that we're looking at a number of options, but I don't want to speculate on specific numbers just yet. Our commanders on the ground are assessing the situation, and we'll make decisions based on their recommendations.

It's worth noting that the 6,500 troops you mentioned are currently serving in Iraq, and their extended tours will help ensure continuity and stability during this critical period. But we'll continue to assess the situation and make adjustments as necessary to support the success of the elections and the Iraqi people.

Our commitment to the Iraqi people is clear: we'll do what it takes to help them build a stable, secure, and democratic country. And we're working closely with our coalition partners to ensure that we've got the right strategy and the right resources in place to achieve that goal.

Thank you for your question. (pauses) Yes, I'm deeply concerned about the preparedness of our first responders and local governments to respond to a pandemic flu. The recent experience with Katrina and Rita has highlighted the need for improved response capabilities and better coordination between federal, state, and local authorities.

We took a hard look at our preparedness, and I was not satisfied with what I found. Our public health infrastructure is not where it needs to be, particularly when it comes to distributing and administering vaccines, antivirals, and other medical countermeasures in a timely manner.

That's why I've directed Secretary Leavitt to develop a comprehensive national strategy to deal with a pandemic flu. We need to make sure our first responders, hospitals, and healthcare systems are equipped to handle a surge of patients.

Now, regarding the use of defense assets, I think it's a good idea. We need to be prepared to respond quickly and flexibly in the event of a pandemic. That may involve using military assets to support state and local responders, such as airlifting supplies, people, and medical equipment. We can draw on the expertise and resources of the Department of Defense to augment the civilian response efforts.

But let me be clear: our first priority is to support the states and local governments, not to supplant them. We want to work closely with them to build their capacity, share intelligence, and ensure that we're coordinating our efforts effectively.

So, we're working hard to get our act together, but I must say that there's still much to be done. We're not yet where we need to be in terms of our preparedness. (pauses) And that's why we're pushing forward with this effort. Thank you. Next question, please.

I appreciate that question. You know, it's a tough situation, but I want to assure the American people that our goal remains the same: a stable, secure, and democratic Iraq. We cannot and will not accept a disorderly retreat from Iraq. That would only embolden our enemies, give them hope, and undermine our own security here at home.

Now, regarding the sectarian violence, I agree that the situation is dire, but I believe it's still a bridge too far to say that a civil war is inevitable. The Iraqi people, we've seen, have shown remarkable resilience, and we are working intensely, side by side with our allies and with the Iraqi government to quell the violence, to train up the Iraqi forces to take on that responsibility.

We will not abandon Iraq to a sectarian conflict. I mean, what that says to me is, it says to the terrorists, you've won, and to the Iraqi people, you're on your own. We can't live with that.

Now, I've always said that we'll continue to adapt our strategy to the conditions on the ground. If things worsen, we'll reassess and make necessary adjustments. That's the hard work that Secretary Rumsfeld and the Joint Chiefs have been doing, along with Ambassador Khalilzad and others.

But we've got to stay true to our principles here: a secure, democratic Iraq is in our national security interest. We can't abandon our allies. We can't let our enemies prevail. And we can't leave until the job is done.

Make no mistake about it, we are working day and night, along with the Iraqis, to secure, stabilize, and rebuild their nation. And with our help, I have every confidence that the Iraqi people will prevail in this fight for freedom.

(in a thick Texas accent) Ah, thank you for your questions. First of all, let me make one thing clear: I have confidence in Attorney General Alberto Gonzales. He's a good man, a good lawyer, and a tireless advocate for the American people. I believe he has served this nation with distinction, and I will continue to support him. Now, I understand there may be some folks in the Senate who may have some questions, and that's perfectly fine – that's part of the process. But I'll tell you, I'm not letting speculation or speculation about a vote of no confidence get in the way of making sure that the Department of Justice is strong and running smoothly.

And just to clarify, I think there's been some confusion about the timing of Mr. Gonzales's role – we're nearly through the Bush Administration (indicating with hands). I would like him to be the AG for the remainder of the time.

Now, regarding the situation in Afghanistan, I am deeply concerned about the loss of innocent life, no matter who is responsible. As Commander-in-Chief, I recognize that the loss of civilian life undermines the progress we're making with the Afghan people and it is a real concern that the violence – terrorism, as you know, has no innocence to spare. We need to work with our international partners to minimize the loss of life and stay focused on our objective, which is to defeat the enemies of freedom and help the Afghan people build a free, peaceful society.

(nodding) Thank you for the question.

Thank you for that question. Let me start by saying that our relationship with France is strong and has been strengthened, as you've noted, over the past few years.  This is a sign that both of our countries recognize the importance of working together to address common challenges, such as the ones I talked about earlier, like Iran and Afghanistan.

Now, regarding Iraq, I want to make one thing clear: our strategy in Iraq is focused on success, and we will make decisions based on the conditions on the ground, not on artificial timetables. Our goal is to support the Iraqi government and security forces in their efforts to take control of their country, defeat the extremist elements, and build a stable democracy.

We are making good progress on that front, despite the challenges that remain. The Iraqi security forces are taking more responsibility for their own security, and we are adapting our troop posture accordingly. However, I want to emphasize that we cannot set a specific date for withdrawal of American troops without taking into account the ongoing situation on the ground.

Regarding France's potential help, I appreciate the support that President Sarkozy has offered, and we are working with our French partners on areas of mutual interest in the region. However, when it comes to the security challenges in Iraq, our allies, including France, have a role to play in supporting the Iraqi government and the international efforts to bring stability to the region.

But I want to make it clear that the United States will not be rushed into making decisions that would undermine the progress we've made. We will make decisions based on what is best for our national security, based on the advice of our military commanders and the progress on the ground, not based on domestic politics or artificial timetables.

Thank you for your question. I just met with President Clinton, and I appreciate his visit here, and I'm glad we could discuss a range of issues together.

Regarding the genocide in Rwanda, it's a stark reminder of the horrors that human beings can inflict on each other. And I agree with President Clinton's assessment that the international community, including the United States, could have done more to prevent this atrocity.

To my successor, I would say that the United States has a moral obligation to confront and prevent genocide, whenever and wherever it occurs. We must be prepared to act, using all tools at our disposal - diplomacy, sanctions, humanitarian aid, and in some cases, military force.

As for Darfur, it is a pressing humanitarian crisis, and the United States is committed to helping the people of Sudan. I did discuss Darfur with President Kagame today, and I assured him of our ongoing commitment to supporting the African Union's peacekeeping efforts in Darfur.

We will continue to work with our international partners, including the United Nations, to pressure the Sudanese government to accept a robust peacekeeping presence, and to provide humanitarian aid to the people of Darfur. We will also maintain our economic sanctions on Sudan, and consider additional measures to hold accountable those responsible for the atrocities in Darfur.

To President Clinton, I welcome his commitment to continuing U.S. engagement on Darfur.

You know, I think there's been some, uh, misunderstanding. Our position on missile defense has not changed, but I am pleased with the progress we're making on the, on the reductions in the nuclear arsenal. And, uh, I reiterate, we are willing to go forward with, uh, deep cuts in our nuclear arsenal, and that's what we've been discussing with the Russians.

Now, as for missile defense, I believe it's essential for the security of the United States and our friends and allies. We will continue to make our missile defense systems, to, uh, make sure that they're, uh, as advanced and as effective as possible. And I'm not going to be in a position to, uh, sacrifice national security, but I want to assure you that we are making good progress on reducing the nuclear arsenals, which we think will reduce the, uh, the likelihood of a, uh, nuclear arms race.

Now, I do want to assure you that we'll be pretty flexible on these matters. We want to make sure that we can work with the Russians to, uh, get, uh, a kind of mutually beneficial approach that enhances security for all of us. So, we'll be watching, uh, pretty closely how these matters evolve.

Thank you for that question. I appreciate the opportunity to talk about this critical issue. Let me start by saying that we're deeply concerned about the ongoing violence in the Middle East, and the fact that the peace talks have not yet begun is a disappointment.

We've worked closely with the parties involved, and we will continue to do so. We've been engaged in a number of initiatives, including our support for the Mitchell Report, which outlines steps that both sides can take to reduce tensions and create a more positive atmosphere for negotiations.

Now, I understand the calls for more U.S. involvement, and I want to assure the American people and the people of the region that we're committed to playing a constructive role. However, we cannot impose a solution on the parties. The parties must be willing to work together, and we're doing everything we can to encourage them to do so.

That being said, I believe it's time for a more intensive effort to get the parties to the table. We're exploring ways to do that, and we're discussing it with our international partners, including the Egyptians and others.

We'll be taking a more active role in the coming days and weeks, but I want to emphasize that our involvement must be constructive. We cannot dictate a solution, but we can help facilitate one. We'll be working closely with the parties, and I'm committed to doing everything we can to help bring about a just and lasting peace in the Middle East.

Thank you for your question. I'm not going to get into the specifics of the resolution just yet, but I will tell you that we are working with our partners in the United Nations to craft a resolution that deals with the threat posed by Saddam Hussein's regime.

We are pleased that Iraq has expressed a willingness to destroy the al-Samoud missiles, but we also know that this must be verified. We must be able to verify that these missiles are indeed being destroyed, and that Saddam Hussein is serious about disarming.

As for an ultimatum or a deadline, I think it's fair to say that we are running out of time. Saddam Hussein has had 12 years to comply with the resolutions of the United Nations, and he has refused to do so. So, we are at a point where we must consider all options, including the use of force, to disarm Saddam Hussein and to protect the American people and our friends and allies.

But let me be clear: the use of force is not the only option. We would much rather that Saddam Hussein would disarm, that he would comply with the resolutions of the United Nations, and that we could do this peacefully. But we will not be deterred from our mission to disarm Saddam Hussein and to protect our people.

Now, I also want to say that I think that the Prime Minister and I are in agreement on the importance of working together to achieve this goal. We have a strong partnership, and we are working together to craft a resolution that will address the threat posed by Saddam Hussein's regime.

And finally, let me just say that we will continue to work with our friends and allies, with the members of the United Nations, to craft a resolution that will be effective in disarming Saddam Hussein and in protecting our people.

Thank you for the question. I appreciate the opportunity to address this issue. First of all, let me say that the decision to go to war in Iraq was not taken lightly. It was a difficult decision, and I and my advisors deliberated extensively before making it.

Now, regarding the intelligence, I can tell you that the intelligence was clear: Saddam Hussein's regime was a threat to the region and to the world. We had evidence of his weapons of mass destruction programs, and we had evidence of his support for terrorism. I'm not saying it was a slam dunk, but there was no doubt in my mind that Saddam Hussein was a threat.

Now, I understand that the intelligence has been somewhat disputed, and I've asked for and received investigations into the intelligence. But I will tell you this: the intelligence community, on a bipartisan basis, looked at the same information and came to the same conclusion that I did, and that is that Saddam Hussein was a threat.

Now, did I rely too heavily on some sources? Perhaps. But I will not apologize for the decision to take down Saddam Hussein. I will not apologize for liberating the people of Iraq from a brutal dictator.

And I will tell you this: the world is a better place without Saddam Hussein. And I will tell you that I'm proud of the men and women who have served in Iraq, and I'm proud of the progress that we're making towards a more peaceful and stable Iraq.

Now, there's still work to be done, and I acknowledge that there have been setbacks. But I will not second-guess the decision to go to war.

I think that's all I want to say on that.

Good morning. Well, I think it's interesting that you bring up my own election in 2000. I think that's a good point, but let me tell you, I believe in the democratic process, and the state of California has set forth a system by which a recall can take place. And it appears that the people of California are going to participate in that process.

Now, I do have a relationship with Governor Schwarzenegger. I supported his candidacy in the past, and I think he's a good man. But I also believe in the integrity of the system. I believe that the people of California will make a very good choice.

I'm not going to get into whether or not I think the recall is legitimate. I think that's a matter for the courts to decide, and that's a matter for the people of California to decide. But I do think it's interesting that you bring up the fact that one individual has funded a good portion of the recall effort.

Now, I want to make it very clear that I'm not going to get involved in the election, but I do think it's interesting that the people of California are going to have a chance to choose a new governor, if that's the direction they choose. And I think it's a testament to the strength of our democracy that they have this option available to them.

But I want to make it very clear that my role as President is to stay out of this election and to work on the issues that face our nation. And I'm not going to get involved in the internal affairs of the state of California.

Well, thank you for your question. I appreciate it. First of all, let me just say that I'm committed to changing the tone in Washington. And I think that tone can be changed by working together to get things done. Now, regarding my statement in Texas, I was trying to draw a clear distinction between our approach to Iraq and that of the Democrats.

I firmly believe that our strategy in Iraq, while difficult and complex, is one that is based on a vision for a stable and democratic Iraq that is a key to a stable Middle East. The Democratic position, as I understand it, is one that can be interpreted as a pullback, which would embolden the terrorists and result in a region that is less free and less stable.

That being said, I think we can have good and respectful debates about the strategy in Iraq without resorting to name-calling or heated rhetoric. And that's exactly what I'm committed to doing during the next two years.

Regarding oversight and investigations, I believe that our administration has been and will continue to be fully cooperative and forthcoming with all the appropriate congressional committees and investigations. We have an obligation to the American people to be accountable for the decisions that we make and the policies that we implement.

But I will say this: we will work with the Congress to ensure that our national security efforts are not compromised, and that our administration and agencies can function effectively in carrying out their responsibilities. We're looking forward to working in a bipartisan way to get things done for the American people.

That's a perceptive question. Look, the date of September is a way for the Congress, the American people, and the international community to hold us accountable for progress. It's a benchmark, a way to measure success. I believe that General Petraeus and the Iraqi government will be able to make a clear assessment of the progress we're making.

Now, I understand what you're saying about giving the enemy a date to focus on, but I believe that the Iraqi security forces, along with our troops, are up to the task of handling whatever challenges the enemy throws our way. We'll continue to work with the Iraqis to improve their capacity to deal with the insurgency.

Regarding the phrase "a different configuration," I'm not sure I'd call it a "Plan B." What I am saying is that, as we assess progress, we'll be looking for ways to adjust our strategy to best achieve our objectives. We're constantly evaluating, adjusting, and refining our approach, and that's what I mean by "a different configuration." We're not going to be rigid, we're going to be flexible and adapt to the situation on the ground.

And I'd say that one of the things that's important for the American people to understand is that we're not just in a war against the insurgency; we're also in a battle of ideas. We're trying to help the Iraqi people build a stable, free society that's an ally in the war on terror, and we'll continue to adjust and adapt our approach to achieve that objective.

Thank you for that question.  Well, I think it's fair to say that Dmitry Medvedev is a bit of an unknown quantity, and I think it's too early to make any definitive judgments about his leadership style or how much power he truly wields, especially with President Putin still influencing from behind the scenes. But I do believe that Russia remains a significant player on the world stage, and our next president is going to have to take that into account.

Now, I know some folks have criticized my decision to look into Vladimir Putin's soul, and I'll admit that I was mistaken in thinking that he and I could build a strong personal relationship and trust each other. That didn't exactly pan out, did it? But I will say that I've always believed in engaging with leaders, even when we disagree, and trying to find common ground.

My advice to my successor would be to approach Russia with a clear-eyed view of their interests and our own. We've got to be realistic about the areas where we're going to compete, and we've also got to be willing to cooperate where our interests align. We need to be strong, but we also need to be smart.

And I think it's also worth noting that Russia's a country that's still in transition, still figuring out its place in the world. They've got a lot of challenges at home, from demographics to energy to terrorism. And so, I think it's in our interest to engage with them, to try to understand their perspectives, and to find ways that we can work together on issues of mutual interest.

But make no mistake, we also need to be clear and strong in our resistance to any kind of aggressive behavior or attempts to undermine our allies or our interests. We've got to be firm, we've got to be consistent, and we've got to be united, as a country, in our approach to Russia.

So, that's my two cents on this. I hope it's helpful.

Thank you for that question. First of all, I appreciate the Chancellor's candidness about his position on Iraq and the United States' position as well. We are, indeed, reviewing our options in regards to Iraq and considering a range of possibilities. However, I will not speculate on what those options might include at this time.

As for our goals, the United States' top priority is to disarm Iraq of its weapons of mass destruction. Saddam Hussein has failed to comply with numerous UN resolutions, and it's our firm belief that his regime poses a significant threat to the stability and security of the region, and potentially to the world.

We are also committed to promoting freedom and democracy in the region, and to seeing that the Iraqi people are able to live in a safer, more prosperous future. It's our hope that Iraq will become a partner in the region, and a member of the international community that respects the rule of law.

Regarding Germany's contribution to the fight against terrorism, I want to express my deepest gratitude to the Chancellor and the German people for their efforts. Germany has indeed shouldered a significant burden, and their support has been invaluable. The United States values our partnership with Germany, and we appreciate the cooperation we've received on a range of fronts, from intelligence sharing to military operations.

I'm satisfied with the progress we've made so far, but as you know, the fight against terrorism is ongoing. We'll continue to work closely with our German allies to ensure that we're doing everything we can to prevent terrorist organizations from plotting, planning, and carrying out further attacks.

Thank you, I'm glad to take that question.  The Jackson-Vanik amendment is a relic of the Cold War but an important one, as long as the Russian government is not fully respecting the rights of its citizens. And as long as restrictions in the Russian market remain, America's entrepreneurs will not see that Russia is a full partner in trade.

Now, with regard to the WTO, Russia's joining that organization is something America very much supports... (pauses) because we believe in the values of transparent-trade and fair play. The sooner Russia is in the WTO, and the sooner America is able, to use an old Texan saying, "get a deal done," and have a zero-tariff treatment with Russia the better off our citizens will be.

To the third part of your question, one of the priorities of any meeting, by the way Mr. Putin will be with me, as well as, Commerce Secretary Evans, so a commerce-delegation will be up here, is trying to be, to talking about a civil aviation, but we are willing to start the dialogue.

Well, I appreciate the question. Let me make it clear: our position on the settlements in the West Bank has not changed. We believe that Israel should take steps to ease the humanitarian situation in the Palestinian territories, and that includes taking a harder look at settlement activity.

Now, I understand that there are different interpretations of my speech, and I'm not surprised by that. But let me tell you, our message to Israel has been consistent: we want to see progress on the ground, and that includes addressing the issue of settlements.

Regarding Chairman Arafat, we've made it clear that we have concerns about his leadership. We believe that he's got to take more steps to fight terrorism, to reform the Palestinian Authority, and to be a partner for peace. But that doesn't mean that we're telling the Israelis to stay in the settlements. We want to see a peaceful resolution to this conflict, and that means taking steps on all sides to get there.

So, I wouldn't take my silence as an indication of a change in policy. Our policies are clear, and we're working hard to get the parties back to the negotiating table. We're working with all parties, including our friends in Israel, to make progress on the ground. And I'm hopeful that in the days and weeks ahead, we can see some positive developments.

And let me just say, we're not going to let the lack of progress in the peace process be dictated by the actions of one person. We've got to keep pushing for peace, and we've got to keep working with all parties to get there.

Thank you for the question. Let me tell you, America's vital interests are at stake here. The failure in Iraq would be a catastrophic defeat for the United States. If we were to fail in Iraq, it would embolden our enemies. It would hurt our reputation around the world. It would make it harder for us to work diplomatically on other issues.

This reconstruction aid package is not just about helping the Iraqis, it's also about helping ourselves. We're trying to create a stable and secure Iraq, which will allow us to reduce our military presence there and bring our troops home. We're talking about the chance to succeed, a chance to create a region that is peaceful and prosperous.

And I think the American taxpayer is willing to shoulder the burden, the financial burden, of this because they understand the consequences of failure. We're talking about a total of $87 billion for this fiscal year for the global war on terror, including this $20 billion aid package. That's less than one day's worth of the U.S. GDP per day.

This is an essential and necessary investment in our national security. And I believe the American people understand that.

Thank you for your question. I appreciate your opportunity to ask it. 

First of all, I want to express my deep condolences to the families of the two Americans who have been beheaded. These acts of brutality will not deter us, but they will only strengthen our resolve to bring those responsible to justice. The beheadings are a grim reminder of the nature of the enemy we're facing, and the evil they represent.

Regarding Al Zarqawi, I want to assure the American people that we are aggressively going after him, and our forces are working closely with Iraqi security forces to bring him to justice. It's a very difficult task, but I have every confidence that our military will ultimately succeed in apprehending or neutralizing him.

Concerning General Abizaid's comment, I appreciate his assessment, and I have great respect for the General. However, I want to emphasize that we are constantly reviewing and assessing our troop levels in Iraq to ensure that our forces have what they need to complete their mission. At the same time, our strategy is not solely based on numbers; it's based on a comprehensive approach that includes building the capacity of the Iraqi security forces, training them, and supporting their efforts to take control of their own country.

I believe our current strategy is working. It's a tough fight, but I have every confidence that our troops, our coalition partners, and the Iraqi forces will ultimately succeed in securing Iraq and bringing democracy to the Iraqi people.

Thank you. Next question.

The consequences I'm talking about are real, and they're immediate. I'm not just speculating about what might happen if Senator Kerry becomes President. I'm saying that the mixed messages he's sending right now are having an impact on our efforts in Iraq.

When American politicians talk about pulling out of Iraq, when they talk about abandoning our mission, it emboldens the enemy. It gives them hope that they can wait us out, that they can outlast us. And that's not good for our troops, it's not good for the mission, and it's not good for the Iraqi people.

Make no mistake, the enemy is listening. They're watching our television, they're reading our press, and they're hearing the mixed messages that are being sent. And that's why it's so important for us to stay united, to stay focused, and to stay committed to our mission.

As for the campaign, I believe that debating the war in Iraq is a legitimate part of the process. But I also believe that we have to be mindful of the impact that our words can have on the men and women who are serving overseas. We have to be careful not to embolden the enemy, not to undermine our troops' confidence in their mission.

So, to answer your question, I do believe that the mixed messages being sent by Senator Kerry are having a negative effect on our efforts in Iraq, right now. And I also believe that making the war in Iraq a part of the campaign has to be done in a responsible way, with an awareness of the potential consequences for our troops and for the Iraqi people.

I appreciate the question. You know, I believe that we can have a constructive dialogue, and I'm committed to doing just that. I think it's essential to separate politics from policy, and I'm willing to listen to their ideas and share my own. Now, I understand that we may have differences, but I'm a optimistic fella, and I believe we can find common ground.

On the issue of Social Security, I think it's essential to acknowledge that the system has a problem. We know that there's a structural issue that needs to be addressed, and I've laid out a plan to reform the system, to make sure it's solvent for future generations. I'm willing to listen to alternative plans, but I think it's essential to acknowledge that there is a problem.

Regarding the economy, I'm optimistic about the US economy, and I think our fundamentals are strong. I think we're well-positioned for future growth, but I'm mindful of the challenges we're facing. I'm committed to working with Congress to address these challenges and to ensure that our economy continues to grow and prosper.

Now, I know that there may be some folks who are more pessimistic about the economy, and I respect that, but I think it's essential to be realistic about the challenges we're facing and to work towards solutions. And I'm committed to doing that, and I'm committed to working with both parties to get the job done.

I think the American people expect us to put aside our differences and work towards common ground, and that's what I'm committed to doing.

(with a serious tone) First of all, I want to express my deepest gratitude to the men and women serving in our armed forces. Their selflessness and bravery inspire us all. Now, regarding the issue you raised, I'm not surprised that some of our troops may be expressing concerns or questioning the mission. We're in a tough fight, and we've faced challenges we didn't anticipate.

My commanders in the field, including General Petraeus, are constantly assessing the mood of our troops, and they tell me that while there may be frustrations and fatigue, the overwhelming majority of our troops believe in the importance of our mission. They're proud to be serving, and they know their service is making a difference.

As for the concern, I'd say it's a minority opinion. We have over 150,000 troops in Iraq, and a vast majority of them are doing their duty with honor and distinction. That being said, I do take these concerns seriously, because our troops deserve our support and our understanding.

We're doing everything we can to support our troops, to improve their quality of life, to provide them with the resources they need, and to make sure they're equipped to succeed in their mission. I've also made it clear to my commanders that we'll be rotating troops in and out of Iraq in a way that minimizes the impact on individual soldiers.

But let me be clear: we cannot let the enemy dictate our strategy. We're fighting a global war on terror, and Iraq is a critical front in that war. We're making progress, and we will not be swayed by the critics or the terrorists. Our mission is to bring stability to Iraq, to help the Iraqis build a free and secure nation, and to protect our own national security. And we will see it through.

(determined tone) Well, thank you for the question. I understand the skepticism, and I understand the frustration. But I want to remind the American people and the press that we are dealing with a very complex situation in Iraq. It's not going to be easy, and it's not going to be solved overnight.

First, let me say that I do believe the surge is working. The military progress we've made has been substantial. The sectarian violence has decreased, al-Qaeda in Iraq is on the defensive, and we are seeing some of the Sunni tribes turn against the terrorists. That's a positive development.

Now, regarding the benchmarks, I think it's essential that the Iraqi Government must demonstrate that they are capable of governing this country. They need to demonstrate that they can make tough decisions, that they can work together, and that they can take ownership of their own future.

One of the benchmarks that I've talked about is the passing of the hydrocarbon law, which will help to bring some sense of economic stability to the country. Another benchmark is the provincial elections, which I believe will give the Iraqi people a voice in their own government. And, of course, the amnesty law, which would help to bring some closure to those who have suffered.

But, let me tell you, I also understand that this is not just a matter of checking the box. We need to see real progress on the ground. We need to see real reconciliation among the Iraqis. And, we need to see the Iraqis taking steps to secure their own country.

It's also essential that, we, the international community, continue to support the Iraqis in this effort. We need to continue to provide them with economic assistance, with diplomatic support, and with military help, as needed.

So, it's gonna take time, it's gonna take patience, but I am confident that we can make progress. And I am committed to seeing this mission through to its completion.

(pausing)

And to the Iraqi Government, I say: "We believe in you. We want you to succeed. We're committed to helping you succeed. But, we need you to take the lead, to take ownership of your own future, to make tough decisions, and to work together to build a democracy that's worthy of the great nation of Iraq."

Good morning, thank you for the question. Let me be as clear as I possibly can be. We are reviewing the situation in Afghanistan, and it's a very serious situation. We are looking at all options, but I want to assure the American people that any decision we make will be based on recommendations from our military leaders on the ground, and we will choose the course of action that we believe best achieves our objectives.

Regarding the comparison to Iraq, I would say that each situation is unique, and we must approach them differently. In Iraq, we had to adjust our strategy because of the changing circumstances on the ground, and we did. The surge has been successful, and we're beginning to see progress.

Now, regarding Afghanistan, I agree with some analysts that the Taliban and al-Qaeda are resilient, and they continue to pose a threat to the people of Afghanistan and to regional stability. We're working closely with our NATO allies to address these challenges, and I appreciate the contributions they're making.

However, I also agree that more can and should be done by our allies. We need a shared commitment to success in Afghanistan, and we're expecting our partners to step up and do their part. We're not going to tolerate an uneven distribution of responsibilities in the fight against terrorism.

Now, as for the troop levels in Afghanistan, we're studying all options and taking into consideration our military leaders' advice. No decision has been made on troop levels, but any increase in troop levels would be because we believe it would enhance our ability to achieve our objectives, not as a substitute for our allies' commitments.

I hope that answers your question. Next question.

Thank you for that question. I share your concern, and I think it's a very valid concern. We've been very clear with the North Koreans about the need for full disclosure, and, quite frankly, it's taking too long. I'm disappointed, but I'm not surprised. We've seen this kind of behavior from the North Koreans before.

But we're going to keep the pressure on. We're going to continue to negotiate, and we're going to continue to push for that disclosure. And if we don't get it, we're going to have to consider other options. Now, I'm not going to speculate on what those options might be, but I will tell you that we're not going to tolerate this kind of behavior indefinitely.

As I've said many times before, we're committed to a six-party process, and we think that's the best way to achieve our goals. But we're not going to be held hostage by the North Koreans' stalling tactics. We're going to keep pushing forward, and we're going to keep working with our partners to achieve our objectives.

I think it's also worth noting that the other parties in the six-party process, including China, Russia, Japan, and South Korea, all share our concerns about the North Koreans' behavior. We're not alone in this. We're working together, and we're going to keep the pressure on, and we're going to get the results we need.

And I'd like to let Secretary Rice add to that.

Thank you for that question.  As you know, we've been working closely with our European counterparts, and I've had conversations with Chancellor Merkel, as well as other leaders, about the Iranian issue. We're all united in our desire to resolve this issue diplomatically, and we hope that Iran will take us up on our offer.

Regarding the specifics of what concessions they have or have not made is frankly not available to me, the way Dr. Solana has presented this offer, is a civilian nuclear program, for the most part. But as you know, the Iranians have made statements in the past that seem to contradict that pledge.

Now, if the Iranians reject our offer, we'll work with our allies to consider further measures to pressure them to make the right choice. Let me be clear: we're not taking any options off the table, but we also want to give diplomacy a chance to succeed.

In terms of specific measures, I'm not going to get into details at this point, but rest assured that we're considering all options, including sanctions, and we're working with our allies to ensure that we're speaking with one voice.

 Chancellor Merkel and I have discussed this issue extensively, and we share a common goal of preventing a nuclear-armed Iran. We'll continue to work together, and with our other allies, to achieve that goal.

But again, I want to emphasize that we're not at the point of taking further measures yet. We're still hopeful that the Iranians will make the right choice, and we're willing to work with them to achieve a peaceful resolution.

(in a Texas twang) Well, thank you for the question. I'm glad to be here in Northern Ireland, and I'm committed to helping the people of this great island achieve peace. Now, I understand the sensitivities around the issue of Sinn Fein and Gerry Adams. Let me make it clear: I abhor terrorism, and I abhor the targeting of innocent civilians. However, I also believe that in the pursuit of peace, one must be willing to engage with those who have been involved in the conflict.

Now, I'll be very candid with you: I've had disagreements with Gerry Adams and Sinn Fein on the issue of Iraq, and I think their opposition to our efforts to bring democracy to that region is misguided. But I also believe that our conversation today will be focused on the Good Friday Agreement and the progress that can be made in Northern Ireland.

Regarding the Democratic Unionist Party, I value my relationship with Ian Paisley and the DUP, and I appreciate their commitment to the peace process. I'll be meeting with them as well, although, understandably, my meeting with Gerry Adams is getting more attention today. (pauses for emphasis) I want to assure everyone that my goal is to support the peace process, and that means engaging with all parties involved, even when we disagree on other issues.

It's not always easy, but I believe it's essential for the people of Northern Ireland and for the cause of peace itself. Thank you. Next question, please.

(pausing for a moment, choosing my words carefully) Well, I think it's fair to say that there have been criticisms, and that's the beauty of a free society, by the way. But I also know that, particularly in a post-9/11 world, I have to be mindful of... the decisions I make. And I can assure you that, as the Commander-in-Chief... (pausing again) ...I was provided the best intelligence available to make informed decisions.

I would say that, in hindsight, there may have been things we could have done differently. I mean, every president makes decisions based on the information they have at the time. And as I said previously, I am proud of what we have accomplished in Afghanistan and Iraq, and the progress we've made in fighting the global war on terror.

As for WMDs in Iraq, we were faced with the threat of Saddam Hussein's regime and the intelligence provided by multiple agencies, including those from other countries. While it's true that we didn't find stockpiles of WMDs, Saddam Hussein's intent and ability to use them was very clear.

(postpausing, speaking firmly)

With respect to pre-9/11, I've answered that many times. We, my administration and the American people were shocked by the attacks that morning, and there's no question in my mind that intelligence failures occurred before and after. We have taken many steps to improve our intelligence capabilities to prevent another such attack from occurring.

(firmly yet calmly)

I would counter that to, perhaps, try to show we are making the best decisions possible, and be constantly vigilant. And I believe that is exactly what we've done.

Thank you for that question. You know, I think what's changed since 2000 is the attacks on September 11th. Those attacks served as a wake-up call for Americans, and for me, personally. It made us realize that the threat to our nation's security is not just about traditional state-to-state relations, but also about the ideologies that fuel hatred and entrenched tyrannies. And we understand now that it's not just a matter of our own security, but also about promoting liberty and democracy around the world.

As I said in my second inaugural address, it's a time of great change in the world, and we can be changed by it, or we can lead it. The choice is that stark. I believe that freedom is the alternative to ideology of hatred, and we must nurture it. And that's what changed since 2000. My views as a president since taking office have been shaped by the attacks, by the oath that I took to protect the American people, and by the realization that our own nation's security is linked to the spread of liberty around the world.

And let me just add that it's not a Democracy 'project,' but it's about helping people realize their own aspirations for freedom and the chance to build a better life for themselves and their children. And I believe it's not America's mission alone. It's the collective responsibility of the free world to offer aid and encouragement to those who are fighting for the universal values that make human beings free.

Well, I appreciate the question. The fact that the Senate voted down the proposals to withdraw our troops by a certain date is a indication that the United States Senate believes we ought to support our troops and support our strategy in Iraq. Now, the resolution that did pass, I think it's an opportunity for us to update Congress on the strategy, and I'm more than happy to do so.

As for the party splitting with me, I don't see it that way at all. We've got a strategy to succeed in Iraq, and the reason I'm on this trip is to talk about the importance of succeeding in Iraq. And I believe most Republicans and many Democrats understand the importance of succeeding in Iraq for our own security, for the security of the Middle East, and for the security of the world.

And as for the word "embarrassing," I don't think it's embarrassing at all. I think it's healthy for people to discuss and debate. I'm confident in our strategy, I'm confident in our ability to succeed. And I will continue to listen to voices from all parties about how to make sure we prevail.

And by the way, it's also a reminder to the Iraqis that the American people and the United States Senate expect us to move forward on the benchmarks that we've laid out. And I think that's a positive sign.

Thank you, thank you for that question. Tom, I appreciate that. (turning to the Estonian President) Mr. President and I had a very good discussion about Georgia, and I'm glad you brought it up. I think it's very important for the United States, for Estonia, and for other freedom-loving nations to support the young democracies in this region.

Now, concerning the conflict between Russia and Georgia, I believe that Russia should respect Georgia's sovereignty. I believe that Russia ought to be a partner in helping Georgia to develop its economy, to become a more stable democracy. And I we should work with President Saakashvili to help him move forward on a strategy that will lead to peace and stability.

But I want to remind everybody, we've been vocal in our criticism of Russia's behavior on this issue. We think that Russia's presence in South Ossetia and in Abkhazia is... it's unacceptable. I've made that clear to President Putin. And I think that we've got to continue to speak out on this issue, particularly through international organizations.

Now, I think there are ways we can help that are constructive. One way to help is to provide technical assistance to the Georgians. I think we can encourage the international community to help Georgia rebuild its economy. I think we can encourage the international community to speak clearly about the importance of respecting Georgia's sovereignty.

But I also believe that we've got to continue to work with Russia to try to find a peaceful solution. I think that's in everybody's interest. And I believe that President Ilves and I share the same vision on this - we want peace and stability in the region.

I appreciate the question. First, I want to say that I understand the concerns of the American people. I understand that this war is unpopular, and I understand that there are many people who worry about the direction of the war in Iraq.

But I want to remind the American people that we didn't invade Iraq just for the sake of invasion. We invaded Iraq because the United States was threatened. We invaded Iraq because the United States received intelligence that Iraq had WMD. We invaded Iraq because Saddam Hussein was a threat to the stability of the region.

I will not abandon the mission. I will not leave the Iraqi people to the mercy of the terrorists. I will not undermine the brave men and women who are serving in Iraq, who are serving our country with honor and distinction.

I believe that if we were to withdraw from Iraq before the job was done, we would embolden the terrorists. We would embolden al-Qaeda. We would embolden the jihadists who want to do harm to the United States.

So, I am committed to a strategy that will succeed. I am committed to a strategy that will allow us to complete the mission and then hand over to the Iraqi people.

I understand that there are differences of opinion about this policy. I respect those differences. But I must make the decisions that I believe are in the best interest of the United States of America. And I am willing to take the heat for those decisions.

Well, thank you for the question. I appreciate it. The bully pulpit is a powerful tool, and I've used it to push for reform on Social Security and immigration. Now, I know some folks might say, "Well, you haven't gotten the results you wanted." But I'd say, we've had some significant accomplishments, and we're building a foundation for future reform.

Let me tell you, the fact that the Democrats control Congress doesn't change my approach. I'm still going to use this microphone to promote my vision for America. I'm still going to push for the values and principles that I believe in.

Now, I will say, I'll be adapting my strategy. I'll be working to build more bipartisan support, reaching out to Democrats and Republicans to find common ground. I'll be using my executive authority to get things done, where I can. And I'll be using this microphone to explain to the American people why these reforms are important.

Look, the American people are looking for results, and I'm committed to delivering them. I'm a optimistic person, I'm a patient person, but I'm also a persistent person. And I'm going to keep using this microphone, and all the tools at my disposal, to push for the reforms that I believe in.

And let me tell you, I'm not naive. I know that it's going to be a challenge, but I'm up for it. I'm ready to work with the Democrats, to find common ground, and to get things done. And I'm confident that, ultimately, we'll make progress, and we'll get the results that the American people are looking for.

Thank you. That's a very good question. And I appreciate you asking it. First, let me just say that the Taliban has become a more brutal organization since the days when we first liberated Afghanistan. They're more brutal, and they're more extreme.

As for who supports them, I think it's well-documented that these are the people who were quite busy prior to the War in Iraq and my presidency. Our intelligence and information supports the fact that unless girls are educated, communities are not empowered.

I appreciate the question. You know, I've always believed that finding common ground is a two-way street. And I've reached out to Democrats on numerous occasions to try to find areas where we can work together. I've had some successes, and I've had some disappointments.

Now, I think it's fair to say that the Democratic leadership in Congress has been more interested in obstructing our agenda than in finding common ground. I mean, take the issue of the war on terror, for example. I've had to veto a number of bills that I thought were detrimental to our national security, because Democrats insisted on trying to put conditions on our troops that I thought would undermine our ability to win the war.

But despite those challenges, we have had some successes. We've worked together on issues like expanding funding for children's health care, and on passing a comprehensive energy bill. And I've worked hard to build personal relationships with Democrats, like Senator Dianne Feinstein and Senator Joe Lieberman.

But I think it's also fair to say that I could've done a better job in finding common ground. I mean, I'm a strong leader, and I'm not afraid to take a stand on principle. But I know that tone and rhetoric can sometimes get in the way of building relationships. So, I've been trying to do a better job of listening to Democrats, and finding areas where we can work together.

Ultimately, my goal is to get results for the American people. And if that means working with Democrats to find common ground, then that's what I'll do. But I'm not going to compromise on my core principles, and I'm not going to back down from fights that I think are important to the future of our country.

The Venezuelan people have spoken, and they have rejected the constitutional reforms that would have allowed President Chávez to continue in power indefinitely. This is a significant moment for Venezuela, and it's a testament to the strength of democracy in the region.

I think it's also a rejection of the kind of authoritarianism that President Chávez has been promoting. The Venezuelan people have made it clear that they want a more democratic, more participatory government, and that's something that the United States supports.

As for President Chávez's comments, I'm not surprised. He's made similar comments about me and the United States before. But I think it's worth noting that this election was not about me or the United States; it was about the Venezuelan people and their desire for a more democratic government.

I'm heartened by the fact that the Venezuelan people have rejected the notion that they need a strongman in power, and instead are looking for a more democratic, more participatory form of government. And I think that's something that we can all support.

So, we'll continue to watch the situation in Venezuela closely, and we'll continue to support the Venezuelan people as they work towards a more democratic future.

I appreciate your question. Let me be clear: I have been forthright about my involvement with Harken Energy, and I've been called on it many times. The SEC has looked into the matter thoroughly, and I have done nothing but cooperate with the investigation. I'm not asking for the SEC to turn over these documents because it's a matter of law, and I'm not going to interfere with the independence of the SEC. 

As it pertains to the Vice President, he has been very forthright about his role at Halliburton, and he's answered questions about his role. I'm confident that he'll continue to do so. He's a man of great integrity, and I trust him. 

I want to assure the American people that we are committed to transparency and accountability, and I believe that's exactly what we've demonstrated.

Thank you for your questions. First of all, let me address the issue of Iraq and the nuclear materials in Africa. I want to make it very clear that the intelligence information that was provided to me and to Prime Minister Blair was credible and was based on a high level of confidence. We believed, and we still believe, that Saddam Hussein was a threat to the security of the United States and to the world, and that he was actively seeking to acquire nuclear capabilities.

Now, it has come to our attention that some of the specific information regarding the purchase of uranium in Africa may not have been as solid as we thought. But let me tell you, the broader threat posed by Saddam Hussein and his regime was very real, and we had to take action to address it.

Regarding the second part of your question, I want to make it clear that we are committed to helping the people of Zimbabwe and supporting their aspirations for democracy and human rights. We have concerns about the ongoing situation in Zimbabwe, and we are working with Prime Minister Mbeki and other partners in the region to try to resolve the crisis.

Regarding a meeting with a representative of the opposition leader, I would say that we are open to meeting with representatives of all parties who are committed to peaceful and democratic solutions to the crisis in Zimbabwe. We want to see a resolution to the crisis that reflects the will of the Zimbabwean people, and we will work with all parties who share that goal.

I want to emphasize, however, that we do believe that President Mbeki can play a constructive role in facilitating a resolution to the crisis. He has been actively engaged in efforts to promote dialogue and reconciliation, and we support his efforts. We believe that a comprehensive, African-led solution to the crisis is the most likely means of achieving a durable peace in Zimbabwe.

Thank you for that question. I appreciate Chairman Roberts' commitment to reforming our intelligence community. We're in the process of reviewing his proposal, and I'd say it's too early to give a definitive answer on whether we agree or disagree with every aspect of it.

But I will say that we share the same goal, and that's to make sure our intelligence community is better equipped to deal with the 21st-century threats. We need to be more agile, more accountable, and more focused on the threats that face our nation.

Now, as for the restructuring, we're going to take a close look at it. I think the idea of strengthening the NID, I think that's a good idea. The National Intelligence Director should have the authority to direct, should have the authority to make sure that our intelligence efforts are focused on the threats.

However, we're also going to carefully examine the funding and personnel authorities. We need to make sure that whatever changes we make, they're done in a way that enhances our national security, and doesn't inadvertently create new problems.

Our National Security Adviser, Condoleezza Rice, and other officials here in the White House, are closely working with Chairman Roberts and other members of Congress to make sure that we get this right. We want to make sure that we don't just reform for reform's sake, but that we create a more effective and efficient intelligence community.

So, we'll take our time, we'll work closely with Congress, and we'll make sure that whatever changes we make, they're in the best interest of our national security.

Thank you for your question. Well, I think it's fair to say that the security situation in Baghdad is a challenging one, and we're working closely with the Iraqi government and our coalition partners to improve it.

One of the changes that we're considering is a new strategy that focuses on having more Iraqi security forces on the ground, working side by side with our coalition forces. We believe that by increasing the Iraqi presence and ownership, we can better address the sectarian violence that's been plaguing the city.

Now, I want to caution that this is a complex issue, and there's no easy solution. We've got to continue to work closely with the Iraqi government to build up their capacity, their ability to secure their own country. But I'm confident that with the right strategy and the right partnership with the Iraqis, we can make progress.

We're also exploring ways to... (pausing for a brief moment) ...to increase the visibility of security in Baghdad. You know, it's a big city, and it's tough to secure every single neighborhood. But by having a more effective police force, a more effective Iraqi security force, I think we can... (pausing once more) ...make a difference.

That's a long answer to your question, but I hope it gives you a sense of the kind of changes we're considering. Next question, please!

Well, thank you for that question. First, let me just say that I'm proud to stand alongside the Prime Minister, and I appreciate the strong alliance that our two nations enjoy. Now, regarding the issue at hand, I think it's fair to say that when it comes to terrorism, we both view it as a serious threat that necessitates a comprehensive strategy.

Now, in the past, I have been critical of those who view terrorism purely as a law enforcement issue, because I believe that it's more than that – it's a war. And I still believe that. However, I also recognize that law enforcement plays a critical role in the global war on terror, and we must use all tools at our disposal to track down and bring to justice those who seek to harm innocent people.

Now, I think there might be some nuance in our interpretations, but I think we're more in agreement than we are in disagreement on this issue. And I'll tell you why – the Prime Minister and I have spoken at length about this, and I know he shares my commitment to winning the war on terror.

To the Prime Minister's question, I think it's up to him to describe how his approach will differ from that of his predecessor. But I will say that I'm heartened by the fact that he has already expressed his commitment to our strong bilateral relationship and his recognition of the importance of our cooperation on issues like counter-terrorism and the spread of democracy.

(Pauses for the Prime Minister to address the question)

Thank you for your question. I'm glad to address the situation on the financial markets. First of all, I believe that housing prices are going to correct themselves, but at the same time, we need to recognize that the market is going through a bit of a rough patch. And the good news is that we've had strong economic growth over the past year, but we need to find ways to keep that growth going.

Now, regarding the ability to borrow money, we've had some volatility in the credit markets recently, and it's had an impact on people's ability to get loans, to buy homes, et cetera. I believe that the Fed, the Federal Reserve, has taken some steps to help, by lowering interest rates and providing more liquidity to the market. But we're also working with the regulators and the financial institutions to find ways to stabilize the market and get more lending going.

Now, as for a bailout for people who are losing their homes, I don't think that's the right term. What we want to do is help those people who are struggling to stay in their homes. We've got a number of programs in place already, such as the HOPE NOW initiative, that's helping families who are in trouble with their mortgages, to refinance and restructure their loans.

But I think it's also important to note that we've got to be careful not to oversubsidize the market. We don't want to put the government in the business of bailing out people who made bad investments. But we do need to help those who are struggling. So, we're working with the organizations that are providing assistance to people, to see if there's more we can do, within reason. We can't save every house, every mortgage, but we can provide support and help to those who are struggling.

Now, we're also looking at other ways to restore confidence in the market. For example, we're exploring some additional legislative steps that could be taken to stabilize the market and prevent the kind of reckless lending that got us into this mess in the first place.

Thank you for that question. I appreciate your interest in this matter. The United States values its partnership with Canada, particularly in the efforts to stabilize and secure Afghanistan. The Canadian military has indeed played a crucial role in the NATO-led mission in Afghanistan, and I want to express my deepest gratitude to the government and people of Canada for their contributions.

As for whether Canada has done its job and fulfilled its duties, I'll say that their efforts have been vital to the overall mission, particularly in Kandahar province. However, I'm not sure that I would agree with the notion that their job is done.

We must recognize that the security situation in Afghanistan remains challenging, and the fight against terrorism is far from over. The contributions of all coalition partners, including Canada, are essential to preventing Taliban and al-Qaeda elements from regrouping and extending their destabilizing influence.

That being said, I also understand the importance of burden-sharing and the need for partners to reassess their commitments from time to time.
