I have no doubt that the Canadian government will carefully consider its role in Afghanistan and make informed decisions that align with its national interests.

Ultimately, I'd like to emphasize the importance of continued international cooperation in Afghanistan, including the vital role that Canada has played. I look forward to continued collaboration with Prime Minister Harper and the Canadian government on this and other pressing global challenges.

Good question.  I appreciate that question.

First, on the description, Iraq is not an endless war. It's not a war without end in sight.  We have made great progress. We've made real progress. Iraq is a functioning democracy, thanks to the efforts of the United States and our coalition partners.

The Iraqi security forces are taking more and more responsibility for their own security. And as they do, we'll continue to reduce our military presence. And when we're done, we'll have succeeded.

Now, I know there's a lot of critics out there who don't think that's possible. They believe that Iraq is a war that drags on forever. I strongly disagree. I firmly reject that notion. We've got a plan in place. We're making progress on that plan. And when we're done, there will be a stable Iraq that will be a ally in the War on Terror.

Now, with regard to the question regarding the Prime Minister's meeting with the candidates – (laughter) – I think that's up to the Prime Minister to respond. Tony?

And Prime Minister Blair says,:

Thank you, George. (laughter) Well, I'm not going to fall into the trap of expressing a preference. (laughter) That's not for me to do. I mean, they're all very nice people, I'm sure. (laughter) No, seriously, I did meet with all three candidates, and I thought it was a very useful meeting. The questions we face, of course, are the same for whoever is President of the United States in terms of the transatlantic relationship.

I think that relationship is strong. It's deep. It's historic. And I think it will endure, whoever is President of the United States. We have common interests, common values that we share as nations, and I think that will continue to take us forward, whatever the outcome of the presidential elections.

And as for a special kinship with any one of the candidates, I think, diplomatically speaking, I'm not going to go there. (laughter)

Thank you for that question. I appreciate the opportunity to address these important issues.

First, let me say that the Middle East peace conference is a very high priority for my administration. We believe that peace in the Middle East is essential for the stability of the region and for the security of all the nations involved, including the United States.

Regarding President Arafat's participation in such a conference, I am looking forward to seeing Chairman Arafat at the conference table, provided that he renounces violence and commits to a peaceful process. We believe that he is an important player, but we also believe that the Palestinian people need to know that their leaders are committed to peace.

With regard to the timeline for this conference, I've instructed Secretary Powell to accelerate our efforts to bring this conference about as quickly as possible. We're working closely with all parties, including the Israelis and the Palestinians, to resolve the necessary steps for this conference to take place in the near future.

Now, regarding the question on the Iraqi regime. Saddam Hussein is a threat to his own people, and to his neighbors, and to the global village. We need to take the threat of Saddam Hussein seriously, and we are making it clear that there will be consequences for his actions. We have a range of options available to us, from diplomatic efforts to economic sanctions, to other options, to make it clear to Saddam Hussein that his regime must change its behavior.

Now, let me be clear: I have said as clearly as I can there's one thing certain: Saddam Hussein will disarm, or we'll disarm him. And that is a decision that I make with moral clarity, working closely with our coalition partners and friends.

We are working with our allies to take the necessary steps to bring pressure on Saddam Hussein, and we will continue to explore all options to bring about a new government in Iraq, one that is more representative of its people, and one that will give hope to the Iraqi people for a better future.

And, I want to emphasize, that our policy is to liberate the Iraqi people, not occupy Iraq, or to dominate Iraq, but to liberate the Iraqi people, and to help them achieve a better future.

Thank you for that question. I appreciate the concerns of the FBI agents, and I understand their point of view. I've spent a lot of time thinking about this issue, and I've talked to a lot of experts, including Secretary Ridge and Director Mueller.

Let me tell you, the question of whether or not to reorganize our intelligence structure is a tough one. But I believe that we must be willing to challenge the status quo and think outside the box if it means making America safer.

Now, I'm not ready to announce any specific decisions on this matter today. But I will say this: I'm committed to doing what it takes to protect the American people, and if that means reforming our intelligence agencies, then we'll do it. We'll do it in a way that's smart, that's effective, and that makes sense.

One thing's for certain: we need to make sure that our intelligence agencies are working together seamlessly, sharing information and coordinating their efforts. We can't afford to have duplicated efforts or overlapping responsibilities. We need to streamline our operations and make sure that our people have the tools and the resources they need to get the job done.

And let me be clear: I will take an active role in leading this effort. I'll work with Congress, with the intelligence community, and with law enforcement to make sure that we're doing everything we can to keep America safe.

So, while I appreciate the concerns of the FBI agents, I'm committed to taking a fresh look at our intelligence structure and making the changes that are necessary to keep America safe. Thank you.

Thank you, I appreciate that question. You know, I've had a chance to reflect on my relationship with President Putin, and I must say that I'm disappointed by the recent actions you've mentioned. When I first met with President Putin, I did believe that we had found some common ground and a shared desire to move our countries forward in a positive way.

However, his recent comments and actions have caused me to reevaluate that assessment. I'm deeply concerned about the potential for destabilization in the Middle East and the implications of providing advanced weaponry to nations that don't necessarily share our values.

As the leader of the free world, it's my duty to express my concern and to ensure that we're taking steps to protect our allies and to prevent the spread of weapons of mass destruction. I plan to have a candid conversation with President Putin about these issues when we meet, and I'll be looking for a clear demonstration of his commitment to responsible international behavior.

Let me be clear: the United States will not stand idly by while nations that sponsor terrorism or pursue nuclear ambitions are armed with advanced weaponry. We will take all necessary steps to protect our allies, our interests, and the safety of the American people.

Good question. I appreciate it. Let me try to put this into perspective. On the 11th of May, I was indeed informed -- or, I'm sorry, I was not informed -- while I was away from the White House. But let me tell you, the good news is that our system worked. We've got a great system in place that protects the White House and the White House complex. And an unidentified plane, which poses a threat, was intercepted in a very professional and safe manner.

Now, as the President of the United States, I believe it's very important that the protocols in place are followed. And I'm confident that the people who are overseeing this particular incident followed protocols. 

I don't -- you know, hindsight is easy to use, but I don't think it's necessary for the President to be in the loop when the system's working. I mean, you want systems in place that are able to respond quickly. And the American people can rest assured that they are safe.

I think that's a fair question. Let me try to answer it. First of all, I want to assure the American people that the training of Iraqi security forces is going very well. We have made significant progress, and I'm proud of what the Iraqi people are doing. They're taking control of their own country, and that's what the strategy is all about.

Now, as for the numbers, I think it's a little misleading to look at just one number, which is the total number of Iraqi forces trained. What's important is the effectiveness of those forces on the ground. And I would argue, and our commanders on the ground would argue, that we do have Iraqi units that are performing very well.

Now, you're right, during the same period, we haven't decreased our forces. But that's because our commanders have told me that, in order to fully train these Iraqi units, to make sure they're effective, they need the support of coalition forces. And that's what we're doing.

Now, I believe, as the Iraqi forces become more effective, as they take on more responsibilities, we will be able to adjust our troop levels. And I've said that publicly. But I'm not going to get into a position where I'm making decisions based on polls or based on politics. I'm going to make decisions based on the conditions on the ground, and what our commanders tell me.

So, while the numbers may not be decreasing at the rate that some might expect, I believe we're making progress, and we will be able to make adjustments as the Iraqi forces become more effective. But it's a complex situation, and we've got to be patient and focus on the ultimate goal, which is a free and democratic Iraq.

I appreciate Ambassador Bolton's strong convictions, and I've always respected his ability to speak his mind. However, I must respectfully disagree with his assessment of this deal. This agreement represents a major step forward in our efforts to address the threat posed by North Korea's nuclear program. It's a carefully negotiated agreement that takes into account the twin goals of verifiable denuclearization and strict economic and security measures.

While it's true that the financial pressure we applied played a significant role in bringing North Korea back to the negotiating table, our strategy was always aimed at achieving a comprehensive agreement that addresses the core of the problem. We're not simply rewarding North Korea for showing up; we're requiring them to take meaningful steps towards disarmament and transparency.

Make no mistake, this agreement isn't a free lunch. It comes with significant measures, including intrusive inspections and strict accounting for their nuclear programs. The financial benefits they'll receive are conditional on their compliance with the terms of the agreement. And if they were to cheat or renege on their commitments, the consequences would be severe.

Now, I understand that some people may have concerns about this deal, and I respect their skepticism. But I believe this agreement represents the best available option for achieving our objectives in this challenging region. It's a step forward, and I'm willing to take that step, because I believe it will help us build a more secure and more peaceful future for the American people.

Well, thank you for the question. I'd be happy to answer. First of all, let me say that I've had the pleasure of working with General Peter Pace, a fine man, a fine General, and a great patriot. He's served our country with distinction, and I appreciate his service.

Regarding his decision to step down, I think it's a testament to the fact that we've got a good team in place, and we're thinking about the next chapter in the history of our military. Mike Mullen, who will take General Pace's place, is a man of great experience, great expertise, and great qualifications. I've worked with Admiral Mullen, and I'm confident that he'll do a fantastic job as the Chairman of the Joint Chiefs.

Now, I know there's been some speculation about the fact that this might have been, you know, influenced by the politics on Capitol Hill. Let me tell you, I've made it clear to my team, and to the country, that I'm not going to play politics with the nation's security. I'm going to make decisions based on what's best for the country, and what's best for our military.

Now, I will say that General Pace did indicate to me that he was concerned about the confirmation process, and the potential impact that it could have on the Department of Defense, and on our military. And I think, in the end, we made a decision that was in the best interests of all parties concerned. But let me be clear: the decision to move forward with Admiral Mullen was not driven by politics; it was driven by a desire to do what's best for the country.

So, I'm confident that Admiral Mullen will do a fine job. I'm grateful for General Pace's service, and I think we're going to be just fine.

Thank you for your question. I appreciate the opportunity to address this issue. As you know, we've made it clear to the Iraqis that it's essential to have a national hydrocarbon law that will allow for the equitable distribution of oil revenues. We've encouraged the Iraqis to work towards that goal, and we believe that it's in the best interests of the Iraqi people.

Regarding the Hunt Oil deal, I will say that I wasn't involved in this decision-making process. While Ray Hunt is a respected businessman and a long-time friend, that doesn't change our support for a national hydrocarbon law that would govern oil exploration and development in Iraq.

It's also important to note that the United States is committed to respecting Iraqi sovereignty and territorial integrity. We encourage companies to recognize those principles as they operate in Iraq. I do think this deal with the Kurdish regional government has the potential to complicate the discussions regarding oil legislation, which we believe is crucial for Iraq's future.

As a result, we have made it clear to all parties involved that we are encouraging them to work closely with the Baghdad government to find a solution that takes into consideration the interests of all Iraqis, rather than pursuing these kinds of agreements in isolation. Our goal is a stable and prosperous Iraq, and we believe a national hydrocarbon law will be a crucial part of achieving that.

Well, Paul, thank you for that question. I understand the decision made by the Australian government, led by Prime Minister Rudd, to withdraw 500 combat troops from Iraq. I respect that decision, and I appreciate the contributions that Australia has made thus far in the fight against terror.

Now, I know that my remarks yesterday about withdrawing troops at this time might seem to be in conflict with the Australian decision. But I believe it's essential to contextualize this issue. The Australian troops are being repositioned in Afghanistan, which is a critical front in the fight against al-Qaeda.

I've spoken to Prime Minister Rudd, and I appreciate his commitment to continuing the fight against terror. As for how I'd describe him, I think it's early days in his tenure, and I'm looking forward to seeing how he leads his country on this critical issue. But I'll tell you this: he's a determined leader, and I respect that.

Now, as for the "man of steel" remark, I was paying tribute to my friend, former Prime Minister John Howard, who stood strong with us during some very trying times. I believe that Prime Minister Rudd will find his own voice and his own resolve, and I'm committed to working with him in this fight.

So, to answer your question, Paul, I accept the Australian decision, and I respect their continued commitment to the fight against terror, even if it's in a different theater of operations.

Thank you for your question. I appreciate the opportunity to discuss this critical issue.

First, let me say that I remain committed to the goal of achieving a two-state solution, with Israelis and Palestinians living side by side in peace and security. I understand that the recent developments in the region, including the challenges facing Prime Minister Olmert, have made the process more difficult. However, I believe that these obstacles, while significant, do not necessarily mean that peace is far away.

Now, I want to be realistic – the construction of settlements in eastern Jerusalem and the occupied territories is a problem. It's a significant issue, and it needs to be addressed. The Israelis have a right to security and a right to express their concerns, and at the same time, the Palestinians have a right to their legitimate aspirations for a state. And the settlements, in my judgment, are not conducive to the peace process.

That being said, I still believe that there is a window of opportunity for peace. The prime minister and I have been in close consultation on this issue, and I'm convinced that he is committed to the process. And I urge the Palestinian leadership, as well as the Israeli people, to continue to work towards a peaceful resolution.

It's going to be a challenging journey, and we'll hit bumps along the road. But I've always believed that the door to peace is still open, and I'm committed to pushing that door open as wide as I can.

Now, I'm not naive – I know that my – quote, unquote – "deadline" for peace by the end of the year is certainly ambitious. But I believe that by setting ambitious goals, we can make progress. And I'm not going to take my eye off the ball. We're going to continue to push forward with a sense of urgency and purpose, because I believe that the prize of peace is worth fighting for.

So, to answer your question directly, I still believe that peace is achievable this year. And I'm committed to working with our partners in the region, with our allies and with the international community to make it happen. Thank you.

Thank you for the question. I appreciate it. As you know, we've been working very closely with the international community, including our partners in the Six-Party Talks, to bring about a more peaceful and stable Korean Peninsula.

Removing North Korea from the list of state sponsors of terrorism is a serious matter, and it's not something we take lightly. However, I'm pleased to say that we're making progress in our discussions with the North Koreans, and we're getting close to achieving several important milestones.

As for the specific timing, I'd say we're on track to take a decision on November 11th is not the correct date. I expect, assuming the North Koreans follow through on their commitments, that we can remove North Korea from the state sponsor of terrorism list shortly after we verify the disablement of their nuclear facilities, which is part of the agreement they made with the international community.

Now, I want to emphasize that there are several preconditions that must be met before we take this step. First and foremost, the North Koreans must follow through on their commitments to disable their nuclear facilities, and we need to verify that they've done so. They must also provide a complete and accurate declaration of their nuclear programs, including any nuclear activities they've conducted in the past. And finally, they must also commit to not proliferating nuclear technology to other countries.

If these conditions are met, and we're confident that they're committed to denuclearization, then I believe it would be appropriate to remove North Korea from the list of state sponsors of terrorism. But let me be clear: this is a step forward, not a final destination. There's still much work to be done to achieve our goal of a nuclear-free Korean Peninsula, and we'll continue to work with the international community to achieve that goal.

Thank you for your question.  I appreciate the chance to address these concerns. Let me start by saying that our missile defense is a vital part of our national security, and I'm committed to deploying a system that will protect the American people from the threats of the 21st century.

Now, regarding the testing of the system, we're making great progress. We're on schedule, and we'll continue to do the necessary tests to make sure the system works. Now, I'll tell you, we're not going to wait for all the testing to be done before we start deploying the system. We'll start deploying the system, and then continue to test it.

As for the ABM Treaty, I think it's an outdated treaty, one that prevents the United States from exploring new defensive technologies. And I believe that's a problem. The treaty was signed during the Cold War, and it doesn't reflect the threats that we face today.

Now, we'll work with our allies, we'll work with Congress, to figure out the best way to move forward. But I'm committed to building a missile defense system that will protect our country. And if the ABM Treaty gets in the way of that, we'll have to take a hard look at it.

But let me be clear: our goal is not to abrogate the treaty, but to adapt it to the new security landscape. We want to find a way to move forward in a manner that's consistent with our obligations and also allows us to defend ourselves.

Nihal, thank you for your question. The United States has been consistent in its position that Israeli settlement activity can be an obstacle to peace. As you noted, previous administrations have held this view as well. I agree with that assessment.

In my vision of a two-state solution, Israel and Palestine can coexist in peace, with both sides enjoying secure borders. However, settlement activity, especially the expansion of settlements, undermines trust and makes it harder to achieve that goal.

I've had discussions with Prime Minister Sharon, and I've made it clear that our Administration's view on settlements remains unchanged. We encourage Israel to be mindful of its settlement activities, particularly in areas that could be – and I believe should be – part of a Palestinian state in the future.

Now, I want to emphasize that we understand the complex issues at play here, including Israel's security concerns. But we must balance those concerns with the imperative of moving toward a peaceful resolution of the conflict.

My message to the Israeli Government is this: we value our relationship with Israel and we will always stand by our ally, but we also believe that it's time to take steps to get the peace process moving forward. That means taking a close look at settlement activity and working with the Palestinians to build a just and lasting peace. We're committed to helping both sides achieve that goal.

Thank you, and good morning.  ( pause ) The Prime Minister and I did discuss  —  had a very good conversation about the situation in Iraq. We appreciate the Italian contribution to the effort thus far. They've made a significant contribution, and we're grateful for that. We did talk about the possibility of Italian troops taking on more responsibilities, particularly in the southern part of Iraq, where the Italian troops are deployed. We think that's a very good idea. Our goal is to have a multinational division in Iraq, and we think the Italian contribution can be a significant part of that division.

In terms of reconstruction, we had a very good discussion about the needs of the Iraqi people. The Prime Minister and I are committed to helping the Iraqi people. We believe that the Iraqi people want to be free and live in peace, and we're committed to helping them achieve those objectives. We talked about, of course, the role of other countries that may not have been part of the coalition but are interested in participating in the reconstruction of Iraq. We're interested in countries participating, and we'd like to see other countries contribute to the efforts to help the Iraqi people. It's in the world's interest that Iraq become a free and peaceful country, and we're committed to working with others to achieve those objectives.

It's also worth noting that we discussed the role of the United Nations. The UN has got a significant role to play in helping the Iraqi people. We're committed to working closely with the UN, and I believe the UN can play a significant role in helping the Iraqis write a constitution and in helping with the reconstruction efforts.

So, all in all, it was a very good conversation. The Prime Minister and I see eye to eye on these issues, and we're committed to working together to achieve our objectives.

Thank you, I appreciate that question. First of all, we're committed to helping Colombia defeat the narco-terrorists. We believe the FARC, ELN, and the AUC are terrorist organizations that threat stability not only in Colombia but in our own hemisphere. We're working closely with President Uribe and his government to provide assistance, training, and support to help them combat these terrorist organizations.

Regarding the peace process, I believe that President Uribe's government is taking the right steps to try to bring some of these groups to the negotiating table, but we must be cautious. We've got to make sure that any peace process is fair, transparent, and leads to a result that doesn't allow these terrorist organizations to continue to wreak havoc on the Colombian people.

Now, regarding the conversation I had with President Uribe, we talked about our commitment to support Colombia in its fight against terrorism and our desire to move forward on a Free Trade Agreement. We believe that this FTA will be beneficial not only to the United States but also to Colombia, and we're committed to working with the Colombian people and the Colombian government to make sure that this agreement is fair and equitable.

Now, regarding the issue of flexibility, I will tell you that we're open to listening to the concerns of the Colombian farmers and the Colombian people, and we're committed to making sure that this agreement is one that benefits both our countries. But we've also got to make sure that we're not sacrificing the principles of free and fair trade.

And let me say something, I think it's very important for the American people and for the Colombian people to understand that this is a two-way street. There's going to be benefits for both countries. There's going to be more opportunities for trade, more opportunities for economic growth, and more opportunities for the Colombian people to realize their potential.

Now, I know there are concerns, and we'll listen to those concerns, but I firmly believe that this agreement is in the best interest of both our countries, and we'll work hard to make sure that it's something that benefits both our countries.

And, President Uribe, would you like to add something?

Thank you for the question. Well, let me start by saying that I am disappointed, but not surprised, by the actions of the Democratic leadership in the Senate. Their obstructionist tactics are becoming all too familiar. The American people did not elect me to nominate judges only to have them held up indefinitely by a minority of senators. I believe that every judicial nominee deserves an up or down vote on the floor of the Senate.

Now, I understand that the Democrats are threatening to halt our agenda, but I say to them, what's the agenda? The agenda is to make America safer, to make America more prosperous, and to make America more just. And if they're willing to hold up good judges, the people who can help make that agenda a reality, then I say to them, that's not good for the country.

The fact is, my judicial nominees are highly qualified, well-respected individuals who will interpret the law and uphold the Constitution. They deserve a fair shake. And if the Democrats are going to continue to filibuster these nominees, then we will have to consider other options. One of those options is a change to the filibuster rule. I believe that's a extreme measure, but it's one that we're considering because the American people expect us to get things done.

So, to answer your question, I think both judges and our agenda are important. But if I had to choose, I'd say the agenda is more important because it's about the big picture. It's about creating a better America for all Americans. But I don't think we have to choose between the two. I think we can have both. I think we can have good judges and we can make progress on our agenda. But we need the Democrats to be willing to work with us to get that done.

Thank you for the question. First of all, let me just say that we've got a good relationship with the government of Mexico, and President Fox is a friend of mine. We work together on a lot of issues, and I'm interested in seeing who the Mexican people choose as their leaders. As you know, democracy is democracy, and we're not in the business of picking leaders for other countries.

Now, as for the issue of left-leaning leaders, I think it's interesting that many countries in our hemisphere are experimenting with different forms of government. Some are choosing a more traditional, I guess you'd say, social democratic approach, and others are choosing a more market-oriented approach. And that's what democracy is all about: choosing the leaders you want.

But let me just say that we are interested in working with whoever leads Mexico, to ensure that our two countries can work together on the issues that matter most: security, trade, and migration. We've got a lot of common interests, and I think we can work well with a leader from any part of the political spectrum.

Now, regarding national security, let me just say that we've got a significant challenge on our southern border. We're working closely with the Mexican government to control and secure that border, to make sure that we're not allowing terrorists or other types of smugglers to cross into the United States.

It's a challenging task, but we're working hard to build up our own border security apparatus, and we're working closely with the Mexican government to make sure that we're sharing intelligence, sharing best practices, and making sure that we're doing everything we can to secure that border.

As for the issue of illegal crossings, I'll just say that we take these issues very seriously. We believe in the rule of law, and we believe in the importance of securing our own borders. We're working hard to make sure that we're able to protect our own citizens, while also respecting the rights of people who want to come to the United States and work.

And I might add that it's also in our interest to make sure that the economies of Mexico and Central America are growing, so that people can find jobs in their own countries and not feel the need to come to the United States. So we're working on a comprehensive approach that addresses all these issues.

But we're committed to securing our borders, and we're committed to working with whoever leads Mexico to ensure that we're able to do so in a way that's respectful of our own laws and our own values.

Well, I appreciate the question. And I understand why you're asking it. But I believe that the optimism and the desire to get things done is still strong in Washington, D.C. I mean, I was just up on the Hill this morning, meeting with some Democrats, talking about getting an energy bill done. 

Now, on some issues, we're not going to agree, and that's just fine. I mean, that's the nature of democracy. But I am confident that on big issues, we can find common ground. I'm working very hard, as are my team members, to reach out to Democrats to find out where we can agree.

You know, I think one of the things that's sometimes misunderstood about my style is that I'm not a guy who tries to be confrontational for the sake of being confrontational. I try to be straightforward and honest. Sometimes that gets to voices raised. But I'm still very optimistic about getting a lot done. Do I wish things would go smoothly and easy? of course I do. But I'm a realist. And I understand that politics can be tough sometimes, and heated, and I can handle it. It's okay to disagree, that's the way the system is set up.

But you know, we may have disagreements, but on big issues, I think we can make progress. Social Security reform is a big issue, I know the Democrats have raised some concerns and I appreciate and respect their concerns. But I'm looking forward to listening to their ideas, taking a step back and finding that piece of common ground. That's what I'm committed to doing, and I think we can make progress.

I'm not worried about getting enough done, I really am not. I'm an optimistic guy, I think we can get a lot done this year. And you know, I think we've made some significant progress so far, don't you? (pauses for a moment)

I appreciate the question. Let me be clear: I have zero tolerance for corruption, and I expect all members of my staff to adhere to the highest standards of ethics and integrity.

Regarding Mr. Abramoff, I do recall meeting him briefly on one occasion, as I think you mentioned, at a White House function, and I'm told that some of my staff did meet with him, as did many members of Congress and other government officials.

Now, I understand that Mr. Abramoff is under investigation for certain activities, and that's being handled by the Department of Justice. I have confidence in their ability to conduct a thorough and fair investigation.

As for throwing open our books, we're cooperating fully with the Justice Department, and we'll continue to do so. We're also taking steps to ensure that the White House is a place of integrity and transparency.

But let me be clear: we will not be swayed by unsubstantiated rumors, speculation, or name-calling. We will not be diverted from our agenda of keeping America safe and prosperous.

I think it's also worth noting that the Democratic leadership in Congress chose to not hold hearings on Mr. Abramoff's dealings until after the '04 elections, so I think some folks are just playing politics here.

So we'll continue to work with the Justice Department, we'll continue to cooperate, and we'll continue to uphold the highest standards of integrity in the White House. Thank you.

Yes, I have been briefed on this incident, and I'm deeply concerned about it. The notion that the People's Republic of China is involved in hacking into our Defense Department's computer systems is a very serious matter. As you know, we've had a complex relationship with China on a number of fronts, and this incident only adds to that complexity.

I'm not pleased that this happened, and I expect the Chinese government to take this seriously and take necessary steps to prevent it from happening again. We're reviewing our own systems, and we're working to prevent such incidents in the future.

Now, I do plan on discussing this with President Hu Jintao on Thursday. I'll be very direct with him, as I always am. We have a number of issues with the Chinese government, and this is one of them. It's a matter of national security, and I expect them to take it seriously.

It's also a reminder that in this global age, protecting our information and protecting our systems is a top priority. We're doing everything we can to strengthen our defenses, but we'll also hold other countries accountable for their actions in the cyber realm.

Now, I want to note that this incident does not change our overall approach to China. We have a complex set of interests with China, from counter-terrorism to trade to non-proliferation. But we will address this issue directly with them, and we expect them to address it as well.

Next question, please?

I think I've made it clear that we're going to do what it takes to protect this economy, but I want to be careful not to create a false impression. The Government hasn't always got to bail out every corporate entity. No, the market works. And the market should work. But in times of extraordinary crisis, and I believe we're in an extraordinary period, the Government has got to take action to provide liquidity and to provide some confidence.

Now, the auto industry is very different from the financial industry. I mean, the auto industry is an important industry, it's a big industry, it's a vital industry, but it's not necessarily a systemic risk in and of itself, if you know what I mean. I mean, the financial industry is basically the lifeblood of the economy. If the financial system doesn't work, then it's going to be very difficult for the economy to function. Automobiles are important, but we've got to prioritize our actions based on the systemic risk, and that's why I'm focusing on the financial industry.

Now, having said that, we are working with the automakers. We are working to … we understand that they're going through a tough time, and we're going to try to help 'em, but we've got to get it into perspective, okay? The financial industry is a different industry, and we've got to deal with the systemic risk first.

You know, I do. I think American life will go back to a sense of normalcy. The hunger for freedom, the desire for prosperity, the love of our children, our families, our friends, the will to live will overcome. And I do believe that we can go back to normalcy, but at the same time, we've got to be vigilant. We've got to be aware of the fact that there's still an enemy out there that wants to harm America and our values.

In terms of sacrifices, I think Americans will have to be patient with travel, for example. There's going to be more security checks, for example, at airports, and we're going to have to be mindful of our public gatherings, large gatherings, so that we can make sure that Americans are safe.

But I don't expect Americans to sacrifice their rights, their freedoms, or the way we live. I mean, we're a free society, and we should behave like a free society. People should go back to work, open up their businesses, go about their daily lives, but at the same time, we've been warned to be vigilant.

And I think one of the great things about America is the American people have shown an incredible capacity to work together in times of crisis. And I think we'll see the same kind of spirit, the same kind of resolve, to overcome, and to provide the needed resources, and by the way, to share the burden, if necessary.

So, to answer your question directly, I don't think we need to call for some massive sacrifice. I think Americans will behave like Americans. They'll be vigilant, but they won't be cowed. They'll be vigilant, but they'll go about their ways and work hard to overcome any disruptions that may occur in their daily lives.

But it's also important for me, as the Commander-in-Chief, to tell the American people that we will do everything in our power to defend the American people. And we will. We'll do everything we can to protect this great land of ours, and the people who live in it.

Thank you for your question.  As the President of the United States, I can tell you that we do share some differences with our European allies in our approaches to combating terrorism. While we agree that economic and political factors can contribute to the root causes of terrorism, we also believe that a strong military response is necessary to disrupt and dismantle terrorist networks.

I don't think it's accurate to say that we're solely focused on a military solution, though. We're working hard to build international cooperation on counter-terrorism efforts, including sharing intelligence, cracking down on terrorist financing, and promoting economic development in regions vulnerable to extremist ideologies.

Regarding trade issues, we do have some differences with the European Union, particularly on agricultural subsidies and trade in services. But we're committed to working through these issues in a spirit of cooperation and mutual respect.

Now, regarding Poland's accession to the European Union, we welcome Poland's membership and see it as a positive step for European stability and prosperity. We have a very strong and close relationship with Poland, and we don't see their membership in the EU as complicating our bilateral relations.

In fact, we believe that Poland's membership in the EU will enhance our cooperation on a range of issues, including counter-terrorism, non-proliferation, and regional security. We're committed to maintaining a strong and enduring partnership with Poland, and we look forward to continuing to work together on these and other important issues.

(pausing for a moment, considering the question) Well, Nick, I appreciate the opportunity to address the concerns that have been raised. First of all, let me express my deepest gratitude to the British people for their support in our efforts to fight terrorism. The partnership between our nations is strong and essential in our mission to defend our citizens from the threat of terrorism.

To the British people who are concerned about my visit, I want to assure them that our alliance is built on a foundation of shared values, including a commitment to democracy, the rule of law, and the defense of human rights. We have worked closely together to tackle the threat posed by al-Qaeda and its affiliates, and I believe that our cooperation has been vital in making the world a safer place.

Regarding the demonstrations, I am not surprised that there are differing opinions on the issue of the war on terror. As a nation, we welcome debate and dissent, and I respect the right of people to express their views peacefully. However, I must also emphasize that we cannot let the voices of a few dictate the course of our actions.

(looking at the ITV News reporter) As for the people who hate or fear me, I can only say that as President, I have made decisions that are in the best interests of the United States and our allies. I understand that not everyone will agree with these decisions, but I hope that they will recognize that my motivations are rooted in a desire to keep our citizens safe and to promote freedom and democracy around the world.

I would also remind everyone that in a free society, it's healthy to have a debate and to disagree, but it's also important to respect the office of the presidency and the sacrifices that are made by our brave men and women in uniform.

(glancing across the room) I believe that our joint efforts with the United Kingdom and with other like-minded nations will ultimately prevail, and that together, we will defeat the forces of terrorism and create a safer world for all our citizens.

[pausing for a moment, looking serious]

Well, I think it's essential to clarify our position on this matter. As I've said before, we share a mutual understanding with Prime Minister Sharon regarding the major settlement blocs. In our view, Ariel, as you mentioned, is one of those major settlement blocs that are likely to be part of Israel in any final agreement.

Regarding the issue of settlements, I want to emphasize that we believe it's essential to have an outcome that is defensible and that respects Israel's security concerns. We've talked about this with the Israelis, and I think we've reached a common understanding on the major principles involved.

However, as I've also made clear, the final status agreement will ultimately be negotiated between the Israelis and Palestinians. We'll support the parties in their negotiations and provide guidance, but the ultimate decision will be theirs.

Regarding the other issues, I think we've been quite clear in our discussions with both the Israelis and Palestinians. We believe it's essential to move forward on the roadmap, which lays out a clear vision for a two-state solution, with Israel and Palestine living side by side in peace and security.

I'll have to admit that I didn't follow the last part of your question [smiling slightly], but I hope I've managed to address your concerns. Do you have a follow-up question?

Thank you for that question. I'm glad to be here with Prime Minister Juncker, and I want to thank him for his hospitality. The United States and the European Union share a common commitment to peace and stability in the world, and our relationship has been strong for many years.

Now, regarding the speculation about a second track on foreign and security policy, I want to say that our discussions here today have indeed been focused on strengthening our transatlantic relationship, not creating new institutions or competing with existing ones like NATO.

NATO is a cornerstone of our transatlantic relationship, and we value our partnership within the Alliance. But we also recognize that the European Union is an emerging player on the world stage, and we welcome its growing role in global affairs.

Our talks today have indeed laid the groundwork for a new era of cooperation between the United States and the European Union, but I wouldn't necessarily call it a new track. I think it's more accurate to say that we're deepening and broadening our existing relationship to address the new challenges we face in the 21st century, such as terrorism, proliferation, and global poverty.

So, what we're doing here is building on the solid foundation we have, updating our partnership to meet the demands of a rapidly changing world. And I believe that this new spirit of cooperation will strengthen our ability to work together, within NATO and outside of it, to address the complex challenges we face.

So, to answer your question directly, I wouldn't say that this meeting is the foundation of a new second track outside of NATO. Rather, it's a strong statement of our mutual commitment to work together, building on the foundation we have, to create a safer, more prosperous, and more just world for all our citizens. Thank you.

Thank you for the question. The United States is committed to promoting peace and stability in the region, particularly with regards to the Kashmir issue. While I believe in a self-determined solution, which we've seen, we encourage the neighbors to get along through the diplomatic channel, not through crossing the line of control. We are supportive of dialogue between India and Pakistan, and we're willing to help facilitate that dialogue in any way that we can. At the same time, the President has been very clear about defending ourselves in this global war on terror.

 As for the line of control, I reiterate that the U.S. has made clear that it must be respected by all parties. We recognize the line of control as the de facto border between Indian and Pakistani-administered areas. It's in everyone's interest for this line to be respected and not to have destabilizing incidents. We urge all parties to work towards reducing tensions.

Well, I appreciate your question. And I've given a lot of thought to that, as you can imagine. There have been a lot of decisions, a lot of tough choices, and there's been a lot of criticism. And I've made mistakes, to be sure. I wish I could rerun some of the decisions I made. And I think one of the biggest mistakes I made, and this is with hindsight, not foresight -- hindsight's much easier -- was not letting the economy receive a stronger employment surge through tax cuts.

One of the things I wish I had done was more... was to have acted faster on the intelligence reforms prior to 9/11 to potentially, maybe, prevent the 9/11 attacks. I have taken responsibility for that, and I will again today. 

Also, I made miscalculations of what Iraqi society had gone through. So, I called upon a lot of faith in people and their ability to self-govern. Now let's take these numbers in 2002; I thought we'd see a more peaceful aftermath. I thought that the Iraqis would be more capable of governing quickly -- it is clear to me that those miscalculations led to not having enough troops on the ground after the initial invasion. 

That's a tough pill for me. But I will tell you, I will always do what I think is right, regardless of what some in the elite may say.

Well, I think it's interesting that some Europeans would view the United States in that light. I believe that's a misperception, a misconception about the United States and our intentions. We are a peaceful nation. We're a nation that values freedom and human dignity.

I think it's essential to remind our European friends that we're working together to address some of the world's most pressing issues. We're working with them on the Iran issue, for example. We're working with them on non-proliferation efforts.

Now, it's true that we had disagreements, disagreements on how to handle Saddam Hussein and the threat he posed. I firmly believe that removing him from power was the right decision. I understand that not everyone agreed, but I hope that people can see that our intention is to help make the world a more peaceful place.

It's also essential to recognize that as the world's sole superpower, we've got a responsibility to lead. And that's precisely what we're trying to do – lead, not dictate, not bully, but lead – to help create a more peaceful and stable world.

Thank you, Helen. First of all, we did discuss the Iranian issue. We have some tactical differences, but I believe we can find common ground, and I appreciate the President's willingness to listen and to think about how we can work together.

We did discuss the possibility of sanctions in the United Nations. The President made it very clear that Russia's position is that we ought to try to find a diplomatic solution to this problem, and I agree. We also discussed the possibility of using financial restrictions as a way to convince the Iranians to disarm. But I also made it clear that the United States reserves all options and will continue to make it clear to the Iranian government that they will be held accountable for their actions.

Now, on North Korea, we discussed the six-party talks and how important it is to get those talks back on track. We discussed the possibility of providing energy assistance to North Korea, as we've done in the past, and we discussed how we can work together to achieve a common goal, which is a denuclearized Korean Peninsula.

Thank you, Helen. I appreciate the question. Russia is a... a complex country, and our relationship with Russia is complex as well. I've had a good relationship with President Putin, and I've worked hard to establish a dialogue with him on a lot of issues.

Regarding proliferation, I'm concerned about Russia's behavior when it comes to sharing sensitive technologies with nations that could potentially use them for not so peaceful purposes. Iran, in particular, is a concern, as you mentioned. We've had numerous discussions with the Russians about this, and we've asked them to be more mindful of the consequences of their actions. I believe President Putin understands our concerns, but we need to see more tangible progress on this front.

On the question of democracy, I'm a strong believer in the potential for Russia to become a full partner in the community of democracies. President Putin has said that he wants Russia to be a democratic country, but we've seen some worrying signs, particularly with regards to the media and civil society. The Russian government's actions in Chechnya have also raised concerns.

Now, I want to emphasize that I think it's essential to maintain an open dialogue with Russia, even when we disagree. I've told President Putin that we'll be watching closely to see how Russia handles these issues, and we'll be working with them to try to address our concerns. Thank you for the question.  I must respectfully disagree with the implication that our administration's recent decisions on trade are motivated by reelection strategy.  Our commitment to free trade is unwavering, and we believe that the measures we're taking are essential to ensuring that American industries remain competitive in a rapidly changing global economy.

Now, on the question of China, our decision to impose quotas on certain imports from China is a matter of fairness.  We've long argued that China's accession to the WTO requires it to adhere to the same rules as everyone else.  Unfortunately, persistent imbalances in our bilateral trade relationship necessitate decisive action.

Regarding our disagreement with the WTO on steel, I believe this is a matter of national sovereignty and vital American industries.  The massive surge in steel imports has decimated our domestic producers.  While I value the WTO process for resolving disputes, I will not tolerate reckless practices that threaten critical U.S. industries.

The dollar's fluctuations are primarily driven by the markets, of course.  It's been my administration's policy to let markets instead of governments determine currency exchange rates, which helps the currency reflect true economic fundamentals and global conditions.

Finally, let me state our commitment to worldwide commerce and fair trade remains strong.  President Blair shares our enthusiasm, and we've long agreed that our respective nations will work together, internationally and within the WTO framework, to contribute to mutually beneficial arrangements across the globe.

I believe America benefits from the free market system and fair trade, which most helps those who earn their incomes through labor and are businesses that strive for competitive success and cultivate status all while benchmarking for the globalized market here and abroad in the U.S.

Thank you for your question.  Yes, we have had a productive exchange with the new interim government in Iraq, led by Ayad Allawi.  The Prime Minister's letter laid out the aspirations of the Iraqi people and the Iraqi government, and our own commitment to helping them achieve those aspirations.

The exchange that we had yesterday represents an important milestone in our relationship with a free Iraq.  Iraq's sovereignty will be full as of June 30th, as we've been saying all along.  The Iraqi interim government and that country will be a sovereign nation.

I'm not going to -- I'll let the Prime Minister speak for himself, but we are comfortable with the understanding that the Iraqis, the Iraqi government, will have full sovereignty over their country, and we will be there to help them, of course. We're committed to helping them.

And I see the Prime Minister is nodding in agreement.

Well, I appreciate the concern, and I share the concern. We're a nation of laws, and we're a nation that values human life, and human dignity. I've told our people we must be the beacons of freedom. We're at war, and the war requires tough decisions, but we're not going to, in my opinion, do something that's imprudent, or anything that makes us ashamed of who we are.

Now, I do want to say that we will interrogate people who have information, people who might harm American lives. And we're going to do it in a way that is humane, in a way that conforms to our values, and in a way that is, within the law. I've got great confidence in our justice system, which is the envy of the world, and I've got great confidence in our military. We will find a way to transmit to the value that we hold dear, of respect for human life, to make sure people are treated in a humane manner.

But let me be clear, we will not use torture as an interrogation technique. I've made that clear time and time again, and I'll make it clear again, right here and right now.

Thank you for the question. I appreciate the opportunity to clarify our position. First, let me say that our commitment to our European friends is clear. We value our partnership and are committed to working together on issues that matter most to our shared values and security.

As for the issue of Iran, let me be clear: we will continue to take a firm stance against the proliferation of nuclear weapons. The Iranian regime's nuclear ambitions pose a threat not only to the region, but to the entire world.

Regarding the possibility of military action, I want to emphasize that we are committed to diplomacy and dialogue as the preferred course of action. We are working closely with the international community, including our European partners, to address the Iranian nuclear issue through the UN Security Council.

As for the notion of needing a UN Security Council mandate for any potential action, I want to be clear that we will exhaust all diplomatic efforts before considering any military options. We will work with our allies and partners to ensure that any actions taken are necessary and proportionate.

But I must also make clear that as president, I will not rule out any options when it comes to protecting the security of the American people, our allies, and the international community. We will take the necessary steps to address the threat posed by Iran, and we will do so in close consultation with our European partners and the international community.

Let me be clear: we will work together to address this challenge, but we will not be limited in our ability to take action when necessary.

Well, I appreciate you bringing that up. Let me just say that I have confidence in Don Rumsfeld. He's a good man, he's a strong secretary of defense, and he's doing a fine job in helping me and our country navigate through some very trying times.

Now, I understand that there are going to be critics. That's just part of the presidency. And I'm going to make the decisions that I think are necessary to protect our country and to spread democracy in a part of the world that needs it. And Don Rumsfeld is a key member of my team, and I'm glad he's here.

Regarding the advice that I've received, I think we've made some hard decisions, and we've made some decisions that have been good. And we've made some decisions that, in hindsight, we might have done differently. But I'm the president, and I'm the one who's going to take the responsibility for those decisions.

I don't want to play the blame game, but I will say that we've had some successes in Iraq, and we've had some setbacks. And we're working hard to have more successes. But the war in Iraq is a tough war, it's a difficult war. It's a war that we've got to continue to fight, because if we don't, the consequences would be dire.

So, I think Don Rumsfeld is doing a fine job, and I'm not going to make a change.

I understand the skepticism, and I respect it. But let me tell you, I am the Commander-in-Chief of this great nation, and I've got a responsibility to protect the American people. I've made tough decisions, and I've made them based on the best information available at the time. 

Now, I'll be the first to admit, we've had some setbacks. We've made some mistakes. But the fact is, the threat from Al-Qaeda is still very real, and it's still very dangerous. I wish I could wave a magic wand and make it go away, but I can't. What I can do is lead this country, and that's what I'm doing.

And I understand that some folks may question my credibility, but let me tell you, I'm not going to let a focus group or a poll in Washington dictate how I make decisions about the security of this country. I'm going to make decisions based on what I think is right, what I think is in the best interest of this nation, and what I think will keep our people safe.

Now, I know I'm not perfect. I know I've made mistakes. But I've also made some tough decisions, and I've stuck to them. And I think that's what the American people want – a president who is willing to make tough decisions, who is willing to stand up to the plate and lead this country, even in the face of adversity.

Well, thank you for the question. First, I want to say that President Karzai is a strong leader, and I appreciate his commitment to the people of Afghanistan. We did discuss Iran, and I must say that I still have concerns about Iran's activities in the region. While they may be providing some economic assistance to Afghanistan, I believe their influence can be quite destabilizing.

We also had a frank discussion about the need for all nations, including Iran, to help rather than hinder the progress of the Afghan people. I made it clear that we need to ensure that Iran's actions are transparent and support the goals that we're working towards in Afghanistan. And I believe President Karzai understands our concerns and will work with us to address them.

Regarding civilian casualties, I must say that it is a topic of great concern for me and for our military commanders. We take it very seriously, and we need to do a better job of reducing civilian casualties. President Karzai and I did discuss this issue, and I'm pleased to say that he shares our commitment to minimizing harm to innocent civilians.

President Karzai can answer for himself, but I can tell you that he assured me of his commitment to this goal. He also shared with me some of the steps that the Afghan military is taking to improve its targeting and tactics to reduce the risk of civilian casualties. We will continue to work closely with the Afghan government and military to ensure that we're doing everything we can to protect civilians and minimize harm.

Now, President Karzai, would you like to add anything to this?

Thank you for that question. I appreciate the chance to clarify our position on missile defense. First, I want to say that I appreciate the leadership of President Putin on many issues, but we do have a difference of opinion when it comes to missile defense.

Transparency is a key component of our approach to missile defense. We believe that by being open and transparent about our intentions, capabilities, and operations, we can build trust and confidence with our partners and allies.

Regarding the proposed sites in Poland and the Czech Republic, I can assure you that we are working closely with both governments to ensure that our plans are transparent and that we are addressing their concerns. We are committed to sharing information with Russia and other interested parties about our missile defense activities, and we are open to discussing ways to increase transparency and cooperation.

Now, I want to emphasize that our missile defense system is designed to protect our NATO allies, including Poland and the Czech Republic, from the potential threat of ballistic missiles from rogue states like Iran. We believe that this system is necessary for the security of our allies and the stability of Europe as a whole.

So, to answer your question, I am committed to working with our allies and partners to ensure that our approach to missile defense is transparent, and I am confident that we can achieve a better understanding and cooperation with Russia on this issue.

Thank you, that's a great question. I'm proud of the efforts my administration has made in helping to bring about a ceasefire in the Middle East. It's a fragile peace, and we're committed to making sure it holds.

As for getting more involved, I believe it's in the interests of the United States to be engaged in the region. We've got a lot at stake - stability, security, and the spread of freedom. And we're going to stay engaged, but we're going to do it in a smart way.

Regarding the Secretary of State, I would not rule out a trip to the region in the near future. Secretary Rice has been doing a fantastic job in working with our allies, working with the parties involved, to bring about a lasting peace. And if her going to the region can help achieve that goal, then I wouldn't hesitate to send her.

As for me going to the region, I'd love to go. I think it's essential for the President of the United States to be seen as a partner in the peace process. I believe my presence could help to solidify the gains that we've made, and to give encouragement to those who are working towards peace.

Now, what it would take for me to go? Well, it would take a situation where I believe my presence could make a significant difference. Where the parties are ready to make concessions, where we've got a clear path forward, and where my being there could help to accelerate the process.

But make no mistake, one of my main priorities is to support the efforts of the parties involved, to support the efforts of our allies, and to make sure that we're not getting too far ahead of what the parties themselves are willing to do. We're not going to impose peace on the region. We're going to support those who are working towards peace, and we're going to be a partner in the process.

Thank you for your question.

Good afternoon. I appreciate your question. Let me clarify that the United States has always supported the right of Israel to defend itself, and the separation barrier can be a legitimate means to achieve that goal.

However, we do have concerns about the route of the fence, particularly when it deviates from the Green Line and goes into the West Bank. I've expressed these concerns directly with Prime Minister Sharon and other Israeli leaders.

What we're worried about is making sure that the fence doesn't, in its current configuration, harm the prospect of a two-state solution and make it more difficult for the Palestinian people to live in their own land.

Our opposition, therefore, is not to the concept of a separation fence per se, but to the particular route that's been chosen by the Israeli government, which we believe could be a barrier to peace and a barrier to the hopes of the Palestinian people.

We're working closely with both the Israelis and the Palestinians to find a solution that will allow the fence to be a security measure that doesn't in any way infringe upon the Palestinian people's aspirations for a peaceful and secure future.

So, to summarize, we support the right of Israel to protect itself, but we want to make sure that this security measure doesn't become a permanent obstacle to peace.

Well, I appreciate that question. Let me start by saying that David Kay's report is a very serious and thorough report. I'm glad that he's done this investigation. I think it's a very important work that he's done.

I was not surprised that David Kay's preliminary report did not find the stockpiles of chemical or biological weapons that some of our intelligence suggested were there. As I said in the State of the Union, intelligence is not perfect. We had evidence, based on intelligence reports, that there was a weapons program, a weapons program that was a threat to our security. And I used that evidence to make a very difficult decision.

Now, I want to remind people that Saddam Hussein was a very cunning and secretive leader. And as time goes on, and as our inspectors continue to look, I'm confident that the evidence of his attempt to acquire and develop these terrible weapons will be found. I also want to remind people that he's a man who had a lot to hide, and that's why we went in, because he wouldn't disclose that which we knew.

And as for credibility, I think our credibility is still very strong. I think the American people understand that our decision to go in and protect the United States and the world from a threat was a reasonable decision based on the best intelligence available. And I'm confident that as more evidence comes out, that our credibility will be shown to be intact.

But, as I said, I take these questions very seriously. And I want to assure the American people that we're going to get to the bottom of this, and we'll find out what's in that country. And I'm confident that as we do, we'll be able to show the world that the decision we made was the right decision for the security of the United States and for the world.

That report was part of the President's Daily Brief, or PDB. It mentioned hijacking, like I said, specifically for the purpose of taking hostages to secure the release of extremists who were being held by the U.S. Government. Now, while that information did not specifically mention flying planes into buildings, it was clear that there was a threat of hijacking.

Now, we took this threat very seriously, but I gotta tell you, we didn't have hard evidence of exactly how they planned to use hijackings. I did direct the Attorney General and other agencies to review the PDB and see if we needed to take any additional steps. I was briefed by CIA Director Tenet and FBI Director Mueller on the threat, and we began to work on disrupting the al-Qaeda's ability to plan and carry out these attacks.

However, like I said, we didn't have the exact information on the 9/11 attacks, and our main focus was disrupting the al-Qaeda's operations in Afghanistan. We took several actions to strengthen airport security, but unfortunately, those actions were not enough to prevent the 9/11 attacks.

But I want to tell you, in retrospect, the threat of hijacking was a warning that we should have paid closer attention to, but the nature of the threat was unclear at the time, and we were dealing with a massive and very murky intelligence picture.

Thank you for the question. You know, I took a pledge to be a uniter, not a divider, in my first term, and I wanted to work with the Democrats and the Republicans to get things done. And I'm proud of what we accomplished, including the tax cuts and No Child Left Behind.

Now, on the spending side, I did sign the budget bills that came to my desk, but I also made it clear to Congress that we need to be more fiscally responsible. And I'm gonna make that point again this time around. We've got to control the growth of discretionary spending. We've got to be wise about how we spend the people's money.

Now, as for vetoes, I will veto spending bills if they're not responsible. I will veto spending bills if they're not meeting the priorities of the American people. I will veto spending bills if they're just not good policy.

But, you know, it's not just about vetoing; it's about working with Congress to get spending under control. I'm gonna work with the Congress to try to find common ground, to try to find ways to prioritize, to try to find ways to control the growth of discretionary spending.

And I'm gonna make it clear to the Congress, this time around, that I'm serious about fiscal responsibility. We've got to be fiscally responsible. We've got to be wise about how we spend the people's money. And I'm gonna make sure that we are.

And let me just say one more thing. I've submitted a budget that's got some tough choices, but it's a budget that's responsible. It's a budget that's gonna help us get the deficit under control. And I'm gonna work with the Congress to make sure we get it passed.

Well, thank you for the question. I appreciate the opportunity to clarify my position on this. First, let me make one thing clear: I am committed to making sure that our Social Security system is solvent for generations to come. And I believe that we need to have a straightforward and honest conversation about how we're going to do that.

Now, the payroll tax cap is an important issue, and I understand that by considering raising it, some people might say, "Hey, this is a tax increase." But I don't see it that way. I see it as a way to ensure the long-term solvency of Social Security, which is a vital program for our seniors and our most vulnerable citizens.

Now, I know that I said during the campaign that I wouldn't increase payroll taxes. But I also said that I would work with Congress to find a solution to the problems facing Social Security. And if raising the payroll tax cap is part of that solution, then I'm willing to consider it.

But let me be clear: I'm not talking about raising taxes on everyday working Americans. I'm talking about making sure that our Social Security system is solvent, and if that means asking those who can afford it to contribute a little bit more, then I'm willing to consider that.

Now, I know that some of my opponents and some in the press might try to characterize this as a tax increase. But I think the American people are smarter than that. They know that we're dealing with a serious issue here, and they're willing to have a honest conversation about how to solve it.

So, I'm willing to listen to ideas, I'm willing to work with Congress, and I'm willing to consider any proposal that will help us solve this problem and make sure that Social Security is solvent for generations to come.

Thank you for your question. I want to start by saying that it's understandable that some of our coalition partners have made the decision to draw down their troops, and that's a sovereign decision they have the right to make. However, I believe the mission in Iraq is still critical to our national security, and I'm committed to working with those countries that remain committed to helping Iraq achieve stability and democracy.

Now, on the issue of a timetable, I want to be very clear: a timetable that is driven by external factors would be a serious mistake. Our drawdown will be determined by conditions on the ground, and the readiness of Iraqi forces to take over security responsibilities from coalition forces. We've made significant progress on that front, and I'm proud of the work that our military has done with the Iraqi security forces to give them the training and support they need.

As I said, the seating of the Iraqi Parliament is a significant milestone, and I'm encouraged by the progress they're making. However, I also know that we're not out of the woods yet. There's still a lot of work to be done, and we need to stay the course to ensure that we defeat the terrorists, defeat the insurgents, and help the Iraqis build a stable, free, and democratic society.

I've spoken to Prime Minister Allawi and other Iraqi leaders about this very issue, and I've told them that we're committed to seeing this mission through, but we also want to transition as many responsibilities as possible to them as soon as possible. We're working closely with our coalition partners to ensure a smooth handover of responsibilities and a successful transition to Iraq.

Now, on the number of coalition partners, I want to emphasize that 24 countries is still a significant number, and our coalition remains strong and firm in its commitment to help the Iraqi people. I appreciate the contributions that all our coalition partners have made, and I believe we'll continue to work together to ensure success in Iraq.

Finally, I want to assure the American people that we will make adjustments as needed, but our ultimate goal remains the same: a free and democratic Iraq that will be an ally in the war on terror, and a country that will no longer serve as a safe haven for terrorists.

First of all, I'll make it clear now and I'll make it clear again: I believe the tax cuts we passed in 2001 and 2003 have been a vital part of our efforts to stimulate growth, create jobs, and get the economy moving again. And I firmly believe those tax cuts should be made permanent.

Now, I understand that the bill we passed in '01 had these sunsets, but that was done for technical reasons, if you will. But the intentions of Congress and the intentions of this administration are to make sure that those tax cuts stay in place.

Regarding the budget deficit, we're working hard to deal with the deficit, and we are making progress on that front. But, I'll tell you, we can do it in a way that doesn't hurt the economic growth by taking the rug out from under the feet of small businesses and entrepreneurs who have been helped greatly by those tax cuts.

I believe we can address the deficit, reduce the deficit, and keep the tax cuts in place. And that's the strategy this administration's working towards. So, it was no oversight that I didn't mention the tax cuts earlier. I just gave you my priorities in a certain order. But, I want to reassure you that making the tax cuts permanent is a key element of my economic agenda.

I appreciate the question. First of all, I think it's essential to understand that our mission in Iraq is crucial to the security of the United States. We're fighting a enemy that has declared war on us, an enemy that killed 3,000 of our citizens on a single day. And the idea of withdrawing from Iraq before the job is done would be, in my opinion, a serious mistake.

If we prematurely withdraw, it will allow the enemy to focus on their primary objective, which is to make the United States flinch, and then retreat, and then take advantage of our leaving the battlefield. And I am concerned that would increase the risk of another attack on our soil.

Now, regarding Senator Obama's statement, it sounds like he is thinking along the same lines as I am, which is to say that if al-Qaeda is creating a safe haven in Iraq, we must take action. The key, however, is to make sure that we don't create a self-fulfilling prophecy by allowing our enemies to have the upper hand.

We've got to stay the course. We've got to continue to work towards our objectives in Iraq. We've made progress. We must continue to make progress. And we cannot let the enemy dictate our strategy or our actions.

My goal is to protect the American people, and that's why I firmly believe we must stay in Iraq and complete the mission.

Thank you for your question. Yes, the issue of the GE and Honeywell merger has been discussed during our meetings this week. Both the European Union and the United States believe in promoting a fair and open business environment.

We do have concerns about the European Commission's approach to this merger, and I've expressed those concerns to European leaders. We believe that the deal should be evaluated based on its merits and in accordance with established competition policies. It's essential that we maintain a consistent and transparent approach to these types of transactions.

If the deal is rejected, I believe it could have some impact on U.S.-European relations, particularly with regards to our economic cooperation and trade policies. However, I want to emphasize that our relationship with Europe is broad and deep, and we're committed to maintaining a strong partnership.

That being said, we expect our European partners to uphold the principles of fair competition and not to impose undue burdens on American businesses. We're hopeful that we can resolve this issue in a way that supports the principles of free and fair trade.

Thank you, appreciate the question. I think it's essential to recognize that our economy is dynamic, and there are bound to be fluctuations in the short term. However, I'm pleased that home sales are up, as it's a vital indicator of consumer confidence.

Regarding our economic assumptions, I can assure you that my team and I have worked closely with various experts and relied on the most up-to-date data available. Our 3.2 percent growth forecast for next year is based on a balanced and responsible approach that takes into account the trends and projections. We recognize that there are challenges ahead, but we're also focused on maintaining a policy environment that fosters growth, investments, and job creation.

I'd like to point out that we're still in the process of digging out of the recession we inherited when I took office. And we're doing it without raising taxes or going back on our commitment to fiscal discipline. We're sticking to our pro-growth policies and keeping our promises.

Now, I think it's also important to note that just because some experts might have differing views, it doesn't necessarily mean our assumptions are wrong. We're confident that our policies will lead to sustained growth, create jobs, and provide opportunities for all Americans.
