But we are not going to be deterred. We are going to stay the course, and we are going to help the Iraqis achieve their goal of a democratic society.

General Casey is doing a fine job as commander of the Multinational Force in Iraq, and I have every confidence in his judgment and his leadership. He and his team are working closely with the Iraqi military to develop the capability to take over more and more responsibility for their own security.

Now, I know that it's tempting to look at the violence and the casualties and say that we're not making progress. But I believe that we are making progress, although it's difficult to measure. We're seeing more and more Iraqis stepping forward to take responsibility for their own security. We're seeing the Iraqi army grow stronger and more capable. And we're seeing the Iraqi government begin to take more and more control of its country.

We are being nimble and flexible, I can assure you. We are adapting to the changing circumstances on the ground. We are working with our allies and with the Iraqi government to address the new challenges that arise. And we are committed to seeing this mission through to its successful conclusion.

It's not going to be easy, and it's not going to be quick. But I have faith in the bravery and the resilience of the American people, and I have faith in the determination of the Iraqi people. Together, we can achieve a brighter future for Iraq, and for the world.

Thank you for your question. First, let me say that I understand that there are differing opinions about our efforts in Iraq, and I respect that. But let me tell you what I believe we've accomplished so far. We've removed a brutal dictator, Saddam Hussein, from power, and given the Iraqi people the chance to build a new, democratic future.

We've also made significant progress in the fight against terrorism. Al-Qaeda and other terrorist groups have been dealt a significant blow, and we've dismantled many of their networks and operational capabilities.

Now, I know that the situation in Iraq remains challenging, and we've faced setbacks and difficulties along the way. But I believe that our strategy is working, and that we're making progress towards our goal of a stable, democratic Iraq that can govern itself and defend itself.

Regarding your comment that the United States has brought terrorism to Iraq, I strongly disagree. Saddam Hussein's regime was a terrorist regime, and it was a haven for terrorists. We've actually made Iraq a less hospitable place for terrorists, and we've made it more difficult for them to operate.

As for the Iraqi people being the biggest losers, I understand that the Iraqi people have suffered greatly, and that the violence and instability in their country have caused them immense hardship. But I believe that we're working towards a brighter future for the Iraqi people, one in which they can live in peace and security, and build a better life for themselves and their families.

In the next three years, I expect to see continued progress towards our goals in Iraq. I expect to see the Iraqi security forces become increasingly capable of taking the lead in securing their country, and I expect to see the Iraqi government become increasingly effective in delivering basic services and improving the lives of its citizens.

I also expect that we'll continue to work to isolate and defeat the terrorist networks that are seeking to undermine Iraq's progress, and that we'll make significant strides towards a more stable and secure region.

Now, I know that there will be challenges ahead, and that we'll face setbacks along the way. But I have faith in the Iraqi people, and I have faith in our strategy. And I believe that with perseverance and determination, we can achieve our goals and create a better future for the Iraqi people.

Well, thank you for that question. I appreciate it, and I hope I can provide some reassurance here. First of all, let me say that I believe our nation is a nation of immigrants. I'm a strong supporter of a compassionate and humane immigration policy. And the fact that I signed the Secure Fence Act was not to send a message that Latin Americans are not welcome. No, that's not the message at all.

The message was that we want to have a humane immigration policy, that we want to have compassion, that we want to make sure that people who are employing people who are in our country are employing people who are here legally. And the fence, the wall, or the barrier, if you will, is a part of making sure that we have a safer border.

And I want to assure the people of Mexico and Latin America that our message is we want to work together to have a humane immigration policy that respects the rights of those who are coming to our country. And we also want to assure that we're enforcing our laws.

I also want to say that the fence is a part of 780 miles of border. It's a small part of the 1,900 miles of border that we share with Mexico. And the message is not that we want to keep our friends and allies out, it's that we want to make sure that those that come to our country are coming in a peaceful, lawful way.

And I think I'll stop there. Can I answer a question from one of my-- (turning to President Calderón, not Berger)

Thank you, Helen. Good question. I'm a optimistic man, and I'm optimistic that we can work through our differences with Vladimir Putin on the missile defense issue. We see it as a necessary system to protect our allies and our country from rogue regimes that might develop long-range missiles. We believe that it's in the interest of the American people, and I've been very upfront with Vladimir about our intentions.

Now, I understand there are some issues. The Russians are concerned about the positioning of the radar, and that's an issue we're willing to work on. We believe the system is not a threat to Russia. It's a system designed to protect against threats from other places in the world. And so we'll see. We'll see if we can find common ground. I'm optimistic we can.

Regarding NATO, we're committed to the Membership Action Plan for Ukraine and Georgia. We think these are important countries that need to be part of the community of democracies. We're helping them to meet the requirements, to reform their militaries, to reform their governments, and we're committed to that. We're going to push for it.

Now, I wouldn't rule out the idea that, you know, as you find common ground on one issue, you might be willing to listen on another. I mean, that's just the way diplomacy works. But I want to be very clear to the people: we're committed to the Membership Action Plan. We think it's in our interest to have these countries be part of a strong, stable, and secure Europe.

And so we'll be pushing for it. And I'll be talking to Vladimir about the importance of the Membership Action Plan, and we'll see if we can find common ground on some of these issues. But I wouldn't jump to conclusions on the idea that, you know, we're going to trade this for that. We'll be pushing for what we think is in the best interests of the American people, as well as the people of Ukraine and Georgia.

Well, I appreciate the question. Let me start by saying that, as you know, our policy towards Iraq remains the same – that Saddam Hussein needs to allow the inspectors back in, and he needs to disarm. He's got a choice to make. And we've made it clear that we'll be watching this very carefully.

Now, as for this strike, I want to emphasize that this was a message, a clear message, that if he continues to harbor terrorist organizations, and if he continues to try to develop weapons of mass destruction, the United States will respond, and we will respond forcefully.

Now, I've made it clear in the past that regime change is in the interests of the United States. But I've also said that this is a performance-based process. If Saddam Hussein disarms, then he can stay in power. If he chooses not to disarm, then he's got a problem, and we'll deal with him in a way that we see fit.

As for the frequency or the forcefulness of our response, I will tell you this – we will respond to threats as we see them. We will not take any options off the table. We will use our military power in a way that is commensurate with the threat that we perceive.

So, make no mistake about it – we're serious about this. We're serious about Saddam Hussein disarming. And if he doesn't, there will be consequences. And I hope he understands that very clearly, because I think it's in his interests to understand that very clearly.

Well, thank you for that question. First of all, I want to emphasize that I'm proud of the brave men and women who are serving our country in Iraq. The airstrikes that were conducted were based on the best intelligence available at the time, and I'm pleased to say that we've taken out a significant number of high-value targets.

Now, regarding the issue of accuracy, I understand that there were some misses, and I'm certainly not pleased about that. However, I've been assured by our military commanders that we're working hard to improve our targeting capabilities, and that we're learning from our experiences in the field.

As for the remaining installations that were missed, I'm told that they still pose a danger to our forces, but we're working to mitigate that threat through a combination of military action and other means. I'm not at liberty to discuss the details of our operational plans, but I can tell you that we're taking a careful and deliberate approach to this situation.

If commanders in the field were to request authorization for further airstrikes, I would certainly consider their recommendations. As Commander-in-Chief, it's my duty to provide our troops with the support they need to accomplish their mission safely and effectively. And if that means taking out targets that pose a threat to our forces, then I'll consider it.

But let me be clear: our goal in Iraq is not just to conduct airstrikes, but to help the Iraqi people build a free and stable country. We're working with our international partners to rebuild Iraq's infrastructure, to promote economic development, and to help the Iraqi government establish a secure and stable environment.

So, while we will continue to take the necessary military actions to protect our forces and support our mission, we're also committed to a broader strategy that promotes peace, stability, and prosperity in Iraq.

The issue of Chinese involvement with Iraq's military capabilities is a serious one, and I want to emphasize that we're continuing to gather all the facts and assess the situation carefully.

From our side, I can tell you that we've seen intelligence that raises concerns about Chinese activities in Iraq. We've been discussing this issue bilaterally with the Chinese, and I want to make it clear that any cooperation between China and Iraq on military matters would be unacceptable and will not be tolerated.

As for specific steps, I think it's premature to talk about that right now. But rest assured that we will take all necessary measures to protect our interests and those of our allies. We're a patient people, but we will not stand idly by if we determine that China is actively working against our efforts to disarm Iraq.

Prime Minister Blair and I have discussed this issue at length, and I think it's safe to say that we share a common concern about the potential implications of Chinese involvement. We'll be working closely with our international partners to address this situation and to explore all options.

Mr. Prime Minister, would you like to add anything to that?

That's a great question. Well, I think it's very important for the American people to understand that we're at war. And when we're at war, we have responsibilities to our fellow citizens to protect them. And so, I would not take any options off the table.

We're working with many countries, as you just described, to help them strengthen their capacity to be able to fight the terrorists within their borders. And we're working closely with international organizations and coalitions to help us bring hope and opportunities to these countries so that the terrorists won't be able to flourish.

Now, at the same time, the doctrine of preemption, which I laid out in the National Security Strategy, is very clear. We will take the threats, especially from those who have the capacity to wield weapons of mass destruction, very seriously. And we will work with our friends and allies to prevent them from being able to use those kinds of capabilities.

You know, we're not going around the world saying, "We've got to go find terrorists to hunt down." We're going to each of these countries and saying, "We're prepared to help you, to help you fight this war, because we all have a common enemy, a enemy that hates freedom."

Thank you for that question.  As you know, I've had my concerns about campaign finance reform in the past, but I've also been committed to finding a solution that will strengthen the integrity of our electoral process. After careful consideration, I've decided to sign the bill.

I want to commend the bipartisan efforts of Senators McCain and Feingold, as well as those in the House, who worked tirelessly to pass this legislation. While the bill is not perfect, I believe it's a step in the right direction. It will help to reduce the influence of soft money in our system and increase transparency.

Now, I also acknowledge that there are those who may challenge this bill in court, and that's their right. But I believe that our system of government is designed to allow for the rule of law to prevail. And so, we will vigorously defend this legislation.

I should note that I do have some concerns about the bill's impact on certain aspects of free speech. But overall, I believe that the benefits of this legislation outweigh the potential drawbacks.

I think this bill will have a positive impact on our political system. It'll help to increase the public's trust in the process, and it'll make it easier for candidates to run for office without being beholden to special interests. And that's what this is all about: making sure that our democracy is of the people, by the people, and for the people.

Thank you for your question. I understand the skepticism that some of our European friends have expressed regarding the connection between Saddam Hussein and the war on terror, particularly when it comes to the linkage with Al Qaida. However, let me tell you, I believe there is a connection, and it's not just a matter of a direct linkage.

Saddam Hussein is a man who is a supporter of terror. He has been for a long time, and he has provided financing and support to organizations that seek to harm America, our allies, and his neighbors. The fact is, Saddam has a very long record of dangerous behavior, including the development of and possession of weapons of mass destruction.

Now, I know there's debate about the exact nature of the linkage between Saddam and Al Qaida. But let me tell you, this is not just about a direct connection between Saddam and Osama bin Laden. This is about the broader danger that Saddam poses, and the threat that his regime poses to the region and to the world.

And I would say to our European friends that we're not simply talking about a hypothetical situation here. We're talking about a regime that has consistently demonstrated its willingness to disregard the United Nations, to ignore the demands of the international community, and to place its own interests above those of its neighbors and the world at large.

So, while I understand that there may be some differences of opinion on the exact nature of the linkage between Saddam and Al Qaida, I believe that we are right to take the threat that Saddam poses very seriously, and to take action to address that threat. Thank you.

Well, I appreciate the question.  First of all, let me just say that I appreciate Bernard Kerik, and I wish him well. He's a good man, and I'm sorry that the process didn't work out. 

We did learn some lessons from this process. One, it's essential that the vetting process is thorough. And I'm confident that our vetting process will be thorough on our next candidate, for the DNI as well as the Secretary of Homeland Security.

Secondly, it's clear that the communications between the White House and the appropriate authorities, to make sure that we fully understand an individual's background, worked well in some areas, but can always be improved. So, we're taking a good, hard look at our vetting process.

As for the qualities that I'm looking for in a Director of National Intelligence, first and foremost, we need someone with great management skills. This person is going to be coordinating amongst the different intelligence agencies, and it's a big task. We need someone with the ability to analyze information, very good critical thinker, and someone who's got great communication skills. 

The ability to communicate effectively with our allies and the respect to the DNI's coordination authority is essential. And we're going to do everything in our power to make sure that this person has got all the qualities that you would expect of someone who's running our intelligence agencies.

Well, thank you for the question. I think it's wrong to ascribe [ attribute] discriminatory attitudes or motives to all people who happen to, uh, oppose a judge. Now, as the President, I've tried to appoint highly qualified, intelligent, and – and, uh, principled – principled judges. That's the criteria I used. And, uh, I think some of the judges that have been, uh,_TARGETED for filibusters are incredibly competent and should be supported by all parties on the Hill.

Now, as for faith playing a role in public politics, I think faith is an important part of our culture and history as a nation. I think it's perfectly legitimate for people to express faith and use faith to make arguments – as long as the lines between church and state are observed. And I've done that in my career. I mean, I've been very straightforward about the role of faith in my life, but I have also been very supportive of the Constitution – which clearly states that the separation between church and state means just that: separate.

Thank you for that question.  I appreciate the way you've framed it, in the context of our shared values and our commitment to the principles of compassion and justice.

First, let me say that I am deeply committed to addressing the issue of poverty in America, and to bridging the racial divide that still exists in our country. I believe that we have a moral obligation to ensure that every American has access to opportunity, regardless of their background or the color of their skin.

Now, I know that we've had some setbacks, particularly in the aftermath of Hurricane Katrina. The devastation that we saw in New Orleans and the Gulf Coast was a tragic reminder of the deep-seated problems of poverty and racial inequality that still exist in our country. But I believe that we've learned from those mistakes, and we're committed to doing better.

We're working to revitalize and rebuild the Gulf Coast, with a focus on supporting those who were most affected by the storm. And we're continuing to invest in initiatives that promote economic growth, education, and housing opportunities for low-income Americans, regardless of their background.

Now, on the issue of race, I want to be clear: we have a long way to go, but I am committed to leading this country towards a more perfect union. We must confront the legacy of slavery, segregation, and racism that still haunts our nation today.

Regarding the comments made by Secretary Bennett, I was troubled by them. Those comments were unacceptable, and they do not reflect the values of our party or of our country. We must strive for a level of discourse that is civil and respectful, even when we disagree.

Now, on the question of how the Republican Party can earn the trust of more African American voters, I believe that it's a question of policy and of leadership. We need to demonstrate that we are committed to the values of equality, justice, and opportunity that are shared by African Americans, and that our policies reflect that commitment.

We've made some progress in this area, with initiatives such as the Faith-Based Initiative, the Education Bill, and the African American Outreach. But we have more work to do. We need to engage with African American leaders, listen to their concerns, and develop policies that address the specific challenges that they face.

I believe that if we lead with integrity, compassion, and a commitment to justice, we can earn the trust of more African American voters, and build a more inclusive and diverse party that reflects the best of America.

Thank you.

Thank you for that question. I appreciate the interest in our efforts in Iraq. As the Commander-in-Chief, I want to tell you that our strategy in Iraq is clear: we want to succeed, and that's measured by our ability to able to transfer responsibility to the Iraqi security forces.

The formation of a unity government is a significant step forward, and I do believe it puts us on a sound footing to make progress on security. With the new government in place, we're stepping up our efforts to train Iraqi security forces, so that they can take on the terrorist threat and ultimately secure their own country.

Regarding the numbers, I'd like to make clear that any decisions on troop levels will be based on the conditions on the ground. And those conditions are being assessed right now by General Casey and his team. We'll be working closely with the Iraqi government, with our military leaders, and with the broader coalition to ensure we're making the right decisions about troop levels.

As for the Prime Minister's statement about Iraqi forces being able to take control by the end of next year, I believe it is an ambitious goal, but it's also a goal we share. But make no mistake, we'll be the ones making the decisions on when we can draw down our troop presence. The Prime Minister's statement reflects his optimism and determination for a self-sufficient Iraq, and we're committed to working with him and the Iraqi people to achieve that goal.

So, while we're making progress, and it's encouraging, we're taking it step by step. And we'll continue to assess conditions on the ground before making any decisions on troop levels or withdrawals.

Thank you for that question. You're right, gas prices are high, and it's affecting the American people. I understand the frustration. We are working on the issue of energy independence, and I believe our proposal to accelerate the development of alternative fuels, such as ethanol, is a step in the right direction.

Regarding the need for an emergency energy summit, I think we need to consider that option. I'm willing to sit down with members of Congress, with experts in the field, and with the CEOs of major energy companies to discuss this issue.

However, I also want to emphasize that the problem of energy independence is a complex one. It's not just about symbolic actions or Summit. We need a comprehensive, long-term approach. We've already taken some steps, such as increasing funding for research and development of alternative energy sources.

In terms of making it a higher priority, I think it already is a high priority for my administration. We understand the urgency of this issue. But what I think the American people need to know is that we're working on it, and we're committed to making progress.

Now, I know that the American people are impatient, and I am too. But I want to assure them that we're doing everything in our power to address this issue. We're working on increasing refining capacity, we're working on conservation efforts, and we're working on alternatives. And I'm hopeful that we can make some progress in the months ahead.

Thank you for your question. Well, I do read the morning papers, and I'm aware of the conviction you're referring to. I think it's essential for our justice system to run its course and for all individuals to be held accountable for their actions.

As for my assessment of Mayor Daley, I've always believed in praising people when they do good work, and Mayor Daley has done some good work in the city of Chicago. However, I also believe that when there are allegations of wrongdoing, they ought to be thoroughly investigated, and if there's wrongdoing, people should be held accountable.

So, I still think that Mayor Daley has done some good things, but I also believe in the importance of a fair and impartial justice system, and if that system finds wrongdoing, then actions should be taken accordingly.

Thank you for that question. As I was sayin', we need to make sure our workers have the skills necessary to compete in the 21st century. And I believes strongly that we can do that through various programs, like the Workforce Investment Act, which will help train and educate our workers for the jobs of the future.

Now, when it comes to small businesses, I know they're the backbone of our economy. They're the ones who create the jobs, who innovate, who take the risks. And we need to make sure we're givin' 'em the tools they need to succeed. That's why I'm proposin' targeted tax and regulatory relief, to help 'em reduce their costs, to help 'em grow and hire more workers.

Now, I know some folks might say, "How can we afford this, given the cost of the war on terrorism?" And I understand that concern. But let me tell you, we can't afford not to do this. We need to invest in our workers, in our small businesses, because that's how we're gonna grow our economy, that's how we're gonna create jobs. And besides, we're already runnin' a deficit, but we're also seein' signs of economic growth.

And let me tell you somethin' else. We're not talkin' about givin' out blank checks. We're talkin' about targeted relief, relief that's aimed directly at the areas that need it most. So, we're gonna be fiscally responsible, but we're also gonna be forward-lookin', makin' sure we're set up for success in the long term.

And I gotta say, I'm optimistic about our economy. I'm optimistic about the American people. We're a resilient bunch, and we're gonna get through this tough time, and we're gonna come out stronger on the other side. Thank you.

Well, thank you for the question. I'll try to address both parts of it. 

First off, I don't feel betrayed. I mean, I think it's natural for people who've worked in the administration to have differing opinions, and I respect that. We had a team of folks who worked hard to make tough decisions, and sometimes we didn't see eye to eye. That's okay. I think it's healthy to have diverse perspectives, and if some folks have criticisms after the fact, I respect that.

Now, regarding Chairman Greenspan's criticisms, I'm a little disappointed that he's spoken out. But I understand that's his right, and I respect his service to the country. As for his specific criticisms about my fiscal policies, I think it's quite simplistic to say that the problem was just too much spending or too many tax cuts.

We faced a very different economic environment when we came into office – the dot-com bubble had burst, and the economy was slowing down. We took actions that we believed were necessary to stimulate economic growth and job creation, including the tax cuts. And I think it's hard to deny that the economy did experience a period of growth and expansion after we implemented those policies.

However, I will say that I do take some issue with Chairman Greenspan's timing. If he had concerns about the fiscal direction of the country, I wish he had spoken up more forcefully while he was still in office. Nevertheless, I appreciate the efforts he made to support our economic policies at the time, and I think his legacy on monetary policy is a distinguished one.

Ultimately, as President, I had to make a lot of tough decisions, and I tried to do what I thought was right for the country. I can live with the fact that not every single one of my former officials or advisors agrees with those decisions.

Thank you for the question. Let me make one thing clear: the threat from Al Qaida in Iraq is very real, and they are a brutal enemy. We've made significant progress against them, and we've taken out some of their top leaders. That being said, I would caution against saying we're close to declaring victory just yet.

You see, this is a complex and dynamic situation, and it's not just a matter of defeating Al Qaida in Iraq militarily. We're also working to build a stable and secure Iraq, where the Iraqi people can govern themselves and live in peace. And that's a long-term process.

Now, I understand that some of my critics may say we can't win this war militarily. But I disagree. I believe that our military is making progress, and we're doing so in a responsible and measured way. We're working with the Iraqi security forces to train them up, to mentor them, and to help them take on a greater role in the fight against Al Qaida.

We're also working through diplomatic channels to build consensus among the Iraqi factions, to encourage reconciliation and to promote stability. And we're working with our allies, like the Iraqi government and other international partners, to address the underlying causes of the conflict.

So, while I wouldn't say we're close to declaring victory just yet, I am confident that we're making progress. And I believe that our military efforts, combined with our diplomatic efforts, are the right way forward to achieve our goals in Iraq.

And let me be clear: our mission in Iraq is to succeed. We will not be deterred by the challenges we face, and we will not be swayed by the critics who say we can't win. We will continue to work tirelessly, to adapt to changing circumstances, and to stay focused on our goals. And I'm confident that, in the end, we will emerge victorious.

[Smiling] Well, I appreciate the question. As you know, we're closely monitoring the economic situation, and I want to assure the American people that we're working diligently to ensure that our economy remains strong and vibrant.

Regarding the mortgage market, we're indeed considering a plan to help families who are struggling with their mortgage payments. We believe it's essential to provide relief to those who need it most, while also maintaining the stability of the financial system.

Beyond that, we're looking at a range of options to stimulate economic growth and address the current slowdown. We're considering proposals to boost consumer confidence, support small businesses, and encourage investment in key sectors. We're also working with Congress to pass legislation that will help us tackle the challenges we're facing.

As you know, we've already taken steps to shore up the financial system, including our actions to stabilize the mortgage market and support the financial institutions. But we recognize that there's more work to be done.

I want to assure the American people that we're committed to doing everything in our power to support the economy and help those who are struggling. We're working closely with our economic advisors, the Federal Reserve, and other stakeholders to explore all options and make informed decisions.

Ultimately, our goal is to ensure that America's economy remains strong and resilient, and that all Americans have access to opportunities for growth and prosperity. We'll continue to monitor the situation closely and take decisive action as needed. Thank you.

Thank you for your question. I understand the concern about the world's oil supply and our energy future. Now, I'm not an expert, but I do rely on the experts, and I think we're finding more oil, and we're using technology to extract more oil, not only here at home but around the world.

Now, I'm not sure I agree with the assessment that we're close to tapping out. I think we've still got a lot of capacity to find and extract oil. However, I do agree with you that we need to have a comprehensive energy strategy that includes not only fossil fuels but also alternative energy.

And that's why I'm proud to say that we've increased our investment in renewable energy research by about 27 percent. We're working on hydrogen fuel cells, wind, solar, you name it – we're working on it.

And I think that's important, and we'll continue to do so. It's a necessary step for our country to become less dependent on foreign oil, and we're making progress.

And I would argue that our energy policy, which is a comprehensive policy that includes a lot of good ideas, is being implemented. And I'm proud of the work that's being done by the Energy Department and other agencies.

Now, could we do more? I'm sure there are more things we could do. But I think we're making good progress, and we'll continue to do so.

But it's also important for the American people to understand that as we move forward on energy independence, we can't just rely on one source of energy. We need an all-of-the-above approach – we need to explore, we need to extract, we need to conserve, and we need to use new technologies to bring new energy sources to the table.

(laughs) Well, I think there may be some confusion here. I think the question about climate change was meant for the Prime Minister of Finland, not me, but I'll answer the first part of the question.

Regarding Iran and the debate in Israel, I've always said that the United States, and I believe the international community, wants Iran to be a part of the international system, but not at the expense of undermining the security of countries in the region. Israel is a very close friend of the United States. We've had a long-standing relationship, and we will continue to work with Israel to make sure that the security concerns are addressed.

The United States has made it clear that a nuclear Iran is unacceptable. I've made that clear. I've worked with our European friends and the United Nations to try to get Iran to understand that it's in their best interest to abandon their nuclear weapons program.

And, of course, we'll work with Israel to make sure that they feel secure in the region. I'll stop there. I don't want to get into a hypothetical debate about what Israel's policies might or might not be. Our position on Iran's nuclear program is very clear, and we'll continue to work with the international community, including Israel, to address this issue.

(pauses, turns to the Prime Minister of Finland)

Mr. Prime Minister, I think you've got a question coming your way.

Well, thank you for that question. First, let me say I'm glad to see some progress in Iraq, and I appreciate the efforts of our allies in North Korea to address some of the concerns that led to that designation.

Now, if I were to update the axis of evil list today, I would include extremist groups who seek to harm American interests and our allies. I'm talking about al-Qaeda and its affiliates, who have shown time and time again a willingness to attack innocent civilians. I'd include countries like Syria and Iran, who continue to support these extremist groups, and who pursue nuclear programs that threaten the stability of the region.

And let's be clear: the Iranian and North Korean nuclear programs pose a serious threat to the safety of the free world.

As for the greatest and most urgent threat, I think it's clear that terrorism, in all its forms, is still the greatest threat to our national security. You've got these extremist groups who seek to attack us, and we've got to stay vigilant.

But if I had to identify a specific threat that requires immediate attention from President Obama, I'd say it's the likes of al-Qaeda in the Arabian Peninsula, who have shown a willingness to attack us and our allies in the region.

Now, I believe the war in Afghanistan is a key part of this fight, and we've got to continue to work with our allies to disrupt and dismantle these extremist networks. And let's not forget, we've also got to address the situation in Pakistan, where these extremist groups are seeking to destabilize the region.

So, in short, I think terrorism remains the greatest threat, and al-Qaeda and its affiliates are the ones we've got to stay most vigilant about.

Thank you for that question. The incident involving the U.S. missionary plane is a tragic event, and our thoughts and prayers are with the families of the victims.

As for the U.S. role in this incident, I want to assure the American people that we're taking a hard look at the circumstances surrounding this tragedy. The U.S. had been providing assistance to Peru in their efforts to interdict aerial trafficking of narcotics, but it's clear that there was a terrible mistake made in this case.

While our spotter plane did identify the missionaries' aircraft, it's Peru's Air Force that took the lethal action. However, we recognize that our participation in the broader counter-narcotics effort in the region may have contributed to the circumstances that led to this tragic event.

We're committed to fully cooperating with Peru in the investigation and to determining exactly what went wrong. We'll also be conducting an internal review of our own procedures to ensure that we do everything we can to prevent such a terrible mistake from happening again in the future.

My administration takes the safety of American citizens very seriously, and we will do everything in our power to prevent such a tragedy from occurring again.

I appreciate the question.  Yes, I do agree with the Attorney General that there's no doubt about Timothy McVeigh's guilt.  He was convicted by a jury of his peers, and the evidence was overwhelming.  I think it's fair to say that the American justice system worked in this case, and that justice was delivered to the victims and the victims' families.

Regarding the second part of your question, I do not believe that Director Freeh's decision to retire from the FBI had anything to do with the Timothy McVeigh case or any of these newly released documents.  Director Freeh is a man of great integrity, and I respect his decision to retire after many years of public service.

(smiling) Well, I appreciate the question. I do recall the disappointment of 1992, when my father lost his re-election bid. It was tough, but you've got to remember, I'm a loyal son, and I was there for him. (pauses for a moment)

As for yesterday's conversation, I think it's fair to say we talked about the weight of the presidency, and the lessons he's learned over the years. He offered some sage advice, but I'll keep that between us, at least for now. (chuckles)

Regarding the second term, I do feel a sense of freedom to tackle some tough issues that we may have been hesitant to address in the first term. Now, I don't want to suggest that we were constrained by politics in the first term, but there's no doubt that re-election considerations can influence the way you govern.

One area where I feel more free to act is on Social Security reform. It's a tough issue, and we know it's not going to be easy, but we've got to address it. I think, in a second term, we can push the politics aside and focus on finding a solution that's good for America. (leans in) Now, don't get me wrong, we're not going to try to cram through some ideological agenda, but we will be bold, and we will take some risks to address the big challenges facing this nation.

And, of course, we're also looking to make some changes in the tax code, to make sure that it's fair and that it's promoting economic growth. We'll be looking to reform some of the entitlement programs, and make sure that we're living within our means as a nation.

So, while there's not a single issue that we're going to tackle just because we're in a second term, I do feel a sense of freedom to be more bold, and to take on some of the tougher challenges that face this nation.

"My fellow American, I appreciate your question and the spirit behind it. Bipartisanship, to me, is about finding common ground, not common party affiliation. It's about putting the interests of the American people above the interests of our party or our own personal interests.

Now, I know some folks might think that bipartisanship is just about getting a few Democrats to vote with us on a particular issue. But I believe it's more than that. It's about sitting down with the Democratic leadership, listening to their concerns, and finding areas where we can work together.

I've made it a point to reach out to the Democratic leadership, to listen to their ideas, and to work with them on a wide range of issues. Whether it's on education reform, or Social Security reform, or tax reform, I believe that we can find common ground and work together to get things done.

Now, I know we're not going to agree on everything. That's the nature of democracy. But I believe that by working together, we can find solutions that benefit the American people, regardless of party affiliation.

And let me give you an example. On the education reform bill, we worked closely with Senator Kennedy and Congressman Miller to craft a bill that would improve our nation's schools and help our children succeed. And I'm proud to say that it was a bipartisan effort that passed with strong support from both parties.

So, to answer your question, I believe that bipartisanship is not just about picking off a few Democrats on a case-by-case basis. It's about working regularly with the Democratic leadership to find solutions that can win broad support across party lines and benefit the American people."

Well, thank you for the question. (pauses) I think, you know, when you're dealin' with security for the President of the United States and other world leaders, we have certain requirements that we gotta meet. And sometimes, that can cause, uh, friction, I suppose, with the host country. (clears throat)

Now, I think the Chileans were excellent hosts, and we appreciate the hospitality they showed us. But when you've got a group of folks like the APEC summit, with leaders from all over the Pacific Rim, you gotta be careful about security. And, you know, I think there was just a misunderstanding, really, about some of the measures that we thought were necessary.

I did have to lend a hand to one of my Secret Service agents, but that's just part of bein' the President, makin' sure everyone's safe. (smirks) I'm just glad I could help out.

Now, I will say this: when you're dealin' with international relations, there's gonna be misunderstandings, there's gonna be disagreements. But I think the important thing is how you work 'em out, and I think we did that in a very respectful way with the Chileans.

Good morning to you as well. I appreciate the question. Let me start by saying that our concerns about Iran's nuclear program are rooted in the fact that we cannot trust the regime in its current form. The Iranian leadership has consistently demonstrated that it is not interested in being a responsible player on the world stage, and its pursuit of nuclear capabilities is a threat not just to the region, but to the entire world.

In terms of what we might be willing to accept, let me be clear: we will not stand idly by while Iran develops a nuclear weapons capability. We are working closely with our international partners to find a diplomatic solution that would bring Iran into compliance with its international obligations, including the Nuclear Non-Proliferation Treaty.

However, if Iran were to demonstrate a commitment to transparency, to cooperation with the International Atomic Energy Agency, and to abandoning its pursuit of nuclear weapons, we would be willing to consider a civilian nuclear power program that is subject to strict international safeguards. But let me be clear: this is not a concession, and it's not a guarantee. Iran must earn the trust of the international community, and it must demonstrate that it is willing to be a responsible player.

Regarding the second part of your question, we have made it clear that we support the Iranian people in their aspirations for democracy and freedom. We have taken steps to support the Iranian dissident community, and we will continue to consider ways in which we can support those who are working towards democratic reform in Iran. However, let me also be clear: the United States will not be a party to any efforts that would seek to impose regime change by force or coercion. Our goal is to support the Iranian people in their peaceful efforts to bring about democratic reform, and we will continue to work with our international partners to find ways in which we can support those efforts.

But I want to be clear: our support for the Iranian people is not a euphemism for regime change. We are not in the business of picking winners and losers in Iran. Our goal is to support the democratic aspirations of the Iranian people, and we will continue to work towards that end in a responsible and measured way.

(pausing, choosing words carefully) Well, I appreciate the question. As I've said before, I've got confidence in Karl Rove, he's a trusted advisor, and I've given him my full trust. I'm not going to get into a detailed analysis of every conversation he's had or every move he's made.

Regarding the CIA leak episode, we've been very clear about the Valerie Plame affair. And the fact that the prosecutor found no wrongdoing on Karl's part, I think, is an important aspect of this whole episode. Now, I know there's been a lot of speculation and a lot of speculation about conversations, et cetera, and you know, I just don't think it's productive to get into parsing every single word.

Regarding an apology, that's something that's up to Karl. I will say this: Karl Rove is a very decent and honorable man, and I know he's hurt by some of the things that have been said about him. As for Scott McClellan, Scott McClellan is a fine individual, did a fine job for us, and I appreciate his service. (pausing again) But I'm the President of the United States, and I'm not going to get into assessing apologies. My view is that Karl's been unfairly maligned in certain quarters, and that's about all I'm going to say on that. Next question?

Thank you for that question. I'm glad you asked that. I think, first of all, the multinational force should be a robust one. It's gotta be a force that's capable of making sure that the bad guys can't stir up trouble. And I think that Turkey and Italy have been very forward-leaning in their desire to help. I think it's very interesting that two of America's strong allies, or, at least, allies of the United States, in the neighborhood and in NATO, respectively, are willing to take the lead. And we're working with other nations, as well – France, to a certain extent, although we haven't pinned down France's participation yet.

As for Hizballah, I think it's very important that Hizballah be neutralized, one way or the other. And, of course, that's a subject of ongoing diplomatic discussions, and military planning. And, as the Prime Minister said, the key is to have a resolution that can bring a cessation of hostilities. And, we don't want to see people being killed needlessly, day after day in the Middle East.

In terms of an immediate cease-fire, I'm a bit skeptical, because I think that an immediate cease-fire doesn't necessarily make the situation in the region better. What I want to see is a lasting peace. I want to see a peace that's sustainable. And so, while agreeing to an immediate cease-fire might seem appealing, I'm not sure that's the right way to go, at least, from my perspective, so, it needs to be carefully thought through.

In terms of systemic solutions to this conflict, we also need to address issues that make Lebanon strong, you know, empowering its institutions and its army. We need, also, to do something, to address the Israeli-Palestinian conflict, here. And so, these are – we're talking about a program, a big sweep of agreement.

I appreciate the question. Let me tell you, I understand that the American people are understandably concerned about the situation in Iraq. We've faced some tough times there, no question about it. But I firmly believe that our mission in Iraq is crucial to the safety and security of the American people.

I'm not making decisions based on polls. I'm making decisions based on what I think is in the best interest of this country, and what I think is necessary to keep America safe. I fully believe that the long-term results will vindicate our strategy.

We're making progress in Iraq, despite the difficulties we face. The Iraqis are starting to take control of their own security, and that's a positive step. We're working to build a democracy in a region that's known for, well, not being democratic. And we're taking the fight to the terrorists, so we don't have to fight them here at home.

Now, I know that not everyone agrees with my strategy, and that's okay. I respect that. But I got to make the tough decisions, and I'm convinced that in the long run, we'll be proved right.

It's not about seeking vindication, though. It's about doing what I think is right. And I'm not going to change my policy based on a daily or weekly poll. I'm going to do what I think is in the best interest of this country, no matter what. That's what a President's got to do.

Thank you for the question. The Baker-Hamilton report, I believe, is a very constructive and a very valuable report. The Iraq Study Group, chaired by Secretary Baker and former congressman Lee Hamilton, has done a lot of work on this issue, and their recommendations are worth careful consideration.

As for its weight, I would say it's one of many considerations, but it's an important consideration. I've always believed in seeking advice from wise people and considering various perspectives. That's why I've asked for input from the Pentagon, the State Department, and others. However, I do value the input of the Iraq Study Group. They bring a lot of experience and a lot of breadth of knowledge to this issue.

And as for the personal relationship between Secretary Baker and my family, I can tell you that Jim Baker is a friend, but that doesn't influence my decision-making. What influences my decision-making is what's in the best interest of the country and our troops and the people of Iraq. So, I will consider all these various inputs and then make a decision that I think is right for the country.

That being said, I am grateful for the work of the Iraq Study Group. They've done a lot of hard work, and I appreciate their dedication to this cause. Their report is a valuable contribution to the discussion, and I will certainly give it the consideration it deserves.

I appreciate that question. The fact that Iraq is being debated in the halls of Congress and on the campaign trail shouldn't come as a surprise to anyone. It's a very difficult challenge we're facing, and I'm glad we're having a national conversation about it.

Now, I'm not concerned about the debate hurting our progress in Iraq. Matter of fact, I think a healthy debate will help keep us focused on the task at hand, which is to help the Iraqi government achieve victory over these terrorists and to train the Iraqi security forces to be able to defend themselves.

Regarding briefing the candidates, I think that's a decent idea. I'd be more than happy to have our national security team brief the candidates on the ground situation in Iraq, as well as our strategy going forward. It would be helpful for whoever the next President is to have an understanding of the commitment we're making in Iraq, the progress we're making, and the problems that still remain to be solved.

Laura and I were just in Iraq last June, and we saw firsthand the progress that's being made. The Iraqis are beginning to take ownership of their security, and that's a very hopeful sign. And I'd want whoever the next President is to understand that and to build on that progress.

But I must caution, it's one thing to have a briefing; it's another thing to have, you know, political positions that may or may not be wise. The American people expect the President to have a serious plan, a well-thought-out plan to achieve victory in Iraq, and that's what I've always done, and I'm confident that the next President will, as well.

So, I think the briefing is a good idea, and I'd be more than happy to work with the candidates to make sure they're briefed.

Good morning. Thank you for your question. Well, I believe the Mexican people want reform because, just like the American people, they want a hopeful future. They want their families to have a chance to succeed, they want to be able to live in a system that is orderly and fair, and there is great desire by the Mexican people to have an immigration system that reflects the values of the two nations.

And there's a reason why I believe we can get reform: because the AmerÃ­can people, and I believe the Mexican people, are longing for a result. And we've got a pretty good chance of passing a comprehensive bill that addresses the concerns of border security, as well as dealing with people with dignity and respect.

You know, I've spoken to many Members of Congress, I believe that there's a growing awareness on both sides of the aisle that it's in our interests to pass this bill. Now, I'm not naive about the difficulty of getting comprehensive reform through; it's going to take a lot of hard work.

Thank you for that question. The situation in Iran is a grave concern for the United States and the international community. The Iranian government's pursuit of nuclear capabilities is a threat to regional and global security, and we will not stand idly by while they flout their international obligations.

Regarding the detention of the Iranian Americans, we have made it clear to the Iranian government that it is unacceptable to detain these folks and we are working to get them released, and we expect that they will be released soon.

As for the IAEA's report on Iran's uranium enrichment program, it's clear that the Iranian government is not taking the necessary steps to alleviate the concerns of the international community. The Iranian government must understand that its refusal to cooperate with the IAEA and its defiance of Security Council resolutions will only lead to increased isolation.

Now, regarding sanctions, I do believe that tough UN sanctions with real teeth are necessary to get the attention of the Iranian government. The United States is working closely with our allies and partners at the UN to draft a strong resolution that holds Iran accountable for its actions.

As for Russia and China, I am confident that they will join us in supporting tough sanctions. Both countries have expressed concerns about Iran's nuclear program, and I believe they will see that it's in the best interest of regional stability and security to support a strong UN resolution.

We will continue to work with our partners to build a united international front to address this crisis, and I'm optimistic that we can find a peaceful solution that prevents Iran from developing nuclear capabilities. Thank you.

I appreciate that question, and I'm happy to provide some clarification. Now, let me be clear: we know that Saddam Hussein had a long history of supporting terrorism, and we know that he had ties to terrorist organizations, including Al Qaeda.

Now, with regard to the specific attacks in Iraq, we have reason to believe that Al Qaeda in Iraq, also known as Zarqawi's organization, is indeed affiliated with Usama bin Laden. We've got information that suggests they've got connections to each other, and we're continuing to work to disrupt those connections.

As for the evidence, we've had multiple reports from various sources, including interrogations of senior Al Qaeda leaders, that suggest a link between Saddam's regime and Al Qaeda. Now, I know some folks have questioned the nature of those links, but I can tell you that we take that intelligence very seriously.

Now, I'm not suggesting that Saddam Hussein was directly responsible for the 9/11 attacks. But what I am saying is that Saddam's regime did have a history of supporting terrorist organizations, including Al Qaeda. And we believe that by taking him down, we've disrupted those connections and made America safer.

As for Zarqawi, we know he's a bad guy, and we know he's got connections to Al Qaeda. And we're going to keep working to bring him to justice. We're making progress in Iraq, but it's not going to be easy, and it's not going to be quick. But we're committed to seeing this through, and we're committed to protecting the American people.

Now, I know there are still some who question the connection between Saddam and Al Qaeda. I understand that. But I can tell you that our intelligence community has worked hard to get to the bottom of this, and we believe that the evidence suggests a link. We're going to keep working to build on that intelligence and to root out terrorist organizations wherever they are.

That's all I can say on that for now.

Thank you for the question. The events in Minneapolis were a tragedy, and my heart goes out to the victims and their families. In terms of the infrastructure needs of our country, we do have a significant challenge before us. However, I've always been a bit skeptical of increasing federal gasoline taxes. I believe we have a responsibility to be good stewards of the taxpayer's dollar, and I think there may be other ways to address this issue.

Now, I'm not opposed to taking a fresh look at the issue, and I'm willing to work with Congress to find a solution. But I also think we need to be mindful of the impact any tax increase would have on working Americans and the overall economy. We need to make sure we're not burdening our citizens with unnecessary taxes.

Instead, we should consider a more comprehensive approach that incorporates a range of funding options, perhaps including, for example, increased efficiency in government spending or leveraging the private sector. There may also be opportunities to tie infrastructure funding to reforms in the way we manage and prioritize our transportation programs.

I appreciate the enthusiasm of the Romanian people, and I'm glad to see the strong ties between our nations. We value our relationship with Romania, and we're committed to strengthening it.

Regarding the visa issue, I can tell you that we're working diligently to reform our visa policy, but I must emphasize that it's a complex process that involves national security concerns. We're making progress, but I don't want to give you a specific deadline just yet.

What I can say is that we're committed to making it easier for Romanians to travel to the United States, and we're exploring ways to streamline our visa application process. We're working closely with the Romanian government to address these issues, and we appreciate their cooperation.

I'll make a commitment to you that we'll work hard to make progress on this issue, but I'm not ready to give you a specific deadline just yet. I will, however, ask Secretary of State Condoleezza Rice to continue to work closely with the Romanian government to find ways to improve travel between our two nations. We value our relationship with Romania, and we want to make it easier for our citizens to visit each other's countries.

And I might add, we're also making progress on the issue of Romania's admission to the Visa Waiver Program. We're working closely with the Romanian government to ensure that they meet the requirements of the program, and I'm optimistic that we can make progress on this front in the near future.

Well, Helen, I appreciate the question. You know, I've been very clear with the Congress about what we need to get the job done in Iraq, and that's what the supplemental's purpose is. Now, I've also said that I'm open to other ideas, but we've got to be mindful of the costs.

Regarding extending unemployment benefits, I think that's an idea worth discussing. We want Americans who are looking for work to have the support they need during these uncertain times. However, we've also got to make sure we're not creating a new entitlement program that we can't afford.

When it comes to our veterans, I'm a big supporter of our troops, and I want to make sure we're taking care of them when they come home. Now, I haven't seen the specific language, but I'm willing to consider additional support for our veterans, especially when it comes to education benefits. Those men and women have served our country with honor, and we've got a responsibility to help them achieve their goals.

Now, I will say that I'm still committed to the $108 billion number. We can't just keep adding and adding without considering the fiscal implications. We can do some good things within that framework, and I'm willing to work with the Congress to find ways to support our veterans and those Americans looking for work. But we've got to be fiscally responsible, too.

So, I'm open to discussions, but we've got to make sure we're not just throwing money around without thinking about the consequences. That's not responsible leadership, and that's not what the American people expect from us.

Thank you for your question. I appreciate the opportunity to address this important issue. As we gather here today in Genoa, I want to emphasize the importance of global cooperation in addressing the economic challenges that we're all facing. 

We are committed to working closely with our G-7 partners to promote economic growth and stability around the world. We recognize that there are risks to the global economy, and we will be discussing those risks and the steps that each of our countries can take to address them. We will be urging our partners to adopt policies that promote economic growth, including reducing barriers to trade and investment, and increasing investment in education and infrastructure.

Regarding the strong U.S. dollar, I will be discussing this issue with our G-7 partners here in Genoa. We believe that market forces should be allowed to determine exchange rates, but at the same time, we are monitoring the situation closely and are prepared to take action if it becomes necessary to support global economic growth.

I would like to hear from Prime Minister Blair on the steps that Europe is taking to stimulate the global economy, and I am sure that he will want to address this question directly. Tony?

Thank you for the question. I appreciate the opportunity to address this critical issue. Let me be clear: corporate corruption is not just a matter of justice; it's also a matter of national security and economic security. As I said before, 9/11 taught us that we must confront threats before they materialize, and corporate corruption is no exception.

In response to the scandals we've seen, we're taking several steps to strengthen investor confidence and prevent future abuses. First, we've proposed and signed into law the Sarbanes-Oxley Act, which enhances disclosure requirements and provides tough new penalties for corporate wrongdoers.

Second, we're working with the Securities and Exchange Commission to improve disclosure requirements and strengthen enforcement. The SEC is now more empowered to pursue wrongdoers and ensure accountability.

Third, our administration is committed to improving corporate governance. We believe that boards of directors must be independent, and we're encouraging companies to adopt best practices in this regard.

Fourth, we're working to improve transparency and disclosure, to make sure investors have the information they need to make informed decisions.

Finally, we're encouraging the culture of corporate responsibility to spread throughout our business community. Corporate America must recognize that its social compact with the American people requires a commitment to integrity, transparency, and accountability.

To the investors across the country, I say this: we're committed to creating an environment where you can trust your investments, where you can be confident that the rules are being followed, and where corporate America is working to uphold the highest standards of integrity and responsibility.

(I pause, choosing my words carefully) Well, I think it's clear that Saddam Hussein has not fully cooperated with the inspectors, and the United Nations has given him a choice: disarm, or face the consequences. We're working with the international community to resolve this peacefully, but as I've said, I'm not optimistic that Saddam Hussein will change his ways.

If the resolution is passed, we'll be working with our allies to enforce the will of the United Nations. If it's not passed, we'll be working with our allies to enforce our own national interests. Either way, our goal is the same: to disarm Saddam Hussein and make sure he doesn't pose a threat to his neighbors or to the world.

(Leaning forward slightly) Now, I don't want to speculate about the prospects of going to war. I hope that can be avoided, but I will not rule it out. The American people, the Congress, and our allies expect us to defend our national interests, and we will do just that.

(Pausing, looking around the room) I think it's clear that we're at a critical moment. We've got to be steadfast, we've got to be resolute, and we've got to work together to achieve our goals.

Well, thank you for your question. As you know, the transfer of sovereignty to the Iraqi government is a significant milestone, and it's a testament to the progress we're making in Iraq. Now, regarding Saddam Hussein, we're certainly open to discussions with the Iraqi government about the transfer of custody.

However, I want to make it clear that our primary concern is ensuring that Saddam Hussein is held accountable for his crimes, and that justice is served. We're weighing the ability of the Iraqi justice system to meet international standards of fairness and due process, as well as the potential risks and security implications of transferring custody.

It's also worth noting that Saddam Hussein is being held under a UN Security Council resolution that calls for him to be brought to justice by an Iraqi-led process. We're committed to supporting the Iraqi government in their efforts to bring Saddam Hussein to justice.

Regarding Usama bin Laden and Mullah Omar, our position remains unchanged - we will pursue them and bring them to justice, wherever they may be. As for who will try them, that's a matter that's still being determined. However, I can assure you that we're working closely with our allies and partners to ensure that these individuals are held accountable for their crimes.

Ultimately, our goal is to see justice served, and we're exploring all available options to achieve that goal.

Thank you for your question. I've made it very clear to the world that a nuclear Iran is unacceptable. Iran, as you know, is a threat not only to the region, but to the world. I've worked very closely with Prime Minister Sharon and now with Prime Minister Olmert to make it clear to them that the United States is committed to a two-track approach: one track being diplomacy, to try to convince the Iranians to give up their desire for a nuclear weapon, and the other track being to consider all options necessary to protect America and our friends and allies.

As for Israel, I've had very good discussions with the Israeli leaders, and I've made it clear that while we understand their concerns, we also understand that any action they take should be in the context of international opinion, and in the context of close cooperation with the United States.

I won't speculate on specific actions that Israel may take, but I will tell you that we are in close consultation with them, and we will remain in close consultation with them on how best to protect our shared interests, and our shared values.

But make no mistake about it: we are firmly committed to preventing Iran from becoming a nuclear power, and we will continue to work with our friends and allies in the region, including Israel, to achieve that goal.

Thank you for that question. It's a very astute observation about the changing dynamic in the world, particularly with regards to China. I'd say, first and foremost, we need to recognize that China is a complex relationship, it's a multifaceted relationship, and it's a relationship that's changing rapidly.

We have to recognize the economic reality that we're dealing with. China is a growing economy, a rising power, and we need to welcome that, and we need to work with them economically. The fact that they are financing a large part of our trade deficit is a direct result of our engagement with them, and we need to be mindful of that. But we also need to be mindful of the implications of that relationship.

Regarding their human rights record, we cannot be silent. We must be vocal in our opposition to the oppression of human rights and religious minorities. We've seen evidence of that in Tibet, and in other parts of China. We've expressed our concerns at the highest levels of government, and we'll continue to do so.

Now, regarding the label you asked about – ally, rival, competitor – I'd say we need to be realistic about what our relationship with China is. We're not enemies, but we're not exactly allies either. We share certain common interests – in nuclear nonproliferation, in counter-terrorism – where we can work together. But we also have significant differences that need to be recognized.

I'd say we need to think of China as a strategic competitor. A nation that's rising economically, and is making its presence known in the world. We need to be aware of the implications of that, and we need to work with our friends and allies around the world to help shape our collective response to a rising China.

We'll work with China where our interests align, and we'll work to hold them accountable where our interests diverge. And we'll do so in a peaceful and diplomatic manner, recognizing that we have a long-term interest in a stable and prosperous China.

We've been working very closely with Congress, and I think it's good that there's a lot of interest in finding a way forward that will enable us to protect America, and at the same time, protect our citizens' civil liberties.

As I've said many times, this is a difficult balance, but it's one that we can achieve. And I'm open-minded to the idea of working with Congress to see if we can't find a way to make sure that we're giving our instruments of protection the tools they need, while at the same time, protecting the rights of our citizens.

Now, I do want to emphasize that the existing program, the terrorist surveillance program, is a vital tool, and it's a necessary tool. And it's been successful. We've been able to gather intelligence that has helped us prevent attacks.

But I'm also mindful of the concerns that people are expressing, both about the oversight and the balance between national security and civil liberties. And I think we can work with Congress to find a way forward that will address those concerns.

So, I'm not resistant to the notion of finding a way forward with Congress. I think it's a good avenue to pursue. And I'm confident that, working together, we can find a way that will protect America, and at the same time, protect the rights of our citizens.

Well, I appreciate the question. Let me say that our policy on North Korea is clear: we're committed to a peaceful resolution to the problems on the peninsula, and that involves addressing the nuclear issue, the missile issue, and the concerns about counterfeiting and money laundering. We're working closely with our partners in the region, including China, to achieve this goal.

Regarding the six-party talks, I believe that the format has been productive in the past, and we're willing to participate in a way that's constructive and helps to move the process forward. However, I also want to make it clear that we won't engage in talks just for the sake of talking. We need to see real progress on the key issues, and that's something we'll be discussing with the Chinese and other parties in the days ahead.

Regarding the issue of ballistic missiles, it's a very serious concern for the United States, and for our friends and allies in the region. We're committed to addressing this issue, and we expect North Korea to comply with its commitments under the Non-Proliferation Treaty and other international agreements.

Now, on the issue of money laundering, I believe it's an important issue, but I also agree that it's not the sole focus of our policy. We need to address the broader concerns about North Korea's behavior, including its nuclear and missile programs. But we also need to take seriously the issue of counterfeiting and other forms of illicit activity, because they can have a significant impact on our financial systems and our economy.

So, we'll continue to work with the Chinese and other parties to address the full range of issues related to North Korea, and we're committed to finding a peaceful resolution to the problems on the peninsula. Thank you.

Well, thank you for the question. I appreciate it. First of all, I believe that Social Security is a vital program, and we must make sure that it fulfills its promise to our seniors. The system, as it stands today, is not sustainable, and we need to make some reforms to make sure that future generations have access to Social Security.

As I said in my campaign, I believe that young workers ought to have the option of setting up a personal retirement account as part of their Social Security investment. This is not a privatization of Social Security. This is not taking away from the system; it is adding an add-on. And the reason I think this is a good idea is that it gives young workers the ability to own their assets and make better gains than the current rate of return.

Now, I understand that there's a disagreement on how to reform Social Security, and I appreciate that. I'm willing to work with the Democrats and Republicans to come up with a plan that will strengthen Social Security and make sure that it fulfills its promise.

But I must also say that it's essential that we address this problem now. We cannot keep kicking the can down the road and saying, "It's okay, it'll take care of itself." It won't. We need to be bold and creative in thinking about how we reform Social Security.

I've made it clear: there are some principles that are not negotiable. We cannot afford to bankrupt the system, nor can we reduce the benefits of our seniors. But I am willing to work with — I'm willing to work with the Democrats and Republicans, fiscal conservatives and liberals, to get this job done.

This is an important issue for the country, and I'm committed to working across party lines to make sure that we solve the problem and strengthen Social Security for our future generations.

Thank you for the question. I appreciate the opportunity to address this important issue. With regards to the Iraq Study Group Report, I think it's a thoughtful report, and I appreciate the time and effort that went into it. As for the recommendation on talking to our adversaries, I think we've got to be careful about who we're talking to and what we're talking to them about. I've got a problem with talking to people who are trying to harm our troops, and I've made that clear.

We've got a situation where the Syrians are housing Hamas, where the Iranians are providing arms to bomb our troops in Afghanistan and Iraq. It's a complex situation. And I believe we can't just rush into negotiations without having a clear agenda and a clear set of goals.

Now, I do think we need to be open-minded to talks, but it's got to be talks that are aimed at producing concrete results, not just talks for the sake of talks. I think I understand what Secretary Baker's getting at – that we need to be willing to engage. But we also need to be mindful of our national security interests and ensure that we're not engaging in a way that undermines our own security.

So it's a delicate balance. I appreciate the advice from my predecessor, from a man I admire. But we'll make our decisions based on what we think is in the best interest of the United States of America.

Thank you. Good afternoon, everyone. I'm glad to be here with President Vazquez, and I appreciate the question.

Regarding the trade agreement with Uruguay, I want to assure you that my administration is committed to pursuing free and fair trade agreements that benefit both our countries. We recognize that there are some obstacles to overcome, but I'm pleased to report that we've made some good progress in our discussions today.

We've had productive conversations with President Vazquez and his team, and I think we've identified some areas where we can move forward. We're willing to listen to Uruguay's concerns and work together to find solutions that benefit both our nations.

In terms of specifics, I'd say that we're exploring ways to address some of the non-tariff barriers that have been impediments to trade between our countries. We're also discussing ways to increase bilateral trade in areas such as agriculture, energy, and services.

I'm optimistic that we can make progress on these issues, but I also want to be clear that we will only pursue agreements that are in the best interests of the American people.

Regarding the second question, I'd say that President Vazquez and I did discuss the issue of the mill plants and the disagreements between Uruguay and Argentina. While these are bilateral issues between Uruguay and Argentina, we're willing to offer support and assistance to help resolve these disputes.

President Vazquez and I agree that it's in the interest of both our countries to resolve these issues in a way that promotes economic cooperation and integration in the region. I think we can play a helpful role in facilitating dialogue and cooperation between Uruguay and Argentina, and we're willing to do so.

Well, that's a hypothetical, and I'm going to answer it in a way that's going to be very clear: We have a good relationship with President Musharraf, and we've had discussions about the need to share intelligence, to collaborate, to work together to bring to justice those who would harm our country or harm his country.

Now, I'm not going to get into the specifics of what we would or wouldn't do, because we've got to make sure that we're respecting the sovereignty of other nations, at the same time recognizing the threat that we face.

That being said, I will tell you, we've had extensive discussions with President Musharraf, and I believe he understands the threat that Al Qaida poses to his country, as well as to ours. And we're working closely with him to make sure that we can bring to justice, or if necessary, take out those who would harm our people.

And as for President Karzai, he's the President of Afghanistan, and he's got to meet with whomever he can to make sure that Afghanistan continues to make progress towards being a stable, democratic society. And one of the concerns that I'm sure he'll talk to President Musharraf about is making sure that those who would try to destabilize Afghanistan, namely the Taliban, don't have safe haven.

Now, I think it's also worth noting that we've got a good relationship with President Karzai, and we're working closely with him to help him be successful.
