We want to make sure that Afghanistan is a stable society, that it can provide its own security, and that its neighbors understand that a stable Afghanistan is in their interests as well.

But to answer your question specifically, it's not a hypothetical anymore, because I'm not going to reveal what we would or wouldn't do in that situation, because it's important to keep our operational capacity to ourself (sp), our friends and allies.

Thank you, and good morning to everyone. Well, I think it's a very tough situation, as we all know, in the Middle East. President Abbas and the Palestinian people deserve a chance to live in a peaceful, democratic society, and I believe that's possible.

First, let me say that we fully support Mahmoud Abbas and the Palestinian Authority in their efforts to establish a free and democratic society. But, it's got to be a two-way street. We need to see the Palestinians acknowledging Israel's right to exist, and we need to see them take control of their own territory. Gaza's a very tough case, because Hamas, which is a terrorist organization, is interfering with the ability of the Palestinian Authority to govern.

Now, I've talked to Prime Abbas about this, and I've talked to other world leaders about this. We need to work together to figure out ways to help the Palestinian Authority get control of Gaza. And that means helping them to develop their security forces, their military, their law enforcement capabilities, so they can take on the terrorists who are trying to destabilize their own government.

But it's also crucial that we see compliance from the Palestinian side. We need to see the Palestinian leaders adhering to the principles of the Roadmap, and that means stopping the violence. It's also crucial that the international community stands strong in our support for the Palestinian people, giving them the opportunity to succeed.

So, I believe it's a very, very difficult situation, but I'm optimistic that, with the right strategies, the right approach, and the commitment to the cause of peace, we can achieve a two-state solution, and help the Palestinian people to live in peace.

Thank you for the question. I'll address the issues you raised. 

First, on the state of our economy, I understand there's a lot of concern, but I'm not going to make a determination like that based on one quarter of economic data. The jury's still out, in my view. Now, we've seen some turbulence in the markets, some contraction in growth, but we've also seen some strong fundamentals in place - low unemployment, low inflation, and a consumer that's still spending.

Now, we're watching the data closely, and we're taking steps to address the challenges we face, particularly in the housing and financial sectors. But I'm not going to make a judgment about whether we're in a recession or not based on a single quarter's numbers. We'll continue to monitor the situation carefully and work with our economic advisors to take the necessary steps to keep our economy growing.

On Zimbabwe, the situation is unacceptable, and we're deeply concerned about the humanitarian crisis there. We're working closely with our international partners, including the African Union and the United Nations, to support a peaceful and democratic resolution to the situation.

Regarding South Africa's role, we appreciate the efforts of the South African government to help resolve the crisis in Zimbabwe. President Mbeki has been active in trying to mediate a peaceful resolution, and we support those efforts. We also urge the government of Zimbabwe to respect the will of the Zimbabwean people and to take immediate action to address the humanitarian crisis there.

We'll continue to work with our partners in the region to address this crisis and to support the people of Zimbabwe in their quest for a more prosperous and democratic future.

That's a great question. You know, I've thought about that a lot, and I've talked to some of my fellow former presidents about it. We've all been through this experience, and it's... it's a unique one, to say the least.

I think for President Obama, that moment, that feeling of the weight of the office, it's going to hit him at different times, in different ways. It might be a crisis like we saw on 9/11, or it might be a quiet moment, when he's sitting in the Oval Office, pondering a tough decision.

As for advice, I've had a chance to meet with President Obama, and I've shared some of my own experiences with him. I think the best advice I can give him is to stay focused on the big picture, to keep his priorities straight, and to never forget where he came from. The presidency is a... it's a remarkable honor, but it's also a tremendous responsibility. You've got to be able to make the tough decisions, even when they're not popular.

I've also told him to surround himself with good people, people who will give him honest advice, people who will tell him what he needs to hear, not just what he wants to hear. And I've encouraged him to take care of himself, to make time for his family, to get out of the bubble every now and then. It's easy to get caught up in the bubble, but it's not good for your soul.

You know, I've also talked to President Clinton, and we've shared some of our own experiences with President Obama. We've all been in his shoes, and we've all felt the weight of the office. I think we've tried to pass on some of the lessons we've learned, some of the things we wish we'd known when we were in his shoes.

But at the end of the day, it's his presidency, and he's going to have to find his own way. He's going to have to learn to navigate the bubble, to deal with the isolation, to make the tough decisions. And I have confidence that he's going to do just fine.

Thank you for the question. Let me first say that we had a very productive discussion on currency issues at the summit, and I'm pleased to report that we're all committed to flexible exchange rates and to avoiding protectionism.

Now, with regard to the strong dollar, I believe it's a reflection of the underlying strength of the US economy. Our economy is growing, our budget deficit is declining, and we're making progress on issues like energy and trade.

Now, I know that some of our exporters may face challenges in competing with foreign producers, but I believe that our free trade policies and the competitiveness of US business will ultimately help us to stay ahead of the curve.

I would argue that a strong dollar also helps to discipline the federal budget and promote fiscal responsibility. It sends a signal to the markets and to the American people that we're serious about keeping our economic house in order.

Now, I understand that a strong dollar can also have implications for other countries, and I acknowledged that in my discussions with President Putin and other leaders. But I believe that it's in everyone's interest to see a stable and balanced global economy, and that's what we're working towards.

And, if I might, I think President Putin might like to add his own thoughts on this issue.

(clears throat) Thank you for the question. Well, I think it's fair to say that our focus has broadened. We're at war with terror, and we're in a global conflict, not just focused on one individual. Now, make no mistake, Osama bin Laden is a terrorist, and he's a killer, and we want him brought to justice. But I don't spend a lot of time, I don't dominate my conversation with Osama bin Laden. We're broader in our thinking. We understand that there's a network, a global network of terrorists, and we're after all of them.

As to whether — you know, is he alive or dead, we don't have concrete evidence. I wouldn't rate it. We don't have information, credible information that would lead us to know for certain, one or the other.

(leaning forward)
Now, let me address the last part of your question. Deep in my heart, I know that there are going to be terror threats no matter what. There's a danger out there that — in this world that we live in, it's a different kind of war. And I understand it's going to take time and effort to deal with this threat. That's why I've got this Homeland Security office set up, to help coordinate the efforts of our nation to make sure our homeland is secure.

But, I do believe, I firmly believe, that if he's out there, and if we have evidence that would lead us to a more accurate conclusion, that would be a success for the United States and for our coalition.

The Iraqis' sudden invitation to the arms inspectors. Well, I think it's a tactical maneuver by Saddam Hussein, a ploy to muddy the waters, delay the inevitable, and throw a wrench in the works. We can't let the cat-and-mouse game fool us. We must remain resolute and steadfast in our determination to disarm Saddam Hussein and hold him to account. 

The arms inspectors made it clear in their report that Iraq's declarations were incomplete, that there were significant discrepancies and omissions. We will not be deterred by empty gestures or cosmetic efforts to deflect attention from the real issue. We will continue to work with the international community to keep pressure on Saddam Hussein to ensure that his government takes concrete actions to disarm.

I must say, I'm not surprised that Saddam is making these overtures, given the increasing pressure he's facing. This is a clear sign that our efforts are having an effect. But the world won't be fooled. We'll keep the pressure on, holding Iraq to account and pursuing our diplomatic efforts to secure a peaceful resolution that will bring disarmament to the world. Thank you.

Tom, thank you for your question. I'm joined here today with Prime Minister Blair, and I'll let him have a chance to respond as well.

First of all, I do view the attacks today as a direct attack on our efforts to bring stability and democracy to Iraq. The enemy we're facing is a terrorist enemy that will stop at nothing to achieve their goals. And their goal is to undermine the efforts of the Iraqi people to become a free and democratic society.

As for the question of sovereignty, I'm as committed as ever to transferring sovereignty to the Iraqi people. We're working hard, along with the Iraqi Governing Council, to ensure that we have a legitimate, representative government in place by June 30th. The transfer of sovereignty will be a significant milestone in our efforts to bring stability and democracy to Iraq.

Now, the attacks are certainly a challenge, and we're doing everything we can to confront the enemy and to protect our troops and the Iraqi people. But I'm confident that we'll be able to meet our goal of transferring sovereignty by June 30th.

Tony, would you like to add anything to that?

I think one of the great things about America, one of the great strengths of America, is our capacity to harbor great compassion and tolerance. People from different walks of faith can live together in peace. We value the relationship between church and state. And the President of the United States and the Prime Minister must, must respect the faiths of others.

And so when I say "the Almighty," I'm simply saying that there is a higher power, that's different from me and from Bin Laden. I believe that there is an Almighty, and I try to be humble in recognizing that there's a higher power, that guides our lives in many ways. And, of course, Americans come from all different faiths, and we're united in our — in our devotion to the Almighty, and the freedoms that derive, that are delivered from the Almighty.

We have different views, obviously, on how the Almighty affects our lives, but to me, that's what so wonderful about America. And the Prime Minister and I have had wonderful conversations about the power of faith, the power of faith to bring people to a solid understanding, common humanity and the importance of people treating others with respect and dignity.

Go ahead Mr. Prime Minister, I think you've got a reaction on this.

Thank you for that question. I'm happy to be here with President Fox, and we've had some very productive discussions about trade and other issues.

First of all, let me say that the United States is committed to free trade. We believe that trade is a powerful tool for economic growth, for creating jobs, and for improving the standard of living for people around the world. And we're committed to moving forward with free trade agreements in the Western Hemisphere.

Regarding a free trade agreement for North America, President Fox and I have discussed this issue, and we agree that it's a goal worth pursuing. However, we also recognize that there are some complex issues that need to be worked through, such as transportation and agricultural trade. But I'm confident that with hard work and a willingness to compromise, we can make significant progress on these issues.

Now, regarding a free trade agreement for the Americas, it's a more ambitious goal, but one that I think is worth striving for. We've already made significant progress through the Free Trade Area of the Americas initiative, and we're committed to continuing to work with our partners in the region to move this process forward.

Now, I know that there are some countries that have expressed opposition to a free trade agreement, and that's not unexpected. But I'm confident that we can work through those concerns and find common ground. And I'm willing to work with the leaders of those countries to address their concerns and find a way forward.

I think it's worth noting that a free trade agreement for the Americas could bring significant benefits to the people of this hemisphere. It could create jobs, increase economic growth, and improve the standard of living for people across the region. And so, while there are certainly challenges to be overcome, I believe that the potential benefits make it worth pursuing.

Thank you for that question.

That's a great question. I, of course, understand why Americans might feel that way. But I want to remind everyone that this is a global effort. We're not going it alone. The United Nations has passed a resolution, as you mentioned, that calls for international cooperation in stabilizing Iraq.

Now, I understand that we've taken the lead in this effort, and we will continue to do so. But I'm confident that our allies and friends around the world will begin to step up and provide the assistance that's needed.

We've got some countries that have already committed to helping, like the South Koreans and the Poles, who have sent troops. We've got Japan and Italy who are committed to sending troops. And we've got other countries who are interested in participating as well.

In terms of debt relief, that's an important part of helping Iraq get back on its feet. The Paris Club, as you know, has worked out a deal to forgive a significant portion of Iraq's debt. And we're working with other countries to try to get more debt forgiveness.

Now, I know it's a slow process, but it's a process that's underway. And I'm confident that, over time, our friends and allies will step up and help us with the security effort.

But make no mistake about it, we will do what it takes to succeed in Iraq. We're committed to the success of the Iraqi people, and we're committed to making sure that the mission is accomplished.

It's tough work, but we're making progress, and I'm confident that in time, the world will see the progress we're making.

Thank you for the question. I'm glad to be here today to talk about this very issue. You know, I believe that Social Security is a vital part of our safety net, and we need to make sure that it's solvent and sustainable for future generations. And that's why I'm proposing personal accounts as a part of a comprehensive reform package.

Now, I understand that there are concerns among some of the Democrats, and I respect that. But I believe that personal accounts offer a way to give younger workers, in particular, a chance to build a nest egg of their own, to have a stake in the system, and to know that they're going to have a more secure retirement.

Now, I know some of the Democrats are saying that this would undermine the Social Security system. But I think they're misunderstanding how personal accounts would work. Personal accounts would allow workers to take a portion of their payroll taxes and invest them in a diversified portfolio of stocks and bonds. This would give them a chance to earn a higher rate of return than what they're currently getting from the Social Security trust fund.

And here's the key point: the accounts would be voluntary. Nobody would be forced to participate if they don't want to. And those who choose not to participate would stay in the traditional Social Security system, just as it exists today.

Now, I believe that this would help to build a more sustainable Social Security system for the future. By giving younger workers a chance to build their own wealth, we would reduce the burden on the system over time. And by allowing workers to invest a portion of their payroll taxes, we would create a more efficient and effective way to manage our retirement system.

So, I think personal accounts offer a way to strengthen and modernize Social Security, to make it more secure for future generations. And I'm willing to work with Democrats and Republicans to make sure that we get this done.

And let me just say one more thing. This is not just about politics; this is about making sure that our Social Security system is secure for the people who depend on it. And I'm committed to working in a bipartisan way to make sure that we get this done. Thank you.

(pausing for a moment) Well, I appreciate the question. Let me be clear: the United States is committed to promoting democracy and freedom around the world, and that includes Belarus. We believe that the Belarussian people deserve to have a say in their own government, and that means free and fair elections.

Now, I'm not going to negotiate or speculate about specific deals or arrangements with the Russians or anyone else when it comes to the internal affairs of Belarus. What's most important is that the Belarussian people have the right to choose their own leaders and determine their own future.

As for Russia's influence in the region, we've been clear that we're concerned about the erosion of sovereignty and the bullying of neighboring countries. We've made it clear that we stand with our friends and allies in the region who are committed to democracy and freedom.

But let me also say this: I do believe that the United States and Russia have common interests on a range of issues, including counter-terrorism, non-proliferation, and energy security. And we're going to continue to pursue those interests in a way that's consistent with our values and our principles.

So, I wouldn't say that we're prepared to "go all the way" in the sense of trying to impose our will on the situation, but we are going to continue to advocate for democracy, freedom, and the rule of law, and we're going to work with our partners and allies to achieve those goals. Thank you.

Thank you for the question. I think it's a great opportunity to discuss this important power granted to the President.

First of all, I believe that the power to grant pardons is a solemn responsibility, and it's not something that should be taken lightly. I've always approached this issue with a great deal of care and thoughtfulness.

My philosophy on granting pardons is that they should be awarded in cases where there's clear evidence of an individual's rehabilitation, or where the circumstances of the pardon would serve the interests of justice. I've been guided by a commitment to fairness, compassion, and the rule of law.

I'm not concerned about comparisons to my predecessors. I'm concerned about doing what's right and just in each individual case. I believe that the pardon power should be used judiciously and with restraint, rather than as a way to curry favor or reward supporters.

I think that my record on pardons reflects my commitment to these principles. I've taken a careful and deliberate approach, reviewing each case on its merits and consulting with my advisors to ensure that we're making the right decision.

So, I don't view myself as being stingy when it comes to pardons. I view myself as being a careful and thoughtful steward of this great power that's been entrusted to me as President.

You know, I think it's very important for us to learn a lesson from the politics of the past, and that is, we must not make personal attacks. We must be respectful, even when we disagree on policy. I think it's very important for our leaders in Congress to understand that we can disagree without being disagreeable.

Now, I do believe we've got a difference of opinion when it comes to our strategy on terrorism. I strongly believe that the United States must be a steadfast and strong leader in the world, and that we must do everything in our power to protect the American people. And I think there are going to be legitimate differences of opinion about how to do that.

But to question the motivations of a person who is in public service is not the kind of tone that I think is going to help us come together as a nation. I think it's very important for all of us to be respectful of each other's dignity, even when we disagree. And I'm not going to get into the business of casting aspersions, and I hope the leaders of both parties will be respectful of each other as we go forward.

Well, thank you for your question. First of all, my heart goes out to the families of those who have lost their loved ones. The American people need to know that we're praying for the families, and we're thinking of them.

Now, regarding our policy in Iraq, I believe that we are making progress. It's tough, there's no question about that. The enemy is determined to undermine our efforts, but I believe we've got a good strategy in place.

The joint operations with the Iraqi forces, the surge that we implemented earlier this year, I believe has been effective in addressing the security concerns in Baghdad and in Anbar Province. There's still a lot of work to be done, don't get me wrong, but I believe we're making progress.

Now, regarding the missing soldiers, we're doing everything we can to locate them. Our military's working hard to find those missing soldiers, and we will do everything in our power to bring them home. I'm confident that the brave men and women of our military will do everything they can to locate and rescue our missing soldiers.

As to sustaining our policy, I believe that we must stay the course. The stakes are high in Iraq, and we cannot let the terrorists and the insurgents win. If we were to leave now, I fear that the consequences would be catastrophic – for us, for our allies, and for the Iraqi people.

I know that there are those who disagree with our policy, and I respect that. But I believe that we're doing the right thing, and I'm committed to seeing this through.

Let me make one thing clear: we will not be deterred by this violence. We will not be deterred by the terrorists and the insurgents. We will continue to work towards a free, democratic Iraq, where the Iraqi people can live in peace and prosperity.

And I believe that with the right strategy in place, with the bravery and sacrifice of our military, and with the support of the American people, we can achieve that goal. Thank you.

Thank you for the question. You know, I've always believed that our country needs a comprehensive energy strategy, one that promotes energy security and reduces our dependence on foreign oil. Now, I know some folks might say, "Hey, with oil prices high, we don't need those tax breaks." But the truth is, we need to create a stable environment for our energy producers, so they can make the investments necessary to increase supply and reduce our reliance on foreign oil.

Now, I understand that some of my critics might say we're being inconsistent, but I'd argue that we're not. We're simply acknowledging that the world has changed since we first started talking about this issue, and we need to adapt to those changes. But the underlying principle remains the same: we need to promote energy production, energy conservation, and energy efficiency.

That being said, I'm open to having a constructive conversation about our energy policy, and that includes looking at tax breaks and incentives. But we need to be careful not to send the wrong signal to our energy producers. We need to make sure that we're giving them the confidence to move forward with their investments.

And let's not forget, we've made some significant strides in this area, like the Energy Policy Act of 2005. It's a commonsense approach that promotes conservation, increases energy efficiency, and encourages the development of new technologies. So, I'm open to working with Congress to make sure we're getting our energy policy right, but I'm also committed to making sure that we're promoting energy security and reducing our dependence on foreign oil.

(excitedly interrupting) Ah, hold up, I think there's been a mistake! I'm not the Prime Minister, I'm the President of the United States! (chuckles from the press corps) 

Now, let's answer your question. On the issue of climate change, I believe we made some progress in our talks, but there's still a lot of work to be done. We need to find a way to balance our economic interests with our responsibility to the environment. I'm hopeful that we can reach an agreement in Copenhagen, but it won't be easy.

Regarding the Democratic contenders, I'm not going to get into a debate with them from up here. But I will say this: my foreign policy has been guided by a commitment to protecting America and its interests, as well as promoting freedom and democracy around the world. If my successor wants to take a different approach, that's their prerogative. But I believe our policies have been successful in making America safer and more secure.

Thank you for the question. First of all, I want to acknowledge that the global food crisis is a serious issue that requires a comprehensive response. The Secretary of State, Condoleezza Rice, did express concerns about the impact of biofuels on global food prices, and I share those concerns.

Now, while the development and use of biofuels have been important goals of my administration, particularly with regards to our commitment to reducing our nation's dependence on foreign oil, we also understand the unintended consequences, especially when it comes to food prices.

As for what the United States can do, I'd like to highlight a few areas of action. First, we've made significant contributions to international food relief efforts. We've committed over $2 billion to food aid programs around the world. I also announced a request for an additional $1 billion in the '09 budget to support food aid and agricultural development programs.

Second, we're also working to improve the global agricultural productivity. We've committed to support research and development initiatives, including drought-tolerant crops and other new technologies to help increase yields and reduce the pressure on global food supplies.

Third, we recognize the need for market-based solutions. We'll continue to push for more open trade and market liberalization in international agricultural markets, as well as continue our efforts to address the distortions caused by subsidies and other trade barriers that artificially raise food prices.

Lastly, we must look at the role of biofuels more closely. I instructed the EPA Administrator, Stephen Johnson, to review the impact of our biofuels policy on global food prices. We're also engaged in talks with U.S. farmers, automakers, and other key stakeholders to make sure we're on the right path.

Now, this crisis requires a coordinated global response, and I'm committed to working with international partners, including the G8, to ensure that we're doing everything possible to support global food security and alleviate the suffering of those who are most vulnerable.

Thank you for your question. First, I want to express my deepest sympathies to the families of those brave men and women who have lost their lives in Afghanistan. It's a sober reminder of the sacrifices that our troops and their loved ones make every day.

Regarding your question, I would say that Afghanistan remains a critical front in the war on terror, but it's not necessarily a replacement for Iraq. Both countries present unique challenges that require our attention and action. In Afghanistan, we're making progress. The Taliban are on the ropes, and the Afghan people are increasingly turning against them.

However, we do face a challenge in the form of increased attacks, particularly in the east and the south. But I'm confident that our strategy is sound, and I appreciate the strong support of our NATO allies and the international community in Afghanistan.

Now, regarding the question of troop levels, I've always said that we'll adjust our force posture based on the needs on the ground. We're constantly reviewing our options, and if we need to make adjustments, we will. But we also have to be mindful of the military's ability to sustain itself and to make sure that we're not overstressing our troops.

As for the 2009 date, I'd say that we're on track to meet our goals, but we're also prepared to make adjustments as needed. We're working closely with the Afghan government, with our NATO allies, and with the international community to make sure that we're providing the necessary support to the Afghan people.

But I will say this: we will not let Al-Qaeda or the Taliban succeed. We will stay the course, and we will continue to work towards our goal of a free, secure, and stable Afghanistan.

Thank you for that question. I'm deeply concerned about the situation in Liberia. The violence and the loss of innocent life is unacceptable and a major humanitarian crisis. As Commander-in-Chief, I have to weigh the options carefully.

First, I want to assure you that the safety of American citizens is our top priority. The U.S. Marines that we have deployed to Liberia are there to protect our embassy and our diplomatic personnel, as well as other American citizens who may be in harm's way.

Regarding the situation with the civilians, I am deeply troubled by reports of atrocities and human rights abuses. We are working closely with our international partners to address the humanitarian situation and to find ways to stop the violence.

As for sending U.S. peacekeepers, we are considering all options, but we also have to be mindful of the fact that this is a complex situation. We need to ensure that any U.S. involvement would be effective in stopping the violence and would not lead to further escalation. I'm in close consultation with our allies, the United Nations, and other international organizations to determine the best course of action.

But make no mistake, we will not stand idly by while innocent civilians are being targeted and killed. We will continue to work towards a peaceful resolution and to find ways to end the bloodshed and stabilize the situation.

Thank you for the question. I understand that the recent reports from Iraq have been difficult to hear, and I want to assure the families of our brave men and women in uniform that their sacrifice will not be in vain. The comparison to Vietnam is, in my view, a false one. We're on the offensive in Iraq, and our enemy is not a homogenous, sovereign state, but a ragtag group of terrorists and insurgents who are using Iraq as a battleground.

We are working diligently, with the Iraqi people and the international community, to build a stable, democratic government that can provide security and hope to the Iraqi people. We have made progress, despite the challenges and setbacks. The insurgency is a real challenge, but we are adapting our tactics, and we will prevail.

I understand that there are doubts and concerns among the American people, and I respect that. But we must be mindful of the facts on the ground. We are not in a stalemate; we are making progress. We've trained over 140,000 Iraqi security forces, who are taking on more responsibility for their country's security every day. We're reconstructing Iraq's infrastructure, its economy, its schools, and its hospitals.

This is a vital mission, and I believe it's worth the fight. I believed that on September 12, 2001, and I believe it today. We will not be intimidated by the tactics of the enemy, and we will not abandon the Iraqi people to the mercy of the terrorists. We will see this through, and we will succeed.

And to those who doubt our strategy, I'd say: our strategy is to train and stand up the Iraqi security forces, to improve the Iraqi economy, and to bring the small bands of terrorists to justice. And I believe that we are making progress, and I believe that we will succeed.

(pausing for a moment, reflecting on the question) Well, I appreciate the question. You know, as President, you're going to make decisions, and you're going to make mistakes. And I've made my fair share of them. But, if I had to look back, I'd say one of the biggest mistakes I made after 9/11 was the handling of the intelligence on Iraq, specifically WMD.

You see, we were given intelligence that suggested Saddam Hussein had weapons of mass destruction, and I relied on that intelligence to make my decision to go to war in Iraq. Now, in hindsight, it's clear that the intelligence was flawed, and we didn't find those WMDs. That was a difficult lesson to learn, and it had significant consequences.

One of the lessons I learned from this experience is the importance of critically evaluating intelligence, questioning assumptions, and being more careful in articulating the justifications for going to war. I also realized that, as President, you've got to be willing to challenge your own assumptions, to question the advice you're getting from your team, and to seek diverse perspectives.

And I'd like to think that, as a result of this experience, I became a more thoughtful and cautious leader, particularly when it comes to matters of war and peace. But, you know, as President, you've got to be willing to learn from your mistakes and move forward, and that's exactly what I've tried to do.

(pauses)

And one other thing: I've also learned that, in the aftermath of 9/11, we were all feeling the heat of the moment, and it's easy to get caught up in the immediacy of a crisis. But, as President, you've got to take a deep breath, reflect on the situation, and think carefully about the long-term consequences of your actions.

(lowering his voice)

These are hard lessons to learn, but I believe they've made me a better leader, and I hope they'll serve as a reminder to future Presidents to always approach these kinds of decisions with caution and humility.

Thank you for that question. Let me tell you, the security of our border, not just with Canada, but with all our borders, is of utmost importance to me and to our nation. And I think, in the aftermath of 9/11, it became clear that we needed to do some things differently. We've made some progress in securing our borders, but I'm not satisfied yet.

My vision is that we continue to work with our friends and allies, including Canada, to ensure that our borders are secure, but not at the expense of hindering the free flow of trade and commerce between our two countries. We can achieve that through better technology, better cooperation, and better information-sharing.

Now, regarding the concept of a common security perimeter, I think it's an interesting idea. We've already begun initiatives with Canada to share intelligence and collaborate on counter-terrorism efforts. But I think any proposal for a common perimeter would need to be studied carefully, taking into account our respective sovereignty and laws.

Now, regarding the issue of Canada's marijuana laws [chuckles], I believe it's a legitimate concern that we have the potential for the increased flow of illegal substances across our borders. I'm not pointing fingers at Canada, but it's an issue we'll need to work on together.

Well, thank you for that question. Let me start by saying that I have a lot of trust in Prime Minister Sharon. I believe he's a man of his word, and I believe he's committed to the process. The roadmap is a critical part of bringing peace to the Middle East, and I think it's a good plan. 

As you know, I've been very clear with the Prime Minister about my disapproval of settlement activity. I've made it clear that it's not helpful. On the other hand, I also understand the Prime Minister's need to protect his people, and I think he's made a very bold move in pulling out of Gaza. I think it's a historic move, and I think it's a move that will cause some discomfort, but it's a necessary step towards establishing the conditions for peace.

In terms of the Prime Minister getting support, I think we've been very clear with him that when he makes a bold move like this, there will be support from the United States of America. I think we've been consistent in our message. Obviously, there are different opinions within any administration about various issues, but our core commitment to the peace process and to the prime minister's efforts has been unwavering.

Well, thank you for your question. I believe that the progress we're making in Iraq is clear. We've achieved a significant victory with the death of Abu Musab al-Zarqawi, and the formation of a new, democratically elected government is a major step forward. I understand that there's still work to be done, but I believe we're making real headway.

Now, as for whether the American people are winnable back, I think it's a fair question. Look, there's been a lot of skepticism, there's been a lot of criticism, and that's to be expected. But I also know that Americans are a fair-minded people, and when they see progress, when they see results, they're willing to give credit where credit is due.

I think we've got to continue to remind the American people of the stakes. We're not just fighting for Iraq; we're fighting for the security of America, we're fighting for the values of freedom and democracy. And I think as we continue to remind people of those stakes, and as we continue to make progress, we can win back the American people.

Now, I'm not naive; I know it's going to take time. I know there's going to be ups and downs. But I believe in the American people; I believe they're smart, I believe they're fair-minded, and I believe they'll come to see that this effort was worth it.

I appreciate the question. I understand where Secretary Powell is coming from, and I value his opinion. However, I disagree with his assessment. We're at war, and the war is aimed at a particular enemy: radical Islamic extremists who want to destroy our way of life.

I believe that our strategy is sound. We're on the offense against these terrorists, and we're using all the tools at our disposal to win this fight. We're working with our allies, we're building democracy in Afghanistan and Iraq, and we're working to spread freedom and hope around the world.

Now, I know that there will be disagreements about the conduct of this war, and I welcome a healthy debate about our strategy. But I firmly believe that we're on the right course.

I'd also like to remind the American people that we're making progress in this fight. Al-Qaeda is on the run, and we're determined to bring Osama bin Laden to justice. We've also seen significant reforms in the Middle East, as more and more countries begin to adopt democratic values.

I appreciate Secretary Powell's concerns, but I'm confident in the choices we've made, and I'm committed to seeing this through to victory.

Well, thank you for that question.  I appreciate your candor. Look, I'll tell you, we're a big party, with a lot of members and we're not immune to the frailties of human nature. People are going to make mistakes, and when they do, it's my job as the leader of the party to address those mistakes and make sure that we hold ourselves to a higher standard.

Now, I'll tell you, I'm not happy about the scandals that have occurred.  I think they're unacceptable, and I think we need to learn from them.  But I will tell you this, that we're taking steps to make sure that our party members understand that accountability is part of being in public service.

It's easy to point fingers, but at the end of the day, you have to take responsibility.  And I think our party is doing that. I mean, we're taking a hard look at ourselves, and we're saying, "How can we do better?" and "What can we do to restore the trust of the American people?"

Now I will say, that we're not perfect, we've got our flaws. But I'll tell you this, we're a party of accountability, and we're going to work to make sure that our members live up to the standards that the American people expect of us.

I believe that the American people want a government that's worthy of their trust.  And that's what we're going to work for every day. But I will tell you this; there are some parts of the story that the media might not be reporting, and that is we've also done a lot of good. We've cut taxes, we've created new jobs, we are winning the war on terror, we're making progress on education.

We are also reforming the system to make sure it is more honest and transparent, but we have to fix this country and I'm still able to proudly serve this country for the next couple of years so we have a lot of work to do, but I've got faith in the American people that ultimately we will get it right.

Thank you for your question. First of all, the National Intelligence Estimate is a confidential document, and I'm not going to get into the specifics of it. But I will tell you that the situation in Iraq is complex, and it's tough. There's no question about it. There's sectarian violence, there's ethnic violence, and there's terrorists who are trying to stop the advance of a young, fledgling democracy.

Now, I've always said that Iraq is a central front in the war on terror, and I believe that's true. I believe that if we were to leave before the job is done, it would embolden the enemy, and they would be more likely to come to our shores. I mean, these people have made it clear what their intentions are. They want to harm Americans, they want to harm our allies, and they want to disrupt the economy.

Now, regarding the notion of an open-ended commitment, I would say that, first of all, we're working on a specific task, and that's to help the Iraqis get to the point where they can take care of themselves. And that's a clear goal. It's a noble goal. And I believe we're making progress towards that goal.

It's also important for Americans to remember that we've had troops stationed in Japan since 1950, in South Korea since 1953. We don't consider those open-ended commitments. What we consider them is the United States being a reliable partner and helping our friends and allies to achieve their objectives. And that's exactly what were doing in Iraq.

And as for the issue of victory, I believe that victory is important, because I believe that it's in our interest to help the Iraqis succeed, and I believe we can succeed. We've got a plan in place. It's a good plan. It's the Baghdad Security Plan, and it's making progress.

And I understand that it's tough, but I also understand that, you know, resolve is needed in order to achieve a difficult objective. And I'm committed to seeing this through to the end.

Thank you, appreciate that question.  I, uh, I was briefed on this deal, and I'm, uh, it's a... it's a deal, it's a... it's a, uh, proposed deal, I guess I should say. And, uh, I think it's, uh, it's a deal that we're gonna take a close look at.

Now, I understand, there's, uh, concerns about, uh, national security. And I want to assure the American people that, uh, we will make sure that any deal that's made is in the best interests of our country. And, uh, if there's any concerns about national security, we'll, uh, address 'em.

Regarding, uh, protectionism, I am a free trader. I believe that, uh, the more trade we can have between our nations, the more likely it is that people can find good-paying jobs. I think it's, uh, very, very important for us to be mindful of protectionism, because I think it can be, uh, a, uh, a path that leads to kind of a... a, uh, downward spiral.

But I also understand, uh, that we've gotta be confident in the deals we make. We've gotta, uh, make sure that the deals we make are, uh, good for America. And, uh, that's exactly what we're gonna do.

I haven't seen the details of this deal yet. I'm looking forward to, uh, getting briefed by my, uh, my team. And, uh, after we, uh, examine the deal, we'll, uh, make a decision. But I will tell you this: We will look at it with an eye towards, uh, what's in the best interests of our country.

Missile defense. Well, I appreciate that question. As you know, I've been a strong advocate for missile defense for a while now. I believe it's essential for the security of the United States, and I also think it's essential for the security of our friends and allies.

Now, I want to make it clear that we're having very constructive conversations with our allies about this issue. We're working together to address this threat. And I'm optimistic that we can get a consensus on a approach that will allow us to move forward.

Now, I'm not going to prejudge what we'll do if we don't get a consensus. But I will tell you this: I think it's essential that the United States is able to defend itself, and that our allies are able to defend themselves. And if that means that we have to move forward without approval from some of our allies, I'm prepared to do so.

But I want to stress that we're not there yet. We're still in the process of consulting and working with our allies, and I'm optimistic that we can get a positive outcome. And I think, by the way, that our allies are beginning to understand the threat that we face, and I think they're beginning to understand the logic of a missile defense system.

And I'd like to hear from the Prime Minister on his views on this. (turns to Prime Minister) Tony?

Thank you, and I appreciate the question. I understand that there may be some frustration out there among our allies, and I want to assure them that we value our relationships and the partnerships we've built.

Now, I know there are some differences of opinion on the Kyoto treaty. We're committed to finding common ground, but we've got to be realistic about the impact it would have on the American economy. I believe our proposal for a flexible, market-based approach to reducing emissions is the right one. We'll continue to work with our allies to find a solution that works for everybody.

Regarding North Korea, we're committed to a peaceful resolution to the situation, but we're also clear-eyed about the challenges we're facing. We're working closely with our allies, particularly South Korea, Japan, and China, to find a way forward.

Now, I know the international press may be critical at times, but I'm focused on doing what's right for the United States. We'll keep working with our allies, we'll keep talking, and we'll find a way to resolve these differences.

I remember during the campaign, I talked about a new era of U.S. diplomacy, and that's exactly what we're trying to achieve. We're not going to just accept the status quo; we're going to challenge our friends and our foes alike to join us in finding new solutions to the world's problems.

So, I assure our allies that we value our relationships, we're committed to working with them, and we'll continue to do what's right for the United States and for the world. Thank you.

Thank you for the question. I understand the concerns that have been raised about the energy situation in our country, and I want to assure the American people that we're working hard to address these issues.

Regarding the recess, I believe it's essential for members of Congress to return to their districts and hear from their constituents. It's crucial that we allow them the time to do so.

Now, on the issue of energy policy, I've made it clear that we need to address our nation's energy needs in a comprehensive manner. We cannot afford to be held hostage by fluctuations in global energy markets. I support a broad approach that includes increased exploration, research into alternative fuels, and conservation.

Regarding the Republican bill in the House, I'm willing to consider measures that could help ease the burden on our energy consumers, including those in California. However, we must also ensure that any steps we take are environmentally responsible and consider the long-term implications.

I understand that there are concerns about my background, and I want to assure the American people that my policies are driven solely by what's in the best interest of this great nation. As a nation, we need to come together to find solutions to our energy challenges, rather than resorting to partisan blame. We must take a comprehensive approach that balances the needs of our economy, our environment, and our energy security.

And let me be clear: we will do what's right for America, not just what's convenient for the oil industry. We'll make decisions based on the facts, not on speculation or special interests.

Thank you for the question. I appreciate that. Well, first of all, let me just say that we've got a lot of work to do in order to make America safer. And I'm committed to working with Congress to get the resources necessary to do that.

We're going to have to do some cost estimates, but I'm not going to estimate the cost of a battle, and that's what this is – a battle to protect America against terrorism. One of the things we're going to have to do is to find new technologies, to find new ways to do our business, and to make sure that we allocate our resources wisely.

I think it's going to take a sustained effort, and I think it's going to take a commitment from all levels of government. Now, I know the federal government's going to have to take a lead role, but I also expect the state and local governments to step up and to be creative in the way they work, just like the federal government will be creative in the way we work.

And the private sector, of course, is going to play a significant role, too. I mean, one of the things that we're going to have to do is to work with our INS to make sure that we can create a system that helps us track in and out, and the private sector's going to be involved with that.

Now, I know we've got to be careful. We can't break the bank, but on the other hand, we can't just shortchange at a time of war. And I'm going to work with our budget team to figure out the best way to allocate these resources. I'm not going to give you a specific dollar estimate, but I can tell you that we'll continue to work to make sure we get it right.

Well, I appreciate the question. First, let me just say that I'm proud of the role I played in supporting our candidates across the country. It was a fantastic election, and I think our message resonated with the American people.

Now, regarding my own election, I think it's clear that the outcome was confirmed by the Supreme Court, and I accepted that decision. I think the American people, when given a choice, can make good decisions. And I think they made a decision to give me a second chance to serve, and I'm grateful for that.

As for whether this election validates my presidency, I think what validates my presidency is the hard work that we've done over the past four years to make America safer, more prosperous, and more compassionate. I mean, we've worked tirelessly to defend our country against terrorism and responded to natural disasters like Katrina. We've also pursued a foreign policy that's based on American values, such as freedom and human rights. So, the validation comes from the work that we've done, not just one election or another.

But, I must say, the midterm elections were a powerful reminder that the American people are responding to our message. They believe that we're on the right path, and I'm proud of the results.

Thank you for that question. I'm looking for the Deputy Chairman of the Federal Reserve. We're lookin' for a fella with expertise in the financial markets, somebody who's got a good understanding of monetary policy, and someone who's got a calm and steady hand.

We'll move as quickly as we need to, but we're not gonna rush into it. We'll take our time, make sure we get the right person, 'cause this is a critical position. It's a big job, and we want to make sure we get it right.

Now, regarding the question of should the new Chairman get a chance to pick their own person, I think that's a mighty fine idea. When I named Alan Greenspan to the Fed, he had his own team, and that was important to him. And I think that's important to the new Chairman. They've got to have their own folks in place, people they trust, people they believe in, in order to make informed decisions.

So, the answer is, I'll certainly take that into consideration, but ultimately, the decision is gonna be based on who's the best person to fill that job. We'll move as quickly as necessary, but we won't rush it. We'll take our time, and we'll make sure we get the right person for the job.

Thank you for your question. I appreciate your interest in this matter. Now, I understand what you're saying, and I want to assure the American people that I am committed to getting to the bottom of this leak. It's a serious offense to divulge the identity of a CIA agent. But I must remind you that this is a ongoing investigation, and I'm not going to jeopardize the opportunity for the Justice Department to pursue this investigation.

Now, I think it's a little premature for me to step in and ask for affidavits. We've just begun this process, and I don't want to interfere with the Department of Justice's ability to conduct this investigation. The attorney general, John Ashcroft, is a highly capable man, and I have every confidence in his ability to conduct a thorough and fair investigation.

We're going to let the Justice Department do its job, and if they determine that there's a need to take further action, we'll take that action. But at this point, I think it's best to let the investigation proceed without any... any prejudging or any efforts to try to... you know, inject politics into this process. We're going to let the Justice Department do its job.

材 Good afternoon. I'd be happy to address that question. First of all, let me just say that I have every confidence in Secretary Rumsfeld's ability to lead the Pentagon. He's a strong leader, and he's a good man, and I'm not going to make any decisions based on headlines or 24-hour news cycles.

I also want to remind the American people and the press corps that the President is the one who decides on personnel matters, not the Congress, not the media. And I appreciate Senator Harkin's comments, but I make the decisions.

Regarding the Abu Ghraib prison situation, I can tell you that it's unacceptable, it's shocking, and it's disturbing. It's a sad day for our country and for the military, because the actions of a few have tarnished the good name of the United States and the fine men and women who serve in our military.

As for the images, I think it's safe to say that they've caused significant damage, not just in our country, but around the world. The images of abuse and mistreatment are terrible, and they do not reflect the values of the United States of America or the values of the men and women who serve in our military. We value human rights, we value human dignity, and we will get to the bottom of this, I promise you that.

But I want to remind everyone that we are a nation of laws, and we will conduct a thorough investigation, and we will take the necessary action to address this situation and prevent it from happening again.

Thank you for the question. I understand that there are concerns about America's image around the world, and I take those concerns seriously. The actions we took after 9/11, in my view, were necessary to protect our national security and to spread freedom and democracy in a part of the world that had been plagued by tyranny and terrorism.

Now, I understand that those actions may have created tensions and concerns among some people, particularly in the Muslim world. And I want to assure you that we're actively working to address those concerns and to build stronger relations with our allies and friends.

First, we're working to promote a positive vision of America, one that emphasizes our values of freedom, tolerance, and opportunity. We're also working to engage with the Muslim world through efforts like the Middle East Partnership Initiative, which is designed to promote economic and educational opportunities, particularly for young people.

We're also working to strengthen our alliances with our traditional friends and allies, like the UK, Germany, and Japan, and to build new partnerships with countries like India and Indonesia.

And most importantly, we're working to help create a new generation of leaders in the Muslim world who share our commitment to freedom, tolerance, and human rights. We're providing support for moderate voices within the Muslim world who are working to build a more tolerant and inclusive society.

In terms of concrete steps, we plan to increase our public diplomacy efforts, to engage in more dialogue and outreach with Muslim communities around the world. We'll also work to provide more support for programs that promote tolerance, education, and economic development.

But I also want to emphasize that America's image is not just about how we're perceived by others; it's also about who we are as a people. And so, we're also working to promote a more positive image of America by living up to our values of compassion, generosity, and hope.

And let me just say one more thing. I'm proud of the way America has come together after 9/11 to support those in need, whether it's in Afghanistan, or in the tsunami in Asia, or in the hurricane ravaged parts of our own country. America's generosity and compassion are values that I think are worthy of our image and that will ultimately help us build stronger relationships around the world.

[Laughter] Well, first of all, I want to thank the press corps for a question that's so cleverly phrased. [Laughter]

I will make changes to the Cabinet, as dictated by desire of individuals to leave, for whatever reason. I will make changes, and I will pick people who can get the job done, who share my philosophy, and who will work well with the team.

I've learned a great deal about Cabinet government. I think consistency is very important. I think it's very important for a president to be able to have trust in the people who serve him or her. And I think I've got it. I think I've been able to assemble a team that has worked well together.

I've also learned that accountability is very important. And I think I've been able to instill a sense of importance – a sense of accountability in the Cabinet, and I intend to keep it that way. And I've learned that it's very important to surround yourself with people who will tell you what they think. And I've got a lot of people around this town who will tell me what they think, and I appreciate that.

Now, as for the White House staff, I am very pleased with the White House staff, I must say. I've been very impressed with their discipline, their dedication, their hard work. And I've also been impressed with the way they've been able to handle a lot of the tough issues that we've faced.

Now, I will make changes as necessary. I mean, people do burn out in this business. And I will make changes as necessary. But I will do so, by picking people who are – like I said – who share my philosophy, who will get the job done, and who will work well with the team.

And let me – let me just add one other thing. I haven't been disappointed with the quality of people in the White House, or the Cabinet. I think I've been very blessed to have had the kind of people who have come to work here. And I appreciate their service, I really do.

Thank you for the question. I appreciate the interest in pursuing comprehensive reform. On the issue of combining tax reform and Social Security reform, I believe it's essential to approach these two critical matters separately and in a methodical manner.

While I acknowledge that there are some who believe that a comprehensive overhaul of the tax code could provide alternative revenue streams for Social Security, I remain focused on addressing the pressing issue of Social Security's solvency first.

Make no mistake, I'm committed to tax reform, and we're making progress in that area. However, addressing the fiscal challenges facing Social Security is a top priority for this administration. I'm concerned that combining the two efforts might divert attention and resources away from our goal of ensuring the long-term solvency of Social Security.

That being said, I am open to exploring alternative financing mechanisms for Social Security, and we're considering various options. However, any proposal must meet several key criteria, including not raising taxes, not increasing the burden on low- and moderate-income Americans, and ensuring the solvency of the Trust Fund for generations to come.

So while I appreciate the suggestions, I believe it's essential to pursue Social Security reform and tax reform in a separate, yet complementary, manner.

(laughs) Well, I understand that math is not always the most exciting topic, but I appreciate your affection for it, nonetheless. Now, on the issue of Social Security, I truly believe that the numbers are clear. The trust fund will be exhausted by 2042, and if we don't act, our children and grandchildren will be left with a system that's unsustainable.

Now, as for why it's tough on the Hill, I think there's a mix of both. Some folks are genuinely looking at the numbers and saying, "We don't see a crisis." But I think the crisis is very real. What I'm trying to do is to get people to focus on the long-term problem, not just the short-term politics.

And yes, I understand that Social Security has historically been called the "third rail" of politics – touch it and you get shocked. But I believe that's exactly why it's time for us to have a serious, honest discussion about how to fix it. We need to be willing to tackle this issue, to make the tough choices now, so that we can ensure the system's solvency for future generations.

It's not going to be easy, but I'm committed to working with members of both parties to find a solution. We need to put politics aside and focus on what's best for the American people.

Well, I think it's natural for there to be scrutiny and debate in Washington, D.C. It comes with the territory. I'm not concerned about the scrutiny on my administration or on my nominees. What I am concerned about is getting the right people in place to help me make good decisions and to carry out our policies.

And I think it's healthy for there to be debate. I think it's healthy for people to ask tough questions. And I think our nominees have shown that they are more than capable of answering those questions.

Now, I will say that I hope that my nominees won't get held up unnecessarily. I think we need to get about the business of getting good people in place to help us make decisions. And I'm confident that, in the end, the Senate will confirm our nominees because they're highly qualified, they're talented, and they're committed to the law.

As for me, personally, I'm used to criticism. I've been criticized for a lot of things. But I know what I'm doing. I'm doing what I think is right for the country. And if some people don't agree with me, that's fine. That's democracy.

Well, thank you for the question, I appreciate it. First of all, let me reiterate my position on steroids: I believe that the use of steroids is, in no uncertain terms, cheating. And I think it undermines the integrity of the game. And I think it's particularly damaging to young people who look up to athletes as role models.

Now, regarding Congress's involvement, I do think there's a fine line between legitimate oversight and interference. As I've always said, my preference is for the leagues and the players to handle this issue themselves. I believe that the Major League Baseball needs to be more proactive in ensuring the integrity of the game, and I've been encouraged by the steps they've recently taken.

Now, I also understand, however, that Congress has a legitimate interest in this issue, particularly when it comes to the impact on public health. So, I wouldn't call the subpoenas an abuse of power per se, but I would caution that Congress should approach this issue with a measured hand, ensuring that their actions are well-intentioned and informed.

Ultimately, my goal is to see a fair and level playing field for all athletes, and to protect the integrity of the game. I hope that Congress and the leagues can work together to achieve that goal. Thank you.

This is a complex issue, and I appreciate you bringing it up. As I've said before, I believe life is sacred, and it begins at conception. Now, when it comes to fertility treatments, I understand that many loving couples struggling with infertility want to start a family, and I support their desire. 

However, we have to be mindful of the ethics involved. I don't think it's right to create more embryos than we're going to implant, knowing that many of those embryos will never have the chance at life. 

As for what should be done with those embryos that don't become pregnancies, I believe that they should be treated with dignity and respect. We should support adoption and other alternatives that would allow them to be given a chance at life. I also support stem cell research using adult stem cells and other alternatives that don't involve the destruction of human embryos.

But let me be clear: as President, I will ensure that we prioritize the respect for human life, at every stage, from conception to natural death.

Well, I appreciate the question. You know, I've always said, as you mentioned, that I don't pay much attention to polls. And I think that's served me well. But I do think it's worth noting that, you know, polls go up and down. And in times of uncertainty, people's anxiety can be pretty high.

Now, I think we're in a challenging period for our country, and I'm not surprised there's some skepticism. But I am confident that the policies we've put in place, whether it's on the economy, or on national security, are the right ones.

Regarding the PATRIOT Act vote, I think that's a great example of Democrats and Republicans working together to make our country safer. We didn't get everything we wanted, but that's how the legislative process works. And I think, at the end of the day, we'll get credit for the important work we did on that legislation.

Now, as for independents losing confidence in my leadership, I think it's natural for people to have doubts. But I believe that we've shown that we can work in a bipartisan manner to get things done. And I think that's good for the country.

And I'll tell you this: I've been a leader who's made tough decisions, and I've got a bedrock of support from the American people. They know I'm a man of integrity, that I'll make decisions based on principle, not on polls.

Thank you for the question. I appreciate the Prime Minister's optimism about a window of opportunity for the Iranians, and I share that optimism. We're at a stage where the international community has come together to address the concerns about Iran's nuclear program. And I believe the Iranians have a chance to demonstrate to the world that they're willing to comply with international norms.

Now, I want to be clear: we're not discussing a specific timetable, but we are discussing a set of principles that Iran must adhere to if they want to be in good standing with the international community.

The first step is for Iran to give the IAEA, the International Atomic Energy Agency, the access it needs to ensure that their nuclear program is peaceful. And secondly, we're waiting for the Iranians to suspend enrichment and reprocessing activities.

We believe that it's in the best interest of the Iranian people for their country to have a peaceful nuclear program, one that's transparent, and one that's in line with the Nuclear Non-Proliferation Treaty.

Now, we're working closely with our allies, including the European Union, Russia, and China, to ensure that we're sending a clear and united message to the Iranian government. If the Iranian government and the Iranian people choose to comply with international norms, I believe there's a bright future for Iran.

But if they continue down a path of non-cooperation, there will be consequences. And the international community is united in our commitment to address this issue, and to ensure that Iran does not become a nuclear power.

Thank you for the question. Well, I believe that if Republicans retain control of Congress, we'll be able to continue on the path of economic growth, job creation, and fiscal responsibility. We've made significant progress in the past few years, with tax cuts and regulatory reforms that have unleashed the energy of the American people.

If Democrats take control of Congress, I worry that they'll try to raise taxes and increase government spending, which could stifle economic growth and put a damper on job creation. We've seen this before - every time the Democrats get the keys to the car, they tend to drive it right back into the ditch. My opponent's tax plan, for example, would increase the tax burden on American families and small businesses, which would hurt our economy, not help it.

Now, I know some folks might say that's just partisan talk, but the facts are clear. Our economic growth has been robust under Republican leadership, and our policies have created a climate of opportunity and entrepreneurship that has allowed Americans to thrive.

I believe that by keeping taxes low, regulations reasonable, and the economy growing, we'll continue to see the best job market in a generation, with higher-paying jobs, and increased economic growth. That's the difference between our two approaches. And I firmly believe that the American people will see that, if Congress stays in Republican hands, the economy will continue to grow and prosper.

lậpI believe that Congress does have the authority to exercise its power of the purse, and I respect that. However, the issue at hand is not just about funding, it's about supporting our troops in a time of war.

If Congress were to cut off funding without providing a plan for the consequences, I believe that would be an abdication of their responsibility. It's not just a matter of saying, "We're not going to fund it." There are consequences to those actions.

I've had discussions with the leaders in Congress, and I'm still hopeful that we can work out a bill that supports our troops, that gives them the resources they need to succeed in Iraq and Afghanistan, and that takes care of the families of those troops.

You know, it's a difficult position to be in, but I'm the Commander-in-Chief, and I've got to make the decisions that I think are necessary to protect America. And I'm willing to work with Congress to get legislation that supports our troops.

But let's be clear: if they try to cut off funding without a plan, it would be a historic mistake, and it would put our troops in danger. We've got to work together to get this right.

Thank you for the questions.  Yes, I have had the opportunity to talk to President Sarkozy, and I was very impressed by his strong support for our efforts in the war on terror and his commitment to the transatlantic alliance. We talked about a range of issues, including Iran, Lebanon, and the Middle East peace process. I'm pleased to say that we share a common view on the importance of confronting extremism and promoting democracy around the world.

Regarding the coalition, we welcome France's continued support for our efforts in Afghanistan and Iraq. We appreciate their contributions to the NATO-led mission in Afghanistan, and we look forward to continuing to work together to help the Iraqi people build a stable and secure future.

As for the Vice President's trip to the Middle East, we are seeking cooperation from our friends in the region on a number of key issues. First and foremost, we are working to build a united front against the threat posed by Iran's nuclear program. We believe that Iran's pursuit of nuclear weapons is a threat to the entire region, and we are urging our friends in the Middle East to join us in calling on Iran to abandon its nuclear ambitions.

Second, we are seeking support for the Iraqi government as it works to build a stable and secure future for its people. This includes efforts to secure the borders, disrupt the flow of foreign fighters and funding to the extremists, and promote economic development.

Finally, we are seeking to build momentum for the Middle East peace process. We believe that a two-state solution is the only viable way to bring peace to this troubled region, and we are urging all parties to take bold steps to restart negotiations and work towards a lasting peace.

Overall, our message to the leaders of the Middle East is clear: we are committed to working with you to build a more peaceful and secure region, and we look forward to your continued cooperation and support.

Well, I've spoken to Secretary Gates, and I think it's very clear that he supports the decision that was made at the time, based on the information that we had. Now, hindsight is always 20/20, and I think that Secretary Gates was simply saying that, you know, we've learned a lot since the decision was made. And I think it's fair to say that, you know, we've had some successes and some setbacks in Iraq.

But I still firmly believe, based on the intelligence that was presented to me at the time, and to the American people, and to the Congress, that the decision to take out Saddam Hussein was the right decision. And I think that the world is a better place because of it.

Now, I understand that there are plenty of folks who disagree with me on that, and that's okay. We're a democracy, and people are entitled to their opinions. But I think, you know, Secretary Gates was just reflecting the fact that, you know, we've learned a lot about the situation in Iraq since the decision was made, and that's just the way it is.

But I want to assure the American people, I have confidence in Secretary Gates, and I think he's doing a great job. We've talked about this issue, and I don't see any daylight between us. We're on the same page when it comes to our commitment to winning this war, and to defending this country, and I'm glad to have him as my Secretary of Defense.

I appreciate the question.  I understand that we need the cooperation of both parties to solve this energy crisis and I am committed to work towards that goal. We've made some progress in the past, for example, we worked with both Democrats and Republicans to pass a bill on nuclear energy.

Now, that being said, today's vote on ANWR, the Arctic National Wildlife Refuge, was a key part of our comprehensive energy plan, and I strongly believe that it's an important part of addressing our energy needs. And I'm disappointed that it was, was rejected.

But I'm not going to give up. I understand the Congress is a co-equal branch of government and you 've got to work with the Congress to make progress on issues.

Now, I can tell you this: we will continue to push forward on our energy policy, we will work with Congress to try to find areas of agreement and do what is right for this country, to try and address the energy crisis that we face. And I'm confident that we'll be able to make some progress.

We've also got to make it clear to the American people that there 's bipartisan support in Congress for the rest of our energy policy, for example, on nuclear power, on conservation, on expanding refining capacity. There's broad bipartisan support for clean technologies. There's bipartisan agreement on doubling this nation's commitment to hydrogen fuel cells and to renewable energy and wind and solar energy.

We'll continue to push forward. It's the President's job to lead, it's the President's job to push the issue, to make sure that the American people understand what's at stake here. And I'm committed to doing that.

Thank you for that question. You know, as Commander-in-Chief, it's my duty to inform the American people about the threats that we face, and I appreciate your willingness to help spread the word.

First and foremost, I want to emphasize that the vast majority of Americans are safe, and the chances of being a victim of a terrorist attack are extremely low. But, as we've seen, there are those who seek to do us harm, and it's our responsibility to be vigilant.

As for what people should be on the lookout for, I'd say the following: any suspicious activity, such as people loitering around critical infrastructure like power plants, bridges, or government buildings, should be reported immediately. If someone sees a strange vehicle or a person behaving in a suspicious manner, they should not approach them, but rather contact the authorities right away.

Also, we're asking Americans to be aware of any unusual patterns of behavior, such as people who seem to be surveilling a particular location, or who are taking pictures of sensitive areas. If someone receives a suspicious package or letter, they should not touch it, but rather contact the authorities.

Now, I want to stress that we're not asking Americans to be paranoid or to treat every stranger as a potential terrorist. But rather, we're asking for their help in being vigilant and reporting anything that seems out of the ordinary.

The FBI and local law enforcement are working tirelessly to investigate any leads and to disrupt potential terrorist plots. And I'm proud to say that, thanks to the hard work of our intelligence agencies and law enforcement, we've been able to prevent numerous attacks and bring many terrorists to justice.

So, I urge all Americans to remain vigilant, but not to let fear dictate their lives. We will not let the terrorists win. We will continue to work tirelessly to protect our great nation, and we'll do so with the help of the American people.

And, as I always say, "If you see something, say something."

(pausing for a moment) Well, let me be clear: I appreciate the contributions that many immigrants have made to our great nation, including those from Pakistan. And I understand the concerns of folks from Pakistan who are here in this country, working hard and trying to make a better life for themselves and their families.

As for the issue of guest worker status, we're still in the process of considering that proposal, and we'll evaluate it on a case-by-case basis, country by country. I will say that we do have a strong relationship with Pakistan, and we're working closely with President Musharraf on a range of issues.

Now, regarding the idea of granting legal status to a small number of illegal Pakistanis, I want to emphasize that we need to have a comprehensive approach to immigration reform.
