We need to make sure our borders are secure, and that we've got a system that's fair and humane for those who are trying to enter our country.

That being said, I'm open to exploring options for those who are here, who are law-abiding, who are paying taxes, and who are contributing to our economy. We'll have to take a hard look at this, work with Congress, and come up with a solution that's in the best interests of this country.

But I want to reassure the American people that we're committed to upholding the law, and we're also committed to treating all people with dignity and respect.

Well, thank you for that question. I appreciate the opportunity to talk about the nuclear issue. First of all, I think it's ambitious to think that we can get an agreement by May, but it's worth striving for. I believe that the relationship between the United States and Russia is a very important one, and we're committed to working hard to make sure that we can reduce the nuclear arsenal.

As for the second part of your question, I believe that we're making progress on the issue of treating this as a treaty. I think it's essential that we make it clear that we're committed to reducing our nuclear arsenals, and we want to do it in a way that is verifiable and reliable.

And on the third part of your question, I think we're making good progress on the issue of destruction versus storage. I have made it clear to the Russians that I want to see a commitment to irreversibly dismantling these nuclear warheads, and not just storing them. I think that's essential.

Now, I know that there's a lot of technical work to be done, and there's a lot of negotiating to be done, but I'm optimistic that we can get something done. I've had some good conversations with President Putin about this issue, and I think we're on the right track.

But let me make one thing clear: my commitment to reducing nuclear arsenals is not just about the size of the arsenals; it's about making sure that we're not creating a situation where these nuclear arms start to proliferate to other countries. That's a great concern of mine, and I think it's a concern of the Russian government as well.

So, we'll keep working hard, and we'll see what we can accomplish. But I think it's too early to say for sure whether we'll have an agreement by May or not. We'll just have to keep working at it.

Regarding Iran, our message is clear: we take seriously their attempts to develop nuclear technology, and we've made it clear that we cannot allow them to possess nuclear weapons. The situation with Iran is different than it was with Iraq, and we're approaching it in a different way.

We're working with the international community, through the United Nations, to put pressure on Iran to comply with the nuclear non-proliferation treaty, and to demonstrate that their nuclear program is indeed peaceful.

Now, we are prepared to deal with the Iranian regime, but we must take a firm stance. We cannot stand idly by while they continue on a path of developing nuclear technology that could threaten not only the region but also the entire world.

Regarding the comparison to North Korea, it's a different situation, as you know. The six-party talks have been ongoing for some time now, and we're working to bring North Korea back to the table. But let me be clear: our goal is not to march to war with Iran. Our goal is to see that the Iranian people are able to live in peace, and that the regime in Tehran understands that they cannot pursue nuclear technology that will lead to threatening their neighbors.

Our diplomatic efforts will continue in full force, but make no mistake: we're strong and resolute, and we will do what is necessary to protect our country, our interests, and the world from the threat of proliferation.

Thank you for that question. I understand why some folks might be concerned about the approach we're taking with regard to Iraq reconstruction contracts. But let me be clear: our policy is not about retaliation or blackmail. It's about recognizing the immense sacrifice that our coalition partners have made alongside us in this war.

These countries have put their troops in harm's way, just like we have. They've lost brave men and women in the fight against terrorism and tyranny. And they've done it without hesitation, because they share our values and our commitment to spreading freedom and democracy.

Now, when it comes to rebuilding Iraq, we believe it's only fair that our coalition partners have a role to play in the process. They've earned it. And we're not just talking about big contracts, we're talking about small and medium-sized enterprises, too. We want to create opportunities for those nations that have stood by us in this fight.

As for international support, I believe this approach will actually help generate more of it. We're not just looking for one-time contributions to the reconstruction effort; we're looking for long-term commitments from our partners. And by involving them in the contracting process, we're creating a sense of ownership and investment that will last well beyond the initial phases of reconstruction.

Now, I know some folks might see this as a form of favoritism or preferential treatment. I understand that perspective, and I'm willing to have an open and honest discussion about it. But I firmly believe that our allies have earned our gratitude and our respect. And if recognizing that sacrifice through this policy helps to build stronger relationships and more cooperation in the future, then it's a small price to pay.

Make no mistake, we're committed to transparency and fairness in the contracting process. We'll make sure that all bidders, whether they're from coalition nations or not, have a fair shot at securing these contracts. But we will also take into account the contributions and sacrifices of our coalition partners as we move forward. Thank you.

Thank you for your question. First, let me tell you, I'm glad you brought up the issue of Latin America. We've taken note of China's growing interest in the region, and we welcome their investment, but we will not let our guard down. The United States has a long-standing commitment to our friends in Latin America, and we're going to continue to strengthen those ties. We'll work with our partners in the region to advance our shared interests in democracy, economic growth, and security. We're going to make sure that the United States remains a reliable and trustworthy partner for the people of Latin America.

Regarding the fiscal deficit, I want to assure the American people that we're committed to restoring fiscal discipline. We've taken steps in our first term to reduce the deficit, and we're going to continue to work towards a balanced budget. We'll do it in a way that's responsible and sustainable, without raising taxes or harming the economy. We're going to make tough choices and set priorities, and we're going to work with Congress to get it done. We'll make sure that our economy remains strong and competitive, and that we're preparing for the future, not just for today.

Now, I want to emphasize that addressing the deficit is a top priority for my Administration. We're going to work with Republicans and Democrats alike to get a budget that makes sense, that reduces the deficit, and that meets the needs of the American people. It won't be easy, but we're going to get it done, because that's what the American people expect from us. Thank you.

I appreciate that question. I firmly believe that the partnership between the United States and Europe is stronger today than it was when I first took office. We've worked together on a wide range of issues, from counterterrorism to trade, to the global economy.

And I think we've made some real progress in strengthening our alliance. The summits that we've held, including the one just last month, have shown that we can work together effectively and find common ground.

Now, I know that we're not always going to agree on every issue, and we shouldn't expect to. But I do think that our shared values of democracy, freedom, and human rights create a foundation for a strong and enduring friendship.

As for the Luxembourg Presidency, I think Prime Minister Juncker and his government have done a fine job of helping to promote this partnership, and we appreciate their leadership. They've been good partners in our efforts to strengthen the transatlantic alliance, and we look forward to continuing to work with them in the months and years ahead.

I think it's also worth noting that our partnership is not just about governments; it's also about the connections between our peoples. And I'm heartened to see the growing exchanges and collaborations between our universities, our businesses, and our civil societies.

So, all in all, I think the prospects for our friendship and partnership are bright, and I look forward to continuing to work with our European friends to build an even stronger relationship in the years to come. Thank you.

I'm not going to go beyond the comments I've already made about an ongoing investigation. But I can tell you that if there's a leak out of my administration, I want to know who it is, and if the person has broken the law, they'll no longer work in my administration. 

Now, I understand that Karl Rove did have a conversation with... (pauses) ... with more than one reporter, it seems like, about this issue, though... if there is a leak out of my administration, I want to know who it is.  That's correct.

Thank you for that question. We're deeply concerned about the situation with North Korea, and we've made it clear that our goal is a nuclear-free Korean Peninsula. Now, I understand that the sanctions have been a point of contention, and we're willing to work with our partners, including South Korea, to find a way to get North Korea back to the negotiating table.

However, I gotta be careful about what we're doing here. We can't just give in to demands without getting something in return. I mean, we've made it clear that we want to see North Korea dismantle its nuclear program, and we want to see them comply with international law.

Now, that being said, I'm a reasonable man, and I'm willing to listen to ideas. If our partners, including South Korea, believe that suspending or easing some of these sanctions would be a way to get them back to the table, I'm willing to consider it. But let me be clear: we're not going to unilaterally disarm, if you will, and give up our leverage without getting something in return.

So, we'll continue to work with our allies, continue to work with our partners, and see if we can find a way to get North Korea back to the table. But we're not going to give up on our goal of a nuclear-free Korean Peninsula. That's the bottom line.

I think the American people, as reflected in the polls, are rightly focused on their concerns about the state of the nation right now - the economy, national security, et cetera. And I understand that, at this point in the administration and in this period of great challenge and upheaval for America, that would lead people to ask questions about who can get the job done.

Now, let me tell you, we've got a broad agenda as a party, that we can point to and say, this is the leadership that America needs. We've got a strong record on national security. We've been successful working with our allies to take down a brutal, terrorist regime in Afghanistan. We're working to promote democracy around the world, and we've advanced America's interests through diplomatic channels.

We've also had a positive impact on our economy, through tax cuts, as you know. We put millions of dollars back into the hands of the American people, and that helped us come out of a recession.

Now, I know we're in a tough period - gas prices are high, and people are feeling the pinch, and so am I. But I've got faith in this country's resilience. Americans are strong and resolute.

Now, do I worry about the elections? Yes. As the leader of the party, I want our people - our candidates - to win.  But we've just got to put it in perspective here. This is still a presidential election issue: people are looking for leadership from the person at the top. So in '06, I've got a responsibility, as the party's leader, to go out and campaign for our candidates.

So the answer is, we've got work to do, and I will be out there, stumping for our folks, reminding the country about our record of achievement and our vision for the future.

(laughs) Well, Terry, I think that's a mighty fine question. I'll let Chancellor Merkel respond to the first part of that question. As for my part, I do think we've got some concerns about Russia in regards to her democratic progress. We've been clear in our discussions with President Putin, and the Chancellor has too, that it's real important for Russia to maintain democratic progress, and we're watching that closely.

Regarding the Vice President's comments, I think he made it clear that we believe Russia should be a responsible partner in the energy sector. As for the hunting shot, (laughs), well, I think the Vice President's a pretty good shot, but I think we'll leave the hunting to our leisure time, not to diplomacy.

But, let me just say, we're looking forward to having a productive discussion with President Putin at the G8 summit, and we're going to bring some of these issues to the table.

Thank you for your question. I appreciate the opportunity to address this matter.

First, let me say that the situation on the ground is indeed complex and fluid, and we are closely monitoring the developments. The United Arab Emirates, for example, has taken a strong stance against Hizballah's aggression, and we appreciate their efforts to contain this conflict.

Regarding the risk of a wider war, I believe that it's our responsibility to help avert that from happening. We're working closely with our partners in the region, including Saudi Arabia, Egypt, and Jordan, to help find a solution to this conflict.

As for Secretary Rice's mission, she will continue to engage with the parties involved to encourage a cease-fire and a return to diplomacy. Her instructions will be to speak with anyone who can help us achieve that goal, and that includes the Lebanese government, of course. As for meeting with the Syrians, we've made it clear that Syria can play a constructive role in this conflict by exerting its influence over Hizballah and encouraging them to halt their aggression.

But let me be clear: we will not engage with Syria until they meet certain conditions, including the release of the Israeli soldiers who were kidnapped, and a demonstration that they're serious about moving forward on a peaceful resolution to this conflict.

We're committed to finding a lasting solution to this conflict, one that protects Israel's security, and respects Lebanon's sovereignty, and helps the people of Lebanon rebuild their lives.

We believe that a United Nations resolution that includes a robust international force is the key to a sustainable solution. And we'll continue to work with our partners to achieve that goal.

Thank you for the question. I think it's essential to make a distinction here between knowledge and capability. Of course, knowing how to enrich uranium is one thing, but actually having a program to enrich uranium is another. And the reason I'm concerned about Iran is because I believe they're hiding a nuclear program. They've been murky about their intentions, and I believe they've got a nuclear weapons program hidden from the international community.

Now, when it comes to the Non-Proliferation Treaty, it's true that countries that sign onto that treaty are allowed to have peaceful nuclear programs, and we support that. But I think the international community has got to be careful not to be naive about countries that are developing nuclear capabilities that could be used in a way that's not consistent with the principles of the treaty.

So, what I'm trying to do is to work with the international community to say, "Look, we've got to draw a line here. We've got to make sure that countries that sign onto this treaty are indeed being transparent and indeed have pure intentions." And I believe that's a standard that the international community should be able to agree on.

In terms of pressure at the United Nations, I believe the Security Council has an important role to play here. We've been working with our allies to bring pressure to bear on Iran to be more transparent, to stop the nuclear program, and we're hopeful that that pressure can be effective.

But let me make one thing clear: we will not accept a nuclear-armed Iran. And we're working with the international community to say, "This is a threat not just to the United States, but to the entire free world."

Thank you for the question. Let me be clear: our policy in Iraq is to continue to transition responsibility to the Iraqi security forces. We've made significant progress, and I want to commend General Petraeus and General Odierno for the fine work they're doing. Now, when it comes to troop reductions, we'll make decisions based on the conditions on the ground. The surge has been successful, and we're at a point where we can start to transition.

As for a pause in troop reductions, I think it's a reasonable concept. We need to ensure that the progress we've made is sustainable, and that's what our commanders and their teams are evaluating right now. I don't want to speculate on specific numbers or timelines, but I can tell you that we'll continue to reduce our troop presence in a way that's responsible and sustainable.

Regarding the visit by President Ahmadi-nejad, I do think it's worrisome. I've made it clear that Iran's behavior in the region is unacceptable, particularly when it comes to supporting terrorist organizations and undermining the democratic government in Iraq. I'm disappointed, but not surprised, by the Iraqi government's decision to host the Iranian president. We'll continue to press the Iraqi government to be mindful of the company it keeps, and to work with us to prevent Iranian interference in the region.

But make no mistake, our main focus remains on supporting the Iraqi people, their government, and their security forces as they build a stable, democratic future for themselves.

Yes, I appreciate the question. Let me just say that we're at an important moment in our diplomatic efforts with Iran. And I want to commend the Europeans, particularly the E3+3 – that's Germany, France, Great Britain, the European Union, as well as Russia and China – for putting together a package that addresses Iran's concerns, while also addressing our concerns about their nuclear program.

I understand the Iranians' initial reaction. It's not unexpected. They've been squirrelly throughout this process. But I believe this is a fair and reasonable offer, and I'm confident that our allies and partners will see it in the same light. We've worked closely with them to develop this approach, and I believe they understand the importance of Iran meeting its international obligations.

Now, as for enforcement, let me be clear: we will work with our allies and partners to implement the necessary measures if Iran chooses to reject this offer. We've made it clear all along that we will not let Iran develop a nuclear weapon, and we're committed to working through diplomatic means to achieve that goal.

I've had conversations with leaders around the world, and I believe there's a growing consensus that Iran must comply with the IAEA's demands and the UN Security Council resolutions. We'll continue to work with our allies to build that consensus and to prepare for the possible need for more robust measures if Iran continues down its current path.

But let's not get ahead of ourselves. This package offers a clear way forward for Iran to satisfy the international community, and I hope the Iranians will take it seriously and respond positively. Thank you.

Thank you, Helen. I appreciate the opportunity to address this issue. Yes, I do share some concerns that have been raised by members of my party regarding the European rapid-reaction force and its potential impact on NATO.

As I've said before, I strongly believe in a strong and unified NATO, and I think it's essential that we maintain a clear and consistent approach to European defense. While I agree that the European Union should work towards becoming a more capable and effective partner for the United States, I also believe we need to be careful not to duplicate effort or create unnecessary competition between NATO and this new force.

That being said, I had a very productive conversation with Prime Minister Blair yesterday, and I believe we share a common goal of strengthening our transatlantic relationship and improving European security. I'd like to hear the Prime Minister's thoughts on this issue, but I can tell you that we're committed to working closely with our European allies to ensure that any new initiative is complementary to, rather than in competition with, NATO.

Prime Minister Blair, would you like to add your thoughts on this matter?

Thank you for that question. Let me start by saying that we take the threat of terrorism very seriously, and we're very concerned about the situation in the region. We're committed to working with our friends and allies in the region to combat terrorism and to help them build the capacity to deal with these kinds of threats.

Regarding Peru specifically, we've got a good relationship with President Toledo and the people of Peru. We're watching the situation closely, and we're working closely with them to see if there's anything we can do to help them.

Now, I wouldn't want to speculate on specific assistance, but I will say that we're always willing to consider requests for assistance from our friends and allies in the region. We believe that it's in our mutual interest to work together to combat terrorism and to promote stability and security in the region.

And you're right; we are concerned about the spread of terrorism across borders. It's a problem that knows no borders, and it requires an international effort to deal with it. We're committed to working with our friends and allies in the region to build up their capacity, to share intelligence, and to work together to combat this threat.

But I want to emphasize that we're also committed to working with the government of Colombia to help them deal with the terrorist threat within their borders. We believe that it's a problem that requires a comprehensive approach, and we're committed to working with our friends and allies in the region to get the job done.

I'm glad you asked that question. The Harken Energy issue has been thoroughly vetted, and I'm confident in the decisions I made during my time as a director at the company. The sale of my Harken stock was made in accordance with SEC regulations, and I filed my Form 4, as required. The issue of the timing has been explained time and again: it was an administrative mistake, and I relied on the company to file the report.

Let me be clear, I made the sale of my stock in June of 1990, and the Form 4 was filed in April of the following year – eight months later – not because I was trying to evade the law, but because my accountant filed the report in accordance with the company's processes. It's just that simple. And I'm proud of the way I handled my decisions while in that position.

I'll tell you this: the real issue here is an attempt by my opponents to divert attention from the issues that matter most to the American people – like the economy, education, and our national security. I'm confident that when the American people review the facts, they will see this for what it is – a partisan attack to distract from the real issues of this campaign.

Well, that's a great question. I want to assure the American people that we're constantly assessing our military's readiness and its ability to meet its missions around the world. We've got a big military, a powerful military, and a military that's well-trained. And we've got a military that's got a lot of experience in different parts of the world.

Now, I understand that there's some concern about whether or not we're spread too thin. But I believe that our military is capable of handling multiple challenges at the same time. We've got a great logistics system, and we're able to move troops and equipment quickly and easily around the world.

Now, on Liberia, I spoke with President Mbeki about our concerns about Liberia and the region. We're watching the situation very carefully. We're concerned about the violence there, and we're concerned about the humanitarian situation. We're also working with our allies and with the United Nations to determine what the best course of action is.

I'm not ready to commit U.S. troops to Liberia. At this point, our emphasis is on the international community coming together to help Liberia achieve peace and stability. We're working with the Economic Community of West African States, or ECOWAS, and with other African nations to try to find a peaceful solution to the problem.

We're also providing humanitarian assistance to the people of Liberia, and we're going to continue to provide humanitarian assistance. We're committed to helping the people of Liberia, but I'm not ready to commit U.S. troops at this point.

Thank you for the question. Let me make one thing very clear: I have made my position on Chairman Arafat very clear. I have reservations about his ability to lead the Palestinian people to a peaceful resolution. His leadership has been, in my opinion, a hindrance to peace.

That being said, I am committed to the vision of a two-state solution, where Israel and a free Palestinian state can coexist in peace and security. And we are working with the government of Israel and our international partners to try to make that a reality.

As for Chairman Arafat, the question of his role is a Palestinian decision to make, not an American one. We will work with the new Prime Minister, Mahmoud Abbas, to implement the road map and to take the necessary steps to move the peace process forward. And we will not limit ourselves to just one interlocutor in the Palestinian Authority if it becomes clear that that interlocutor is not willing or able to take the necessary steps towards peace.

Now, I know there are some who say that we can't go around Chairman Arafat, but I say we can work with a variety of leaders within the Palestinian Authority who share our commitment to peace. We are looking for partners for peace, and if there are other Palestinian leaders who are willing to take the necessary steps to make peace a reality, we are more than happy to work with them.

So, we will continue to work with the government of Israel, the Palestinian Authority, and our international partners to make progress on the road map and to try to bring peace to the Middle East.

Well, I think, you know, the reason we're working with the United Nations is because we want to signal to the world that this is not just a U.S.-led operation. It's an international effort to bring stability and democracy to the Iraqi people.

Now, regarding your question, I understand that there have been some concerns about the role of the Iraqi government in terms of exercising its sovereignty, particularly with regards to the presence of coalition forces. But I think it's essential to recognize that our goal is to train and empower the Iraqi security forces to the point where they can assume responsibility for their country's security.

But we also understand that Iraq's security is a regional issue, and we're not talking about, you know, giving Iraq a verse in the international community here completely unilaterally. That's why this work with the Security Council needs to represent all nations which interact with the region and have a stake in building as much peace stability and global resilience to that numerous terror threats.

Well, I appreciate Chairman Greenspan's thoughtful comments on this issue.  I know that he, like me, wants to make sure that we approach this issue of Social Security reform in a responsible and thoughtful way.

Regarding the issue of transition costs, I understand that this is a legitimate concern. However, I do not believe that it is an insurmountable one. We have been working on this issue for some time now, and we believe that there are ways to phase in private accounts over time that would help to mitigate the financial costs of implementing this plan.

It's also important to remember that the transition costs, while significant, are a one-time expense. Once we make this transition, we will not only be adding a new layer of security for our citizens but also addressing the long term fiscal problems that threaten the very solvency of our Social Security system.

Regarding the issue of rushing into print, I can assure Chairman Greenspan that we are moving forward on this issue in a careful and deliberate manner. We are taking the time to listen to all perspectives on this issue, to work with the Congress to build support and to make sure that we are getting this right. I believe that we will have time to have a thorough and thoughtful debate on this issue and we will timing it with a deliberation that is proper.

And let me just add, that the status quo on Social Security is not acceptable, we have a problem that's been kicked down the road for decades and I'm committed to solving the problem. I agree with Chairman Greenspan that we should take our time to get it right, but I don't believe we should delay.

Thank you for your question. The United States is committed to supporting the territorial integrity and sovereignty of Georgia, and we strongly believe that the conflict in the regions of South Ossetia and Abkhazia must be resolved peacefully.

In terms of the kind of help we can offer, we are working closely with the Georgian Government to support their efforts to resolve this conflict through diplomatic means. We are providing economic assistance and humanitarian aid to help those affected by the conflict.

But I want to emphasize that our involvement is not just about providing aid, it's also about using our diplomatic influence to encourage all parties to come together and find a peaceful solution. We are working with the United Nations, the European Union, and other international organizations to support this process.

Regarding the position of the Georgian Government, I think it's commendable that they are committed to a peaceful resolution of this conflict. And I agree with them that the main problem is indeed the presence of outside forces - or third forces, if you will - that are interfering in this conflict.

It's clear that the conflict in Georgia is being fueled by external factors, and it's our assessment that Russia's support for separatist groups is a contributing factor to this conflict. We urge all parties to exercise restraint and to work towards a peaceful solution.

The United States is committed to supporting the people of Georgia in their efforts to build a stable, democratic, and prosperous future, and we will continue to work with them to find a peaceful resolution to this conflict. Thank you.

Well, I appreciate the question. Let me first say that I understand the Democrats are likely to oppose whoever I choose, that's just politics. I'm not going to let the timing of the nomination be dictated by their campaign against my choice. 

As for the timing, I'll tell you this: we're going to nominate a highly qualified candidate when we're ready, and we won't be rushed into making a decision. However, I made a commitment to the American people to have this process completed by the time the Court begins its new term, and I intend to keep that commitment.

Now, as for the process, I'm not going to tell my prospective nominees that I'm going to sit down and ask them a list of 'gotcha' questions. No, I'm going to get to know them, ask them about their philosophy, their approach to judging, their judicial temperament, and their accomplishments.

These are the things that matter, not some cleverly crafted question designed to trip someone up. I want to understand how they think, how they approach the law, and what kind of judge they would be.

I'm looking for a judge who will strictly interpret the Constitution, who will not legislate from the bench, and who will be a fair and impartial arbiter of the law.

That's what I'll be looking for, and that's what I'll be asking about. Thanks.

Well, I'm confident that the world community recognizes the threat of a nuclear Iran. And I'm working closely with our allies, the European Union, China, and Russia to make sure that we send a clear message to the Iranian regime: that they will be isolated, that there will be consequences for their actions.

I think the U.N. Security Council will act, though I'm not going to predict exactly what will happen or when. But I do know that we're working diligently to make sure that the world understands the gravity of this situation.

And I believe that the Iranian people deserve better than a government that has isolated them from the rest of the world, and a government that's focused on developing a nuclear program versus developing their economy.

The message to the Iranian regime is: "You've got a choice to make. You can either continue down a path of isolation, or you can change your behavior."

(pausing for a moment)

I think it's no secret that we had a very serious conversation with President Musharraf after 9/11, and I'm not going to confirm or deny any specific details about the nature of those conversations. (pausing again)

However, I will say that we made it very clear to the Pakistani government that we expected their full cooperation in the war on terror, and that we expected them to take a strong stance against terrorism and those who harbor terrorists.

As for the specifics of the conversation, I think it's safe to say that we were extremely serious about the threat that the Taliban and al-Qaeda posed, and we were willing to take whatever steps necessary to address that threat.

(pausing once more)

I will say that President Musharraf has been a valuable partner in the war on terror, and we've worked closely with him to combat terrorism in the region. And I appreciate his cooperation.

(looking around the room)

Now, I think that's all I'm going to say on this topic. Next question.

Thank you for the question. I understand the concerns that many Americans have about the situation in Iraq, and I share those concerns. But I must respectfully disagree with the notion that our actions in Iraq have enhanced Al Qaeda.

First of all, our actions in Iraq were not just about Iraq. We were part of a broader global strategy to prevent terrorists from finding safe havens and sponsoring states. Saddam Hussein's regime, with its proven track record of aggression and animosity towards the United States and its neighbors, posed a real threat to regional stability and to our national security.

Now, I will acknowledge that Al Qaeda has indeed taken advantage of the situation in Iraq to try to foment violence and to try to, as you said, use it as a recruiting tool. But the key is that now, they're public enemy number one in Iraq. We've got a new government in Iraq that is committed to the advance of democracy and the rule of law, and we're working with them to defeat these killers.

We must remember, the terrorists were in a position to attack us before we went into Iraq. They were a threat before we began this war on terror, and they will remain a threat unless we continue to take decisive action to stay ahead of them.

Now, I'm not saying that our work in Iraq has been easy or that we haven't encountered challenges along the way. We have, and it's tough. But I will say this: we're making progress in Iraq, we're making progress against Al Qaeda, and we will not allow the terrorists to dictate the course of history.

We will not retreat. We will not surrender. We will not be intimidated by the tactics of these cold-blooded killers, and we will continue to take the fight to them, wherever they try to hide and wherever they try to operate.

Make no mistake, we are determined to win the war on terror, and we will succeed in our mission to make America safer and the world a more secure and a more peaceful place.

Well, let me start by saying that I understand the importance of investing in our nation's infrastructure, and that includes bridges and housing. We've made some significant investments in those areas, and we'll continue to do so.

Now, when it comes to appropriations bills, I'm committed to working with Congress to make sure that we're being fiscally responsible. That means we've got to set priorities and make some tough decisions. But I'm confident that we can do that without resorting to raising taxes.

Let's be clear: raising taxes would be a bad idea, especially during a time when our economy is still growing. We need to keep our tax relief in place to continue to stimulate economic growth.

Now, with regard to Iraq, we're committed to supporting our troops and the mission to bring stability and security to the Iraqi people. We're working closely with the Iraqi government to help them build their own security forces, and we're making progress.

In terms of the overall budget, we'll continue to work with Congress to find ways to cut unnecessary spending, streamline government, and eliminate waste and abuse. That's the way we'll be able to meet our priorities, including supporting our troops and investing in our nation's infrastructure.

But let me be clear: we will not raise taxes. We will not go back to the days of high taxes and slow economic growth. We'll work together to find a way to fund our priorities in a fiscally responsible way.

I believe I made it clear that, yes, there were differing opinions within the administration, but I had made up my mind, we had made a commitment to press for, quote, "regime change" in Iraq, and that was not going to change. I relied on the advice of my Director of Central Intelligence and the NIE, which concluded that Saddam Hussein was reconstituting his nuclear program. Now, in hindsight, of course, we know there were no WMDs found in Iraq, but at the time, I, along with my national security team, felt it was essential to protect the American people from the threat that we believed was real.

Regarding the rhetoric, yes, I do recall that there were increased tensions and strong language being used, particularly with the phrase 'world war III'. However, I think it's essential to remember the broader context: this was in the aftermath of the 9/11 attacks, and we were taking a hard stance against terrorism and proliferation of WMDs. While perhaps it could be seen as intense, I believe the seriousness of the situation warranted decisive language and decisive action.

Thank you for your question. Yeah, that's a great way to put it - the NATO mission has indeed undergone significant changes over the years. And I agree with you, Russia continues to play a crucial role in the security landscape of Europe. We're aware of the concerns regarding missile defense and NATO expansion.

As for my upcoming meeting with President Putin, I want to assure the American people that we're committed to finding common ground and strengthening our relationship with Russia whenever possible. We'll discuss a range of issues, including missile defense. I believe that there are areas where we can cooperate, such as counter-terrorism and non-proliferation.

However, I also want to be clear that we'll be discussing our differences in a straightforward and candid manner. We cannot compromise on issues that involve the security of our allies, and we cannot ignore Russia's actions in certain regions, including their involvement in Georgia. We will work towards finding a diplomatic solution, but we'll also be firm on our principles.

So, to answer your question, we're working diligently to avoid a diplomatic train wreck, but we won't shy away from tough conversations. We'll be respectful, but we'll also be clear in our positions. Our goal is to emerge with a more constructive and positive relationship with Russia, one that benefits both our nations and the international community.

Well, thank you for your question. I'm disappointed in Scott McClellan's book, I'm glad I got to visit with him the other day and told him that. I asked him why he did it and he said he was just telling the truth, and I said, well, it would have been a whole lot easier for me to have heard it face-to-face. But, you know, Scott was a good man, a good public servant. And you know, I've made my peace with it.

Now, on Senator Obama's trip to Iraq, I hope he'll give the surge the time it needs to succeed. I think it's very important for him, if he wants to have a better understanding of the situation on the ground, that he meet with General Petraeus, who's doing a fantastic job, and more importantly, talk to the troops. I would tell him to go out there, in harm's way, and see what's going on. See the rebuilding going on, see the governance going on. I'm confident if Senator Obama does that, he'll come away with a much more positive view of the situation on the ground in Iraq.

And also, I'd advise him to remember what the consequences of defeat would be. I think it's very important to remember the history of the region. The terrorists will become more emboldened, the violence will spread, there will be more instability in the region. And I believe that's not in the interest of the American people.

But I think it's great that Senator Obama is going. It's good to go and see for yourself what's going on in the region, it's good to get out and talk to people. But, you know, I wish he would've gone a little earlier, we might have had more support for the surge.

Thank you, I appreciate that question. You know, I've always believed that free trade is a powerful engine for economic growth, and I'm committed to working with our friends in Latin America to spread the benefits of free trade throughout the region.

Now, I know that there are some obstacles we need to overcome, and I appreciate the willingness of Latin American governments to help. One thing they can do is to continue to demonstrate their commitment to the principles of free trade and open markets. By doing so, they can help build support for trade agreements here in the United States.

I also believe that it's helpful when our Latin American friends make it clear to members of our Congress that they're committed to trade agreements and that these agreements will benefit both our countries. Personal relationships and direct communication can go a long way in building support.

Furthermore, we need to work together to address the concerns of those who may be skeptical of trade agreements. We need to make the case that trade can benefit workers, farmers, and small businesses in our countries, and that the benefits of trade are not just limited to large corporations.

I'm optimistic that with the help of our Latin American friends, we can overcome the obstacles and achieve our goal of a Free Trade Area of the Americas. And I want to thank the leaders of Latin America for their leadership and commitment to trade liberalization.

Well, I think the — first of all, I think it's a great opportunity for the United States and Russia to work together on a missile defense system. And I've had conversations with President Putin about this issue. He's concerned about the lessons of the past, as am I. I'm concerned about the future, and the threat from rogue nations.

Now, in terms of incentives, I think what we're going to be doing is looking at ways in which we can work together to address the concerns that Russia has — for example, on the NATO-Russia Council, where we're going to be sitting down and talking about ways in which we can share information and coordinate our activities.

Now, I don't get ahead of the discussions that need to take place. I think that we can work out a mutual agreement. But let me just say, I think it's a grand opportunity for us to work and move beyond the Cold War mentality, and to treat Russia as a friend, rather than, as you said, an adversary.

As for what I want Russia to become, I want Russia to become a trusted partner, in terms of security, and in addressing the problems that we face together. And I believe we've made some good progress in that direction. And I think that the ABM Treaty, in particular, has got to be one that is adapted to the 21st century. It's a treaty that was focused on the past, rather than the future.

So what I envision is a new responsibility between us, where we work together on global issues, like counterterrorism, and non-proliferation, and proliferation, and addressing the threats of ballistic missiles. And in that sense, I think it's a great opportunity for us to move forward.

Thank you, and thank you for having me. (pausing for a moment) Now, I'm happy to take that question and provide a little bit of clarity.

First, let me just say that the treaty we've signed today is a historic step forward in reducing the number of nuclear arsenals that we have between our two great nations. We believe it's an important step towards reducing the nuclear threat that exists around the world.

Now, I'd like to answer your first question about nuclear parity. This treaty does not, in our view, skew the balance in any particular direction. It reduces the number of nuclear warheads, but it does so in a way that maintains a rough parity between the two sides. It's a balanced treaty that reflects the concerns of both countries.

Regarding the second part of your question - can the treaty be terminated? - the answer is yes. Like many treaties, this one does provide for the possibility of withdrawal under certain conditions. But let me be clear: we do not anticipate that happening. We're committed to this treaty, and we believe it's in the interests of both our countries to move forward with this reduction in nuclear arsenals.

Now, I'd like to address the final part of your question: is Russia still a target for nuclear forces? The answer is, we will always maintain a strategic deterrent to protect our allies and friends. However, this treaty is not just about numbers of warheads, but a profound change in the relationship between our two nations.

Over the past year, we've seen a significant shift in our relationship with Russia. We've begun a new chapter in the strategic relationship between our two countries. We're cooperating on a range of issues, from counter-terrorism to non-proliferation to economic issues.

And I'm proud to say that, because of this shift, we're now able to talk about Russia in a much more positive way. We believe that, over time, we can, indeed, envision a future in which Russia is no longer a nuclear target. But let me be clear: that future is dependent on Russia continuing to move forward on a range of non-proliferation and counter-proliferation efforts.

So, to summarize, this treaty is a major step forward in reducing nuclear arsenals, maintaining parity, and looking towards a new future in our relationship with Russia.

Thank you for the question.  Well, I'm the President of the United States, and I take personal responsibility for the words that I speak, particularly in the State of the Union Address.  And I'll tell you, I believe the words were proper.  I believe it's very important for the American people to understand that the adornments – that the people who adorn these terrorists, who provide sponsorship for these terrorists – are just as guilty.  And I made that very clear.

Now, I understand some would have liked the delivery to be different.  I understand some might have liked a more nuanced delivery.  But this is a very important issue.  And I made a decision, and I'm comfortable with the words I chose.

Regarding your question about Iraq, I think it's very important to put in perspective what's happened in the past year.  We did achieve, with a broad coalition, a significant goal:  We've got Saddam Hussein removed from power.  And I believe that's a major achievement.

That's a great question. Thank you for askin' it. Let me start by sayin' that June 30th is not an arbitrary date. It's a date that was agreed upon by the coalition, by the Iraqi Governing Council, and by the international community. And I firmly believe that it's essential to meet this deadline, because it sends a signal to the Iraqi people that we're committed to empowerin' them to run their own country.

Now, I understand that some folks might say, "Well, what if we're not ready?" And my answer is, we are ready. The Iraqis are ready to take control of their country, and they're makin' great progress in this process. We're workin' closely with the United Nations to ensure a smooth transition, and we're helpin' the Iraqis to build the necessary institutions and infrastructure to govern themselves.

As for the organization that we'd like to see power transferred to, I'd say it's the Iraqi Interim Government that we've been workin' with. They're a broad-based government that represents all the major ethnic and sectarian groups in Iraq. They're workin' hard to establish the necessary institutions, like a constitution, an judiciary, and a military, so that they can provide security and stability for their people.

I'd like to also give a special mention to Prime Minister Allawi, who's doin' a fantastic job in leadin' the transition process. He's a great leader, and I have every confidence that he and his team are goin' to do a terrific job in buildin' a free and prosperous Iraq.

So, I'd like to reiterate that June 30th is not just a deadline, it's a milestone in the transition process. We're committed to helpin' the Iraqis to succeed, and we're goin' to do everything we can to make sure that they do.

I believe that our plan for a smooth transition of power in Iraq has been executed in a manner that ensures the continued stability and security of the country. While there may have been some bumps along the road, I have every confidence in the abilities of the Iraqi people and their leadership to move forward in a positive direction.

The transfer of sovereignty is a significant milestone in Iraq's journey towards democracy and self-governance, and I'm proud of the progress we've made so far. However, I'm not naive to think that the transition will be without its challenges. 

Our goal is to work with the Iraqi people, to help them rebuild their nation and provide a foundation for a brighter future. We will continue to provide support and assistance to the new Iraqi government, but we're also committed to our stated goal of reducing our military presence in the country as circumstances permit.

It's my firm belief that we're on the right path, and the transfer of sovereignty is an important step in that journey. We will continue to work closely with the Iraqi people and the international community to ensure that this transition is a success.

Now I'd like to turn to Prime Minister Blair and ask him if he'd like to add anything.

Thank you for the questions. As I stand before you today, I'd like to emphasize our commitment to helping Iraq become a stable democracy. The cost of this endeavor is indeed significant, but I firmly believe it's a crucial investment in the future of the region and the world at large.

Regarding the financial cost, we anticipate that the supplemental appropriations for Iraq will likely be around $80 billion for fiscal '05. However, it's essential to note that these funds aren't solely allocated for military operations but also include resources for vital reconstruction and humanitarian aid efforts.

Concerning troop levels in Iraq, our commanders in the field are continuously assessing the situation and making adjustments as needed. I want to assure the American people that our military is capable of handling the current situation, but I also want to underscore that we'll be providing sufficient forces to ensure a successful outcome in Iraq.

Now, regarding the broader issue of the Middle East peace process, I agree that it's an extremely pressing issue. I'm in lockstep with Prime Minister Blair's sentiment on this matter. We must foster an environment conducive to peace negotiations between Israelis and Palestinians. The stakes are high, but I remain hopeful that a two-state solution can be achieved through diplomacy and dialogue. Our administration will continue to work tirelessly with our international partners, particularly the Quartet, to revive the Road Map for peace and encourage both parties to stick to their commitments.

I'd like to conclude by reiterating that these daunting challenges in the Middle East require a steadfast commitment to our shared values of freedom, democracy, and human dignity. Thank you.

Thank you for the question. Let me address that. What I meant by not negotiating with myself is that I don't want to come to Congress with a preconceived notion that, you know, here's the plan, take it or leave it. I want to work with the members of Congress, both Democrats and Republicans, to come up with a solution.

Now, I have put some parameters on the table, and I think that's a necessary part of leadership. One of the parameters is that we're not going to cut benefits for people who are retired, near-retired, or who will be retiring soon. And by near-retired, I mean people in their 50s and above.

But, you see, that doesn't mean we can't reform the system for younger workers. We can make changes to the system that will make it more sustainable, more solvent, for future generations. And that's what we're trying to do. We're trying to take a long-term approach to making sure that Social Security is there for our younger citizens.

Now, I understand that some people might say, "Well, that's still negotiating with yourself." But I think it's a necessary part of the process to put some parameters on the table and say, "This is what we're not going to do." And then work from there.

And I'm confident that we can find a solution that works for everybody. And I'm looking forward to working with the Congress to get that done.

Thank you, appreciate the question. I'm glad to report that the fundamentals of our economy are strong. We've had a remarkable period of economic growth, job creation, and low unemployment. Now, I do acknowledge that the latest GDP numbers were a little softer than we anticipated, but we also know that the momentum in the economy is still there.

Now, when it comes to inflation, we're closely watching the figures. We believe that our policies are in place to keep inflation in check, and we're confident that the Fed, with Chairman Greenspan's leadership, will make the necessary decisions to keep inflation from getting out of hand.

In terms of consumer spending, it's true that we've seen a slight slowdown, but American consumers are resilient. We believe they've just gotten a little cautious, and we think that's prudent. We think that's a wise decision.

Now, in terms of our agenda, I can assure you that Social Security reform remains a top priority for this administration. We've had some very constructive discussions with members of both parties on the Hill, and I'm optimistic that we can get this done.

These bumps, as you put it, are just that – bumps in the road. We're taking a long-term view here. Our policies are designed to promote – long-term growth, and we're confident that, with steady, consistent policies, we can overcome these speed bumps and get back on track.

So, in short, I remain confident in our economic forecast. I'm optimistic about the potential for growth, and I'm committed to continuing to work with Congress to get our Social Security reform passed. Thank you.

Thank you for your question. As I said earlier, the United States' position remains clear: we do not support the expansion of settlements. It's an impediment to peace, and it's something that makes it more difficult to achieve our goal of a two-state solution.

Now, I understand that the Israeli government has certain obligations to its citizens, but I also believe that the Israeli government has a responsibility to work towards a solution that will bring peace and security to both Israelis and Palestinians.

Regarding the wall, I believe that it's a necessary response to the security threat posed by the Palestinians, but I also made clear that it must not be a pretext for further Israeli territorial expansion.

To the American voters, I want to assure them that my administration has been actively engaged in efforts to promote a two-state solution, and we will continue to work tirelessly towards this goal. It's in the interests of both Israelis and Palestinians, and it's in the interests of the United States.

To the Palestinian public, I want to say that I understand your frustration and disillusionment with the current situation. I want to assure you that the United States is committed to a fair and just solution, one that will bring an end to the occupation and allow for the creation of a sovereign Palestinian state.

But I also want to be clear that the United States will not support a state that is based on terror and violence. We will support a state that is based on democratic principles, and one that recognizes the right of Israel to exist in peace and security.

I hope that answers your question. Thank you.

Thank you for your question. As I've said many times, Harriet Miers is a woman of great character and strong conviction. And I can tell you that we have, over the course of many conversations and discussions, talked about a wide range of topics, including her judicial philosophy and her potential approach to certain key issues.

Now, I know that there are some folks out there who are speculating about Harriet's views on abortion, and I'm not going to get into any specifics on that today. But I will say this: Harriet Miers is a woman of great respect for the law, and she will approach any case that comes before her with the utmost seriousness and integrity.

As a Supreme Court Justice, I expect Harriet to make decisions based on her interpretation of the Constitution and the law, and not on any preconceived notions or personal opinions. And as her friend, I have every confidence that she will do just that.

Now, I understand that some folks may be looking for a clear litmus test or a definitive statement on certain issues, but I'm not going to provide that today. I've made my decision to nominate Harriet Miers based on her exceptional qualifications, her commitment to the rule of law, and my trust in her character. And I stand by that decision.

I appreciate the question, and I think it's a fair one. Let me start by saying that I'm proud of my nominees to the Supreme Court, and that includes Harriet Miers. She's a fine lawyer, an outstanding public servant, and I know she'll make a great Justice.

Now, I understand that there are some concerns about her qualifications, but I have to respectfully disagree with those concerns. Harriet has a long and distinguished career as a lawyer, both in the private sector and in public service. She's got a sharp mind, a strong work ethic, and a deep commitment to the law.

And let me say, I find it a little ironic that some of the same people who are questioning Harriet's qualifications are the same folks who said I should have chosen someone with more experience on the bench. Well, I did choose someone with experience in the law, and a proven track record of achievement.

I also want to say that I was influenced by the fact that Harriet is a trailblazer. She was the first woman to be elected President of the Texas Bar Association, and she's broken down barriers her whole career. And that's the kind of leadership and that's the kind of example that I think will be beneficial to the Court, and to the country.

Now, I understand that not everyone will agree with my choice, and that's okay. I'm willing to make tough decisions, and I'm willing to take the heat. But I can tell you this: Harriet Miers will make a fine Justice, and I'm proud to have nominated her. Thank you.

The administration's decision regarding the testimony of senior staff is a matter of executive privilege, and it's a principle that we're upholding. We're cooperating with the investigations, both the Congressional inquiry and the White House's own review. However, we're doing it in a way that ensures the integrity of the executive branch and protects the ability of the President to get unvarnished advice from his advisers.

Now, regarding Michael Brown, I think it's best that he has the opportunity to make his own decision. As a private citizen, he can choose whether or not to testify before Congress. I'm not going to pressure him one way or the other, because that's his decision to make.

I do want to say that I've got confidence in our review process. We're doing a careful and thorough investigation, and we're going to find out what went wrong and what went right. And I'm confident that in the end, we'll come up with a plan that will help us better prepare for natural disasters in the future.

But again, the issue of executive privilege is a critical one, and we're going to uphold it. It's not just about this administration; it's about all future administrations, and the ability of the President to get the kind of advice that he or she needs to make tough decisions.

Well, I appreciate that question. You know, it's a good question. One of the things we're going to do is to work with the Iraqis to establish some benchmarks, some measurements that will help us determine whether or not progress is being made. And those benchmarks will be based upon measurements such as the number of people who've got electricity, for example, or the amount of oil that's being produced.

As for a specific timeframe, I think, you know, we want to make sure that we continue to have a measured and patient approach. We're not going to put a specific timeframe on it. We want to make sure that we work with the Iraqis to establish a timeframe that is realistic, so that we can measure progress.

But I'll tell you this: I'm optimistic. I'm optimistic that we'll begin to see some real progress in the coming months. And I believe that's due in part to the Iraqi government's - new Iraqi government's determination to succeed, and the fact that we've got a new strategy on the ground.

Thank you for that question. As President, it's my responsibility to ensure that America remains competitive in the global marketplace, and that our national security interests are protected.

First, let me say that the decision to approve or reject a merger like the one between Lucent and Alcatel is made by the Committee on Foreign Investment in the United States, or CFIUS, which is an interagency committee that reviews these kinds of transactions for national security implications.

In general, I believe that foreign investment in the United States is a positive force. It brings in new capital, new technology, and new ideas that can help our economy grow and create jobs. However, I also believe that we have to be mindful of our national security interests and make sure that any foreign acquisition or investment does not compromise our ability to protect our country.

In the case of Lucent and Alcatel, the CFIUS reviewed the transaction and concluded that it did not pose a national security risk. The committee considered a range of factors, including the potential impact on our military and defense industries, and determined that the merger does not compromise our national security.

Now, I know some of my fellow Americans may have concerns about foreign companies buying out U.S. firms with military contracts. I share those concerns, and I want to assure you that we will continue to carefully review any transaction that raises national security questions.

But we also have to be careful not to use national security as a pretext for protectionism. We need to be mindful of the global nature of the economy and make sure that we're not inadvertently cutting ourselves off from the rest of the world.

So, to answer your question, I'm confident that our process for reviewing foreign investments is robust and effective, and I'm committed to making sure that America remains open to foreign investment, while also protecting our national security interests. Next question, please?

Well, thank you for that question. First of all, I appreciate the progress that's been made with the EU-3, and I appreciate the way that Chancellor Merkel, Prime Minister Blair, and President Chirac have worked together to try to achieve a diplomatic solution with Iran. The incentives package, as you describe it, is a generous offer to the Iranian people.

Now, if, in fact, the Iranians do not respond positively, we will, of course, reassess our strategy. And I would say to you that all options are on the table. The G-8, by the way, is a very important meeting. It's a chance for the G-8 nations to get together and talk about a lot of important issues, including this one.

And I would tell you that I would hope that the G-8 would be a unified voice in saying to the Iranians, "It's time to make a decision." Now, I know that some countries may have different views about how to deal with Iran, and I respect those views. But I believe that it's essential that the G-8 be a united voice in saying, "We need to work together to achieve a diplomatic solution."

Regarding the U.N. Security Council, I would say that all options are on the table. We're working closely with our friends and allies to make sure that the U.N. Security Council is a relevant and effective body in dealing with the Iranian issue.

And to the American people, I would say, first of all, that we're working hard to achieve a diplomatic solution. It's in our interest to do so. It's in the interest of peace and stability. But, secondly, I would say to you that we will not back away from our principles. We will not back away from our values. We will not back away from our commitment to defend our country and to defend our friends and allies.

Now, regarding China and Russia, I appreciate the efforts of those countries to try to deal with the Iranian issue. I think it's essential that all nations work together to achieve a solution. But I would also say to you that we're not going to shy away from our principles. We're not going to shy away from our values. We're going to stand strong.

And so, to those Americans who are frustrated, I understand that frustration. But I would say that we're making progress, and we're committed to achieving a solution that will bring peace and stability to the region. Thank you.

Thank you for your question. I appreciate the opportunity to address this critical issue. First, let me say that we take this situation very seriously. The revelation that North Korea has indeed developed a nuclear capability is a grave concern for the United States and for the world. When I said we would not tolerate a nuclear North Korea, I meant it. We cannot allow the proliferation of nuclear weapons, especially in the hands of a regime that has shown such disregard for international norms and human rights.

In response to these developments, we're engaging in intense diplomatic efforts. We're working closely with our friends and allies in the region, including Japan, South Korea, and China, to find a peaceful resolution to this crisis. We're also in consultations with the United Nations Security Council to ensure that the international community speaks with one voice in condemning North Korea's actions.

Make no mistake, we will not take any options off the table, but our preference is for a diplomatic solution. We want to see North Korea abandon its nuclear program and return to the negotiating table. We're willing to work with the international community to provide North Korea with a better alternative, one that does not involve developing and proliferating nuclear arms.

To the American people, I want to assure them that we take this threat seriously, but we will not be intimidated. We will continue to work tirelessly to protect the United States and our interests abroad. We will not let North Korea's actions dictate our policy or undermine our resolve.

And to the international community, I say that now is the time for collective action. We must stand together against the threat of nuclear proliferation, and we must demonstrate our resolve to uphold the non-proliferation treaty. We will not stand idly by while rogue regimes flout the rules and put the security of the world at risk.

Thank you, and I appreciate your question.

You know, I've spent a lot of time thinking about that, and I think it's fair to say that there are certainly things that we could have done differently. One thing that comes to mind is the disbanding of the Iraqi army. We made a decision to disband the army, and in retrospect, I think that was a mistake.

We had a plan to take the Baathist elements out of the army, and we should have done that, but we shouldn't have disbanded the whole army. There were many professional soldiers in that army that had a lot to offer, and by disbanding it, we created a lot of disillusioned, unemployed young men who became easy prey for the terrorists.

Another thing that I think we could have done differently is we could have brought in more troops earlier. When we hit the surge, and David Petraeus implemented the surge strategy, it worked. It worked, and it worked in a relatively short period of time.

Now, that's not to say that we didn't make mistakes. We did make mistakes. We made tactical mistakes, we made strategic mistakes, but I think that we also, you know, we also had some successes. And when I look back on it, I think that the strategic decision to get rid of Saddam Hussein, the world is a better place without him, and the Iraqi people are better off without him.

But anyway, there's a lot of lessons learned, and I'm confident that as the future unfolds, people will take a harder look, a more nuanced look at what happened, and we can draw lessons from it to make sure we don't repeat some of the mistakes that were made.

(thoughtfully) Well, thank you for the question. Let me tell you, we took all intel into consideration, and I'm not going to get into specific conversations that took place in the Situation Room. But I will tell you this: we made the decision to go into Iraq because we believed Saddam Hussein was a threat to the United States, a threat to our allies, and a threat to global peace.

(postures confidently)

Now, I know some folks have suggested that we didn't think this through, that we didn't consider all the contingencies. But I'm here to tell you, we did. We weighed the risks, we weighed the benefits, and we made the decision we thought was best for the country.

(pauses for emphasis)

And as for our warnings about Iran and Al Qaida, let me tell you, we've been very clear: we will not tolerate those who seek to destabilize the region or harm American interests. We will continue to pursue our strategy of opposing those who seek to undermine freedom and democracy.

(pauses to glance around the room)

We're dealing with a complex situation in the Middle East, and we're dealing with it in a bipartisan way, with the support of Congress. We'll continue to work with our allies, we'll continue to take the fight to the enemy, and we'll do what it takes to protect the American people.

(firmly)

I hope that answers your question.

No. Our mission in Iraq is to help the Iraqi people achieve democracy and stability, and ultimately, our goal is to bring our troops home. We're working closely with the Iraqi government to assist them in taking control of their own security, and as they become more capable, we will be able to draw down our forces.

Thank you for your question. First, let me make it clear that I have great confidence in Alberto Gonzales, and I think he's doing a fine job as the Attorney General of the United States. Now, I understand that Congress has expressed its no-confidence vote, and I respect that. However, I do not believe that this vote should necessarily dictate the Attorney General's continuation in his position.

Now, the Attorney General serves at the pleasure of the President, and I am the President. And I've made it clear that I have confidence in his ability to carry out his duties. And I believe he can be effective, despite the no-confidence vote. We've got a lot of work to do in this country, and that includes the Department of Justice, and I think Alberto is the person to carry out that work.

Regarding General Peter Pace, the Chairman of the Joint Chiefs, I did accept his offer to step down rather than go through a contentious reconfirmation process. Now, I understand that some folks may see a contradiction here, but I don't. General Pace served our country with great distinction, and it was his decision to step down, not mine.

And as the Commander-in-Chief, I have a responsibility to consider the overall impact on the country. In this case, I didn't want to see General Pace go through a difficult confirmation process, and that's why I accepted his offer to step down.

Now, in the case of the Attorney General, I believe Alberto Gonzales is doing a fine job, and I don't think the no-confidence vote should necessarily dictate his continuation. We'll continue to work together to get the job done.

Thank you for your question. Well, I'm not disappointed, I'm still optimistic that the Israelis and Palestinians can reach a peace agreement that meets the needs of both parties. The Annapolis Conference was an important step forward, as it brought both leaders together and outlined a framework for negotiations.

Now, I understand the road to peace will not be easy, and it's going to take time and effort from both sides. But I'm confident that with continued dialogue and a commitment to the shared goal of a two-state solution, progress will be made.

As for my role, I'll continue to stay engaged and support the negotiations in any way I can. I've always said that I'd apply pressure if necessary, but I believe that for now, the parties are making a good-faith effort. I urge them to redouble their efforts, and I'll be urging them to do so in the coming weeks and months.

And to the Prime Minister, I think it's best to let him speak for himself on the specific assurances he's willing to offer. But I will say that I did discuss this issue with him at length, and I'm confident that he understands the importance of addressing the settlement issue in a way that's consistent with the Roadmap and with the desire for a two-state solution.

I'd like to hear the Prime Minister's thoughts on this, if you'd like. Prime Minister?

I appreciate the question. On the first part, I do believe we need to take a comprehensive approach to energy policy. However, suspending or rolling back the Federal gasoline tax might provide some short-term relief, but it's not a long-term solution to the problem.

We've proposed an energy policy that encourages more exploration and more production, including domestic production, which will help stabilize the price. And, as I mentioned in my opening statement, we're also investing in alternative technologies, such as ethanol and hydrogen.

Regarding the gas prices, I understand it's a big burden for the American people. It's like a hidden tax. And, you know, I'm concerned about it. I don't have a magic wand to make the price go down, but we're working to create conditions in the energy market so that the price will stabilize.

And I do think the oil companies, which are our -- are making profits, some of which are based upon the increased price of oil -- we need to make sure they're treating the consumers fairly and transparently, and we're going to implement the energy bill that encourages competition in the right way.

Now, I will say that those companies have responsibilities as well. They are making significant profits out of some of their investments, but that's also an opportunity for them to invest in exploration and production.

Thank you for the question. Well, I think it's a fair point you make. The Kyoto Protocol was a non-binding agreement when it was signed, and I think it's reasonable to look at the actions of others in determining whether they're serious about the treaty.

As for the European Union nations, I believe they are struggling with the economic implications of Kyoto. You see, this treaty is not just a environmental agreement, it's also an economic one. And I think many of our European friends are finding it difficult to reconcile their environmental goals with their economic realities.

Now, I'm not saying the EU nations don't care about the environment. I think they do. But I do think they're having a tough time meeting the tough targets set out in Kyoto. And I think that's why we haven't seen any of them ratify the treaty yet.

As for our own position, I've made it clear that we're committed to reducing greenhouse gas emissions, but we need to do it in a way that's fair to the American people. We're not going to sign a treaty that's going to harm our economy or unfairly penalize American workers and businesses. We need a more balanced approach, and that's what we're working towards.

And I'd like to invite President Prodi to respond to your question.

Thank you for your question. The situation in Afghanistan is indeed a complex and fluid one. While the Northern Alliance's take-over of Kabul is a significant development, I want to emphasize that our ultimate goal is to see a stable and representative government in Afghanistan, one that is not a haven for terrorists.

Regarding the reports of executions and violent reprisals, I am deeply concerned and disturbed by these allegations. We take these reports seriously, and we will be working closely with the United Nations and other international partners to ensure that the rights of all individuals, including prisoners of war, are respected and protected.

As for the Northern Alliance's ability to form a broad-based government, we will be closely monitoring the situation to ensure that any government that emerges is representative of all the Afghan people, including the many ethnic groups that make up the country. We want to see a government that is committed to the values of democracy, tolerance, and human rights.

In terms of the U.S. role in this process, we will continue to work with the international community to support a peaceful and stable transition in Afghanistan. We will be providing humanitarian assistance to the Afghan people, who have suffered greatly under the Taliban regime, and we will be working with the United Nations to help facilitate a peaceful and inclusive political process.

As for the potential deployment of U.S. troops in a political phase, I want to emphasize that our primary objective is to disrupt and defeat the terrorist networks that operating in Afghanistan. However, we are also committed to supporting a stable and secure Afghanistan, and we will work with our international partners to consider all options to achieve that goal.
