Ultimately, the future of Afghanistan must be determined by the Afghan people themselves. We will support the Afghan people as they work towards a more stable and secure future, but it is up to them to define their own path forward. Thank you.

(pausing, collecting my thoughts) Well, I appreciate the question. I think it's essential to provide some context here. The National Intelligence Estimate did indeed express some concerns about the relationship between Saddam Hussein and al-Qaeda. Now, I know there's been a lot of discussion about the strength of that intelligence, and I'll tell you that at the time, we were dealing with a threat that we considered very real.

While it's true that the NIE expressed some doubts about the likelihood of Saddam providing WMD to al-Qaeda, it's also important to note that the report did suggest that Saddam had, in fact, had some interactions with al-Qaeda officials, and that there were some connections between Iraq and other terrorist groups.

(firmly) Now, as Commander-in-Chief, I had to make a decision based on the information I had at the time. And I believed then, and I believe now, that Saddam Hussein was a threat to the United States, and to the stability of the region. The fact that he had used WMD in the past, the fact that he had the intent to develop more, and the fact that he was a supporter of terrorism, all contributed to my decision to take action.

(smiling faintly) Now, I know there's been a lot of debate about this, and I respect that debate. But I think it's essential to remember that the decision to go to war was not based solely on the question of whether Saddam was working with al-Qaeda. It was based on a broader assessment of the threat that he posed, and our determination to protect the American people.

(firmly) As for definitive evidence of a connection between Saddam and al-Qaeda, I think it's fair to say that we've had a lot of indications of contact and cooperation between the two. Now, I'm not going to get into all the specifics of that intelligence, but I will say that it's clear that Saddam was a supporter of terrorism, and that he had relationships with groups that shared al-Qaeda's ideology.

(serious tone) Look, I understand that this is a complex and contentious issue, and I respect the views of those who disagree with me. But I want to assure the American people that I made the decision to go to war based on the best information available at the time, and with the sole intention of protecting our country and our interests.

I think it's, uh, natural to have some mistakes, some misinformation in the intelligence. And I appreciate your question, but let me tell you, Dr. Rice is an excellent public servant, and she's done a wonderful job as my National Security Adviser. And I'm proud to have her by my side.

Now, regarding the statement in the State of the Union Address, I take responsibility for the information that's given to me by our intelligence agencies. And if there's an error, then I'm the one who's ultimately responsible. But I can tell you, the, uh, the raw intelligence, if you will, the raw intelligence was provided to us by our intelligence agencies, and it was based on that information that the statement was made.

And, uh, I think it's, uh, I think it's a classic case of, uh, "bad information in, bad information out." And, uh, we're doing our best to make sure that our intelligence is accurate and reliable. And, uh, I think we're making progress in that regard.

But, uh, let me just say, Dr. Rice is, uh, a fine public servant, and I'm not gonna sacrifice her or anybody else on the altar of, uh, the debate that we're having here.

Well, I'd like to address that. You know, I understand that there's skepticism. And I can understand why people might be skeptical. But I believe that we are safer today than we were prior to my presidency. We've taken steps to make America more secure. We've dismantled the terror network of Al-Qaeda, we've disrupted their finance, we've trained and assisted other countries to help us fight the war on terror.

And let me tell you, I think it's very important for Americans to understand that the world is a more complex place today. It's a more dangerous place today. And we are in a long-term struggle against ideological extremists who have a twisted view of history and our country. And we're working hard to disrupt their plans.

Now, I understand that the American people may not agree with me on every issue, and that's the beauty of our democracy. But I want to assure the American people that I take my responsibility to protect them seriously. And I believe that we are making progress in the war on terror.

Now, would I like to be able to say that, you know, there's no more danger? I wish that would be the case. But I want to make sure that the American people know that we're working hard to protect them every day, and that we're making progress in that effort. And that's what I believe.

Thank you, Helen. I appreciate your question. You know, I've said from the beginning that this is a long-term commitment we're making in Iraq. We're not just talking about winning a war, we're talking about building a stable democracy in a part of the world that's, let's face it, been a hotbed of instability for decades.

Now, as to the timeline, I'm not going to put a specific date on it, because I don't think that's wise. But I will say this: we're making progress, and we're going to continue to make progress. We're working with the Iraqi government to build up their security forces, and they're beginning to take the lead in more and more areas. We're also seeing the Iraqi economy start to grow, and the Iraqi people start to take ownership of their country.

Now, I will say this: it's going to take time. It's not going to happen overnight. But I'm confident that with our help, the Iraqi people are going to be able to build a better future for themselves. And as they do, we'll be able to begin to bring our troops home.

I don't have a specific date in mind, but I do think that as Iraq becomes more stable, as the Iraqi forces become more capable, we'll be able to begin to draw down our troops. But I want to emphasize that we're not going to leave until the job is done. We're not going to leave until Iraq is stable, until it's a strong and independent country that's a positive force in the region.

And I want to assure you, Helen, and the American people that we're doing everything we can to support our troops over there. We're giving them the best equipment, the best training, and the best support that we possibly can. And we're doing everything we can to bring them home as soon as possible, while still getting the job done.

(clears throat) Well, I appreciate the question. Let me start by saying that we have acknowledged that there were intelligence failures prior to the decision to go into Iraq. We've said that before. I've said it myself. But let me make one thing very plain: intelligence is a tough business. Nobody's perfect. We're dealing with people who are trying to keep secrets, and it's a tough task.

But I do think it's essential for the American people to understand that the intelligence that was gathered, and the analysis of that intelligence, led the world to believe that Saddam Hussein was a threat. It wasn't just our intelligence services; it was the intelligence services of many countries that believed he was a threat.

Now, we're also saying that we have learned from our experience in Iraq. We've made changes to the intelligence community. We've improved the way we gather intelligence. We've improved the way we analyze intelligence.

But I am not validating the notion that we were lying. We made the best decision we could based on the information we had at the time. And the American people know that the decision I made was made with the best of intentions, and it was made in the interest of the American people.

(pauses)

As for the way it's been characterized by some in the debate, I think it's unfortunate that there are some who are trying to pull apart the country with these kinds of charges. It's not helpful. We need to be working together to make sure we succeed in the task at hand, which is to make America safer and more secure.

I appreciate the question.  First, let me remind you that I've been very careful about the programs that have been implemented.  I've had the benefit of some great advice from some very smart people outside of government, as well as from within government.

First, let me tell you, we've got to be careful not to alarm people.  There's a difference between an NSA wiretap and putting out an alert to the authorities to be on the lookout for, you know, someone who might be suspicious.

We've worked to get a better system in place.  We behind FISA laws, for example, there's a series of safeguards, strictly limiting the number of people who can intercept these communications and what is done with them. 

It's true that we disclose the information to a variety of individuals who understand the nature of the threats, and so the burden is passed to other authorities of government, but we are indeed only doing what is lawful and necessary in the agenda.

Thank you. I appreciate your concern about the operational effectiveness of the National Guard troops. The truth is, these troops are doing a great job in assisting the Border Patrol, and their rotations are designed to ensure that we don't have burnout. This is a targeted mission, and I've been assured by the Department of Defense and the National Guard leadership that they can handle this mission and still meet their other responsibilities.

Now, regarding the rotations, these are planned in a way that ensures continuity of effort. The outgoing troops will be thoroughly debriefed, and the incoming troops will be thoroughly briefed, so we won't miss a beat in terms of our efforts to secure the border.

As for the members of Congress, I'm optimistic that they'll come around. I've been meeting with many of them, and I believe that they want to get a bill done. I'm a policymaker, and I've made my position clear: we need a comprehensive approach to immigration reform that includes better enforcement, a guest-worker program, and a path to citizenship for those who are already here.

Now, I know there are some who don't agree with me on the guest-worker program, but I believe it's essential to a functioning system. It's a way for us to match willing workers with willing employers in a way that's safe and orderly.

I'm going to continue to make my case to the members of Congress, and I'm hopeful that we can find common ground. We need to get this done, because our immigration system is broken and it's in the national interest to fix it.

Thank you for that question.  First of all, let me talk about the Treasury Secretary.  I asked Secretary Snow to stay on, he's decided to move on. I appreciate his service, and he's been a vital part of my economic team. But I can tell you, we're going to miss him. He's a good man. He's done a fine job.  And, of course, I'll be announcing a replacement soon.

Regarding the economy, I understand concerns about health care costs and gasoline costs. They're real concerns. But the fundamentals of our economy are strong. We've got low unemployment, low inflation, and the economy is growing. We're working on these concerns.  One, we've got a comprehensive health care agenda. Two, we're working on getting more oil and gas supply.

And the fact that gasoline prices have gone up is not going to cause me to blink. We've been working to make sure that the American people have access to Iraqi oil, so that there is more supply on the market to deal with these prices. We've been working with Congress to get more drilling on ANWR.

Thank you for that question. Yes, I did refer to a "Third Awakening" in a conversation with some conservative journalists, and I'd be happy to explain what I meant by that.

As you may know, the first Great Awakening was a period of spiritual revival in America, led by folks like Jonathan Edwards in the 1740s. And then we had a Second Great Awakening in the mid-19th century, which was marked by a significant increase in church membership, missionary work, and social reform.

Now, I believe we're seeing a Third Great Awakening in America today. I see it in the way people are looking for meaning and purpose in their lives. I see it in the way people are searching for a sense of community and belonging. And I see it in the way people are looking for answers to the big questions of life.

I believe this awakening is being driven by a sense of discontent with the status quo, a sense that there's more to life than just material possessions or personal fulfillment. People are looking for something deeper, something more meaningful.

Now, I know some might say that this is just a backlash against the excesses of modern society, or that it's just a fad. But I believe it's something more profound than that. I believe it's a genuine spiritual hunger, a desire to connect with something greater than ourselves.

As for contradictory evidence, well, I think we can all see signs of a culture that's still pretty divided and pretty materialistic. We still see people who are more focused on their own interests than on the common good. We still see a lot of conflict and division in our society.

But I believe that's always been the case in America, even during times of great spiritual awakening. We're a complex and imperfect people, and we always will be. But I believe that, despite our flaws, we're capable of greatness, and that this Third Awakening can be a moment of great renewal and rebirth for our country.

So, that's what I meant by the Third Awakening. It's a sense of hope and optimism that I have about the direction our country is headed. Thank you.

Well, thank you for your question. I did instruct my staff to look into the leak of the Hadley memo. I am disappointed, but not surprised, that this memo found its way into the press. I believe it is a serious offense to leak classified information, and I take these matters very seriously.

As to the cause of the leak, I am not prepared to make any accusations at this time. However, I can tell you that we are looking into the matter, and we will take all necessary steps to protect sensitive information and to prevent leaks in the future.

Now, as for the suggestion that someone is trying to undermine my Iraq policy, I would say that's speculation at this point. But I will tell you this: my team and I are united in our resolve to support the Iraqi government, to help them achieve their goals, and to bring stability and security to the people of Iraq.

And as for my meeting with Prime Minister al-Maliki, it is business as usual. We had a productive conversation, and we are working together to address the challenges that we're facing in Iraq. So, to speculate about sabotage or undermining, I just don't think that's productive, and I don't think it's accurate.

Thank you. Next question.

Well, thank you for that question. I had a very enriching conversation with Pope Benedict, as I've had with many other world leaders, and I want to start off by saying that we share a deep commitment to the downtrodden, the poor, and those who are suffering. And we share a commitment to peace and to freedom.

Regarding the conflict in Iraq, the Pope did express his concerns, as many have, and I respect those concerns. I listened carefully to what he had to say and explained our position and the reasoning behind it. I want to remind you all that our goal is to bring peace and security to the Iraqi people. And I truly believe that the actions we have taken have put Iraq on a path towards self-governance and democratic rule.

We did not have any deep disagreements on a matter such as whether the Iraq conflict was just or not. The Holy Father recognized my own good intentions. I am quite sure that he felt a personal concern for the security and well-being of Roman Catholics living in Iraq.

Thank you for your question. The United States is deeply concerned about the humanitarian situation in Kosovo, and we believe that the international community must take action to resolve this crisis. As for a deadline, I think it's essential that we see some progress from the United Nations in the coming days, and I'd like to see a deadline set for the end of June.

Regarding our relations with Russia, I understand that our position on Kosovo may not be in line with Russia's, but we cannot let that disagreement hold us back from taking a strong stance on an issue of such great humanitarian importance. We'll continue to engage with the Russians, and we hope that they'll ultimately see the wisdom in taking a firmer stand against the Milosevic regime.

As for the Russian missile defense proposal, I've been reviewing it carefully, and I appreciate the efforts of the Russian government to address concerns about national missile defense. However, our position remains that we need a robust defense system to protect our country from rogue states and terrorist organizations. We'll continue to work with the Russians and other nations to address these concerns, but our primary responsibility is to protect the American people.

I understand why you'd ask that question. And I appreciate the opportunity to address it. Let me tell you, I've always said that when the facts change, you better change your assumptions, and that's exactly what happened here.

In the past, our intelligence community, in its assessment, indicated that Iran was pursuing a nuclear weapon, and I had high confidence in that assessment. However, in this latest National Intelligence Estimate, or NIE, our intelligence community has reviewed the available information, and it has made a judgment that we should change our assessment.

I'm not angry about the new assessment, because I'm not an apologist. I'm a realist. And the reality is, our intelligence community has made a new assessment based on new information, and we should accept that.

In terms of the rest of the world, I'm confident that they understand that the United States is committed to keeping the world safe, and that we will continue to work with our partners and allies to address the serious challenges that we face.

Now, I'll tell you this, the fact that the intelligence assessment has changed doesn't mean the threat from Iran has diminished. It's still a threat, still a challenge, and we're still committed to addressing that challenge.

And so, we'll continue to work with our allies and friends, and we'll continue to advocate for a diplomatic solution to this problem. We'll also continue to work to make sure that our military remains strong and capable of defending our interests.

So, to answer your question directly, I'm not concerned about whether or not the rest of the world will rally around us, because I'm confident in the approach that we've taken, and I'm confident that our friends and allies will continue to work with us to address the challenges that we face.

Thank you, thank you for that question. I've been very clear with the Saudi Arabians, as well as other oil-producing nations, that it's in their interest to increase production, not just in America's interest, but in their own interest. I mean, think about it: higher prices can reduce demand. And it's in their interest to make sure that there's a stable and secure supply of energy. And I've been having these conversations for a while now.

Now, we've had some success in the past, where we've been able to get them to increase production temporarily, short-term. But we need to see more commitment across the board. I'm sending the Energy Secretary, Sam Bodman, to Saudi Arabia to continue these conversations. And I'm confident that we can make some progress.

Now, on the economic stimulus package, I understand your concern, but I believe that the effect of the stimulus package will still be positive. I mean, think about it: people are going to have more money in their pockets, and that's going to stimulate economic activity. Now, I know that higher gasoline prices can partially offset that. But we've got a package that we believe will help small businesses, help individuals, and our economy.

Thank you for your questions.  I'm glad to be here with Prime Minister Harper. 

First, let's address the issue of oil prices.  I believe that this is a global problem that requires a global solution. The United States is working closely with other nations, such as members of the OPEC cartel, to increase production and stabilize the supply of oil. We are also encouraging Americans to conserve energy and reduce their reliance on fossil fuels. We support efforts to enhance energy efficiency, and our administration has proposed a number of measures to increase the supply of renewable energy.

Regarding the U.S. dollar,  we believe that market forces should largely determine exchange rates. However, we will closely monitor the situation and work with our international partners to ensure that currency markets remain stable.

And to answer your question, Prime Minister Harper may have some comments on this as well, the way I see it, we are not the ones lagging on climate change. We have created several initiatives,  and that is evident by my administration's action with the Energy Policy Act of 2005,  the policy includes such measures as improving the energy efficiency of federal buildings and increasing funding for the development of alternative fuels.

Well, I think we've got a good model in place for Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac. They're well-capitalized, they're well-regulated, and I think the model is working. Now, I think the GSEs should continue to be regulated by the federal government, but the private nature of them allows for there not to be a subsidy from the federal government. In other words, we don't want the taxpayer to be at risk. We want there to be a private capital market, with the government in a regulatory role to make sure that the -shared-market and mortgage qintegritrage maintained, in such a way that there's confidence in the mortgage market.

But the idea of totally privatizing them, I think, doesn't make sense. What we need to do is to make sure that the regulatory framework is such that there's confidence within the market, that these companies are being run in a responsible way, and that there's a strong regulatory framework in place to ensure that. And that's what we're going to do.

I appreciate the question. First, I want to express my sympathy to the people of Afghanistan and President Karzai for the recent attacks that have taken place in their country. The loss of innocent life is a tragedy, no matter where it occurs.

Regarding the comments that President Karzai made about Pakistan's intelligence services, I must say that we're working closely with both the government of Pakistan and the government of Afghanistan to address the issue of terrorism. It's a complex issue, no question. I've spoken to President Musharraf, as you know; I've spoken to President Karzai. Both of them are deeply committed to working together to deal with the terrorist threat.

Now, I think it's too early to make definitive conclusions about the participation or complicity of the Pakistani intelligence services. We're going to continue to work with both governments to get to the bottom of it.

Regarding the strength of Al Qaida, I'm not going to speculate about their regenerated capabilities. What I will tell you is that we're spending a lot of time and effort to make sure that we stay on top of the intelligence. We're working closely with our allies, including Pakistan, to make sure that we share intelligence and have a comprehensive approach to dealing with the terrorist threat.

And finally, I'm convinced that the new government in Pakistan is committed to fighting terrorism. They have, no question, taken some bold steps to deal with extremists along the border region. And I was touched by the new Prime Minister's comments the other day, where he recognized the threat that terrorism poses to his country and his people. So, we're going to continue to work together to make sure that we address this threat.

Well, I'm not too concerned about the distractions, to be honest with you. I think the American people elected us, including me, to get the job done, and I'm focused on getting the job done. We've got a lot of big initiatives on the table right now - from tax reform to education reform to Social Security reform. And I believe we can walk and chew gum at the same time.

Now, I'm not saying that these hearings aren't important. If there's wrongdoing, there needs to be accountability. But I do think it's essential for Congress to focus on the people's business. We've got a lot of work to do to make sure that the economy continues to grow, to make sure that we've got a foreign policy that's strong, and to make sure that we're educating our children well.

So, I'll continue to push for my agenda, and I hope Congress will do the same. We'll just have to kind of work through it, and I'm confident that we can. I mean, we're a resilient country, and we've been through a lot of controversies over the course of our history. And I think we'll come out of this just fine.

Now, you know, I'm not trying to be too cavalier about it. I realize this is serious business. But I do think it's possible for Congress to walk and chew gum at the same time.

That's a fair question. Let me be clear: our budget, which we'll be unveiling shortly, includes a $1.6 trillion tax cut that we believe is reasonable and responsible. It's designed to provide broad-based tax relief for all Americans, particularly middle-class families, and to stimulate economic growth.

Now, I understand that Congress may have some additional ideas, and I'm happy to work with them to achieve our shared goals. However, I must emphasize that we cannot and will not support tax cuts that would threaten our fiscal discipline or jeopardize our ability to meet our priorities.

If additional layers, such as corporate tax cuts or capital gains reductions, were to be added, I would need to carefully review the entire package to ensure that it remains fiscally responsible and aligned with our priorities.

As for signing a bill that reaches my desk at a higher level, I would have to evaluate it on its merits. I'm committed to working with Congress to pass a responsible and reasonable tax cut. But if the final product becomes too expensive or threatens our fiscal health, I would have to carefully consider whether it's in the best interests of the American people.

Let me be clear: we're not just talking about cutting taxes for the sake of cutting taxes; we're talking about cutting taxes as part of a comprehensive plan to stimulate economic growth, create jobs, and meet our national priorities. And I'm committed to working with Congress to achieve that goal in a responsible and fiscally sound way.

Thank you for that question. I'm glad to be joined by my friends and counterparts from Canada and Colombia. 

First and foremost, I want to say that the United States strongly supports the peace process in Colombia, and we're committed to doing our part to help bring an end to the violence and the terror that's consumed that great country. We believe that a peaceful Colombia is not only in the best interests of the Colombian people, but also in the best interests of the region and the world.

Regarding our level of involvement, I can tell you that we're already quite engaged in the peace process. We've been providing funding, we've been providing technical assistance, and we've been providing negotiating support to the Colombian government as they work through this difficult process.

As for whether we would be willing to take a more active role, I can tell you that we're open to exploring ways to increase our involvement, but we've got to be careful. We've got to make sure that our involvement is welcome by the Colombian government and that it's consistent with our own interests. We don't want to do anything that would be seen as heavy-handed or intrusive.

I think, Andres, you've made some real progress in the peace process, and we want to support that progress. We want to support your efforts to bring an end to the violence and to ensure that the Colombian people can live in peace and security. And I think that together, we can make a real difference.

President Chretien, I'm sure, has some thoughts on this as well, and I'd be interested to hear them. But from the United States' perspective, we're committed to supporting the peace process in Colombia, and we're open to exploring ways to increase our involvement in a constructive and helpful way.

Thank you for that great question. As the President of the United States, I'm pleased to say that we're already making great progress on strengthening our economic ties with Russia. I've had a very productive conversation with President Putin about this very issue, and I'm confident that we can expect a delegation of American businessmen to visit Moscow in the near future.

In fact, we're already working on arranging a high-level trade mission to Russia within the next few months. This delegation will include representatives from various industries, including energy, technology, and manufacturing, and they'll be looking to explore new opportunities for cooperation and investment between our two countries.

As for the intergovernmental commission, I think that's a great idea. We're already discussing the possibility of establishing a joint commission that can focus on promoting economic cooperation and removing trade barriers between our two countries. This commission would bring together representatives from our respective governments, as well as the private sector, to identify areas for cooperation and to work on resolving any outstanding issues that may be hindering our economic ties.

I'm optimistic that we can make significant progress on this front, and I'm committed to working closely with President Putin to make sure that we're doing everything we can to strengthen our economic partnership. Thank you.

I appreciate that question. I think it's a little premature to say that the tone in Washington is back to the partisan bickering of the past. Now, I will say there have been some shots fired across the bow, and that's disappointing. But I think we've made some real progress in changing the tone in this town.

One thing I'm committed to, and I've made it clear to the Congress, is that we're going to have a respectful dialogue, a civil dialogue, about our differences. And I think we've been able to do that for the most part.

Now, I'm not naive. I know that when you're advocating for significant change, like tax relief or education reform, there's going to be some pushback. And that's okay. That's part of the process.

But I do believe that, in spite of some of the negative ads and in spite of some of the early signs of partisanship, that we're still on a trajectory towards a more civil and respectful dialogue in this town. And I intend to keep pushing for that.

You see, I believe that the American people are tired of all the bickering and the endless campaigning. They want to see us get things done. And I think we've shown, time and time again, that we can disagree without being disagreeable.

So, while I do think there have been some steps back, I'm not ready to call it a failure yet. I'm going to keep pushing for a more civil tone in this town.

Thank you for that question. I appreciate the support of the Indian-American community, as well as the Indian government, in our efforts to bring the perpetrators of 9/11 to justice.

As for Usama bin Laden, we are working tirelessly to bring him to justice, and we're making progress in our efforts to dismantle the al-Qaeda network. I want to assure the American people and the world that we will not rest until we have brought those responsible for the 9/11 attacks to justice.

I'm not going to put a specific deadline on it, but I will tell you that we're working day and night, using all the tools at our disposal, to track down bin Laden and his associates. We're working closely with our allies and friends around the world, including the government of Pakistan, to bring an end to this terrorist threat.

I'm confident that we'll ultimately be successful, but I want to caution that this is a difficult and challenging task. We're dealing with a ruthless and cunning enemy, and it's going to take time and effort to bring them to justice. But we're committed to this mission, and we will not be deterred.

So, I appreciate the support of the Indian-American community and the Indian government, and I want to assure them that we're doing everything in our power to bring Usama bin Laden and his associates to justice.

Well, thank you for that question. My faith is a source of strength and guidance for me, and it's a reminder that there's a higher power that's watching over us. As President, I've made it clear that I believe in the goodness and decency of the American people, and I believe that we're engaged in a noble cause in the war on terror.

Now, I know that there are differences of opinion about how to proceed, and that's healthy in a democracy. But I believe that our cause is just, and that we must stay the course. As I said before 9/11, "faith and prayer" can provide sustenance and comfort in times of uncertainty and crisis. And I encourage all Americans to pray for the safety and well-being of our troops, for the innocent victims of terror, and for the strength and unity of our nation.

But our response to this crisis must also be guided by a sense of resolve and determination. We cannot let the terrorists dictate our actions or undermine our will. We must stay vigilant, we must stay strong, and we must work together to protect our country and our values.

I understand that there are those who may disagree with our approach, and I respect that. But I firmly believe that our actions are necessary to protect our nation and our way of life. And I would say to the American people that we must remain united and steadfast in the face of this threat. We must continue to work together to support our troops, to support the victims of terror, and to show the world that we will not be intimidated by the forces of evil.

And so, I would say that prayer is an important part of our response, but it is not a substitute for action. We must also take concrete steps to address this threat, and that's exactly what we're doing. We're working with our allies, we're supporting our military, and we're taking steps to strengthen our homeland security. And I'm confident that, together, we will prevail.

Well, I appreciate the opportunity to talk about unity, and I believe that's an important subject. I think I've made it clear throughout my campaign that I'm a president who will continue to reach out to people from both parties, and I've done that throughout my campaign.

Now, in terms of whether or not the Democrats have made a sincere and sufficient effort to meet me halfway, I think we've had moments of progress, but I think we've also had moments of partisanship. I'm not one to point fingers or assign blame. I'm more interested in getting things done.

I will say that I was disappointed in the negative tone of the campaign. I think that there were some very personal attacks that I don't think America needs. I'm not one to turn the other cheek, but I'm not one to retaliate, either. I'm a uniter, not a divider.

But to answer your question, in light of the election results, I hope that those who are in the Democratic Party will recognize that the American people have spoken, and it's time for us to put politics aside and work together on the big issues. And I'm willing to continue to reach out and work with the Democrats to solve some of these big problems.

Well, I appreciate the question. Let me be clear: we're very serious about the six-party talks, and we expect North Korea to participate. We've made it clear that time is of the essence, and we're not gonna be patient forever. Now, I'm not gonna get into specific deadlines or timelines, but I will tell you that we're working closely with our partners in the region, including China, to ensure that North Korea understands the importance of returning to the talks.

As for consequences, let's just say that we've got a range of options on the table, and we're prepared to take a hard look at 'em if North Korea continues to stall. We're talking about a country that's got a history of proliferation, that's made promises and broken 'em, and that's causing instability in the region. So, we're not just gonna sit back and wait for them to come to their senses.

Now, on China, I think they've been a constructive partner in the six-party talks, and we appreciate their efforts. But, we also expect 'em to use their influence to help bring the North Koreans back to the table. We've had good discussions with President Hu and the Chinese leadership on this issue, and we're gonna continue to work with 'em to see if we can't get North Korea to make the right decision.

But, make no mistake, we're not gonna tolerate North Korea's behavior forever. We're gonna keep pushing, and we're gonna keep working with our partners to find a resolution that works for everybody in the region.

Thank you for the question. Let me tell you, I'm a strong believer in fiscal responsibility, and I've made it clear to the Congress that we need to be mindful of the budget and the deficit. Now, I've used the veto pen before, and I'm not afraid to use it again.

Now, I work with the Congress, and I've had some successes in the past, like the tax cuts, which have helped our economy grow. But on spending, I think the Congress needs to show more restraint. We've had some bills come across my desk that I just can't sign into law, because they're not responsible, they're not fiscally prudent.

So, to answer your question, I do think I need to be more aggressive in using the veto pen, and in making it clear to the Congress what our priorities are. We need to get a handle on discretionary spending, and we need to make sure that we're not saddling our children and grandchildren with tremendous debt.

Now, I'm not looking for a fight with the Congress, but I am looking for responsible government. And if that means vetoing some bills, then that's what I'll do.

I'm happy to talk about my relationship with John Howard, the Prime Minister of Australia. We've had a wonderful friendship over the years, and I think that's really important in international relations. We've worked together on some very difficult issues, particularly in the war on terror and in our efforts to spread freedom around the world. John is a man of great integrity and strong values, and I have a lot of respect for him.

I think the chemistry between us is based on our shared values and our commitment to promoting freedom and democracy around the world. We've been able to work well together because we trust each other, and we have a deep mutual respect.

As for working with a future Australian leader, I believe that the relationship between our two countries is strong and deep, and it's not dependent on any one individual. I've had the pleasure of getting to know some of the other leaders in the Australian government, and I think we've had a good relationship with their opposition party as well.

If the opposition party were to come to power in Australia, I think we could work effectively with them, too. I think our shared interests and values would remain the same, and we would continue to work together on the issues that are important to both of our countries.

You know, I'm a firm believer that relationships between leaders are important, but they're not the only thing that determines the relationship between two countries. There's a deep affection between the American people and the Australian people, and I think that's what ultimately drives our relationship.

So, while I'm sad to think about John Howard not being Prime Minister anymore, I'm confident that we'll continue to have a strong and productive relationship with Australia, no matter who's in charge.

Well, I think it's, first of all, I want to say that I appreciate the work of the Iraq Study Group that's done by people who care deeply about the situation on the ground in Iraq.  We do know that there's been a lot of violence in Iraq, and we do know that a lot of innocent people have died.

I, you know, I'm not a statistician, but I think it's, I appreciate the work that's been done to try to determine the number of deaths. However, I think we need to be very careful about inflating the numbers, and there's also an estimate by the Iraqi Ministry of Health, that is significantly lower. 

I think that it's very hard to – very difficult to get an accurate number.  I think it's – I'm not going to try to analyze this report in front of you, but I think it's – it's a serious issue.  We're concerned about the death of any innocent life in Iraq, and we're working every day to try to improve the lives of the Iraqi people, and to help them arrive in a more peaceful existence.

We understand that the situation is difficult, and we're doing everything we can to stabilize the country, to help the Iraqi government to establish their own security measures, and to help the country to become more peaceful and prosperous.

But to give an exact number, I think it's just – I'm not going to try to make judgments on the data.

Thank you for that question. I'm glad you asked that. Let me be clear: the international community, with the support of the United Nations, has sent a strong message to the government of North Korea. We will not tolerate their pursuit of nuclear arms, and we will not back down.

Now, regarding South Korea and China, I am confident that they will implement the sanctions as passed by the U.N. Security Council. Both countries have expressed strong support for this resolution, and I expect them to honor their commitments.

As for North Korea, let me make one thing clear: if they continue to defy the international community and pursue a nuclear program, there will be consequences. The United States, along with our international partners, will take all necessary steps to protect our national security and the security of the region.

We've made it clear to North Korea that we prefer a diplomatic solution to this crisis. We're willing to talk with them, but we also expect them to signal that they're serious about changing their behavior. If not, the international community will not hesitate to take action.

And let me emphasize that our patience is not infinite. The stakes are too high, and the risks are too great. We will not stand idly by while North Korea pursues a nuclear program that threatens regional stability and global security.

So, to the government of North Korea, I say this: the clock is ticking. We urge you to take this opportunity to change course and choose a path of peace and cooperation. If not, we will take all necessary steps to protect our interests and those of our allies.

That's a very good question. I appreciate you bringin' it up. Let me be very clear: the intelligence on Iran's nuclear program is credible, it's strong, and it's multiple-source based. We have multiple sources of intelligence, and I'm pleased with the work that's bein' done.

Now, I understand that some folks might be concerned, given the lessons we learned in Iraq, and for good reason. We've taken a number of steps to ensure that the intelligence we gather and the intelligence we present is solid, is credible, and is understood by all parties involved.

Let me assure you, I take the responsibility of gatherin' and analyzin' intelligence very seriously. And I can tell you that the information we have on Iran's nuclear program is different from what we had in Iraq. The international community has more insight into Iran's program than it did with Saddam Hussein's programs.

And I also want to emphasize that we are approachin' this issue in a very different way than we did with Iraq. We're workin' closely with our allies, we're workin' closely with the international community, and we're pursuin' diplomacy to address the issue of Iran's nuclear program. So while I understand the concerns, I believe that the intelligence we have and the approach we're takin' are fundamentally different and much stronger than what we had with Iraq.

Thank you for the question. I want to assure the American people that we take the issue of civil liberties and national security very seriously. The use of national security letters is an important tool for our law enforcement agencies to keep America safe, but it's also important to ensure that they're used in a way that respects the rights of our citizens.

I've spoken to the Attorney General and the FBI Director about these concerns, and they're taking steps to address them. We're working to make sure that these powers are used in a targeted and limited way, and that there are proper safeguards in place to protect the rights of innocent Americans.

Regarding my confidence in Attorney General Gonzales and FBI Director Mueller, I have every confidence in both of them. They're dedicated public servants who are committed to keeping America safe, and they're taking the necessary steps to address these concerns.

However, I also want to make it clear that we need to be vigilant and make sure that the balance between national security and civil liberties is properly maintained. We're working with Congress to make sure that there's proper oversight of these powers, and that we're using them in a way that's consistent with our values as a nation.

I'm committed to making sure that we're doing everything we can to keep America safe, while also protecting the rights of our citizens.

You know, I've given this a lot of thought, and I think there's several issues that our next President is gonna have to tackle head-on. But if I had to pick one, I'd say it's entitlement reform. Now, I know that's not a popular topic, especially not in an election year. But the fact is, our Social Security and Medicare programs are facing some serious long-term financial challenges.

You see, with our aging population and rising healthcare costs, we're headed for a fiscal train wreck if we don't take action. I've tried to address some of these issues during my time in office, but I know there's still a lot more work to be done.

Our next President is gonna have to make some tough decisions, like indexing the retirement age to life expectancy, and means-testing benefits. It's not gonna be easy, but it's essential that we get this done to ensure the long-term solvency of these vital programs.

Now, I know some folks might say, "Mr. President, this is a tough political sell." And I agree, it won't be easy. But I truly believe that our next President has a responsibility to tackle this issue, to put the long-term needs of our nation's retirees ahead of short-term politics.

It's a tough job, but it's one that needs to be done. And I hope that our next President will have the courage and the leadership to tackle entitlement reform, and put our country on a path towards fiscal sustainability for the future. Thank you.

I appreciate your question, and I'll try to provide some clarity on this matter. The United States will indeed be represented at the United Nations Conference on Racism, but at this point, we've made the decision that it will be at a low-level diplomatic representation. Our administration is deeply concerned, however, about some of the agenda items that have been proposed for discussion.

We have been very clear and consistent in stating our opposition to any attempts to brand Zionism as a form of racism or racial discrimination, because that's just not our view. Zionism is the belief in a homeland for the Jewish people, and we think it's a legitimate and worthy goal, one that's deeply rooted in history and a sense of identity.

Regarding reparations for past injustices, we understand the strong emotions and sense of justice that drive this agenda item, but we also think that it's a very complex issue with many different perspectives and considerations. We don't believe that a conference like this is the right forum to resolve these extremely difficult questions, which are better left to bilateral negotiations between countries.

Now, we'll continue to engage with the conference organizers and other participating nations to try to find common ground, but our core concerns regarding these agenda items remain unchanged. We hope to contribute to the fight against racism, but we will do so with our eyes wide open and our principles firmly in place.

I appreciate the question. The capture of Saddam Hussein is a significant moment, a moment of justice for the Iraqi people, and it's a moment that I believe will help bring stability to the region. And I also believe that it will help those nations that were opposed to our actions – or, you know, perhaps uncomfortable with our actions – to understand that our intention was pure.

We've always said, "Let's look over the horizon and see a better world," and I believe that's what this step represents. It's a step towards peace. It's a step towards stability. And it's a step towards a world where nations can work together to achieve a common goal.

Now, I hope that this moment can, in fact, be a bridge that heals the wounds of the past. I hope that nations will look at this moment and say, "You know what? We can work together to effect a peaceful outcome." And I believe that's possible.

But I also understand that there are going to be nations that still won't agree with the actions we took. But I hope they can begin to see that the rationale for our action was to disarm a man who was a threat to the region, a threat to his own people, and, by the way, a threat to the world.

And so, I'm hopeful that this moment can be a moment that people can get beyond our differences. But I also understand that we will continue to have our differences. That's the nature of international diplomacy. But I hope we can put those differences aside and work together to effect a peaceful world.

The situation in Iraq is a tough one, no question about it. We've seen an increase in violence, and it's regrettable, the loss of innocent life. I believe the enemy is feeling the pressure. They're feeling it from the Iraqi forces and the coalition forces. And I think that's one of the reasons we're seeing an increase in, you know, a desperation move. I mean, these people are desperate. They're attacking innocent lives. They're attempting to undermine the new Iraqi government.

But I'm optimistic. I believe the new Iraqi government is up to the task. They've shown some early signs of being able to coordinate their efforts with coalition forces to, you know, to help bring security. And we're committed to helping them get to that point where they can defend themselves against these insurgent attacks.

And I don't think it's accurate to say the enemy is gaining strength. I think, you know, they're able to inflict damage, no question about it. But they're not able to break the will of the American people or the coalition. People are resolute about this. We're working to help the Iraqis to be able to defend themselves, and we're working hard to bring order to the country.

And let me remind you, since the government has been announced, over 60 million Iraqis have gone to the polls. That's a major accomplishment. And I think that there are signs of progress. It's just, you know, this is a – this war on terror is a tough conflict. We're fighting an enemy that's got no regard for human life. And it's – it's tough. But I believe we're making progress, and we're committed to seeing it through.

Thank you, and I appreciate the question.  The Supreme Court's decision today, affirming the right of habeas corpus for the detainees at Guantanamo, is a significant moment in this ongoing discussion.  As I have stated before, I do intend to close Guantanamo Bay. We're going to work through this, as we move forward with great care, ensuring that we don't compromise the security of the United States or our international obligations.

Dealing with the most dangerous detainees, as you've referenced, will be quite a challenge. We will work with Congress to ensure that our system is adequate to handle those individuals who are deemed too difficult to release, and at the same time be mindful of our constitutional standards. Some of the people being held at Guantanamo are enemy combatants. There are people, let's just say, like Khalid Sheikh Mohammed, captured on the battlefield, and they are a threat to the security of the United States and the world, we will have to find a way to make sure that justice is meted out and make sure we protect the security of our country.

This will require cooperation with the Democrats in Congress as well as the international community.  It is time to close Guantanamo, as it's become a symbol of U.S. actions, that while necessary for national security grounds have, as I said, been mishandled.

We must make sure that even as we close a difficult chapter in our nation's history, we do so in a responsible way, mindful of our shared global responsibilities in the courts. Our responsibility within the bounds of our constitution.

Thank you for your question. Let me be very clear on this point. The issue here is that these nations have, in the past, acted in ways that have destabilized the region and harmed American interests. However, I also recognize that the situation on the ground in Iraq is dynamic, and we need all the help we can get.

That being said, I believe we have a responsibility to our own values, to our own principles, to work with people who have clean hands. If there is a way for Iran and Syria to be helpful in addressing the situation in Iraq, I would be more than happy to consider their role. But let me make one thing very clear: if they want to be helpful, they've got to prove it.

Now, I've made it clear in the past that we have significant differences with these countries. Their record on human rights, their support for terrorism, and their refusal to live up to their international obligations, are all major issues for us.

But I also believe that we're at a point in time where we need to think creatively about how we can solve these problems. And if there is a way for Iran and Syria to be part of that solution, I'm more than willing to listen.

It's time for these countries to prove that they're willing to be constructive, that they're willing to be helpful, that they're willing to be responsible members of the international community.

That's a fair question, I think. I believe, however, my commitment to these issues remains strong, and I'm just as confident in my own policies as the day I proposed 'em. Now, I understand why some folks might say, "Well, he's tried, and he hasn't been able to get it done." And that's a legitimate concern.

However, I would argue to the American people, particularly in the case of a comprehensive immigration reform, that our approach was the right one, it's just that we didn't have enough Republican votes to get it across the floor. I believe our plan was a good plan, a plan that would've secured the border, a plan that would've established a guest worker program, and a plan that would've dealt with the 12 million people in a decent, humane way.

If the Democrats come to me with a plan that I can live with, I'll work with 'em. But if the plan looks like an amnesty plan, or a plan that doesn't secure our borders, I'd have to oppose it.

The American people know that I'm a man of principle, and I've been consistent in my views, and I will take those views to the very end of my presidency, and I believe that's what's expected of a president.

Well, I will tell you, the American people did deliver a message. They're frustrated with the gridlock in Washington, D.C., and I understand that. And, frankly, I'm disappointed that more objectives weren't achieved in the past 2 years, when we had a Republican-led majority in the Congress.

Now, as to my leadership style, I am who I am. And I'm proud to lead the country with a clear vision and an optimistic outlook. I will continue to be the same man, working as hard as I can on behalf of the American people.

It is true, however, that with a Democratic-led Congress, we're going to have to work in a different way, obviously. And so I will work with the new leaders of Congress to try to get things done. And we'll find common ground where we can, and where we can't, we'll respectfully disagree. And I am committed to being a leader that will work towards getting positive results for the American people.

Now, one thing I will not do, is I will not change my core convictions in order to try to get approval in the polls. I will continue to do what I think is right for the country, and I'm proud to lead the country with a clear vision and an optimistic outlook.

We'll work with the Democrats, as I have said, to get some important business done. We've got an opportunity to work on some bipartisan initiatives, such as immigration reform, on health care, on some other key issues. And I'm looking forward to the challenge of working with a new Congress.

But I will not change who I am, and I will not change the basic values that have driven my agenda.

Thank you for your question. The Attorney General, Alberto Gonzales, has been a strong supporter and a good friend. I've spoken to him about these matters, and I must express my confidence in him. He is a man of great integrity, and he has done nothing to compromise his leadership or the mission of the Department of Justice.

Now, I acknowledge that mistakes were made, but as you know, I'm the one who's ultimately accountable for the actions of my administration, and I take full responsibility for the mistakes that were made. So, as far as Alberto's future in my Cabinet is concerned, I can assure you that we will work together, we will learn from those mistakes, and we will move forward.

Regarding his effectiveness in Congress, let me tell you that he's a seasoned and skilled administrator, and I'm confident that he can continue to work effectively with Congress. As you noted, the Democrats may have lost confidence in him, but I still believe that he has the support of many Republicans. We will work with Congress to ensure that the Justice Department's mission continues to be accomplished, and we'll do that in a bipartisan manner.

It's also worth noting that I consider Alberto a key member of my team, and I'm not going to abandon him simply because we've faced some setbacks and some criticisms. We've stood together in the face of adversity before, and we'll continue to do so. Thank you for the question. Next?

Well, I appreciate the question, and I'm glad you brought it up. Let me tell you, our goal remains the same, and that is to help the Iraqi people stand up a free government that can defend itself, sustain itself, and deliver services to its people. Now, I know there's been a lot of discussion about the timeline, but the fundamental goal hasn't changed.

Now, I understand that General Petraeus and Ambassador Crocker are working closely with the Iraqi government to assess the situation on the ground. And what's happening is, they're taking a province-by-province approach to hand over security to the Iraqis. It's a conditions-based approach, not a calendar-based approach. In other words, we're not going to hand over security to the Iraqis unless they're ready to take it.

Now, I know there's been some slippage in the timeline, but I'm not deterred. I'm still confident that we can achieve our objectives, and that's to get all 18 provinces turned over to the Iraqis by the time I leave office. But I also want to make it clear that we're going to do this in a way that's going to make sure the Iraqis are prepared to take over.

And let me just say, I'm heartened by the progress we're making in some of the provinces. We've got some good news stories coming out of places like Anbar Province, where the Sunnis are joining the fight against al-Qaeda, and we've got the Coalition forces working closely with the Iraqis to help them stand up their own security forces.

So, while the timeline might have slipped, the goal remains the same, and that's to help the Iraqi people stand up a free government that can defend itself, sustain itself, and deliver services to its people. And I'm confident we can achieve that goal.

Thank you for your question. I think it's essential to acknowledge that the recent elections in Pakistan were a significant step forward for democracy in that country. The people of Pakistan have spoken, and they've made their voices heard through the ballot box.

As for President Musharraf, I believe he's still a vital partner in the global war on terror. He's made significant contributions to our shared efforts in fighting al-Qaeda and the Taliban. I recognize, however, that these recent election results indicate a certain level of dissatisfaction among the Pakistani people with the current government.

As a democracy, the United States respects the will of the people, and it's essential for President Musharraf's government to take the results of these elections into consideration and work towards maintaining stability in the country.

It's too early to speculate about the future of President Musharraf's leadership. What I do know is that the United States will continue to work closely with Pakistan to combat terrorism, and we remain committed to our efforts to support democracy and stability in the region.

I'd like to reiterate that our relationship with Pakistan is not solely tied to President Musharraf; it's with the Pakistani people and the Pakistani government as a whole. We'll continue to work with our allies in Pakistan to assure that our goals of fighting terror, promoting democracy, and supporting regional stability are met.

Thank you, Mark. I appreciate your question. Now, I think it's natural that close friends like Australia and the United States might have some differences in their views on certain issues. That's what makes the world an interesting place, right? But I will tell you this: the foundation of our alliance remains strong.

We've been through tough times before, and we've always come out stronger on the other side. And I'm confident that's what will happen this time. We're going to continue to work together on a wide range of issues where our interests align, from counter-terrorism to non-proliferation, to trade and security in the Asia-Pacific region.

Now, I understand that the new government in Australia has some different views on certain issues, and that's okay. We can respectfully disagree without being disagreeable. And I'm confident that we can find common ground on many of these issues.

Take climate change, for example. We may have different approaches to addressing this issue, but we both agree that it's a serious problem that requires international cooperation to solve. And I'm committed to working with the new Australian government to find common ground on this issue.

So, I don't see the alliance as being in a state of flux or change. I think it's a strong, enduring relationship that can withstand our differences. And I'm committed to working closely with the Australian government to make sure that our alliance remains a cornerstone of stability and security in the Asia-Pacific region. Thank you.

(speaking clearly and firmly) Well, thank you for that question. Let me explain, our approach to dealing with North Korea has been methodical and deliberate. We've worked closely with our international partners, including the United Nations, to bring pressure on the North Korean regime to renounce its pursuit of nuclear ambitions.

Now, we believe that progress is being made, and that this agreement is a significant step forward in that process. Is it perfect? No, but it's a way forward. And let me remind you that we're dealing with a nation that has, as you said, been untrustworthy in the past. However, we believe that the verification mechanisms we're putting in place will help to ensure compliance.

John Bolton, with whom I respect and admire his commitment to non-proliferation, knows that dealing with North Korea requires a measured approach. While I understand his concerns, I believe that this agreement reflects the fact that we must continue to engage with the international community to address the needs and the complexities of the situation.

Selling out to get an agreement? I strongly disagree with that characterization. Our objective remains unchanged: the complete dismantlement of North Korea's nuclear program. This is a step in the right direction.

(pausing for a moment, then smiling) Well, let me tell you, I understand the implication of that question, and I gotta respectfully disagree. What we're doin' here is promoting sound regulatory policy, not payback. We're talkin' about gettin' rid of unnecessary regulations that burden small businesses, that hinder economic growth, and that don't make sense for the American people.

These regulations, many of 'em were proposed without thorough review, without a careful consideration of the impact on our economy. And I believe that by rollin' 'em back, we're actually makin' life better for the American people. We're makin' it easier for 'em to start businesses, to create jobs, to grow our economy.

Now, I know some folks might not agree with our approach, but I'll tell you this: we're committed to protectin' the health and safety of the American people. We just think we can do it in a more effective way, a way that balances regulation with the need for economic growth.

As for what else we plan to repeal, we're gonna take a careful look at all the regulations on the books, and we'll make decisions based on what's good for the American people. We're talkin' about gettin' rid of the ones that don't make sense, that are outdated, or that are duplicative.

But let me be clear: we're not gonna sacrifice the health and safety of the American people on the altar of deregulation. That's just not gonna happen. We're gonna find a balance, and we're gonna make sure that the American people are protected.

(smiling) That's the Bush administration's approach, and I think it's the right one.

I appreciate the question. I think it's a fair question, and I think it's one that I've thought a lot about, and one that I've discussed with our military leaders and with our national security team.

As Commander-in-Chief, my primary concern is the safety of our troops. And I've made it clear to our military commanders that our mission in Iraq is to help the Iraqi government establish security and stability, not to get bogged down in a long-term conflict.

Now, I understand the concerns about Vietnam, and I understand the lessons of history. But I must say that I believe our mission in Iraq is fundamentally different from the mission that existed in Vietnam. Our goal in Iraq is to help the Iraqi government stand up and take control of their own security, and to help them build a democratic government that can protect its own people.

Regarding the role of our military advisers, I am deeply concerned about the safety of our troops, and I've made it clear to our military commanders that they are not to engage in direct combat unless it is absolutely necessary to protect themselves or to complete their mission.

Now, I understand that there are risks involved, and I'm not going to sugarcoat the situation. There are risks involved in sending our military advisers into these chaotic places. But I believe that the risks are worth it, because I believe that our mission in Iraq is critical to the security of the United States and to the security of the world.

And so, to answer your question directly, I am prepared to do what is necessary to complete our mission in Iraq, while always keeping in mind the safety of our troops and the risks involved.

Thank you for your question. First, let me say that we're glad that talks are ongoing, that there's a dialogue between the Koreas, between the United States, China, Japan, and Russia, as part of this six-party talks. It's an important step. However, I reiterate that the position of the United States is that we will not accept a nuclear North Korea. It's not in our nation's interest, or in the interests of our friends in the region, or for the world.

In terms of negotiations, we can assure the North Koreans, as well as other nations around the world, that we are a peaceful nation, that we seek peace in the region, that we want the North Koreans to make a choice: a choice of either continuing down the road of isolation and deprivation, or choosing a different path that will lead to a more prosperous future for their people.

With that in mind, I've made it clear that we'll work with the North Koreans, but they've got to do more than just talk the talk, they've got to walk the walk. They've got to take concrete actions towards dismantling the nuclear program, and we'll verify the dismantlement of that program. So, it's a process that requires verification, and we're working with our allies to make sure that verification takes place.

Now, I know this is a challenging issue, but I believe we can make progress. And I believe, if North Korea chooses to make the right choice, chooses to dismantle the nuclear program, I'm confident that the international community can come together to help North Korea, to help them become a more prosperous nation, but it requires their choosing the right path.

Well, let me start on the first part of your question. I had a very frank discussion with President Putin about my concerns regarding Russia's sale of nuclear technology to Iran. And I'm pleased to report that we've made some progress on this issue, but we still have more work to do.

While I didn't receive a specific commitment from President Putin to stop all nuclear technology sales to Iran, he did acknowledge that the Russian government will be more careful and more transparent in the future regarding the transfer of sensitive technology to countries that could potentially use it for malicious purposes.

Now, as for the second part of your question, President Putin and I did discuss the situation in Iraq, and I think we share a common understanding of the need for Iraq to become a stable, sovereign, and democratic nation.

Regarding Russian contributions, I think President Putin has said that Russia is not going to send troops to Iraq. I respect his decision. What I did ask President Putin, though, was to consider providing other forms of support to the efforts of the multinational force, such as training Iraqi security personnel or helping with reconstruction efforts. And I think we'll continue to have discussions with Russia on how they can best contribute to the overall effort.

You see, we're working together on a lot of issues, and I believe we can find common ground on Iraq. But I do think that Russia can be a valuable partner in the region, particularly when it comes to sharing intelligence, or helping to broker diplomatic efforts, or even contributing financially to reconstruction efforts.

Russia's got a stake in a stable Iraq, just like we do. And I believe that, together, we can make a difference.

I don't view it as a personal slap, I view it as a disappointing decision. I understand that not all countries will agree with our initiative, but I wish more countries would engage in this process. I believe this initiative is in the best interest of the Palestinian people and in the Israeli people. 

I firmly believe that the potential for peace in the Middle East is enormous. And I believe that the more countries that are committed to helping the Palestinian people achieve their dream of a homeland and the Israeli people's desire for security and peace, the more likely we are to achieve this goal.

So, while I'm disappointed that some countries have chosen not to participate, I remain cautiously optimistic that we'll be able to make progress in these talks. And I would hope that these nations would reconsider their decision, because I think it's in the interest of peace that they do so.

Sonny, thank you. It's great to be here in Georgia, and I'm glad you're a native son. I'm glad to have the opportunity to come to this great state and experience the hospitality of the people here. And I must say, it's been a fantastic experience so far.

Now, regarding the logistics and facilities, I gotta give a lot of credit to the people who've worked on this summit. The folks at the Department of State, in particular, have done a fantastic job of making sure that this place is secure, but also making sure it's comfortable for all the world leaders who are here.

I've had a chance to look around, and I've been impressed by the preparations that have been made. The Sea Island family, they've done a great job of getting this venue ready. And I know it's a big undertaking, but I think we've done a great job of making sure that this place is ready for the leaders of the G-8.

Now, in terms of security, I can tell you that we take the security of our guests very seriously. We've got a lot of good folks working on this, from the Secret Service to the local law enforcement, to make sure that everybody's safe. And I think we've done a great job of balancing the need for security with the need to make sure that the leaders can move around and have the conversations they need to have.

So, all in all, I'm very pleased with the way this summit's gone so far. It's been a lot of hard work, but I think it's been worth it.

Thank you for the question. I appreciate it. Yes, we're making progress in the six-party talks. It's a difficult process, but it's an important one. We've got China, Japan, Russia, South Korea, and the United States all sitting at the table with North Korea, and that in itself is a significant development.

Now, I understand that North Korea's continued threats and the growth of their nuclear stockpile are deeply troubling. And I share that concern. But I believe that by working together with our partners in the region, we can bring greater pressure to bear on the North Koreans to dismantle their nuclear program.

Now, I'm not gonna set a specific time limit on the talks, because I think that would be counterproductive. But what I will say is that we expect results, and we expect them soon. We're working closely with our partners to reach a common understanding on what those results should be. And I'm confident that if we stand together, we can achieve our goals.

In terms of the U.N., all options are on the table. I believe that the Security Council can play a vital role in helping to resolve this crisis, and if necessary, we'll go to the U.N. for a resolution. But I want to emphasize that our preference is to resolve this issue through diplomatic means, through the six-party talks.

So, we're gonna keep pushing forward, keep working with our partners, and I'm confident that we can make progress.

Well, I think it's, uh, it's been a challenge, no question about it, to convince people that Iran has a nuclear program, and that's a concern of ours. Now, in terms of intelligence, I think we, as a nation, have to constantly improve our intelligence capabilities, and we've taken steps to do so.

I don't think, however, that the debate about the, the, uh, the, about the intelligence regarding Iraq should, uh, cloud our, our focus on dealing with future threats. In fact, I think it's the opposite. We need to, we need to, uh, use the lessons we've learned to improve our intelligence capabilities, and I'm confident that we are doing that.

In terms of dealing with Iran, we've, uh, made it clear to the, to the world that, uh, that we're concerned about their, uh, nuclear program. We've worked, uh, closely with our allies, like the Europeans, and, uh, taken steps to make, to make it, uh, clear to the Iranians that, uh, we expect them to be transparent and, uh, we'll continue to, uh, pressure them to, uh, to comply with international, uh, obligations.

And I think, uh, on North Korea, we're making progress, working, uh, closely with our allies in the region, particularly the, uh, the South Koreans, and, uh, China, and Russia, and Japan, and we've, uh, made it clear, uh, that, uh, we expect the North Koreans to, uh, to disarm, and, uh, we're working towards a, a peaceful solution to that problem.

So, uh, I don't think that, uh, the, uh, controversy surrounding the intelligence on Iraq has limited our ability to deal with these, these threats.

Thank you for the question. I'm deeply troubled by the incident at Guantanamo, and I want to assure the American people that we're doing everything in our power to ensure the safety and the security of the detainees, as well as the people who work at the facility.

Regarding our image abroad, I believe we've got to be mindful of the perception, but I also believe that the vast majority of the world understands the United States is a compassionate nation, a nation that cares deeply about human rights and human dignity. But I also know that we've got to constantly work to reassure our friends and allies that we're committed to the rule of law and to the principles of justice and fairness.

Now, as for Guantanamo, I understand the concerns, and I understand why some people would want to see the facility closed. But we've got to be very careful about what we do. We've got a tough war on terror on our hands, and we've got to make sure that we're not releasing individuals who might return to the battlefield and cause harm to innocent people.

I've always said that I'd like to see Guantanamo closed, but I'd like to see it closed in a rational and thoughtful way, based on the advice of our military and our intelligence experts. We've got to make sure that if we do close Guantanamo, that we've got a better solution, a solution that ensures the safety and the security of the American people.

So, I understand the concerns, I understand the criticism, but I want to assure the American people that we're doing everything in our power to get it right, to make sure that we're protecting our national security, and at the same time, upholding the principles and the values that we hold dear.

Well, thank you for the question. I appreciate the opportunity to speak on this important issue. First of all, let me reiterate my respect for the Supreme Court and the institution of the judiciary. It's a cornerstone of our democracy, and I believe in the principle of checks and balances.

Now, regarding the recent ruling, I understand the Court's decision, but I don't necessarily agree with it. As President, I have a solemn duty to protect this country and its citizens, and I will continue to take that responsibility seriously.

That being said, I do believe in the importance of being mindful of the limits of my authority as President. I'm a strong believer in the Constitution, and I've always sought to act within its boundaries. However, I also recognize that, in times of crisis and uncertainty, the President must be able to respond effectively and decisively to protect the nation.
