But I will tell you this:  We're committed to helping the Iraqis achieve their objectives.  We're committed to helping them secure their country.  And we're committed to helping them have a peaceful and prosperous future.  We'll continue to work closely with them to help them make the right decisions about how to restore order and security in their country.

Thank you. Good afternoon. I appreciate the question. Our objective in Fallujah is to restore security and order, and to bring hope and opportunity to the Iraqi people. The city of Fallujah has become a safe haven for terrorists, including Abu Musab al-Zarqawi and his associates. These folks are a threat not only to Iraq's stability, but also to American citizens.

Our mission is to clear the city of these terrorists, to disrupt their operations, to bring them to justice. And we believe that by doing so, we will make the city a safer place for the Iraqi people.

The stakes are high, indeed. If we allow Fallujah to become a safe haven for terrorists, it will embolden them to continue their brutal attacks on innocent civilians. And it will undermine the progress we've made in Iraq. On the other hand, if we succeed in restoring order to Fallujah, we will send a clear message to the Iraqi people that we are committed to their security and their freedom.

The elections in January are a critical milestone in Iraq's transition to democracy. And I believe that by taking care of the security situation in Fallujah, we will create a more stable environment for those elections to take place.

I want to thank our men and women in uniform for their bravery and their service. I want to thank our allies for their support. And I want to assure the Iraqi people that we will do everything in our power to help them achieve their dream of a free and peaceful Iraq.

Thank you. Next question.

Well, I think that's a fair question. Now, I'll tell you this: I think Secretary Rumsfeld is a man of great integrity, and he's a man who cares deeply about the families of those who have lost their lives in combat. And I think it's easy to second-guess somebody's decision, and that's what you're doing here.

I've spoken to Secretary Rumsfeld about this issue. He has explained to me why he made the decision he did, and I trust his judgment. And let me tell you, this man has been a great Secretary of Defense. He's helped me make some very tough decisions, and I appreciate his counsel.

Now, I understand that some may be offended by the fact that he didn't sign every condolence letter. But I think you've got to look at the overall picture of what this man's done. He's a dedicated public servant, and I'm proud to have him on my team.

And let me just say this: it's easy to take one mistake, or one decision, and make it seem like it's the only thing that matters. But the truth is, Secretary Rumsfeld has made a lot of good decisions, and I'm grateful for his service.

So, while I understand why you might ask the question, I think we need to look at the bigger picture here, and recognize that Secretary Rumsfeld is a good man who's done a lot of good things for this country.

Well, thank you for your question. As you know, I've been urging Congress to take action on this critical issue, and I believe that we can get a bill done this year. 

In terms of a specific timeline, I've always said that I'd like to see significant progress by the end of the summer, and a bill on my desk by the end of the year. Now, I know that's ambitious, but I believe it's achievable. And I think it's essential that we make meaningful strides on this issue, because every year we delay, the problem gets worse.

Now, regarding the issue of personal accounts, I believe that personal accounts are a crucial part of any comprehensive Social Security reform package. They're a way for workers to own a piece of their own retirement savings, to have more control over their own futures. That being said, I'm willing to discuss and debate different ideas, different approaches.

But I will not support a bill that doesn't address the long-term financial solvency of Social Security. If we don't make changes to the current system, we'll be leaving future generations with a tremendous burden. So, I'm open to talking about different ideas, but I won't support a bill that doesn't address the long-term challenges facing Social Security.

I believe that personal accounts can and should be part of the overall solution, but I'm willing to listen to other ideas, to work with members of Congress, to find a way forward that we can all support. And I'm confident that, together, we can get something done this year.

(pausing for a moment) Well, I appreciate the question. First of all, I'm proud of the fact that the Iraqi people were able to go to the polls and vote for their leaders. It's a remarkable achievement, and it's a testament to the bravery of the Iraqi people.

Now, I know there were a lot of predictions made, before the war, about what would happen after the war. And some of those predictions turned out to be wrong. But I've always been a firm believer that the Iraqi people had the capacity to govern themselves, and that with the right support, they could build a more democratic and more free society.

I think it's premature to say that we've reached the end of the journey, but I do think that the Iraqi people have made significant progress. And as for vindication, I don't really think that's the right word. What I feel is a sense of pride in the fact that we were able to help the Iraqi people achieve this goal. And I also feel a sense of hope that the spread of democracy in the Middle East will lead to a more peaceful and more stable region.

But I'll let history judge whether or not the decisions we made were the right ones. I'm proud of what we've done, and I think that time will tell if we were correct in our assessment of the potential for democracy in Iraq and the region.

(looking around the room) And I'll take another question.

Thank you for that question. I've had several conversations with President Abbas, and I believe he's a man of peace. I believe he sees a different vision for the Palestinian people, one that is hopeful, one that is peaceful. 

Now, I understand your concerns about the Hamas, and I share those concerns. Hamas is a terrorist organization. And, of course, I think it's very important for President Abbas to deal with that group in a way that will show the world that he's committed to fighting terror, that he's committed to peace.

As for what the Palestinian Authority ought to do, in terms of dealing with Hamas, I think it's very important for the Palestinian Authority to dismantle the terrorist organizations. And that includes the infrastructure of Hamas, the leadership of Hamas. It's very important for them to take a strong stand against terror, and I believe they will.

Now, I'm not going to dictate to the Palestinian Authority how they should do their business. But I will continue to encourage, along with our international partners, encourage the Palestinian Authority to take the necessary steps to deal with terrorism, to build a democracy, to become a peaceful partner with Israel.

Thank you. Well, I'd say the White House is focused on doing the people's business. We're moving forward on a bold agenda, and we're not going to let these distractions get in the way of doing what's right for America.

Now, I understand that there are investigations and controversies, and we'll cooperate fully with those investigations. But I've got a job to do, and that's to protect the American people, to strengthen our economy, and to spread freedom around the world.

I'm a strong believer in the concept of a staff, and I've got a fine staff that's capable of handling many tasks at once. We've got a lot of talented people who are focused on the issues that matter most to the American people.

I'd say the nomination of Harriet Miers to the Supreme Court is a great example of that. She's a highly qualified candidate who will make a great justice, and I'm confident that she'll be confirmed by the Senate.

As for the CIA leak investigation, we're cooperating fully with that investigation, and I've instructed my staff to do so. I want to get to the bottom of it, just like the American people do.

And look, I understand that there's going to be criticism, and I can take it. I'm a big boy, I can handle it. The important thing is to stay focused on the tasks at hand and keep moving forward.

So, I'd say the White House is working very effectively, despite the distractions. We're keeping our eyes on the ball, and we're going to get a lot done.

The allegations have been made, and I understand why they've been made. But let me be clear: we're at war, and we must use all constitutional means at our disposal to protect the American people. The accelerated techniques that have been used by our law enforcement and intelligence agencies, including the Terrorist Surveillance Program, are lawful. They are constitutional, and they're necessary.

Now, I've given these authorities a lot of thought. The reason I've given them thought is because I understand we're at war. 9/11 changed the world. The enemy is sworn to attack us, and it's our job to protect the American people. We'll continue to do so.

Now, I'm willing to explain to the Congress, in the appropriate forums, our strategy for protecting the American people, because I believe it's very important that they understand the logic and the reasons why we're doing what we're doing. However, I also want to caution that in public forums, the enemy can gain information about what we're doing. And I'm not going to put the doctrine of our methods out in the public, for these reasons.

We're on the offense in this war. We're on the offense. We're gathering information. We're gathering intelligence. We're using that information and that intelligence to protect the American people, and we're going to continue to do so. And I'm willing to share that with Congress, but I'm not going to share it with the enemy.

As for the independent investigation, I think there are plenty of investigations going on, for starters. We're working with the comptroller general of the United States, and also with the Senate and House leaders to make sure that Congress and the American people understand what we're doing.

Now, if Congress wants to work with us in the oversight capacity, we'll work with them in the oversight capacity. However, I believe we've got plenty of oversight. We've got plenty of congressional committees that are looking into our activities. And I'm confident that the American people, once they understand the logic and the reasoning behind the decisions we've made, will support what we're doing.

Because at the end of the day, the most important duty of the president of the United States is to protect you and your family. And that's what I'm going to continue to do.

Well, I appreciate the question. Let me try to clarify this for you. First of all, I have a lot of confidence in General Casey, he's a fine military leader. And I also have a lot of confidence in Secretary Rumsfeld, he's a good Secretary of Defense.

As for the study, I'm not exactly sure what the report said I haven't personally read it. But I do know that our troops are working hard, both in Iraq and Afghanistan. And I'm proud of the work they're doing.

What I can tell you is that we're constantly assessing our force posture around the world, including in Iraq and Afghanistan. And we will make adjustments as necessary to meet our national security needs.

 Secretary Rumsfeld and General Casey may have slightly different perspectives on our force posture, and that's okay. As Commander-in-Chief, it's my job to consider all the information and make the decisions that are in the best interest of our country.

So, I would say that both Secretary Rumsfeld and General Casey are right in their own way. We're constantly assessing, constantly evaluating, and we'll make the necessary adjustments to make sure our troops have the support they need to complete their mission.

(pausing for a moment) Well, I understand the question, and I appreciate the candor. I believe that as President, I've made some tough decisions, and the decision to liberate the Iraqi people from Saddam Hussein's tyranny was one of them. I still firmly believe that was the right decision, and I'm proud of the progress we've made.

Now, in terms of whether or not the war has affected my ability to provide moral leadership, I'd say this: I'm a President who has taken on some tough challenges, and I've had some tough issues to deal with, but I've always tried to be guided by my principles and my values. And I believe that the American people appreciate that about me.

As for whether or not I've been weakened, I'd say that I'm still standing here as the President of the United States, and I'm still committed to pursuing the policies and the agenda that I believe are in the best interest of the American people. And I'm confident that the American people will continue to support me in that effort.

And I'd also say that I'm a President who's not afraid to take the tough decisions, even if they're unpopular. I've made the case, I've made the decision, and I've proceeded with it, and I think that's what the American people expect from their President.

Now, I know that not everybody's going to agree with me, and that's fine. But I'm proud of what we've accomplished, and I'm proud to be the President of the United States.

Thank you for the question. I'm glad to address this important issue. The reason the world should care about North Korea's pursuit of a long-range missile capability is that it poses a threat to regional and global security. The development of a missile that can reach as far as North America, or our allies in Asia, such as Japan, is a grave concern. It's not just a matter of national security, it's a matter of international stability.

Make no mistake, we take this threat very seriously, and we're working closely with our allies and partners to address it. If North Korea were to go ahead with a test, we would view it as a highly provocative act, and we would respond accordingly.

As for penalties, I think it's clear that the international community would need to take strong action to demonstrate our collective disapproval. This could include economic sanctions, through the United Nations or through bilateral actions, to pressure the regime in Pyongyang to change its behavior.

But let me be clear: we're not looking for confrontation. We're looking for a peaceful resolution to this situation, one that addresses the concerns of all parties involved. And we're willing to work with North Korea to find a way forward that respects its sovereignty, but also respects the security concerns of its neighbors and the international community.

Now, I'd like to turn it over to Chancellor Merkel, to get her perspective on this issue.

(looks over to Chancellor Merkel)

I understand the question, thank you. Let me try to address that. First of all, I want to assure the American people that the federal government is fully committed to helping the people affected by this devastating disaster. The storm was a national emergency, and it required a national response.

Now, it's true that we've provided a significant amount of funding to the affected areas, but that's not a one-time deal. We're committed to providing ongoing support to help these communities rebuild and recover.

Regarding the role of local government, I want to assure you that we're working closely with Mayor Nagin, Governor Blanco, and other local officials to ensure that the resources we're providing are being used effectively. We're not just throwing money at the problem; we're working together to develop a comprehensive plan to rebuild and revitalize these communities.

Now, I will admit that the recovery efforts are not moving as quickly as we would like. Dealing with a disaster of this magnitude is a complex and challenging task. But I want to assure the American people that we're committed to seeing this through, and we're committed to helping the people of Louisiana and Mississippi, and the other affected states, get back on their feet.

So, I'd like to ask for a little patience, and a little understanding, as we work through this difficult process. We're making progress, but we've got a long way to go. And I appreciate your question, and I appreciate the opportunity to provide this update to the American people.

I appreciate the question. First, let me say that I'm troubled by the allegations surrounding Mark Foley. His actions were unacceptable and inexcusable. We expect our elected officials to uphold the highest standards of behavior, and it's clear that Mr. Foley fell short of that standard.

Regarding Speaker Hastert, I believe that his efforts to deal with this situation are admirable. He's taken steps to address the allegations and ensure that the House is taking all necessary actions to protect its Members and staff. Now, I think it's also important to note that these are serious allegations, and we need to let the investigation run its course. We need to get to the bottom of this and find out exactly what happened.

As for Speaker Hastert's credibility and effectiveness, I think he's a fine leader. He's a man of integrity, and I believe he's doing the best he can under difficult circumstances. But ultimately, that's a decision for the Members of the House to make, not for me.

In terms of the midterm elections, I think that the American people are a lot smarter than the speculation would suggest. They can differentiate between the serious work being done in Washington and the sensational coverage of this scandal. I'm confident that the Republican Party will do just fine in the midterms, because we've got a strong agenda, and we're focused on the big issues that matter to the American people.

So, while this is a difficult situation, I think we'll get through it, and I think we'll come out stronger on the other side.

Thank you, and I appreciate the question. I've got a lot of confidence in Alberto Gonzales. He's a good, decent man and a fine Attorney General. He's been a loyal member of my staff, and I've got confidence that he'll continue to be a fine Attorney General. I understand that there's been some controversy, some important questions that need to be answered.

I've met with Alberto Gonzales about these issues, and I've told him to go out and find out the facts, to lay out all the facts, be as open and transparent as possible. And that's what he's done. He's testified before Congress, and I'm sure he'll continue to do so.

As to the timeline, it's up to Alberto Gonzales to make sure that he's got a good understanding, that he's laying out all the facts to Congress. I've made it clear to him that he needs to be as open as possible, to be as transparent as possible, to make sure that the American people have confidence in him.

Now, I know there's been some bumps along the way, but I've got confidence in Alberto's ability to make things right. And I believe that he will be able to continue to serve the American people as a fine Attorney General.

Let me just add one thing: I don't think it's proper for us to jump to conclusions about Alberto's future until all the facts are known. Let's find out what the facts are, and then we'll make judgments based upon those facts.

Thank you for that question. Yes, we've got a lot of work to do, and I'm feeling energized about the remaining months of my presidency. We've made some great progress on a number of fronts, but I'm not satisfied with just checking boxes. I want to see meaningful legislation passed that's going to benefit the American people.

Now, regarding immigration, I'm deeply concerned that it's going to get caught up in politics. I've made it clear that this is a bipartisan issue, and we need to approach it in a comprehensive manner. We've got to secure our borders, and we've got to provide a path to citizenship for those who are here in the shadows. It's a tough issue, but I'm confident that we can get it done.

I've been working closely with members of Congress, and we've made some progress. But as we get closer to the elections, I worry that the rhetoric's going to get hotter and the politics is going to get more intense. I've been in office long enough to know that politics ain't always pretty, but I'm urging both sides to put aside their differences and focus on what's best for the country.

We can't afford to let this issue get stuck in the trenches of politics. We've got to be guided by a sense of what's right and what's fair for the American people. I'm confident that we can get this done, and I'm committed to working day and night to see it through.

Now, I know some folks might say, "Mr. President, you're a lame duck." But I'm here to tell you, I'm not a lame duck. I'm a president who's committed to getting things done, and I'm going to keep pushing hard until my last day in office.

(I pause, taking a deep breath, looking directly at the reporter)

I understand the concerns about the situation in Iraq, and I appreciate your passion. However, I must respectfully disagree with your assessment of the situation. This is not a war of my choosing; it is a war to protect the American people, and our friends and allies, from the threat of terrorism and weapons of mass destruction.

Regarding the role of al-Qaeda in Iraq, I agree that their presence has grown, but that is precisely because of the environment created by Saddam Hussein's regime. Saddam's support for terrorist groups and his efforts to destabilize the region created a situation that drew in extremist elements.

As for bringing in UN peacekeepers, I appreciate the idea of international participation, but it's not simply a matter of bringing in peacekeepers. The security situation on the ground requires a more comprehensive approach. We're working with the Iraqi government, our coalition partners, and the international community to establish stability, build Iraqi security forces, and facilitate economic development.

(leaning forward, firmly)

I will not be swayed by the prospect of negation or hesitation. We have a clear strategy to achieve our objectives, and we will see it through to its conclusion. We will work with the international community to find solutions, but we will not cow to the demands of the media or other critics. I am the Commander-in-Chief of this nation's military, and I will not accept the defeatism and lack of resolve that seems to pervade so much of the critics' thinking.

(folding my arms, surveying the room)

Well, I'll tell you, I'm comfortable with Secretary Ridge's statement. He's a good man, a competent man. He's been working hard to make sure our country's safe. And I appreciate his commitment to the safety and security of our country.

Now, when it comes to the intelligence, I'm constantly being briefed by the, by our intelligence agencies. And they'll tell you that there's a, there's certain intelligence that's, that suggests al-Qaeda would like to attack us again. We know that. And we know that they've had difficulty organizing, but that doesn't mean they, they're not trying.

When it comes to a gut feeling, I can, I'm not, I, I don't think we should be basing our decisions, you know, on gut feelings, I think we should be, you know, trying to gather as much intelligence as we can and acting on that intelligence, in a practical, sober way, with common sense.

But I will tell you, the Patriot Act, the homeland security initiative that I've put in place, has made our country more secure. And we, we'll continue to be on high alert.

Thank you, that's a great question. We understand the concerns of families who are struggling to make ends meet, and high gas prices are affecting their daily lives. In the short term, we've taken steps to increase producción by releasing oil from the Strategic Petroleum Reserve. It's a good way to add some oil into the market and help stabilize the prices. 

We also are very much in favor of an energy bill that encourages conservation, as well as exploration and production. I'm optimistic that the Congress will work with us in a bipartisan fashion to get an energy bill that makes sense and allows us to be less dependent on foreign oil in the long run.

And then, you brought up OPEC. I do agree with Secretary Abraham. The inability of OPEC to increase production is a contributor to the current market tensions, and they bear some of the responsibility for the high prices we're seeing today.

Thank you for that question. I appreciate the opportunity to address this issue. As the President of the United States, I believe it's natural for nations and regions to pursue their own economic interests and ambitions. A stronger, more united European Union can be a positive development for the global economy, and we will certainly welcome the EU's efforts to increase economic cooperation and integration.

Now, I do not view a stronger EU as a threat to the United States. In fact, I believe our two economies are complementary, and we can work together to promote economic growth and stability around the world. The EU is one of our closest allies and trading partners, and we have a deep and abiding relationship based on shared values and interests.

That being said, we do expect the EU to be a strong and responsible global partner. We will continue to engage with the EU on key issues such as trade, security, and counter-terrorism, and we will work to strengthen our bilateral relationships with individual European countries.

As for our engagement in Europe, I can assure you that we will not decrease our commitment to the region. We will continue to work closely with our European allies on a range of issues, including NATO, counter-terrorism, and non-proliferation. Our engagement in Europe is critical to our national security and economic interests, and we will continue to prioritize it.

However, we do hope that the EU will remain committed to the principles of free and fair trade, and that it will not seek to create unnecessary barriers or protectionist policies that could harm our bilateral relationship or the global economy.

Overall, I believe a stronger, more united European Union can be a positive force for global stability and prosperity, and we look forward to working with our European partners to promote our shared interests and values. Thank you.

Thank you, Nick. I appreciate your question. Let me set the record straight. The events of 9/11 changed the world, and it changed our approach to national security. While it's true that we did consider a wide range of options in the aftermath of those attacks, our primary focus was on addressing the threat of terrorism and the organization that perpetrated those heinous acts, al-Qaeda.

Now, I did assign the Secretary of Defense, Don Rumsfeld, to examine the options for dealing with Iraq, as well as other countries that could potentially harbor terrorists. But I want to assure you that our approach was not to rush to war. We spent many months gathering intelligence, building international coalitions, and pursuing diplomatic options.

Let's be clear: our primary goal was to disarm Saddam Hussein's regime and bring him into compliance with the international community. We pursued a number of diplomatic avenues, including working with the United Nations, to achieve that goal.

Now, I understand that Bob Woodward's book presents one interpretation of events, but I can assure you that we explored all options, including diplomatic efforts, to address the threat posed by Saddam's regime. This was not a charade, Nick. This was a serious and considered process to address a real and legitimate threat to our national security.

I hope that helps clarify the record. Next question, please.

That's a very good question. Let me assure the American people that we'll take every precaution necessary to protect human life, innocent human life. We'll work with the international community to make sure that inspectors do have time to leave, that humanitarians, journalists -- people who are there to do good work -- are able to get out of the country.

As for the timing of our military action, we'll take it into consideration, the need to get those people out safely. But make no mistake about it, we will not be intimidated by the threat of a tyrant. We will not be deterred. We will move at a time and a date of our choosing.

I want to remind all of you that we're not just talking about inspectors and journalists. We're talking about a brutal dictator who is holding innocent people hostage. We're talking about a regime that is developing and harboring weapons of mass destruction. We cannot let the risk of inaction outweigh the risk of action.

We will work to minimize the risks to innocent life, but we will not be deterred in our mission to disarm Saddam Hussein and bring him to justice.

Thank you for the question. The relationship between the United States and Russia can be complex, with areas of both cooperation and disagreement. However, I firmly believe that we've made significant strides in building a strong foundation for dialogue and cooperation, particularly in combating terrorism and non-proliferation.

Regarding our differences, it's true that we don't always see eye to eye, but we're working together to acknowledge and address these differences in a constructive manner. I've had productive discussions with President Putin, and I'm encouraged by our shared commitment to tackling global challenges, such as counter-terrorism and non-proliferation.

Now, I'd like to address your second question. Our actions in Iraq have been guided by a deep commitment to freedom, security, and democracy. We'll continue to work closely with the international community, including the United Nations, to promote peace and stability in Iraq.

However, I also believe that the United States must reserve the right to act in its own national security interests. In certain situations, this may mean taking the lead and working unilaterally, or in coalitions of the willing, to protect our citizens and advance our values.

Now, I'm not going to speculate on hypothetical scenarios, but I will say this: our approach to international relations will be based on a commitment to democracy, a commitment to freedom, and a commitment to working with the international community in the pursuit of peace and stability.

We rely on both multilateral and unilateral efforts, because we recognize that we don't live in a one-size-fits-all world. Different situations require different approaches, and as President, I'm committed to taking the necessary steps to protect America's interests and promote our shared values.

Let me just say that we value our relationship with the United Nations and we will continue to work with them in areas of mutual interest.

(clears throat) Thank you for that question. I appreciate the opportunity to address these concerns. First of all, let me say that the critics who say we allowed the 9/11 threat to mature too far are, in hindsight, correct. We did receive intelligence warnings, but we didn't have the luxury of connecting the dots in time. We had a wall of separation between law enforcement and intelligence, and it hindered our ability to share information effectively. We've since taken significant steps to address those shortcomings, and I'm proud of the progress we've made in reforming our intelligence agencies.

Regarding Iraq, I understand that some folks feel we acted too hastily. However, I still firmly believe that the threat posed by Saddam Hussein was real, and the intelligence we had at the time supported that assessment. While the WMDs we feared were not found, we did discover a terror-sponsor state with a regime that was a destabilizing force in the region.

As for the appropriate threat level to justify action in the future, I believe it's essential to consider the new global landscape we're operating in. The 9/11 attacks taught us that our enemies are no longer just states but also non-state actors, like terrorists, who can wreak havoc on our nation.

In the face of such threats, we need to adopt a prudent yet proactive posture. We must be willing to take bold action when the threat is imminent and credible. However, we must also ensure that our actions are carefully calibrated and that we're working with international partners whenever possible.

I'd say that the key threshold for action should be when a threat is "gathering" – that is, when the pieces are coming together to a point where intervention is necessary to prevent a significant loss of life, destabilization of a region, or the emergence of a rogue state. It's not just about "gathering" intelligence; it's about connecting those threads to our overall strategic objectives.

We'll always have to balance the imperative of protecting the American people with the imperative of upholding our values and respecting the sovereignty of other nations. These are not mutually exclusive goals; in fact, they're complimentary. We must continually calibrate and re-examine our threat tolerance to address the ever-changing landscape of the 21st century.

We will continue to work with Congress, the international community, and other stakeholders to ensure that our approach to these complex challenges is as thoughtful, effective, and proportionate as possible.

Well, I appreciate the Prime Minister's willingness to express his views, and I share his desire for Iraq to be a peaceful and stable nation. However, I must respectfully disagree with his assessment that we didn't plan properly for the postwar period in Iraq.

We did have a plan, and it was a plan that was widely debated and discussed within the administration. The State Department, led by Secretary Colin Powell, and our coalition partners, all played a role in developing that plan. The Coalition Provisional Authority, which was established by Ambassador Paul Bremer, was working to establish a stable and democratic Iraq.

However, we did face some unexpected challenges on the ground. The insurgency was more fierce and more determined than we anticipated. We also faced some unforeseen challenges in terms of Iraq's infrastructure and its bureaucracy.

But I would argue that our commitment to Iraq has been strong, and our support for the Iraqi people has been unwavering. We've made significant progress in training and building up the Iraqi security forces, and we're going to continue to support them as they take on more responsibility for their own security.

It's also worth noting that the Prime Minister's comments were not the first time we've heard concerns about our planning and execution in Iraq. We've heard them from members of Congress, from other foreign leaders, and from many of our own citizens. And we take all of these concerns seriously.

But I believe that history will show that our decision to liberate Iraq was the right one, and that our efforts to help the Iraqi people build a new and better future for themselves will be seen as a noble and necessary endeavor.

Well, thank you for the opportunity to clarify the matter. Yesterday, the Vice President was discussing the threat posed by Saddam Hussein and the fact that he's a sponsor of terror. And I believe that Saddam Hussein has ties to a lot of different organizations, including Al Qaida.

Now, let me be clear – we've had a number of authorities and a number of reports that have suggested that there are connections, and I believe that – to my knowledge, the CIA Director, Director Tenet, has met with my team and provided information to us that there's a connection there.

Saddam Hussein and Al Qaida, while their ties may not be always seen, we believe that there's a relationship there, and I think it's very ominous that the possibility of a man like Saddam Hussein, who has a long record of aggressiveness, a desire to obtain and use weapons of mass destruction, could possibly work with a group like Al Qaida, which has a hatred for the United States and its allies and therefore a possibility that they could boot strap one another in different ways.

Now, is the evidence always clear, and all, uh, linking the President of Iraq directly to the – to the acts of terror in the US? We don't have direct evidence of that, but I don't think that necessarily, one has to see something in order to know that there's, that there's some, that there's some very strong connections.

So, while the relationship between Saddam and Al Qaida and the degree, some sensibilities, are sensitive intelligence and I... I expect to see continued statements and and potential evidence emerge that will back the statement that the Vice President made yesterday.

Thank you for your question.  We have been working closely with President Karzai and the Afghan government to address the issues surrounding the detention of Afghan citizens. I am pleased to announce that we have agreed to turn over custody of Afghan detainees to the Afghan government, with the understanding that they will be held to the same standards that we've maintained, that they will be properly interrogated and treated in accordance with international standards.

Regarding the involvement of the Afghan government in U.S. military matters, we have been working closely with President Karzai and his team to ensure that they have a greater role in decision-making processes that affect their country. We recognize that Afghanistan is a sovereign nation, and we want to make sure that the Afghan government has a voice in the decisions that impact their citizens and their country.

And I believe that this is an important step forward in our relationship with Afghanistan, and it reflects our long-term commitment to the Afghan people and the Afghan government.

As for the issue that you raised about the prisoner abuse at Bagram, I did discuss this issue with President Karzai. I assured him that we take allegations of abuse very seriously, and that we will investigate them thoroughly and hold anyone who is found guilty to account. I also assured him that we are committed to upholding the highest standards of human rights, and that we are committed to working closely with the Afghan government to ensure that all detainees are treated with dignity and respect.

President Karzai can speak to the specifics of our conversation, but I think it's fair to say that we both share a commitment to the values of human rights and the rule of law.

Thank you for that question. First, let me reiterate that the United States is deeply concerned about Iran's decision to resume its uranium conversion activities. We believe that this move is a disturbing indication of Iran's intent to pursue a nuclear program, and it's a serious challenge to the international community.

As for the next steps, we're in close consultation with our European allies, as well as with other members of the international community, to consider the best way forward. We're – we're evaluating all options, and we're considering a range of measures to address this situation.

Now, regarding referral to the Security Council, I think it's clear that this is not a decision we'll take lightly. But let me be very clear: we will not rule out any options. If Iran continues to defy the international community, we will work with our partners to pursue a diplomatic solution that includes a referral to the Security Council.

As for sanctions, our view is that they should be targeted, they should be effective, and they should be focused on the Iranian regime's behavior. We believe that the focus should be on changing the behavior of the Iranian government, rather than on harming the Iranian people.

We're considering a range of economic sanctions, including but not limited to, restrictions on Iranian oil exports, as well as on the import and export of dual-use materials. We're also looking at the possibility of financial sanctions, including measures that would restrict Iran's access to the global financial system.

Let me be clear: the United States is committed to working with our partners to resolve this crisis through diplomacy. But we will not stand idly by while Iran pursues a nuclear program that threatens the stability of the region and the security of the world.

Thank you for that question. The situation in Darfur is a grave concern for the United States, and we're deeply troubled by the humanitarian crisis that's unfolding there. I want to assure the American people that we're committed to helping the people of Darfur, and we're working closely with our international partners to bring relief and protection to those who are suffering.

As for leveraging the Sudanese Government, we've already imposed sanctions, and we're working to increase pressure on the regime to comply with the demands of the international community. We're also seeking a U.N. Security Council resolution that would authorize stronger action, including a possible peacekeeping mission.

My message to the Sudanese Government is clear: the world is watching, and we will not stand idly by while innocent civilians are targeted, displaced, and killed. We urge them to allow humanitarian access, to cooperate with international efforts to broker a peace agreement, and to bring an end to the violence.

We're also prepared to take additional measures if the Sudanese Government fails to act. We're considering a range of options, including targeted sanctions against individuals responsible for the atrocities, and support for the African Union's efforts to deploy a peacekeeping force.

But let me be clear: the Sudanese Government has a choice to make. They can choose to cooperate with the international community and work towards a peaceful resolution, or they can face the consequences of their inaction. We will continue to work with our partners to bring pressure to bear on the regime, and we will not give up in our efforts to bring relief and protection to the people of Darfur.

Thank you for your question. Let me assure you that the United States is committed to upholding the principles of human rights and treating detainees in a manner consistent with those principles. I want to say that, as Commander-in-Chief, I have the obligation to protect the American people and our allies, and we do that through a variety of means. I'm not going to discuss specifically what those means are. It's the policy of the United States to comply with our laws and to work with our friends and allies to make sure that we're able to protect our people effectively.

Now, regarding the European Council's report, I'd like to say that we take these allegations very seriously. If there have been any activities that have taken place that are contrary to our laws and our values, we will investigate them. But I'm not going to get into specifics about intelligence activities. The American people would expect their President to do what it takes to protect them, and I will.

As for my meeting with Chancellor Merkel today, we discussed a wide range of issues, including global security, cooperation between our two nations, and our shared values of democracy and freedom. I'm proud to say that we have a strong relationship with Germany and the European Union, and we will continue to work together on these and other issues that are important to both our nations.

Well, I think I can assure the American people that I am resolute. I understand the consequences of terrorism, and I understand the stakes in Iraq. And I will tell you, I don't think about 'it won't end well.' I think about the moment when Iraq becomes a free society, where the people of Iraq are free to make their own decisions, where the free Iraq will be a catalyst for change in the broader Middle East.

And I do have doubts at times. You would be unrealistic if you didn't have doubts, especially with so many lives at stake. But I also rely on the advise of some very capable and dedicated public servants. We've got a really good team of people in the National Security Council who keep close tabs on the events in Iraq. And General Casey and General Abizaid, who are on the ground, provide us with advice.

But I also believe that it's essential to be a steadfast. And I am. I believe we're making progress. And the way to achieve the goal, the strategy is to change the dynamics on the ground. The enemy is using a terror tactic, trying to get us to withdraw. That's their goal. Our goal is to help the Iraqis police themselves; it's to get the Iraqis up to speed to a point where they can defend themselves.

The ultimate victory is not elusive. We will achieve this goal in Iraq, but I will tell you that this is difficult. It's hard. It's in these moments where the End-Time choice must be plan so we can at least hold the pale time Strategic enough from material loads at.

Thank you for your question. I've said it before and I'll say it again: I'm not going to get into the details of the conversations I had with the Attorney General regarding the U.S. attorneys. I will say that I have every confidence in the integrity of Alberto Gonzales. He's a good man, and he's an honest man.

I want to assure the American people that this administration is not going to politicize the justice system. We've got a system in place where the Department of Justice is supposed to make decisions based upon the evidence, and the facts on the ground.

Now, I know there's been a lot of, shall we say, idle speculation about the U.S. attorneys. But I can assure you that I've made it very clear to the Attorney General that the White House has not directed the Department of Justice in terms of who to prosecute and who not to prosecute.

We've got a system in place that says that the Department of Justice is supposed to make decisions based on the facts, not on what the politician wants. And I will assure you that we will continue to uphold those high standards and the American people can have confidence that the Justice Department is acting independently and making decisions based on the evidence.

As for the allegations, we're going to work with the Congress to get to the bottom of it. And I'm confident that once we get all the facts out on the table, people will see that this administration has not politicized the justice system.

Thank you. Next question, please.

Well, I'd say I'm disappointed, is the best way to put it. I'm disappointed in the progress that we haven't made on some key issues, like the Colombia free trade agreement, like renewing the Protect America Act, the FISA update. These are important issues that I think will help us stay ahead in the war on terror, and also strengthen our economy.

And I'm frustrated that we can't seem to get some of these big issues done. But I'm also a realist. I understand that we've got a disagreement, and I'm working to resolve the disagreements.

However, I am hopeful. I'm hopeful that both parties will rise above our differences and take care of business that the American people expect us to take care of. I think that the Democrats would like to work with us on some of these issues, but they're seeing signals from special interests or what have you that are causing them to hesitate.

But I'm the kind of fellow who, when I see obstacles, I try to find a way around them. I'm not going to give up. I'm going to keep pushing the Congress to get results.

Thank you for those questions. First, let me address the issue of domestic energy production. I am confident in the ingenuity and capabilities of American energy producers. They are the safest and most environmentally responsible in the world. We have encouraged them to explore and develop our domestic resources, including those offshore. And I believe they are doing just that.

Now, I do think there's more we could be doing to encourage the development of those resources. That's why I've called on Congress to lift the moratorium on offshore exploration and development. I believe it's a common-sense approach that would allow our producers to access new areas in the Outer Continental Shelf.

Regarding Iraq, we are making good progress with the government of Iraq on a Strategic Framework Agreement, as well as a Status of Forces Agreement. These agreements will allow us to deepen our relationship with the Iraqi people and ensure a peaceful and stable Iraq.

Now, I'll tell you that we're making progress toward completing these agreements, but I'm not going to prejudge the outcome or confirm exactly what the language might say. Our negotiators are working hard to ensure that the agreement reflects the interests of both our countries.

As for whether I would sign an interim agreement, I'll just say that I'm confident we're working towards a successful completion of these talks. And I'm going to leave it to my successor to deal with future agreements, of course. But I will say this: any agreement would have to be one that serves the interests of the United States and the people of Iraq, and ensures a stable and secure future for the Iraqi people.

I appreciate the question. And I must correct a misimpression, that my decision was based on science. It was based on a moral calculation, as well, and a political calculation. I made a decision that I thought was a good compromise.

Now, I do recall our scientific advisors telling us that, while they were uncertain about the viability of these lines, they did believe that there was some potential there. However, it's also true that they told us that there were limitations to these lines, and that they might not be as useful as we had hoped.

In terms of the mixing of human and mouse cells, I don't recall that this was a part of our discussion, but it's a point that's been made subsequently, and I think it's a valid concern.

Now, I want to emphasize that my decision was based on a principle, and that principle was that we ought not to be creating human life for the purpose of experimentation. That's a line that I think was a reasonable line to draw.

It's also important to note, that while the question of the viability of these lines may be an important scientific question, our efforts to advance medical science are not confined to the limitations of these particular cell lines. There are other avenues of research that we can pursue, and that we are pursuing, to advance the cause of medical science.

So, I think the American people can be confident, that we are taking a reasonable approach to the challenge of medical research, one that takes into account both moral and scientific considerations. Thank you.

(pausing for a moment) Well, I think it's a very disturbing issue, and I'm concerned about the allegations that have been made. I believe that the Catholic Church has a responsibility to address this issue in a forthright and transparent manner. I think the American people expect that.

Now, I have met Cardinal Law, and I consider him a friend. But I don't know the specifics of every case, and I don't want to make judgments about individual cases. What I do know is that the Church needs to move quickly to address these allegations, to make sure that the right steps are being taken to protect the children of God, and to hold people accountable for their actions.

It's a tough issue, but I'm confident that the Church will take it seriously and take the necessary steps to correct any wrongdoing. And as President, I'll certainly be watching this situation closely, and I urge the Church leadership to take a strong stance against this kind of behavior. It's unacceptable.

I think I see where you're going with this. You're talking about the Corporate and Auditing Accountability and Responsibility Act, also known as the Corporate Responsibility Bill. I pushed for significant reforms in our corporate governance laws to protect investors and rebuild trust in our markets.

Now, I understand that some folks, including Chairman Pitt, are saying that the budget I proposed may not be sufficient to fully carry out the provisions of this new law. And I appreciate their candor. Let me tell you, I'm committed to making sure we have the resources we need to enforce these new standards and protect American investors.

I believe that the proposals I've put forward are a good start, but I'm also a realist – I know that we may need to revisit the funding level to ensure that we're truly effective in rooting out corporate wrongdoing and holding accountable those who engage in it. So, I'm open to working with Congress to make sure we get it right. The American people deserve nothing less.

Thank you for that question.  We've had some discussions with our Mexican counterparts about, you know, migration, and how to make the border more secure, but we've also talked about migration patterns, and the idea of working towards a comprehensive reform of our immigration system.

And I appreciate President Carter's input on this matter. He's a man of great compassion and experience, and I respect his views. As for amnesty, I believe it's an idea worth considering, but it's not that simple. We have to make sure that any solution we come up with is fair, that it's humane, and that it upholds the law.

I've said before that I believe we need a comprehensive immigration reform that includes tightening our borders, cracking down on employers who hire undocumented workers, and providing a pathway to citizenship for those who are already here, working hard, paying taxes, and contributing to our society.

Now, I know there's a lot of different opinions on this issue, and we're going to continue to have a healthy debate about it. But I'm willing to work with Congress, with our Mexican counterparts, and with other stakeholders to find a solution that's in the best interest of America and in the best interest of our relationship with Mexico.

And I'll tell you this: we're not just going to focus on the presence of these workers; we're also going to focus on the conditions that drive them to leave their homes in the first place. We're going to work with Mexico to strengthen their economy, to provide more opportunities for their citizens, so they don't feel like they have to come to the United States to find work.

So, that's where we are, and we'll continue to work on this issue and see where we can find common ground.

Thank you, sir. Poland is a great friend and ally, and we appreciate the strong relationship we've developed with the Polish people. As I said earlier, Poland has been a leader in the region, and its contributions to the global war on terror and its efforts to promote democracy and stability in places like Bosnia and Kosovo are truly commendable.

Regarding Poland's role in Central and Eastern Europe, I believe this nation is poised to play a vital part in this region's economic and security development. As a proud member of NATO, Poland's participation in the alliance is a testament to its commitment to peace and stability. We're also working closely with Poland to strengthen its borders, particularly with regard to issues like energy security and counter-terrorism efforts.

As we move forward in this region, Poland will continue to be a crucial partner in our efforts to promote democratic values and economic cooperation. We're exploring ways to deepen our bilateral relationship with Poland, including through the proposed U.S.-Poland free trade agreement. This agreement will not only boost economic growth but also solidify our strong alliance.

Specifically, we believe Poland's unique position between Eastern and Western Europe gives it a critical role in bridging the gaps between the United States and Russia. Poland and Russia have a long and complex history, and we understand that improving relations between the two nations will take time. However, we encourage both countries to engage in constructive dialogue and to cooperate in areas like economy, education, and counter-terrorism.

We appreciate Poland's commitment to a unified and democratic Europe, and we're confident that its continued leadership will help drive progress in the region.

Well, thank you for the question. I'm lookin' forward to my trip to Europe, and I'm excited to meet with our friends and allies to discuss the situation in Iraq. Now, I understand that there's a sense of, uh, frustration and concern among the European public, and I understand that.

But let me be clear: we're makin' progress in Iraq. The Iraqi people have just held successful elections, and they're beginnin' to take control of their country. We're also makin' progress on the security front, with the Iraqi security forces gettin' stronger every day.

Now, as for our role in Iraq, I believe it's essential that we continue to provide support to the Iraqi government, especially in terms of security and military training. We've got a solemn obligation to help the Iraqi people protect themselves against the terrorists and insurgents who are tryin' to undermine their democracy.

But I also understand that the Iraqis want more control over their own country, and we're workin' with 'em to transfer responsibility to them as quickly as possible. We're trainin' their military, we're helpin' 'em build up their government, and we're graduatin' responsibility to 'em as we make progress.

Now, I'm open to discussin' with our European allies how we can work together to support the Iraqi government and the Iraqi people. But I'm not gonna tie the hands of our military commanders on the ground. They need to have the flexibility to respond to the changin' circumstances on the ground.

So, I'm lookin' forward to some good discussions with our European friends, but I'm also gonna make it clear that we've got a strategy for success in Iraq, and we're gonna stay the course.

Thank you for the question. I appreciate your interest in this matter. First, let me just say that I'm disappointed that we weren't able to get the intelligence reform bill through. I think it's a crucial piece of legislation, and I think it's essential for the safety and security of the American people.

Regarding Secretary Rumsfeld's involvement, I think it's unfair to say that he's partly responsible for the bill's failure. The Secretary has been a strong supporter of intelligence reform, and he's worked hard to help us pass this bill. Now, I know there were some disagreements, particularly with regard to new intelligence oversight mechanisms and the Pentagon's role, but that's just the way the legislative process works.

As for me, personally, I think I did everything I could to help pass this bill. I met with Congressional leaders, I spoke to members of both parties, and I made it clear how important this legislation was to me and to the country. Now, I'm the first to admit that I'm not a legislator, I'm the President, and sometimes that means you've got to rely on other people to get the job done.

And as for my ability to achieve my legislative agenda over the next two years, I'm not worried. I've got a strong track record of getting things done, and I'm confident that we'll be able to work with Congress to pass other important legislation, whether it's on Social Security reform, or tort reform, or any of the other issues that are important to the American people.

But I will say this: I'm not going to give up on intelligence reform. We're going to keep pushing, we're going to keep working, and we're going to get this done. Because I believe it's essential for the security of our country, and I believe it's essential for the confidence of the American people. Thank you.

Good day, Mr. Shanahan. I appreciate the opportunity to address that question. As you know, our coalition, including the Australians, has made significant progress in both Iraq and Afghanistan. However, the fight against terrorism and the establishment of stable democracies in these countries will undoubtedly take time. 

I must give credit to the bravery and dedication of the Australian troops, who have worked tirelessly alongside our forces to put pressure on the insurgency. While it's difficult to predict an exact timeline, I do believe that our continued cooperation will lead to a more secure environment in the region.

In terms of a timeline, I'm not willing to give the enemy a specific date for withdrawal. That would only play into their hands. What I can say, however, is that our commitment to the people of Iraq and Afghanistan will continue until we've accomplished our goals.

We'll continue to work closely with the Iraqi government to build their capacity to secure their own country, and with the government of Afghanistan to bring stability to their nation. It's also worth noting that Australia has been a vital partner in our efforts to train Iraqi security forces, and their efforts have been invaluable.

Prime Minister Howard and I will continue to work together to adjust our strategy as necessary, and we will also be guided by the conditions on the ground. We're making progress, and I believe that one day, we'll be able to stand down our troops in Iraq and Afghanistan, knowing that we've left behind countries that are more stable and more secure. But for now, I think it's fair to say that we'll be committed to this effort for some time to come.

Thank you for that question. I understand the concerns about the cost of this recovery effort, and I appreciate the vigilance of the American people when it comes to the nation's finances.

Let me be clear: the devastation caused by Hurricane Katrina is a national emergency, and it requires a national response. We're not just talking about rebuilding homes and infrastructure; we're talking about saving lives, supporting our fellow citizens, and ensuring the economic stability of our nation.

Now, as for the cost, I believe it's a necessary investment in the future of our country. We're not going to nickel and dime our response to this disaster. We're going to do what it takes to get the job done, and then we'll work together with Congress to figure out how to pay for it.

As for the national debt, I understand that it's a concern. But let me remind you that during times of war and national emergency, it's not uncommon for the country to take on additional debt. What's important is that we're transparency and accountability in our spending, and that we work towards a balanced budget over the long term.

We'll work with Congress to pass a supplemental appropriations bill to provide the necessary funds for this relief effort. And we'll work to identify cost-savings and budget adjustments to offset the costs of this effort. We'll also be looking at proposals to reform the tax code and make it more efficient, as well as supporting the growth of the economy, which will help to generate revenue to cover some of these costs.

So, to answer your question, it's going to take a collective effort – both from the federal government, the states, and the private sector – to pay for this recovery. And we'll work together to ensure that it's done in a responsible and fiscally sound manner.

Thank you for that question. I think one of the most important things we can do is to isolate the Hizballah fighters in Lebanon. And that's why I'm working closely with the international community to apply diplomatic pressure on Syria, who's a main sponsor of Hizballah, and to press the Lebanese government to assert its authority and control over its own borders and its own territory.

I also believe that we need to support the people of Lebanon, who are being held hostage by Hizballah's actions. We need to support their efforts to rebuild their country, and we need to help them strengthen their government so they can deal with the internal security threats. 

And I also believe that we need to make it clear to the leaders of Hizballah, as well as to their sponsors in Iran and Syria, that they will be held accountable for their actions. We'll be working with the international community to further isolate Hizballah and its sponsors, and to ensure that they're held accountable for their actions.

This is a difficult situation, but I am confident that with a concerted effort, with a clear and consistent message, and with support from the international community, we can get Hizballah to accept a ceasefire, to release the Israeli prisoners, and to disarm, as demanded by United Nations Security Council Resolution 1559.

Israel has the right to defend itself, and it is going to exercise that right. But our strategy is not just to support Israel, it's also to bring peace to the region. We're working to create a situation in which all countries, all parties, can feel secure, and where the people can live in peace.

Thank you for that question. The anniversary of Hurricane Katrina is a somber reminder of the devastating impact that storm had on the people of Louisiana, particularly in New Orleans. We've made a commitment to the people of the Gulf Coast to help them rebuild their lives and their communities.

Over the past year, we've taken some significant steps. First, we've made a major investment in the levee system. We've committed over $7 billion to repairing and upgrading the levees in New Orleans, to make sure that they're safe and secure. We've also taken steps to improve the Army Corps of Engineers' ability to respond to future disasters.

We've also made significant progress on housing. We've demolished over 25,000 homes that were severely damaged, and we've made funds available to help families rebuild or get back into their homes. We've also made over $11 billion available to the state of Louisiana and other affected areas to help rebuild their infrastructure and their communities.

But I'll be the first to tell you that there's still a lot of work to be done. We've got to continue to work with the state and local governments to make sure that the recovery efforts are effective and that the needs of the people are being met.

We've also got to continue to address the issue of affordable housing. We've made some progress on this front, but it's still a challenge, particularly in New Orleans.

And we've got to continue to support the economy. The Gulf Coast was hit hard by this storm, and we've got to make sure that we're doing everything we can to support the local businesses and to encourage investment in the region.

So, while we've made some progress, I'll be the first to tell you that we've still got a lot of work ahead of us. And we're committed to seeing this through and making sure that the people of the Gulf Coast get the support they need to rebuild their lives.

Thank you for your question. First of all, let me just say, Jim Baker is a good friend of mine, and I respect his opinion, but I must respectfully disagree with him on this point. Iran is a country that is pursuing a nuclear weapon, and that's unacceptable to the United States of America.

As for working with them, we have made it clear that we are willing to talk to the Iranians, but we're not going to do it in a way that is going to legitimize their pursuit of a nuclear weapon. And I'm also mindful that the Iranian government has been a destabilizing force in the region, and we're not going to reward that kind of behavior.

Now, when it comes to Iraq, I will pursue any avenue that will help us succeed in Iraq, and if that means talking to the right people, including Iran, about how to help stabilize the region, that's something we'll consider. But what I'm not going to do is I'm not going to compromise our principles, I'm not going to compromise our values, and I'm not going to compromise our national security.

And let me just say, it's interesting that Iran would talk to us about Iraq when they're not even willing to come to the table to discuss their own pursuit of a nuclear weapon. That just doesn't seem like a credible or serious approach to me.

Well, thank you for that question. I appreciate the opportunity to address the points you've raised. First, let me make it clear: we have made significant progress in Iraq since the invasion. The removal of Saddam Hussein and the establishment of a democratically-elected government are major achievements.

However, I do acknowledge that the situation in Iraq is more complex and challenging than we anticipated. The insurgency has proven to be a formidable foe, and the sectarian violence has caused significant instability. That's why we're working closely with the Iraqi government to develop a comprehensive strategy to address these issues.

Regarding the Baker-Hamilton report, I've had a chance to review the recommendations, and while I appreciate the efforts of the commission, I disagree with some of the conclusions. Specifically, I do not believe that direct engagement with Syria and Iran at this time would be productive. Those countries have shown no willingness to support our efforts to bring stability to the region, and we cannot afford to give them a veto over our policies.

As for the recommendation to withdraw combat troops by 2008, I believe it's premature to set a specific timeline for withdrawal. We need to be guided by conditions on the ground, not by artificial deadlines. Our military commanders will continue to assess the situation and make recommendations to me based on the security needs of Iraq.

Make no mistake, we are committed to supporting the Iraqi government and people, and we will do what's necessary to help them achieve stability and security. But we will not be dictated to by a specific timeline or by the machinations of our adversaries. We will act in the best interests of the United States and our allies.

Well, first of all, I've had good conversations with President Musharraf. He's a man who has given his word that he's committed to fighting extremism and terrorism, just like we are. And I believe him. He understands the threat that we all face, and he's committed to helping us deal with it.

Now, I've also made it abundantly clear to the President that we expect him to honor the commitments that he's made, and that includes, of course, restoring democracy in Pakistan. I'm a strong believer in democracy, and I'm a strong believer in President Musharraf's ability to lead a democratic Pakistan.

Now, regarding the, the distractions in Pakistan, and their impact on Afghanistan... well, I'm concerned about the situation in Pakistan. But I also have confidence in the leadership of the Pakistani military, as well as the leadership of the Pakistani intelligence services, to stay focused on the threat. And, of course, we're working closely with our Pakistani counterparts to help them deal with the threat.

Let me just make one thing very clear: The United States is committed to helping Pakistan defeat the Taliban and al-Qaeda, not just for Pakistan's sake, but for our own security. And I'm confident that we can work together to achieve that goal.

And secondly, regarding Secretary Gates's comments, I think they were appropriate. He's simply stating the obvious, that the more attention, the more resources the Pakistanis have to devote to their internal problems, the less attention and resources they may have to devote to some of their external security challenges, including, of course, the ones they face along their border with Afghanistan.

But I think we can work through this. I think we can work closely with the Pakistanis to address their internal challenges and also ensure that they stay focused on the threat posed by extremists and terrorists. And that's exactly what we'll do.

Thank you for that question. We are, of course, closely monitoring the situation on the ground in northern Iraq. Our message to the Turkish government has been clear: we understand their concerns about the PKK, a terrorist organization that they have to deal with, but they need to be mindful of the impact of their actions on the region as a whole.

As for the duration of the operation, we would like to see it brought to a close as quickly as possible. We're urging Turkey to work with the Iraqi government to address their concerns about the PKK in a way that minimizes the disruption to the region. We're committed to helping to support Iraq's sovereignty and territorial integrity.

Regarding the potential for further destabilization, that's a concern that we have. A protracted presence in northern Iraq could indeed have unpredictable consequences, and we're worried about the impact on the region as a whole. We're in close communication with both the Turkish government and the Iraqi government, urging them to work together to resolve the issue as quickly as possible.

Now, I want to emphasize that our relationship with Turkey is very important, it's a strategic relationship, and we value our friendship with the Turkish people. At the same time, we also have a strong commitment to the people of Iraq, and we're working hard to help them build a stable, secure, and prosperous future.

Thank you for that question. I understand the concerns that some of the Democrats have expressed, but I must tell you, the safety and security of the American people is my utmost concern. And I believe that the FISA legislation we've proposed is necessary to protect our citizens from the threat of terrorism.

You know what, to answer your original question - and I think I can answer it more concisely now - if I knew what I knew today, and I had the chance to do it over, I probably would have gotten more troops on the ground faster in Baghdad, because I think we let a vacuum develop that certainly led to violence and endangering circumstances for the Iraqi people and our troops on the ground.

Thank you for the question. I want to assure the American people that I have full confidence in the Department of Justice and their ability to conduct a fair and impartial investigation into the CIA leak. I've been assured by the Attorney General that this investigation will follow the evidence wherever it leads, and I have no reason to believe otherwise.

As for any potential wrongdoing by my staffers, I've made it clear that if anyone in my administration is found to have broken the law, they will be held accountable. I expect all members of my team to uphold the highest standards of ethics and integrity, and I will not tolerate any behavior that falls short of those standards.

Regarding the criticism that our administration retaliates against those who disagree with us, I'd like to say that that's simply not true. We are committed to an open and honest discussion with the American people, and we value dissenting voices. While we may disagree with those who disagree with us, we respect their right to express their opinions.

However, I will say that when an individual is found to have leaked classified information, which puts our national security at risk, that's a serious matter. It's not about retaliation; it's about accountability and the rule of law. We will take all necessary steps to protect our national security and uphold the law.

We'll see how the investigation unfolds, and I'm confident that justice will be served. I believe in the system, and I believe that the American people will be satisfied with the outcome.

Thank you for that question. Our first priority is to gather as much information as we can from Saddam Hussein. He's a valuable source of intelligence, and we want to make sure we use this opportunity to learn everything we can about the security threats still facing our country and the Iraqi people.

Regarding his future, we're currently discussing with the Iraqi government and the international community what would be the best course of action. It's likely that Saddam Hussein will be turned over for trial, but it's up to the Iraqi people to decide how to bring him to justice. We want to support the new Iraqi government in its efforts to provide stability, security, and accountability.

As for the question of execution, I think it's fair to say that the punishment has got to be a response to the severity of the crimes, and we have tragically gained a lot of information about what this man was capable of in terms of the mass executions and the discovery of the graves. But it's up to the Iraqi people to decide what will be the proper punishment, and we will support them in their decision.

"Well, I appreciate the question. The situation in Northern Ireland is indeed a very important issue, and I want to commend President Clinton for his efforts in helping to bring about the Good Friday Agreement. That was a significant achievement, and we're going to continue to support the process.

As for where it sits on my list of priorities, I'd say it's very high. We believe that the progress that's been made in Northern Ireland can serve as a model for other conflict resolution efforts around the world, including the Middle East. The fact that former enemies can come together, talk, and work towards a common goal is a powerful lesson.

Now, I know the Middle East is a very, very difficult situation, with deep-seated issues and emotions. But I believe that the principles of diplomacy, dialogue, and mutual respect that drove the Northern Ireland process can be applied elsewhere. So, while the specifics may be different, the idea that you can bring people together to work towards peace is something that we'll continue to push for.

We're committed to supporting the people of Northern Ireland as they move forward, and we're going to be actively engaged in helping to find a peaceful resolution to the conflicts in the Middle East. It's a tough road ahead, but I'm optimistic that, with persistence and dedication, we can make progress."

Well, thank you for the question. I appreciate it. Let me tell you, I believe in the universal values of democracy. I believe that freedom, human rights, the rule of law, and transparency are fundamental to a functioning democracy. And those values aren't just American values, they're universal values that apply to every human being.

Now, I know that every country has its own unique history, its own unique culture, and its own unique circumstances. And I'm not naive enough to think that every country is going to adopt our system, the American system, lock, stock, and barrel. But I do believe that there are certain fundamental principles that should apply to every country, regardless of its history, culture, or circumstances.

The idea that there's no standard for democracy is, I think, a flawed idea. I think that's the kind of relativism that can lead to a watering down of the values that we hold dear. And I'm not willing to accept that. I believe that we should strive for the highest standards, the highest ideals, when it comes to democracy.

Now, that doesn't mean that every country is going to get there in the same way or at the same time. But I do believe that we should be pushing, that we should be encouraging, that we should be helping countries to move towards those universal values of democracy.

And I think that's exactly what we're doing, whether it's in the Middle East, whether it's in Eastern Europe, or whether it's in other parts of the world. We're working with countries to help them build strong, stable, democratic institutions that will serve the needs of their people.

So, to answer your question, I don't think that standards for democracy should be flexible. I think that we should be pushing for the highest standards, and I think that's what the American people expect us to do.
