Well, thank you for the question. Let me be clear: the United States does not condone torture. We abhor torture. We would never condone the use of torture. The values of our nation, the values of our troops, the values of our CIA agents are such that interrogation techniques used will be humane and will comply with U.S. law and our international obligations, including Common Article 3 of the Geneva Conventions.

Regarding the issue of access to the Red Cross, I can say that we will be working with our international partners to ensure that the International Committee of the Red Cross is able to perform its mission, and that includes access to all detainees.

As for the concerns raised by the Vice President regarding the CIA's exemption from certain legislation, let me be clear that we must ensure our intelligence community has the tools it needs to protect this nation, and that includes being able to effectively interrogate those who would do us harm. However, I will reiterate that any interrogation techniques employed by any U.S. agency, including the CIA, will always be in compliance with U.S. law and international obligations.

Now, I want to emphasize that the United States stands strongly against torture and cruel, inhumane, and degrading treatment. We do not condone it, we will not tolerate it, and our interrogations will always be humane and in compliance with U.S. law and our international obligations.

Thank you for your question. I'm glad to take a moment to address this important issue. As you know, the Western Hemisphere Travel Initiative is a vital part of our efforts to secure our borders and protect our citizens from the threat of terrorism.

In essence, the initiative requires that by the end of 2006, travelers between Canada and the United States will need to present a passport or other secure documents, such as a passport card or an enhanced driver's license, to enter the United States by land or sea. This is an effort to standardize and strengthen the documentation requirements for crossing our shared border.

No this isn't the first time both countries have worked on more standardized and secure crossings have happened as the two nations have in the past teamed up on things like a trusted traveler program known as NEXUS.

As for the potential economic impact, I want to emphasize that this initiative is not intended to impede the flow of legitimate travel and trade between our two great nations. We value our relationship with Canada and recognize the importance of our economic partnership. In fact, we believe that a more secure and efficient border will ultimately benefit both our countries by facilitating the movement of people and goods.

However, if Canada does not meet the deadline, it could lead to delays and disruptions at our border crossings, which could have negative economic consequences. It's in the interest of both our countries to work together to implement this initiative in a way that minimizes disruptions and supports our shared goal of enhancing security while facilitating legitimate travel and trade.

We're working closely with our Canadian partners to ensure a smooth transition and to address any concerns they may have. We're also committed to providing ample notice and education to travelers about the new requirements, so that everyone can be prepared.

In the end, we believe that this initiative will make our borders more secure, while also supporting the strong economic ties between our two nations. Thank you.

You know, I think we've made some progress on this issue. I've had a chance to speak to President Putin, and I think we're on the same page when it comes to trying to convince Saddam Hussein to disarm. But I understand the skepticism about past behavior. He's let the world down before.

In terms of tactics, I think the most important thing is to work closely with our friends and allies to show that we're willing to contemplate the use of force if necessary, but also that we're interested in exhausting all diplomatic options first. It's a delicate balance, I know. But I believe that's the right approach.

Now, as for Russia, I've had some frank discussions with President Putin on this issue, and I think we'll work to try to persuade them of the merits of a strong resolution. But I think we can agree to disagree in a way that doesn't damage our overall relationship.

Thank you for the question. Let me make one thing very clear: our offer to the Iranians is based on the principle that they must suspend their uranium enrichment activities, and we expect a serious and timely response from them. 

If they're saying they'll get back to us in late August, that's a pretty casual response, with all due respect. We've been waiting for answers for a long time, and we believe it's time for them to get serious.

Now, as for negotiations before a final answer, we're willing to listen to what they have to say, but we're not willing to negotiate while the enrichment continues. We believe that's a contradictory message, and it's not how you build trust.

We're serious about a diplomatic solution, but the Iranians have to be serious about it, too. We can't have it both ways. They can't be enriching uranium and claiming they're willing to negotiate. The two messages don't match.

We're still hopeful that they'll change their behavior and choose a path of cooperation. But if they don't, we'll be left with no choice but to consider other options.

Thank you for the question. I want to thank Secretary Rice for her excellent work on this issue. The United States is committed to a peaceful and stable outcome in the Middle East, and particularly in Lebanon.

Regarding the resolution, I want to make it clear that we believe it's a good resolution. It's a resolution that calls for an end to the violence, a call for a ceasefire, and a framework for moving forward. We're working with our international partners to make sure that this resolution is implemented in a way that brings stability to the region.

Now, regarding the specific point you raised about the withdrawal of Israeli troops, I think it's a topic that's open to discussion. However, we must also consider the concerns of Israel, particularly when it comes to her security. The withdrawal of Israeli troops must be done in a way that ensures that there is no vacuum created that would allow for Hizballah or other extremist groups to exploit.

As for Secretary Rice's contact with Speaker Berri, I think it's safe to say that we'll be in communication with all parties involved to find a resolution to this conflict. Secretary Rice has been in contact with a wide range of leaders in the region, and I'm sure she'll continue to be in contact with Speaker Berri and others to find a way forward.

But I want to emphasize that we must not give in to the demands of Hizballah, which is a terrorist organization. We must find a solution that's rooted in the principles of peace, stability, and democracy. And that's what we're working towards.

Thank you for the question. I appreciate the opportunity to address this issue. I would say that our relationship with the United Nations is one of cooperation and mutual respect, but also of disagreements. We have worked closely with the UN on many important issues, such as fighting terrorism, promoting democracy, and providing aid to those in need.

However, we have had disagreements on certain matters, such as the handling of some peacekeeping operations and the role of the International Criminal Court. And, as you mentioned, Secretary-General Annan has expressed some concerns about our policies in Afghanistan.

Let me be clear: we value the contributions of the United Nations and the leadership of Secretary-General Annan. We believe that a strong and effective UN is essential for maintaining international peace and security.

But we also believe that the UN must be willing to adapt and reform to meet the challenges of the 21st century. And, at times, this requires us to take steps that may not be universally agreed upon.

Now, when I go to the UN next week, I will be speaking to a global audience about the need for collective action on some of the world's most pressing challenges, including terrorism, poverty, and the spread of WMDs. And I look forward to working with Secretary-General Annan and other world leaders to build a more peaceful, prosperous, and secure world.

But make no mistake, as the President of the United States, I will not hesitate to defend our nation's interests, our values, and our principles. We are a sovereign nation, and we will not be shy about advancing our own agenda on the world stage.

[Smiling] Well, I appreciate the question, and I appreciate the... [pauses for laughter] ...amusement in the room. As the President of the United States, I've got a lot of confidence in the Republican Party, and I've got a lot of confidence in our candidates. And I believe that we will hold the House and the Senate.

Now, I understand that there's an election pending, and I understand that people are trying to parse every word that I say. But I will tell you this: I believe in the agenda that we've put forth, and I believe that the candidates who are running on the Republican ticket are running on that agenda. And I think the American people will see the wisdom of our policy and will support our candidates.

As for whether or not I'm resentful that some candidates are perhaps distancing themselves... [pauses for a moment] Look, I'm the President of the United States, and I'm proud of the work that we've done. I'm proud of the policies that we've implemented. And I believe that, in the long run, those policies are going to be vindicated.

Now, I understand that... [pauses, smiling] ...sometimes people like to create a little distance between me and their own campaign. But I'm comfortable with that. I'm not a candidate for anything. I'm the President of the United States, and I'm going to keep working hard for the American people, regardless of what the candidates do.

That's a good question. I'd like to remind everyone that we've had our differences, yes, but I also want to emphasize that I'm a firm believer in the power of diplomacy. However, in this case, I believe it's essential to consider the context of Iran's current behavior and leadership.

While it's true that past Presidents engaged in face-to-face talks with the Soviet Union, those were often conducted within a framework of established diplomatic channels, reciprocal concessions, and clear goals for the negotiations. Furthermore, the Soviet Union's malevolent actions were largely aimed at containment and expansion within the sphere of the Cold War.

In Iran's case, we have a nation that sponsors terrorism, defies the international community on the nuclear issue, and mistreats its own citizens. These actions pose a direct and unpredictable threat to our allies, partners, and ultimately, to the United States itself.

I will reiterate that we're willing to engage in diplomatic talks, but it has to be done in a manner that does not legitimize bad behavior, that does not obscure the gravity of this threat, and that advances the United States' national security interests. What we cannot afford to do is participate in empty symbolic gestures without the genuine prospect of meaningful concessions from the other side.

I'd be open to direct diplomacy with the Iranian leadership if there is some sort of convincing evidence, or promise, of a fundamental shift in their posture and a willingness to abandon their supreme goal of obtaining nuclear capabilities.

Good morning. Thank you for the question. Let me start by saying that we've been engaged in a process with the Chinese government, urging them to reform their currency policies, and to let the market play a greater role in determining the value of their currency.

We believe that China's currency is undervalued, and that's a concern for us, as it can create an uneven playing field for American businesses and American workers. We've talked to the Chinese about this, and they've taken some steps, but more needs to be done.

I announced in Singapore, at the APEC meeting, that we want to work with the Chinese to find a solution to this issue. We're going to stay on it, we're going to urge the Chinese to move forward. We want to avoid protectionism, and we want to find a solution that's good for both our countries.

Now, I think it's still too early to talk about specifics, such as tariffs or duties. We're going to work with the Chinese, and we're going to use all the diplomatic tools at our disposal to get a result that's fair and that's good for the American people.

We're for free trade, we're for open markets, but we're also for fairness. And we're going to work to make sure that the Chinese understand that this is not a partisan issue in the United States; it's an issue that affects our workers, our businesses, and our economy.

Thank you for the question. I want to make it clear that the NIE, this National Intelligence Estimate, confirms that Iran is still a threat. The fact that they've halted the program in 2003, that's an important piece of information, but it also says they have the capacity to start it up again.

And one of the central points I want to emphasize is that our policy is this: we want a policy of carrots and sticks, with the international community, to address the issue of whether or not they're going to continue to work on a nuclear program. In other words, we want them to verifiably suspend their enrichment activities.

Now, in terms of the military option, all options are on the table. I have always said that, and I will say it again. I would like to resolve this peacefully and diplomatically, with the help of our partners and allies, and I think we can make some progress in that regard.

But the American people need to know that we're committed to a strategy that will secure our nation, protect our allies and paces in that region, like Israel, and we're going to continue to work this issue extremely hard.

So, the NIE has confirmed some suspicions we had about the program, but it also indicates that they're a threat and that we need to deal with that threat.

It's an evolving situation. We're dealing with a sophisticated and capable adversary, and we'll continue, with our friends and neighbors, to address it.

Well, thank you for your question. I want to assure the American people that I have always acted in accordance with the law and the Constitution. As for the CIA interrogation tapes, I'm not going to comment further on the specific details of that issue, as it's currently being investigated by the Department of Justice and the Senate Intelligence Committee. 

I have been briefed on the general matter, but I don't want my comments to in any way prejudice the outcome of their investigation. I'm confident that we will get to the bottom of this matter, and that when we do, the facts will demonstrate that we have acted in a way that is consistent with the principles and the laws of our great nation.

With regard to the tapes themselves, I can tell you that I'm confident that the CIA has made decisions that they believe are in the best interests of our national security. As Commander-in-Chief, I rely on the advice and counsel of our senior intelligence officials, and I expect them to make the decisions they think are in the best interests of the United States.

Thank you for your question. I appreciate the opportunity to address this issue. As the President of the United States, I believe that leadership is not about simply following the crowd or consensus, but about making tough decisions and standing by your principles.

Now, I know some folks might label our approach as "unilateralist," but I see it as leadership. When we take on tough challenges, such as confronting Saddam Hussein in Iraq or pushing for free trade agreements, we're not always going to have everyone on our side. But that doesn't mean we shouldn't take the lead and push for what we believe in.

There's a difference between being a leader and being a follower. A leader sets the agenda, sets the tone, and makes the tough decisions. And that's what we've done on a range of issues, from combating terrorism to promoting democracy around the world.

Now, I will say that we do value our alliances and our relationships with other countries. We work closely with our partners, we consult with them, and we seek their input. But at the end of the day, as the President of the United States, it's my job to make the decisions that I believe are in the best interests of the American people. And that's what I've done, and that's what I'll continue to do.

So, I don't see it as a choice between "unilateralism" and "leadership." I see it as leadership, plain and simple.

Well, thank you for that question. First of all, let me make it very clear that we are working tirelessly to bring both Usama bin Laden and Saddam Hussein to justice. They are both a threat to the global war on terror, and we're gonna do everything in our power to make sure they're held accountable for their actions.

Regarding Usama bin Laden, I can tell you that our intelligence indicates he is still at large in the region, but we do believe he's been weakened significantly since the fall of the Taliban in Afghanistan. We're working closely with our allies and partners in the region, including Pakistan, to disrupt and dismantle al-Qaeda's operations and to bring bin Laden to justice.

I would not say that bin Laden is back in business, per se, but we do believe he's still a threat, and we're taking that threat very seriously. We're gonna continue to pursue him, and we're gonna do everything in our power to make sure he's brought to justice.

Regarding Saddam Hussein, I can tell you that our intelligence indicates he is not in Iraq. We believe he is in hiding, possibly in Syria or another location. We're working closely with our coalition partners to track down Saddam and bring him to justice.

I want to assure the American people that we're gonna stay the course, we're gonna stay vigilant, and we're gonna do everything in our power to make sure that these two individuals are brought to justice. We owe it to the American people, we owe it to the world, and we owe it to the victims of 9/11 and the victims of Saddam's brutal regime.

Well, thank you for that question. I appreciate the opportunity to respond. I've had a chance to read Mr. Clarke's statement, and I appreciate his willingness to take responsibility for the actions of his agency at the time.

As for me, I've said it before, and I'll say it again - I'm the President of the United States, and I'm responsible for the actions of this administration. I've taken responsibility for the decisions that we made, and I've learned from the experiences that we've had.

Now, do I think the American people deserve an apology from me? Well, I think the American people deserve to know that we did everything we could to protect this country, given the information that we had at the time. And I believe that we did.

That being said, I've also acknowledged that with the benefit of hindsight, there were things that we could've done differently. And we've worked hard to correct those mistakes and to improve our systems so that we can better protect the American people in the future.

As for an apology, I'll tell you this - I'm not one to dwell on the past. I'm focused on the future, and I'm focused on protecting this country. And I believe that the American people deserve a President who's forward-looking, not backward-looking.

So, while I appreciate Mr. Clarke's sentiments, I'm not going to apologize for doing my best with the information that I had, and I'm going to continue to work hard to protect the American people from future threats.

Thank you for the question. The issue of settlements is a difficult one, and it's a sensitive one. As I've said before, I believe that Israel has the right to defend itself, and it has the right to have secure borders. And the settlement issue is a part of that.

In terms of our policy, it's a policy that dates back to 1967, and it is one that we've reaffirmed many times since then, that settlements are an obstacle to peace. And I believe that.

But as I also said in my first term, it's unrealistic to think that the solution to the Israeli-Palestinian conflict is going to be a total and complete withdrawal back to the '67 lines. That's just not going to happen. And it's not going to happen for a reason: because there will be parts of the West Bank that are likely to be part of a sovereign Israel, a sovereign Israel with secure borders.

Now, I'm not trying to prejudge the outcome of final-status talks, but I do think that it's necessary to recognize that there will be some sort of territorial adjustment that's going to have to take place. And I think that it's very important to acknowledge that reality.

In terms of the settlements themselves, I've made it clear that I do not support the expansion of settlements, and I think that the expansion of settlements would be a mistake. I do believe, however, that there are some settlements that will become part of Israel proper, as a result of a negotiated boundary.

Now, all of this, of course, is subject to negotiations between the two parties. And I want to be very clear: it's for the parties themselves, the Israelis and the Palestinians, to negotiate this. It's not for me, or for the United States, to impose our will on either party. But what we are trying to do is to create an environment in which negotiations can be successful.

Thank you for that question. I appreciate the opportunity to address this important issue. As I said in Chile, I did have a discussion with President Putin about the actions his government has taken, particularly with regards to the restriction of the media and the treatment of certain individuals who have spoken out against his administration.

Now, I believe that President Putin's intentions are to consolidate power and establish a strong central government in Russia. And I understand the temptation, but I also believe that this approach can lead to a stifling of dissent and a limitation of individual freedoms. That's not the model that the United States has chosen, and we've got to make that clear.

As for the impact on relations between our two countries, I think it's evident that the actions taken by President Putin's government have created some tension. But I still believe that we can cooperate on a range of issues of mutual interest, from counter-terrorism to non-proliferation. And I'm committed to maintaining a dialogue with President Putin, even when we disagree.

However, I must emphasize that the United States will continue to speak out when it sees actions that undermine democracy and individual freedoms. We've got a responsibility to do so, not just as a matter of principle, but also because the spread of freedom and democracy is in our strategic interests.

So, while there may be some challenges ahead, I'm determined to continue the engagement with Russia and to work on areas where we can find common ground, while also being clear and consistent in our support for democratic values and the rule of law. Thank you.

Thank you for the question. As I said in my Inaugural Address, I believe we've made significant progress in advancing the cause of civil rights and equality, but there's still much work to be done. My administration is committed to ensuring that America is a land of opportunity for all its citizens, regardless of their background or the color of their skin.

Now, I know some people might say, "What's the President going to do?" And I'll tell you, we're going to continue to focus on education as a key component to making sure that all Americans have access to a good education, so they can compete in this global economy. And I believe the No Child Left Behind Act, which I signed into law, is a significant step in that direction.

We're also going to continue to support initiatives that promote home ownership, that promote small business ownership, that help create economic opportunities in underserved communities. And I think it's also important to note that our tax cuts have benefited a lot of low-income families, African American families, who are now keeping more of their own money.

Thank you for that question. I appreciate the Chancellor's efforts to persuade Iran to abandon its nuclear ambitions. Regarding the assessment, I do think that Iran's concerns need to be addressed, but I also believe that those concerns can't be used as a bargaining chip to continue a nuclear program.

As for joining talks with Iran, we've made it clear that we're open to discussions, but there needs to be a genuine commitment from the Iranian government to end their nuclear program. I do think it's possible for the international community, including our European partners, to address Iran's concerns through the European Union's negotiations. However, ultimately, Iran's got to make the choice to abandon its nuclear ambitions.

Now, we're not ruling out the possibility of joining the talks in the future, but for now, I think the EU-3, France, Germany, and the UK, have a good process in place to move forward with the negotiations. We're keeping a close eye on the situation, and we're in close coordination with our international partners. But I must emphasize that our position remains firm: Iran's nuclear program is a threat not only to the region but also to the world, and it must be stopped.

Thank you for the question. I appreciate the Prime Minister's enthusiasm and commitment to helping the people of Africa. We do agree that Africa faces significant challenges, from poverty to disease to conflict. However, simply doubling aid isn't necessarily the solution.

As you know, I've already taken significant steps to increase our nation's commitment to Africa. The Emergency Plan for AIDS Relief, which I announced in my State of the Union address in 2003, is a major effort to combat the scourge of AIDS on the continent. And we've been working hard to ensure that aid is being used effectively and efficiently, with an emphasis on accountability and transparency.

Now, I'm not opposed to increasing aid, but we've got to make sure that it's done in a smart way. We've got to make sure that our aid is supporting real partnerships with governments and organizations that are committed to reform and good governance. We can't just write a check and expect problems to be solved. We've got to work with the Africans to build capacity, to build institutions, and to promote economic development.

And let's be clear: doubling aid is not just about throwing more money at the problem. It's about making tough decisions and setting clear priorities. We're already the largest donor to Africa, and I believe we've got a good record to stand on.

But I will say this: I'm open to further increasing our aid, and we're working closely with our G-8 partners, including the Prime Minister, to develop a comprehensive strategy to address the challenges in Africa. And we'll consider all options, including further increases in aid, as part of that effort. But we've got to do it in a way that's smart, effective, and responsible.

Thank you for that question.  I'd be happy to discuss this with you. First of all, let me just say that the Vice President was simply reaffirming what has always been the case, that is that the president has the authority to defend the country and will use that authority to defend our nation.

The NSA program, which I authorized shortly after 9/11, is a vital tool in our fight against terrorism. It allows us to gather intelligence on those who are seeking to harm the American people. Now, I understand that some have raised questions about the legal authorities and the appropriate scope of this program. And I can assure the American people that I have every confidence in the program's legality, and I am comfortable with the way that the program is being administered.

We have been working closely with the Congress to ensure that our nation is protected, while at the same time respecting the rights of the American people. Listen, I am particularly concerned about this: That the Democratically-controlled Congress and the broader Democratic party seems to be more focused on weakening the president's authority and undermining America's national security than they are on doing the hard work required to find real consensus on issues.

You know, I have worked hard to build trust with the Congress, and I will continue to work closely with them, but I am not going to let them tie my hands in the effort to protect this country.

I understand the concern, and I appreciate the context you've provided. The FISA law, as it currently stands, was enacted in a different time, and our enemies were different back then. We're dealing with a new kind of threat today - the threat of terrorism. And I believe the FISA law wasn't designed to address the kind of threats we're seeing today.

Now, after 9/11, I signed an authorization that allowed our intelligence community to gather information that would help us to defend the country from attacks. It's a vital tool in the War on Terror. I want to assure the American people that the actions we're taking are in accordance with the Constitution and our nation's laws.

Now, the program I'm talking about has been briefed to the relevant members of Congress, and I've reauthorized this program over 30 times. This is not a "circumvention" of FISA; it's actually a robust program that allows us to go after the enemy. I believe we have a duty to our citizens to do everything in our power to protect them.

But, let me be clear: we're not spying on American citizens. We're monitoring phone calls, and other communications from individuals who are most likely to be involved in terrorist activities. And, the only way we can do that is if we're able to, in real time, gather information. It's all part of the ongoing effort to protect the American people.

Now, I understand there are concerns about civil liberties, and I share those concerns. But, we've already seen that our terror courts and judges have many, many mechanisms in place to prevent any kind of abuses. And, in my view, that's working.

I think it's interesting that some Senate Republicans are considering that approach, but I gotta tell you, I'm opposed to it. I don't think it's the right way to address the issue. You see, I believe that if you tax their profits, it'll just lead to higher gas prices for the consumer. It's just simple economics.

Now, I do get frustrated when I see oil companies making record profits, while American families are feeling the pinch at the pump. That's the kind of thing that gets my attention, and I'd like to think that we can find a solution that encourages energy companies to work with the American people, not just their shareholders.

My approach is to focus on increasing production, both foreign and domestic. We need to find more oil and gas, but also invest in alternative energy sources. And I think we need to get America to be more energy-efficient. That's where we can make real progress, not just punishing the oil companies.

I appreciate the question. You know, I've had the pleasure of listening to a lot of smart folks outside of this administration who have some very good ideas on how to succeed in Iraq. And I'll tell you one idea that I've found to be particularly intriguing, is the concept of a more robust provincial reconstruction team, as proposed by Ambassador Khalilzad, which would provide more assistance to the provinces of Iraq. That idea, which originated outside of the administration, but was discussed extensively within it, and I think it's a darn good one.

I'm also interested in the ideas that General Casey and General Abizaid have discussed with me about the importance of training Iraqi security forces. Obviously, this is an idea that's had significant discussion within the administration, but also outside of it. It's a fundamental component of our strategy going forward, and I think we can do a better job of getting the word out to the Iraqis that we're committed to training their forces, to helping them stand up, so they can secure their own country.

These people - and I'm just mentioning a couple - are folks who have good ideas. I'm a guy who likes to listen to good ideas and put them into practice. And whether the idea comes from inside the administration or outside the administration, if it's a good idea that's going to help us achieve our objective, we'll take it.

Thank you for the question. I appreciate your interest in the legislative agenda that's being proposed by the new Speaker of the House. I'm a strong believer in staying within our means and being fiscally responsible.

I think there are some ideas that have merit. Raising the minimum wage, for example, is an issue that I've always said I'm open to. I've proposed a minimum wage increase in the past, but we need to be careful about unintended consequences, like what happens with the employment of low-skilled workers. We need to find a balance.

On the other hand, rolling back the tax cuts would be a non-starter. I firmly believe that our tax cuts have helped to stimulate economic growth, and going back on them now would be a mistake. I think we should keep the tax cuts, not just for the wealthy, but for working-class Americans who have benefited from those tax cuts as well.

And as for stem cell research, we need to be mindful of the ethical implications of this issue. I support stem cell research, but I also want to make it clear that I believe in the sanctity of human life and the protection of embryos.

So there are areas where we can work together, but there are also areas where we may disagree. And that's okay. I'm a strong believer in the separation of powers, and I look forward to having a constructive dialogue with the new Speaker and the Democratic leadership on these issues.

I appreciate the question. I've been in politics long enough to develop a thick skin, and I'm not going to let personal attacks get in the way of doing what's best for the American people. I've always believed in the importance of bipartisanship and working across the aisle, and that's exactly what I intend to do.

Now, I will admit, it's not always easy when someone makes personal attacks, but I'm not going to engage in that kind of rhetoric. I'm going to stay focused on the issues that matter most to the American people: our economy, our national security, and our values. And I'm going to keep working with Congress, including Speaker Pelosi, to get things done.

I've had good conversations with Speaker Pelosi in the past, and I'm hopeful that we can put aside our differences and work together on the issues that are important to the American people. The American people don't care about the petty squabbles and name-calling in Washington; they care about results. And that's what I'm committed to delivering.

So, I'm going to take the high road, and I'm going to keep working with anyone who's willing to work with me to get things done for the American people. That's the way I've always operated, and that's the way I'll continue to operate as President.

Thank you, and I appreciate the question.  Let me start by saying we are in this situation because we care about the future of Iraq. We care about the lives of the Iraqi people. We care about the stability of the region. And we care about the national security of the United States.

Now, as commander-in-chief, I have a solemn duty to make decisions based on the advice of our military commanders and the experts on the ground. And I'm telling you, we're making progress in Iraq. We're making progress in terms of the security situation. We've made significant gains in Anbar Province, which was once a hotbed of insurgency. We're seeing signs that ordinary Iraqis are turning against the terrorists and the militants, which is a positive sign.

Now, I know some folks want a quick end to this war. I understand that. But as the commander-in-chief, I have to think about the consequences of our actions. I have to think about the consequences of leaving Iraq before the job is done. And I firmly believe that if we leave before the Iraqis can defend themselves and govern themselves, we'll be inviting chaos and instability, and that would be a mistake.

As for the surge, it's working. It's doing its job. We're seeing results. We're seeing a decrease in sectarian violence. We're seeing an increase in confidence among the Iraqi people. And I'm committed to seeing this through to completion. I'm not putting an artificial deadline on the surge. I'm going to be guided by the best military advice. And I'm confident that we're on the right path.

Now, I understand, and I respect those who have a different view. I respect the fact that Americans are questioning the course of action. But I believe I have a solemn duty to do what I think is right, and that's what I'm doing.

Thank you, that's a great question. As the President, I've been working closely with my economic advisors to address the challenges facing our economy. I appreciate the input from Chairman Greenspan and Dr. Feldstein, two highly respected voices in the field.

While we've taken steps to support the economy, including the Economic Stimulus Act of 2008, we're not out of the woods yet. I agree that we need to do more to prevent further economic downturn. However, I also believe we must be responsible in our approach and make sure that any new measures are targeted, effective, and fiscally sound.

Regarding Chairman Greenspan's suggestion on foreclosure prevention, I think it's worth exploring options that would help homeowners who are struggling to stay in their homes. Perhaps we could consider some form of assistance for mortgage holders, such as temporary relief or refinancing options. However, we must also ensure that any such program is carefully targeted and doesn't create unintended consequences or moral hazard.

As for Dr. Feldstein's proposal for more tax cuts, I'm open to considering additional tax relief, but we need to make sure it's done in a way that stimulates economic growth and doesn't add to the deficit. We've already passed significant tax cuts in the past, and I believe we should focus on making those permanent, rather than layering on new temporary measures.

Ultimately, our approach must be guided by a commitment to fiscal responsibility and a willingness to take a balanced and bipartisan approach. I'm willing to work with Democrats and Republicans alike to find common ground and pass legislation that will help support our economy and get America back on track.

Thank you, and I'll take the next question.

Well, thank you for the question. I'm not surprised to hear that kind of question, given the kind of scrutiny that comes with this job. Now, I do believe the fundamentals of the economy are strong. I think there's a lot of uncertainty in the world today, a lot of consequence, and that affects people's perception of the economy. However, I want the American people to know we're working hard to create jobs, to stimulate the economy.

As for the '92 election, I've spoken to my father about it, and I'm aware of the concerns that you've just articulated. My answer is I'm not worried about historical parallels. I'm worried about solving the problems that are at hand. We're working closely with the Fed to keep the economy strong and I think that with the fiscal discipline we've shown, combined with the tax cuts we've implemented, will help the economy grow.

Now, as for Senator McCain, he's a strong candidate with great experience, good instincts on the issues and he'll make his own case to the American people. I think we can all agree that we want to keep America prosperous, be in the lead, keep our freedom prosperous as a people, have our troops safe and help those in need.

Thank you for the question. Well, let me be very clear: The United States is a steadfast supporter of human rights, and we expect all nations to adhere to the universal declaration of human rights. In the case of China, we've been very clear with the Chinese government that we expect them to respect the rights of their citizens, including freedom of speech and the right to peaceful assembly.

As for my planned trip to the Olympics, I want to make it clear that our presence at the Olympics is a symbol of our athletes and our nation's commitment to the spirit of the Games. We support the Olympic Charter, which promotes peace, unity, and international understanding.

Regarding the freedom of expression for athletes, we believe that the international community should support the rights of athletes to express their views in a peaceful manner. However, we also understand that the Olympics are a celebration of athletic achievement, and we would encourage athletes to respect the host country's laws and traditions while also exercising their right to free speech in a responsible manner.

I want to emphasize that our diplomatic efforts with China are multifaceted, and we will continue to press the Chinese government on human rights issues, while also engaging with them on a range of other issues that are important to our two nations.

(As President George W. Bush) Ah, thank you for that question. I'm glad to be here with Prime Minister Blair, and I think our collective efforts to promote peace and stability around the world are vital.

Regarding Northern Ireland, I do believe we have a role to play, and we will continue to be involved. As you know, Secretary of State Colin Powell will be exploring ways in which the United States can be supportive of the peace process. While I'm not going to get overly involved in the day-to-day negotiations, we recognize the importance of this issue and want to lend a hand. I believe that the framework that's in place, the Good Friday Agreement, is a good foundation, and we're committed to supporting it.

Now, I'm not going to get into comparisons with my predecessor, but I will say that the United States has always been a strong supporter of the peace process in Northern Ireland. We recognize that it's a fragile process, and we'll continue to work with our friends in the region to see it through.

(Turning to Prime Minister Blair) I think Tony and I have had some good discussions about this issue, and I'm confident we share a common commitment to the peace process.

(Pausing for a brief moment)

We'll continue to be supportive, to be a catalyst when we can, and to work closely with our friends in the region to see a lasting peace in Northern Ireland.

Thank you for the question. I appreciate the opportunity to address this issue. First of all, let me be clear: our focus is on defeating al-Qaeda and those who harbor them. And that's what the American people expect us to do. We are working diligently to bring to justice those who murdered thousands of innocent Americans on September 11th, and we will not be deterred from that mission.

As for the suggestion that we're going to widen the war to other countries, I can assure you that we will take the fight to the enemy wherever they may be, but we will do so in a measured and deliberate way, always mindful of the risks and the consequences of our actions.

We are working closely with our international partners to build a coalition to defeat terrorism, and we will continue to work through diplomatic channels to isolate and bring pressure to bear on those who would harbor or support terrorist organizations.

Let me be clear: we will not be intimidated, and we will not be deterred by the threat of terrorism. We will, however, be guided by a careful and thoughtful consideration of the options before us, and we will always put the security and well-being of the American people first.

And now, I believe you had a follow-up question?

Thank you for that question. First of all, the Palestinian elections are an important step towards establishing a more democratic Palestinian government. We believe that the free and fair elections can help pave the way for a more peaceful and stable future for the Palestinian people.

Now, regarding the Middle East peace process, while we're hopeful that these elections will lead to a more moderate Palestinian leadership, we're not naive about the challenges ahead. Getting a lasting peace agreement won't be easy, and it's unlikely to be achieved overnight. But we're committed to staying engaged and working with all parties involved to try to drive this process forward.

Regarding the rise of anti-Semitism in Europe, I must say that this trend is deeply disturbing. The idea of anti-Semitic threats, hate crimes, and rhetoric being directed toward Jewish communities in Europe or anywhere else is absolutely unacceptable. We take it very seriously and we strongly condemn such actions.

As for whether this concern could spread to the United States, well, while I have faith in the American people, we must always remain vigilant against any form of prejudice, intolerance, and hatred. We have a long history of standing against such evil in our country, and we will continue to work hard to prevent such a spread.

Our Department of Homeland Security and other agencies will certainly be monitoring this issue closely, both domestically and in cooperation with our international partners, to ensure the safety and security of Jewish communities here at home.

We value the special relationship we have with the Jewish community, not just here in America, but throughout the world. And as the leader of the free world, we're committed to upholding the values of tolerance, liberty, and justice that have made America great.

Thank you for that question. I'm glad you brought up the relationship between our two nations. We've got a long-standing friendship with Australia, and I'm proud to say it's stronger than ever. And I believe that's because we share the same values: a commitment to freedom, a commitment to fighting terror, and a commitment to spreading liberty around the world.

As for the Free Trade Agreement, or FTA, I'm optimistic that Congress will see the benefits of this agreement and move it forward. We've been working closely with the Australian government to get it done, and I'm confident that it's going to be a good deal for both our countries.

As for the timeline, I'd like to see it happen as soon as possible. We're aiming to finalize negotiations by the end of the year, and I'm hopeful that Congress will take up the agreement early next year. Of course, we'll need to go through the usual process, but I'm optimistic that we can get it done in a timely manner.

It's worth noting that this agreement is going to create jobs, increase trade, and promote economic growth for both our countries. It's a win-win, and I think Congress will recognize the benefits it brings to our nation.

Nick, I appreciate your question. Let me be clear: the individuals being held at Guantanamo Bay are enemy combatants, captured in the context of terrorist activities. We've made it clear that these are individuals who have chosen to fight against the United States and its allies. Now, I understand the concerns about the principles of justice, but we're dealing with a unique situation here. These individuals are not covered by the conventional Geneva Conventions, as they are not state-sponsored military personnel. 

That being said, we are working to ensure that they will receive a fair review of their status and any potential prosecution through the military commissions established under the Department of Defense. Our procedures are designed to provide individuals with an opportunity to contest the basis of their detention, and we have taken additional steps to ensure the integrity and legitimacy of these proceedings.

I also want to emphasize that we will conduct these proceedings in a manner that balances our commitment to upholding our values of fairness and due process with the imperative of protecting our national security. So, while I understand that there are doubts and concerns, we're doing our best to figure out how to make the system work and protect the American people at the same time.

Well, I think Americans can see the progress we're makin' in Iraq, and I think they can see that we're takin' the fight to the enemy. We're not waitin' for 'em to come to us. We're on the offense, and that's a fact. And I understand that there's an unease, and I understand that the news from Iraq is sometimes difficult to watch. But the people of Iraq are makin' progress towards democracy, and that's a difficult task.

And let me tell you, I've made it clear, and I'll make it clear again, the decision to invade Iraq was the right decision. Saddam Hussein was a threat, not just to the United States, but to the region. He was a threat to his own people. And I firmly believe that the world is better off without Saddam Hussein.

Now, I understand that there are some who are skeptical of my judgment and my assessment of the situation in Iraq. But let me tell you, I'm the commander-in-chief, and I've got a responsibility to make the tough decisions to keep this country safe. And I'm gonna keep on doin' what I think is right, even when it's difficult.

And I would remind people, the alternative to our strategy is to let the terrorists win, to let 'em take over the Middle East, to let 'em create a safe haven from which to launch further attacks on the United States. And that's a scenario that I'm not gonna let happen. We're gonna stay the course, we're gonna succeed in Iraq, and we're gonna make America safer as a result.

Thank you for that question.  I appreciate the opportunity to address this important topic. We are moving deliberately and carefully, because the Director of National Intelligence is a crucial position. We need to find the right person for the job. We're looking for someone who has got the experience, knowledge, and the character to be able to make tough decisions and to lead effectively.

Now, I know there's been some speculation about the pace of the search, but I want to assure the American people that we're not taking our time for the sake of taking our time. We're taking our time to make sure we get the right person. And I'm confident that we're making good progress.

I don't worry about what some people might think in the short term, because in the end, the American people will judge us on the quality of our decision, not on the speed of our decision. And I'm committed to finding someone who will serve this nation well and help us to stay ahead of the threats that we face.

That's a great question. As Commander-in-Chief, I've made the decision to increase our troop levels in Iraq to ensure the security and stability of the country, particularly as they move forward with these historic elections. Our military is doing a fantastic job, and I have every confidence in their ability to help the Iraqi people realize their democratic aspirations.

Now, regarding your question about troop levels, I want to be clear: our job is to train and assist the Iraqi security forces so they can take the lead in providing security for their country. If additional troops are needed to ensure the security of the Iraqi people, I will make that decision, but I want to emphasize that our goal is to transfer the responsibility to the Iraqis as soon as possible.

As for the deadline for drafting the new constitution, I believe the Iraqi people are dedicated to this process, and we're working closely with them to support their efforts. If they need a little more time, we'll be flexible. The Iraqis understand the importance of meeting this deadline, but ultimately, it's their constitution, and they need to take ownership of it.

I think it's essential to recognize that this is a process, and it's going to take time. There will be setbacks, and there will be challenges. But I'm confident that the Iraqi people will rise to this challenge, and we'll be there to support them every step of the way.

We're working hard to ensure that the elections are successful, and the Iraqis can move forward with this critical process. Our goal remains the same: to help the Iraqi people build a democratic, free, and stable society, and we'll continue to work tirelessly to achieve that objective.

Well, I can understand why some folks might be skeptical about progress in Iraq, but I'll tell you, I am cautiously optimistic about the path forward. The Iraqi people have shown tremendous resolve and determination in the face of terrorist attacks, and that's a testament to their desire for democracy.

Now, I do acknowledge that there are risks, including the potential for sectarian violence. We're working very closely with Prime Minister Allawi and other leaders to help them build the capacity to provide security, to demonstrate to their fellow Iraqis that the government can protect them. We're also pushing for elections that are fair and inclusive, and an Iraqi constitution that represents all the people.

Now, I've got faith in the Iraqi people. I think the United Nations can play a helpful role in helping the Iraqis come together and form a government. But make no mistake, the American people can be proud of what we've done so far. We've helped a nascent democracy to get off the ground. We've shown that those who stand for democracy will be supported. And I think in the end, the Iraqi people will have found a way forward that reflects their values and principles.

I will push them as hard as I can but I am not going to push them in a way that would overstep my bounds because I believe that ultimately, Iraq's fate will be settled in Iraq.

Well, thank you for the question. I appreciate it. We are committed to helping the people of Lebanon and the government of Lebanon to have a peaceful country, and we believe that a UN force is an important way to do so.

As for the participation of U.S. troops in this force, we've had discussions with our allies and with the UN Secretary-General Kofi Annan. And we believe that, at this point, it's best for the United States to support this mission with other means, such as logistics, such as financial support, and with the command structure, if asked to do so.

Now, I know there's a lot of speculation about our military being overtasked. And I want to tell you, our military is a mighty and capable force, and we're proud of the job they do. But we also believe that it's in our interest to work with our allies, to work with the international community, to solve problems. And in this case, we believe that the participation of countries other than the United States is an important way to achieve the objective of a peaceful Lebanon.

As for the question of credibility, I'd say, we've got a lot of credibility in the region, because we're willing to work with our allies and friends to achieve a common goal. And I'm confident that the international force will achieve its objective, in spite of speculation to the contrary.

Well, I think it's natural to draw comparisons to the Vietnam War, but I believe they're fundamentally wrong. The situation in Iraq is different in many ways.

First of all, in Iraq, we're fighting a brutal dictator who had a history of attacking his neighbors, using weapons of mass destruction, and threatening to the region. We're also fighting a terrorist network, al-Qaeda, that is bent on harming America and our allies.

In Vietnam, the conflict was more of a Cold War conflict, with the Viet Cong backed by the North Vietnamese, and it was also a much larger conventional force that we were facing.

In Iraq, we're not only fighting to defeat the enemy, but we're also fighting to help the Iraqi people build a free and democratic society, which is a fundamentally different mission.

And in terms of the deployment, our troops are more agile, more mobile, and more technologically advanced. They're not dug in for years; they're going on missions to clear out terrorists, and they're not getting bogged down.

Furthermore, I would say that our goals in Iraq are much clearer. We're working closely with the international community, unlike Vietnam. We're trying to enforce UN resolutions and the UN is actually endorsing our efforts.

I want to emphasize that the war on terror is a global conflict. It's being fought on many fronts, not just in Iraq. But I am confident that with our coalition and our military's capabilities, we'll make progress and ultimately win.

So, I think they're wrong to compare it directly to Vietnam, while it's understandable that there are some similarities, the circumstances, the people involved, the geography.

Well, thank you for the question. We have taken a hard look at our strategy, not just in Iraq, but in the global war on terror. And I believe it's essential to understand how we got here to determine the right course forward.

We've learned some key lessons over the past five years. One of the most important is the need for a more comprehensive approach – military, economic, diplomatic, and ideological. We can't just defeat the terrorists on the battlefield; we also have to counter their twisted ideology, encourage freedom and democracy, and address the underlying conditions that extremist groups often exploit.

In Iraq specifically, we've learned that it's not just a matter of putting more troops on the ground, but also working with the Iraqi government to strengthen their institutions and build a functioning economy. We've learned that brutal tactics like Abu Ghraib can undermine our efforts, and we've taken steps to address these issues.

In the final two years of my presidency, we'll be guided by these lessons. We'll work closely with the Iraqi government to train and strengthen their military, accelerate economic growth, and build on the progress made in the surge. We'll also engage our partners and allies in a more coordinated way, leveraging their unique strengths and capabilities to combat the threat of terrorism.

My commitment to the security and the freedom of the American people remains unshakeable. I am confident that with a strong military, a clear strategy, and a commitment to working with our partners, we can chart a course for victory in the global war on terror.

Yes, I do believe Prime Minister Maliki is the right guy for Iraq. We've just received this report, and we're analyzing it, but I'm not one to change my opinions based on one assessment. I think he's made some tough decisions, and I think he's made some wise decisions.

Now, I understand that there's a lot of pressure on him, and there's a lot of work to be done. But I believe he's the best person to help the Iraqis move forward. We've got a lot of confidence in him, and we're going to continue to work with him to make sure that the Iraqi people have the chance to live in a free society.

We've also got to remember that the people of Iraq are going to have to take ownership of their problems, and that's what we're trying to facilitate. I've talked to Prime Minister Maliki, and he's committed to moving forward, and I believe he can make the tough decisions necessary to bring about a peaceful and prosperous Iraq.

I want to thank you for the question. The actions and the activities of the Iranian regime are unacceptable. We have made it clear to the Iranians, through various diplomatic channels, that they should not be providing — or should not be allowing arms to flow into Iraq, where they're harming our troops.

And we're seeing — we know for a fact that some of the explosive devices that are harming our troops are being provided, or sent from Iran, into Iraq. We're working hard to stop that. We're working with the Iraqi government to stop that.

And I want to make it clear to the Iranian government that we're watching, and we will do what it takes to protect our troops. We'll work with our allies and friends to make that — make sure that our troops are safe.

But it's a message that we're — we've sent before. We're not just going to sit idly by and allow the Iranians to provide — to send arms or help people who are killing our troops. It's a moment to deliver a message that is constructive, hopefully, but also wanted to be understood — that we will protect our troops at all costs.

And as a President of the United States, it is my foremost responsibility to protect our folks, make sure our troops are safe. And we will work to do that.

Thank you. I'm concerned, very concerned, about the actions of China and Russia in blocking those sanctions at the U.N. Security Council. I think it was a missed opportunity for the international community to come together and take a strong stance against a regime that has shown no qualms about suppressing democracy and human rights.

The Mugabe regime has brought great suffering to the people of Zimbabwe, and it's the responsibility of all of us to stand up for what's right. By blocking these sanctions, China and Russia are essentially giving Mugabe a free pass to continue his authoritarian rule.

Now, we'll continue to work with our allies and friends to find ways to support the people of Zimbabwe and to promote democracy and human rights. We'll also continue to coordinate our efforts with regional leaders in Africa to put pressure on the regime to respect the rule of law and to hold free and fair elections.

Make no mistake, we will not give up. We will continue to push for a better future for the people of Zimbabwe, and we'll work with anyone who shares that commitment. We'll use every tool at our disposal – diplomatic, economic, and otherwise – to encourage a transition to democracy in Zimbabwe, and I'm confident that ultimately, justice and freedom will prevail.

Well, I'd like to start by saying that I'm excited about my upcoming trip to Mexico, and I believe it's going to be a very productive visit. As for our relationships with our European allies and Canada, I want to assure them that we value those relationships deeply and that we intend to maintain and strengthen them.

But I also think it's time for us to recognize the importance of our relationships in our own hemisphere. Mexico is our neighbor, it's our No. 1 trading partner, and we have close cultural and historical ties. We share a 2,000-mile border, and that makes us intertwined in many ways.

I'm not saying that we're going to compromise our relationships with Europe and Canada. Not at all. We're going to maintain those relationships, and we're going to work closely with our allies there. But I do think it's time for us to focus on our own hemisphere and to work on building a more prosperous and stable region.

I think it's a false choice, by the way, to say that we have to choose between our relationships with Mexico and our relationships with Europe and Canada. We can and will do both. We'll work with our allies in Europe and Canada to strengthen our relationships there, while also working to build stronger relationships in our own hemisphere.

I hope our friends in Europe and Canada will see this trip for what it is - an opportunity for us to strengthen our relationships in our own hemisphere and to promote our common interests and values.

Well, I appreciate the question. I think there's been a bit of a misunderstanding here. What I said, and what my staff said is, is accurate. I did say that we're committed to addressing the issue of climate change, and we are. We've got a very important commitment to the international community to do just that.

Now, as for the specifics of a package, I recall saying that we would be presenting the details of our approach in February, not at Marrakech. We've got some work to do on it, and we're going to be forthcoming with it. We're going to make sure that our package is one that makes sense for our economy, but also addresses the concerns about greenhouse gases.

And I don't recall saying anything that would indicate we'd have a package ready for Marrakech. So I think there's just been a bit of a miscommunication here. But I appreciate the opportunity to clarify it.

Well, let me address the Iraq situation first. We're looking at all options, and we're not taking any options off the table. Saddam Hussein is a threat to the United States, to the region, and to the world. He's a brutal dictator who has massacre his own people, invaded neighboring countries, and has not lived up to his international obligations, including those related to disarmament. We're working with the international community to find a way to disarm Saddam Hussein, and to hold him accountable for his actions.

Regarding military action, I'm not going to speculate on specific tactics or strategies. I will say that we're exploring all options, and we're working closely with our allies to build a coalition that will help us achieve our goals.

Now, regarding President Musharraf and the situation with Daniel Pearl, I'm deeply concerned about the safety of Mr. Pearl. I appreciate the efforts the Pakistani government is making to try to secure his release. We are working closely with the Pakistani government to try to resolve this situation as quickly as possible.

As for whether Mr. Pearl is alive, I don't have any information that I can share with you. We're making every effort to secure his release, and we're working closely with the Pakistani government to do so. We're doing everything we can to try to bring a peaceful resolution to this situation.

I'll tell you one thing - we're committed to working with President Musharraf, and we appreciate his cooperation in the war on terror. He's been a strong partner in this effort, and we appreciate his efforts to help resolve the situation with Daniel Pearl.

Thank you, and thank you for your question. I'm honored to be standing alongside my friend, President Mubarak. Today, we did indeed have a very productive discussion on the issue of terrorism, and I'm pleased to say that we found common ground on many areas.

President Mubarak and I share a strong commitment to defeating terrorism in all its forms, and we recognize that this is a global threat that requires international cooperation. We both agree that terrorism is a threat to the safety and security of our citizens, and we're committed to working together to prevent and respond to terrorist attacks.

We discussed a range of initiatives to enhance our cooperation on counter-terrorism, including intelligence sharing, law enforcement cooperation, and efforts to cut off terrorist financing. We also talked about the importance of promoting moderate voices and countering extremist ideology.

Egypt, under President Mubarak's leadership, has been a strong partner in the war on terror, and I want to thank him for his country's contributions to the global effort. We look forward to continuing our close cooperation and working together to make the world a safer and more secure place.

And I'd like to add that our talks were not limited to counter-terrorism, we also discussed other important regional issues, such as Middle East peace process and the situation in the region. We have a strong partnership, and we'll continue to work together to promote stability and prosperity in the region.

And I'll turn it over to President Mubarak to add anything he'd like to say on this question.

That's a great question. I appreciate your concern for the well-being of the American people. Let me tell you, the decision to stockpile smallpox vaccine is a prudent one, and I'm proud of the steps we're taking to prepare for any potential public health threat.

However, I gotta tell you, we're taking a careful and thoughtful approach to distribution. The reason we're prioritizing emergency and healthcare workers is that they're the ones on the front lines, they're the ones who would be most likely to be exposed to smallpox in the event of an outbreak. We gotta protect those who would be most at risk.

Now, I understand that some folks might want to get vaccinated, and I appreciate that. But we gotta make sure that we're not creating unnecessary demand, not creating a false sense of security. You see, the smallpox vaccine is not without risks. There are side effects, and we don't want to needlessly expose people to those risks.

We're taking a cautious approach, working with the CDC and other experts to make sure that we're making the right decisions for the American people. We'll continue to monitor the situation, and we'll adjust our approach as needed.

But I gotta tell you, I've got confidence in the plan we've got in place. We're doing everything we can to keep Americans safe, and we'll continue to do so.

Well, thank you for the question. I'm glad I had a chance to meet with the Muslim leaders and have a constructive dialogue. First of all, let me assure the American people that our foreign policy is based on principles of freedom, justice, and peace. And we're committed to working with all nations, regardless of their faith, to achieve those goals.

Now, I don't agree with the notion that our foreign policy is biased. I think it's quite the opposite. We're a nation that values freedom, and we're willing to work with those who share our values. The United States has a long-standing commitment to the security of Israel, but that doesn't mean we're not committed to the security and prosperity of other nations in the region.

It's also important for the world to understand that we value the relationships with Muslim-majority countries. We're working closely with them on a variety of issues, from counterterrorism to education and trade.

Now, I do acknowledge that there's a perception out there that we don't get it, that we don't understand Islam. But I can assure you, we do get it. We understand the importance of faith, and we understand the importance of working with faith leaders. That's why I've taken the initiative to meet with Muslim leaders, here and abroad, to discuss the importance of peace, the importance of fighting terror, and the importance of working together to achieve our goals.

We also understand that there are those who would seek to use our actions or our policies as a means to recruit and radicalize. And we're working to counter those forces. We're working to show the world that the United States values peace, values justice, and values the life of every citizen, regardless of their faith.

In the end, I believe our foreign policy is guided by a strong moral compass, a commitment to freedom, and a commitment to working with nations to achieve those goals.

Well, I appreciate the question. You know, I've made it clear from the beginning that our decision to liberate Iraq was not based on oil. Our decision was based solely on removing a threat to the United States, freeing the Iraqi people from the grip of tyranny, and making this world a safer place.

Now, regarding the issue of oil, I think it's interesting to hear some of our critics suggest that we should be asking for Iraq's oil in exchange for our help. Let me be clear: the Iraqi people own their oil, and it's up to them to decide how to use it. We're focused on helping the Iraqi people rebuild their country, and we're doing so in a way that's transparent and accountable.

We do believe, however, that Iraq's oil revenues should be used to benefit the Iraqi people, not just a privileged few. And we're working with the Iraqi government and the international community to ensure that those revenues are used in a responsible way.

So, to answer your question, I don't find it frustrating. I think it's just another example of the shifting sands of criticism. Our critics were wrong when they said we went to war for oil, and now they're wrong when they say we should be taking Iraq's oil as repayment. Our focus has always been on doing what's right, and that's what we'll continue to do.

Thank you for the question. I appreciate the opportunity to clarify our progrowth agenda. While tax cuts have indeed been a vital part of our efforts to stimulate economic growth, I do not believe they are the only component. In fact, our approach has always been multifaceted.

We've had tax relief, but we've also invested in education, in healthcare, and in infrastructure. And so, what I'd say is that we'll be evaluating the economic situation and the needs of the country, and we'll make decisions based on that. While I don't rule out any option, including additional tax relief, I also want to make it very clear that our progrowth agenda will also focus on other areas, as I've mentioned.

We are considering all the tools available to us to promote economic growth, and we'll be watching the economy carefully to make sure that we're taking the right steps to keep it strong and growing. We want to make sure that the American people have the tools and the environment they need to be successful.

So, to answer your question directly, I wouldn't rule out further tax cuts, but I also don't want to give the impression that that's all we're going to focus on. We're going to take a comprehensive approach to economic growth.

Thank you for the question. I'd like to correct you - my name is Bush, George W. Bush, not Fox. I appreciate the chance to address this very serious topic.

The loss of any American life is a tragedy, and my heart goes out to the families who have lost loved ones. However, I do not have any reservations about our mission in Iraq. We are fighting for a noble cause - the spread of democracy, the defeat of terrorism, and the protection of the American people.

The Saddam Hussein regime was a danger to the world, and the fact that he's no longer in power is a major accomplishment. We're helping the Iraqi people build a free country, and that's going to be a source of stability in the region.

I understand the critics, I respect their skepticism, and I welcome the debate. But I believe that the American people understand that we are in a war against terror. We're not just fighting in Iraq, we're fighting a global war. And the stakes are high, but I believe it's worth it.

We're making progress, and I'm proud of the bravery and the skill of our troops. I'll continue to support them, and I'll continue to do what I think is necessary to protect the American people.

(taking a deep breath) Well, thank you for that question. I think it's a very important one. You know, I strongly believe that the development of a Palestinian state alongside the state of Israel is not only in the interest of the Palestinian people, but it's also in the interest of Israel and the interest of the region. And I've made that clear from the very beginning of my term.

Now, the Israeli settlements and the wall do pose a challenge, no question about it. But I've also made it clear to Prime Minister Sharon that I think it's important for Israel to be mindful of the steps it takes and to ensure that any actions it takes don't prejudge the outcome of a final agreement.

I've also made it clear that I believe the wall should be consistent with the 1967 lines, and I made that clear to Prime Minister Sharon. And I think it's essential that we all work together to see that ... that that doesn't become a barrier to the development of a Palestinian state that's contiguous.

And, Mr. President Mubarak, you asked about Egypt's role. I believe Egypt can play a very constructive role in helping to support the emergence of a Palestinian state, particularly after a hypothetical Israeli withdrawal. Egyptian leadership... of, uh, by standing with the Palestinian people – the Palestinian leadership, excuse me – can provide an important residual link with the broader Arab world... So that the withdrawal .. takes place within a valid agreement that sets in motion the significant donation to help turn a pull withdrawal of territories that would forecast on have been... freezes conflicts amongst   statements say that must enable!

Thank you for that question. The international community's support in the rebuilding efforts of Iraq is crucial, and I'm pleased to report that we're making progress on that front. The fund you're referring to is the United Nations Development Group's Trust Fund, which we've established with the help of several donor countries, including the United Kingdom, Japan, and the European Union.

Our plan is to accelerate the disbursement of these funds by working closely with the Iraqi government, the United Nations, and other stakeholders to identify priority projects that can create jobs, stimulate economic growth, and improve the lives of the Iraqi people.

We're also working to simplify the procedures for accessing these funds, making it easier for international investors to do business in Iraq. Additionally, we're providing technical assistance to help the Iraqi government build its capacity to manage and implement projects effectively.

Now, I know that unemployment is a significant challenge in Iraq, and we're committed to helping the government address this issue. We believe that by investing in Iraq's infrastructure, supporting the growth of the private sector, and promoting economic reforms, we can create jobs and opportunities for the Iraqi people.

I want to assure the Iraqi people that we're committed to their country's future, and we're working diligently to ensure that the international community's contributions are used effectively and efficiently to benefit the Iraqi people. Thank you.

[smiling] Well, thank you for the kind advice. [laughter] Don't worry, I can handle it. Now, to answer your question, we are in constant dialogue with the Iraqi government. And as I said earlier, our Army and our coalition forces are making good progress in helping the Iraqis stand up and take control of their own security.

Now, I've always said that our troop levels will be conditions-based, not time-based. In other words, we'll withdraw our troops when the Iraqis can handle their own security. We've got a plan to transition responsibility to the Iraqis, and as they're able to take more and more responsibility, we'll be able to reduce our troop levels.

Now, I'm not going to give the Iraqis a specific timetable. That would defeat the purpose of being conditions-based. I mean, you can't give a terrorist a timetable for when you're leaving, and expect them to just go ahead with their plans. That doesn't make any sense. We're constantly evaluating the situation on the ground, and working with the Iraqis to make sure they're able to take control of their own security. That's the way to achieve success in Iraq.

Thank you for that question. I have indeed been made aware of the allegations regarding Ambassador Bolton's conduct with his subordinates. And I can tell you that I take these allegations seriously, as I would any accusations of wrongdoing by a member of my administration.

However, I also want to be clear that Ambassador Bolton has been a valuable member of my team, and I have confidence in his ability to represent American interests at the United Nations. That being said, I have asked the relevant parties to look into these allegations and report back to me.

As for personal intervention, I will not prejudge the outcome of any investigation. But I will say this: if the allegations are true, and if Ambassador Bolton's conduct was indeed unacceptable, then yes, that would be a serious matter. As President, I expect all members of my administration to act with the highest standards of integrity and professionalism.
