But let's be clear: we need to be careful not to rush to judgment. We need to let the facts come out, and we need to make decisions based on the evidence. That's what Americans expect from their government, and that's what I intend to deliver. Thank you.

Thank you for that question. I'm glad you asked. You know, I've been in regular contact with leaders across the region, and I believe that we're making progress in building a coalition of responsible nations who are committed to supporting the cause of peace and stability in the Middle East.

Now, I know that not every nation is going to agree with us on every issue, but I do believe that we can work together to find common ground and achieve our shared goals. And that includes, of course, the issue of Hezbollah. I've made it clear to all of our allies, including the Prime Minister here, that Hezbollah is a terrorist organization that must be held accountable for its actions.

And I'm pleased that the international community is now beginning to see Hezbollah for what it is - a radical, extremist group that's committed to violence and bloodshed. And I think that it's only a matter of time before the international community as a whole is willing to take the necessary steps to hold Hezbollah accountable.

(To the Prime Minister) I think it's worth noting, by the way, that my friend here, the Prime Minister, has taken a very strong position on the importance of disarming Hezbollah and getting them to stand down. And I think that's a position that the international community can and should support.

(To the reporter) I think that's what I'd like to emphasize, is that we're not in this alone. We're working with a growing coalition of nations who are committed to peace and stability in the Middle East, and I'm confident that together, we can achieve great things.

 Prime Minister?

Well, thank you for the question. I appreciate it. Making decisions in a post-9/11 world can be very difficult. I'm also mindful of the challenges we face, and I'm also mindful of the fact that we're at war. In order to be candid, I do believe we've made some mistakes, but I don't think the strategy itself is a mistake. There have been tactical mistakes made, and we learn from those mistakes. 

However, we must be steadfast in our principles, which are to defeat the radicals and extremists, protect ourselves from harm, and to help lay the foundation of peace. I would say that our strategy, though, in Iraq, has changed. We've had generals on the ground who have tried different tactics, and I've always asked our military leaders to evaluate what's working, what's not working, and come back and tell me.

Now, in terms of the Iraq Study Group, we're looking at it, we're analyzing it, and I appreciate the Baker Group coming in and giving their suggestions and their evaluations. But, what is important is to understand that whatever decision we make must be done in consultation with our allies and partners in the region and the United States Congress.

Now we will change, and we will adjust, but for one reason, which is to succeed.

Well, thank you for that question. I appreciate the opportunity to address this issue. Let me tell you, as Commander-in-Chief, I have a solemn responsibility to ensure that our men and women in uniform have a clear mission, the resources they need, and the support of the American people. And that's exactly what we're providing in Iraq.

Now, I understand there are some concerns about the direction of the war, and I appreciate the candor of my fellow Republicans. I've been meeting with many of them, and I believe we share a common goal: victory in Iraq and the defeat of al-Qaeda. Where we may differ is on the tactics to achieve that goal.

Let me tell you, I've been to Iraq, I've seen the progress firsthand, and I've talked to our brave men and women serving on the ground. And I can tell you, we are making progress. It's tough, it's challenging, but we're making progress. And I believe our current strategy is the right one to secure a stable, democratic Iraq.

Now, I understand the pressure of elections, I've been in tough elections myself, but I believe that if we give up and withdraw prematurely, we will embolden our enemies, we will give them a boost, and we will put our national security at risk. We must not let the terrorists win.

To my fellow Republicans, I say: we must stay the course. We owe it to our troops, we owe it to the Iraqi people, and we owe it to our future security. We can't let the terrorists win, we must not send mixed signals, we must show resolve. And I believe that if we do, we can and will succeed in Iraq.

Thank you.

You know, that's a great question. As the President of the United States, I've made it clear that I believe the decision to go into Iraq was the right one, and that we're making progress in Iraq. Now, I understand that not everybody agrees with me, and that's okay. That's our democracy. People have different opinions, and they're free to express them.

Now, I will tell you that when I make decisions, I'm not worried about whether they're popular or not. I'm worried about whether they're right or not. And I'd rather have people look back on my presidency and say, "He stood on principle, and he did what he thought was right," rather than say, "He did what the crowd wanted him to do."

Don't get me wrong, I'm the President of the United States, and I respect the will of the people. But I also know that as the Commander-in-Chief, I have a duty to our troops, to our citizens, and to the future of our country. And so, when I make decisions, I'm thinking about what's best for this country, not just what's popular.

Now, I do get comfort from the fact that there are still a lot of Americans who support our efforts in Iraq. I get letters all the time from people who say, "Mr. President, thank you for what you're doing." And that's encouraging, because it tells me that there are people out there who understand the stakes, and who understand what we're trying to do.

But ultimately, I'm not going to be swayed by polls or by public opinion. I'm going to do what I think is right, and I'm going to do what I think is necessary to protect this country. That's my duty, and that's my responsibility.

And I've got to tell you, it's not always easy. There are times when I get tired, and there are times when I get frustrated. But I'm not going to let those emotions get the best of me. I'm going to stay focused on the task at hand, and I'm going to see this through to its conclusion.

And when the history of this presidency is written, I'm confident that people will say that I did what I thought was right, and I did what I thought was necessary to protect this country and its people.

iggins, thank you for that question. I believe it's a very good question. First of all, I want to thank John Howard for his leadership on the issue of climate change. I think it's a very important issue, and I think it's necessary to address it.

Regarding the meeting in Washington, I don't think it undermines John's efforts at all. In fact, I think it's complementary. We're having a separate meeting with major economies, including the Europeans, to discuss our own proposal, which includes a non-binding goal of reducing greenhouse gas emissions.

Now, I know some people might say, "Wait a minute, why are you having a separate meeting?" And my answer is, we're not trying to undermine the APEC process. We're trying to be constructive. We want to be a part of the global discussion on climate change. And we believe that our proposal, which we'll be discussing in Washington, can help us achieve that goal.

Regarding Kyoto, I think it's not relevant to the discussion anymore. We've made it clear that we're not going to ratify the treaty. We have different approaches to addressing climate change, and we think our approach is more effective.

Now, I know some people might disagree with that, and that's okay. But I think what's important is that we're all serious about addressing the issue of climate change. And I think John Howard's efforts here at APEC, and our own efforts in Washington, are both constructive steps in addressing this very important issue.

So, I hope that answers your question.

Well, thank you for your question. I appreciate the opportunity to share my thoughts on this important issue. As you know, I vetoed the SCHIP bill because it increased spending by too much and expanded the program beyond its original intent. Now, I agree that children's health care is a top priority, but we've got to be fiscally responsible in how we approach this issue.

As for working together, I believe I acted in good faith. I proposed a more modest expansion of SCHIP, one that would have increased funding by $5 billion over five years. Unfortunately, the Democratic-led Congress chose to go a different route and passed a bill that went too far. I made it clear that I would veto this version of the bill, and they chose to push it to a vote anyway.

I think part of the problem here is a philosophical difference. We have a disagreement about the role of government in providing health care. I believe in a limited government that works with the private sector to provide health care solutions. The Democrats, it seems, want to take the federal government in a direction that I think would be costly and create a new entitlement program that we can't afford.

I'm willing to work with Congress to find common ground on this issue. In fact, I've invited leaders from both parties to the White House to discuss a way forward. We can find a solution that will help children who need it, but we've got to do it in a way that's responsible and doesn't put us further in debt.

Thank you for that question. I'm glad you asked that. Now, let me start by saying that we are in challenging economic times, no question about it. Energy prices are high, food prices are high, and we're doing everything we can to help the American people weather this storm.

Now, regarding the recession, I still firmly believe that this economy is strong. We've had 52 months of consecutive job growth. Our economy is resilient. We've been through tough times before, and we'll get through these tough times again.

Now, regarding your question on Saudi Arabia, I will indeed be meeting with King Abdullah during my visit next week. I intend to have a very candid and straightforward conversation with him about the importance of increasing oil production to meet the demands of a growing global economy.

We've got a very good relationship with the Kingdom, and I'm hopeful that we can work together to find a solution to this high price of gasoline that the American people are paying. I believe that by continuing to invest in alternative sources of energy, increasing domestic production, and working with our friends and allies around the world, we can get more oil on the market, and that will help to reduce the price at the pump.

But I want to remind you all that this isn't just about politics. This is about policies that will help the American people. And I'm committed to working with anyone, Democrat or Republican, who is serious about finding a solution to this problem.

Now, I've also asked the Saudi leadership to use their influence to encourage other OPEC countries to also increase their production. And I'm hopeful that we'll see some movement on that front as well.

So, in summary, we're doing everything we can to help the American people, and we're working hard to find a solution to this high price of gasoline. Thank you.

Thank you for that question. I'm glad to be here today to address the concerns of the American people. I can tell you with great confidence that my administration is committed to getting this economy growing, creating jobs, and making sure that the American people have access to affordable energy.

Now, I understand that the energy prices are high, and I'm concerned about it too. That's why we've got a comprehensive energy plan that's going to help reduce our dependence on foreign oil, increase conservation, and promote the development of new technologies.

You know, I'm an optimistic person, and I believe that with the hard work of the American people, with sound policies, and with a little bit of luck, I think that we can get this economy growing again. And I'm committed to working every day to make sure that that happens.

Now, as for whether or not I should be held accountable, I believe that the American people should hold me accountable. That's part of the job of being President. I'm willing to take the responsibility, and I'm willing to make the tough decisions necessary to get the job done.

But I want the American people to know that we're going to work hard every day to make sure that they are better off at the end of my term than they are today. And I'm confident that with the help of the American people, we can achieve that goal.

Thank you. Next question, please.

Thank you for the question. I appreciate the interest of our Spanish allies in renewing the defense cooperation agreement. We value our relationship with Spain, and I believe it's in the best interest of both our nations to work together on defense issues.

As for the renewal of the agreement, I think it's definitely possible before the end of the year. We've been discussing this with our Spanish counterparts, and I'm optimistic that we can come to a mutually beneficial agreement. Our goal is to strengthen our cooperation on defense matters, and I believe we can achieve that through this agreement.

Regarding the presence of U.S. military in Spanish bases, that's a topic that's still under discussion. I don't want to get ahead of the negotiations, but I will say that we appreciate the hospitality of the Spanish government in allowing us to have a military presence in their country. We believe that a continued presence can be beneficial for both our nations, and we'll continue to discuss the details of that with our Spanish friends.

Overall, I'm looking forward to a positive outcome in our negotiations, and I'm confident that we can find a path forward that strengthens our alliance and promotes our shared security interests. Next question, please.

The development of low-yield nuclear weapons is a serious consideration, and I'd be happy to provide some context. The war on terrorism has shown us that we're facing an unconventional threat, one that doesn't always follow traditional rules of warfare. We're dealing with enemies who don't care about the consequences of their actions, who are willing to use horrific tactics to achieve their goals.

In this environment, we need all options on the table. The development of low-yield nuclear weapons is one way we're thinking about how to counter the unconventional threats we face. These weapons would be designed to be more flexible, more useable, in a way that would allow us to respond to the kinds of threats we're seeing in the war on terrorism.

Now, I want to be clear: we're not talking about developing a new generation of nuclear arms that would be used willy-nilly. We're talking about developing a capability that would be used in the most extreme circumstances, where conventional forces wouldn't be sufficient, and where the consequences of not acting would be catastrophic.

In terms of the countries you mentioned, I'd say that we're looking at a range of potential threats, from state sponsors of terrorism to rogue states that possess WMD. We need to have the capability to respond to these threats in a way that's effective and proportional.

But let me be clear: we're not going to rush into anything. We're going to take a thoughtful and deliberate approach to this question. We'll be consulting with our allies, with the international community, and with the experts to ensure that we're making the right decision.

And I want to emphasize that our first priority remains the same: to prevent proliferation, to prevent the spread of nuclear weapons. We're committed to non-proliferation, and we'll work tirelessly to ensure that these weapons don't fall into the wrong hands.

So, in short, we're thinking about the development of low-yield nuclear weapons as one tool in our toolkit to counter the unconventional threats we face. It's a serious consideration, and we'll approach it in a careful and deliberate way.

Well, Bob, first of all, let me clarify that the situation in Iraq and the Israeli-Palestinian conflict, while connected to the Middle East, are distinct and separate issues. I believe that Saddam Hussein's regime in Iraq is a threat to America's national security, to the stability of the region, and to the world at large.

Vice President Cheney, Secretary Powell, and other members of my administration are working diligently to communicate our concerns about Iraq's WMD programs and Saddam Hussein's defiant behavior to our Arab allies and other nations. We're building a strong case to hold Saddam Hussein accountable for his actions, and to encourage support for his disarmament or regime change.

Now, regarding the Israeli-Palestinian conflict, I'm deeply troubled by the recent increase in violence. We're working to bring the parties together to find a peaceful resolution to their differences. We believe that a resolution to the Israeli-Palestinian conflict will require leadership from both sides and a willingness to make difficult choices. Ultimately, our goal is to see the emergence of two states, Israel and Palestine, living side by side in peace.

However, I must emphasize that the situation in Iraq is not directly linked to the Israeli-Palestinian conflict. Saddam Hussein's pursuit of WMD and his refusal to comply with UN resolutions pose a unique threat that requires a separate response. We will continue to work with our Arab allies and other nations to address both of these critical challenges in the region.

(pausing for a moment) Well, I'd like to address that statement. (clears throat) You're referring to Director Tenet's testimony. I think it's essential to understand the complexity of this situation. Saddam Hussein is a threat, not just to the United States, but to the entire world. He's a man who has shown a reckless disregard for human life, for international law, and for the stability of the region.

Now, regarding the specific question of whether or not he would become more aggressive if we were to take military action... (pauses again) I'd say that's impossible to predict with certainty. But one thing's for sure: Saddam's got a record of miscalculation, and that's what makes him so unpredictable.

However, we cannot afford to let fear of what he might do dictate our actions. We must look at the facts, and the fact is that Saddam's got these terrible weapons, and he's demonstrated the willingness to use them. (firmly) We will not wait for him to make a move that could potentially harm our citizens or destabilize the region.

As Commander-in-Chief, I will do what is necessary to protect this great nation, its people, and our interests. Thank you. ( gestures to the next reporter)

Thank you for that question. We're still gatherin' intelligence, and we're still analyzin' the situation on the ground. I think it's safe to say that Saddam Hussein's regime supported and encouraged the kind of violence we're seein' in Iraq today. Now, with Saddam in custody, we're optimistic that some of the command structure, if you will, that was directin' these attacks will begin to fall apart.

Now, I want to caution the American people that there are still those in Iraq who want to do us harm, who want to disrupt the progress we're makin' towards stability and security in that country. In the short term, I don't think it's wise to assume that the violence will suddenly end. But in the long term, I'm confident that with the capture of Saddam Hussein and the continue efforts of the coalition, we will see a reduction in the level of violence and a increase in the stability of that country.

Make no mistake, we're makin' progress in Iraq, and this is a significant step forward. But we're not gonna let our guard down. We're gonna continue to work with the Iraqi people, continue to work with the international community, to bring peace and stability to that region. And I'm proud of the men and women in uniform who are makin' it possible for us to be in this position today.

(sternly) I appreciate the question. The interim government that we've helped establish in Iraq is a vital step toward a free and peaceful Iraq. And I'm confident that we've made the right decision, along with Ambassador Brahimi and the Iraqi people, in selecting this diverse group of leaders.

Now, I understand there may be some perceptions out there that the process was rushed or somehow influenced. I can tell you that we worked very closely with Ambassador Brahimi to ensure that this government is representative of the Iraqi people. We engaged in a thorough and inclusive process that brought together leaders from various backgrounds and regions.

Now, I'm not gonna sit here and tell you that it's gonna be easy. I mean, we're dealing with a country that's been devastated by decades of tyranny and malaise. We're dealing with factions that have had no history of working together, with no tradition of democracy. But I am confident that this government has the legitimacy it needs to move forward.

Iraqis are frustrated with the lack of security, they're frustrated with the lack of electricity, they're frustrated with the lack of basic services. And this government is committed to addressing those concerns. And I'm committed to supporting them.

So, to answer your question directly, I believe that this government has the legitimacy to bring stability to Iraq, to begin the process of reconciliation, and to lay the foundation for a free society.

(pauses, looking around the room) Next question?

Thank you for the question. Regarding Prime Minister Blair's call for an international conference on the Middle East, I appreciate his enthusiasm and commitment to finding a peaceful solution to the Israeli-Palestinian conflict. As for what needs to happen before the United States would sign on to such a conference, I'd like to see some tangible steps taken towards creating a more constructive and conducive environment for dialogue.

First, we need to see a significant reduction in violence and terrorism from Palestinian groups. We need to see a real commitment to dismantling terrorist infrastructure and a focus on peaceful negotiations, not violence. We also need to see Israel taking steps to support the Palestinian economy and improve the humanitarian situation on the ground.

Furthermore, any conference would need to be grounded in a clear set of goals and principles, such as the two-state solution and the principles outlined in the Roadmap. We need to see all parties, including the Palestinians, Israelis, and Arab states, genuinely committed to making progress and moving towards a lasting peace.

Regarding the naming of a U.S. envoy, we're actively considering various names and options. We'll need someone who has the credibility, expertise, and the ability to get the parties to the table and help them focus on achieving concrete results.

As for this upcoming trip to Europe, I'm looking forward to meeting with our allies and partners to discuss a range of critical issues, including the Middle East peace process, global terrorism, and economic cooperation. We'll be working to strengthen our partnerships, find ways to increase international cooperation, and advance our shared values of democracy, freedom, and human rights.

In particular, I'm looking forward to meeting with Prime Minister Blair and other European leaders to discuss the Middle East, as well as the situation in Afghanistan and Iraq. We'll be exploring ways to deepen our cooperation on these issues and find new ways to work together to address global challenges.

Thank you, I'm happy to take that question. As you know, we've been working closely with our partners in Africa to promote democracy, stability, and prosperity on the continent. We've made significant progress in countries like Liberia, the Democratic Republic of Congo, and Sudan, but there's still much work to be done.

We're committed to helping the people of Africa build a brighter future for themselves, and we're exploring a range of options to do so. I want to emphasize that our preference is always for diplomatic and economic engagement, but in certain circumstances, military power may be necessary. However, I want to assure the American people and the international community that any decision to use military force will be made with great care and in close consultation with our allies.

Now, regarding a potential coalition of the willing, including Danish forces, I've had the pleasure of speaking with Prime Minister Anders Fogh Rasmussen on several occasions, and I appreciate Denmark's commitment to global security and stability. We value our partnership with Denmark and will continue to work together on a range of issues, including counter-terrorism and peacekeeping efforts.

I'll ask the Prime Minister to add any additional thoughts he might have on this topic. Prime Minister?

Thank you for the question. First, let me clarify that my administration's commitment to supporting the people affected by natural disasters, such as Hurricane Katrina, remains unwavering. In terms of federal involvement and troops, I believe it's essential for the federal government to have the necessary authority and resources to respond to catastrophic events. What I was referring to last night is the potential for the federal government to take a more proactive role in providing support and assistance in the aftermath of a disaster.

Now, as it relates to the specifics of troop deployments or federalizing the National Guard, those are decisions that we'll make on a case-by-case basis, taking into account the unique circumstances of each situation. Our goal is to ensure that we're providing the necessary support to the affected communities and that we're not overstepping our bounds.

Regarding my conversation with President Putin, I had a very productive discussion with him on the issue of Iran's nuclear program. I believe it's essential for the international community to work together to prevent Iran from developing a nuclear weapon. I made it clear to President Putin that the United States believes Iran's actions pose a significant threat to global security and stability, and that we must take a strong stance against their pursuit of nuclear capabilities.

As for sending the issue to the Security Council, I think there's a growing international consensus that this issue needs to be addressed, and the United Nations is the appropriate forum to do so. I'm heartened by the conversations I've had with President Putin and other world leaders who share our concerns about Iran's actions, and I believe we're making progress towards presenting a united front on this issue.

I appreciate your question. I want to start by saying that our work in the Gulf Coast region is ongoing, and I've been heavily involved in making sure that we're doing everything we can to help the good people of Louisiana, Mississippi, and Alabama.

You're right; the initial response was unacceptable, and I took responsibility for it. We've made significant progress since then. The federal, state, and local governments have worked together to provide critical aid, including food, water, shelter, and medical care to those in need.

However, I understand that there's still much work to be done. I've visited the region multiple times, and I've seen firsthand the devastation and the progress we've made. I can tell you that people are getting the aid they need, but we're not satisfied yet. We're working hard to make sure that the resources are getting to the people who need them most.

We've also taken steps to improve our response efforts, including the appointment of a new head of FEMA, R. David Paulison. He's doing a great job of streamlining the process and making sure that aid gets to those who need it quickly.

But I want to be clear: we're not where we need to be yet. We'll continue to work tirelessly to ensure that the people of the Gulf Coast receive the support they need to recover and rebuild their communities. And I appreciate the patience and resilience of the American people, who have come together to support their fellow citizens in this time of need.

You know, I appreciate the Prime Minister's concern about the violence in Iraq, but I don't think we're quite there yet. What we're seeing is an escalation of sectarian violence, certainly, and it's unfortunate. But I believe we need to be careful with the terminology we use.

Civil war connotes a situation where the government has lost control and is pitted against its people. What we see in Iraq is a government that is struggling to exert its authority, with extremism and terrorism trying to tear the country apart.

Now, that's not to say the situation isn't serious - it is. We've seen the implication of sectarian violence, and it's a major challenge to the new Iraqi government. But I think we should avoid, you know, reflexively falling into the characterization of a civil war. We need to be mindful of the fact that Iraq has made significant progress, there are elections coming up, and the Iraqi people are trying to rebuild their country.

The key here is, will the Iraqi people and their government be able to confront this problem, with our help and with the help of the international community? I think they can, and I think we need to maintain our commitment to helping them succeed.

Well, thank you for that question. I appreciate it. You know, I understand the skepticism and the frustration that many Americans feel about the situation in Iraq. And I want to assure the American people that I share that frustration, and I'm committed to making sure that we succeed in our mission there.

Now, as for the question about violence, I've said that, look, it's a little unrealistic to expect there to be no violence in a country that's been ravaged by sectarian strife and terror. But what we are trying to do is help the Iraqis create a condition where the Iraqi security forces are capable of taking control, where the government is strong enough to make the necessary decisions, and where the Iraqi people have confidence in their government.

Now, as for the reduction in violence, I believe we are making progress. We've seen a significant decrease in sectarian violence, for example. But what we need to see is a commitment from all parties to work towards a peaceful solution, to reconcile their differences, and to rebuild their country.

In terms of drawing down our troops, I've said that our goal is to get to the point where we can start to reduce our force size. But we need to be careful not to do it too quickly, because we want to make sure that we're leaving behind a stability that will be sustainable.

Now, as for the exact figure, that's something that General Petraeus and our military commanders will be working on, in consultation with the Iraqi government, to determine what's the right pace and the right size of our drawdown. But I will say that we are making progress, and we're optimistic that we can get to the point where we can start to reduce our force size in the not-too-distant future.

Well, thank you for that question. First of all, I want to emphasize that we're in the early stages of helping the Iraqis form a unity government. It's a process that's been underway, and I'm encouraged by the progress that's been made so far. I do not think that allowing insurgents who have killed Americans, Italians, and for that matter, a lot of Iraqis to get amnesty. You cannot allow killers to be granted amnesty. Accountability is important. And I understand that a lot of the Iraqis will work to grant immunity to those and amnesties to Iraqis who fought against the coalition forces because we are fighting against the tyranny. As for the second part of your question regarding the Iraqi oil, we believe the Iraq's oil revenues belong to the Iraqis people. That's exactly why the Iraqi interim government is working to come up with the best framework possible to allow the oil revenues to flow to benefit all the Iraqi people by giving each group a claim.

(smirking) Well, I appreciate the question. Look, as the Commander-in-Chief, I understand that there are going to be different opinions about the War in Iraq. But let me tell you, I remain steadfast in my commitment to our mission. I believe that we're making progress, and I believe that our strategy is working.

Now, I'd be the first to admit that the war has been a challenge. It's a tough fight, and we've faced some setbacks. But I think it's essential to remember that we're not just fighting for Iraq; we're fighting for a more secure America, and we're fighting for the cause of freedom.

As for support, I believe that the American people understand the importance of this mission. They know that we're not just fighting for a specific country; we're fighting for the principles of democracy and liberty. And I believe that the vast majority of the American people support our efforts.

Of course, I recognize that there are some who disagree with my decisions, and that's okay. That's a part of the democratic process. But let me tell you, I'm not going to make decisions based on popular opinion or public polls. I'm going to make decisions based on what I believe is right for the country.

So, no, I don't feel like the walls are closing in on me. I feel like I'm making the right decisions for the American people, and I'm committed to seeing this mission through to its successful conclusion.

Thank you for the question. The situation in Iraq is, indeed, a very serious and complex one. I understand why some people might be tempted to call it a civil war, but I don't think that's entirely accurate.

What we're seeing in Iraq is a mix of sectarian violence and a terrorist campaign led by al-Qaeda and other extremist groups, as well as some insurgents who oppose the Iraqi government. Now, it's true that there are Sunni and Shia factions involved, and that's why some people might see parallels with a civil war.

However, I don't think that fully captures the nature of the problem we're facing. You see, the vast majority of Iraqis, both Sunni and Shia, want to live in peace and stability. They want a unified Iraq, free from the grip of terrorism and extremism.

What's driving the violence is a relatively small group of radical Islamists, who have chosen to target innocent civilians, by the way, regardless of their sect or creed. These are the very same folks who would like to drive us out of Iraq, and embolden the broader extremist movement across the region.

If you call it a civil war, it could indeed give some folks, not in this administration, but critics, the impression that it's somehow acceptable, or mainly an internal Iraqi issue. But the truth is, the stakes are much higher than that.

The consequences of failure are regional, if not global. It would be an existential threat, if a chaotic, failed state in Iraq becomes a safe haven for these terrorist groups. That would not just affect the region, that would affect America.

You know, I appreciate your question. It's a fair one. I believe that you can most certainly support our troops, our brave men and women in uniform, without necessarily agreeing with the policy. I've always said that it's okay to disagree with me, and I think it's okay to agree or disagree with the decision to go into Iraq.

What I do think is important is to support our troops, to give them the equipment they need, to give 'em the funding they need to do their job, and to make sure their families are taken care of. And I think it's also important to recognize that these men and women are volunteering to serve our country, and that they're making sacrifices on behalf of our country.

Now, I do think that when you're in a time of war, and we are at war, that there's a time for debate, and there's a time for decision-making. And I've made the decision to go into Iraq, based on the intelligence I had, and based on the idea that we needed to take a different approach to Saddam Hussein.

But I think it's perfectly legitimate for people to express their opinions, to express their disagreement, and to say, you know, "I think you made a mistake, Mr. President." I mean, that's just part of the democratic process.

What I don't think is helpful is when people resort to personal attacks, or when people criticize our troops. That's not supportin' the troops. Supportin' the troops is, as I said, givin' 'em the equipment they need, the funding they need, and takin' care of their families.

So, I think there's a line there, between constructive criticism and support for our troops, and then the kind of criticism that, in my view, is not particularly helpful.

Well, thank you for the question. I appreciate it. We've been in office for a while now, and I think we've made some good progress on a variety of fronts. Now, I will say that there's always a natural tension between the parties, and that's healthy. I think that's part of the system.

But I will say that, in terms of working with Democrats, I've been a bit disappointed in some areas. It seems like some of the Democrats have been more interested in playing politics than finding common ground. And I understand the nature of politics. I'm not naive about it. I've been around long enough.

But, on the other hand, I've had some pretty productive conversations with some leading Democrats. I've found that on some key issues, like on clarifying the rules of engagement for allocating funds for the military, we're making progress.

It's still early in the term, and we're working to get our message out, to articulate our priorities and work with people of good faith to find solutions. I'm optimistic that we can make some serious inroads on key issues.

Now, will we agree on every issue? No, I don't think so. But, I think we can have a healthy and constructive debate, one that strengthens the country. And that's my goal.

I wouldn't call it "grounds for divorce," as you put it. That's too dramatic. I think that what we're seeing is what you see in a healthy democracy – differing opinions, differing ideas, and then trying to hammer those out.

In my judgment, there's still a lot of goodwill on both sides. We just need to make sure that goodwill translates into action.

Well, I appreciate the question. Let me just say, I understand that there are a lot of folks who disagree with my decision to go into Iraq, and that's okay. But let me tell you, I made the decision based on the information I had at the time, and I believed it was the right thing to do.

And as for the insurgency that has developed in Iraq, we have been facing a unique challenge. We've been fighting an enemy that is not just a conventional military enemy, but a terrorist enemy that is willing to kill innocent civilians.

Now, I know that the casualties are high, and they're heartbreaking. Every time I get a report about a young soldier being killed or wounded, it's a reminder of the sacrifices that our troops are making. But I firmly believe that our strategy is working.

We've had a lot of successes in Iraq. We've had successful elections, we've had the Iraqis take control of more and more territory, and we're training Iraqi security forces that are becoming increasingly effective.

Now, I understand that there are a lot of folks who are frustrated, who are worried, and who are skeptical. But I believe that we are making progress. And I believe that our strategy is sound.

As for being stubborn or in denial, I'd say that's just not fair. I've always been willing to adjust and adapt our strategy as the situation on the ground changes. And I'm confident that we're on the right path.

And as for the cost, I understand that it's high. But let me tell you, the cost of failure would be even higher. The cost of letting Iraq become a haven for terrorists would be a threat not just to our nation, but to the entire world.

So, I understand that there are a lot of folks who disagree with me. But I'm not in denial, I'm not stubborn, I'm resolute. And I'm committed to winning this war.

I appreciate that question, and it's a very important one.  We've been workin' hard to achieve a global consensus on climate change. Now, I know there's been some discussions about the participation of emerging economies, like China and India, in any potential agreement.

First off, let me tell you, we've made some progress.  We've had some very good conversations with these countries, and they understand the problem. They're startin' to take steps to reduce their own emissions, and we're helpin' them with technology and other forms of assistance.

Now, in terms of what we're gonna do to get 'em to come around, we're gonna continue to engage in bilateral and multilateral talks with these countries.  We're workin' through the G8, the G20, and the Major Economies Meeting on Energy and Climate to try and find common ground.

We've also proposed some measures that we think are reasonable, such as a sector-based approach, where we work with, for example, the Chinese steel industry to improve their energy efficiency and reduce their greenhouse gas emissions.

It's gonna take time, it's gonna take patience, and it's gonna take persistence. But we're committed to gettin' this done, 'cause we understand the urgency of the problem.

And let me just say, this is not just a economic issue; this is a national security issue, an environmental issue, and a moral issue.  We've gotta take the lead on this issue, and we will.

And I'll tell you this, we're makin' progress, slow but sure.  We'll continue to work with our allies, with the international community, and with these emergin' economies to try and find solutions to this critical problem.

Thank you. Next question, please.

Thank you. Well, I'm not going to predict the price of oil. I mean, I wish I could. I think it would be helpful if I could, but I'm not an econometric modeler, nor do I have a crystal ball. (Laughter)

I do know that the price of oil is influenced by a variety of factors, from global demand and supply to geopolitical events and natural disasters. And trying to guess what's going to happen to the price of oil, long-term, is a challenging business.

But what I do know is that we need to take steps to reduce our dependence on foreign oil. And that's why we're pushing for energy independence policies, ranging from diversifying our energy mix through the expansion of alternatives like ethanol and other renewables, to increasing domestic production of oil and natural gas, and promoting conservation.

We've also made it clear that OPEC –- or, the OPEC nations need to understand that it's in their interest as much as it is in ours for the price of oil to be reasonable, so people can afford to buy it. And so we'll continue to work with our international partners to make sure that the global market is working in a way that benefits both consumers and producers.

I think this market will adjust. I mean, if you look at history, the price of oil has gone up and down, and it will continue to adjust based upon a variety of factors. But my main focus is on the steps that we can take to ensure that America is more energy independent.

Thank you, sir. First and foremost, I want to express my deep appreciation for Poland's strong support in the global war on terror. Your nation has shown unwavering commitment to our shared values of freedom and democracy. We value our friendship and alliance with Poland, and we appreciate your participation in the coalition.

Regarding the future of the coalition, we believe that the mission in Iraq and Afghanistan is crucial to achieving our objective of defeating the terrorists and spreading freedom. We're working closely with our coalition partners, including Poland, to ensure that our efforts are coordinated and effective.

As for Poland's involvement, I believe that your country has made significant contributions to the coalition effort, and we're grateful for that. We've had discussions with the Polish government about the future of our cooperation, and I'm confident that we'll continue to work together to meet the challenges ahead.

Regarding Poland's readiness to meet expectations, I can say that we've been impressed by the bravery and professionalism of the Polish military. Your troops have faced danger and hardship, and they've demonstrated remarkable resilience and courage. We're committed to supporting Poland's efforts to modernize and transform its military, and we believe that our cooperation will only strengthen our ability to work together to address the challenges of the 21st century.

So, to answer your question, I think Poland is absolutely ready to meet the expectations, and we look forward to continuing our close cooperation in the days ahead.

Mike, I appreciate that question. I'd like to start by saying that we take all these attacks very seriously. The bombings in Morocco and Saudi Arabia are a tragic reminder that the threat of terrorism is still very real. 

As for whether Al Qaida is regrouping, we're constantly assessing the situation, and I can tell you that we're doing everything in our power to prevent these type of attacks from happening. We've had success in the past in disrupting their operations, but this is a global network, and we're gonna have to stay vigilant.

Now, as for whether we overestimated the damage we did to the organization, I don't think so. We've dealt a significant blow to Al Qaida, no question about it. We've removed them from Afghanistan, we've captured or killed many of their top leaders, and we've disrupted their operations.

But Al Qaida is a resilient group, and they're gonna try to adapt, and they're gonna try to find ways to demonstrate their nefarious ideology. We can't let our guard down, and we won't. We'll continue to work with our international partners, and we'll use every tool at our disposal to disrupt their operations and bring these terrorists to justice.

It's a long-term struggle, Mike, but we're committed to winning the war on terror.

Well, thank you for that question. Let me be clear: the United States will not tolerate a nuclear North Korea. The North Koreans have already taken steps that we consider to be unacceptable, and we are working with our international partners to address the threat that they pose.

The current situation is serious, and we're not going to stand idly by while the North Koreans continue to pursue a nuclear program that we believe is destabilizing to the region. We're already working with the United Nations to impose tough sanctions, and we're prepared to take additional steps to increase the pressure on the regime.

Now, if the North Koreans were simply to do nothing, that would not be a satisfactory outcome. We need to see concrete steps towards denuclearization, and we need to see a commitment to ending their nuclear program. If we don't see that, we'll have to consider what other measures we can take to persuade the North Koreans that it's in their interests to cooperate.

We're not going to get into a game of nuclear blackmail with the North Koreans. We're going to take a principled stand that says, "We will not tolerate nuclear proliferation in the Korean Peninsula." And we'll work with our international partners to take the necessary steps to enforce that principle.

Ken, thank you for the question. I appreciate it. You know, I'm a glass-half-full kind of fellow when it comes to the economy. We've had some good news, with the unemployment rate lower than people anticipated, and the economy is growing. And I think our economy is fundamentally sound.

Now, I do recognize the deficit's an issue. I've got a plan to deal with it. We've put forth a budget that's got some tough choices in it, but it's a real plan to reduce the deficit. We're going to reduce non-security discretionary spending. We're going to make sure our agencies are running more efficiently.

On the discretionary side, we're going to take a hatchet to unnecessary and ineffective programs. We're also going to promote private sector growth, which will help us meet our goal of cutting the deficit in half by the year 2009.

Now, I know some folks in Washington will say, "Well, the President needs to have a specific plan that raises taxes or cuts entitlements." I'm not going to adhere to a specific litmus test on how to reduce the deficit, other than to say we've got a comprehensive plan to do so.

And I'm confident it's going to work. I'm confident because I understand that the best way to deal with the deficit is to make sure our economy's growing, is to make sure we're entrepreneurial, and making sure that the private sector is healthy.

So, we've got a plan. We've presented it to the Congress. We're working closely with the Congress to see that it passes. I'm optimistic that we can make some progress on reducing the deficit. And I'm not worried, by the way, about the weakening dollar. The fundamentals of our economy are sound, and I'm confident in the future of America's economy. Next question, please.

I think I've made my case... look, I'm a results-oriented person. And we're making progress on the security front, we're making progress on the economic front. I'm a glass half-full kind of fellow. I'm optimistic about America. And I've made the case as clear as I can make it, and I'll continue to do so.

You know, I've been in this office for over four years now, and I realize that there's going to be criticism. And I've come to realize that the best way to handle criticism is to do my job, and to trust the American people to make the right judgment.

Now, I admit, there have been some tough moments. We've had some tough moments as a country. But I firmly believe that we're on the right track, and that the decisions I've made have helped keep this country safe, and have helped our economy grow.

You know, perhaps I could have done a better job of explaining some of these issues. That's always a possibility. But I'm a straightforward, plainspoken fellow. I try to be as honest and as direct with the American people as I can. And I think that, over time, the American people will come to realize that the decisions I've made were made with their best interests in mind.

Thank you for the question. I'd like to address this issue head-on. First, let me say that the war on terrorism is a long and complex fight. We're making progress, and we're winning battles. But we're also facing an enemy that's adaptable, resilient, and determined.

Now, I understand that the numbers may not reflect that progress, at least not immediately. But let me tell you, we've made significant strides in dismantling the al-Qaeda network, taking out key leaders, and disrupting their financing and communication channels.

However, this enemy has also changed tactics. They've become more decentralized, they're using more unconventional methods, and they're targeting softer targets. They're trying to create a sense of chaos and fear, and they're trying to undermine our will.

But let me be clear: we're not going to be intimidated, we're not going to be deterred, and we're not going to back down. We're going to keep pushing forward, we're going to keep going after them, and we're going to keep working with our allies to dismantle these terrorist networks.

Now, I know that the numbers may not be what we want them to be right now, but I can tell you that we're making progress. And I'm convinced that with the brave men and women of our military, with the help of our allies, and with the resilience of the American people, we're going to win this war on terrorism.

And one more thing: we're not going to let the terrorists dictate the agenda. We're going to stay on offense, we're going to stay proactive, and we're going to stay committed to spreading freedom and democracy to those who are willing to stand up and fight for it.

Thank you for your question. Next question, please.

Thank you for that question. First of all, I'm proud of the progress we've made with No Child Left Behind. This legislation is making a real difference in the lives of many young Americans. It's helping to ensure that every child, regardless of their background or zip code, has access to a quality education.

Regarding the funding concerns expressed by the teachers union, I want to assure the American people that we are fully committed to supporting our nation's schools and teachers. While we may have differences of opinion on the amount of funding, I believe that we've made significant strides in increasing federal support for our nation's education system.

Under No Child Left Behind, we've increased federal funding for K-12 education by nearly 40% since 2001. This is a significant investment in our nation's future, and it's helping to support important initiatives like teacher quality, educational technology, and targeted support for disadvantaged students.

Now, I understand that some may argue that more funding is needed, and I respect that perspective. However, I also believe that we must be responsible stewards of taxpayer dollars and ensure that funding is being used effectively. We're working closely with states, school districts, and educators to identify areas where we can better support their efforts to improve student achievement.

As for whether No Child Left Behind is working, I firmly believe that it is. We're seeing early signs of progress, particularly in reading and math scores. In addition, we're making strides in closing the achievement gap that has long plagued our education system. These gains are promising, but I'm also committed to continuing to work with educators, policymakers, and other stakeholders to build on this momentum and make necessary adjustments to ensure the law is working as intended.

We will continue to work with the teaching profession and all stakeholders to ensure that every child has access to a quality education, and we will keep pushing to make sure that No Child Left Behind is a success for every child in America.

Thank you for that question. As President, I believe that one of my key responsibilities is to ensure the federal judiciary is staffed with highly qualified, fair-minded, and impartial judges who will uphold the Constitution. And I firmly believe that my judicial nominees meet those high standards.

Now, I understand that the Senate has a vital role to play in the confirmation process, and I respect that institution. But I also expect the Senate to give these nominees a fair up-or-down vote, without unnecessary delays or obstruction.

Regarding the notion that Republicans did the same thing during President Clinton's administration, I'd say that the situation is quite different. During the Clinton era, many of his nominees received a vote on the Senate floor, even if they didn't get confirmed. We've had multiple instances now where nominees have been blocked from even getting a confirmation hearing, let alone a vote on the floor.

As for the impact on my domestic agenda, I believe that these judicial confirmations are an integral part of that agenda. We need judges who will respect the laws passed by Congress and uphold the principles of federalism. If the Senate fails to move forward on these nominees, it will hinder our ability to govern effectively.

So, I urge the Senate to focus on the qualifications and fitness of these nominees, rather than resorting to procedural roadblocks. We need to work together to ensure the federal judiciary is the best it can be, and I'm willing to have that discussion and work with the Senate to get there. Thank you.

I appreciate the question. As you know, Chairman Greenspan's term is set to expire in 2004, and I have indeed begun the process of considering his eventual successor. It's too early for me to announce any specific names, but I can tell you that we're taking a thorough and deliberate approach to identifying the right person for this critical position.

We're looking for someone with a deep understanding of monetary policy, a strong track record of leadership, and a commitment to the principles of sound economic management. I'll be consulting with a range of experts, including members of my economic team, senators, and other stakeholders.

I want to emphasize that the Fed Chairman is an independent position, and I'll be looking for someone who can make decisions based on what's best for the economy, not based on any particular ideological or partisan agenda.

We'll be taking our time to get this decision right, and I'm confident that we'll find the right person to build on Chairman Greenspan's legacy. Thank you.

Well, I appreciate the question. Abu Musab al-Zarqawi's death is a significant blow to the terrorist organization, al-Qaeda in Iraq. Our top commanders are telling me that this development has the potential to disrupt their leadership, and bring a sense of hope to the Iraqi people.

Now, in terms of the strategy meetings we're having here at Camp David, we're looking at this in a broader context. We're discussing ways to build on the momentum of Zarqawi's death, to increase our efforts to defeat the insurgency, and to help the Iraqis build a stable, democratic society.

We know that the insurgency is still a threat, and that we've got a lot of work to do. But I believe the death of Zarqawi is a key moment in this struggle, and we intend to take advantage of it, to move forward and to make progress.

I've instructed our commanders to do everything in their power to capitalize on this moment, to stay on the offense, and to continue to work closely with the Iraqi security forces to build their capacity and to help them take the lead in their own country.

It's a major step forward, but it's just one step. We've got a long way to go, but I'm confident that with the bravery and skill of our troops, and the commitment of the Iraqi people, we can succeed in our mission and create a peaceful, stable Iraq.

Well, let me start by saying that our Number One priority, of course, is to protect the United States of America, and that means doing everything in our power to capture or bring to justice those who would do us harm. 

We have a good relationship with the Pakistani government, led by President Musharraf. We've worked closely with him on a number of issues, including the issue of the Taliban and the al-Qaeda presence in the tribal areas. And I'm satisfied with the assurances I've received from President Musharraf.

Now, when it comes to capturing Usama bin Laden – or finding him, I should say – we will do what it takes to bring him to justice. We will work with our allies and our friends, and we'll do it in a way that's consistent with the principles of the United States. In terms of whether we need permission to take action against Usama bin Laden, I'm not going to get into hypotheticals about this or any other situation. We'll do what it takes to protect the United States.

I think it's fair to say that we are working closely with the Pakistanis to help them deal with the issue of the Taliban and al-Qaeda presence in their country. We've got good cooperation, we're sharing intelligence, and we're working together to take out these terrorists. And if we get actionable intelligence that would take us to Usama bin Laden, we'll take the necessary action to bring him to justice.

This is a collaborative effort, and I believe we're making progress. But make no mistake, we will not hesitate to take action when we think it's necessary to protect the people of the United States.

Thank you.

Well, I appreciate the question. I've known Matthew Dowd for a long time. We worked together on the campaign, and I appreciate his service. As for his comments, I think it's just a matter of a former staff member expressing his opinion. I'm used to people having opinions and expressing them. That's America.

And as for worrying about losing support, I don't spend a lot of time worrying about what other folks say. I'm focused on doing the job that the American people elected me to do. And that is to protect this country, to grow the economy, and to spread freedom and democracy around the world.

I think Matthew Dowd has the right to express his opinion, and I'm confident that our policies are sound, and our record speaks for itself. We're focused on moving forward, not looking back.

I do want to say that I appreciate Matthew's work on the campaign. He was an important member of our team, and I'm proud of the work we did together. But I don't get too worked up about what other people say. I'm the President of the United States, and I've got to do the hard work of making the decisions that I believe are in the best interest of the country.

I think you're misunderstanding the facts. The Democrats were elected to make sure the troops have what they need to succeed in Iraq. And what they've done, however, is voted to undermine General Petraeus, voted to hamstring our troops, and voted to give a date certain for withdrawal of our troops, which I think would be a bad decision.

It's one thing to have a debate about policy, and that's healthy. But it's another thing to deny funding for our troops to get what they need to succeed. And that's what the Democrats have done. They've voted to deny funding for the troops. And that's a fact.

Now, I know there's concerns about the war. I share those concerns. I want our troops to come home as soon as possible. But I also know that we can't leave this region, we can't leave Iraq until we've achieved our goals. And that's exactly what we're working towards.

And I believe the enemy is emboldened when the Congress votes to withdraw troops at a certain date. It makes it more difficult for General Petraeus to achieve the mission that we've given him. And I think that's a mistake.

So, yes, I do think the American people expect the Congress to support our troops, and that's exactly what I'm asking them to do.

Thank you for that question. First, I want to say I'm optimistic about the relationship between our two countries. We've had a very good dialogue, and I'm proud of the progress we've made. Now, regarding the anti-missile defense shield, I believe it's essential for our mutual security and the security of our friends and allies.

I think there's a lot of misinformation about the shield. It's not aimed at any particular country; it's aimed at protecting our citizens and our allies from the threats of rogue nations. I've made it clear to your government, as I'm speaking publicly, that we're willing to cooperate and work together on this issue.

Now, regarding common sites, we're open to discussions about how we can work together to enhance our defenses. But I want to make it clear that our commitment to the Poles, to the Czechs, and to other allies remains strong. We're committed to working with them to protect our collective security.

On the trade investment front, I'm a strong believer in free trade. I think it's essential for economic growth and prosperity. And I'm committed to working with your government to enhance our trade relationship. We've got some issues to work through, no question about it. But I'm optimistic we can work through those issues and strengthen our trade relationship.

So, in summary, I'm optimistic about the relationship between our countries. I think we've made some good progress, and I'm looking forward to working with your government to strengthen our cooperation on security, trade, and investment.

Well, I appreciate the question, and I'm glad you said you're not trying to play "gotcha," because I think that's a fair question. You know, as the President of the United States, I've made a lot of tough decisions, and I'm proud of the decisions I made. But, of course, there are some decisions that I wish I could go back and, you know, do differently.

One area where I wish I could have done things differently is in my handling of Katrina, specifically in the early stages, the preparations and the immediate aftermath of the hurricane. I think we could have done a better job of anticipating the devastation, and we could have done a better job of communicating the severity of the situation to the American people.

Now, I'm proud of the work that we did eventually, in terms of providing support to the people of the Gulf Coast, and in terms of helping to rebuild and recover. But in those early stages, I think there were some missteps, and I take responsibility for those.

But I want to remind people that I'm a firm believer in Katrina, we faced a catastrophic event. And we had to work to help the people of New Orleans, and the Gulf Coast. And the provision that the federal government, the private sector, the NGOs, made a big difference in terms of providing help.

But overall, I think, you know, you can't change the past, and all you can do is try to learn from those experiences.

(pausing for a moment, choosing words carefully) I believe that all loss of innocent life is tragic and unfortunate. The death of a baby in Gaza, and the brutal murder of the teenagers near Tekoa – it's just heartbreaking. The murder of those boys is particularly heinous. We condemn acts of terrorism, and the people responsible for these barbaric acts must be held accountable.

As the President of the United States, my heart goes out to the families of the victims and the people of Israel who are suffering from these acts of terror. We will continue to work with our friends in the region to bring peace and stability, and to seek justice for those who have been wronged.

(pausing again)
But let me be clear: the United States will not draw a moral equivalence between the actions of terrorists and the actions of governments that are trying to protect their people. The deliberate targeting of innocents is never justifiable, and we will always stand with those who are working to protect their citizens from terrorism.

Thank you for that question. As I've said, the expansion of NATO is indeed a question of when, not whether. I believe it's essential for the security and stability of Europe, and for the United States' own national interests.

As for the timing, I will be meeting with NATO leaders tomorrow, and I do plan to discuss the expansion process with them. I think it's reasonable to consider starting the process next year, but I want to emphasize that any decision on the timing will depend on the readiness of the applicant countries and the Alliance as a whole.

Regarding the Balkan States, I do believe that they should be considered in the expansion process. We've seen the progress that's been made in the region, from Bosnia to Kosovo, and I think it's essential to build on that progress by integrating these countries into the mainstream of European security structures.

But let me be clear: the expansion of NATO will be done in a way that's fair, transparent, and based on the performance of the applicant countries. We'll be looking for countries that share our values, that are committed to democracy, individual liberty, and the rule of law, and that are able to contribute to the security of the Alliance.

So, while I think the Balkan States should be considered, we'll be looking at each country on a case-by-case basis, and we'll be making decisions based on their individual merits.

I understand the question, and I appreciate the skepticism. Let me tell you, as Commander-in-Chief, I've got a responsibility to protect the American people, and that's exactly what I'm doing. Our defense priorities are not just about numbers on a spreadsheet, they're about keeping America safe and strong.

Now, I know that the budget process can be a challenge, but I've been working closely with Congressional leaders to ensure that we prioritize our spending in a way that reflects our values as a nation. We've made some tough decisions, and we'll continue to do so.

I'm not asking Congress to abandon their priorities, but I am asking them to work with me to find common ground on the issues that matter most to the American people. And I believe we can do that.

I recall the days following 9/11, when we came together as a nation to pass the PATRIOT Act, and we passed a series of bills to support our troops. And I believe we can do the same thing today.

Now, I'm not naive to think that this is going to be easy. I know there will be disagreements, and there will be tough negotiations. But I'm willing to work with Congress, to listen to their concerns, and to find solutions that meet our shared goals.

So, I'd say to the American people, we're going to work hard to get this done. We're going to work hard to make sure that our defense priorities are funded, and we're going to do it in a way that's responsible and fiscally sound. And I'm confident that together, we can achieve that.

Terima kasih, thank you. (referring to an interpreter) Ah, can you, can you translate for me, please... (clears throat)

Well, I, the decision for me to visit Indonesia, it is a very important trip for me as the President of the United States. We value our relationship with Indonesia, the world's third-largest democracy, and the largest Muslim-majority nation. We're committed to a strong partnership with Indonesia, based on mutual respect, and shared values.

(smiling) And let me just tell you, I'm looking forward to meeting with President Yudhoyono, and other leaders here in Indonesia, to talk about how we can work together to fight terrorism, to promote economic growth and development, and to advance our shared interests in the region.

Regarding our foreign policy, I... we, as Americans, believe that freedom, and democracy, are universal values, and we want to promote these values, all around the world, including in the Middle East. And I believe, that our policy towards the Islamic world is one of respect, and one of partnership.

Now, I know that there are concerns about our policy, about the war in Iraq, about the Middle East peace process. I understand these concerns, and I want to assure the people of Indonesia, and the Muslim world, that our goal is peace, and stability, and that we're committed to a two-state solution, for the Israeli-Palestinian conflict.

/pausing for a moment

I want to emphasize that our policy is not against the Islamic faith, or the Muslim world. We have many friends and allies in the Muslim world, and we respect, and value these relationships.

We also recognize that there are differences of opinion, and perspectives, and we're willing to listen, and to learn from these perspectives, as we move forward.

(Concluding) So, to answer your question, I'm, I'm committed to continue, to promote our partnership, with Indonesia, and the Muslim world, based on mutual respect, and shared values.

I appreciate the question. Well, I think, first of all, it's essential to understand that we've made it clear to President Putin and the Russian government that we believe in the sovereignty of the Ukraine. We believe that the decisions that the Ukrainian people make ought to be made without undue influence from any outside nation.

Regarding the comment, I think it's interesting that President Putin made that comment. I think it's essential for all countries, including ourselves, to be careful not to exert undue pressure on the Ukrainian government or the Ukrainian people.

As for whether or not President Putin has lived up to his own words, I think it's essential to point out that there are some concerns about whether or not Russia has done that. There's a delicate balance that can be struck between legitimate influence and undue pressure. And I'll continue to communicate with President Putin about our shared concerns on this issue.

Our aim is to support the Ukrainian people's democratic aspirations, and we'll work with all concerned parties to help that process forward. And I might add, the Ukrainian people deserve to have a presidential election that is free from outside interference.

Thank you.

Well, thank you for that question. Laura and I were in Egypt, and we were there to, uh, encourage President Mubarak to move towards democratic reforms. And I believe it's, uh, it's positive that he has announced his intention to hold multi-candidate elections.

Now, I'm deeply concerned about the, uh, violence that erupted in the streets. That's not what we're about. We're about peaceful expression of dissent, not violence. And I expect President Mubarak to, uh, take steps to ensure that the opposition is treated fairly and that the rights of the Egyptian people are respected.

And to President Mubarak, I would say that, uh, the world is watching. We're watching to see how you respond to the aspirations of the Egyptian people for democratic reform. We want to support you as you make these steps, but we also expect you to take seriously the need to protect the human rights of all Egyptians.

We're committed to helping Egypt become a more democratic and prosperous country, but, uh, we will be paying close attention to how this process unfolds. Thank you.

Thank you for the question. I've been following this situation closely, and I'm deeply troubled by the sentencing of Mikhail Khodorkovsky. While I think it's impossible for me to know the inner workings of the Russian judiciary, I do believe that there's reason to be concerned about the fairness and independence of this trial.

As the President of the United States, I'm always mindful of the importance of protecting human rights and the rule of law. I've expressed my concerns to President Putin about the need for Russia to uphold these principles, both domestically and internationally.

Now, regarding the potential impact on U.S.-Russian relations, I believe this case does raise concerns. The United States values its partnership with Russia on a range of issues, from counter-terrorism to non-proliferation. However, our relationship must be built on a foundation of shared values, including respect for the rule of law, democracy, and human rights.

I'll continue to engage with President Putin and his government to express my concerns and to encourage them to uphold the highest standards of justice and fairness. We'll be closely watching the developments in this case and its implications for our bilateral relationship.

But let me be clear: the United States will continue to pursue a strong and pragmatic relationship with Russia, one that advances our mutual interests while also promoting our values of democracy, freedom, and human rights.

Thank you, I'd be happy to address that. Our process for selecting a Supreme Court Justice is extensive and deliberate. We're looking for individuals who are highly qualified, who will interpret the law, not make the law, and who will strictly adhere to the Constitution.

We've got a great team of folks who are reviewing potential candidates and I'm confident that when we make a nomination, the American people will be proud of the person we put forward.

Regarding the agreement between the 14 Senators, I think it's a positive development. It's a recognition that the Senate's got a responsibility to considering judicial nominees in a fair and timely manner. And I'm told that the agreement doesn't bind the executive branch but could impact the way that the Senate proceeds with a nomination.

Now, make no mistake, we're going to nominate someone who we think is an outstanding candidate, and then we'll work with the Senate to get them confirmed.

(pausing for a moment, reflecting on the question) Ah, the devastation of Hurricane Katrina. It's a tragedy that still weighs heavily on my heart, and I think about it often. You know, I've had a lot of time to reflect on that period, and I believe that in hindsight, there are certainly things that could have been done differently, things that I could have done differently.

First and foremost, I think I could have been more visible and more vocal, more quickly, in expressing my concerns and my frustrations with the situation on the ground. I remember flying over the Gulf Coast and seeing the devastation firsthand, and it was just... it was just breathtaking. And I think I could have done a better job of communicating that sense of urgency and concern to the American people, and to my own administration, for that matter.

I also wish that I had been more forceful in my conversations with the leadership in Louisiana, particularly with Governor Blanco. I think we could have worked more closely together to get more resources on the ground more quickly. And I think we could have done a better job of anticipating and preparing for the storm's aftermath.

Now, I'm not second-guessing the good work that many, many people did in responding to that disaster. There were a lot of heroic efforts, and I'm proud of the way that many Americans came together to help their fellow citizens. But, you know, as president, you've got to be willing to look back and say, "What could I have done differently?" And I think if I had to do it all over again, I would try to be more proactive, more forceful, and more visible in the early days of that crisis.

(looking around the room) And I will say, I don't think it's just about the response to Katrina. I think it's also about the broader issue of how we, as a nation, prepare for and respond to natural disasters. We need to be doing more to invest in our infrastructure, to invest in our emergency preparedness and response capabilities. And that's a lesson that I think we can all learn from, and that we can apply to other challenges that we're facing today.

(glancing up) That's my take on it.

Thank you for the question. I'm satisfied with the way the Miers nomination has been handled. It's normal for a nomination of this magnitude to generate some debate and discussion. The Senator's characterization of it being chaotic, I think, may be a little strong.

But, you know, we're not surprised that the nomination has generated a lot of interest, because it's a very important position. And I think Harriet Miers is a fantastic choice. I think she's going to make a great addition to the Court.

Regarding releasing more documents, we've made available a tremendous amount of information about Judge Miers' qualifications and her background, and that will continue to be the case. We want the Senate to have all the information it needs to make an informed decision about her nomination. But I think we've been very transparent, and I think we'll continue to be.

Now, let's just remember that the real issue here is the qualifications of Harriet Miers, and her record, and her commitment to interpreting the law. And I think she stands up very well. She's got a lot of support - some from on the Hill, some from around the country. And I'm confident that she'll do a great job on the Supreme Court.

Thank you for the question. As we move forward, our top priorities remain the same: to protect the American people, to spread freedom and democracy, and to support our troops.

Looking ahead to this time next year, I'd like to highlight a few key achievements we're working towards. First, we hope to have made significant progress in training and equipping the Iraqi Security Forces. We're committed to helping the Iraqi people take ownership of their security, and we're making good progress in that regard.
