Second, we hope to have made significant strides in our efforts to disrupt and dismantle al-Qaeda and other terrorist organizations. We're working closely with our international partners to share intelligence and to coordinate our efforts, and we're seeing results.

Third, we hope to have made progress on the domestic front, particularly in the area of energy policy. We're working to reduce our dependence on foreign oil, to increase our energy production, and to promote new technologies that will help us meet our energy needs in a way that's good for the environment and good for the economy.

Regarding troop levels in Iraq, I'd like to emphasize that our decision to reduce our troop presence will be based on the conditions on the ground. As the Iraqi Security Forces become more capable, we'll be able to transition more responsibility to them, and we'll be able to reduce our troop levels accordingly.

In the best case scenario, I'd hope that by this time next year, we'll be able to reduce our troop levels to around 100,000 or lower. But I want to emphasize that this will depend on the progress we make in the coming year, and we'll continue to work closely with our military commanders and with the Iraqi government to determine the right force levels to achieve our objectives.

Let me make one thing clear: our goal is not to set arbitrary deadlines or to pull out of Iraq prematurely. Our goal is to complete the mission, to help the Iraqi people build a stable democracy, and to ensure that Iraq becomes a partner in the war on terror.

Well, thank you for that question. I've made it clear that I support comprehensive immigration reform, and a guest-worker program is a vital part of that. I believe that such a program would not only help our economy but also help us better secure our borders. It would provide a way for people who are already here, who are working hard and playing by the rules, to come out of the shadows and join the system.

Now, as for whether or not I would veto a bill that didn't include such a program, I'd have to take a close look at the overall bill. But I will tell you this: I've made it clear to the Congress that I expect a comprehensive approach to this issue. A guest-worker program is an important part of that comprehensive approach. And so, it's difficult for me to imagine supporting a bill that didn't have such a provision.

As for the concerns from some of my fellow Republicans, I understand their concerns, and I respect their opinions. But I also believe that this is an issue that requires a comprehensive solution. We can't just focus on one aspect of the problem; we've got to solve the whole problem. And that's exactly what this guest-worker program would help us do.

Now, I've spoken to my fellow Republicans, and I've told them that I believe this is an issue that's not only important for our economy but also important for our party. We need to show the American people that we're willing to take on tough issues and solve them in a way that's fair and just.

So, while I understand the concerns, I'm confident that, in the end, we'll be able to pass a comprehensive immigration reform bill that includes a guest-worker program, and it will be good for our economy, good for our country, and good for the Republican Party.

Well, I appreciate the question. First, let me say that I disagree with the suggestion to abolish FEMA. I believe that FEMA plays a vital role in our nation's response to disasters, and we're working hard to make sure that agency is functioning effectively.

Regarding the lessons of Katrina, I want to assure the American people that we have learned from that terrible tragedy. We've been working diligently to improve our response capabilities, and I'm confident that we're better prepared today than we were just a year ago.

We've taken steps to strengthen FEMA's leadership, to improve our emergency planning and preparedness, and to ensure that our first responders have the resources they need to do their jobs effectively. We've also worked to improve our communications with state and local officials, so we can respond more quickly and effectively in the event of a disaster.

Now, I know that we're not perfect, and we can always do better. But I'm confident that we've made significant progress, and we'll continue to work hard to make sure that we're prepared for any disaster that may come our way.

And let me just say, with hurricane season approaching, we're taking all necessary precautions. We're monitoring the situation closely, and we're working with state and local officials to make sure that they're prepared to respond quickly and effectively. We'll do everything in our power to protect the American people and to minimize the impact of any disaster that may occur.

So, I want to assure the American people that we've learned from the lessons of Katrina, and we're working hard to make sure that we're prepared for whatever challenges may come our way.

Thank you for that question. I want to make one thing very clear: the United States remains committed to finding a diplomatic solution to the Iranian nuclear issue. We've been working closely with our allies, including our fellow permanent members of the UN Security Council, to find a way forward.

As for the current state of negotiations, I would say that we're not there yet. The Iranians have yet to accept the package that we've proposed, which includes a variety of incentives, including economic and energy cooperation, as well as security guarantees. But I remain hopeful that, with continued diplomatic effort, we can find a way forward that addresses the concerns of all parties involved.

As for what Iran stands to gain, it's quite clear: if Iran were to agree to verifiably suspend its enrichment program and cooperate fully with the International Atomic Energy Agency, it would be able to enjoy the benefits of international cooperation, including access to civilian nuclear technology and integration into the world community. And I think that's a pretty attractive prospect.

Now, regarding these recent back-channel overtures from Iran, I can assure you that we take all communications from the Iranians seriously, and we're always willing to listen to proposals that could lead to a peaceful resolution of this issue. However, we also need to be clear-eyed about the Iranian government's history of broken promises and duplicity.

We can't just take the Iranians' word for it; we need to see concrete actions that back up their words. And until that happens, we'll continue to work with our allies to apply pressure on the Iranian government to cooperate.

And let me just say one more thing: the United States will not be deterred from pursuing our goal of achieving a diplomatic solution to this issue. We're committed to working with the international community to find a way forward that addresses the concerns of all parties involved, and we'll continue to pursue that effort until we succeed. Thank you. Next question, please.

Well, I think the American people understand that after 9/11, I had a duty to do what it took to protect the country. And I believe that the programs we put in place were necessary to protect the American people. Now, I understand that there's been litigation on these matters, and I respect the judiciary, the third branch of government.

As I said, I'm the President of the United States, and it's my duty to do what I think is necessary to protect this country. I've had conversations with the Congress, and I'm willing to work with the Congress to make sure that these programs are implemented in a way that's consistent with the Constitution and consistent with what the American people expect.

Now, I don't think that my willingness to work with the Congress is an acknowledgment of any overstepping, because I believe I've acted within the bounds of my authority as Commander-in-Chief. But I do think it's a sign of my commitment to making sure that we work together as a government, the executive branch and the legislative branch, to do what's necessary to protect the American people.

We can have disagreements, we can have discussions, we can have debates, but at the end of the day, we've got to make sure that we're working together to protect this country. And I'm committed to doing that, and I'm committed to working with the Congress to find a way forward that's consistent with our values and with the Constitution.

Thank you for that question. Let me make one thing clear: our strategy in Iraq remains the same – to help the Iraqis build a free, self-sufficient, and secure nation. Secretary Rumsfeld's departure was a contentious decision, but I believe it was in the best interest of our nation.

As for the American people's concerns about our engagement in Iraq, I hear their frustration. I understand their desire to see progress in Iraq, and to see American troops come home. We all share that hope. However, we cannot allow our decisions to be driven solely by public opinion or timetables; we must make decisions based on what is in the best interest of our national security.

I've received advice from General Petraeus and other military leaders on the ground in Iraq. I'm committed to working with Congress to develop a bipartisan strategy for Iraq that is flexible, that adjusts to changing circumstances, and that gets the job done.

I'm fully aware that there is skepticism and even cynicism among some Americans about the war. I understand those feelings, but I believe the mission is crucial to the security of our nation and to the stability of the region. So, we'll continue to push forward in a way that reflects the evolving situation on the ground and the advice of our military commanders, while working with Congress to develop the best way forward.

That's a great question, and I appreciate the opportunity to address it. We're deeply concerned about the Iranian regime's pursuit of nuclear capabilities, and we must take a strong stance against them. Now, I understand the delicate balance we have with our European allies, who do indeed have significant trade ties with Iran.

As we move forward with our strategy, we'll work closely with our international partners to ensure that any economic pressure on Iran doesn't unfairly burden our friends and allies. But we also expect them to understand the gravity of this situation and the threat that a nuclear-armed Iran poses to global security.

One approach we're considering is targeting specific sectors of the Iranian economy that are more directly linked to their nuclear program, such as the banking and energy sectors. This would help minimize the impact on our allies while still putting pressure on the regime.

We'll also engage in close diplomatic efforts with our allies to find ways to mitigate any negative effects on their economies. We're all in this together, and we'll work to ensure that we're sharing the burden fairly.

But let me be clear: the Iranian regime must understand that their pursuit of nuclear capabilities will not be tolerated. We'll use all tools available to us to prevent that from happening, and we expect our allies to stand with us in this effort. Thanks for the question.

Thank you, I appreciate the question.  First of all, the Supreme Court's decision is a significant ruling. As you know, I'm a strong believer in the importance of the rule of law, and the Supreme Court has made a decision. We will, of course, abide by that decision.

Regarding the specifics of the issue, I do think it's essential for us to be mindful of the separation of powers. And, you know, the executive branch and the legislative branch will work together to come up with solutions that are reasonable and wise.

Now, as you know, I've been clear on my position on climate change. I believe it's a significant issue, a global issue. And as a matter of fact, the United States has been a leader in reducing greenhouse gas emissions.

Regarding caps, I think it's essential that we be careful and thoughtful before we impose what could be considered a rather significant tax. I believe there's a better way, and that's through the use of technology and encouraging new practices that will reduce greenhouse gas emissions.

I'm also concerned about the economic implications of broad caps on greenhouse gas emissions, and the potential impact on the American economy and, most importantly, the American people.

So, I think the Court's decision is significant, but it doesn't necessarily mean we must impose caps. I think we can find a better solution, one that will protect our environment and also protect the American economy.

Thank you for that question. The issue of missile defense is one that I believe is of utmost importance to the security of our great nation and to our allies in Europe. And, let me tell you, we've had some very good discussions with President Putin on this issue.

I believe that Russia has concerns about the system that we're proposing, but I also believe that once they understand the true nature of this system, they'll see that it's not aimed at them, but rather aimed at rogue nations that would try to threaten our security and the security of our allies.

Now, in terms of concrete steps, we're going to continue to work with the Russians to alleviate their concerns. We'll be providing them with information about the system, about its capabilities, and about our intentions. We'll be engaging in diplomatic efforts, through various channels, to make sure that they understand that this is not a threat to them.

And, I'm pleased to say that Chancellor Merkel of Germany has been very supportive of our efforts on this front. She's been a strong ally, and I'm confident that she'll continue to help us in our efforts to build a more secure Europe, a more secure world.

But, make no mistake, we're going to move forward with this system, because we believe it's essential to the security of our nation and to the security of our allies. And, I'm confident that, with the help of Chancellor Merkel and other leaders in Europe, we can build a system that will protect us all from the threats that we face.

Thank you.

Thank you, appreciate that question.  September is a long time, but it's a fixed point on the horizon where we can assess howIraq is going. I've always said that the troop levels will be conditions-based; in other words, we will be asking our generals, our secretary of defense, Mike, and our national security team to evaluate the conditions on the ground to make determinations about troop levels going forward.

Well, I appreciate the question. I want to start by saying that the incident involving Blackwater was, first and foremost, a tragic loss of life. My thoughts and prayers are with the families of those who were killed. 

With regard to the relationship with Prime Minister Maliki, we are working closely to resolve this matter. We have a significant stake in the success of Iraq, and we have a very good relationship with the Prime Minister and the Iraqi Government. The Prime Minister did express concerns and frustration, which I understand, in the wake of this incident. Our Ambassador, Ryan Crocker, has been in close touch with the Iraqi government, working to understand the facts of this incident.

Now regarding Blackwater and other private security companies, I think it's worth noting that these firms have a critical role to play in securing not just US diplomats and US Embassy personnel, but also other coalition forces and contractors who are helping the Iraqi people rebuild their country. There have been circumstances in which the Iraqi Government has, indeed, requested their assistance.

In terms of accountability – and I believe this is where you're heading – it's true that under the Coalition Provisional Authority Order 17, private security contractors do have immunity from Iraqi law. However, this is a complicated issue, and I have spoken to Secretary Rice and Secretary Gates about it. We need to make sure that our contractors are held to high standards, but also, that we ensure that they are able to carry out their duties safely and effectively.

It's worth noting, however, that these contractors are not above the law. They are subject to US law and the Uniform Code of Military Justice. We are investigating this incident, and if there is wrongdoing, there will be accountability. And I have confidence that the investigation will be thorough and complete.

Now, this incident, in my view, serves as a wake-up call that it's time to start passing laws and deciding what is the best way to handle private security contractors in a theater of operation, be they State Department contractors or Defense contractors. And, as you know, I have asked Secretary Gates and Secretary Rice to review the precisely-balanced laws – or lack thereof – governing security contractors, so that there is a clearer understanding of what rules and regulations apply.

We need to balance the needs of security with our commitment to the rule of law and Iraq's sovereignty.

Thank you for that question. I appreciate the opportunity to discuss this important conference. First of all, I want to thank Secretary Rice for her hard work in helping to bring people together to address the issues in the Middle East.

The minimum expectation I have, and I believe the American people have, is that we will begin to see a commitment from all parties to address the issues that have held back the region for far too long. We're talking about the Israeli-Palestinian conflict, the issue of statehood, economic development, and the issue of political reform in the region.

In terms of what we are offering to Arab nations, we want to encourage them to participate because it's in their interest to do so. We believe that a peaceful resolution to these issues will bring greater stability and prosperity to the region. We're talking about a commitment to economic development, to investment in the Palestinian territories, to support for reform efforts in countries like Egypt and Jordan.

And we're saying to the Arab countries, "You've got a stake in this, too." If we can resolve the Israeli-Palestinian conflict, if we can begin to address the issue of statehood, it will create a more stable and prosperous region, which will be beneficial to all countries in the region.

We're not looking for any specific concessions from Arab nations. We're not looking for them to do anything that's not in their interests. We're looking for them to exercise their influence, their leadership, to encourage all parties to come to the table and begin to make progress.

So, it's a win-win situation. If we can make progress, everyone benefits. And I'm optimistic that we can make some progress, and that's what I mean by saying substantial issues will be discussed. We're not going to be sitting around the table twiddling our thumbs; we're going to be rolling up our sleeves, working hard to begin to address these difficult issues.

Thank you for that question. I've made it clear that the missile defense system we're proposing for Europe is not aimed at Russia, but rather at rogue states, and at the threat of ballistic missiles from terrorist organizations or from countries like Iran. And so, I believe our position is reasonable, our commitment to NATO's Article Five is strong, and we're committed to helping new democracies like Ukraine and Georgia as they continue on a path towards greater integration with the Atlantic community.

Now, I know that Russia has expressed concerns about the deployment of missile defenses. And I've made it clear that we're willing to address those concerns through dialogue and through a commitment to making sure that they understand our intentions. We also have a commitment to countries like Slovakia, the Czech Republic, who are allies of ours and have concerns that they won't be attacked by any nations including potentially Middle Eastern nations, countries, for using the point defense protection we're planning.

Thank you for that question. I appreciate it. We're making progress, but we've still got work to do. I just came from a very productive meeting with the NATO leaders, and I'm pleased to report that several nations have made new commitments to deployments in Afghanistan.

Now, I'm not going to get into specific numbers right now, because I believe that would be not only premature but also not wise. The timetable for deployments is being worked on as we speak, and we'll be announcing those numbers in due course.

But I will tell you this: we do need more troops. The situation on the ground in Afghanistan is difficult. The Taliban is a determined enemy, and they're not giving up without a fight. But I'm confident that with the bravery and skill of our men and women in uniform, we can succeed.

Now, as for the consequences, if those pledges fall short, I think it's safe to say that we'll have to take a hard look at our strategy. We'll have to assess whether or not we've got the resources we need to succeed. But I'm optimistic that we will get the commitments we need. I'm optimistic that our allies will step up, because I believe that this is a critical mission for our common security.

Let me just say, I believe that freedom is the ultimate goal for the people of Afghanistan. I believe that we've made great progress there, but we've still got a long way to go. And I'm confident that with the help of our allies, we can achieve our objectives and bring stability to that troubled region.

Next question, please.

Thank you, buenos días. It's great to be here in Mexico, and I'm looking forward to my visit to Cancun. I appreciate the warm welcome.

Regarding globalization, I want to assure the people of Mexico that my administration is committed to a free and fair trade policy. We believe that through institutions like NAFTA and the WTO, we can promote economic growth, create jobs, and bring prosperity to both our nations.

As for the support to Mexico, I want to emphasize that our relationship is a strong and vital one. We're working closely with President Fox on issues such as border security, trade, and combating organized crime.

Now, regarding the certification process, we've had some concerns about the effectiveness of Mexico's anti-narcotics efforts, and I think it's fair to say that we've seen some progress, but there's still more work to be done. We want to work with President Fox and his government to make sure that Mexico is doing everything it can to combat the flow of narcotics into our country.

As for my trust in President Fox, I consider him a friend and a fellow democrat. We've developed a strong working relationship, and I have faith in his commitment to our shared goals. But I also want to make it clear that our certification process will continue, and we'll be monitoring progress closely.

Ultimately, our goal is to have a relationship that's based on mutual trust and cooperation, and I believe that with President Fox and his government, we can achieve that.

Thank you for that question. I understand the concerns about this issue, and let me tell you, we're walkin' a fine line here. On one hand, we've got a problem with people breakin' the law to get into our country, and that's just not acceptable. We are a nation of laws, and we need to enforce 'em. On the other hand, we've got a practical problem - we've got people who are already here, workin' and contributin' to our economy. And we're talkin' about hard-workin' folks, many of whom are just tryin' to make a better life for themselves and their families.

Now, when it comes to the guestworker program, I believe it's a way for us to acknowledge that we need these workers, and provide a way for them to come here and work legally. It's not a pathway to citizenship, it's just a way to allow 'em to work temporarily. And I think it's a way to deal with the reality on the ground.

As for the competing interests of folks tryin' to come here legally, I understand that concern, and I'm committed to boostin' the efficiency of our immigration system. We're gonna speed up the process, make it more efficient, and make sure that people who are tryin' to come here the right way are treated with respect and dignity. It's a tough issue, but I believe we've got a solution that's gonna work.

Thank you for your question. (pausing for a moment)

First of all, I'd like to say that we're making good progress on building an international coalition. We've had many productive conversations with our allies, and I'm confident that we're going to have a strong team to, you know, deal with the threat posed by Saddam Hussein's regime.

Now, as for the violence in the Middle East, (shaking head) it's a tragic situation, and it's certainly a complicated one. We're deeply concerned about the situation in Israel and the Palestinian territories. But let me be clear: we will continue to pursue our goal of disarming Saddam Hussein, regardless of the other challenges in the region. We believe that this is a critical step towards achieving a more stable and secure world.

( Turning to Tony Blair ) And, Tony, I think it's safe to say that we have had many productive conversations on this issue. Tony's a strong leader, and he shares my commitment to dealing with the threat posed by Saddam Hussein's regime. (looking at Blair with a smile) Tony, would you like to add anything?

 Lean back and give Blair the opportunity to talk

Well, let me assure you that I've been very forthcoming about my involvement with Harken Energy. As a member of the audit committee, I can tell you that we thoroughly reviewed the company's financial statements, but I was not aware of any accounting issues that would lead to a restatement of earnings.

I relied on the auditors, the accountants, and the financial officers of the company to ensure that our financial reporting was accurate and in compliance with the law. I can assure you that I had no knowledge, none whatsoever, of any improper accounting or reporting at Harken.

As a member of the audit committee, my role was not to be an accountant or an auditor, but to provide oversight and direction. I relied on the expertise of others to ensure that our financial reporting was accurate, and I had every reason to believe that it was.

Look, I'm not trying to deflect or avoid taking responsibility. I'm telling you what I knew at the time, and I'm telling you that I relied on others to do their job. And I believe that they did their job to the best of their ability.

Now, I know that there have been some claims made that I should have known more, that I should have been more involved. But let me tell you, I was a part-time director of this company, and I relied on others to provide me with the information I needed to make informed decisions.

I hope that answers your question.

Thank you for that question. The vital role the U.N. plays, in my judgment, is that the U.N. can help facilitate a peaceful solution to the reconstruction of Iraq. It's a role that's crucial for the international community to be involved, to help us achieve that goal.

Now, my vision for the vital role of the U.N. is that it can provide the necessary framework, the necessary resources, and the necessary support for the Iraqi people to rebuild their country. The U.N. has a special responsibility to help Iraq transition from a totalitarian, a dictatorship, to a free society.

As for the debate, I'm not worried about it. I think the debate is healthy. I think there's going to be a lot of opinions, and that's good. We're going to work with our friends and allies to try to find a consensus, to find a way forward that meets the needs of the Iraqi people.

Now, I've spoken to many leaders around the world, and they all want to help. They all want to see Iraq free and peaceful. I'm confident that we'll be able to work through the U.N. to achieve that goal.

And let me just say one other thing: the U.N.'s vital role is not just about conveying the will of the international community; it's also about providing assistance to the people of Iraq, especially the refugees, the wounded, and the children.

So, I'm—optimistic, I'm hopeful that we can get something done through the U.N., and we'll be working closely with them to make that happen. Thank you.

We're making good progress in the search for weapons of mass destruction. We've not yet found any actual, you know, stockpiles of weapons, but we have found some programs and plans and development that's gone on, intel that suggests they had intentions to develop these kinds of capabilities.

Important to note that the Kay report came out, the Iraq Survey Group report came out, and it showed that, while we didn't find the stockpiles that we thought were there, that the Saddam Hussein regime did have a more extensive clandestine capability to develop and deploy these kinds of capabilities.

Now, in terms of seeing eye-to-eye with our leader, I think the British Prime Minister, I mean, we've always had a strong relationship on Iraq, and I think we've drawn closer over the past, I'd say, year or so. I mean, Tony Blair has been a strong supporter of the policy in Iraq, and I'm grateful for that support.

Oil production is an important issue in Iraq, we agree on that. We think it's crucial that the Iraqi people and government take control of their economy and resources and develop a strong and transparent and accountable system for managing their oil revenues, so that those revenues can benefit the Iraqi people and their economy. And we've worked closely together on that.

Well, I appreciate that question. You see, we've got a couple of different situations on our hands here. In Afghanistan, we had a very clear enemy in the Taliban, and the Afghan people, by and large, were eager to see them go. They'd had enough of their tyranny, their brutality, and their efforts to keep the country in the Stone Age. So, when we worked with the Northern Alliance and other freedom fighters to take out the Taliban, we had a pretty receptive audience.

In Iraq, the situation's a little more complicated. Saddam Hussein's reign of terror was more, shall we say, entrenched. He'd been there for a long time, and he'd set up a complex network of informants and enforcers to keep the population in line. Plus, you've got some deep-seated sectarian differences in Iraq that we didn't have to deal with in Afghanistan.

Now, that being said, I will tell you that we're making progress in Iraq. We've taken out Saddam, we're training up the Iraqi security forces, and we're starting to see some real improvements in the security situation. It's just a tougher nut to crack, that's all.

And let me tell you, it's not for lack of trying. Our military's done a superb job in both Afghanistan and Iraq, and I'm proud of the sacrifices they've made. We're gonna keep working at it, keep pushing forward, till we get the job done.

I appreciate your question. I understand the concerns of my fellow Republicans, and I share their commitment to fiscal responsibility. As you know, we've already taken steps to restrain discretionary spending, and I'm committed to continuing that effort.

However, I also recognize that more needs to be done to achieve our goal of halving the deficit in five years. As I've said before, we must take a comprehensive approach to reforming our entitlement programs, such as Medicare and Medicaid. These programs are vital to our seniors and most vulnerable citizens, but they also drive a significant portion of our federal spending.

To address this, I propose that we introduce market-based reforms that bring more competition and efficiency to these programs. For example, we can give seniors more choices and options for their healthcare, which would help drive down costs and improve quality.

Additionally, I'm committed to finding ways to streamline our federal bureaucracy, eliminating waste and duplication, and ensuring that our government agencies are focused on their core functions. We've made some progress in this area already, but there's more work to be done.

Finally, I believe that we must take a closer look at the tax code. Our tax system is too complex, and it's creating unnecessary burdens on our small businesses and working families. By simplifying the tax code and closing loopholes, we can make our tax system more efficient and more fair.

These are just a few of the steps we'll take to cut costs and reduce the deficit. I'm committed to working with members of both parties to achieve our goal of a more fiscally responsible government that serves all Americans.

Well, thank you for the question. First, let me just say that I believe the bravery and resilience of the Iraqi people, in the face of incredible challenges, is something that the whole world can learn from. And I think it's a powerful example for the region, and it's a reminder that democracy is a powerful force that can help to bring people together.

In terms of improving prospects for a Mideast peace, I believe that a stable and secure Iraq, one that's determined to build democratic institutions and protect the rights of all its citizens, is going to be a powerful force for good in the region. And I think it's going to make it easier for other countries to take risks for peace, and to work towards a more comprehensive settlement.

Now, as for the diplomatic dental chair, I can assure you I won't be sitting in it this year, or any time soon. The work of diplomacy is a serious business and it should be done with careful consideration, determination, and working together towards a common goal. Now, the agreements to solve Middle East peace in long-term basis requires that all parties engage in serious and dedicated and good-faith negotiations.

Well, I think it's very important for the American people to understand that we're a nation at war, and we've got to use all the tools at our disposal to protect our citizens. Rendition is a long-standing practice that's been used by our government, and it's a vital tool in the War on Terror.

Now, I know some folks might not agree with the methods we use, but I can assure you that our primary goal is to extract information from these individuals that can help us prevent further terrorist attacks on our homeland. These are not just ordinary individuals we're dealing with – these are people who want to kill Americans, and we need to take action to stop them.

As for the second part of your question, I think it's a bit of a hypothetical situation, but I'll answer it anyway. If foreign agents were to come into our country and take an American citizen without going through the proper diplomatic channels, that would be unacceptable. We expect other nations to respect our sovereignty, just as we respect theirs.

However, let me be clear: I'm not going to discuss the specifics of our methods or the specifics of our counterterrorism operations. We've got to be careful about what we say in public, because we don't want to give our enemies information that they can use against us.

But I will say this: we're a nation that's committed to upholding the law and respecting human rights. We've got a system of checks and balances in place to ensure that our intelligence agencies are operating within the bounds of the law. And I'm confident that our agents are acting in a way that's consistent with American values.

Thank you for the question. I understand the concerns that have been raised, and I want to assure the American people that we do not condone torture. What we are proposing is a set of tools and techniques that can help us interrogate and detain high-value targets, those who pose a significant threat to our national security.

Now, I understand that some of these techniques may push the bounds of what we consider acceptable treatment. But I want to assure the American people that we will always adhere to the principles of the Geneva Conventions, and that we will always treat detainees with dignity and respect.

Regarding Senator McCain's concerns, I have a great deal of respect for him and his service to this country. He is a war hero, and his opinions matter to me. However, I believe that our proposal is carefully crafted to ensure that it does not put our troops at risk. In fact, our intelligence experts tell me that the techniques we are proposing will actually help us gain more reliable intelligence, which will help keep our troops safer in the field.

Look, I understand that this is a contentious issue. But I believe that we need to give our law enforcement and intelligence agencies the tools they need to keep America safe. And I am willing to work with Congress to make sure that we get this right, that we find the right balance between security and civil liberties.

(in a Texas drawl) Ah, thank you for that question. Well, I'll tell you this: I do believe that I was able to get a sense of Vladimir Putin's soul, as you put it, when we first met. And at that time, I did believe that he was a man we could work with. Now, that doesn't mean we agree on everything, and we certainly don't.

What we're seeing now is that Russia is trying to reassert its influence on the world stage, and that's led to some disagreements. But I still believe that we can have a constructive relationship with Russia, and I think it's essential that we do. However, we can't just sit by and let our concerns about their actions go unaddressed. We're gonna keep talking, keep trying to find common ground, but at the same time, we're gonna stand up for what we believe in, especially when it comes to security and democracy.

As for whether Putin has changed, I think it's fair to say that his tactics have become more assertive, but that doesn't mean our values and principles have to change. We'll keep reaching out, keep engaging, but also keep holding firm on the things that matter most to us.

Let me make one thing clear: our commitment to freedom, to democracy, and to the security of our allies remains strong. And we're gonna continue to work with Russia where we can, but we'll also stand up to them when we have to. That's the American way.

The whole notion of this being based on loyalty to me, George W. Bush, is simply not true. What we were looking for in these U.S. attorneys was people who would carry out the policies of the administration. Loyalty, in this context, means loyalty to the Constitution and to the laws of the land.

Now, I believe that the attorney general and I have the authority to make the decisions we made. The U.S. attorneys serve at the pleasure of the President. We have the right to evaluate their performance based on an array of factors, including whether or not they're carrying out the laws of the land, whether or not they're supporting our policies.

I must say, however, that I'm a little frustrated with this notion that somehow there was a litmus test for loyalty to me personally. I say that's not true. The American people expect their U.S. attorneys to enforce the law, to do their job in a way that is consistent with the values of our great country. And that's what we expected.

And I also want to remind you that we've also found that there's been a lot of misinformation and speculation about this whole issue. We're happy to work with Congress to get to the bottom of this. We're happy to provide documents. But I just want to assure the American people that the decisions we made were based on a careful evaluation of who's best suited to carry out the duties of the U.S. attorney's office.

We've also got to get this into perspective. This is a normal part of the transition of a Presendency. U.S. attorneys are changed. It's not unusual for an administration to replace U.S. attorneys. I think it's about time for the media and others to move on to more important things.

Thank you for asking, though.

Thank you for that question. I'm concerned, of course, about the housing numbers. I think it's a serious issue. But I also believe that the fundamentals of our economy are strong. We've got low unemployment, low inflation, and we've got a strong labor market.

Now, I know that the housing market is an important part of our economy, and I think the decline in housing starts is a cause for concern. But I also believe that we're taking steps to address the issue. We've already passed the Economic Stimulus Act, which provides tax incentives for housing and for small businesses. We've also taken steps to improve the availability of affordable mortgages.

I think it's also worth noting that the Federal Reserve is keeping a close eye on the economy, and they're taking steps to ensure that the economy remains strong. I have confidence in Chairman Bernanke and his team at the Fed.

In terms of what more we can do, I think we need to continue to focus on the fundamentals. We need to keep our economy competitive, we need to keep our tax rates low, and we need to keep promoting job creation.

I'm also open to considering additional steps to address the housing market, but I think we need to be careful not to overreact. We don't want to stimulate the housing market in a way that would lead to artificial inflation or other unintended consequences.

Overall, I'm concerned, but I'm not panicked. I think we're taking the right steps, and I'm confident that our economy will continue to grow and thrive.

And I'll just say one more thing. This is a global economy, and we're not immune to events beyond our borders. But I think we've got the right mix of policies in place to keep our economy strong, even in the face of global challenges.

Well, I appreciate the question. Let me tell you, we're watching the situation in Pakistan very closely. And I'm concerned, I'm deeply concerned, about the events that are unfolding there. But I want to remind you that President Musharraf has been a valuable ally in the War on Terror, and his cooperation has been crucial in helping us take down key Al-Qaeda leaders and disrupt the terrorist networks that pose a threat to our security.

Now, I understand the concerns about the state of emergency he's declared, and I've expressed those concerns directly to him. But I also believe it's essential to recognize the complexities of the situation on the ground in Pakistan. We want to see the return to democratic rule, no question, but we also don't want to push Pakistan in a direction that would allow the extremists to take over.

So I would reject the idea that there's a double standard here. The United States is committed to promoting democracy around the world, and we will continue to speak out for the values that we believe in. But we also have to be realistic about the circumstances on the ground, and we've got to work with our friends and allies to achieve our objectives.

I think we should be judged by our actions, not by some hypothetical yardstick of consistency. We're working hard to support moderate voices in Pakistan, to promote democracy, and to help root out the terrorist threat that's a menace to us all. And I believe that our policy is guided by a clear commitment to our values, as well as a realistic assessment of the circumstances on the ground.

Well, I appreciate the question. Let me address this issue. First of all, I still believe that the world is a safer place without Saddam Hussein in power. He was a tyrant, a dictator who had a history of aggression and a desire to acquire and use weapons of mass destruction.

Regarding Iraq's WMD, there was intelligence suggesting that Saddam Hussein had the intention and the capability to reconstitute his WMD programs. And I relied on that intelligence when I made my decisions. While it's true that we didn't find stockpiles of WMD, I believe we made the right decision to take action.

As for Iran, I'm glad to hear that they've halted their nuclear program, but we need to verify that. We need to work with the international community to ensure that Iran doesn't resume its efforts to develop nuclear weapons.

Regarding our credibility, I understand that there are those who disagree with our actions, but I can confidently say that we've taken the right decisions to protect our country and our interests. We're the leader of the free world, and we're going to continue to lead. We're going to continue to work with our allies to build coalitions and to confront threats to global security.

And I reject the notion that we're the "boy who cried wolf." We're a country that's taken seriously the threat of terror, the threat of proliferation, and the threat of tyranny. And we're going to continue to take those threats seriously and take action to address them.

So, I'm not concerned about our credibility. I believe that the world knows that we're a consistent and reliable partner, and that we're committed to defending freedom and defending our allies.

Well, thank you for that question. I think it's clear that we're dealing with a very serious situation, one that demands our attention and action. Now, in terms of recognition, I'd say that we've been monitoring this situation for a while now. Our team, led by Secretary Paulson and Chairman Bernanke, has been following it closely.

Now, I'd be the first to admit that we didn't fores— fully foresee the magnitude of this crisis. But I'll tell you this: we're not just sitting on our hands. We're taking action to address the root causes of the problem.

First, we're working to get the markets stabilized. This includes the actions we took last weekend, like the rescue package for Bear Stearns, and we're considering other measures to shore up the system.

Second, we're supporting the continuity of our financial institutions. That's critical to maintaining confidence in our system.

And finally, we're looking at ways to address the causes of the crisis, particularly the housing market.

Now, when it comes to specific proposals, I'd rather not get into details until later this week when we'll be laying out a comprehensive plan. But rest assured that we're considering a wide range of options to support homeowners, to stabilize the markets, and to prevent similar crises in the future.

It's going to be a tough road ahead, but I'm confident that with decisive action, we can work through this and keep our economy strong. Next question?

Well, I think it's... interesting that other Presidents are commenting on this matter. As for the Rich pardon, I'll tell you again, I stand by the decision I made. Marc Rich's pardon was reviewed thoroughly by the Justice Department and the White House counsel. It's a normal process that the President makes these kinds of decisions. 

Now, I understand that there may be differing opinions, and I respect those opinions. But I'm the one who made the decision, and I feel that the decision I made was the right decision. It's not unprecedented for presidents to grant pardons; it's a power given to me under the Constitution, and I followed the procedures to ensure that it was properly vetted. 

As for the criticism I've received, I'll just say that I hold President Carter in high regard, but we obviously disagree on this issue. I think that's okay, too, in the great American system of government and democracy.

Thank you for the question. I appreciate your concern for the safety and security of our great nation. Vice President Cheney's location is, of course, a matter of national security, and I'm not at liberty to discuss the details. I can tell you that the Vice President is conducting crucial work, and his location is necessary to ensure the continuity of government.

As Commander-in-Chief, I can assure the American people that the safety and security of our leaders, including the Vice President, is of utmost importance. We take all necessary precautions to protect them, and I have every confidence in the work that is being done to ensure their safety.

I'm not going to get into the specifics of the Vice President's location or how long he will remain there. I can tell you that he is carrying out his duties as Vice President and is in close touch with me and the rest of the administration.

Let me be clear: we will not let threats or rumors of threats dictate how we conduct the business of the American people. We will continue to take all necessary precautions, but we will not hide from our duties or our responsibilities. We will continue to lead the nation forward, and we will do so with confidence and courage.

Thank you, and I'm glad you asked that question. As you know, President Putin and I have been working closely together to improve relations between our two nations. And I must say, I'm encouraged by the progress we've made.

First of all, let's talk about the political sphere. We've seen a significant improvement in our dialogue and cooperation on a range of issues, including nonproliferation, counter-terrorism, and regional security. For example, we've worked together to address the threat posed by Iran's nuclear program, and we've made progress on the six-party talks with North Korea.

In the military sphere, we've increased our cooperation on counter-terrorism and nonproliferation efforts, including joint exercises and training programs. We've also begun to explore ways to increase transparency and confidence-building measures in our military relations.

Now, when it comes to the economic sphere, I'm glad to report that we've seen significant progress in recent years. U.S.-Russia trade has increased by over 50% since 2001, and we're working to increase investment flows between our two countries. We've also established a number of new economic initiatives, including the U.S.-Russia Energy Working Group, which is focused on promoting cooperation in the energy sector.

One specific example of our economic cooperation is the agreement we've reached on uranium enrichment. Under this agreement, Russia will provide fuel for U.S. nuclear power plants, and we'll work together to develop a new generation of nuclear reactors that are more fuel-efficient and proliferation-resistant.

So, all in all, I'm proud of the progress we've made in our relations with Russia, and I'm optimistic about the future. We still have a lot of work to do, but I believe that our partnership will continue to grow and deepen in the years to come. Thank you.

Andrew, thank you for the question. As I'm sure you know, the issue of a second UN resolution on Iraq has been a topic of much discussion and debate among world leaders. I can tell you that the Security Council is indeed working on a new resolution, and we're hopeful that our allies on the Council will agree to move forward with it.

Now, I understand that some folks might be skeptical about the need for another resolution. But let me tell you, Andrew, we believe that another resolution is necessary to bring clarity and cohesion to the international community's efforts to disarm Saddam Hussein and hold him accountable for his actions.

By passing another resolution, we're sending a clear message to Saddam Hussein that the world will not tolerate his continued defiance of the UN and his failure to disarm. It's time for Saddam Hussein to take the UN seriously and comply with its resolutions.

Now, I will admit, we are mindful of the fact that France and Russia have expressed some questions about the timing and content of the resolution. We're engaged in active consultations with them and other members of the Security Council to address their concerns.

We believe that a second resolution can provide a vital signal of unity and determination from the international community. And so, I would say, yes, we are willing to spend the time and energy necessary to assemble a coalition on this critical issue.

Thank you, Andrew. I think it's... well, we've had some discussion on this, but I don't think we've finally resolved it, to be honest with you. I think the role of the UN is going to be very important in this process, but I think we're gonna have to work out the details. We're gonna have to work with the UN and the Iraqi people to make sure that this interim authority is one that's representing the Iraqi people, not the interests of the occupying force.

Now, I think what I'd like to emphasize is that the mission of our coalition is to create the conditions for there to be an interim authority that's representative of the Iraqi people. And we'll work with the UN, and I think there's a lot of discussions going on between UN officials and our people, as well as with the Iraqis themselves, about how this is gonna work out.

But I must say, I think the idea of this... of an interim authority is something that we all agree on. We want there to be an Iraqi government that's representative of the Iraqi people, and I think we can work with the UN, and we'll continue to do that, to make sure that we achieve that goal.

Well, thank you for the question. The war on terror has actually strengthened the relationship between the United States and the Philippines. The Philippines has been a valuable partner in our efforts to combat terrorism in Southeast Asia, and we appreciate their commitment to this global effort.

President Arroyo and I have worked closely together to enhance our counter-terrorism cooperation, and I'm pleased to say that our bilateral efforts have yielded positive results. We've seen a decrease in terrorist activity in the region, and we've also seen an increase in the capabilities of the Philippine military to deal with these threats.

Now, beyond the military aspect of our relationship, we want to nurture a broader partnership with the Philippines that promotes economic development, trade, and investment. We believe that a strong and prosperous Philippines is not only good for the Filipino people, but also good for the region and for the world.

To achieve this, we're committed to supporting the Philippines' economic development efforts, particularly in areas such as trade, investment, and infrastructure development. We're also committed to supporting the Philippines' efforts to address the root causes of terrorism, such as poverty and inequality.

In addition, we're also working to strengthen our people-to-people ties, through educational exchanges, cultural exchanges, and tourism. We want to promote a greater understanding and appreciation between our two peoples, and we believe that this will be an important foundation for a long-term and sustained partnership.

So, in summary, our relationship with the Philippines is not just about fighting terrorism; it's about building a broad and comprehensive partnership that promotes peace, prosperity, and stability in the region.

I appreciate the question. First, let me say that the United States is a strong supporter of Israel's right to defend herself. And we believe that Israel has the right to take actions necessary to protect herself from terrorist organizations and states that sponsor terrorism. Now, with regard to the incident you're referring to, I think it's best to call it what it is - an Israeli response to Syrian action, and that the Israelis fully explained to us their reasons for taking this action. 

I obviously condemn all acts of terrorism, and any country has a right to stop, to prevent such acts from happening. And I would encourage the international community to make clear to Syria that harboring terrorist organizations is unacceptable behavior.

Regarding the second part of your question, we could work with Palestinian leaders who are committed to dismantling terrorist groups. It's a essential to achieving peace and securing a stable Middle East. And I welcome the Palestinian Prime Minister's commitment to non-violence, but we expect all parties to take concrete steps in order to achieve that goal.

It's a step in the right direction. But we want a comprehensive approach - dismantling of terrorist organizations and reform of the Palestinian government. And our special envoy, General Kofi Annan, will be working with all parties to achieve this goal and we will be holding everybody accountable. Thank you.

You know, I like to think that my personal relationships with the leaders of the G-8 countries are built on a foundation of trust and mutual respect. Now, we don't always agree on everything, that's just the nature of international diplomacy. But, I believe that when you can sit down with someone, look 'em in the eye, and have a straightforward conversation, that helps to build a strong relationship.

And I've worked hard to build those relationships with my fellow leaders. I mean, we've had our differences, particularly with Chancellor Merkel of Germany and President Chirac of France on issues like Iraq, but we've always maintained a level of respect and a commitment to working together on common goals like fighting terrorism and promoting global economic growth.

You know, I recall a conversation I had with Vladimir Putin at the G-8 Summit in Evian, where we had a real difference of opinion on the issue of Iraq. But, we were able to set that aside and work together on other issues like non-proliferation and energy security. That's what these personal relationships are all about.

Now, I'm not naive, I know that policy differences can sometimes create tension, but I believe that when you can separate the policy differences from the personal relationships, that's when you can really get some work done. And that's what I've tried to do in my relationships with my fellow leaders. Thank you.

Yes, I can say that. I have said that the two-state solution is in the best interests of Israel, in the best interests of the Palestinian people, and in the best interests of the region. We've got a lot of work to do to get there, but I believe it's a realistic goal. I believe it's an important goal. And I believe that, with courage, with will, and with negotiation, that we can achieve it.

Now, I know it won't be easy. I know there's a lot of issues, a lot of difficulties that need to be worked through. But I firmly believe that the concept of the Jewish people having a homeland is in the best interests of the world, and that concept also requires that we have peace. And the best way for there to be peace is for there to be a Palestinian state that can coexist in peace with Israel.

So, that is the goal, and that's what we'll be working towards, and I believe that we'll make good progress between now and the end of my term in office.

Well, thank you for your question. Let me be clear: we will do what it takes to protect this great nation and the American people. Rendition is a vital tool in our fight against terrorism. Its purpose is to transport individuals who pose a threat to our national security to a third country where they might face prosecution. I'm well aware of concerns regarding some of these countries' human rights records, but I can assure you that these are not decisions we take lightly.

I want to emphasize that our policies on rendition have been developed to ensure compliance with U.S. laws, including our torture treaty obligations. We take allegations of mistreatment seriously and investigate them. We do not, I repeat, do not transport individuals to countries with the intention that they will be subjected to torture.

I understand the concerns, but it's essential to note that these operations have helped us disrupt plots, prevent further terrorist attacks, and bring to justice those who have committed heinous crimes. Our priorities remain, first and foremost, the safety and security of the American people.

However, it's a delicate balance we walk in this war on terror – finding a balance between being a humane and compassionate society and protecting our citizens from those who seek to harm us.

Thank you for your question. As I've said before, our mission in Iraq remains a vital part of the global War on Terror. The Iraqi people have made tremendous progress since the fall of Saddam Hussein, but we've all been sobered by the increased violence in recent times.

Regarding our focus, I've decided to sharpen it because I believe it's essential that we make progress on several fronts, not just military but also economic and diplomatic. We must continue to support the Iraqi forces as they build their capacity, and at the same time, we need to encourage the Iraqis to take ownership of their future.

Now, with regards to the Vice President's assessment, I understand that the enemy is indeed wounded, but we must not underestimate them. They still pose a threat, and it'll take a sustained effort to secure victory. We should not misinterpret the enemy's willingness to fight as a sign of their strength, but rather as a sign of their increasing desperation.

Our commanders on the ground and our experts here in Washington agree that the insurgency is being severely strained, and their losses are mounting. However, I do not believe it is accurate to say that they are in their last throes just yet. This is still a very tough fight, and we will see more days of tough fighting ahead.

So we will stay the course, support our troops, and bolster the Iraqis as they work towards stability and security. We're making progress, but we must remain vigilant and determined. This is an effort that will require patience, and I ask the American people to stand by our troops and our mission in Iraq.

Thank you for the question.  Yes, we do view Iran as a threat, particularly in terms of their nuclear ambitions and their support for terrorism. But, as I've always said, diplomacy is a way to achieve our objectives and to push both parties to the negotiating table.

Now, the discussions with Iran - and let me emphasize that these are discussions, not negotiations - would focus on one issue and one issue only: stabilizing Iraq. Our goal would be to determine whether the Iranians are truly willing to work towards a peaceful, democratic, and sovereign Iraq, and to commit themselves to stopping the flow of arms and foreign fighters into the country.

We're not going to dance around the nuclear issue forever, and Iran must recognize this as a separate and distinct challenge that needs to be addressed. As a matter of fact, the discussions with the EU3 regarding the Iranian nuclear program will continue, and that remains our top concern. However, this separate channel could help to keep those broader issues in context.

And to answer your question on the risk, let's be clear: it would be self-defeating to let another purely contentious issue - such as their nuclear program - consume and stop these talks. The goal of the initial talks would be to simply explore if a mutually beneficial atmosphere can be established to further Iraq's post-Saddam progression.

However, on a separate track, the United States is prepared to move forward toward deeper engagement should Iran choose to demonstrate different behaviors.

Thank you for that question. We've been working closely with our international partners, including Japan, to address the growing concerns surrounding North Korea's nuclear program. The decision to drop the sanctions threat was a pragmatic one, aimed at increasing the likelihood of a unified international response.

You see, we want the North Koreans to know that we're serious about their provocative behavior, but we also want to leave the door open for dialogue. By removing the sanctions threat, we're creating space for a diplomatic solution.

Now, as for penalizing a country that's already isolated, I understand the concerns about tightening the screws on an already impoverished people. But let me be clear: the North Korean regime's actions are a direct threat to regional and global security. Our goal is not to punish the North Korean people, but to change the behavior of their government.

We're working with our international partners to target our efforts at the regime, while also providing humanitarian assistance to the people of North Korea. We believe that by isolating the regime, rather than the people, we can make progress toward a more stable and secure world.

It's a delicate balance, but one that we're committed to maintaining. We'll continue to work with the international community to address this challenge in a way that's both firm and constructive. Thank you. Next question, please.

Thank you for the question. I want to first express my deep concern about the escalating violence in the Middle East, and the humanitarian toll it's taking on innocent civilians. It's a very serious and delicate situation.

President Putin and I have been in close touch, and we've been working together to try to find a way to bring an end to the violence. We agree that the immediate priority is to stop the bloodshed and get a cease-fire in place.

Now, I understand there are differences among our allies about the use of force by Israel. And I want to make it clear that we're not going to agree on everything. But what we can agree on is the need for restraint, the need for calm, and the need for an immediate end to the hostilities.

As for the United States, we're going to continue to work with our partners in the region to try to find a way to bring an end to this violence. We're going to continue to urge all parties to exercise restraint and to work towards a peaceful resolution.

It's a complicated and difficult situation, but I'm committed to doing what's necessary to help bring peace and stability to the region. And I'm committed to working with President Putin and other world leaders to achieve that goal.

We'll also continue to provide humanitarian aid to those who are affected by this violence. We'll do our part to alleviate the suffering, and we'll continue to work towards a long-term solution that brings peace and stability to the region.

In terms of specifics, we're going to continue to work through diplomatic channels, through the United Nations, and through direct engagement with the parties involved. We'll also be working with our allies to see if there's a way to get a revival of the peace process, to get the parties back to the table, and to work towards a lasting resolution.

It's a tough situation, but I'm confident that with the combined efforts of the international community, we can find a way to bring peace and stability to the region. Thank you.

I think I need to clarify that I didn't exactly say that. I said that Osama bin Laden is a terrorist, a killer, someone who has no regard for human life, and I believe he's a threat to the United States and to the free world.

Now, when it comes to hunting down Osama bin Laden, I will remind the press corps that we are making progress. We're working with our allies, we're working with the Afghans, we're working with the Pakistanis to bring this man to justice.

But I'll tell you, we're not just focused on bin Laden. We're focused on dismantling the al-Qaeda network, which is a vast and sophisticated network that seeks to harm America and harm our allies.

As for resources, I can tell you that we are committed to using all the resources necessary to bring bin Laden to justice, and to bring the al-Qaeda network to an end. We're working hard to disrupt their financing, their communication networks, and their operations.

But I will tell you, we're not going to micromanage the efforts to bring bin Laden to justice. We're going to give our commanders and our troops the flexibility they need to get the job done.

And I'll tell you, we're making progress. We've already captured or killed many high-ranking al-Qaeda officials, and we're going to keep the pressure on until the job is done.

Well, thank you for the question. As the President of the United States, I've had the opportunity to work with a number of leaders in the region, including President Vazquez of Uruguay and President Chavez of Venezuela.

First, let me say that I believe in the importance of strong, democratic institutions in our hemisphere. And I think that's one area where there are some differences between some of the leaders in the region. President Vazquez, for example, has been a strong supporter of democratic institutions and has worked to strengthen the economy and promote social justice in Uruguay.

On the other hand, I've had my differences with President Chavez. While he was elected democratically, I've been concerned about some of the steps he's taken to consolidate power and restrict individual freedoms in Venezuela. And I've also been concerned about some of the rhetoric he's used, particularly with regard to the United States.

Now, in terms of similarities, I think all of these leaders share a desire to promote economic growth and development in their countries. And I think they all recognize the importance of trade and investment in achieving that goal.

As for Uruguay, I have a lot of respect for President Vazquez and the Uruguayan people. Uruguay is a strong democracy with a long tradition of stability and the rule of law. And I think President Vazquez has done a good job of promoting economic growth and social justice in his country.

One area where we've worked closely with Uruguay is on trade. We recently completed a free trade agreement with Uruguay, which I think will help to promote economic growth and job creation in both our countries.

Overall, I think President Vazquez is a leader who shares our commitment to democracy and free markets, and I look forward to continuing to work with him to promote a more prosperous and secure hemisphere.

Thank you for that question. From my perspective, the threat posed by Iran is a matter of grave concern, not just for the United States, but for the entire international community. As we all know, the IAEA has raised serious questions about the nature of Iran's nuclear program, and their enrichment activities, which we believe pose a risk of them developing a nuclear bomb.

Now, I'm not going to speculate about the use of force, but I will tell you that all options are on the table. We will continue to work with our friends and allies to try to convince the Iranian regime to stop their pursuit of nuclear weapons. We believe it's in their interest, it's in the interest of the Iranian people, and it's in the interest of the entire region.

As I prepare to go to the U.N. next week, my message will be clear: we will not tolerate nuclear proliferation. The international community has spoken through the Security Council resolutions, and Iran must comply with those resolutions. We'll work with our friends and allies to try to find a peaceful resolution to this problem, but make no mistake, we will defend our interests, we will defend our friends, and we will defend the security of the world from the threat posed by a nuclear Iran.

And to my friends in Europe, and particularly to the French, I say we appreciate your willingness to join us in this cause. We will continue to work closely together to convince the Iranians to abandon their nuclear ambitions, and to find a peaceful solution to this problem.

But let's be clear: the burden is on Iran. They must choose a different path, a path that leads to prosperity, to stability, and to a future that is peaceful for their people and for the world.

Thank you for that question. You know, I've had the privilege of serving this great nation for seven years now, and I've learned a thing or two about what it takes to be a good leader. In my opinion, experience in government is incredibly important. You can't just walk into this job without knowing how to get things done in Washington. You gotta know how the system works, how to build coalitions, how to work with Congress.

Now, I'm not saying that's the only thing that's important. You've also got to have core principles, a strong sense of values. For me, my faith has always been a guiding light. As a Methodist, my faith has taught me the importance of compassion, of helping those in need, and of standing up for what's right, even when it's hard.

Now, I don't think a candidate's specific denomination is as important as their values and their character. What I care about is whether they're a person of integrity, whether they're honest, and whether they're willing to make tough decisions.

But I do think that a candidate's worldview, shaped in part by their faith, can be an important factor in how they make decisions. You see, as President, you're not just making decisions for yourself, you're making decisions for the entire country. And if you don't have a strong sense of what's right and wrong, it's easy to get swayed by special interests or polls.

So, to answer your question, I think experience in government is crucial, but it's not the only thing that matters. A candidate's values, their character, and their worldview are just as important. And as for their religious views, I think it's okay to ask questions, but what matters most is whether they're a person of integrity and principle.

Wait a minute, I think there's been some confusion here. I'm President George W. Bush of the United States, and I'm happy to answer questions from the press corps, but I'm not here with President Kagame at this time.

To answer your question, however, I'd be happy to provide some context. Rwanda and the United States have a strong bilateral relationship, and we've been working together on a number of areas, including trade and investment.

While I don't recall a specific investment treaty that we've signed recently, I can tell you that we've been exploring ways to strengthen our economic ties with Rwanda, and that includes increased investment in key sectors such as energy, agriculture, and infrastructure.

Our goal is to create a more favorable business climate for American companies to invest in Rwanda, and to encourage Rwandan businesses to invest in the United States as well. We believe that this can lead to mutual benefits, including job creation, economic growth, and poverty reduction.

But specifics about a particular treaty, I'd have to check on that and get back to you. Thank you.

Thank you for the question. The Jeddah Summit, as it's being called, is an important meeting, and I appreciate the Saudi Kingdom's willingness to host it. As for my attendance, I can tell you that I'm very interested in being there, but I haven't made a final decision on that yet.

However, I will say this: We have a crisis in America when it comes to gas prices. It's affecting our economy, it's affecting the lives of American families, and I'm committed to doing everything we can to address this issue.

We've taken steps already to try to alleviate some of the pain at the pump, but more needs to be done. So, I'm certainly supportive of participating in this summit, and I'll make a decision on whether or not to attend in the coming days.

But let me be clear: We'll continue to push for a comprehensive energy policy that includes all aspects, from increasing domestic production to conservation to alternatives, like biofuels and nuclear power. We need a comprehensive plan, and we need it soon.

I'll be discussing this further with our allies, including Prime Minister Brown, and we'll make a determination about attendance at the summit based on our own interests and the interests of the American people. Thank you.

Thank you for that question. You know, I've made it clear that we're disappointed in the actions of the Syrian regime. And I've told President al-Asad that in order to improve relations with the United States and the rest of the free world, he's got to take some concrete steps.

First and foremost, he must cooperate fully with the United Nations investigation into the assassination of former Prime Minister Hariri in Lebanon. That's a necessary step, and we expect him to do so.

Secondly, he must stop enabling groups like Hezbollah and Hamas, who are taking innocent lives and undermining the stability of the region. These groups are not friends of peace; they are enemies of peace.

Thirdly, he must begin to respect the sovereignty of Lebanon and allow that country to chart its own course, free from Syrian interference.

And fourthly, he must begin to cooperate with us on the war on terror. We've had problems with Syria in the past, and we expect them to help us in this global effort to defeat the terrorists.

Now, I know that some people might say that by making these requests, we're being too tough on President al-Asad. But I believe that's the wrong way to look at it. We're making these requests because we believe that they're essential to achieving the goals that we all share: stability, peace, and prosperity in the region.

And I've made it clear, by the way, that we're willing to work with the Syrians if they're willing to work with us. We're willing to have diplomatic relations, to have cultural exchanges, to have trade. We want to have normal relations with Syria, but it's going to take some effort on their part.

And I hope that President al-Asad will take these requests seriously, because we're not going to back off. We're going to continue to push for the kind of reform and the kind of behavior that we believe is necessary for the region to be peaceful.

Thank you for that question. Let me be clear: the American financial system is strong, but it's going through a tough time. We took the steps to rescue Freddie Mac and Fannie Mae because they play a critical role in the housing market, and we wanted to stabilize the system and maintain confidence in our economy.

Now, I understand the concern that some institutions may be perceived as "too big to fail." But let me tell you, we don't have a policy of bailouts. What we've done is take steps to address the problems we're facing, and that's what we did with Freddie and Fannie.

I want to assure the American people that our goal is to promote market discipline, to promote transparency, and to promote regulation that works. We've taken steps to strengthen the regulatory framework, and we're committed to making sure that our financial institutions operate in a way that's safe and sound.

Now, I know some folks might say, "Well, this sets a bad precedent." But I believe that in this unique circumstance, where we had a systemic risk to the entire financial system, we had to take action. And we did it in a way that was responsible, that was prudent, and that was fair.

We're going to continue to work to strengthen the system, to make sure that our regulatory framework is robust, and to make sure that our institutions operate in a way that's consistent with the values of this country: free markets, hard work, and personal responsibility. Thank you.

I'm glad you asked that question. As the President of the United States, it's my duty to promote freedom and human rights around the world, and China is no exception.

During my trip to Beijing, I do plan to meet with Chinese leaders, and I will make it very clear that the United States is committed to promoting religious freedom and human rights.

Regarding meeting with dissidents and Christian activists, I will not be meeting with them publicly, as that would likely create more tension with the Chinese government. However, I will be making it clear to the Chinese leaders that the United States values our relationship with China, but that relationship is not at the expense of our values.

As for what actions we plan to take, I've instructed our Secretary of State, Condoleezza Rice, to work closely with the Chinese government to encourage them to take steps to improve their human rights record. We're going to continue to provide humanitarian assistance and we will work with other countries to promote a United Nations resolution on China's human rights record.
