Regarding Saudi Arabia, we do have a good relationship, and I've spoken to the Crown Prince about the importance of a stable oil market. I've made it clear that it's in everyone's best interests to make sure that there's stability in the oil supply. 

Now, I'm not gonna sit here and tell you what level of influence I think I have over Saudi Arabia or their decisions on oil production. What I can tell you is we've had good conversations about this issue, and I'm working with our partners and friends in the region to try to make sure that the world understands the importance of a stable oil market.

But what's also important, and I want to emphasize this, is that we're working on reducing our dependence on foreign oil. We've got to diversify our energy supplies, and that's why I'm pushing for energy policy here in the United States to make sure we've got a comprehensive plan to deal with our energy challenges.

So while we're working with countries around the world to make sure there's stability in the oil market, we're also taking action here at home to ensure we're less dependent on foreign oil in the long run.

Thank you for that question. I appreciate it. I can assure the American people that we're mindful of the lessons of history, including Vietnam. We're also mindful of the nature of this enemy, and we're going to do what it takes to get the job done. I will not set an artificial deadline, nor will I be precipitous in my decision-making.

Now, I will tell you we're making good progress. The airstrikes are effective. The Taliban is reeling. But I will not say how long it's going to take, because I don't know how long it's going to take. I do know that we will, with our allies, with our coalition partners, bring to justice those who perpetrated this act. And we will do it in a way that's decisive and effective.

And I want to assure the American people, we're going to do everything we can to protect our troops, to make sure they've got the resources they need to do the job. We're going to do it in a way that minimizes loss of innocent life, and we're going to do it in a way that ultimately results in the defeat of the terrorists and the removal of the Taliban.

So, I understand the concern, but I want to assure the American people that we're thinking long-term, we're thinking strategically, and we're not going to be deterred.

Well, thank you for that question. I appreciate it. First of all, I believe that our policy has been clear from the start, and that is that we expect Iraq to disarm, to comply fully with the U.N. resolutions. I've made it clear that we will not tolerate any noncompliance, any threating gestures by Saddam Hussein. 

Now, the question of whether we're looking for a pattern of behavior is a tactical issue. And I think what Secretary Rumsfeld and Kofi Annan are trying to express is that we're not going to be, you know, trapped by a single incident. We're going to look at the overall performance of Iraq and see whether or not they're making a good-faith effort to comply.

But let me be clear:  I expect Iraq to comply. I expect them to disarm. I expect them to meet the conditions laid out by the international community. And if they don't, we'll be taking very seriously our options, and we will take whatever action is necessary to enforce U.N. resolutions and protect our national interest.

Now, we're working very closely with the United Nations. We're working closely with Kofi Annan and his team, as well as other members of the Security Council, to make it clear that this is a test not only of Saddam Hussein's intentions, but of the international community's willingness to stand up for what we believe in. And we're going to, I think, pass that test, and we're going to make it clear to Saddam Hussein that he's got one final chance to comply.

Well, thank you for that question. Let me tell you, the 9/11 report, it's a complex issue. We've worked hard to declassify as much of the information as we can, while still protecting our national security and sources and methods of our intelligence agencies.

Now, regarding Saudi Arabia, we've had a long-standing relationship with them, and we've worked closely together on counter-terrorism efforts. They've been a strong partner in the global fight against terrorism, and I believe that will continue.

It's my judgment that this decision will not affect our relationship with the Saudi government, nor will it impact their efforts to counter terrorism. Saudi Arabia has a vested interest in battling the terrorist threat, just as we do.

Now, I do understand that there are some concerns, there are some concerns about the classified information that's not being released. But let me assure you, we've been through this thoroughly, we've taken a very deliberative and careful approach to declassify as much as we can, while still protecting our national security interests.

As for qualms, I'm confident in the decision we've made. We're doing the best we can to balance the need for transparency with the need to protect our national security. That's my responsibility as the Commander-in-Chief, and I'm confident that we've struck the right balance here.

So, I'm not worried about the impact on our relations with Saudi Arabia or their efforts to counter terrorism. We'll continue to work closely with them, just as we do with many other countries around the world, to battle this global threat. Thank you. Next question.

Thank you for the question. I think Senator Kerry's comments were misinterpreted by some, and I'm not sure that's exactly what he was getting at. I believe he was trying to make a broader point about the role of faith in public life.

Now, as for me, I'm very proud of my faith. I believe it informs my decisions, and I'm unapologetic about that. I think it's perfectly fine for people to talk about their faith and how it affects their decisions. I've always been open and upfront about my own faith, and I'm glad to have a bipartisan group of faith leaders who have stood with me on many issues.

I do think, though, that we have to be mindful of the role of faith in public life. It's not just about me or Senator Kerry; it's about how we make decisions that affect the American people. And I believe that when it comes to issues like stem cell research, we have to be careful to make decisions based on the best science and the best ethics, and to try to find common ground where possible.

But I don't think there's anything wrong with being open about one's faith. In fact, I think it's essential. And I'm glad to be able to talk about it, and I'm glad to have a relationship with faith leaders across the country who help me make some tough decisions.

Thank you, thank you very much. I'm glad to be here today to talk about the Middle East, a region that's very important to our national security and to the stability of the world.

First of all, I want to make it clear that my goal, our goal, is to create an environment in the Middle East where democracy and freedom can flourish. We believe that the best way to bring about peace and stability in the region is to promote democratic values and democratic institutions.

In the next year, I'd like to see the Iraqi people continue to make progress towards building a sovereign, democratic government. We've made significant strides in that regard, but there's more work to be done. I'd like to see the Iraqi security forces become more capable of defending their own country, and we'll continue to support them in that effort.

In Afghanistan, I'd like to see the Taliban and Al-Qaeda continue to be defeated, and for the Afghan people to consolidate their gains towards building a free and democratic society. We'll continue to support our friends in Afghanistan, President Karzai and the Afghan people, as they make progress towards stability and prosperity.

In the Israeli-Palestinian conflict, I'd like to see the parties make progress towards a two-state solution, where Israelis and Palestinians can live side by side in peace and security. We'll continue to support the roadmap for peace, which envisions a Palestinian state that's free and democratic, and secure for all the people of the region.

In Iran, I'd like to see the Iranian government listen to the voice of its people, and to begin to take steps towards greater freedom and democracy. We'll continue to support the people of Iran who are yearning for freedom and democracy.

In Lebanon, I'd like to see the Lebanese people continue to consolidate their democratic gains, and for the government to be able to exert its authority throughout the country. We'll continue to support the Lebanese government and the Lebanese people as they make progress towards stability and prosperity.

And finally, I'd like to see the Gulf states, our friends in the Gulf, continue to take steps towards greater freedom and democracy. We'll continue to support our friends in the region as they make progress towards stability and prosperity.

These are ambitious goals, but we're committed to working towards them, and we believe that with the support of our international partners, we can make a real difference in the lives of the people of the Middle East. Thank you.

Well, thank you for that question. You know, I've always believed that it's in our nation's interest to promote freedom and democracy around the world. It's not just a moral imperative; it's also a strategic imperative. When people are free, they're more likely to be our friends and allies.

Regarding the troop issue, I believe it's crucial for the United States to support our friends and allies who are working towards democratic progress. We've got a responsibility to help those who are seeking freedom and democracy, and we've also got a responsibility to protect our national security interests.

Now, when it comes to separatist regions, it's a complex issue. My commitment to democracy is unwavering, but that doesn't necessarily mean that we support independence for every separatist region. We've got to look at each situation on a case-by-case basis.

As I've said before, our goal is to promote democracy and freedom, but it's also to promote stability and security. We've got to be careful not to inadvertently fuel separatist movements that could lead to more instability and conflict.

So, what we're trying to do is support democratic development and reform, so that people have a stake in their future and don't feel the need to seek independence. We want to work with governments and peoples to build institutions, to promote economic development, and to support the rule of law.

Ultimately, the question of independence is a decision for the people of a given region to make, but we'll always support those who are working towards democracy and freedom. That's our commitment. That's what we stand for as a nation.

Thank you for the question. I appreciate the Chancellor's concerns, and I understand why she's raised this issue. We've been working closely with our international partners, including Germany, to address the situation at Guantanamo.

As you know, the detention center at Guantanamo was established to hold enemy combatants who were picked up on the battlefields of Afghanistan and elsewhere. Our goal has been to find a way to safely and securely bring these detainees to justice, while also ensuring that we're protecting the American people from further terrorist attacks.

I've authorized the Secretary of Defense to work with the Department of Justice and the State Department to explore options for closing the facility, but we need to make sure that any decisions we make are consistent with our national security interests and that we have a plan in place to handle the detainees in a way that protects the American people.

We've already made significant progress in reducing the number of detainees at Guantanamo, and we're committed to continuing that process. However, we cannot simply release these individuals into the general population, as some of them have been determined to be a threat to our national security.

I'm willing to consider alternative approaches, but we must ensure that any solution we adopt is one that protects the American people and our allies, while also upholding our values and our commitment to the rule of law.

(turning to Chancellor Merkel) Chancellor, I'd be happy to hear your thoughts on this issue and how we can work together to address your concerns.

Well, thank you for your question. I appreciate it. The plan we put forth is a vision for peace, it's a two-state solution, just as you mentioned. It provides for the Palestinian people to have their own country, their own state, based on certain conditions, which are delineated in the plan. I believe it's very important to have a vision of what could be. It is not a dictate, it is not a, you know, a "here's the deal, take it or leave it," but rather, it's, this is what could happen.

And so, we strongly believe in the two-state solution, and I believe there are many Israelis and Palestinians who want a two-state solution as well. Now, we certainly believe the Palestinian leadership needs to be involved in any discussions about this plan. And the reason we brought the plan out is we want to facilitate the discussions to be able to figure out the better way forward.

And it's not a determination that Israel's final borders will not be negotiated. But what it does do, is give a clear vision to where to go. It's like, you know, when you're trying to get to a big city, I'm trying to get to New York City. It's good to have a map. It's good to know the direction you're headed. And that's what we provided, is a direction for a two-state solution that we think could be beneficial to both sides.

It's very important, however, for people to recognize that there are still issues that will have to be discussed and resolved. And the issues that can't be resolved off the bat, such as borders, refugees, Jerusalem – there's the concept of Jerusalem and what happens to it in the future, and also, the importance of ensuring that this state should be sovereign, but not created as a takeover of another state but extending the rights of the people in Judea and Samaria, would still have to come about.

Let me make it clear to you. No, these weren't take-it-or-leave-it proposals put on the table. It is a series of the whole base of proposals and potential visions for continued dialogue and fruitful negotiations so that both sides can be better off for coming together for their mutual betterment.

Thank you for the question. Well, I think it's always wise to be cautious when dealing with situations like this. We've confirmed that Zarqawi is no longer a threat, and that's a significant development in our efforts to bring stability to Iraq. But I also want to remind everyone that this is a continuing operation. The work of our brave men and women in Iraq is far from over.

We've got to stay focused on the big picture. We can't just declare victory and then see the terrorists regroup and start causing more harm. The fact that Zarqawi's been taken care of does not mean that the insurgency is going to go away instantly. We've still got a lot of work to do.

Now, when Saddam Hussein was captured, that was a major milestone. We've been saying that this was a guy who had the potential to be a major threat to the security of our country, and by capturing him, we also achieved a significant goal of the multinational force in Iraq.

In this case, I do think Zarqawi's death is a significant blow to the insurgency, but we've got to be measured in our response. We cannot be shouting "mission accomplished" when, in fact, there's still much work to be done.

Thank you for that question.  Well first, the U.S. government has achieved some significant objectives when it comes to North Korea. First of all, we've worked to reduce the threat of North Korea's nuclear program. We've gotten them to agree to the denuclearization of the peninsula, and we've also gotten them to agree to inspections, to have the international community come in and verify their compliance. That's a major achievement.

Secondly, we've worked to interdict shipments of dangerous materials, like missile components, that North Korea was seeking to acquire from other countries. We've worked with our allies, like Japan and South Korea, to strengthen their defenses, to make sure they're better prepared to deal with the North Korean threat.

Now when it comes to the Six-Party Talks, those talks were designed to bring the key stakeholders in the region together to discuss the issues, try to resolve the issues. And I believe they've been productive. Now, I know some of my critics say, "Why are you still talking to them, the North Koreans, if they're not living up to their commitments?" And my response is, "We're talking to them because we're trying to change their behavior."

Now I understand that some people may think that's naive. I don't think it's naive. I think it's necessary. Because the consequences of failure are too great to ignore this problem. We've got to keep trying to find a peaceful solution.

And let me tell you why I think it's worth continuing the Six-Party process: because the alternative is not a good one. The alternative is an unstable, unpredictable North Korea, potentially with a nuclear weapon, causing chaos in the region. We can't afford that.

Thank you for that question.  I understand the concerns of the Lebanese Prime Minister, and I share his desire to see an end to the violence in the region. We're working closely with our international partners, including the United Nations, to bring about a comprehensive and lasting peace.

Regarding the timing, I would say that we're making progress in our diplomatic efforts, but it's a complex situation, and it's going to take some time to work out the details. We're talking to all parties involved, including Israel, Lebanon, and Hezbollah, to find a solution that addresses the concerns of all sides.

Our goal is to achieve a sustainable cease-fire that will lead to a longer-term resolution of the conflict. We're exploring various options, including a UN Security Council resolution, and we're working hard to get all parties to agree to a framework that will allow for a cessation of violence.

As for the timeline, it's difficult to predict exactly when we'll see a cessation of violence, but I'm committed to making it happen as soon as possible. We're working around the clock, and we're making progress, but it's a difficult and delicate process.

I want to assure the people of Lebanon and the region that we're committed to finding a peaceful solution that will allow them to live in safety and security. We'll continue to work tirelessly to achieve that goal.

Thank you for that question. I'll be glad to answer it, and I'll start. I did have a chance to talk with Chancellor Angela Merkel of Germany earlier today, and with Prime Minister Tony Blair from the United Kingdom. We did discuss the matter at hand, regarding President Wolfowitz.

My advice to Paul is that I think he ought to seriously consider stepping down. I think it would be in the best interest of the World Bank, and the United States publicly supports this notion. The situation at the World Bank, I believe, is ripe for a fresh start, and reform is the agenda that we are all interested in moving forward.

And secondly, I've talked to Chancellor Merkel about this matter. And I'll let them speak for themselves, but I think they'll express similar sentiments. It's been, I think, clear that the United States, the United Kingdom, and Germany are interested in moving forward with reform at the World Bank, along the lines of the governance reform, which is something that Tony will address.

Well, thank you for your question. I've made it clear that I support Paul Wolfowitz, and I think he's doing a fine job as the President of the World Bank. He's a man of great integrity, and I think he's got the leadership skills necessary to do the job.

Now, I understand there's been some controversy surrounding him, and I think it's only fair that those allegations be thoroughly investigated. But I want to emphasize that the President of the World Bank has a very important role to play in helping to eradicate poverty and promote development around the world, and I believe Paul Wolfowitz is the right man for the job.

As you know, the Europeans were very much involved in the selection process when we nominated Paul for this position, and I think they had confidence in him then, and I think they should continue to have confidence in him now.

Now, I understand that the Board of Directors at the World Bank is going to review the allegations and make a decision, and I think it's best to let them do their job. But I want to reiterate my support for Paul Wolfowitz, and I think he's doing a fine job.

Thank you for your questions. First, on Kosovo, the United States has long supported the Ahtisaari Plan, which provides for the supervised independence of Kosovo. We believe this plan offers the best chance for stability and prosperity in the region.

Regarding recognition, we will consider the declaration of independence in the context of the Ahtisaari Plan, and we will work with our international partners to ensure that any steps taken are consistent with the plan's principles.

I want to emphasize that the United States is committed to a future for Kosovo that is safe, secure, and prosperous, and we will work closely with the Kosovo people, the Serbian government, and the international community to achieve this goal.

Now, on Darfur, I appreciate the opportunity to discuss this critical issue. As President of the United States, I'm committed to doing everything we can to help bring peace to the people of Sudan.

We're working closely with the United Nations, the African Union, and other international partners to deploy additional peacekeepers to the region, and we've already begun to do so. We're also committed to supporting the African Union Mission in Sudan, or AMIS, and we've provided financial and logistical support to help it succeed.

But more needs to be done. I believe that the international community, including the United Nations, must do more to support the people of Darfur. We need to move forward with the deployment of a hybrid U.N.-A.U. peacekeeping mission, as proposed by the Secretary-General.

I'm also calling on the Sudanese government to cooperate fully with the international community, to allow the peacekeepers to do their job, and to end the violence against the people of Darfur.

Well, thank you for that question. I think it's a great opportunity for me to talk about our strategy in Iraq and how we're gonna succeed. Now, I know there's a lot of debate about the surge, and I think it's a healthy debate. But let me tell you, I've talked to our commanders on the ground, I've talked to the Iraqi leaders, and I firmly believe that the surge has given us a window of opportunity to succeed.

Now, I know some folks might say, "Well, we should just pull out, get out of there, it's not our problem." But I think that's a mistaken view. We've got a responsibility to help the Iraqi people build a stable government, a democratic government that can sustain itself, that can defend itself, and that can deny safe haven to terrorists.

Now, I think Senator McCain and I have a lot of areas of agreement when it comes to our Iraq policy. We both believe that we need to show patience, that we need to be persistent, and that we need to give our commanders the flexibility they need to succeed.

Now, I don't think it's productive to get into a lot of hypotheticals about what might happen or what might not happen. What I will say is that I believe our strategy is working. We're seeing some progress on the ground. We're seeing the Iraqi security forces step up and take more responsibility. We're seeing a reduction in violence in some parts of the country. And I think that's a good sign.

But let me tell you, it's not gonna be easy. It's not gonna be quick. And it's not gonna be without risk. But I firmly believe that the effort is worth it. The American people expect us to succeed, and I'm committed to doing everything in my power to make sure that we do succeed.

So, I'm not gonna get into a lot of speculative discussion about what might happen or what might not happen. What I'll say is that I'm committed to victory, and I'm committed to doing what it takes to help our troops succeed.

Thank you for the question. I want to assure the American people and our allies that we take the situation in North Korea very seriously. Our position on North Korea's nuclear program is clear: we will not tolerate a nuclear North Korea. 

If North Korea were to restart its plutonium plant, it would be a deeply troubling development, and it would have consequences. We've been working closely with our friends and allies, including Japan, South Korea, China, and Russia, to try to persuade the North Koreans to change their behavior and to dismantle their nuclear program.

We're also working to ensure that North Korea understands that there are consequences for their actions. We've made it clear that we will not reward bad behavior, and we will not respond to blackmail. We'll continue to work with the international community to bring pressure to bear on North Korea to change its behavior.

But let me be clear: we've not resigned ourselves to a nuclear North Korea. We believe that that would be a destabilizing force in the region, and it would be a threat to peace and security. We'll continue to work towards a diplomatic solution, one that would result in the dismantling of North Korea's nuclear program and the re-engagement of North Korea with the international community.

Make no mistake, we're committed to this process, and we'll continue to work towards a resolution that would bring peace and stability to the region. Thank you.

Thank you for that question. I've been following developments in Russia closely, and I'm concerned about some of the steps they've been taking. There's no doubt that Russia has made significant progress in the past decade, especially in terms of economic reforms and their growth. However, there are some disturbing trends that indicate a backsliding on democratic principles.

What troubles me most is the restriction of civil liberties, the emergence of a more authoritarian tone from the Kremlin, and the consolidation of power within a smaller circle. These aren't the signs of a healthy democracy. Russia should be a country that cherishes its democratic institutions, but some of the moves they've made, such as the handling of independent media, NGOs, and especially the case of Mikhail Khodorkovsky, raises serious concerns.

Now, I know some folks might say, 'What's the concern here, Mr. President? Why are we worried about this?' And my answer is, I believe that a strong Russia, a Russia that's stable and prosperous, is in our interests. But a Russia that's not democratic, that's not respecting its own citizens' rights, is not going to be a country that we can work with in a truly strategic partnership.

Now, when I sit down with President Putin in a couple of days, I'll be discussing these concerns with him directly. I'll be reiterating our commitment to Russia's integration into the global economy and our hopes for Russia's playing a more constructive role in the world, but I'll also be clear that our friendship and cooperation have to be based on a set of shared values, including respect for democratic principles and human rights. I expect to have a candid conversation, and I expect us to continue the dialogue that we've had on a range of issues, including non-proliferation and counter-terrorism.

Make no mistake, our relationship with Russia is important, and I'm committed to seeing it flourish. But we also have to be honest about the areas where we disagree, and make sure that we're working together to promote democratic values that we believe are in the best interest of the Russian people and of the world.

Well, that's a very valid question. I appreciate the opportunity to address it. The situation in Iraq is complex, and we always knew it would be a tough fight. The enemy we face there is a determined one, and they've been using tactics that are not only violent but also cowardly.

Now, I understand that General Myers made those comments, and I respect his assessment. But I'd also say that while the insurgency might be as strong as it was a year ago, we've made some significant progress. We've got more Iraqis in uniform, we've got more coalition forces on the ground, and we're seeing a steady increase in the capabilities of the Iraqi security forces.

Now, as for why we haven't been more successful in limiting the violence, I think it's because this is a tough enemy, and it's a tough fight. We're up against an enemy that's got the backing of some external forces, and they've got a lot of resources at their disposal. We're also fighting in a country that's been traumatized by decades of Saddam Hussein's rule, and it's going to take time to rebuild.

But I'm confident that we're on the right course. We're adapting our strategy, we're working closely with our coalition partners, and we're making progress. We've got a new Iraqi government in place, and that's a major step forward. We're also seeing the Iraqi people begin to take ownership of their own security, and that's crucial.

Now, I know it's tough, and I know that there are going to be setbacks along the way. But I'm convinced that we're making progress, and I'm convinced that we're going to succeed.

I think that would be a missed opportunity. I'm glad you brought this up, because I think this is an important issue. The reason I proposed personal accounts is because I believe it's a way to make sure that younger workers have a more modern retirement system that addresses the realities of today's economy. The current system is based on a 1935 system, and we've had a lot of changes since then.

Now, if Congress were to pass a bill that just shored up the system, but didn't provide personal accounts, I would consider it a partial success. We would have addressed the solvency issue, which is important, but we wouldn't have addressed the issue of providing options for workers. I strongly believe that every worker should have the option of having a personalized account, where they can make decisions about their own retirement savings. That's what I've been advocating for.

Now, I'm a reasonable fellow, and I'm willing to listen and see what the Congress comes up with. But I think it's very important for the American people to understand that this is a moment when we can make some important choices about the future of our retirement system. And we ought to take advantage of it.

Thank you for your question. As Commander-in-Chief and a strong supporter of our nation's space program, I believe that the decision to return to space was a necessary step forward. While the Discovery mission has indeed faced some challenges, I'm proud of the work that NASA has done to address these issues and ensure the continued safety of our astronauts.

The fact that we're even having this discussion is a testament to the transparency and vigilance of our space program. We're not taking any unnecessary risks, and I have every confidence in the professionalism and expertise of NASA's top scientists and engineers.

Now, I'd be less than honest if I said I wasn't concerned about the return journey – I am. I'm concerned about the safety of our astronauts, and I'm concerned about the success of the mission. But I also have faith in the skills and training of our astronauts, and I have faith in the preparedness of the shuttle itself.

As for the return next week, I expect it to be a successful re-entry. We've taken every precaution, we've addressed the issues that we needed to address, and I have every confidence that our astronauts will come home safely.

The United States is a nation of pioneers, and we don't shy away from challenges. We face them head-on, and we push forward. And I'm proud of the work that our space program is doing to continue to push the boundaries of what's possible.

Thank you for your question. As Commander-in-Chief, I've had the privilege of working with world leaders to promote a safer and more just world. Regarding the creation of an international community, I do believe that cooperation among nations is crucial for building a more peaceful world.

During my administration, we worked to strengthen our alliances and to build new partnerships to address the complex challenges we face, including the war on terror, proliferation, and poverty. The promotion of justice, peace, and the rule of law has been at the forefront of our efforts.

We've also taken steps to strengthen institutions and mechanisms that promote justice and peace, such as the United Nations. However, I must emphasize that our approach has always been to lead by example, and to work to reform and strengthen these institutions, rather than relying solely on them.

But I do believe that nations must come together to condemn and fight against terrorism, proliferation, and other threats to peace. We cannot allow the forces of tyranny and oppression to threaten our way of life. 

Now, I'd like to add, that as I've always said, America and our friends and allies must work together, free nations, to promote the spread of freedom and the spread of justice, and there's no doubt that a well- functioning international community can certainly play a role in achieving these goals.

Well, I appreciate the question. First of all, I think it's hard to make predictions on troop levels. But I can tell you the strategy that we're working on, and that is to continue to work with the Iraqi troops to get them up to speed, to get them trained, and to get them deployed. And as they become more capable, we'll be in a position to begin to reduce our own forces.

Now, by the end of the year, I think that's an ambitious goal, but it's a goal that I think is possible, if the commanders in the field tell me that it's possible. I trust our military commanders to give me the advice on troop levels, because they're the ones who are on the ground, they're the ones who are working with the Iraqis, they're the ones who understand the dynamics on the ground.

Thank you for the question. I had a good meeting with Prime Minister Anders Fogh Rasmussen, by the way. The Danish have been a stalwart ally in our efforts in Iraq. Now, regarding the Prime Minister's remarks, I believe Maliki is right to be optimistic about the capabilities of the Iraqi security forces. We've seen some very positive developments on the ground, and the training and equipping of the Iraqi military is proceeding well.

With the elimination of Zarqawi, Al-Qaeda's number two in Iraq, it's a significant blow to the terrorist organization. His death will undoubtedly make it more difficult for them to carry out attacks and undermine the government.

Now, regarding the timeline, I think it's a reasonable goal to expect the Iraqis to be able to take more responsibility for their own security in the next 12-18 months. But it's not a hard and fast deadline, it's a goal. We're going to be working closely with the Iraqis to help them build their capabilities, and we'll make adjustments as necessary.

It's also worth noting that the Iraqis are already taking the lead in several provinces, and they're doing a good job. So, I think Maliki's confidence in his own forces is well-placed, and we're committed to helping them achieve that goal.

I'd like to think that on the issue of immigration, we can find common ground across party lines. We've made a commitment to secure our borders, but we also understand that we've got to have a temporary worker program, and we've got to make sure that those people who are here, who are decent folks who are paying their taxes and working hard, have a chance to become American citizens.

I believe the Democrats, as well as Republicans, want to get a bill done. I'm heartened by the fact that the Democratic leaders want to work with us on this issue. We've got to convince the American people that we can, in fact, get a bill done. We've worked hard to identify common ground, and, as a matter of fact, I think we've made some good progress.

I've made it clear that if the bill isn't balanced, if it doesn't address all aspects of immigration reform, I won't sign it. We need to have border security, a temporary worker program, and a pathway to citizenship that's fair and compassionate. If we can agree on those principles, then I'm confident we can get a bill done, regardless of whether it's a Democratic or a Republican Congress. But we'll see. It's going to take some hard work on both our parts to make sure that that happens.

Thank you for that question. I understand the concern that Americans have right now with the rising gas prices. As the President, I want to assure the people that we are doing everything we can to address this issue. 

In the short term, I would advise Americans to be responsible and Conservation-minded with their energy use - carpool where you can, drive slower, maintain your vehicle, and maybe look at buying a fuel-efficient vehicle when you next go to the market for a new vehicle.

We're also working aggressively to increase our nation's energy supply by increasing our refining capacity and addressing infrastructure bottlenecks that are contributing to the pinched supply. We're working to speed through permits and liquefied natural gas terminals - All of those reforms that have been talked about do help increase supplies.

It's going to take a long-term solution to fix this problem, But in this short term, I would advise Americans to be patient.

Thank you, Helen. On the G-8, I do expect that the Middle East and the Arab-Israeli conflict will be on the agenda. The G-8 leaders have a keen interest in this issue, and I'm confident that we'll have a productive discussion.

As for where we'll be by the time we get to Istanbul, I'm hopeful that we'll be on a path towards peace. It's a difficult process, but the parties are engaged, and we're making progress. The Palestinian leadership is showing a willingness to take on the tough issues, and the Israelis are as well.

Now, I want to caution, this is a difficult and complicated process, and there are many steps to be taken between now and a final resolution. But I'm optimistic. The fact that the parties are talking, the fact that we have a road map that we can follow, gives me a sense of hope.

And I think that the international community must stay engaged, must continue to pressure the parties to move forward, to take the tough decisions. We're in the midst of a diplomatic push, and we'll see how successful we are. But I'm optimistic, and I'm hopeful that we can make progress, not just for the people of the region, but for the world.

Thank you for that question. I'm glad you asked. We're doing a number of things, in addition to our energy proposals, to try to mitigate the price of oil. First of all, we're working closely with OPEC to try to increase production. We've had some mixed signals from OPEC, but we're working hard to persuade them that increasing production will not only help the global economy, but it will also help their own economies.

Secondly, we're working to increase our own domestic production. We're working with Congress to open up new areas for exploration and production, both onshore and offshore. We're also working to streamline our permitting process to allow for more efficient and timely production.

Thirdly, we're investing in alternative energy sources, such as nuclear, wind, and solar power. We believe that by reducing our dependence on oil, we can reduce our vulnerability to price shocks.

And finally, we're working to improve the efficiency of our transportation sector. We're working to improve the fuel efficiency of our cars and trucks, and we're investing in new technologies that can help us reduce our oil consumption.

Now, I know these are long-term solutions, and I know that in the short term, we've got to deal with the reality of high oil prices. But I'm confident that by working together, we can address this challenge and create a more secure and stable energy future for our country. Thank you.

Well, I think it's a, uh, it's a misconception, but I understand why it may exist. And I'm here to tell you that our policies are aimed at helping all Americans, not just a certain group of people. We believe in, uh, growth and opportunity for everyone, and I think our tax cuts, for example, have helped people at all income levels.

Now, I will say that we've had an agenda that's focused on making America more competitive in the global economy, and that's benefited businesses of all sizes, not just big businesses. I mean, we've seen, uh, small businesses thrive under our policies, and we're proud of that.

But I will say this: we're not satisfied with the economy yet. We know that, uh, there are still too many Americans who are struggling to make ends meet, who are worried about their job security, or who are feeling left behind in this fast-changing world. And so, we're committed to continuing to work on policies that are gonna help 'em, whether it's, uh, education, or, uh, healthcare, or, uh, job training.

Now, as for what we can do to, uh, overcome this perception, well, I think we just need to, uh, keep talking about the results of our policies, and, uh, show people how they're working. I mean, we can't, uh, just sit back and, uh, let our critics define us. We've gotta, uh, get out there and, uh, tell the good story of what we're doing. And I think, uh, that if people take a hard look at our record, they'll see that we're, uh, fighting for the little guy, too.

It's also worth noting that I've, uh, had a pretty good track record as governor of Texas of helping low-income and minority groups. We increased funding for education and healthcare, and, uh, we made sure that, uh, those who were most in need were taken care of. And I believe that record will, uh, speak for itself.

But I'll, uh, keep trying, and I'll, uh, keep listening, and we'll, uh, keep working to make sure that our policies are benefitting all Americans, not just a select few.

I think I understand where you're going with this. Let me be clear: our nation will not be swayed by the whims of nations who do not share our values. And when it comes to the pursuit of justice and freedom, particularly for those, like Mr. Hattar, who are being unfairly held, we will work with our allies to pressure those nations to do what is right.

Now, being a friend to a nation like Saudi Arabia, who has been a long-standing partner in the region, makes perfect sense. But that does not mean that we will shy away from speaking the truth and calling for the humane treatment of all. Does that clarify?

Well, thank you for that question. You know, I've been thinkin' about this a lot lately, and I gotta say, I'm concerned about the tone in Washington. Now, I think both sides, we're all to blame, in some way or another. But I think it's time for us to take a step back, take a deep breath, and try to find ways to work together.

Now, as for me personally, I'd be the first to admit, I'm not perfect. I've made my share of mistakes, and I've had my own share of passions and emotions, that have probably contributed to the problem. But let me tell you, I've also reached out to the other side, to try and find common ground.

I think we've got to get back to the idea that we're all in this together, that we're all Americans, and that we've got a responsibility to work together, to solve the big problems that face our country. And I'm gonna keep on preachin' that, till my last day in office.

But I also think, that we've got to be willing to listen to each other's ideas, and to try and find the common ground. I mean, it's easy to get caught up in the emotion of the moment, and to start throwin' rocks, and sayin' things we might regret. But I think we've got to be better than that.

So, I take responsibility for my part in this atmosphere, and I'm gonna keep on tryin' to do my part to fix it. And I hope others will join me.

Well, I appreciate the question. I do believe that President Putin and I have had some good conversations about the importance of democracy and freedom. And I was heartened by his speech in Munich, where he talked about the importance of the rule of law and the importance of democracy.

Now, I'm not going to kid you, we've also got some disagreements. I've expressed my concerns about the recent actions in Russia, the prosecution of a prominent businessman, for example, and the concern about the transparency of the election process.

But I do believe, I do believe that President Putin is committed to Russia's prosperity and security. And I believe that a prosperous and secure Russia is a strong, democratic Russia.

So, have we made progress? I think we've made some progress, but I'm not going to stand here and say that we've made all the progress that I would have liked. We still have a long way to go.

I am optimistic, I am hopeful that President Putin will take steps to increase transparency, to respect the rule of law, to make sure that the elections are free and fair. And I'm going to keep pushing him to do so.

But I also understand that I'm not going to agree with him on every issue. But I will tell you, my conversations with him have been candid, they've been straightforward, and they've been productive.

And I think, in the end, it's going to be important for the world to see a Russia that is a partner, not a adversary, a Russia that is a partner in fighting terrorism, a partner in spreading freedom, and a partner in promoting peace.

Well, I think it's clear that the Democrats and I have some fundamental disagreements on policy. One area of great divide is our approach to national security, particularly in the War on Terror. My administration has taken a strong stance against terrorism, and we've made some tough decisions to keep America safe. Some Democrats may not agree with our actions in Iraq, or our detainee policies at Guantanamo Bay. We've also differed on issues like taxes and the economy, with Democrats pushing for higher taxes and more government spending, whereas my administration has pushed for tax cuts to stimulate growth.

Now, I'm not gonna change who I am, and I'm not gonna change my policies just to try to find common ground with Democrats. But I do think there's room for us to work together on some common-sense issues, like education reform and Medicare reform. But at the end of the day, I'm gonna stay true to my convictions and continue to make decisions that I think are in the best interest of the country.

And one thing I'll say, 85 percent of Republicans may be supporting me, but that doesn't mean I'm just catering to them. I'm the President of the United States, and I'll make decisions that are good for all Americans, regardless of party affiliation.

That's a great question. I'd say to the American people, I understand that high gas prices are causing a strain on many families' budgets. It's affecting the way they live, and I empathize with that. And I want to assure them that we're taking steps to increase energy production here at home, as well as working with our international partners to try to ease the supply concerns that are driving those high prices.

We're also taking steps to help those Americans who are struggling by providing assistance through programs like LIHEAP (Low-Income Home Energy Assistance Program) to help low-income families pay for their energy bills.

Now, in terms of politics, I'm going to do what I think is right, regardless of the polls or the headlines. I am committed to our energy policy, and I am convinced that the decisions we are making, even though they're tough in the short term, will pay off in the long term for America.

And I'd also remind the American people that we need to address the root causes of high energy prices – we're consuming too much oil, we're not conserving enough, and we didn't invest in our infrastructure like we should have in the past. We're taking steps to correct those imbalances, and I'm committed to seeing it through, no matter what the price.

Well, I'd like to address that. I think President Clinton has got it a bit wrong. We did have discussions about the threat of al-Qaeda and Osama bin Laden. However, I will admit that our initial focus was on the al-Qaeda network and broader Middle Eastern policy, rather than having a single focus solely on Osama bin Laden.

That being said, we were taking action to address the threat. I had asked the CIA to revisit the al-Qaeda issue and come up with a comprehensive strategy. I had tasked the Joint Chiefs of Staff to refine the military plans, and I had signed several Presidential Directives to outline our objectives.

The CIA did, in fact, produce a comprehensive review of our counter-terrorism strategy in December of 2000, just before I took office. And in the Spring of 2001, Condoleezza Rice, my National Security Advisor, was engaged in a policy review that involved multiple agencies. 

We were taking this threat seriously and working on these issues, and I reject the notion that we were doing nothing, or somehow were asleep at the switch. The 9/11 attacks were a wake-up call to America and our allies, but they didn't catch us by surprise. Before 9/11, we had anticipated that al-Qaeda might be planning large-scale attacks.

So, while the quote that President Clinton gave you might be an oversimplification, I don't accept that we were ignoring the problem. We took the threat seriously and were actively working on a comprehensive strategy.

Well, I appreciate the question. Let me be clear: the decision to have Secretary Rumsfeld continue in his position had nothing to do with the recent elections. I mean, I've got a lot of confidence in Secretary Rumsfeld. He's a good man, a capable man, and he's been doing a fine job leading the Defense Department, particularly as we work to bring terrorists to justice and make America more secure.

Now, I know there's been some speculation about the timing of my announcement, but the truth is we're in the middle of a war, and I don't think it's the right time to be making changes in the Defense Department. We need to stay focused on the mission, and Secretary Rumsfeld is the right man to lead that effort.

I made the decision about Secretary Rumsfeld's future some time ago, and I chose to announce it when I did because it's the right time for the American people to know that we're going to stay the course and that we're committed to winning this war on terror. The election results didn't play a role in that decision, except in this sense: the American people have reaffirmed our strategy in the war on terror, and I think that's a good thing.

So, to summarize: I've got confidence in Secretary Rumsfeld, I think he's doing a fine job, and I think the American people agree with the direction we're headed.

That's a great question. I appreciate you asking it. First of all, let me just say that the situation with Iran is very serious, and we can't just ignore the fact that they're enriching uranium, which could lead to them developing a nuclear weapon. The threat of a nuclear Iran is a threat to the United States, it's a threat to our allies, and it's a threat to the entire world.

Now, when it comes to oil prices, I'm just as concerned as the American people are. We're in a tight spot, no question about it. But I don't think that our strong stance against Iran's nuclear program is the primary driver of oil prices. Global demand for oil is up, there are other factors at play here, and speculation is playing a role in the price of oil.

That being said, we are taking steps to address our energy situation. We're working to increase our domestic production, investing in alternative energy sources, and we're also working with our international partners to stabilize the global energy markets. We're doing everything we can to make sure that our economy remains strong, even in the face of these high oil prices.

But let me make one thing clear: we will not sacrifice our national security on the altar of oil prices. We will not back down from our commitment to preventing Iran from developing a nuclear weapon. That's a non-negotiable.

I think that's a label that some of our critics have used, but I don't necessarily buy into it. The United States has a unique position in the world, and we have a responsibility to lead. And I've said it's a mighty joyful responsibility, but it's also a serious responsibility.

Now, I will tell you that we've had our disagreements with our allies. We've had disagreements on Kyoto, we've had disagreements on the International Criminal Court, we've had disagreements on Iraq. But I think what people need to understand is that we're not arrogant, we're confident. And there's a difference.

We're confident in our values. We believe that freedom is a universal value that applies to every human being. We're confident in our system of government. We believe that democracy is the best way to bring hope and peace to people.

Now, I think it's also important to recognize that when we work with our allies, it doesn't mean that we always have to agree. We have tough, honest discussions with our allies, and sometimes those discussions lead to disagreements. But that doesn't mean that we're not committed to our friendships.

And as for the danger of going it alone, I'd say that the United States will do what's necessary to protect our national interests. We will not let the interests of terrorists and tyrants push us around. We'll work with our allies, but we'll also make decisions based on what we think is right for America.

I think the danger is, is when countries who oppose us try to label us as isolated. It's a partisan argument, it's a argument that some countries use to try to undermine our leadership. And I don't think it's accurate, and I don't think it's fair.

Thank you for that question. I'm glad to be here in Tanzania, and I'm glad to be in Africa. You know, I've often said that Africa is a continent of great promise and great challenge. And I believe that it's in the national interest of the United States to be engaged with the nations of Africa, to help address those challenges, and to help realize that promise.

Now, I know that some folks might say, "Well, why now?" And the answer is, we're here because we're seeing real progress in Africa. We're seeing democratic governments take hold, we're seeing economic growth, and we're seeing a renewed sense of hope and optimism among the people of this great continent.

And I think it's in our interest to support that progress, to help build on that momentum. And that's why we've made Africa a priority in our foreign policy, particularly in my second term as President.

I'm proud of what we've accomplished through initiatives like the President's Emergency Plan for AIDS Relief, or PEPFAR, which has helped to bring anti-retroviral treatment to millions of people across the continent who are living with HIV/AIDS.

We've also made significant investments in education, in healthcare, and in economic development, through programs like the Millennium Challenge Account and the African Growth and Opportunity Act.

So, it's not just a question of, "Why now?" It's a question of, "Why not?" Why not support the people of Africa as they work to build a brighter future for themselves and their children?

And I believe that by investing in Africa's development, we're not only doing something that's morally right, we're also doing something that's in the national interest of the United States.

Because when Africa is stable, when Africa is prosperous, when Africa is democratic, it's good for the American people. It's good for our economy, it's good for our security, and it's good for our values.

So, that's why Africa is important, and that's why Tanzania is important. And I'm glad to be here, and I'm glad to be a part of this effort.

Well, I think it's interesting that the question is framed that way. I'm not willing to budge on a fundamental principle, and that is, our economy needs tax relief to grow. And I believe the $1.6 trillion is the right amount. And I think it's interesting that the American people, a lot of them are beginning to realize that we're not just talking about a tax cut, we're talking about a $1.6 trillion tax cut that will help everybody, or a $1.6 trillion surplus that could be spent by Congress.

Now, I'm willing to listen to ideas. I'm willing to work with people. But I must say to you, I'm not going to give up on something that I believe in, that I believe will help this economy grow. And I think it's also interesting that the -- some of the critics are saying, well, you need to reduce the size of the tax cut to balance it. Well, I think we've got a responsible plan. I think the plan is the right size, and I think it's balanced.

Now, I'm willing to talk about other aspects of the plan, perhaps some of the provisions in the plan that could be tweaked. But the size of the package, I believe, is the right size, given the surplus that we have coming in. And I think we've got a good program, and I'm willing to defend it.

[Laughter] Well, thank you for that question. I think it's safe to say that the gun in question is now securely stored in a secure location, and I'm not sure it would be a good idea to be gifting it to anyone as a symbol of friendship, particularly given its history. [Laughter]

But let me say this: the fact that we have possession of that gun is a reminder that the American people have been protected from the evil that Saddam Hussein represented. And I'm proud of the work that our troops have done to bring him to justice and to protect the American people from the kind of harm that he was capable of inflicting.

So, I think we'll just leave the gun right where it is, and we'll consider it a symbol of our success in the war on terror. Thank you.

Thank you for that question. First, I'd like to extend my condolences to the Palestinian people on the passing of Yasser Arafat. While we had our differences, he was a significant figure in the peace process, and I recognize the impact of his death on the region.

Regarding your question, I firmly believe that the Roadmap for Peace, which was agreed upon by both Israel and the Palestinians, remains the best path forward for a lasting and comprehensive peace. Now, I know there are many challenges ahead, but I still hold out hope that both parties can come together and make progress.

Regarding settlements, I've said it before, and I'll say it again: I believe that Israel's expansion of settlements in the West Bank can be an obstacle to peace. I think it's essential for Israel to exercise restraint and diminish the growth of these settlements, especially as we move forward with the peace process. However, I also understand the legitimate security concerns of the Israeli people, and I believe that these concerns need to be taken into account as well.

The Palestinians also have a critical role to play in reviving peace negotiations. They must demonstrate a commitment to responsible governance, and to taking the necessary steps to prevent terrorism, which is a major concern for Israel. We cannot expect Israel to move forward in the peace process if it doesn't feel secure.

I want to emphasize that I believe Abu Mazen, the new Palestinian leader, is a man of peace. I look forward to working with him and supporting his efforts to lead his people towards peace.

Ultimately, peace in the Middle East requires cooperation, mutual trust, and a willingness to make compromises. The United States will remain committed to facilitating this process, and I will continue to work closely with both parties to achieve this objective. Thank you.

Thank you. I'm glad you brought up my dad's visit to Mainz. You know, I've always admired his commitment to building strong alliances, and Germany is no exception. Today, I'd like to say that Germany is indeed a vital partner to the United States of America.

We share a deep commitment to freedom, to human dignity, and to the values that we hold dear. We've worked together on a number of critical issues, from fighting terrorism to promoting economic growth and stability in Europe.

As we move forward, I believe that our partnership with Germany will only continue to grow stronger. We'll work together to address the challenges of the 21st century, from counter-terrorism to nuclear non-proliferation, and from promoting free trade to addressing the root causes of poverty and despair in troubled regions of the world.

So, to answer your question directly, I do believe that Germany is a crucial partner to the United States, and I'm committed to strengthening our relationship and working closely together to address the challenges that we face.

And I might add, our personal friendship with Chancellor Schröder is quite strong, Laura and I have been honored to have him and his wife visit us at the White House. And, you know, it's a friendship built on a foundation of shared values and a commitment to work together in this complicated and changing world.

I appreciate your question, and I want to start by saying that I understand the concerns of our allies who have made the decision to withdraw their troops from Iraq. We respect their decision, and we appreciate the sacrifices they've made alongside us in the pursuit of a safer, more peaceful world.

Now, I want to remind everyone that the United States has a vested interest in seeing this mission through to completion. The threat of terrorism is real, and it's a threat not just to America, but to the entire civilized world. By completing our mission in Iraq, we're preventing a vacuum that could be filled by extremist forces, and we're giving the Iraqi people a chance to build a free and democratic society.

Our coalition partners may be leaving, but our commitment to this mission remains strong. And let me tell you, we're making progress. We're training Iraqi security forces, we're building up their capacity, and we're handing over more and more responsibility to the Iraqi people themselves.

Now, I understand that we're shouldering a significant burden in terms of costs and casualties. But I believe that this is an investment in the future of our country, in the future of our children, and in the future of the world. We can't afford to leave this job unfinished, and we can't afford to let the forces of tyranny and terrorism prevail.

We'll continue to work with our coalition partners, we'll continue to work with the Iraqi government, and we'll continue to do what's necessary to ensure that our mission is accomplished. And I'm proud of the bravery and sacrifice of our men and women in uniform who are serving in Iraq today. Thank you.

That's a great question. Let me clarify the position of the United States. While it's true that we have concerns about Iran's intentions, we have also reiterated our support for Iran's right to a civilian nuclear program, as long as it's done in accordance with international law and safeguard agreements.

The key difference between Iran and North Korea is this: Iran is a signatory to the Nuclear Non-Proliferation Treaty, and we're pressing them to meet their obligations under that treaty. We're willing to work with the international community to ensure that Iran's program is peaceful, and we're pushing for greater transparency and cooperation.

North Korea, on the other hand, has withdrawn from the NPT and has made it clear that they're pursuing a nuclear weapons program. That's a major difference in our approach. We've made it clear that we're willing to work with North Korea to address their concerns and to provide economic and energy assistance, but we need to see concrete steps towards dismantling their nuclear program.

In the case of Iran, we're seeking a diplomatic solution that will allow them to have a peaceful nuclear program, but we're also very clear about the need for transparency and cooperation. So, it's not a question of supporting a civilian nuclear program for one country and not the other, it's a question of dealing with the unique circumstances and the specific challenges of each country.

The unauthorized disclosure of classified information is a serious matter, and we will do everything in our power to determine who is responsible for leaking this highly classified information. As Commander-in-Chief, I have the authority to authorize the surveillance of international communications in order to protect this country from another 9/11-style attack.

Regarding the issue of going to the courts for permission, I want to remind everyone that we are at war, and the executive branch has the authority to conduct these kinds of operations to protect the country. The Patriot Act and other laws give me the authority to do what it takes to protect our country.

Now, I know some people may disagree with my decision, but I made the decision based on the advice of our Intelligence Community, and based on the fact that these intercepts were necessary to help protect the country from those who are sworn to destroy us.

We will do a full investigation, and if we find the leakers, they will be held accountable. And I'm not going to comment any further on the details of this program, because I don't want to compromise our ability to gather the intelligence we need to protect the country.

I appreciate your question, but I gotta tell you, I'm not sure that's the best course of action right now. The problem with engaging with Syria and Iran directly is that both of those countries have been unhelpful, to say the least, when it comes to the global war on terror.

Iran, in particular, has got a history of supporting terrorist organizations like Hezbollah, and I'm not convinced that they're interested in being helpful. And Syria, as you know, has been a transit point for insurgent activity into Iraq. So, I'm not sure that engaging with them directly would necessarily get us the kind of cooperation we need.

Now, that being said, we do have diplomats who talk to Syria and Iran, but I'm not sure that having a big, high-level meeting with their leaders would be productive. I think it's more important to continue to put pressure on them to cooperate, and to make it clear that we expect them to be a part of the solution, not a part of the problem.

We've got to keep in mind that the region is changing, and we're seeing a lot of variables in play. And I'm not sure that engaging with Syria and Iran would be the right move, at least not right now. But I do think it's an option that we're considering, and we'll continue to evaluate the situation as it evolves.

But let me make one thing clear: we will not engage with those countries unless they're willing to help us make progress in the war on terror, and help us stabilize the region. Anything short of that, I think, would be a waste of time.

Thank you for that question. Let me try to paint a picture for you. The vision I have is one of a safer America, where our children can grow up without the fear of terrorism hanging over their heads. We've made significant strides in the War on Terror, taking the fight to the enemy in Afghanistan and Iraq.

Now, I know some folks might be thinking, "But Mr. President, how does this keep us safe here at home?" And my answer is, it's a comprehensive approach. We're not just fighting terrorists on foreign soil, we're also working tirelessly to protect our homeland.

We've strengthened our intelligence agencies, increased security measures at our borders and airports, and invested in new technologies to detect and prevent threats. We're also working closely with our international partners to share intelligence and best practices.

But, I want to emphasize that the threat of terrorism is still real, and we must remain vigilant. We can't let our guard down. That's why I'm committed to continuing our efforts to hunt down and bring to justice those who seek to harm us.

Now, I know some might say that our efforts are expensive, and they are. But I say, what price can you put on freedom? What price can you put on the safety of our children? We owe it to ourselves, our families, and our future to do everything in our power to protect this great nation.

I'm confident that our vision for a safer America is within our reach, and we'll continue to work tirelessly to make it a reality.

(pausing for a moment) Well, I think it's a misunderstanding of our strategy. We are committed to achieving success in Iraq, and we are working towards that goal every day. The notion of a "corner" is not correct. We're on a path towards transition. We're on a path towards having the Iraqis take more responsibility for their own security. We're on a path towards drawing down the number of troops as the situation on the ground improves.

Now, I understand people want to know what's around the corner, and I can't give you a set date. I can't give you a set timeline, because it's going to be dependent on the conditions on the ground. But I can tell you, we're working closely with the Iraqis, we're working closely with General Petraeus, who's the commander on the ground, and we're going to make our decisions based on the advice we receive from our military commanders.

We're not trying to "play it both ways." We're working hard to achieve success in Iraq. It's a complex and difficult challenge, but we're committed to seeing it through.

I appreciate the question. As I've said in the past, I believe that sustainability is a goal we must strive for, and it's essential that we find ways to ensure our economy grows in a way that doesn't harm our environment.

Now, when I talk about sustainability, I'm thinking about it in a broad sense. It's not just a slogan; it's a commitment to our children and grandchildren. I mean that we must be good stewards of the Earth, and that includes our air, our water, our land, and our natural resources.

In terms of specific goals, we've set a lot of ambitious targets. For example, we've increased our parks and wildlife refuges by over 54 million acres, and we've established or expanded 86 national parks, monuments, and historic sites.

We've also made a commitment to reduce our greenhouse gas intensity by 18 percent by 2012, and we're working hard to meet that goal. We're investing in clean energy technologies, like nuclear power, wind power, and solar power, to reduce our dependence on fossil fuels and reduce our emissions.

Another important goal is to improve America's fuel economy. We've set new fuel economy standards for SUVs and light trucks, which will save millions of gallons of fuel and reduce emissions.

We've also signed a number of executive orders to reduce our own federal government's environmental footprint. For example, we've set a goal to reduce greenhouse gas emissions from federal buildings and operations by 30 percent by 2010.

Now, I want to emphasize that sustainability's not just about the federal government; it's about personal responsibility, it's about the choices we make in our daily lives. It's about the consumer choosing products that are environmentally friendly. It's about corporate America recognizing that good environmental practices are good business practices.

So, my goal is to leave America with a cleaner environment, a stronger economy, and a healthy and sustainable way of life for our children and grandchildren. That's what sustainability means to me.

Thank you for the question. The situation in Afghanistan is a top priority for my administration. The latest attempt on President Karzai's life is a grim reminder of the dangers that still exist in that country. But I'm pleased to report that our efforts to stabilize and secure Afghanistan are making progress.

We've had significant successes in disrupting and dismantling al-Qaeda's operations, and the Taliban's grip on the country is loosening. The Afghan people are beginning to see the benefits of a more stable and secure society, with improved economic opportunities, better healthcare, and greater access to education.

Now, I know that the insurgency is still a threat, and we're taking that threat very seriously. Our military, along with our coalition partners, is working closely with the Afghan security forces to root out the Taliban and other extremist groups. We're making progress, but it's not going to be easy, and it's not going to happen overnight.

I'd say we're winning in Afghanistan, but it's a tough fight, and it's a fight that requires patience and perseverance. We're in this for the long haul, and we're committed to seeing it through.

But I want to emphasize that our strategy is not just about military might. We're also working to rebuild and strengthen Afghanistan's institutions, promote economic development, and support the Afghan people as they build a brighter future for themselves.

So, while there are still challenges ahead, I'm optimistic about the prospects for success in Afghanistan, and I believe we're on the right track.

Well, thank you for that question. I appreciate the opportunity to address this issue. We're still working hard to get this tax relief plan passed, and we're making good progress. Now, I understand there are some concerns that some senators have expressed, and we're listening to those concerns.

As for cutting the size of the plan, I'll tell you this: we've already compromised quite a bit to get this plan where it is today. We think it's a good plan, it's a plan that will help our economy grow, a plan that will help people who are working hard to make ends meet.

Now, I'm a flexible person, I can work with people, and we'll see what we can do to get this plan passed. But what we won't do is sacrifice the principles of the plan. We won't do is abandon the idea of giving American workers a tax cut, because we think that's essential for growth.

So, we'll work with members of the Senate, we'll listen to their concerns, and we'll see if we can find a way to get this plan passed. But I'm not willing to give up on the core principles of it. We'll keep working, and I'm hopeful that we can get it done.

It's a big issue, by the way. This is not just about passing a tax cut, it's about the jobs of the American people, it's about the well-being of the American people, and we're gonna keep pushing. Thank you.

Noting you said you had a question for both Presidents I am left here by myself. Nevertheless I will answer for myself. The phrase "this President" did imply you did know I was alone.

As President of the United States my desire is that the next team, when I leave the oval office will proceed with lovely bold steps as seen with my administration's work for natural disaster peace partnerships and security matters.

Faith and reason and necessity insist we have some compromise on emotionally charged issues.

Thank ya for the question. Now, I know there's been some concern about the debt limit, and I want to assure the American people that we're takin' a responsible approach to manage our nation's finances. Secretary Snow's plan to borrow from the Federal retirement funds is a temporary measure, and I want to emphasize that it's a precautionary step to ensure that we can meet our obligations.

Now, let me be clear: we're not gonna touch the principal of those retirement funds. We're talkin' about borrowing against the interest that those funds earn. It's a sound financial practice that many companies and governments use, and we believe it's a responsible way to manage our cash flow.

I know some folks might be worried that we're raidin' the cookie jar, but that's just not the case. We're talkin' about a temporary measure to help us bridge a short-term gap, and we're committed to payin' it back with interest.

I'd also like to remind everyone that we've made significant progress in reducin' the deficit since I took office. We've cut taxes, we've reduced spending, and we've taken steps to improve the overall health of our economy. And I believe that with this temporary measure, we can continue to move forward on the path of fiscal responsibility.

So, to the American people, I want to assure you that we're takin' a careful and responsible approach to manage our nation's finances, and we're committed to protectin' the interests of our retirees and our citizens.

Well, I appreciate the question. Let me be clear: our administration's core principles remain the same. We're committed to low taxes, a strong national defense, and the promotion of freedom and democracy around the world. These aren't up for negotiation.

Now, as it relates to working with Democrats, I believe in bipartisanship. I think it's essential to find common ground and work towards the best interests of the American people. But just because we're willing to listen and work together doesn't mean we're compromising our values or moving toward the left.

We've got a responsibility to the American people to get things done, whether it's on education reform, energy policy, or reducing the deficit. And if that means working with Democrats on certain issues, then so be it. But our North Star remains the same – we're governing based on the principles that got us elected.

I think we can have a robust debate and still be civil. I think we can disagree without being disagreeable. And I think we can work across party lines without sacrificing what we stand for. That's the kind of leadership the American people expect from us, and that's what we intend to deliver. Thank you.

Thank you for your question. With regards to Liberia, we're monitoring the situation closely, and we're working with the international community, particularly the Economic Community of West African States, ECOWAS, to help bring stability to the region. We're not ruling out the possibility of U.S. military involvement, but any decision we make will be based on careful consideration of our national interests and in close consultation with our international partners.

Regarding the broader question of how far we can go in international conflicts, I believe that we have a responsibility as a nation to promote stability and defend freedom around the world. However, we also recognize that there are limits to our resources, and we must be mindful of the potential risks and consequences of any military intervention.

I don't think that we're stretched too thin at this point. We've got a robust military, and we've got a strong coalition of international partners who share our commitment to promoting peace and stability. But we're always mindful of the need to prioritize our efforts and to focus on those conflicts that pose the greatest threat to our national security and to regional stability.

It's a careful balancing act, but I'm confident that we've got the right combination of diplomacy, military strength, and international cooperation to meet the challenges that we face.

Thank you for that question. The Iraq Stabilization Group, as you know, was established to bring a more coordinated approach to our efforts in Iraq. It's not an acknowledgment that our efforts to stabilize Iraq are flagging, but rather a recognition that the situation in Iraq is complex and multifaceted, requiring a more comprehensive approach.
