We're making progress in Iraq, no question about it. The Iraqi people have shown remarkable resilience and determination in the face of tyranny and violence. But we're also facing determined and ruthless enemies who seek to undermine our efforts.

Regarding Secretary Rumsfeld, I have complete confidence in Don's ability to lead the Defense Department, and he's doing a fine job. The Iraq Stabilization Group is not intended to diminish his authority in any way. Rather, it's a recognition that we need to bring all of the government's resources and expertise to bear on this problem.

You see, the Group will consist of representatives from the Departments of State, Defense, and other agencies, all working together to ensure that our efforts in Iraq are coordinated and effective. We're committed to succeeding in Iraq, and we're committed to doing it as a team.

I want to emphasize that the creation of the Iraq Stabilization Group is a natural step in the evolution of our efforts in Iraq. It's not a sign of trouble; it's a sign of progress and a sign of our commitment to getting the job done. Thank you.

Thank you for your question. I understand the concern and the emotions that come with the loss of life in Iraq. I honor the sacrifice of those brave men and women who have given their last full measure of devotion. It's a reminder that the work we're doing in Iraq is difficult and it's hard, and it's tragic.

Now, I do not believe that we are losing in Iraq. I believe that we are making progress. The facts are that Iraq has a new government, Iraq has a new democracy, Iraq has an economy that's beginning to grow. And Iraq has a military that's beginning to take hold.

Now, I concede that the recent violence has been disturbing, and I'm deeply concerned about it. But I believe it's a sign that the terrorists and the Saddamists are, they're on the run. They're on the run from freedom, they're on the run from democracy, and they're desperate.

We're working closely with our coalition partners, with the Iraqi government, and with the Iraqi security forces to improve security and to bring hope to the Iraqi people. We're also recognizing that this is not just a military effort, but it's also a political and an economic effort.

And I'll tell you, I'm optimistic about Iraq's future. I'm optimistic that we're making progress, and I'm optimistic that we're going to succeed. And I want to assure the American people that we're on the right course in Iraq, and we're going to see this through to its conclusion.

I appreciate your question. Look, I understand that not everyone's going to agree with my policies, and that's okay. That's the beauty of democracy. But I'll tell you this: I'm not in this job to win a popularity contest. I'm in this job to lead. And I've made some tough decisions, particularly on issues like national security and the war on terror.

Now, I know some folks might disagree with those decisions, and that's their right. But I can tell you, the folks I'm worried about are the American people, not the folks in the polls. I'm working hard every day to make America safer, to promote American values, and to support our allies.

And let me tell you, I've had some very good conversations with European leaders, people like Tony Blair and Berlusconi, and others. We may not always agree, but we're working together to address some of the tough challenges facing the world today.

So, to answer your question, I'm not worried about my poll numbers in Europe. I'm worried about doing what's right for America and for the free world. And if some folks over here don't agree with me, that's okay. We'll just have to agree to disagree. But at the end of the day, we're all working towards the same goal: a safer, more peaceful world.

Thank you for the question. I'm glad to answer it. You see, Laura and I, we've always believed that the best way to bring people together is to lead with conviction and principle. We're not gonna change who we are just to try to placate people who may disagree with us. What I plan to do is to find common ground, where possible.

On the matter of the Supreme Court, we'll nominate a highly qualified judge, someone who's well-respected in the judicial system. And we'll work with the Senate to get that person confirmed. Now, I understand that not everyone may agree with our choice. But I'm the President, and I've got the responsibility to make the nomination.

As for the Cabinet, we're gonna put together a team that's dedicated to the kind of change we campaigned on. We'll look at people who share our vision, our values. We're not worried about party labels; we're worried about finding the best and brightest to help us get the job done.

Now, I'll tell you this: we'll work hard to get people on our side of the aisle, and on the other side, to find common ground. We're not gonna change who we are, but we'll work to get people working together on important issues like the tax code, like education reform. But make no mistake about it, we'll be leading, not just me, the whole administration.

The lifting of the EU arms embargo on China would be a serious shift in international policy, and I want to emphasize that the United States has made its concerns clear to our European allies.

First and foremost, the lifting of the embargo could pose a threat to regional stability in Asia. China's military modernization is a concern for all of us, and we must ensure that any decision to lift the embargo does not inadvertently contribute to an imbalance of power in the region.

Furthermore, we also have concerns about the potential for China to export military technology to rogue states or other countries of concern. This is a critical issue in the global fight against terrorism and proliferation.

Now, I do believe that it's possible to find common ground on this issue. The EU and the United States share many of the same concerns and values, and we have a shared interest in promoting peace and stability in Asia.

If the EU were to consider lifting the embargo, we would encourage them to do so in a manner that would address our concerns about the potential risks and negative consequences. This might include, for example, the development of a robust and enforceable end-use monitoring regime, to ensure that any arms sales are properly tracked and do not end up in the wrong hands.

Ultimately, we must work together to address the challenges we face in Asia and around the world. I'll be meeting with European leaders in the coming weeks to discuss this issue further, and I'm confident that we can find a way forward that addresses our shared concerns and promotes our common interests.

I appreciate your question. First of all, I want to make it clear that we take the Iranian regime's nuclear ambitions very seriously. We believe that it's a threat to peace and stability in the region, and we're not going to tolerate it.

Now, I think it's also important to note that we're working with our partners in the international community to try to resolve this issue diplomatically. And we're hopeful that the incentives package that's been presented to the Iranians will cause them to abandon their pursuit of nuclear weapons.

But make no mistake, all options are on the table. We're not taking anything off the table. We're working with our partners to apply economic pressure, to apply diplomatic pressure, and we're working closely with our military planners to ensure that we're prepared for any scenario that might develop.

But as I said, our preference is to resolve this issue peacefully, to work with the international community, and to convince the Iranian regime that pursuing nuclear weapons is not in their interests.

I understand that the Iranian president says they're not making nuclear weapons. But the world doesn't necessarily believe them, based on the evidence we've seen. And we're going to continue to press the issue, to press the International Atomic Energy Agency to investigate the Iranian nuclear program and to make sure that they're in compliance with the Non-Proliferation Treaty.

So, we're working hard to resolve this issue peacefully, but all options are on the table, and we're prepared for any scenario that might develop.

Well, I don't think so. I think we've made some great progress over the past year, and I'm proud of what we've accomplished. Now, I know there are some folks in Congress who don't agree with me on every issue, and that's okay. I expect that. We're a democracy, and we're supposed to have disagreements.

But I'm not worried about momentum because I believe in the cause. I believe in the policies we're promoting. And I think the American people believe in them too. We've had some setbacks, yes, but we've also had some big wins. And I think our message is resonating with the American people.

Now, I know it's not always easy to get things done in Washington. It's like trying to herd cats, sometimes. But I've got a great team, and we're working hard to keep pushing forward. And I think we're going to make some more progress in the months to come.

So, I'm not worried about momentum. I'm worried about getting the job done, and that's what we're going to keep working on. Thank you.
I think it's appropriate for me to, you know, express my respect for the institution, the Supreme Court, but I do believe that Roe v. Wade was wrongly decided.

Well, thank you for that question.  I want to make it clear that when I encouraged China to take a path more similar to that of Taiwan, I was speaking about the importance of embracing democratic values and freedoms, not necessarily about duplicating their exact system of government.

Taiwan's progress towards democracy is something to be admired, and I believe that their model of free and fair elections, an independent judiciary, and a commitment to human rights are all certainly worth emulating. However, every nation is unique, and I'm not suggesting that China must adopt the exact same system as Taiwan.

Rather, I'm encouraging President Hu and the people of China to take steps towards greater openness, transparency, and accountability in their government. That includes, of course, allowing the Chinese people to participate more fully in the decision-making process through free and fair elections, as well as greater protections for human rights and the rule of law.

These are universal values that I believe can be beneficial to any nation, and I'm hopeful that China will continue to move in a positive direction. But make no mistake, I'm not trying to impose our values or system of government on the Chinese people. It's up to them to decide their own path, but I do believe that embracing democratic values would be a positive step forward for their nation.

(pauses, looks directly at the reporter) Let me be clear: the United States of America does not condone or permit torture. We will not allow the use of torture as an instrument of policy. It is against our values, it's against our law, and it's not necessary. We can gather intelligence in ways that are consistent with our values and our laws.

Thank you for that question. Well, we're still analyzing the report, I want to make it clear that we take the IAEA's findings very seriously. The issue of Iran's compliance with the Security Council is of grave concern to us, and we're working closely with our friends and allies to make sure that we have a unified response.

Now, when it comes to sanctions, I believe we should exhaust all diplomatic avenues before we take action. But I will tell you that we're exploring a range of options, and we're consulting with our friends in the region and with our friends in the Security Council to get a unified response.

I think it's safe to say that we're looking at smart sanctions, ones that would put pressure on the Iranian regime without causing hardships for the Iranian people. We're also looking at targeting the leaders of the regime, making it clear to them that the world community is united in our condemnation of their actions.

As for Russia and China, we're confident that they understand the threat that a nuclear-armed Iran poses, and we're hoping that they'll join us in taking a firm stance. We're engaging in diplomatic efforts, and we're making it clear to them that we're serious about this threat.

But let me be clear: the United States will not hesitate to take action if we feel that our national security interests are at risk. We will not tolerate a nuclear-armed Iran, and we will take all necessary steps to prevent that from happening.

Well, I think that's a good question. And the answer to that is, we've always said that as a — as a — an open-ended timeline won't work. We need to make sure we accomplish our mission, and that is to have a country that can govern itself, sustain itself, and defend itself.

Now, I've always said that we will be — look to be a good guest in Iraq. And a good guest doesn't overstay their invitation. We'll — we'll work with the Iraqi government to determine what our troop levels will be, and what our, you know, what our presence will be.

Regarding to the question — the question about, are we going to have permanent bases — the answer is, we've just started the process of discussing what the nature of our relationship will be with the Iraqi government. And we haven't — we haven't — it's not been decided yet.

But I will remind you that we do have permanent bases in places like Japan, like South Korea, like Germany. And it's a — it's a part of our international relationships, to have relations with other countries, to help — to help maintain peace and stability.

And, you know, Iraq is an important country in a part of the world that is — that is quite volatile. But, you know, I wouldn't call that a "permanent" base, any way. I'd just say that we'll work with the Iraqis on what our — the nature of our relationship will be.

As for, you know, renouncing claims to bases — I mean, that's a performance-based measurement, based on what happens on the ground, see? It's our desire to have a country that is free, that is not a threat to its neighbors, that will be a country that can sustain itself.

But, I mean, the — that decision about what our, you know, what our troop presence will be and what our relationship will be with the Iraqis — that's something that will be worked out in the — in the coming months.

Would that include no permanent bases in Iraq?

Thank you for the question. As Commander-in-Chief of the United States Armed Forces, I've been entrusted with the sacred responsibility of protecting our nation and our troops. While I value the input and oversight of Congress, I must ensure that our military commanders on the ground have the flexibility and resources needed to accomplish their missions.

The bill before me would impose a rigid timeline for withdrawal, which I firmly believe would be a grave mistake. It would send the wrong signal to our enemies, embolden the insurgency, and potentially put our brave men and women in harm's way.

I'm willing to work with Congress to ensure that we're holding ourselves accountable for our wartime efforts and making adjustments as necessary. However, I will not compromise on our commitment to success in Iraq. We must allow our military leaders to execute their strategies without undue interference from Washington.

That being said, I've met with Congressional leaders and members of the Armed Services Committees, and I appreciate their input. We will continue to work together to ensure we're doing everything we can to support our troops and achieve our objectives. But at the end of the day, as President, I must make the tough decisions to protect our national interests and our troops.

Thank you for that question. As your President, I've had the privilege of working closely with our European allies, and I've seen firsthand the incredible progress we've made in strengthening our ties.

Now, I know there are challenges, no question. The European Union is going through some growing pains, and we've got some differences on issues like trade, security, and energy. But I'm optimistic about the future of the EU, and I believe our relationship with them is essential to the peace and prosperity of the world.

First, let's acknowledge that the EU has been a remarkable experiment in history – a voluntary association of sovereign nations, united in their commitment to democracy, free markets, and the rule of law. That's something we should celebrate.

Now, we've had our differences, as I mentioned. We've had debates on issues like the war in Iraq, climate change, and trade policies. But I believe our shared values and interests far outweigh our disagreements. We've worked together to combat terrorism, to promote democracy in the Balkans and elsewhere, and to address global challenges like pandemics and economic instability.

Looking ahead, I see tremendous opportunities for cooperation. We need to work together on energy security, to reduce our dependence on oil, and to promote clean technologies. We need to strengthen our economic ties, through fair trade and investment. And we need to work together to address the challenge of terrorism and the proliferation of nuclear weapons.

Now, I know there are some who say that the EU is going through a period of introspection, and that it's trying to figure out its role in the world. I say, that's natural. All institutions evolve, and it's healthy to question and reassess. But I believe the EU's fundamental commitment to democracy, free markets, and the rule of law will endure, and that will be the foundation for a strong relationship with the United States.

In fact, I'm proud of the progress we've made on issues like the NATO-Russia dialogue, the Balkans, and the EU's expansion to the East. We've made tremendous progress, and there's more to be done.

So, to answer your question, I'm optimistic about the future of the European Union, and I believe our relationship with the EU is essential to the peace and prosperity of the world. We'll continue to work together, as allies, as friends, and as partners, to address the challenges of the 21st century. Thank you.

I understand the concerns of my fellow Americans who are struggling during these trying times. However, we must be careful not to add spending measures that will detract from the intent of the bailout package, which is to stabilize the financial system and prevent a broader economic crisis.

While I agree that we need to support those affected by the housing crisis, we cannot let the package become too cumbersome or weighed down by extraneous measures. The primary focus must remain on stabilizing the financial markets and restoring confidence.

That being said, I am open to discussing ways to provide support to Americans in need, such as assistance for homeowners facing foreclosure or unemployment benefits. But we need to approach these issues in a responsible and targeted manner, and make sure that any such assistance is temporary and not detrimental to our long-term economic well-being.

I understand that this is a time of great uncertainty, and many Americans are hurting. I want to assure the American people that we are working diligently to find a solution that will get our economy back on track, and ensure that the freedom and prosperity we cherish are available to all.

(pausing for a moment) Well, I understand that some folks may have concerns about my background in the oil industry, and Dick Cheney's leadership at Halliburton. But let me assure you, our energy policy is designed to benefit the American people, not just one specific industry.

We were elected on a promise to make America more secure, and that includes making us less dependent on foreign oil. That's why we're investing in new energy technologies, like hydrogen fuel cells and renewable energies, and encouraging the development of domestic resources. We're working to open up more areas for exploration, like ANWR, to help meet our growing energy needs.

Now, I will say that our energy policy does include provisions to help the oil and gas industry, but that's because they're a critical part of our energy mix. We need to ensure that we can meet the energy demands of a growing economy. But I can assure you that our policy is not skewed towards benefiting one industry at the expense of others.

Dick Cheney and I, we've worked hard to make sure that our policy is balanced, and that it's in the best interests of the American people. And I'm proud of the work we've done on this issue. We're just getting started, but I think we're on the right track.

Well, thank you for that question. I understand the skepticism, and I appreciate the opportunity to address it. You see, the two issues are quite different. The Kyoto Protocol is an international agreement that would require significant economic sacrifices from the American people, without evidence that it would have a meaningful impact on the environment.

On the other hand, our missile defense plan is about protecting the American people from a real and growing threat. The threat of ballistic missiles, armed with nuclear, chemical, or biological warheads, is very real. And I believe it's our duty as a nation to explore all available options to counter that threat.

Now, I understand that some critics say our missile defense system may not be foolproof, and I acknowledge that risk. But I believe it's a risk worth taking. The consequences of inaction, in the face of this threat, would be catastrophic.

Furthermore, our scientists and engineers are working tirelessly to develop and test this system, and we're making progress. I have every confidence that we can make this system work, and I believe it's a vital component of our national security strategy.

So, while I understand the skepticism, I believe that our missile defense plan is a prudent and necessary step to protect the American people.

Thank you for your question. I'd be happy to share my thoughts on the Genoa summit. As the leader of the free world, I believe the G-8 has a critical role to play in promoting economic growth, security, and cooperation among the world's leading nations.

Regarding the protests and demonstrations that took place on the sidelines of the summit, I understand that there are many differing opinions on globalization and its impact on society. As President of the United States, I believe that globalization is a powerful force for good, as it has lifted millions of people out of poverty and created new economic opportunities around the world.

However, I also recognize that the process of globalization can be uneven and that some people and communities may be left behind. That's why, as G-8 leaders, we have a responsibility to work together to make sure that the benefits of globalization are shared by all, and that we address the legitimate concerns of those who feel that the process is unfairly affecting them.

In this regard, I was pleased that the G-8 leaders were able to come together in Genoa to reaffirm our commitment to promoting sustainable and inclusive economic growth, and to addressing the root causes of poverty and inequality.

We also took important steps to address issues such as debt relief for developing countries, HIV/AIDS, and the environment, which are all critical to the future of the G-8 and the global community.

So, while the protests and demonstrations in Genoa were certainly a distraction, I believe that they also served as a reminder of the importance of the work that we do in the G-8, and the need for us to stay focused on the big picture - building a more prosperous, more just, and more peaceful world for all.

Now, I'm not saying that we've solved all the problems, but I do believe that the Genoa summit was a step in the right direction. And I think it's worth noting that opposition is something that America was founded upon, and we respect people's right to express themselves, as long as it's peacefully done.

That's precisely what I'm sayin'. As the President of the United States, I've got a responsibility to protect this great nation and its people. Now, I believe strongly in workin' with our allies and partners, and we will do so. We'll consult, we'll listen, we'll work together to address the threats we're facin'. But at the end of the day, as Commander-in-Chief, I've got to be prepared to make tough decisions, and if that means takin' action unilaterally to protect America and its interests, then that's exactly what I'll do.

Thank you for that question. Let me make it very clear: the United States is committed to the United Nations and the principles of the UN Charter. However, we also recognize that there are times when decisive action is necessary to protect our national security and promote international stability.

As Commander-in-Chief, I have a responsibility to take all necessary actions to safeguard our citizens and our interests. If the UN is unable to act decisively in the face of a threat like Saddam Hussein's regime in Iraq, then we will not hesitate to take action with a coalition of like-minded nations.

Now, I want to emphasize that we are working closely with our friends and allies, including those on the UN Security Council, to build support for a resolution that ensures accountability and enforcement of the disarmament obligations that Iraq has agreed to. But at the same time, we cannot allow a lack of agreement at the UN to tie our hands or limit our ability to protect our country and advance the cause of peace and stability in the region.

We are not defiant of the UN; we are committed to the principles of the UN Charter and the rule of law. However, we will not be deterred from taking necessary action to defend our interests and values.

Well, thank you for your question. I appreciate it. I can tell you that the intelligence we had was solid, it was credible, and it was compelling. Our military took action based on that intelligence, and I'm proud of the way they performed.

Regarding Saddam Hussein's status, I'm not at liberty to disclose any information about whether he was at the site or not. We're still gathering information, and we'll release it when it's confirmed.

As for the war being nearly over, I'd say we're making good progress, but we still have work to do. We're making strides in Baghdad, and the Iraqi people are beginning to see the light at the end of the tunnel. But we can't let our guard down. We must remain vigilant and continue to work towards our objectives.

We will continue to work with the Iraqi people, with our coalition partners, and with our military to bring about a peaceful and free Iraq. And when we succeed, and I have no doubt that we will, it'll be a major victory for the Iraqi people, for the Middle East, and for the United States of America.

So, thank you for your question, and we'll keep you updated as more information becomes available.

Well, let me tell you, the situation at Abu Ghraib is a serious one, and I'm outraged by the actions of those few individuals who have tainted the good name of the United States and the brave men and women who serve in our military.

Now, as for the timeline, I want to assure the American people that as soon as this information reached my desk, we took immediate action. We launched a thorough investigation, which is ongoing, and we're working closely with Secretary Rumsfeld and the Department of Defense to get to the bottom of this.

Yesterday, I spoke with Secretary Rumsfeld and expressed my strong disappointment and concern about the mistreatment of prisoners. I made it clear that we will not tolerate such behavior, and that we expect our military personnel to uphold the highest standards of conduct. I instructed Secretary Rumsfeld to take all necessary steps to ensure that those responsible are held accountable and that we move quickly to implement reforms to prevent such incidents from happening again in the future.

Let me be clear: the actions of a few do not reflect the values of the United States of America. We are a nation that values human dignity, human rights, and the rule of law. And we will not rest until we have restored the honor and the integrity of our military and our nation.

That's a fair question. Let me be clear: I'm asking our allies and other nations to join us in this fight against terrorism, and I'm asking them to make commitments to help us disrupt and dismantle these terrorist organizations. Now, I know some folks might say, "Well, why aren't you doing more yourself?" And my answer is, we are doing a lot ourselves. We've got a robust military effort underway in Afghanistan to root out the Taliban and al-Qaeda, we're working with our law enforcement agencies to prevent attacks here at home, and we're providing significant financial and diplomatic support to countries that are on the front lines in this fight.

Now, I'll be the first to admit that we can always do more, and I'm open to ideas and suggestions on how to deepen our commitment and broaden the coalition. But I'd say to you that we are not being shy about our efforts, and we're not asking others to do something we're not willing to do ourselves.

And by the way, it's not just about what we're asking of others, it's also about what we're delivering to others. We're providing critical support to countries like Pakistan, which is a key partner in this fight. We're providing significant humanitarian aid to the people of Afghanistan, who have been affected by the conflict. So, we're not just talking the talk, we're walking the walk as well.

But I do take your point, and I'll continue to hear from critics and supporters alike, because that's how we refine our approach and get better at fighting this global war on terror.

Well, thank you for the question. I appreciate it. Let me be very clear: we are constantly reassessing our military strategy in Iraq, and that includes looking at our troop levels. But let me tell you, any decision to draw down troops will be based on conditions on the ground, not on artificial timelines.

Now, I'm aware that some of our military leaders have spoken about the possibility of drawing down troops in the spring, and I appreciate their candor. However, let me be clear: they were speaking about a hypothetical scenario based on certain conditions being met, not about any definitive plan.

Make no mistake, our policy in Iraq is to succeed, and we will not make decisions based on political considerations or pressure from Washington. We will make decisions based on the recommendations of our military commanders and the situation on the ground. And if that means we need to adjust our troop levels, we will do so. But we will not compromise our mission or our goals in Iraq for the sake of a headline or a deadline.

So, to answer your question, those military leaders were not out of line. They were simply engaging in a hypothetical discussion based on possible scenarios. But let me assure you, the decisions will be made by me, in consultation with our military leaders and our national security team, and they will be based on one thing: the safety and security of the American people and our troops in Iraq.

Thank you for the question. I've been told that there's been some speculation and rumors swirling around about photographs of Jack Abramoff and me. Now, I'll tell you this: I don't have any fears about releasing photographs. However, I think it's essential to consider the context in which these photos were taken.

As the President, I've taken countless photos with numerous people, including supporters, politicians, and individuals from various backgrounds. If we were to release every single photograph of me with every individual I've met, it would set an unprecedented precedent, and that might cause unnecessary disruptions and create undue attention towards specific individuals who are simply supporters or acquaintances.

Regarding Jack Abramoff specifically, I'd like to remind everyone that he was convicted of several crimes, and I strongly condemn his actions. Nevertheless, I think releasing photographs of him and me, taken at events, fundraising receptions, or other public gatherings, would do little to address the more significant issues surrounding his wrongdoings.

To address the main concern: my administration is cooperative and open with investigations into Jack Abramoff's wrongdoings. I've directed my staff to be as transparent as possible while cooperating fully with those who are conducting the investigations.

So, to answer your question directly, while I don't fear releasing photographs, I believe our administration should maintain a careful balance between the need to fully cooperate with ongoing investigations and avoiding setting precedents that may be distracting or distort the more significant issues at hand. Thank you.

(in a decisive tone) Well, I disagree with that assessment. We've got a united international community speaking with one voice, saying to the Iranians, 'Comply with the demands of the world.' And that's a powerful statement.

Now, I understand the Iranians are defying the world. And that's unfortunate. But we've got a range of diplomatic tools at our disposal. We're working closely with our allies to increase the pressure on the Iranians to make the right decision.

One thing that is certain is that we will not tolerate a nuclear-armed Iran. That's a genuine threat to global peace, and we will work to prevent that from happening. There are more steps that can be taken, and we're exploring all options.

We will continue to work with the United Nations, and we will continue to work with our allies to send a very clear message to the Iranian government: 'You're isolating yourself, you're making a choice that's not in the best interest of your people.'"

We will hopefully see a change of heart, but if we don't, we'll have to consider other measures to achieve our goal.

I appreciate the question. Let me be clear: our strategy is working. We're making progress in Iraq. We've got a new government, we've had elections, and we've got a plan in place to increase security and stability.

Now, I understand that there are still challenges on the ground, and I'm not naive about the risks and dangers that our troops face. But I believe that we're making headway, and I believe that our efforts are worth it.

Regarding the situation in Baghdad, I remember 2003 when we liberated that city from Saddam Hussein's tyranny. It was a proud moment for our troops and for the people of Iraq. And while the situation is complex and challenging today, I remain optimistic that our strategy can work.

We're adapting to the changing circumstances on the ground, and we're working closely with our Iraqi partners to build a secure and stable Iraq. It's not easy, but we're making progress, and I believe our efforts will ultimately be successful.

And to answer your question directly, I'm not married to a particular timeline. I'm committed to getting the job done, and if that takes more time, then so be it. We'll work together with our Iraqi partners to achieve our objectives and to create a more secure and stable Iraq.

I think that's a fair question. It's a hypothetical, of course. But I believe that Saddam Hussein was a gathering threat, and that's why I made the decision I did. And I still believe that. We had evidence, intelligence that suggested that Saddam Hussein had the capacity to produce weapons of mass destruction, and that he was a threat not just to the region, but to our own country.

Now, you can second-guess it all you want, and I understand that. But the truth is, we made the best decision we could with the information we had at the time. And I still believe it was the right decision.

Regarding the consequences of leaving, I'd say that we've made a commitment to the people of Iraq, to their government, to help them build a stable democracy. And if we were to leave prematurely, I believe there would be chaos, violence, and a totalitarian regime would emerge. And I don't think that's in the best interest of our country or the world.

So, it's a tough decision, and I'm not saying it's popular. But I do believe it's the right decision, and I'm willing to take the heat for it.

Well, I appreciate the question. Let me be clear: we have a stated policy in the United States that we do not negotiate with terrorist organizations, and Hamas is a terrorist organization. They've been designated as such by our government and by the international community.

As for former President Carter's decision to meet with Hamas leaders, I think it undermines our policy and the efforts of our allies in the region who are working towards a peaceful resolution to the conflict. When you negotiate with a terrorist organization, it gives them legitimacy. It gives them a platform to speak from. And it can create confusion among our friends and allies about where we stand.

We need to stand strong against terrorism, and we need to stand strong with our allies who are working towards peace in the region. And I think President Carter's actions were unhelpful in that regard.

Now, I understand that President Carter has a right to his own opinion, and he has a right to express it. But I also believe that he should respect the policies of the current administration, especially when it comes to dealing with terrorist organizations. We can't afford to send mixed signals, and we can't afford to give terrorists a platform to spread their hate and their violence.

We need a clear and consistent policy, and that's what we've been pursuing. We're working with our allies in the region to bring peace and stability to the Middle East, and we're going to continue to do so, no matter what.

Thank you for your question. You know, as President, I've always believed that the death penalty should be used in very rare and extreme circumstances. And I think it's our responsibility, both at the federal and state level, to ensure that it's applied fairly.

First and foremost, it's essential to have a strong and independent judiciary, where judges are confirmed based on their qualifications, not ideology. And that's what I've tried to do throughout my time in office, to appoint judges who will interpret the law, not make it.

Secondly, it's crucial to provide adequate funding for our public defender system, so that those who are facing the ultimate penalty have access to the best possible representation. Now, I know that this is a challenging issue, but it's one we can't afford to ignore.

Additionally, I believe we need to address the issue of racial disparity in the application of the death penalty. It's something that's been studied and documented, and it's something we need to work on. We need to ensure that the system is fair, and that justice is blind to racial and socio-economic factors.

Now, I've also asked the Department of Justice to review our federal death penalty procedures, to ensure that they're fair and consistent with our values. We must always remember that the death penalty is the ultimate penalty, and we must be 100% certain that justice is being served, and that the system is fair.

And finally, I want to emphasize the importance of criminal justice reform at the state level. We need to work with governors and state legislatures to implement reforms that will ensure fairness and accountability in our justice system.

It's a tough issue, but I believe with a combination of these efforts, we can make progress, and make sure that justice is served in the United States of America.

Thank you for that question. I am confident that the United Nations Security Council will take a tough, firm, and necessary resolution that will hold Iraq accountable for denying the inspectors the ability to do their job. I think it's in the world's interest, it's in the coalition's interest, it's in the interest of freedom and of peace that we work through the Security Council.

Now, I'm a patient man. I believe that we can succeed in the United Nations. We're getting good cooperation from our friends in the coalition. We're sharing intelligence, we're sharing concerns, and I believe we can get a resolution that will speak clearly to Saddam Hussein.

As for the next step, we're working on a series of diplomatic efforts, supported by the threat of force. I would remind you that the authorization for the use of military force is already in place. However, I believe we can get a resolution that makes it clear that the world stands united, and that if Saddam Hussein does not disarm, is not cooperating with inspectors, that the coalition is prepared to take action.

I want to emphasize that the use of military force is always the last resort, but it is not off the table. It's an option available to us if the need arises. Our preference, however, is for Saddam Hussein to disarm and to allow the inspectors to do their job.

But let me make it clear that either way, Saddam Hussein will not be allowed to continue to threaten the world with his WMD programs. It is unacceptable to have a nation like Iraq, which is producing biological, chemical, and attempting to produce nuclear weapons. The world is too unstable for him to be allowed to pursue this course. So, whether or not war is inevitable is really up to Saddam Hussein.

Well, thank you for the question. With regards to Harvey Pitt, I appreciate his service to the country as the Chairman of the SEC. However, we have been subjecting the SEC to a thorough review, and we've decided that it's time for new leadership. Harvey Pitt will be stepping down, but I appreciate the work he's done.

Regarding William Webster, I think it's clear that he is currently under scrutiny. As you know, he was the original choice to head the accounting oversight board. But in light of the questions being raised, I have lost confidence in his ability to lead this board effectively. So, yes, I will ask William Webster to step down from his position. We need to have leadership at the accounting oversight board that enjoys the confidence of the American people.

That's a fair question. Let me tell you, our objective is to disarm Iraq and to bring an end to the regime of Saddam Hussein. And I believe we can be successful in achieving that goal, even if we don't capture Saddam himself. Now, I know I've said "dead or alive," but the key is to make sure that he's no longer in a position to harm the Iraqi people or threaten his neighbors.

Our military is prepared to take the necessary steps to achieve that objective, and we're confident that we can do so. We're not just focused on one individual, we're focused on the entire regime. And if we can dismantle the regime, if we can take out the command and control structures, if we can eliminate the ability of Saddam to threaten his people or his neighbors, then I believe we can say that we've been successful.

Now, I'd be happy to catch Saddam, don't get me wrong. But the objective is not just to catch one man, the objective is to bring freedom to the Iraqi people, and to make sure that the world is a safer place. And I believe we can achieve that objective, even if we don't capture Saddam.

I appreciate your question. Well, I think it's a new day in Iraq, and the Iraqi people are taking control of their own destiny. The Governing Council's actions, I think, reflect the kind of democratic process that we're trying to instill in that country. Now, I will say that I was a little surprised, but I welcomed the move by the Governing Council to take more of a leadership role in the process of selecting their government. After all, this is a sovereign nation, and it's their decision to make.

As for the new Prime Minister, Ayad Allawi, I'm looking forward to working with him. I think he's a good man, a capable leader, and he's got a tough job ahead of him. I've heard some of his criticisms, but I also know that he's committed to helping build a stable and secure Iraq, and that's our goal as well. We'll work with him, and we'll work with the Iraqi people, to ensure that their country is a place of freedom, prosperity, and peace.

Now, I understand that there will be disagreements and there will be differences of opinion. But that's the beauty of democracy, and that's what we're trying to install in that country. I'm confident that we'll work through any differences, and we'll come out with a better result for the Iraqi people.

Thank you for that question. I did have the opportunity to meet with President Victor Yushchenko, and I was pleased to hear from him directly about Ukraine's strong desire to participate in NATO and to move forward with the Membership Action Plan.

The United States is committed to supporting Ukraine's efforts to join the NATO Alliance. We believe that Ukraine's membership in NATO would be an important step in solidifying democracy and security in the region.

Regarding the Membership Action Plan, I think it's clear that Ukraine has made significant progress in recent years, and we're encouraged by that progress. We're committed to continuing our dialogue with NATO and other allies to ensure that Ukraine's accession to the Alliance moves forward. While there are no guarantees, we will certainly be supportive of Ukraine's efforts to join the MAP, and we'll continue to work closely with them as they pursue that goal.

I think I was pretty clear about our position. We want to solve this problem peacefully. We're working with our friends and allies to encourage North Korea to dismantle its nuclear program. And I meant to say that the approach we're taking is diplomatic, working with China, working with Russia, and other partners, as well as South Korea and Japan.

We do have a other options available to us, but I think the best way to proceed is through diplomatic means, urging all parties to continue to work through diplomatic channels to resolve this issue peacefully.

Now I also reminded the international community, and I want to emphasize again, that inspectors need to be allowed back into the country, for the good of the international community. And the international community, I believe, will remain united in message and in actions to the North Koreans.

I think there's a better way forward for all of us working together. We want to deal with this problem through diplomatic means rather than through military action.

It's... (pauses) Well, I think it's very clear that the United States believes in democracy and believes in the institutions that help to institutionalize democracy, and we've got, of course, associations with these countries, and we're proud of what we've done to promote democratic reform.

I, and my predecessor, have always made it clear that it's in our national security interest to promote freedom and to promote institutions that will help to solidify freedom. But I also, I think it's very important for the media, and for the, I guess the critics or detractors, to understand that we are not – the United States is not – an instigator or a provocateur of, you know, kind of internal strife, nor a puppet master for key players.

It also seems to me the formula for democratic success is a combination of fair elections, and yes, of fair, visible periods of public discussion and debate, combined with free elections that take place in public light. But fundamentally, you had key players taking the right path.
