Thank you for the question. Alberto Gonzales is a fine public servant and a good friend. I think the criticism of him is unfair, and I believe he's doing a great job as the White House Counsel. However, I also know that he's a private citizen, and there's been some discussion about whether or not he should be the next Attorney General.

As for the litmus test, I think it's well known that I'm a conservative, and I think that's why the American people voted for me. But I also believe in nominating judges who will interpret the Constitution, not make law from the bench. And so, I think it's very important for me to find judges who share that philosophy.

Now, as for the issues of abortion and gay marriage, I think those are issues that are very important to a lot of Americans, and I don't think it's unfair for Americans to want to know where a judge stands on those issues. But I also believe that it's not a litmus test, per se.

I think what I'm looking for is judges who will uphold the Constitution, who will interpret the law, and who will be fair and impartial. And I believe that there are plenty of good men and women out there who share those qualities, and who will be able to check their personal views at the door, and make decisions based on the law, not on their personal views.

So, I think it's a little bit of both – I think it's fair for Americans to want to know where a judge stands on certain issues, but I also think it's very important to make sure that we don't set up a litmus test that would prevent good, qualified people from being considered for the bench.

Well, I appreciate that question. Let me start by saying that I am committed to doing what it takes to make my administration successful, and that includes making changes when they are necessary.

We're at a time of war, we're at a time of transition in the world, and we're also at a time of big ideas in Washington, D.C. And I'm making adjustments to my team to reflect that. I'm bringing in some fresh faces, folks who share my vision for the country, folks who are experienced, folks who can help me drive an agenda that I think is going to make America a safer and more prosperous place.

Now, I know some of the critics have said, "Oh, this is a shake-up." And my answer to that is, "You can't stay stuck in neutral when it comes to making big decisions." You've got to be willing to challenge the status quo, to take a hard look at your team, and to make adjustments when necessary.

And that's exactly what I'm doing. I'm taking a hard look at my team, and I'm making adjustments that I believe will help me achieve my goals. I'm a results-oriented person, and I expect the same from my team.

So, to answer your question, I think these changes reflect my commitment to doing what it takes to get the job done, to make our country safer and more prosperous, and to stay on the offense when it comes to fighting terror and fighting for freedom.

Thank you, I appreciate the question. As you know, we've been reviewing our strategy in Iraq, and I've been meeting with our top military leaders to assess the situation on the ground. While we've made significant progress in training Iraqi security forces and in conducting operations against the enemy, we still have a tough fight ahead of us.

Regarding the potential for sending more troops, I want to be very clear: we're not yet at a point where we can rule it out, but we're also not at a point where we've made a decision to do so. We're taking a careful and deliberate approach, and any decision would be based on the needs of our commanders on the ground and the effectiveness of our overall strategy.

The justification for any additional troops would be to support our military efforts to disrupt and dismantle the enemy's ability to wage terrorist attacks against our brave men and women in uniform and the Iraqi people. Our goal remains to transfer responsibility for security to the Iraqi forces, and we believe we're making progress in that regard.

As for the timetable you mentioned, the 12 to 18 months you're referring to is a rough estimate for when we hope to complete the transition process and have Iraqi forces take the lead on security operations. It's not a hard and fast deadline, but rather a goal we're working towards. We're taking a flexible and adaptable approach, listening to our military commanders, and adjusting our plan as necessary.

Let me be clear: we will not be held hostage by a specific timeline if it means putting our troops or the success of our mission at risk. Our mission is to win the war on terror, and we will do what it takes to achieve that goal.

Thank you for your question. I'm not gonna go into detail about the classified information we have, but I can tell you that we take the situation with Iran very seriously. The reports about their nuclear program are concerning, and we're working closely with our international partners to address this issue.

What I will say is that we're not going to take any options off the table, diplomacy, pressure, or other means. We believe that a nuclear Iran is unacceptable, and we're working to prevent that from happening.

We're also pushing for the international community to come together and address this problem. We need to get the Iranian government to understand that their actions are unacceptable, and that we're united in our resolve to prevent them from developing a nuclear capability.

I've also been in close contact with our friends and allies around the world, from the European Union to Russia and China, and we're all on the same page on this issue. We agree that Iran should not be allowed to have a nuclear weapon.

Now, I know that the estimates given by ABC are one thing, but what's more important is the impact and what do we do about it. This administration will continue to use all means at its disposal to keep the pressure on Iran and make sure that they know the world will not stand idly by if they continue to go down this road.

We'll keep watching, and we'll keep working on this issue, but I want to emphasize that our goal is to solve this problem peacefully, through diplomacy if possible, but not to allow them to get to the point of making a decision that would be unwise for the world.

I think there's been a mistake. I'm the President of the United States, George W. Bush, not the Prime Minister. And I'm happy to answer your question.

Regarding the situation with Israel, I'm aware of the political developments and the potential implications for the coalition. I do have concerns about the stability of the region, and we're closely monitoring the situation. We'll continue to support the Israeli government in its efforts to achieve peace and security, and we'll work with all parties to ensure that the core issues, such as a two-state solution and Israel's right to self-defense, remain on the table.

Now, I'd like to clarify that Avigdor Lieberman is the head of the Yisrael Beiteinu party, and if he were to withdraw from the coalition, that could potentially affect the stability of the Israeli government. But I'm confident that Prime Minister Olmert and his government will take the necessary steps to address the situation and maintain a stable and secure Israel.

Well, thank you for your question. I'm pleased to report that my meetings with Chancellor Schroeder of Germany and President Chirac of France were very productive, and we had a good, open discussion about our mutual interests in the Ukraine.

Regarding their support for Ukraine's integration with Europe, I would say that we're making progress. While we didn't get a definitive "yes" or a "no" from them, we did have a constructive dialogue about the importance of supporting democracy and economic reform in the Ukraine.

It's clear that both Germany and France want to see a stable and prosperous Ukraine, and they're willing to work with us to achieve that goal. We may have some differences about the pace and scope of Ukraine's integration with Europe, but we're committed to finding common ground and supporting the Ukrainian people as they build a more democratic and market-driven economy.

Now, this visit has been remarkable in many ways. First, it's been an opportunity for me to reaffirm America's commitment to a united and peaceful Europe. I've been impressed by the strong relationships that we've built with our European partners, and I'm confident that we can work together to address the challenges that we face.

Second, this visit has allowed us to discuss a range of critical issues, from counter-terrorism and non-proliferation to economic reform and trade. We've made some tangible progress on these issues, and I believe that our cooperation will continue to grow and deepen in the months and years ahead.

And finally, this visit has been remarkable for the opportunity it's given me to see firsthand the progress that Ukraine has made in recent years. The Ukrainian people have been through a lot, but they're working hard to build a better future for themselves, and I'm proud to say that America is supporting them every step of the way.

So, all in all, I'm very pleased with the outcome of this visit, and I believe that we've laid the groundwork for even stronger cooperation between America, Germany, France, and Ukraine in the months and years ahead.

Well, I appreciate that question. As you know, the United Nations played a very important role in the aftermath of the conflict, particularly in the humanitarian area. We've worked closely with the Secretary General, and I've worked hard to make sure that we're paying our dues to the United Nations.

Now, I understand that there are some on the Hill who've suggested we should withhold dues, but I think that would be a mistake. First of all, we need the influence of the United Nations to help us deal with conflicts such as the one in Iraq. And, secondly, I believe in paying our dues.

Now, I do think that the United Nations ought to be reformed. I think it can be a more effective organization, and we've been working with the Secretary General to do just that. But I'm not in favor of withholding dues.

Thank you for the question. I believe that the United States and Europe have a shared interest in the Middle East, and it's essential that we work together to promote peace and stability in the region. Our partnership is crucial in addressing the challenges we face, and I think we can be effective partners in helping to resolve the Israeli-Palestinian conflict.

Now, I will say that as president of the United States, I have made it clear that the United States is committed to leading the international effort to help find a solution to this conflict. We've been working closely with our European allies on the Quartet on the Middle East (which includes the US, the European Union, Russia, and the United Nations) to help the parties achieve a two-state solution.

That being said, I do believe that we need to be mindful of our respective roles and responsibilities. The United States has a unique relationship with Israel, and I've made it clear that we will continue to support our friend and ally Israel. At the same time, we're working to strengthen our relationships with the Arab states, and to encourage them to take a more active role in promoting peace and stability in the region.

So, I think we can be equal partners in the sense that we share a common goal, but I also think it's essential that we be mindful of our respective roles and responsibilities as we work together to promote peace in the Middle East.

(pausing for a moment) Well, I understand that there are some folks out there who think that's the case, but I gotta tell you, that's just not accurate. My duty as President is to protect and promote the interests of all Americans, not just one group or another. We've worked hard to create an environment that's good for business, because we know that when American businesses are strong, the economy is strong, and that means jobs and opportunities for ordinary Americans.

(squaring his shoulders) Now, I'll admit, we've had some tough decisions to make, and we've taken some steps to make sure our economy's competitive in a changing world. But I believe our policies have been sound, and I believe they're bearing fruit. The economy's grown, jobs have been created, and ordinary Americans are better off today than they were when I took office.

Of course, there's always more work to be done, and we're not satisfied with the progress we've made. But I can tell you, our focus has been on making sure that the benefits of our policies are felt by all Americans, not just a select few. That's why we've worked to cut taxes for everyday Americans, to make sure they've got access to quality healthcare and education, and to keep this country safe and secure.

Now, I know some folks might disagree with our approach, but I've always said, we're not going to get everything right. We're going to make some mistakes. But I can tell you this: we've always put the interests of ordinary Americans first, and we're going to keep doing that for the rest of our time in office.

Thank you for the question. As I've said before, it's in the interests of the United States, and indeed the world, to see a stable and democratic Pakistan. The current state of affairs there is concerning, to say the least.

Regarding the reports about President Musharraf dissolving the Parliament, I'd like to say that we're monitoring the situation closely. We're urging calm and restraint, and we're encouraging President Musharraf to adhere to the democratic process.

What I would like to see happen is for Pakistan to continue on the path of democratic reform. This includes holding free and fair elections, allowing for the active participation of opposition parties, and ensuring that the rule of law is upheld.

We've been working closely with the Pakistani government to support their efforts to combat extremism and promote democratic reforms. And I believe that it's essential for the future stability and prosperity of Pakistan that these efforts continue.

I'd also like to emphasize that our relationship with Pakistan is based on mutual interests and mutual respect. We share a common goal of defeating terrorism and extremism, and we'll continue to work together to achieve that goal.

Now, I know that there are many challenges facing Pakistan, and there will be ups and downs along the way. But I remain optimistic about the potential for democratic progress in Pakistan, and we'll continue to engage with the Pakistani government to support their efforts in this regard.

Thank you for your question. Look, I understand that the negotiations with North Korea are challenging, and their rejection of our offer is not unexpected. We've been down this road before, and we know that it's gonna take time, patience, and a strong resolve to get the Koreans to come to the table.

Now, I'm not gonna go into details of our strategy, but I will say that we're not gonna be intimidated by their rhetoric. We're gonna continue to work with our allies, including the South Koreans, the Japanese, and the Chinese, to apply pressure on the North Koreans to come to the table and to make a deal that's in the best interest of the region.

Regarding Iran, I'm convinced that our message is getting through. We've made it clear that the United States will not tolerate a nuclear-armed Iran, and that we're willing to work with the international community to prevent that from happening.

Now, I'm not saying that the Iranians are gonna give up their nuclear ambitions overnight, but I'm confident that our efforts, in conjunction with the international community, are having an impact. We're working closely with the Europeans, the Russians, and the Chinese to send a united message to the Iranians that they must comply with the demands of the IAEA and the UN Security Council.

But let me be clear: we're not gonna accept a nuclear-armed Iran, and we're prepared to take all necessary steps, including diplomatic, economic, and, if necessary, military options, to prevent that from happening.

So, in short, we're gonna stay the course, we're gonna stay tough, and we're gonna keep working towards a solution that advances American interests and secures the peace and security of the region.

I understand their concerns and their feelings. And I appreciate their input. However, I will not be pulling the ad. The ad is factual, it's respectful, and it's understated. I believe it's an important reminder of the significance of this moment in our nation's history. I think the event of 9/11 is something that we as a nation have to be mindful of and work hard to prevent it from happening again. I hope the American people will understand that the threat to our country is very real, and it is a threat that requires strong and decisive leadership, and I intend to provide that leadership.

Thank you for that question. I appreciate it. I've had a good conversation with Prime Minister Martin about our mutual desire to secure Iraq. We both understand that it's in our national interest that Iraq becomes a peaceful, stable country that doesn't become a haven for terrorists.

First of all, I appreciate the Canadian government's willingness to provide humanitarian aid to the Iraqi people. They've done a good job, and I appreciate their efforts.

In terms of security, I think it's very important for all nations to contribute in a meaningful way. Whether or not Canada participates with troops is up to the Canadian government to decide. I believe we can find common ground, though, in terms of providing training and assistance to the Iraqi security forces as they develop their capabilities.

It's going to be a long haul, but I think it's in our national interest, the national interest of both our countries, that we cooperate in this matter. I think it's too early to say exactly how it's all going to shake out, but I appreciate the willingness of Prime Minister Martin to consider contributing in meaningful ways to help the Iraqi people.

Now, I must remind everybody, our goal is to transfer authority and security responsibility to the Iraqis as quickly as possible. That's our strategy, that's our policy. So, to the extent that nations want to contribute, we're open to that. And we'll certainly work with the Canadian government to see how best to take their willingness to help and coordinate it with the international efforts to bring stability to Iraq.

We've also discussed a precedent for international engagement on security issues for civil police assistance in places like Kosovo, where, as you know, Canada played a significant role. The development of Iraqi security forces, I think, will provide another opportunity for us to work together, not necessarily within the coalition, but through a UN mandate or other mechanisms that can bring international support.

So, I appreciate Prime Minister Martin's enthusiasm about wanting to contribute. I think it's very important that we work closely to get this mission done.

Thank you for the question. I understand the challenges we're facing in the Middle East, and I appreciate the complexity of the situation. The United States remains committed to a peaceful resolution in the region, and we're working closely with all parties involved to achieve that goal.

First, I want to commend Secretary Rice for her tireless efforts in the region. She's been working day and night to bring people together and to encourage a peaceful resolution.

In terms of the draft proposal, we're not there yet. We believe it's a good start, but we understand that it's not acceptable to all parties. We're going to keep working. We're going to keep talking to the parties involved, and we're going to make sure that we do everything we can to encourage a peaceful resolution.

One thing's for certain: the United States will not be swayed from our commitment to the security of Israel, and we will not be swayed from our commitment to a peaceful Lebanon. We believe in a two-state solution, and we're going to keep working towards that.

In terms of getting a resolution that both sides will support, we're going to have to be patient. We're going to have to work through the diplomatic channels, and we're going to have to be willing to listen to all parties involved. And we're going to have to be willing to make some tough decisions, but we will not let up in our pursuit of peace.

And finally, I believe that the international community needs to come together in support of a peaceful resolution. We need to stand together, and we need to say with one voice that we support the peaceful resolution of this conflict.

Thank you.

Thank you for the question. I appreciate your interest in the situation in Iraq. As you know, we're constantly evaluating our strategy and tactics to ensure that we're positioning ourselves for success in achieving our objectives. I've been very clear that our goal is to help the Iraqi people establish a stable, self-sufficient democracy that can defend itself.

Now, I've had a chance to speak with Senator Warner and others, and I appreciate their input. But let me be clear: we're not going to be driven by polls or by conventional wisdom. We're going to be driven by the facts on the ground and by the advice of our military commanders.

That being said, I am willing to consider new ideas and perspectives, as always. I've asked my national security team to be constantly looking at our strategy and tactics, to see if there are ways we can improve our position. We're constantly adapting, constantly evolving, to meet the changing circumstances on the ground.

So, to answer your question directly, I'm willing to consider new ideas, but I'm not willing to second-guess myself at this point. We've got a strategy in place that I believe is the right one, and we're going to see it through.

And I might add, it's also important for us to stay focused on the big picture here. We're not just fighting terrorism in Iraq; we're fighting it globally. We're not just fighting it for the sake of the Iraqis; we're fighting it for the sake of security and freedom here at home and around the world.

So, we'll continue to evaluate, we'll continue to adapt, and we'll continue to do what's necessary to achieve our objectives.

Well, first of all, I'm not going to give a green light to Israel. I'm not going to tell the Israelis what to do. But I think it's very important for the world to work together to prevent Iran from having a nuclear program. And the reason I believe that is because a nuclear Iran would be a destabilizing influence in the Middle East.

Secondly, I firmly believe that we have a diplomatic path forward. I'm more optimistic that we can get the Iranians to change their ways. And I'm more optimistic that we can convince the Iranians that we mean what we say. And what we're saying is that we want them to be a non-nuclear nation.

Now, if that doesn't work, then we'll have to work with our allies to consider other options. But I want to lead this world to a place where we don't have to think about using military force. I believe that there's a way to solve this issue without resorting to military confrontation.

And as for when I leave office, I hope that the momentum that we've built on this issue continues. The international community is united, by and large, in saying to the Iranians, "We don't want you to have a nuclear program." And I believe that the next President of the United States will have a very strong foundation to build upon.

Thank you for the question. Yes, we are taking a close look at our assistance programs to Russia, including the Cooperative Threat Reduction, or Nunn-Lugar, initiative. This program has been quite successful in helping the Russians secure and dismantle their weapons of mass destruction, and we believe it's in our national security interest to continue to support these efforts.

However, we're also concerned about the recent actions of the Russian government, particularly in terms of their handling of the media, their treatment of Mr. Khodorkovsky, and other issues that raise questions about the democratic development of Russia. As a result, we are reviewing all of our assistance programs to Russia to make sure that they are consistent with our values and our national security interests.

I want to emphasize that our goal is to work cooperatively with the Russian government to address the threats we face from the spread of WMD, but we also expect the Russian government to live up to its commitments to democratic values and human rights. We're not making any decisions on reductions in assistance at this point, but we are looking very carefully at the relationship and considering all of our options.

It's a delicate balance, but we're committed to pursuing our national security interests while also promoting democratic values and practices around the world.

Thank you for the question. As you know, we've been working very closely with our international partners, particularly the Quartet - that's the United States, the United Nations, the European Union, and Russia - on a comprehensive approach to bringing peace to the Middle East.

Our decision to pursue a UN resolution on a future Palestinian state is a critical part of this effort. We believe that by moving forward with this resolution now, we can build on the momentum from the recent Palestinian elections and the progress that we've made on the ground in areas such as economic development and security.

It's also clear that time is of the essence. The roadmap has been in place for several years, and it's time to build on the progress we've made and push towards a negotiated two-state solution.

We believe that this resolution will send a clear message to the parties that it's time to move forward, to make the necessary compromises, and to demonstrate a commitment to peace.

Make no mistake, this will require sacrifices from both sides. But we're confident that by working together, and with the support of the international community, we can make meaningful progress towards peace in the Middle East.

This is a challenging and complex process, and there will be obstacles along the way. But we're committed to seeing this through, and we're hopeful that our partners in the international community will join us in this effort.

Thank you. Next question, please.

Well, I think it's interesting that the IAEA says they believe the Iranians have suspended their enrichment activities. But I will tell you that my skepticism is high, and it's high because of the Iranians' past behavior. They have not been transparent, they have not been truthful, and they have not been forthcoming about their nuclear program.

We urge Iran to comply fully with the IAEA, we urge them to answer all the questions that the IAEA has, and we urge them to come clean about their nuclear program. And until they do, we're going to be very skeptical.

And let me remind you that our goal is to make sure that Iran does not develop a nuclear weapon. And we're going to work with our friends and allies to make sure that that goal is achieved. So, while we welcome the report, I think it's one step in a process. And we need to remain vigilant and keep the pressure on.

It's also important to remember that just suspension is not enough. We need full compliance, we need Iran to abandon its nuclear ambitions, and we need them to be transparent in their dealings with the international community.

Well, thank you for that question. We are deeply concerned about the Iranians' nuclear program, and we believe it's a threat to peace in the Middle East and beyond. As for the IAEA, I appreciate the work that Director General ElBaradei is doing. However, I must say that we would have liked to have seen a more robust response from the IAEA in their report. 

We're working closely with our allies and friends in the international community to address this issue, and we will be consulting with the Security Council in the coming days. As you know, we've been saying all along that this issue needs to be dealt with in the Security Council if Iran doesn't comply with the IAEA's requests. We can't let Iran become a nuclear power, and we're going to work with our friends and allies to see that that doesn't happen.

Now, I want to make one thing very clear: We're committed to diplomacy, we're committed to working with the international community to find a solution to this issue. But all options are on the table, and we will not take any option off the table.

Well, thank you for that question. I appreciate the opportunity to address this issue. First, let me say that we're disappointed, but not surprised, by the Iranian response. We've seen this kind of rhetoric before, and it's unfortunate that they're not taking the European offer seriously.

Regarding the incentives, I believe we've made a strong proposal, one that offers a path forward for the Iranian people to achieve their economic and security interests. We've been clear that this is a serious offer, and we're not going to engage in endless negotiations without some sense of urgency and seriousness on the part of the Iranians.

Now, as for the timeline, we're still working with our partners in the EU-3 - France, Germany, and the UK - to determine the best course of action. We're not going to put a specific timeline on it, but I will say that patience is wearing thin. We've been at this for a while now, and we need to see some movement.

If the Iranians continue to reject our offer, we'll have to start thinking about other options, including, of course, going to the Security Council. We're not ruling anything out, and we're working closely with our partners to ensure that we're presenting a united front.

Let me be clear: we will not back down on the issue of enrichment and reprocessing. This is a non-negotiable for us, and for the international community. The Iranians need to understand that they're not going to be able to develop a nuclear program in secret, and we're going to hold them accountable.

Well, good afternoon, thank you for the question. I do have high expectations for the Iraq neighbors conference, and we've been working closely with the Iraqis and the United Nations to make sure it's a success. It's a great opportunity for the countries in the region to come together, to discuss ways to support the Iraqi government and the Iraqi people as they work to build a more stable and secure future for themselves.

As for talking directly with Iran and Syria, I have to say that I remain skeptical about the intentions of those two countries, particularly Iran. We've seen their active efforts to destabilize the situation in Iraq, and I've made it clear that any conversations we have with them will need to be aimed at getting them to stop doing that. I'm willing to listen to what they have to say, but I'm not willing to legitimize their behavior or to make concessions to them just for the sake of talking.

I am sending our Secretary of State, Condoleezza Rice, to the meeting, and she'll be able to engage in conversations with her counterparts from Iran and Syria, if they choose to attend. But let me be clear, our message to them will be the same one we've been saying all along: you need to stop supporting the terrorists who are killing our troops and innocent Iraqis, you need to stop your nuclear program, and you need to stop stirring up sectarian violence in Iraq. If they're willing to do that, then we're willing to listen to what they have to say. But until then, I'm not optimistic that we'll make much progress.

Thank you for the question. We've been following the situation with Turkey and the Kurdish rebels very closely. I urge the Turkish parliament to be mindful of the consequences of such an action. We've worked hard to build a united Iraq, and we've got to be careful about troops moving across borders.

That being said, Turkey does have a legitimate concern about the PKK, which is a terrorist organization, operating in Iraq. And I believe that any discussion about military action should be done with the Baghdad government, with President Talabani, and with the unity of the Iraqi people in mind.

We're working with the Turkish government to address their concerns about the PKK, but I'm concerned about any military action that's taken unilaterally. I think we can address this issue through diplomatic efforts and a continued dialogue between Iraq, Turkey, and the United States.

I think there may be some confusion here. I'm not Prime Minister Brown; I'm President George W. Bush. Now, regarding the issue at hand, I agree that the recent spike in global food prices is a pressing matter that requires our attention.

The United States is committed to addressing this crisis. We're working with our international partners to increase global food production, particularly in countries most affected by food shortages. One concrete measure we're taking is to support the work of the World Food Programme and other humanitarian organizations to deliver emergency food aid to those in need.

Regarding biofuel policy, I believe it's essential to consider the unintended consequences of certain policies. While biofuels are an important component of our effort to reduce our reliance on fossil fuels, I think we need to have a more nuanced approach to this issue.

Our biofuel policies must be carefully balanced to ensure that they do not inadvertently drive up food prices or lead to food shortages. In the United States, for example, we're exploring ways to diversify our biofuel production, including investing in research and development of second-generation biofuels that can be produced from non-food sources, such as agricultural waste and switchgrass.

We're also working with our international partners to promote a more sustainable approach to biofuel production, one that takes into account the need to ensure global food security while also addressing the urgent challenge of climate change.

Thank you for that question. Africa is a continent that's near and dear to my heart, and my wife Laura's. We've had a chance to visit several countries in Africa, and we've seen firsthand the incredible potential of the African people, and also the incredible challenges they face.

Now, when it comes to global warming, I know that Africa is one of the regions that's most vulnerable to its effects. Rising temperatures, more frequent droughts, and extreme weather events are all going to have a disproportionate impact on African countries.

That's why, in my 2008 budget, I've proposed a significant increase in funding for our international climate change program, with a focus on helping developing countries like those in Africa adapt to the impacts of climate change.

We're also working with international partners to build on the success of our Millennium Challenge Account, which is providing new development assistance to countries that govern justly, fight corruption, and invest in their people.

In addition, we're committed to the President's Emergency Plan for AIDS Relief, also known as PEPFAR, which is having a significant impact in countries across Africa.

And let me tell you, we're not just stopping there. At the G8 Summit in Heiligendamm, Germany, I had a meaningful discussion with African leaders about how we can work together to address the challenges facing their countries.

Now, I know that there's no single solution to these challenges, but we're committed to working in partnership with the people of Africa to help them build a brighter future for themselves and their children.

Thank you for that question. Regarding U.S.-Russian relations, I do believe that the recent spy case has put a strain on our relationship. However, I remain committed to building a strong and constructive partnership between our two nations. As I've said before, I believe that a strong relationship between the U.S. and Russia is essential to addressing the global challenges we face, from combating terrorism to non-proliferation.

That being said, the alleged espionage activities by Russian officials are a serious matter, and we will continue to take appropriate action to protect our national security interests. We've already made it clear that we expect Russia to end any and all activities that harm our national security, and we'll continue to work diplomatically to resolve this issue.

Regarding missile defense, I must say that we're still waiting to see a willingness on the part of the Russians to engage in serious discussions about our plans for a missile defense system. We believe that a limited defense system, as we're proposing, is a necessary measure to protect our country and our allies from the growing threat of ballistic missiles. We're still open to Russian concerns, but we also believe that our proposals for a limited system are not a threat to Russia's security.

We've got some time yet before the NATO Summit in Riga, and we hope that the Russians will take a more constructive approach to this issue. We're optimistic that we can work through our differences, but we're also prepared to move forward with our plans if necessary.

Well, I appreciate that question. Let me make it clear that my position on tax cuts is well-known. I believe that tax cuts can stimulate the economy, and I'm committed to getting this economy growing. However, I also understand the importance of fiscal discipline.

Now, regarding the specific question, I've made it clear that we cannot let our desire for short-term stimulus get in the way of long-term fiscal responsibility. Therefore, I will not support a package that exceeds $1.6 trillion over the next 10 years. If a tax package came to my desk that exceeded that amount, I would have to veto it.

However, I do believe that we can find common ground. I'm working closely with both Democrats and Republicans to craft a package that will stimulate the economy, but also ensures that we can still meet the commitment I made to the American people about balancing the budget and holding the line on spending.

I think we can achieve that goal, and I'm committed to working with Congress to achieve a package that does just that – stimulates the economy, but also remains fiscally responsible.

Thank you for the question.  Let me tell you, we're not looking for a trade war, but we're going to protect the American steel industry.  The decision I made to impose tariffs on imported steel was a difficult one, but it was necessary to level the playing field, to make sure that our workers and companies can compete fairly in the world market.

Now, I understand that some of our allies are concerned, and we're willing to listen to their concerns. But I've also made it clear that we will not allow our steel industry to be threatened by unfair practices from abroad.

This is not a tax increase, I want to make that clear.  This is a trade decision, and it's aimed at defending our industry. Now, I know some may try to argue that it's a tax, but I'm telling you, it's not. It's anecessary measure to ensure that our economy remains strong and competitive.

And let me tell you, I'm committed to free trade, I'm committed to working with our allies, and we'll continue to do so. But we'll also defend our interests, and that's what this decision is all about. Thank you.

Thank you, and good afternoon. I appreciate your question. The threat of terrorism, unfortunately, is still very real, and we take all threats seriously. The information we have received suggests that there is a potential threat to the aviation industry, but I want to emphasize that we have no specific, credible information about an imminent attack.

We are working closely with our partners, foreign and domestic, to gather all available information and to take the necessary steps to protect the American people. The Department of Homeland Security, the Transportation Security Administration, and our intelligence agencies are all working closely together to analyze the threat and to implement any necessary security measures.

We've also increased the level of security at our airports, and we're working with the airlines to make sure that they are taking the necessary precautions.

I want to assure the American people that we are doing everything in our power to protect our citizens. We have a robust security system in place, and we're constantly reviewing and updating our procedures to make sure that we're doing everything we can to prevent an attack.

I also want to remind the American people that the best way to combat terrorism is to stay informed, to be vigilant, and to report any suspicious activity to the authorities.

We will not let the terrorists succeed in their attempts to disrupt our way of life. We will not be intimidated by their threats. We will continue to work tirelessly to protect our people, and we will not rest until we have brought those who would harm us to justice.

And I want to remind everyone that the American people are a resilient people. We will not be deterred by the threat of terrorism. We will continue to live our lives, to work, to travel, and to enjoy our freedom, and we will do so with confidence and security.

Thank you.

Well, I appreciate the chance to discuss this issue that's very important to our friends to the north. We've had a difficult time, certainly, with BSE, or mad cow disease. We've got a commission, the Office International des Épizooties, that has helped us to work through these issues, and we've made significant progress.

We've been working closely with the Canadians. Secretary Johanns has been particularly active, and I want to thank him for it. We've been working through the tough issues. The Canadians have made some adjustments in their reporting and testing procedures. We're in the process of looking at the Canadian plan, and I'm hopeful that we can begin to allow Canadian cattle into the United States sooner rather than later.

I want to emphasize that my administration is committed to finding a way to restore trade in cattle and beef products with Canada, and to doing so in a way that ensures the health and safety of our citizens. We're working closely with our Canadian friends, and we're optimistic that we'll make progress.

(smiling) Ah, thank you for the courtesy, I appreciate that. (pauses) Italy, our great ally, has indeed been a vital partner in our efforts to combat terrorism and promote global security. Prime Minister Berlusconi and I have had many discussions on these issues, and I must say, we share a strong commitment to the principles of freedom and democracy.

Now, specifically regarding our cooperation with Italy, I'd say that they've been a valued member of the coalition in Afghanistan and Iraq. Their troops have played a key role in the stabilization efforts, particularly in the southern region of Iraq. (pauses) We appreciate their courage and sacrifice, just as we do with all our coalition partners.

In addition, Italy has been a strong supporter of our efforts to counter terrorism, not only in the Middle East but also in the Balkans and elsewhere. Their intelligence services have been helpful in sharing information and coordinating our counter-terrorism efforts.

So, in short, Italy has been a stalwart ally, and we value our partnership with Prime Minister Berlusconi and the Italian people.

Well, I appreciate the question. Let me make one thing very clear: the United States and our allies are working closely together to address the threat posed by Saddam Hussein's regime in Iraq. We are exploring all options to achieve our goal of disarmament and I talked to President Chirac the other day. 

As for the idea that we were proposing that NATO as an organization intervene directly in Iraq, I reject that notion. What the Secretary-General of NATO and I have discussed is not intervention but making a commitment to defend Turkey should it be attacked, providing Franco-British U.S. capabilities which would make the life of any combatant much more uncomfortable.

We are working together, and I believe that we are making good progress in our conversations. There are some differences, no question about it. But we are working through these differences, and I'm very confident that we can find common ground.

Well, first of all, the June 30th handover is a major milestone in the history of Iraq and the history of Iraq's march towards democracy and freedom. It's the beginning of a new era for that country. It's a transfer of sovereignty from the Coalition Provisional Authority to the Iraqi people, and it's a major step towards Iraq taking control of its own destiny.

In terms of an exit strategy, I've said all along that we'll leave Iraq when the job is done. And the job is to help the Iraqis build a stable, secure, and free society. We'll continue to work with the Iraqi government to ensure that they have the capability to defend themselves and their government.

Now, as for Zarqawi, he's a significant threat, there's no question about it. He's a terrorist, an al-Qaeda affiliate, who is trying to drive a wedge between the people of Iraq and the new government. But I'm confident that the Iraqi government, with the help of coalition forces, will ultimately defeat him. We'll continue to work to bring him to justice, and we won't be intimidated by his tactics.

It's also worth noting that the Iraqi people are making a choice. They're choosing a path of freedom, a path of democracy, and a path of peace. And Zarqawi and his associates are trying to disrupt that. But I'm confident that the Iraqi people will remain committed to this course, and we'll continue to support them every step of the way.

Thank you for that question. I believe Pope John Paul II was a truly remarkable leader, and his impact on America's spiritual life has been significant. He was a powerful voice for justice and compassion, and his message of hope and forgiveness has inspired countless Americans. His commitment to the principles of human dignity and the value of every human life has been a source of guidance for me and for many Americans.

Now, regarding his opposition to the war in Iraq, I will say that I respect the Pope's moral authority and his voice in the international community. While we didn't agree on the decision to go to war, I took his concerns seriously and gave them due consideration.

However, as President, I also had a duty to protect the American people and to make decisions based on the best information available to me at the time. I believed that Saddam Hussein's regime posed a threat to our national security, and that it was essential to take action to protect the United States and the world from that threat.

It's worth noting that the Pope and I didn't always see eye-to-eye on this issue, but we did share a deep commitment to human dignity and to the importance of promoting peace and understanding in the world. I valued his counsel, even when we disagreed, and I will always respect his legacy as a champion of justice and compassion.

I appreciate the confidence, and I appreciate the advice. (pauses) I've got a good team around me. We've been working very hard to get a lot done. And we've been making progress. I'm proud of the team I've assembled.

Now, I'm always open to change, if it's in the best interest of the country. But I'm also mindful that I've got a lot of terrific people around me, dedicated public servants who are working for the American people. So, I think it's a bit too early to speculate on any changes. We're gonna keep working, we're gonna keep pushing, and we're gonna keep focusing on getting the job done for the American people.

(pausing briefly)

And by the way, I'm also proud of the message that we're getting out to the country. It's a positive message. It's a message of optimism and hope. And I think that's what the country needs right now. So, we're gonna keep working, and we're gonna keep pushing.

Well, I respect President Carter, and I'm not surprised that we've got differences of opinion. That's the way it is in politics, and I'm used to it. As for what he said, I'll just say that I disagree with his characterizations and his critique of our policies. I think history will show that we've made some very difficult decisions, but the right decisions, for the security and prosperity of the American people.

Now, I understand that not everyone's going to agree with me, and that's just fine. That's part of the democratic process. But I will say that I'm proud of the policies we've implemented, and I'm proud of the record we've built. And I think that, at the end of the day, the American people will judge us on our results, not on the speculation or the criticism of others.

And let me just add, I've always believed in the importance of former Presidents being dignified in their critiques. President Carter and I have a cordial relationship, and I'd like to think that we can disagree without being disagreeable.

The issue of carried interest. Well, I think this is a matter that's been debated in Washington for a long time. As I see it, carried interest is a key component of the way that private equity and venture capital firms operate, and we need to be careful about how we approach it.

I believe that taxing carried interest at capital gains rates is fair, because it's a form of compensation that's tied to the performance of the investments that these firms are making. It's not a salary or a wage; it's a return on investment, and it's treated that way for tax purposes.

Now, I know that some folks might say, "Well, wait a minute, this is just a way for wealthy investors to avoid paying their fair share of taxes." And I understand that concern. But the fact is, carried interest is a key part of the way that these firms are incentivized to take risks and make investments in companies that might not otherwise get funding.

That being said, I'm open to having a conversation about how we can ensure that our tax code is fair and equitable. If there are ways to make sure that wealthy investors are paying their fair share, I'm happy to listen to those ideas. But I think we need to be careful about how we approach this issue, because we don't want to inadvertently harm the ability of private equity and venture capital firms to make investments in companies that are creating jobs and driving economic growth.

Yes, I do have some concerns about the potential risks associated with investments from foreign governments, especially those from countries with, shall we say, less than transparent investment practices.

As you know, our economy is built on the principles of free enterprise and an open market system. And I believe that foreign investment can be beneficial, as long as it's done in a way that doesn't compromise our national security or the integrity of our financial markets.

Now, I've been assured by our Treasury Secretary, Hank Paulson, that the investments we're talking about – from sovereign wealth funds – are subject to the same scrutiny as any other investor. And I've been told that these investments are in the form of minority stakes, not controlling interests.

But I do think it's prudent that we take a careful look at this issue, to make sure that our institutions, our financial markets, and our national security are protected. We need to make sure that we maintain transparency and adhere to our core principles of free market capitalism.

So, to answer your question, I do have some concerns, but I also believe that we can benefit from responsible foreign investment, as long as we proceed with caution and a careful eye on our national interests. Thank you.

Good afternoon, thank you for your question.  The recent controversies in the FBI are, quite frankly, a concern for me and for the American people. I believe it's essential that the next Director of the FBI is a person of impeccable integrity, strong leadership skills, and the ability to unite the agency behind a common purpose. 

I'm looking for someone who understands the magnitude of the role and the trust that comes with it. They must be able to inspire confidence in the American people and within the law enforcement community. We're in the process of vetting candidates, and I'll be making a decision soon.

One thing is certain: the next FBI Director will be someone who shares my commitment to the safety and security of the American people and will work tirelessly to protect our nation from threats, both foreign and domestic. They'll also be someone who understands the importance of upholding the highest standards of ethics and professionalism within the agency. 

Now, I'd like to emphasize that the ongoing controversies will not deter me from finding the right person for the job. We will conduct a thorough and exhaustive search to find the best candidate, and we will not be rushed by speculation or outside pressure.

I think there's a lot of misinformation in that question. First of all, I think the Secretary-General spoke for himself, and I think it's very important for us to speak for ourselves. The United States, of course, supports the goal of a Palestinian state that is viable and peaceful. But we must also recognize the facts on the ground, and the fact is that Israel is a democratic country that is trying to defend its people.

Now, in terms of the situation on the ground, I think Secretary Powell and General Zinni are on their way to the region, and they will be working to try to calm the situation. We are working very closely with all parties to try to bring an end to the violence and to get talks started again. But I think we need to be clear that the terrorist activities of groups like Hamas and the Palestinian Islamic Jihad are activities that we cannot tolerate, and they must be dealt with.

As for the Israeli operation, I think it's very important for us to respect Israel's right to self-defense. We also think it's very important for Israel to be mindful of the potential consequences of its actions, and to work with us to try to bring about a peaceful resolution to this conflict.

In terms of General Zinni's mission, I'm confident that he will be able to work effectively with all parties to try to bring about a peaceful resolution. He's a man of great experience and great integrity, and I have every confidence in him.

But I think we need to be realistic about the challenges that we face. The situation on the ground is very difficult, and it's going to take a lot of work and a lot of effort to bring about a peaceful resolution. But we're committed to trying, and we're committed to working with all parties to try to bring about a better future for the people of the region.

I appreciate the question. Yes, I do believe that Prime Minister Sharon is committed to helping the Palestinians who are not involved in terrorism. I think that's an important distinction to make. There are many Palestinians who do want peace, who do want to live in a safe and secure and prosperous society, just like the Israelis do. And I think the Prime Minister is committed to helping those folks.

But at the same time, I also understand that the Prime Minister has a responsibility to protect his people, and I agree with him that Hamas is a terrorist organization that's responsible for the harm and the suffering of not only Israelis, but also Palestinians. And I think that's a problem that needs to be addressed in any peace negotiations.

Now, I'm optimistic that we can make progress on the peace process. I think we've made some progress since the meeting in Aqaba. I think the roadmap is a good starting point, and I'm hopeful that the next few months will show some – will show some significant movement towards peace. But it's going to require the leadership of both the Palestinians and the Israelis to be willing to take risks for peace, and to make sure that we have a partner in peace that's committed to the same principles that we are: democracy, freedom, tolerance, and security.

That's a great question. I want to make one thing very clear: I've got great confidence in both Don Rumsfeld and John Negroponte. They're two excellent public servants who share my commitment to protecting the American people and projecting American power.

Now, as for the specific matter you just mentioned, I'll tell you this: the President determines the budget, and we work very closely with our Cabinet members to make sure that we're allocating resources in a way that aligns with our priorities.

If there's a disagreement between Don and John, I expect them to work it out, to come to the table and find a solution that works for everyone. And if they can't come to an agreement, then of course, as the Commander-in-Chief, I'll make the decision.

But I want to emphasize that we're all working towards the same goal: to keep America safe and to project American values around the world. We're a team, and we'll work through these issues together.

So, I'll make the decisions that need to be made, but I've got great confidence in both Don and John, and I know they'll work together to find a solution that serves the American people. Thank you.

That's a great question. I believe the contributions, regardless of their size, are a significant step in the right direction. It's not just about the amount of money or the number of troops; it's about the coalition that's building. We're seeing international support for our efforts in Iraq, and that's sending a strong message to the Iraqi people that they're not alone in their struggle.

The financial and military commitments from countries like Italy, Australia, and others demonstrate that the international community is committed to helping the Iraqis build a free and stable society. Every contribution, no matter how small, counts and is a testament to the international will to stand against tyranny and support democracy.

Make no mistake, this is a multinational effort, and we will continue to work with our coalition partners to ensure that Iraq has the support it needs to transition to a stable democracy. The road ahead won't be easy, but I'm confident that together, we'll get the job done.

Thank you for the question. As you know, we're in the process of searching for a new Supreme Court Justice to fill the vacancy left by Justice Sandra Day O'Connor. We've been working diligently to identify the most qualified candidates, and I'm pleased to say that we've made significant progress.

While I'm not at liberty to disclose the exact list of finalists just yet, I can tell you that we've had some very impressive candidates come forward. We've had a thorough and deliberate process, and I'm confident that we'll select a highly qualified and capable individual to serve on the Court.

As for sharing the list with Senate leaders, I appreciate the Democrats' willingness to work together to find common ground. However, I must emphasize that the responsibility for selecting a Supreme Court Justice rests with the Executive Branch, and we'll make our nomination when we're ready.

That being said, I'm committed to consulting with leaders from both parties in the Senate, as is customary, to ensure a smooth confirmation process. We'll work closely with them to address any concerns they may have and to ensure that the nominee is given fair consideration.

But let me be clear: the decision on who to nominate will ultimately be mine, and I'll choose the candidate who I believe is best suited to serve on the Court and uphold the Constitution.

Good morning. Well, I... (pausing for a moment) ...still believe that our military needs to be agile and capable of responding to threats quickly. However, I have come to realize that we must also ensure we have the necessary resources on the ground to succeed in our missions.

In Iraq, we're facing an enemy that is using unconventional tactics, and we need to adapt our strategy to meet that challenge. We're shifting our focus towards building a more robust counterinsurgency effort, one that involves not just our military, but also our diplomats and other agencies.

Now, I still believe that Secretary Rumsfeld was right to emphasize the importance of technological advancements and agility in our military. But, as the situation in Iraq evolved, it's become clear that we need to balance that agility with the reality on the ground.

We need to have the necessary troops and equipment to secure the population and support our allies, and we're working to adjust our approach accordingly. It's a complex situation, and we're continually evaluating and refining our strategy to ensure we're doing everything we can to succeed in Iraq.

As the President of the United States, I've been a strong supporter of Israel, but I also believe that the Israeli-Palestinian conflict requires a comprehensive solution that's fair to both parties.

By urging Israel to accept the relevant UN resolutions, I'm trying to encourage a peaceful resolution to this decades-long conflict. The UN resolutions provide a framework for a negotiated settlement, and it's in the interest of both Israelis and Palestinians to work together towards a two-state solution.

Now, I know that the road ahead won't be easy. There are many challenges to overcome, and both sides have legitimate concerns. But I firmly believe that by working together, we can create a future where Israelis and Palestinians can live side by side in peace and security.

It's not about dictating a solution, it's about facilitating a dialogue that leads to a mutually acceptable outcome. And I'm willing to work with both parties to make that happen. The status quo is not acceptable, and it's time for bold action to achieve a lasting peace.

And let me be clear: the United States will continue to stand by our ally Israel, but we also recognize the legitimate aspirations of the Palestinian people. It's a delicate balance, but one that I'm committed to pursuing.

That's a fair question. Let me tell you, as the President of the United States, I believe in a strong executive. I think it's essential for the President to have the authority to act quickly and decisively on behalf of the American people.

Now, I'm not suggesting that we're trying to consolidate power in the executive branch at the expense of Congress. That's not our intention. We believe in a balance of power among the branches of government.

However, in a post-9/11 world, we face unprecedented threats and challenges. As Commander-in-Chief, I have a responsibility to protect the American people, and I believe that requires a certain level of executive authority.

Now, I'm willing to work with Congress to find common ground and to ensure that we're not overstepping our bounds. But I also believe that the Constitution gives the President certain inherent powers, particularly when it comes to national security.

So, to answer your question, we're not trying to "recalibrate" the balance of power, per se. We're simply trying to exercise the authority that we believe is necessary to keep this country safe and to respond to the challenges of the 21st century.

I'm happy to work with Congress, and we've had many successes in the past, from passing the USA PATRIOT Act to the creation of the Department of Homeland Security. But I also think it's essential that the executive branch has the flexibility to respond quickly and effectively to the challenges that we face.

And let me just add, I think it's worth noting that some of the criticism we've received on this issue has been, quite frankly, a bit excessive. I mean, we're not trying to create an "imperial presidency" or anything of that sort. We're just trying to do our job, which is to protect the American people and to keep this country safe.

Thank you, I appreciate the question. First, on the nominations of Priscilla Owen and Charles Pickering, I will tell you that these are two highly qualified individuals who were nominated for the federal bench and deserve a fair up-or-down vote in the United States Senate.

As you know, their nominations have been held up, and I am disappointed in that. I believe strongly that both Priscilla Owen and Charles Pickering would be outstanding judges, and I will continue to work with the Senate to see that they get the fair consideration they deserve.

And I might add that we need to take steps to prevent gridlock in the Senate. It's the responsibility of the Senate to give an up-or-down vote on judicial nominees who have been nominated by the President. And I believe we need to take steps to ensure that takes place.

Now, on the question of a Supreme Court nomination, I'll just say that anytime there is a vacancy, you can bet it's going to be a contentious process. The Supreme Court, of course, is a very high-profile institution, and people have strong feelings on both sides of the aisle about who should sit on the Court.

I won't speculate on any particular nomination, but I will tell you that I have a commitment to nominate highly qualified judges who will interpret the law, not make law. I believe that's a fundamental difference between some of my, shall we say, critics and me.

But I'm confident that we'll be able to find a highly qualified nominee, and yes, it's likely to be a contentious process, but I'm ready to take on that challenge, because I believe we can find highly qualified people who can serve with distinction on the Supreme Court.

Thank you for that question.

Thank you for the question. I want to start by saying that the bombings that occurred are a reminder of the challenges we face in the Middle East, and a stark reminder that there's still a lot of work to be done to bring peace and stability to that region.

Now, regarding the roadmap, I can tell you that we're not going to let the terrorists win by derailing the peace process. The roadmap remains a vital part of our efforts to bring about a two-state solution, and we're going to keep moving forward with it. We're going to continue to work with Prime Minister Abbas, as well as Prime Minister Sharon, to make sure that we're making progress on this front.

Now, I do have confidence in Prime Minister Abbas. He's a good man, and he's committed to peace. And I believe he's got the best interests of the Palestinian people at heart. But, we need to continue to work together to make sure that we're making progress on the security front, and that we're addressing the concerns of the Israeli people.

This is a difficult situation, and it's not going to get resolved overnight. But, I'm committed to seeing this through, and I believe that by working together, we can make real progress towards a more peaceful and stable Middle East. Thank you.

(pausing, looking serious) Well, I want to start by saying that those images are abhorrent, they're unacceptable. I'm not only disappointed, I'm outraged. The actions of those soldiers are not representative of the values of the United States military, and they're not representative of the values of the American people.

We're investigating these incidents thoroughly, and those responsible will be held accountable. I've spoken to Secretary Rumsfeld, and he's assuring me that we're taking this very seriously.

As for winning the hearts and minds of the Iraqi people, this is a setback, no question. But I still believe that our mission is just, and I believe that the vast majority of our troops are conducting themselves with honor and dignity. We're not just liberators, we're also rebuilding this country, providing humanitarian aid, and helping the Iraqi people to build a better future for themselves.

(pausing, looking directly at the reporter)

We will not be defined by the actions of a few bad apples. We will be defined by the character of our country, and the generosity and compassion of the American people. We will not let these incidents derail our mission or undermine our commitment to helping the Iraqi people.

That's a fair question. I do want to say that the relationship between the United States and Great Britain is a unique and special one. The support that Prime Minister Blair and the British people have given us in our efforts in Iraq is greatly appreciated. And I believe that this alliance is built on mutual interests, shared values, and a deep trust between our two countries.

Now, I don't think of it as a debt that needs to be repaid, per se. But I do think that when we work together, we become stronger, and our friendship and cooperation are beneficial to both our nations. Whether it's on issues like trade, or counter-terrorism, or global security, we're better off when we're working together.

So, I think it's more of a partnership, a partnership of two like-minded nations that are working towards the same goals and same values. And I'm grateful for the strong support that we've received from Tony Blair and the British people.

(pauses, collecting thoughts) Well, I appreciate the question. As I've said before, we are constantly reviewing and refining our strategy in Iraq to better achieve our goals of a stable and democratic government. 

While I understand the sentiment behind the suggestion, I must emphasize that our policy towards Iran and Syria is based on certain conditions and principles. We have serious concerns about Iran's nuclear ambitions, its support for terrorism, and its destructive behavior in the region. As for Syria, we're concerned about its meddling in Lebanon and its support for terrorist groups.

Now, with regards to talks, I've always said that we'll talk to our enemies, but it's got to be in the context of them behaving in a way that's constructive and not destructive. We've made it clear that if Iran wants to have direct talks with the United States, it's going to have to suspend its uranium enrichment activities. And if Syria wants to talk, they're going to have to stop supporting terrorist groups.

(leaning forward) I want to emphasize that the United States is willing to engage in diplomacy, but not at the expense of our principles or the safety of our citizens and allies. We're open to creative ideas, but any talks must be in the framework of our clear values and interests.

(firmly) So, to answer your question, I'm open to exploring new options, but it's got to be in the context of a shared commitment to constructive behavior. And let me emphasize, we'll do what it takes to protect our interests and the interests of our allies in the region.

Well, thank you for your question. As I prepare to leave office, I've got a lot of respect for the office of the presidency and for the man who's about to take over, President-elect Obama. Now, I've got some differences in philosophy, no question about it. But I'm a supporter of the institutions of government, and I'm confident that our system of government is strong enough to handle transitions from one party to another.

That being said, I've always been concerned about the importance of keeping our economy strong, and I've been a strong advocate for tax cuts and for cutting regulatory burdens on small businesses and entrepreneurs. Now, I think that's crucial for job creation and economic growth. And I hope that President-elect Obama will continue those policies, because I think they're proven.

I'm also concerned about national security – making sure that our country's secure, that our troops are successful in operations abroad, and that we stay on the offense against al-Qaeda. And I think we've made some progress in that regard, and I hope that President-elect Obama will build on those gains.

Now, I know we've got some philosophical differences – for example, on issues like tax policy, healthcare, and environmental policy. But I'm a believer that debate and discussion is healthy for our democracy, and I'm confident that our system will work as it should.

Well, I appreciate the question. I did campaign on a promise to re-evaluate our troop deployment in the Balkans, and I still believe that we need to be mindful of our military's priorities and the burdens that we place on our troops and their families.

However, I've also learned a great deal more about the complexities of the situation on the ground in the Balkans. The situation in Kosovo and Bosnia is fragile, and our NATO allies are counting on us to maintain a stable presence in the region.

While I still believe that we need to work towards reducing our troop numbers over time, I've come to realize that this is a process that's going to take some time, and it's not something that we can do precipitously or without careful consideration of the consequences.

So, I wouldn't say that it's politically impossible to reduce our troop presence in the Balkans, but I do think that we need to approach this issue with caution and with a careful eye towards the potential consequences of our actions. We'll continue to work with our NATO allies and with the leaders in the region to find a way to reduce our troops while still maintaining stability and security in the Balkans.

Thank you for that question. We're having some very productive conversations with our friends and allies, particularly the Russians, on the ABM Treaty. I believe that it's a treaty that's, in many ways, out of date, but we're attempting to find a way forward that will allow us to protect America, protect our troops, and our friends and allies from the threat of ballistic missile attack.

I'm not convinced that we'll have to withdraw from the treaty, but I am convinced that we need to make some changes to it. We're discussing this with the Russians, and we have some proposals on the table that we think will help address their concerns about the relationship between the ABM Treaty and our efforts to develop a missile defense system.

We're making progress, but it's a tough issue. This is a matter of national security, and I'm not going to make any decisions that compromise our ability to protect America. But I am optimistic that we can find a way forward that meets the needs of both the United States and Russia.

I think we can have a bipartisan dialogue on this issue. When it comes to Social Security reform, I'm open to different ideas and willing to consider various proposals. Now, on the issue of an income test for slowing the growth of benefits, I'm not opposed to it in principle. But any changes to Social Security should be done in a way that's fair and doesn't disrupt the program.

I think we need to have a honest conversation about the future of Social Security and what we need to do to make sure it's solvent for future generations. Now, I'm open to the income test as a potential solution, but it's got to be part of a broader plan that addresses the long-term sustainability of Social Security.

What we need is a bipartisan approach that puts the American people's interests first. If an income test is something that can help us achieve that goal, then it's worth considering. But we've got to be careful not to hurt those who are vulnerable and who are depending on Social Security as a vital part of their retirement security.

So, I'm open to the idea, but we've got to have a thoughtful and bipartisan dialogue about how to proceed. We owe it to the American people to get this right.

Our relationship with Estonia is a vital one, and I'm proud to say that Estonia is a valued ally and a key partner in our efforts to promote security and stability in the region.

As for the ranking, I'd say that our relationship with Estonia is a top-tier relationship. We consider Estonia to be one of our closest friends in the Baltic region, and we've worked closely together on a range of issues, from counter-terrorism to non-proliferation to promoting economic development.

In terms of our overall foreign policy priorities, I'd say that our relationship with Estonia is definitely in the top 20, and probably in the top 15. We're deeply committed to our relationship with Estonia, and we're going to continue to prioritize our cooperation and our engagement with the Estonian government.

Now, I know that some folks might say, "Estonia? Isn't that a small country?" And yes, it is. But let me tell you, Estonia has a big impact. They're a leader in the region, and they're a critical partner for us on a range of issues. And I believe that our relationship with Estonia is only going to grow stronger in the future.

So, to answer your question, I'd say that our relationship with Estonia is a high priority for us, and we're going to continue to work closely with our Estonian partners to promote our shared interests and values.

Well, thank you for that question. I want to assure the American people that we've learned a great deal from the response to Hurricane Katrina, and we're workin' hard to make sure that we're prepared for any situation that may arise.

First, let me say that Katrina was a catastrophic event, unlike any other in our nation's history. The storm's destruction was widespread, and the levee breaches were a shock to all of us. But in the aftermath, we've taken significant steps to improve our preparedness and response capabilities.

We've invested heavily in improving our emergency management systems, including the creation of the Post-Katrina Emergency Management Reform Act. This legislation has helped us to strengthen our ability to respond to disasters, and to provide better support to affected communities.

We've also taken steps to improve our critical infrastructure, including the repair and reinforcement of levees along the Gulf Coast. And we've worked closely with state and local officials to ensure that they have the resources they need to prepare for and respond to disasters.

Regarding the terrorist threat, let me be clear: we're deeply concerned about the threat posed by al-Qaeda and other terrorist organizations. We're workin' hard to stay one step ahead of these groups, and to disrupt their plans.

We've made significant progress in disrupting al-Qaeda's leadership and operational capabilities, but we know that this threat is constantly evolving. That's why we remain vigilant, and we're takin' steps to enhance our counter-terrorism capabilities, including the creation of the National Counterterrorism Center.

So, to answer your question, I want to assure the American people that we're workin' hard to prepare for any eventuality, whether it's a natural disaster or a terrorist attack. We're committed to doin' everything in our power to protect our citizens and our nation.

Well, I think it's too early to declare Mideast peacemaking dead. There's still hope for a two-state solution. But I do believe that the recent election results in Palestine demand a careful and thoughtful response from the international community.

As for dealing with the Palestinians, I've made it very clear that we cannot deal with a party that advocates the destruction of Israel and holds terrorist views. Hamas must take concrete steps toward peace: disarm, reject terror, and respect Israel's right to exist. If Hamas is unwilling to meet these basic conditions, it's hard to see how a political dialogue can be productive.

We'll continue to work closely with our international partners to find a peaceful solution to this conflict. We'll also ensure that US foreign assistance to the Palestinian people is channeled through mechanisms that do not benefit Hamas or any other organization that advocates terrorism.

Now, I want to emphasize that we'll continue to seek a negotiated settlement to the Israeli-Palestinian conflict. But it's the Palestinian leadership's responsibility to demonstrate its commitment to a peaceful resolution of this conflict.
