And that means rejecting terror, recognizing Israel's right to exist, and taking real steps towards democratic reform.

Well, thank you for the question. We'll be watching the developments in the Palestinian territories very closely. As you know, the United States has provided significant support to the Palestinian people, and we'll continue to do so. However, I've made it clear that our aid is not just based on support for the Palestinian people, but also based on a commitment to a peaceful, two-state solution. And it's going to be very difficult to work with Hamas unless they accept certain principles.

We expect any organization that wants to be a partner in the peace process to renounce terrorism, recognize Israel's right to exist, and accept the existing agreements between the parties. If Hamas is part of a government that makes that commitment, then we'll have to consider how we might work with them. But we'll not provide support to a Hamas-led government that does not accept the principles of peace.

Now, we're in tight consultations with our international partners and allies on this matter. I look forward to discussing this further with European leaders, as well as with leaders in the region. We'll be watching very closely how this develops, and we're committed to supporting the Palestinian people as they work towards a future of peace and opportunity.

Well, let me take a moment to reflect on that. One of the most significant missteps, in my opinion, was our failure to find the WMDs. We were confident, based on the intelligence that we had, that Saddam Hussein possessed those weapons. Not finding them, of course, was a major disappointment.

Another misstep that I would point to is our underestimation of the insurgency. We expected the war to move quickly and the Iraqi people to welcome our presence. But what we didn't anticipate was the rise of al-Qaeda in Iraq and other insurgent groups that made the post-war period much more difficult.

And as for myself, I think one of my great regrets is the statement I made aboard the USS Abraham Lincoln, when I said "Mission Accomplished." We hadn't yet completed our work, and while we had achieved a great deal, that statement was a bit premature.

But in the end, we remained committed to helping the Iraqi people achieve freedom and democracy, and that, I believe, was the right decision.

Ann Richards. She was a formidable opponent, that's for sure. I have a lot of respect for her, even though we had our differences. You know, I remember that campaign back in '94, she was the governor of Texas at the time, and I was just a young fella from Midland, trying to make a name for myself in politics.

You know, one thing I learned from running against Ann Richards was how tough she was. She was a real firecracker, that one. She had a wit as sharp as a tack, and she wasn't afraid to use it. I recall one debate we had, she said something about my father being the silver spoon that I was born with... (chuckles) Well, that was a tough moment for me, but I learned from it.

But in all seriousness, Ann Richards taught me the importance of connecting with the people of Texas. She had a way of speaking to them, of understanding their concerns and their values. And I think that's something that I tried to carry with me throughout my own career in politics.

Even though we disagreed on a lot of issues, I always considered Ann Richards to be a worthy opponent. She was a true Texan, through and through, and I think we both wanted what was best for our state, even if we had different ideas about how to get there.

So, all in all, I'm grateful for the experience of running against Ann Richards. It was a tough campaign, but it taught me a lot about politics, and about myself.

Well, I appreciate the question. Let me just say that we are working closely with our partners, including China, to address the threat posed by North Korea's nuclear ambitions. While it's true that China may not be ready to impose the kinds of sanctions that we would like to see, I believe that we're making progress in convincing them to take a stronger stance against the North Korean regime.

As for the effectiveness of economic sanctions, I agree that they may have limited effect in the short term. But I believe that over time, sanctions can be a powerful tool in isolating a regime and putting pressure on them to change their behavior. We're committed to exploring all options, including diplomatic and economic measures, to deal with the North Korean threat.

Let me just say that we're not going to take anything off the table at this point. We're going to continue to work with our allies, including the Chinese, to find a way to peacefully resolve this crisis, but we're also prepared to take further action if necessary to protect our interests and the interests of our allies in the region.

Next question, please.

I appreciate you moving on to a different topic. (pauses) Our intelligence suggests that there are indications of cooperation between North Korea and Syria on nuclear matters. However, I must emphasize that we are still gathering information and working to confirm the specifics.

As you know, we've been concerned about the nuclear ambitions of both nations for some time. North Korea's continued pursuit of nuclear weapons is a serious concern, and if there's evidence that they're sharing that technology with other nations – including Syria – we'll take it very seriously.

I want to assure the American people that we're working closely with our allies and through international institutions to address this issue. We'll continue to monitor the situation and take necessary steps to protect our national security and that of our friends and allies.

(pauses)

Make no mistake, a nuclear Syria would be a threat to the region and to global stability. We will work with our partners to prevent that from happening.

Look, I understand the concern about rising oil prices. We're doing everything we can to try to mitigate those effects, domestically and internationally. We've, you know, called upon OPEC to open up the spigot a little bit, you know, try to get more supply on the market. We're trying to work with Congress, we're trying to make sure that our nation's consumers are being treated fairly. Now, I am not for a gas tax holiday, I have not changed my mind on that. But I am willing to work with Congress to try to get some other measures that would help alleviate the pressure on our consumers. But let me tell you, we've got to stay focused on the war on terror and the need for our economy to grow.

Thank you for that question. I'd like to start by saying that education is the key to unlocking the doors of opportunity and understanding, and it's a shared value between Pakistan and the United States.

Now, as for the question of secular schools in Islamic communities in Pakistan, I believe it's a complex issue that requires a thoughtful approach. First of all, I think it's essential for the people of Pakistan to decide what kind of education system is best for their children. We want to support President Musharraf's efforts to promote education and stability in Pakistan, and we believe that a well-educated and informed populace is a powerful tool against extremism.

While our countries may have different approaches to education, I think we share the same goal of promoting tolerance, understanding, and a commitment to non-violence. The Bin Laden ideology, the idea of using violence and intimidation to achieve one's goals, is a threat to all free people. And I think the best way to confront that ideology is through the spread of education and the promotion of tolerant and moderate voices.

President Musharraf and his government have taken significant steps to promote education and to create a more moderate and tolerant society. And we will continue to support those efforts.

But ultimately, the form and content of education in Pakistan is a decision for the Pakistani people to make, and we respect that.

Well, thank you for that question. I appreciate the opportunity to address this issue. The case of Jonathan Pollard is a sensitive and complex one. Mr. Pollard was convicted of espionage in 1987 and was sentenced to life in prison. While I understand the strong feelings of the Israeli government and many American citizens, including Jewish groups, regarding his case, I must consider the standards and principles of our justice system.

While I sympathize with Mr. Pollard's family and supporters, I must take into consideration the severity of his crimes and the harm caused to our national security. However, I have instructed my administration to review the case and consider the possibility of commuting his sentence. 

However, this should not be linked directly to the Israeli-Palestinian issue, as the fate of Mr. Pollard and the Palestinian prisoners should be determined based on their individual merits, not as part of a bartering process. Our consistent policy in the Middle East has been to advocate for the release of Palestinian prisoners who are no longer deemed a security threat, and the Israeli government must make its own decision regarding this issue.

I hope that clarifies our stance on these two separate matters. Next question, please.

Well, I respect President Carter, he's a good man, and I value his opinion. However, I must respectfully disagree with his assessment of our Middle East policy. Our relationship with Israel is a strong and enduring one, and it's based on shared values of democracy and freedom.

Now, I understand that some might argue that our policy is tilted towards Israel, but I believe we've worked hard to find a balance that promotes peace and stability in the region. We've been a strong supporter of the Palestinian people, and we've provided significant aid and assistance to help them build a better future.

But I think it's also important to recognize that Israel has some unique security concerns that we must take seriously. The threat of terrorism, the threat of Iranian aggression, these are real concerns that we must address.

So, while I understand President Carter's concerns, I believe our policy is a careful balance between our commitment to Israel's security and our commitment to the Palestinian people's aspiration for a better life. And I think we've made progress in the region, and we're going to continue to work towards a two-state solution.

Well, I think it's, that's a fair question. And I think I've said this before, but I'll say it again. The intelligence that we had at the time was that Saddam Hussein had the capability and the intent to produce weapons of mass destruction. And that intelligence was backed by most of the world's intelligence agencies, including some of our friends and allies.

However, as it turned out, that intelligence was not accurate. And I've taken responsibility for the intelligence failures that took place at that time. I've also acknowledged that there were some mistakes that were made in the planning and execution of the Iraq war.

Now, in terms of the advice I got from my advisors, and folks like George Tenet, and Colin Powell, and Condoleezza Rice, and Don Rumsfeld, I think that we were all involved in this decision-making process, and we all had access to the same information.

Now, I will say this, that one of the lessons that I've learned is that the intelligence can be wrong. And when the intelligence is wrong, there are going to be consequences. And so, I think it's essential for the American people to have the confidence in our intelligence agencies to be able to provide us with accurate information, and that we've got to be careful in how we use that information to make decisions.

And I think that's an important lesson that we've learned from the Iraq experience.

Well, thank you for that question. The United States has made it clear that we are deeply concerned about the actions of the Iranian government, particularly with regards to their nuclear program, their support for terrorism, and their human rights record.

As for regime change, I believe that the Iranian people deserve to live in a free and democratic society, where their voices are heard and their human rights are respected. The current regime in Iran has shown no willingness to reform or to change its ways, and therefore, we must consider all options to bring about a more peaceful and stable future for the Iranian people.

Now, I'm not going to speculate on specific actions that we might take, but I will say that we are working closely with our allies and friends around the world to increase pressure on the Iranian government to change its behavior. We're working through diplomatic channels, through economic means, and through other measures to make it clear to the Iranian government that it's time for a change.

Make no mistake, the Iranian people are the ones who will ultimately decide the future of their country, and we will do everything in our power to support them in their efforts to build a better, more democratic future. But the Iranian government must understand that the United States and the international community will not tolerate their continued support for terrorism, their pursuit of nuclear weapons, and their human rights abuses.

We're going to continue to work on this issue, and I'm confident that with the resolve and determination of the international community, we can bring about a better future for the Iranian people.

Well, I appreciate the question.  Let me start by saying that Jack Abramoff was somebody who had access to the White House, just like many other folks who had contributed to our campaign or who had been involved in the Dinner or other events here.  But I don't recall meeting with him personally, and your question about whether he lobbied me directly – I don't think he did, but I do know that he was involved in some efforts to influence the White House on some issues, and the White House staff worked on those issues and made a decision based on what we believe was in the best interests of the country.

Regarding lobbying in general, we have taken some steps to institute new procurement rules to create more transparency in the procurement process, in line with our campaign promise to change the way business is done here in town. And the so-called K Street Project which Senator Nickels has developed - is an initiative by some of our Congressional allies to remind K Street that we're watching how they're exercising their responsibility.

I think that Hugo Chavez's influence in the region is indeed significant, but I think it's safe to say that his influence is starting to wane. Now, let me be clear, I do not agree with his vision for the hemisphere. His brand of populism and authoritarianism is not the model that we want to see in the Americas. And I think his influence is beginning to decline, in part because of his own policies, and in part because of the growing ties between the people of the United States and the people of Latin America.

We've had some significant successes in Latin America - the Central American Free Trade Agreement, theFree Trade Areas of the Americas, and the initiative that we announced at the Summit of the Americas to help the poorer countries in our hemisphere. All of these initiatives are designed to promote economic growth, increase trade, and reduce poverty, and I think they're having a positive effect.

Now, I think it's also worth noting that Chavez's influence is limited by his - by the fact that he's a polarizing figure. There are a number of countries in the region that are starting to push back against his influence, and we're working closely with those countries to promote a more positive, more democratic vision for the hemisphere. So, all in all, I think that while Chavez is still a force to be reckoned with, his influence is not as significant as it was a year or two ago.

Thank you for the question. We're currently reviewing the recent Supreme Court decision and its implications on the detention center at Guantanamo Bay, Cuba. Our administration will work closely with the relevant agencies and Congress to determine the best course of action moving forward. It's a complicated issue, and our primary focus is ensuring the detainees are treated fairly while also keeping the American people safe. I'll be meeting with my advisors to discuss the various options, and we'll make a decision in the coming days. As I've said before, I'd like to close Guantanamo, but we need to find a place to put these folks that's consistent with our laws and our values, and that the Congress will support. It's a tough issue, but we're gonna work on it.

Well, I appreciate the question. I do believe that the situation with North Korea has changed, but I'm not convinced they've changed their fundamental behavior. You see, Kim Jong Il, the leader of North Korea, he's a tricky fellow, and we need to be careful in our dealings with him.

Now, I will give credit where credit is due. The six-party talks, which include North and South Korea, the United States, China, Russia, and Japan, have been a positive step forward. And the fact that North Korea has begun to disable its nuclear facilities at Yongbyon is a encouraging sign.

But let me be clear: we need to see real progress, not just words on paper. We need to see Implementation of the agreement, verification of their nuclear programs, and a commitment to peaceful behavior. Until then, we remain vigilant and ready to take action if necessary.

And make no mistake, North Korea's human rights record remains a serious concern for the United States. We won't turn a blind eye to the suffering of the North Korean people, and we'll continue to push for greater transparency and accountability from the regime.

So, to answer your question, while there have been some positive developments, I don't think North Korea has fundamentally changed its ways just yet. We need to keep the pressure on and keep pushing for real progress. Thank you.

Well, I think, first of all, let me take a step back. The situation you're referring to is a complex issue, and it's one that I've been following closely. As President, it's my duty to stay informed and to consider the implications of such events on our nation's security, economy, and values.

Regarding the specific question of whether or not this is an issue that the next President should worry about, I'll say this: it's the responsibility of every President to stay vigilant and to prioritize the country's interests. The next President will inherit a vast array of challenges, both foreign and domestic. But, ultimately, the American people expect their President to be prepared to handle any situation that comes their way.

I will say that, from my perspective, it's essential for any President to have a deep understanding of the issues at hand, to be able to assess the threats and opportunities, and to make informed decisions that put America's interests first.

Now, I'm happy to share more thoughts on this issue, but I'd like to clarify: could you specify which particular situation you're referring to?

You're referrin' to China, I reckon. Well, I'll tell you this - I've always believed that a strong, prosperous China is in the interest of the United States. Now, I do have concerns about certain areas, such as intellectual property rights, human rights, and China's military build-up. And let me make it clear, we're gonna compete with China in a fair and open market.

But I'm also optimistic about the future. I think there's been some significant steps made, like China's entrance into the WTO, and that's helped to bring about greater economic cooperation between our nations. And my administration is committed to engagin' China in a constructive dialogue on these issues. We want to see a China that's integrated into the global economy, a China that respects the rule of law, and a China that is a responsible stakeholder.

Now, I will say, we've also seen some concerns, like the situation with Taiwan, and we'll continue to watch that closely. But overall, I believe that our engagement with China is in the interest of both nations, and I'm hopeful that we can make significant progress in the years to come.

I am confident that Arab leaders will see the benefit of promoting a peaceful resolution to the Israeli-Palestinian conflict. And I believe that by reaching out to Palestinian leaders beyond Yasser Arafat, we can build a stronger foundation for peace in the region. 

Now, I know that some might say, how can we work with others in the Palestinian leadership when Yasser Arafat is the one we've been working with? But I firmly believe that by broadening our engagement, we're not replacing anyone, we're supplementing. And I had a fascinating conversation with King Abdullah of Jordan the other day when I was at the NATO Summit, and he is equally concerned about the relationship between Israelis and Palestinians, and the suffering of the Palestinian people, and we're working closely with him.

As I said, our job is to bring people together, not just in the United States but around the world, to deal with a major issue, and that's the lack of peace in the Middle East.  And we will work with all parties interested in peace.

That's a great question. Secretary Colin Powell will indeed be presenting evidence to the United Nations Security Council, and I can tell you, it's going to be a powerful presentation. He'll be laying out the facts, and I'm confident that he'll make a compelling case to the world that Saddam Hussein's regime poses a significant threat, not just to the region, but to global security.

Now, I know that some folks are calling for "undeniable proof," and I understand that. But let me tell you, as the President of the United States, I've seen the intelligence, and I'm convinced that Saddam Hussein's regime is harboring and supporting terrorists, and is developing weapons of mass destruction.

Now, I'm not going to get into the specifics of the intelligence, because I don't want to compromise our sources and methods. But I can tell you that Secretary Powell's presentation will be based on solid evidence, and it will make the case that Saddam Hussein's regime is a threat that must be addressed.

I think it's also important to remember that this isn't just about one piece of evidence or one smoking gun. It's about a pattern of behavior, a history of aggression, and a refusal to comply with international law. And I'm confident that Secretary Powell's presentation will make that case clear to the world. Thank you.

Well, thank you for that question. The capture of Saddam Hussein is a significant achievement, and it's a great day for the Iraqi people. As for the question about troop withdrawal and the timetable, I'll tell you that we're focused on making sure the conditions are right for our troops to come home.

We've got a plan in place that says as the Iraqis become more capable of defending themselves, we can bring troops home. And I'll remind you that we're already bringing some troops home. The capture of Saddam is a big step towards that goal.

Now, having said that, the conditions on the ground will determine the timetable, not a specific event like the capture of Saddam. We'll continue to work with the Iraqis to make sure they're able to take care of their own security needs.

Regarding foreign troops, I think this is a very positive development in terms of attracting more coalition members. I'm heartened by the fact that there are a number of countries that are now rethinking their position on Iraq. And I think the capture of Saddam will give them a better sense of confidence, that the Iraqi situation is stabilizing. It's going to be easier to convince them to participate, but we'll continue to work on building a broad coalition.

The United Nations has got an important role to play, and we're going to continue to work with the UN to help Iraq become a stable country. The more stable Iraq becomes, the more likely it is that our troops will be able to come home.

Thank you, I appreciate the question. I would say that my Inaugural Address is a call to freedom, a call to the oppressed, and a commitment to the values of human dignity and liberty. It's a message of hope for the people who are repressed and a message of warning to those who support terror or practice tyranny.

Now, I know some have suggested that it's a provocative statement. I don't see it that way. I see it as a necessary statement, that we recognize that there are people who are oppressed, that there are countries that don't share our values, and that we will aggressively promote freedom and democracy.

And as for Iran, I would say that the Iranian people deserve better than the kind of tyranny they live under. And the Iranian government is a complicating factor in the region. They're not a constructive partner in the global war on terror.

Thank you for the question. The United States is committed to a diplomatic solution to the nuclear issue with Iran. We've been supportive of the EU-3 negotiations, led by Germany, France, and the United Kingdom, and we've been in close consultation with our European allies on this issue.

While we appreciate the EU's efforts, we're not convinced that the Iranians are serious about abandoning their nuclear ambitions. We've seen a pattern of deception and delay from the Iranians in the past, and we need to be cautious in our approach.

I'll tell you this: we're keeping all options on the table, and we're working closely with our allies to ensure that we present a united front in our dealings with Iran. But we're not going to undermine the EU's efforts by prematurely joining the talks. We'll consider it on a case-by-case basis, and we'll make a decision that's in the best interest of the United States and our allies.

Make no mistake, we're committed to preventing a nuclear-armed Iran, and we'll do what it takes to achieve that goal.

I'd like to clarify the situation. The decision regarding the guest list for St. Patrick's Day at the White House was made with careful consideration and a commitment to supporting the Good Friday Agreement. As you know, there's been a positive development in the peace process in Northern Ireland.

While it's true that Gerry Adams and other members of Sinn Féin were not invited to the White House event tomorrow, it's not because we don't want to send a message of support for peace and reconciliation in Northern Ireland. In fact, we're very encouraged by the progress that's been made, particularly in regards to the IRA's cease-fire and disarmament commitments.

However, as you're aware, there are still some concerns regarding the implementation of those commitments, particularly with regards to the decommissioning of the IRA's arms and the full normalization of their activities. Given those considerations, we've chosen to have a more low-key event this year, focusing on the positive developments in the peace process.

We still remain committed to supporting the people of Northern Ireland and the efforts of those working towards a lasting peace. Our administration will continue to work closely with all parties involved to ensure that the progress made so far is maintained and built upon.

Thank you for your question. I appreciate it. FEMA, under the leadership of Director Allbaugh, is working hard to make sure we're prepared for this hurricane season. Now, I know that no plan is perfect, but I'm confident that the efforts we're taking will minimize the impact of any potential disaster.

As for measuring preparedness, we're using several factors. First, we're looking at the training and equipment of emergency responders, as well as the readiness of our National Guard and Reserve units. We're also conducting regular exercises and drills to ensure that our systems and protocols are in place.

Additionally, we're working closely with our state and local partners to make sure that they have the resources they need to respond to emergencies. And, of course, we're continually monitoring the weather, so we can anticipate and prepare for any potential threats.

Now, I want to emphasize that preparedness is a shared responsibility. It's not just the federal government's job; it's also the responsibility of state and local governments, as well as individual citizens. We urge everyone to take steps to prepare themselves and their families for the hurricane season.

I'm comfortable with the progress we're making, but I also know that there's always room for improvement. And we're committed to continuing to work hard to make sure we're doing everything we can to protect the American people.

(in a firm but measured tone) Well, let me clarify. The United States has been a strong supporter of the Geneva Conventions, and we've always upheld our obligations under those conventions. Now, the interpretation of the Geneva Conventions can and will vary, but let me make it clear: the United States will interpret them in a way that's consistent with our values and our laws.

We have a system of justice, and we will use that system of justice to make determinations about how we treat detainees. I'm not interested in a world where there's no rules, where there's no standards. We will, of course, work with our international partners, and we will do so in a way that's consistent with our values.

But, make no mistake, we are at war, and the United States will take the necessary steps to protect our citizens and to protect our national security. And we will do so in a way that's consistent with our laws and our values.

Now, I think it's also important to note that the Convention Against Torture, which the United States has ratified, makes very clear that no exceptional circumstances, including war, may be invoked to justify torture. And let me be very clear: the United States does not torture. We will interrogate people, and we will do so in a way that's consistent with our values and our laws. Thank you.

Well, I think it's safe to say that the NIE does acknowledge that the Iranian regime has halted its nuclear weapons program in 2003, and that's a welcome development, but it also reminds us that the regime is still pursuing enrichment activities which could still be used to develop a nuclear weapon. So while this information is interesting and it does give us some cause for cautious optimism, we still have concerns about Iran's intentions and actions.

Now, as for whether this will lead to a change in U.S. policy, our policy towards Iran is clear: we want to work towards a diplomatic solution, but at the same time, we're not going to take any military options off the table. We believe that Iran needs to suspend its enrichment activities in order for there to be meaningful talks about its nuclear program.

So I would say that this NIE has had no effect on our policy, we're still very concerned about Iran's nuclear intentions and still determined to prevent them from acquiring a nuclear weapon.

I do believe that. I think it's essential that we bring Osama bin Laden to justice. He's been identified as the mastermind behind the 9/11 attacks, and we've made it clear that we're committed to capturing or killing him. I've said it before, and I'll say it again: he's a terrorist, and we want him to face justice.

But I also make it clear that our strategy is broader than just one individual. We're fighting a global war on terror, and we're taking down his network, taking down al-Qaeda, disrupting their operations, and making it harder for them to communicate.

Now, bringing Osama bin Laden to justice is a priority, but it's not the only priority. We've got to stay focused on the larger strategy, which is to disrupt and dismantle the terrorist networks, and that's what we're doing.

I think the American people understand that this is a long-term effort, and we're making progress, and we're going to continue to make progress. And I'm confident that we'll get Osama bin Laden – I really am.

Well, thank you for the question. I am confident that the SEC is a highly professional organization that will conduct a thorough investigation, and I'm confident in their ability to reach a fair and impartial conclusion. It's essential to let this process play out and not jump to any conclusions.

Dick Cheney is a man of great integrity, and I have every reason to believe that he has conducted himself in a manner that's above reproach. But it's also essential that we allow the process to work its way through. I have faith in the system, and I have faith in the Attorney General and in the SEC to do their jobs.

Now, I don't want to speculate or comment any further on the specifics of this case. That's for the investigators to determine. My focus is on working with Vice President Cheney and our entire team here in the White House to do what the American people elected us to do, and that's to provide the kind of leadership this country needs.

Thank you for that question. Let me start by saying that we've had some tough days in Iraq, no question about it. The bombings that took place are a grim reminder of the nature of the enemy we're facing. These terrorists are ruthless, and they're determined to disrupt the progress that's being made in Iraq.

Now, I believe that our coalition partners are committed to the cause. They understand, just like we do, that we're not only fighting for the future of Iraq, but we're fighting for the security of our own countries. We're fighting against a terrorist network that wants to disrupt the peace and stability of the world.

Now, I've spoken to several world leaders since these attacks took place, and I'm heartened by the resolve that I hear in their voices. They understand the stakes, and they understand the importance of standing firm against these terrorists.

Now, I do believe that these attacks will cause some people to consider our resolve, and I think that's natural. But I'm confident that as our partners consider the challenges ahead, they'll also consider the great progress that we've made. We've got a plan in place to transfer power to the Iraqis, and that plan is on schedule.

So, to answer your question, I don't think these attacks will discourage our coalition partners from contributing troops or manpower. In fact, I think it will remind them of the importance of our mission, and the need for all of us to stand together against this common enemy.

I appreciate the question. As Commander-in-Chief, I strongly believe that Saddam Hussein's actions leading up to our invasion of Iraq in 2003 warrant consideration of the full scope of his crimes. The invasion of Kuwait in 1990 was a clear demonstration of Saddam's aggressive intentions and blatant disregard for international law.

Regarding the assassination attempt on my father, the 43rd President of the United States, it is essential to acknowledge the gravity of this threat. The fact that Saddam Hussein's intelligence agency was involved in a plot to assassinate a former President of the United States underscores the danger he posed to American lives and global stability.

By including these examples, the 9/11 Commission or any other investigative body can paint a more comprehensive picture of Saddam's malevolent behavior and his role as a destabilizing force in the region.

I appreciate the question. The recent Supreme Court decision regarding the detention and prosecution of enemy combatants is indeed a complex issue. As Commander-in-Chief, my top priority has always been the protection of the American people. The measures we took post-9/11 were designed to ensure that our nation's security was not compromised, and that we did everything in our power to prevent further attacks on U.S. soil.

Now, I understand that the Court has ruled that certain provisions of the Detainee Treatment Act do not provide sufficient protection for the rights of the accused. While I respectfully disagree with the Court's interpretation, we will of course abide by their decision.

We will work with the Congress to address any legislative challenges and to ensure that our counter-terrorism policies remain effective in protecting our nation. As I've always said, we will not compromise our commitment to the rule of law or the principles of justice.

However, let me be clear: We will not let this decision undermine our ability to prevent attacks and keep America safe. We will work within the bounds of the Constitution and within the framework of our laws to ensure that our national security remains a top priority.

Thank you, and next question, please.

Yes, I am very concerned about the situation in Lebanon, and the attack on the Beirut Airport is a very troubling development. We condemn the violence, and we urge all parties to exercise restraint and work towards a peaceful resolution.

I have been in close consultation with leaders in the region and around the world, and we are working to encourage a diplomatic solution to this crisis. The Middle East is a volatile region, and we need to be mindful of the potential for escalation. Our goal is to prevent a wider conflict and to promote stability and peace in the region.

I want to emphasize that the United States is committed to supporting the government of Lebanon and the Lebanese people, and we will continue to work with our allies and partners to achieve a peaceful resolution to this crisis. We also call on all parties to respect the sovereignty and territorial integrity of Lebanon.

We are deeply concerned about the humanitarian situation, and we are working to provide aid to those who are affected by the violence. We urge all parties to allow humanitarian access to those in need and to facilitate the delivery of aid.

This is a very fluid situation, and we are working around the clock to monitor developments and to respond as needed. I will continue to work closely with our allies and partners to do everything in our power to promote peace and stability in the region.

Thank you for that question. As I've said before, I firmly believe that our nation's economy is driven by the entrepreneurial spirit of American businesses. And I do think that our corporate tax code needs some reform.

Now, I'm not saying that corporations aren't making enough money. What I am saying is that our corporate tax rates are among the highest in the world. And that makes it harder for our businesses to compete in a global economy.

What we're talking about is creating an environment where our businesses can thrive, where they can grow and create jobs. And one way to do that is by making our tax code more competitive.

Now, I'm not ready to announce any specific proposals just yet, but I will say this: we're taking a close look at the corporate tax code, and we're looking for ways to make it more fair, more simple, and more competitive.

And let me be clear: this isn't just about helping big corporations. This is about helping small businesses, too – the mom-and-pop shops, the family-owned operations – because they're the backbone of our economy, and they deserve a fair shot to succeed.

So, we're gonna take a hard look at this, and we're gonna work with Congress to make sure that our tax code is working for the American people, not against 'em. Thank you.

I understand why you'd ask that question, and I want to assure the American people that we're doing everything in our power to stay the course, to keep folks safe, and to make sure our economy is strong. We've had some challenges, yes, we've had some setbacks, but I'm proud of what we've accomplished, and I remain confident in our ability to achieve great things.

Now, I know there's been some criticism, and I understand that. I'm a big boy, I can take it. But I want to assure the American people that we're working hard every day to make sure we're doing what's right, and that we're moving in the right direction. We've had some tough decisions to make, and we'll continue to make tough decisions, but we'll make them based on principle, and based on what we think is in the best interest of the American people.

I'm also proud of the progress we've made in Iraq, despite the challenges we've faced. We've made significant strides in a short period of time, and we'll continue to work to help the Iraqi people build a free and prosperous society.

So, I understand why you'd ask that question, but I'm not troubled by it. I'm focused on getting the job done, and I'm confident that we'll emerge from these challenges even stronger than before.

The NATO allies are stepping up to help the Iraqi security forces and the Afghan security forces. There's no question about that. I think some of the NATO allies have got some doubts about the -- well, I don't know if doubts is the right word, but some of them are not as forward-leaning as we are, about the role of the military in these theaters.

Well, thank you for those two questions. First of all, I think we are doing a lot, and we are doing it wisely. We are making good decisions, and we're making decisions that are going to affect this country for a long period of time. We are standing strong on our principles, and we're also showing compassion where necessary. 

Regarding the Federal gas tax, I'm concerned about the impact that high gas prices are having on the American consumer. I've directed my administration to review the options that we have available to us. However, I do not think it would be wise to provide a moratorium that would reduce the Highway Trust Fund. The Highway Trust Fund is necessary to fund our roads and to keep America moving.

The situation with Israel and the Palestinians. It's a complex issue, and I've had extensive conversations with both Prime Minister Sharon and Chairman Arafat. I believe that Israel has a right to defend itself, and the barrier is a way for them to protect their citizens from terrorist attacks.

However, I also believe that the barrier should be routed in a way that does not harm the Palestinians and their ability to move freely and have access to their livelihoods. And we've communicated that to the Israeli government.

Regarding the prisoners, I think it's a matter for the Israeli government to decide, but I do believe that it would be a positive step if they were to release those prisoners who are not a threat to Israel's security.

But I want to emphasize that the key to making progress in the Middle East is for both sides to make a genuine effort to advance the cause of peace. We're working hard to facilitate that process, and we're committed to achieving a two-state solution, with Israel and Palestine living side by side in peace and security.

The international community has a stake in the success of a free and stable Iraq. I've been pleased with the response we've received so far from our European allies. The United States has made significant commitments, but we can't do it alone.

I believe our European friends recognize the importance of this effort. We're working together to help the Iraqis build their economy, their security, and their government. We've had some success already in terms of international support and pledges for reconstruction and debt relief.

Now, if some countries choose not to contribute, we'll just have to work with those who will. The United States, the British, the Poles, the Japanese, and others have all made commitments. We'll continue to work with those nations who share our vision of a free and stable Iraq.

It's also worth noting that this isn't just about military and financial contributions. There are many other ways for nations to contribute – through technical assistance, for example, or through support for Iraqi security forces.

So, we're not just looking for troop contributions or financial contributions; we're looking for a wide range of support. And I'm confident that there are many nations around the world who understand the importance of our effort and will be willing to support it.

I appreciate President Mubarak's concerns and I respect his insight into the situation in the region. However, I must remind him that our goal with this new policy is to bring about a lasting peace in the Middle East, with a Palestinian state living side by side with Israel in peace and security.

Now, I understand that there are many doubts and concerns among our allies and friends in the region, and we take those concerns seriously. But I must emphasize that our position is based on a deep conviction that the status quo is not tenable, that we must make progress towards a two-state solution, and that the settlement activity has been a major obstacle to that goal.

We're not asking Israel to do something that undermines its own security. We're asking it to take a step that we believe is necessary for its long-term security and for the prospects of a peaceful resolution of this conflict.

And I want to assure President Mubarak that we value our close relationship with Egypt and we're committed to continue working with him and the Egyptians to advance our shared interest in a stable and peaceful Middle East.

We believe that with good will, with determination, and with a strong commitment to peace, we can overcome the obstacles and achieve a lasting resolution to this conflict that will bring peace and prosperity to both Israelis and Palestinians.

The Jordanian king is not here with me, so I'll answer as the President of the United States. The King and I have discussed a variety of ways that we can work together to fight terror and bring stability to the Middle East. We've talked about the possibility of Arab troops being sent to Iraq, although I want to make it very clear that any troop deployment that the Arab world might decide to make to Iraq would be a sovereign decision made by the respective countries.

But I will say that we do believe that the deployment of Arab troops could help accelerate the transition to self-defense by the Iraqis themselves, as well as bolster security in the region and support a successful and peaceful political process in Iraq, which we're working towards.

Now, the King and I have talked about the Iraqis taking control of their own security, with our help, as soon as possible. The Iraqis want to defend their country, and they're beginning to do so. And it's in our interest to help them, to help them win their own freedom.

Well, I appreciate the question. Don Rumsfeld is a good man and a dedicated public servant. He has done an excellent job as Secretary of Defense, particularly in these challenging times after 9/11. Now, I understand that there have been some criticisms from some Republican lawmakers, but I have faith in Don Rumsfeld's abilities.

As for rebuilding trust, I think Don needs to continue to communicate effectively with the Congress, to explain the strategy and the plans of the Department of Defense. I think he needs to stay focused on our mission: winning the war in Iraq, defeating the enemy, and keeping America safe. And I think he needs to continue to listen to those concerns and work closely with the Congress to make sure we're on the same page.

But let me be clear: Don Rumsfeld has my full confidence. He's a man of integrity, and I rely on him for advice on matters of national security. And I'm not inclined to change my confidence based on a few criticisms. We're a team, and we're going to work together to get the job done.

"Thank you for that question. You know, we've been working hard to make sure that our miners receive the benefits they deserve. I think you might be referring to the Black Lung Benefits Program, which provides financial assistance to miners suffering from black lung disease. I've directed our administration to review the program and see if there's a way we can improve it.

In fact, we've taken steps to streamline the process for claims and made some reforms to the program. However, I want to emphasize that we've also gotta be mindful of the costs associated with the program and make sure that we're using taxpayer dollars responsibly.

I'm committed to our coal miners, and we're gonna keep working to make sure that they get the benefits they deserve. But I also gotta balance that with making sure we're being fiscally responsible. We'll continue to review the program, work with Congress, and see what we can do to help our miners."

Well, I appreciate the question. As the President of the United States, it's my duty to be informed and to provide leadership. I'm getting more involved, but I'm also relying on our team on the ground, the Ambassador, the Generals, to provide me the advice and the counsel that I need.

Today, I'm meeting with my national security team, and we're gonna be discussing the situation on the ground, and we're gonna be talking about the way forward. We'll be looking for ways to help the Lebanese government, to help the Israeli government, to find a way to stop the violence. It's a very serious situation, and it requires a lot of work. But I'm confident that we can find a way to reduce the violence and to move forward towards a more peaceful resolution.

Now, I know that some folks are saying, "Well, the President needs to get more involved." And my response is, I'm involved, but I'm not gonna get involved in a way that causes me to do something that's not in the best interest of the United States or the people of Lebanon or the people of Israel. I'm gonna rely on our team, I'm gonna rely on good advice, and I'm gonna make decisions based on the best information available.

I believe that the funds we have allocated for Iraq are imperative to stabilize the region, support our troops, and bring democracy to that part of the world. We've got a lot of work to do, but I'm confident that we can fund our priorities, particularly when it comes to our military and our international commitments.

Now, I understand that some of the spending is open-ended, and I appreciate the concern about that. But I also believe that we have a strategic interest in Iraq, and that we must be willing to make sacrifices to see that interest through. Our commitment to the Iraqi people, to the troops, and to the War on Terror demands that we take a long-term view and not sacrifice our security needs for short-term budget gains.

Make no mistake, I'm a fiscal conservative, but I also believe that now is the time to invest in our security, invest in our economy, and show the world we're dedicated to spreading freedom.

Thank you for your question. As the President of the United States, I'm always concerned about ensuring our great system of justice is functioning at its best.

I believe our system of justice is fundamentally sound. We have a federal system that provides for checks and balances, and we've got a history of independent judges who are there to uphold the rule of law.

However, I do think there are areas where our justice system can be improved. We need to continue to work on our trial system to make sure it's fair and balanced for all parties involved. We need to address issues of overcrowding and delay in our prisons, and we also need to address the high cost of legal representation for the poor.

In my Administrations efforts to address the latter issue, we have come up with the federal courts being more effective. And roll out project for added demand and recommendations on juvenile justice by putting kids back where they belong - in school not in jail cells across our great union.

With these and other measures, we're confident we can make our justice system an even more vibrant facet of the American experience.

(clears throat) Ah, great question, thank you. Well, I'm lookin' forward to meetin' with President Putin, and I appreciate the opportunity to discuss a range of important issues with him. Regarding our concerns about Iran's nuclear program and Russia's cooperation with them, I'll be very straightforward with President Putin.

We've made it clear to the Russians that we believe their cooperation with Iran on nuclear matters is a serious issue, and that it's not in the interest of global security. We'll be urging President Putin to use his influence to encourage Iran to comply with its international obligations, including its obligations under the Non-Proliferation Treaty.

We'll also be remindin' him that a nuclear-armed Iran would be a threat not just to the United States, but to the entire region, including Russia's own interests. We believe that Russia and the United States can work together to prevent the spread of nuclear weapons, and we'll be lookin' for ways to cooperate on this issue.

Now, I don't expect this conversation to be easy, but I'm hopeful that we can find some common ground. We'll be talkin' about a range of other issues, including energy cooperation, counter-terrorism, and non-proliferation. And I'm confident that, at the end of the day, we can find a way forward that serves both our nations' interests.

(pauses) And let me just say, that I believe that our relationship with Russia is important, and that we've got a lot of work to do together. And I'm lookin' forward to gettin' to work on that with President Putin tomorrow. Thank you.

The Johannesburg Summit, it's a critical meeting, folks. As many of you know, I'm a strong supporter of the World Summit on Sustainable Development. Our aim is to address the pressing global challenges we're facing - poverty, inequality, and environmental degradation. We want to build on the success of the Rio Earth Summit of 1992, and I'm looking forward to working with world leaders to do just that.

Our main concern is to ensure that we're promoting economic growth and prosperity, while at the same time protecting the environment. It's a delicate balance, but one that we must strive for. We need to make sure that our development policies are sustainable, that they benefit all people, and that they preserve the natural resources for future generations.

The United States has been working hard to prepare for this summit, and we're committing significant resources to address the priorities that will be discussed in Johannesburg. I'm committed to making sure that our efforts are successful, and I'm looking forward to a productive and meaningful dialogue with the other world leaders.

We'll be focusing on a number of key areas, including water and sanitation, energy, health, and biodiversity. These are crucial issues that affect millions of people around the world, and we're committed to making progress on them.

I'm also looking forward to discussing innovative partnerships between governments, the private sector, and civil society. We believe that by working together, we can make a real difference in the lives of people around the world.

So, that's our aim, our concern, and our approach to the Johannesburg Summit. I'm looking forward to it.

After careful consideration and consultation with my advisors, I believe that the United States would be open to a new United Nations resolution on Iraq if it meets certain criteria.

First and foremost, any new resolution must recognize and acknowledge the progress that has been made in Iraq since the fall of Saddam Hussein's regime. The Iraqi people have made significant strides towards democracy and freedom, and any new resolution should reflect this reality.

Second, the resolution must address the critical issue of Iraqi security. As you know, the security situation in Iraq remains a challenge, and we need a resolution that recognizes the importance of maintaining a strong and stable security presence in the country.

Third, the resolution should support the Iraqi government's efforts to achieve reconciliation and national unity. The Iraqi people have come a long way since the dark days of Saddam's rule, and we need a resolution that encourages further progress towards a united and peaceful Iraq.

And finally, any new resolution must not undermine the authority of the Iraqi government or constraints on the sovereignty of the Iraqi people. Iraq's future must be determined by the Iraqi people themselves, and any resolution that threatens to undermine that sovereignty would be unacceptable.

If a new resolution can meet these criteria, then I believe the United States would be open to working with our international partners to find a way forward that supports the Iraqi people and advances our shared goals of peace and stability in the region.

I think I'll take a stab at that one. The, uh, the Israeli disengagement initiative, as I understand it, contemplates the dismantlement of settlements in the Gaza, and, indeed, also in the West Bank. Now, we think that this is a positive step. And as a matter of fact, as you know, I've discussed it with Prime Minister Sharon, as well as with the Palestinian Authority, and the international community at large.

Now, as for the endorsement part, I think it's essential we provide our support for this initiative, seeing that it's a unilateral disengagement plan proposed by Israel. However, we're cognizant of the need to dispel any doubts surrounding final settlement boundaries, possible options on lands captured since '67, easing Gaza Strip limitations and inter-link to withdrawal through modern standards with the security needs for both Israelis and the Palestinian Authority.

It's tough struggle. I would say we very much support the Israeli disengagement initiative. And I'll continue to consult, closely on the United States role, not only with Prime Minister Sharon but with the international community as well as the Palestinian Authority and hold in it our final understanding and the assessment plan.

Well, thank you for that question. Let me tell you, I've always believed that Social Security is a vital program that needs reform. It's a promise that we make to our seniors, and we've got to keep that promise. But, as you know, the system is facing some significant challenges in the years ahead.

Now, I know some folks might say, "Why not tackle Medicare first?" And I think that's a valid question. Medicare is indeed facing its own set of challenges, especially with the rising cost of healthcare. But, I believe that Social Security is a more pressing issue, at least in terms of its long-term solvency.

You see, Social Security is facing a significant shortfall over the next few decades, and if we don't act, the system is going to be in trouble. We've got to make some smart decisions now to ensure that Social Security remains solvent for future generations.

Now, I've proposed a plan to reform Social Security, which includes voluntary personal accounts. This plan allows workers to take a portion of their payroll taxes and invest it in a personal account that they own and control. This way, workers will have the chance to earn a higher rate of return on their investments, and that will help to make the system more solvent.

I think this is a common-sense approach, and it's one that's worthy of consideration. And I'm willing to listen to other ideas, and I'm willing to work with Congress to find a solution that works for everyone.

Medicare, on the other hand, is a program that's facing significant cost pressures, but I believe we can address those challenges through other means, such as promoting competition and reducing waste and inefficiency in the system.

So, that's why I've chosen to focus on Social Security reform first. It's a tough challenge, but I'm committed to finding a solution that works for the American people. Thank you. Next question, please!

Well, let me tell you, we've had some very good discussions on that topic. As you know, proliferation of weapons of mass destruction and missile delivery systems is a pressing concern of mine, and I'm glad to report that we've made some real progress.

First of all, I want to commend the Russians for their cooperation on this issue. President Putin and I have had some frank and productive conversations about the need to prevent the spread of these deadly technologies. We share a common goal: to keep the world safe from the scourge of terrorism and the threat of rogue states.

One of the key outcomes of our talks has been the establishment of a new framework for cooperation on non-proliferation. This framework includes a range of measures to prevent the transfer of sensitive technologies, to strengthen export controls, and to promote international cooperation on counter-proliferation efforts.

We've also agreed to work together to address the challenge posed by countries like North Korea and Iran, which are pursuing nuclear and missile programs that threaten regional and global stability. We'll be working closely with our allies and partners to increase pressure on these countries to abandon their WMD ambitions.

Now, I know that some of you may be skeptical about the results of these talks, and I understand that. But let me tell you, we've made a significant step forward. We've established a foundation for cooperation that will help us to tackle these tough issues in a spirit of partnership and mutual trust.

And let me make one thing clear: we're not going to let up on these issues. We're going to continue to push for progress, to work with our partners, and to take all necessary steps to protect the American people and our friends and allies around the world.

I think the war in Iraq, and the issues surrounding it, have certainly been a challenge for our party, and for the country as a whole. But I also believe that the American people understand the importance of our mission there, which is to defeat the terrorists and help the Iraqi people build a stable, democratic government.

Now, I know that there are those who disagree with the strategy, and that's okay. That's democracy. But I believe that the progress we're making, the gains we're making on the ground, will ultimately prove that our efforts have been worthwhile.

Of course, it's been a tough and trying time, but I believe that our party, the Republican Party, has a lot to offer the American people. We've got a strong vision for the country, and we're working hard to implement it.

And I think, in the end, when the history books are written, people will see that the decision I made to remove Saddam Hussein, and to help the Iraqi people build a democratic government, was the right decision, even if it's been difficult at times.

I think it's a little too early to speculate, but I do want to thank Prime Minister Blair for his steadfast support for our efforts in Iraq. He and I shared a strong commitment to the mission in Iraq, and I appreciate the close partnership we've had in this endeavor.

Now, as I understand, Prime Minister Brown is taking over, and I look forward to working with him. We'll have to wait and see how the British government evolves on this issue. But I'm confident that the US-UK relationship is strong, and we'll continue to work closely together on a wide range of issues, including Iraq.

It's worth noting that Gordon Brown has been the UK's Chancellor of the Exchequer, and we've had a good working relationship on economic issues. I'm optimistic that we can build on that foundation and continue to make progress in Iraq. But as I said, it's too early to speculate on what specific changes might occur.

This press conference was indeed coordinated with my team, and I'm glad to be here today. Regarding the situation in Lebanon, I want to assure the American people and the international community that we are deeply concerned about the situation there. The conflict between Israel and Hezbollah is a serious one, and we are working closely with our allies to try to bring a resolution to this crisis.

As for speaking with President Assad, I've made it clear that Syria has a role to play in this conflict, and we've been working through diplomatic channels to encourage them to use their influence to help bring an end to the violence. However, I must say that we also have deep concerns about Syria's support for terrorist organizations, including Hezbollah, and we will continue to press them on this issue.

Now, I want to make it clear that we are committed to a ceasefire, but it's got to be a lasting one. We don't want to just see a temporary halt in the violence, only to have it resume again in the future. We need a lasting solution that addresses the root causes of this conflict, and we're working with our international partners to achieve that goal.

Thank you for that question. Ah, the immigration issue, it's a tough one, but we're workin' hard on it, I assure you. You know, I've always believed that our nation is a nation of immigrants, but we also believe in the rule of law. And so we're workin' with the Congress to pass comprehensive immigration reform.

Now, I know some folks are gettin' a little impatient, and I don't blame 'em. We've got people on both sides of the aisle who are willin' to work on this issue, and I'm encouragin' 'em to keep at it. We need to secure our borders, and at the same time, we need to make sure that we're treatin' people with dignity and respect.

I'm committed to gettin' this done. I'm committed to makin' sure that we pass a bill that addresses all aspects of this issue, from border security to earned citizenship for those who are here and are willin' to work hard and play by the rules.

Now, I don't have a specific timeline to give you, but I can tell you that we're makin' progress. We're havin' good conversations with the leaders of both parties, and I'm hopeful that we can get somethin' done before the end of the year.

And I might add, I've had good conversations with President Fox of Mexico, and we're workin' together to improve our border, to improve our economic relationships, and to make sure that we're treatin' each other with respect and dignity.

So, I'm optimistic that we'll get this done. It's a tough issue, but I think we can get it done.

I'd say we've made some significant progress in getting countries to step up with their contributions, but I'll be the first to admit we'd like to see more. The international community needs to come together to help the Iraqi people rebuild and create a stable democracy. We've had some significant donors, like Japan and the British, and we appreciate their help. But we're gonna keep pushing and suggesting that others join us in this effort.

Now, I know some folks might be skeptical about getting involved, but I believe it's in the best interest of the international community to see Iraq succeed. We're dealing with a country that was decimated by Saddam Hussein's regime, and we've got a responsibility to help them rebuild.

I'm optimistic that over time, more countries will step up and provide the necessary support. We'll keep working with our international partners to make the case for why this is important, and I'm confident that we'll get more help as we move forward.

I will say this: the American people are committed to helping the Iraqis, and we're proud of the efforts of our men and women in uniform who are working hard to bring stability to the country. And we're gonna keep pushing for more international cooperation on this critical issue.

We're working closely with the interim government to determine the best course of action, not just for the short term but for the long term in Iraq. There's been no discussion about a wholesale withdrawal of U.S. troops from Iraq at this point in time. Obviously, we want the Iraqi people to be able to defend themselves, but we're also cognizant of the fact that there are still threats in the country, particularly from insurgents and remnants of the old regime.

We're working closely with the Iraqi officials, with the United Nations, and the coalition partners to determine what's in the best interest of Iraqi democracy and stability. That's gonna be the guiding principle for any decision we make about troop levels and our role in the country.

We're glad to have Central American countries involved in this process and the markets in Central America are important to the United States. However, we'll want to make certain that whatever proposal is made is consistent with the principles of the free trade agreement, and at the same time, provides some flexibility to address the concerns of all the countries participating.

We've got to be careful about creating...new tariffs or new barriers that could impact our ability to enact this free trade agreement, but I'm open to discussing ways in which we can provide support to the countries of Central America to help them take advantage of this agreement, not only for the benefit of their economies but also for the benefit of the American economy.

 Economic integration, in my judgment, is a very important aspect of the free trade agreement. If it provides administration and streamlines, we'll consider ways to provide support to them.

Well, I'd like to say that our efforts to reach out to the Hispanic community are not about courting any particular vote, but rather about doing what's right for our country. We believe that the Hispanic community has been a vital part of the fabric of America for centuries, and it's about time we recognize their contributions and provide them with the opportunities they deserve.

My administration is committed to increasing access to education, healthcare, and economic opportunities for all Americans, including Hispanic Americans. We're working hard to ensure that our immigration policies are fair, humane, and recognize the valuable contributions that Hispanic immigrants have made to our country.

I reject the notion that our efforts are somehow insincere or opportunistic. We're doing this because it's the right thing to do, not just for Hispanic Americans, but for all Americans. The Hispanic community is a vital part of our country's future, and we're committed to working with them to build a brighter future for everyone.

I'll add, by the way, that my wife, Laura, and I, we've lived in Texas, we've seen the importance of the Hispanic culture, and we believe that by embracing that culture, we can build a stronger, more united America.

You know, I want justice. And there's an old poster out West that said, 'Wanted, dead or alive.' And I think the ... that's exactly how I feel about him. I want to bring him to justice. We're after him. He's a killer, and we're going to bring him to justice. And I think that's exactly what I said.

I think I understand your question. You're asking about entitlements, I believe, the national prescription drug plan that we signed into law. As you may recall, we made a commitment to ensure seniors have access to affordable prescription medication, but I know there was some debate whether to extend the entitlement.

What I said was that we want to make sure our seniors, particularly low-income seniors, get extra help. And we committed to do so without raising taxes. And I believe we accomplished that with our legislation. Our focus is to make sure that when the plan rolls out, that it covers all seniors.

Now, as far as long-term costs and the sustainability of the entitlement, I understand the concerns. However, our budget office is working on projection models and should have those numbers available soon. What I can say though, is that we think these total costs are reasonable in the short term and there is some excess at the beginning which will bring these down over time.

We are, however, open to financial mechanisms, like vouchers and low cost plans to help keep all these entitlements sustainable long term. Yet let me reassure seniors now our commitment is that this new plan is here to work and we'll stay on it.

I believe it's essential for the American people to have access to information about threats to our national security. However, I also believe that in the case of sensitive ongoing negotiations, like those with North Korea, it's crucial for us to keep certain information classified in order to protect our negotiating position and the security of our allies.

Now, I understand the importance of transparency, and I'm committed to keeping the American people informed about the progress we're making in our talks with the North Koreans. But I also have a responsibility to ensure that our diplomacy is effective and that we're taking steps to protect the security of the United States and its allies.

We've taken a very strong position on the issue of counter-proliferation, and we're working closely with our international partners to make sure that we're doing everything we can to prevent the spread of nuclear weapons.

I would say to the American people that we're being vigilant, we're being strong, and we're being effective in our efforts to counter proliferation. And I'm confident that we're moving in the right direction.

I believe the relationship between the United States and France is a very important one, and I'm glad you brought it up. I've had some very good discussions with President Chirac, and we've worked together on a lot of issues.

Now, I wouldn't characterize it as the single most important relationship, but it's certainly a vital relationship. Our two countries have a long history of cooperation, and we share a deep commitment to democracy, freedom, and the values of human dignity.

We're working together on a number of fronts, from counter-terrorism to non-proliferation to advancing peace and stability in the Middle East. And I appreciate the French commitment to these causes.

Now, we don't always agree on everything, and that's okay. Friends can have differences of opinion, but our friendship is strong enough to withstand those differences, and we're committed to working together to address the challenges that we face.

So, I'd say the relationship is a very important one, it's a vital relationship, but I wouldn't say it's the only relationship. We've also got very important relationships with other countries in Europe, such as the UK, Germany, and Italy, and we're committed to strengthening those relationships as well.

The situation in Iraq is a complex one, and I appreciate your interest in it. As you know, we've been working with the international community to address the threat posed by Saddam Hussein's regime.

In terms of troop deployment, I've authorized the Secretary of Defense to prepare for the deployment of approximately 250-300,000 U.S. troops to the region. This is a significant commitment, but one that's necessary to achieve our objectives.

The role of our troops will be to support our coalition partners in enforcing U.N. resolutions, disarming Saddam Hussein's regime, and protecting the Iraqi people from the threat of their own government.

As for how long they might stay, that's a difficult question to answer at this point. Our goal is to achieve our objectives as quickly and safely as possible. We're committed to working towards a post-Saddam Iraq, and we'll work with the international community to ensure a seamless transition to a peaceful and stable Iraq.

But make no mistake, we will not cut and run. We will see this mission through, and we will not leave until the job is done. The American people can rest assured that our troops will be safe, and that we will do everything in our power to minimize the risks to them.

I also want to emphasize that we're not going it alone. We're working with our international partners to build a coalition that shares our commitment to disarming Saddam Hussein and building a more secure and prosperous Iraq.

That's all for now. Next question, please.

Well, first of all, I want to remind you that each of these countries has got its own unique set of circumstances. But I do think there's a common thread that runs through 'em, and that is our desire to spread freedom, to spread democracy, to give people a chance to express themselves, to live in peace.

Now, I know some folks don't agree with my foreign policy, that's okay. We can have a respectful disagreement. But I'm convinced thatValueCollection — by helping these countries become democracies, we'll make America and the world a safer place.

Thank you for that question. I appreciate the concern about the economy. I'm pleased to report that our economy remains strong, with low unemployment and steady growth. We've taken significant steps to promote economic growth, investing in tax relief, investing in the private sector, and promoting free trade. And it's working.

Now, I understand that there are concerns, and I share those concerns. I think it's natural to have concerns in times of uncertainty. But I'm confident in the resilience of the American economy. Our economy's strong fundamentals, a low unemployment rate, and high productivity growth, to name a few, give me reason to believe we'll continue to experience economic growth.

And if there is a recession, we'll be prepared to take decisive action. I've met with Secretary Paulson, and we're staying on top of it. We'll continue to implement a sound and responsible monetary policy and maintain a focus on keeping taxes low.

I believe in the strength of the American economy, and I believe in the resilience of the American people. I'm optimistic about the future, and I'm confident that with sound economic policies, we'll be able to navigate any challenges that come our way.

And I want to remind the American people, we've been in tough times before, and we've always come out stronger. And that's precisely what will happen this time as well. Thank you. Next question?

Well, I'd like to think so. We're working hard, along with our friends and allies, to get a resolution passed in the United Nations. It's a process that takes time, you know. But I'm optimistic that we can get a resolution by the time I get to New York. We've been building a strong international coalition to deal with Saddam Hussein and the threat that he presents to the world.

We're making good progress in terms of getting a strong resolution, one that will send a clear message to Saddam Hussein that the world wants him to disarm, and disarm now. And if he doesn't comply, then of course we'll be forced to consider other action.

But I'm optimistic, and we're working hard to get a resolution. The process of diplomacy is a slow and tedious one, but it's an important one. We'll stay the course, work closely with our friends and allies, and hopefully we'll have a resolution in hand by the time I get to New York.

We're workin' closely with our international partners to uncover all the facts, and we're makin' it clear to all nations that they need to be on the side of the United States and the decent people of the world, and not on the side of the terrorists. 

Now, Syria and Iran, they've got a history of sponsorin' and harborin' terrorists. We're watchin' them closely, and we're examinin' their actions, and we're goin' to hold 'em accountable. But we can't jump to conclusions. We gotta make sure we got the facts straight.

We've had discussions with both countries, and I'll tell you this: we're makin' it clear that we expect them to cooperate, and we expect them to take the necessary actions to prove that they're not harboring terrorists. We'll be watchin' their actions very closely, and we'll take all necessary steps to protect the American people.

We're at war, folks. We're at war against terrorism, and we're gonna take the fight to the enemy. And we're gonna make sure that those who harbor terrorists, and those who sponsor terrorists, are held accountable.

Well, I think we gotta be careful about the signals we're sending.
